	"<p id='id'>52</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>51</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>52</p> <p id='keyword'>eminent</p> <p id='kanji'>卓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58D93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>eminent, magic wand, augury, divinging rod, sunflower, sun, day, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>3</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The word <b>eminent</b> suggests a famous or well-known person. So all you need to do - given the primitives of a <i>magic wand</i> and a <i>sunflower</i>&nbsp;- is to think of the world's most <b>eminent</b> magician as one who uses a <i>sunflower</i> for a <i>magic wand</i> (like a flower-child who goes around turning the world into peace and love).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The most eminent magician is he who learned to use his magic wand early in life.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The eminent sunflower is the one that stands above the others.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>食卓(しょくたく): dining table</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>53</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>52</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>53</p> <p id='keyword'>morning</p> <p id='kanji'>朝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69C9D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>morning, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, ten2, needle2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>3</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>On the right we see the <i>moon</i> fading off into the first light of <b>morning</b>, and to the left, the <i>mist</i> that falls to give nature a shower to prepare it for the coming heat. If you can think of the <i>moon</i> tilting over to spill <i>mist</i> on your garden, you should have no trouble remembering which of all the elements in this story are to serve as primitives for constructing the character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There is mist as the moon fades away in the morning.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Morning has come ""ten"" hours ""early""!!! The ""moon"" is still in the sky!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あさ</p> <p id='words'>朝寝坊(あさねぼう): over sleep<br>朝(あさ): morning<br>朝御飯(あさごはん): breakfast<br>今朝(けさ): this morning<br>毎朝(まいあさ): every morning</p> <p id='readingExamples'>朝 (あさ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>55</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>53</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>55</p> <p id='keyword'>only</p> <p id='kanji'>只</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58FAA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>only, mouth, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When we run across abstract key words like this one, the best way to get an image it to recall some common but suggestive phrase in which the word appears. For instance, we can think of the expression ""it's the <b>only</b> one of its kind."" Then we imagine a barker at a side-show advertising some strange pac-manlike creature he has inside his tent, with only a gigantic <i>mouth</i> and two wee <i>animal legs</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine an animal with only a mouth and legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>My girlfriend insists that the only thing I want from her is what´s between her legs.. She´s drawn me this pictograph to demonstrate. It´s a head and two legs spread apart.. I explain that I also love her breasts, and then she smacks me in the face. I´ll never understand women.. (I keep failing this kanji, hopefully this silly story will help me!).</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ただ</p> <p id='words'>只(ただ): trivial matter</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>56</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>54</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>56</p> <p id='keyword'>shellfish</p> <p id='kanji'>貝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B29D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shellfish, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To remember the primitive elements that make up this kanji, an <i>eye</i> and <i>animal legs</i>, you might be tempted to think of it as a pictograph of a <b>shellfish</b> with its ridged shell at the top and two little <i>legs</i> sticking out of the bottom. But that might not help you recall later just how many ridges to put on the shell. Better to imagine a freakish <b>shellfish</b> with a single, gigantic <i>eye</i> roaming the beaches on its slender little <i>legs</i>, scaring the wits out of the sunbathers.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* When used as a primitive, in addition to <i>shells</i>, the meanings <i>oyster</i> and <i>clam</i> will often come in handy.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Eye thought I saw a shellfish legging it down the beach!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Stare at the shellfish, it looks like an eye with legs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>バイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かい</p> <p id='words'>貝殻(かいがら): shell<br>貝(かい): shell, shellfish</p> <p id='readingExamples'>貝 (かい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>58</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>55</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>58</p> <p id='keyword'>upright</p> <p id='kanji'>貞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B29E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>upright, magic wand, augury, divining rod, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Now take the last primitive, the <i>shellfish</i>, and set a <i>magic wand</i> over it, and you have the kanji for <b>upright</b>. After all, the <i>clam</i> and the <i>oyster</i> are incapable of walking <b>upright</b>. It would take a magician with his <i>wand</i> to pull off such a feat - which is precisely what we have in this kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A magic wand is needed to make a clam stand upright.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Just the thought of my magic wand on her clam makes my magic wand stand upright.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さだ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>59</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>56</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>59</p> <p id='keyword'>employee</p> <p id='kanji'>員</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E593A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>employee, mouth, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>How do we get a <i>mouth</i> over a <i>shellfish</i> to mean an <b>employee</b>? Simple. Just remember the advice new <b>employees</b> get about keeping their <i>mouths</i> shut and doing their job, and then make that more graphic by picturing an office building full of white collar workers scurrying around with <i>clams</i> pinched to their <i>mouths</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An employee (member of the company) has to clam up his mouth if he wants keep the job!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An employee is basically a shellfish with a mouth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>イン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>員(いん): member<br>教員(きょういん): teaching staff<br>行員(こういん): bank clerk<br>従業員(じゅうぎょういん): employee, worker<br>職員(しょくいん): staff member, personnel<br>動員(どういん): mobilization<br>委員(いいん): committee member<br>会員(かいいん): member, the membership<br>議員(ぎいん): member of the Diet, congress or parliament<br>工員(こういん): factory worker<br>全員(ぜんいん): all members (unanimity), all hands, the whole crew<br>定員(ていいん): fixed number of regular personnel, capacity (of boat, hall, aeroplane, etc.)<br>満員(まんいん): full house, no vacancy, sold out, standing room only, full (of people), crowded<br>公務員(こうむいん): public servant<br>店員(てんいん): salesclerk</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>61</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>57</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>61</p> <p id='keyword'>see</p> <p id='kanji'>見</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A68B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>see, eye, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The elements that compose the character for <b>see</b> are the <i>eye</i> firmly fixed to a pair of <i>human legs</i>. Surely, somewhere in your experience, there is a vivid image just waiting to be dragged up to help you remember this character....</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. 	"<p id='id'>62</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>58</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>62</p> <p id='keyword'>newborn babe</p> <p id='kanji'>児</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58590.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>newborn babe, olden times, stick, sun, day, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The top part of the kanji in this frame, you will remember, is the character for <i>olden times</i>, those <i>days</i> so old they needed a <i>walking stick</i> to get around. Western mythical imagination has old ""Father Time"" leaning on his sickle with a <b>newborn babe</b> crawling around his <i>legs</i>, the idea being that the circle of birth and-death goes on. This is the first of three times that the kanji for <i>olden times</i> will appear as a primitive element in another kanji, so try to make the most of it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the olden times, a newborn babe came out legs first.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Only 18 and already got a newborn babe. Young girls are so quick to spread their legs these days...　　　RTK2:　ジ　児童　じどう　(child)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　ニ　小児　しょうに(infant).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジ、ニ、ゲイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ、-こ、-っこ</p> <p id='words'>児(こ): child, the young of animals<br>孤児(こじ): orphan<br>小児科(しょうにか): pediatrics<br>育児(いくじ): childcare, nursing, upbringing<br>児童(じどう): children, juvenile<br>幼児(ようじ): infant, baby, child</p> <p id='readingExamples'>児童 (じどう), 幼児 (ようじ), 優良児 (ゆうりょうじ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>63</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>59</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>63</p> <p id='keyword'>beginning</p> <p id='kanji'>元</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58583.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>beginning, two, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""In the <b>beginning</b>...""&nbsp;starts that marvelous shelf of books we call the Bible. It talks about how all things were made, and tells us that when the Creator came to humanity she made <i>two</i> of them, man and woman. While we presume she made <i>two</i> of every other animal as well, we are not told as much. Hence we need only&nbsp;<i>two</i> and a pair of <i>human legs</i> come to the kanji that means <b>beginning</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the beginning were just two who walked on human legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the beginning God created woman, and God asked her how she liked his work. Woman replied, ""Well, you know how I have two eyes, two arms, two legs... it seems redundant to have three breasts. It would look more symmetrical with two."" God nodded, and the middle breast fell off... and it was good. Woman picked up the breast and said, ""Thank you, God! But what do I do with this useless boob?"" And God created man. That´s why the women today only have two boobs to match their two human legs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲン、ガン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もと</p> <p id='words'>還元(かんげん): resolution, reduction, return to origins<br>元年(がんねん): first year (of a specific reign)<br>元来(がんらい): originally, primarily, essentially, logically, naturally<br>元首(げんしゅ): ruler, sovereign<br>元素(げんそ): chemical element<br>地元(じもと): local<br>手元(てもと): on hand, at hand, at home<br>元(もと): origin, original, former<br>元々(もともと): originally, by nature, from the start<br>元気(げんき): health(y), robust, vigor, energy, vitality, vim, stamina, spirit, courage, pep</p> <p id='readingExamples'>元素 (げんそ), 元気 (げんき), 多元 (たげん), 元 (もと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>64</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>60</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>64</p> <p id='keyword'>page</p> <p id='kanji'>頁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A081.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>What we have to do here is turn a <i>shellfish</i> into a <b>page</b> of a book. The <i>one</i> at the top tells us that we only get a rather short book, in fact only <i>one</i> <b>page</b>. Imagine a title printed on the shell of an <i>oyster</i>, let us say ""Pearl of Wisdom,"" and then open the quaint book to its <i>one</i> and only <b>page</b>, on which you find a single, radiant <i>drop of</i> wisdom, one of the masterpiece poems of nature.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji takes the unrelated meaning of a <i>head</i> (preferably one detached from its body), derived from the character for <i>head</i> (Frame 1549).</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A shellfish carrying a page balanced on its head.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>One drop of ink from a shellfish can fill a whole page.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ケツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ぺえじ、おおがい、かしら</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>65</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>61</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>65</p> <p id='keyword'>stubborn</p> <p id='kanji'>頑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A091.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stubborn, beginning, two, human legs, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character refers to the block<i>headed</i>, persistent <b>stubbornness</b> of one who sticks to an idea or a plan just the way it was at the <i>beginning</i>, without letting anything that comes up along the way alter things in the least. The explanation makes ""sense,"" but is hard to remember because the word ""<i>beginning</i> ""is too abstract. Back up to the image we used two frames ago - Adam and Eve in their Eden - and try again: The root of all <b>stubbornness</b> goes back to the <i>beginning</i>, with two brothers each <b>stubbornly</b> defending his own way of life and asking their God to bless it favorably. Abel stuck to agriculture, Cain to animal-raising. Picture these two with their giant, swelled <i>heads</i>, each vying for the favors of heaven, a <b>stubborn</b> grimace on their faces. No wonder something unfortunate happened!</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A stubborn person in the beginning gets something into their head and can´t change their mind.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Picture a STUBBORN schoolboy, with his arms crossed and his book still open to the BEGINNING PAGE. Despite the teacher telling him to turn the page, he refuses and keeps his book on the BEGINNING PAGE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かたく</p> <p id='words'>頑固(がんこ): stubbornness, obstinacy<br>頑丈(がんじょう): solid, firm, stout, burly, strong, sturdy</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>66</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>62</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>66</p> <p id='keyword'>mediocre</p> <p id='kanji'>凡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E587A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mediocre, drop, wind</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>While we refer to something insignificant as a ""<i>drop</i> in the bucket,"" the kanji for <b>mediocre</b> suggests the image of a ""<i>drop</i> in the <i>wind</i>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A drop of breeze is naught but a mediocre wind.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Is there anything as mediocre as a drop of piss in the wind?</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボン、ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>およ.そ、おうよ.そ、すべ.て</p> <p id='words'>凡そ(およそ): about, roughly, as a rule, approximately<br>大凡(おおよそ): about, roughly, approximately, as a rule<br>平凡(へいぼん): common, commonplace, ordinary, mediocre</p> <p id='readingExamples'>凡人 (ぼんじん), 凡百 (ぼんひゃく), 平凡 (へいぼん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>67</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>63</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>67</p> <p id='keyword'>defeat</p> <p id='kanji'>負</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2A0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>defeat, bound up, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Above we have the condensed form of <i>bound up</i>, and below the familiar <i>shellfish</i>. Now imagine two <i>oysters</i> engaged in <i>shell</i>-to-<i>shell</i> combat, the one who is <b>defeated</b> being <i>bound and gagged</i> with seaweed, the victor towering triumphantly over it. The <i>bound shellfish</i> thus becomes the symbol for <b>defeat</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Tied up, the shellfish had to accept defeat!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Defeat is defined by a shellfish in binds.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>フ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ま.ける、ま.かす、お.う</p> <p id='words'>負う(おう): to bear, to owe<br>御負け(おまけ): a discount, a prize, something additional, bonus, an extra, an exaggeration<br>背負う(しょう): to be burdened with, to carry on back or shoulder<br>勝負(しょうぶ): victory or defeat, match, contest, game, bout<br>負債(ふさい): debt, liabilities<br>負傷(ふしょう): injury, wound<br>負担(ふたん): burden, charge, responsibility<br>負かす(まかす): to defeat<br>背負う(せおう): be burdened with, carry on back or shoulder<br>負け(まけ): defeat, loss, losing (a game)<br>負ける(まける): lose</p> <p id='readingExamples'>負う (お.う), 負かす (ま.かす), 負ける (ま.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>68</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>64</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>68</p> <p id='keyword'>ten thousand</p> <p id='kanji'>万</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B887.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ten thousand, one, ceiling, bound up</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Japanese counts higher numbers in units of <b>ten thousand</b>, unlike the West, which advances according to units of one thousand. (Thus, for instance, 40,000 would be read ""four <b>ten-thousands</b>"" by a Japanese.) Given that the comma is used in larger numbers to <i>bind up</i> a numerical unit of one thousand, the elements for <i>one</i> and <i>bound up</i> naturally come to form <b>ten thousand</b>. The order of strokes here needs special attention, both because it falls outside the general principles we have learned already, and because it involves writing the element for <i>bound up</i> in an order opposite to the one we learned. If it is any consolation, this exception is consistent every time these three strokes come together.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I bound ten thousand dollars together and hid it under the floor.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>We have ""one"" at the top and if you turn the kanji 90 degrees you will see arabic 4 shich means it has four zeros in front of it!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>マン、バン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よろず</p> <p id='words'>万(ばん): many, all<br>万人(ばんじん): all people, everybody, 10000 people<br>万能(ばんのう): all-purpose, almighty, omnipotent<br>万歳(ばんざい): strolling comic dancer<br>万一(まんいち): by some chance, by some possibility, if by any chance, 10,000:1 odds<br>万(まん): 10,000, ten thousand, myriad(s), all, everything<br>万年筆(まんねんひつ): fountain pen</p> <p id='readingExamples'>万一 (まんいち), 万年筆 (まんねんひつ), 巨万 (きょまん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>69</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>65</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>69</p> <p id='keyword'>phrase</p> <p id='kanji'>句</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58FA5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>phrase, bound up, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>By combining the two primitives <i>bound up</i> and <i>mouth</i>, we can easily see how this character can get the meaning of a <b>phrase</b>. After all, a <b>phrase</b> is nothing more than a number of words <i>bound up</i> tightly and neatly so that they will fit in your <i>mouth</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Some Japanese phrases are difficult to wrap your mouth around.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A bound mouth cannot utter a single phrase.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>佳句(かく): beautiful passage of literature<br>語句(ごく): words, phrases<br>句(く): phrase, clause, sentence, passage, paragraph, expression, line, verse, stanza, 17-syllable poem<br>句読点(くとうてん): punctuation marks<br>俳句(はいく): 17-syllable poem<br>文句(もんく): phrase, complaint</p> <p id='readingExamples'>句 (く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>70</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>66</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>70</p> <p id='keyword'>texture</p> <p id='kanji'>肌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8828C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>texture, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, wind</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ever notice how the <b>texture</b> of your face and hands is affected by the <i>wind</i>? A day's skiing or sailing makes them rough and dry, and in need of a good soft cream to soothe the burn. So whenever a <i>part of the body</i> gets exposed to the <i>wind</i>, its <b>texture</b> is affected. (If it is any help, the Latin word hiding inside <b>texture</b> connotes how something is ""to the touch."")</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you expose your flesh to the wind it gets textured: goosebumps!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The moon´s lack of wind preserves its texture.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はだ</p> <p id='words'>肌(はだ): skin, body, grain, texture, disposition<br>肌着(はだぎ): underwear, lingerie, singlet, chemise</p> <p id='readingExamples'>肌 (はだ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>71</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>67</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>71</p> <p id='keyword'>decameron</p> <p id='kanji'>旬</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E697AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>decameron, bound up, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>There simply is not a good phrase in English for the block often days which this character represents. So we resurrect the classical phrase, <b>decameron</b>, whose connotations the tales of Boccaccio have done much to enrich. Actually, it refers to a journey of ten <i>days</i> taken by a band of people - that is, a group of people <i>bound together</i> for the <i>days</i> of the <b>decameron</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Hesig should be BOUND for a DAY (or maybe 10 days - a decameron) for calling this Kanji DECAMERON. See martyrdom (#809).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you bind up ten days, you get a decameron.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュン、シュン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>下旬(げじゅん): last third of month<br>上旬(じょうじゅん): first 10 days of month<br>初旬(しょじゅん): first 10 days of the month<br>中旬(ちゅうじゅん): second third of a month</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>72</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>68</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>72</p> <p id='keyword'>ladle</p> <p id='kanji'>勺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58BBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ladle, bound up, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>If you want to <i>bind up drops</i> of anything - water, soup, lemonade - you use something to scoop these <i>drops</i> up, which is what we call a <b>ladle</b>. See the last <i>drop</i> left inside the <b>ladle</b>?</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A ladle binds drops together.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Forget about the primative ´bound up´. Imagine instead the shape of a ladle and holding it upside down to drink the last DROP (of water).</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>73</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>69</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>73</p> <p id='keyword'>bull´s eye</p> <p id='kanji'>的</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79A84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bull’s eye, white, dove, ladle, bound up, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The elements <i>white bird</i> and <i>ladle</i> easily suggest the image of a <b>bull's eye</b> if you imagine a rusty old <i>ladle</i> with a <b>bull's eye</b> painted on it in the form of a tiny <i>white bird</i>, who lets out a little ""peep"" every time you hit the target.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I managed to hit the bull´s eye by throwing my white ladle.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A white, bound up, drop in the center is the bull´s eye. (why Heisig had to use ""ladle"" instead of the original two primitives that make up ""ladle"" I´ll never understand!).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>テキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まと</p> <p id='words'>静的(せいてき): static<br>先天的(せんてんてき): a priori, inborn, innate, inherent, congenital, hereditary<br>知的(ちてき): intellectual<br>的(てき): -like, typical<br>的確(てきかく): precise, accurate<br>動的(どうてき): dynamic, kinetic<br>的(まと): mark, target<br>消極的(しょうきょくてき): passive<br>積極的(せっきょくてき): positive, active, proactive<br>比較的(ひかくてき): comparatively, relatively<br>目的(もくてき): purpose, goal, aim, objective, intention</p> <p id='readingExamples'>的 (まと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>74</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>70</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>74</p> <p id='keyword'>neck</p> <p id='kanji'>首</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A696.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>neck, horns, nose, one, ceiling, drop, eye</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Reading this kanji from the top down, we have: <i>horns</i> . . . <i>nose</i>. Together they bring to mind the picture of a moose-head hanging on the den wall, with its great <i>horns</i> and long <i>nose</i>. Now while we would speak of cutting off a moose's ""head"" to hang on the wall, the Japanese speak of cutting off its <b>neck</b>. It's all a matter of how you look at it. Anyway, if you let the word <b>neck</b> conjure up the image of a moose with a very l-o-n-g <b>neck</b> hanging over the fireplace, whose <i>horns</i> you use for a coat-rack and whose <i>nose</i> has spigots left and right for scotch and water, you should have no trouble with the character. Here we get a good look at what we mentioned when we first introduced the element for <i>horns</i>: that they can never be left floating free and require an extra horizontal stroke to prevent that from happening, as is the case here.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The V shape is your neck on top of your collar bone, or the straight line. Yourself, or the rest of your body is below that!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The mooses neck supports it´s big horns and long nose.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くび</p> <p id='words'>首飾り(くびかざり): necklace<br>首輪(くびわ): necklace, choker<br>元首(げんしゅ): ruler, sovereign<br>自首(じしゅ): surrender, give oneself up<br>首脳(しゅのう): head, brains<br>首相(しゅしょう): Prime Minister, Chancellor (Germany, Austria, etc.)<br>首都(しゅと): capital city<br>手首(てくび): wrist<br>部首(ぶしゅ): radical of a kanji<br>首(くび): neck</p> <p id='readingExamples'>首 (くび)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>75</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>71</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>75</p> <p id='keyword'>fish guts</p> <p id='kanji'>乙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B999.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fishguts, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>1</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji shown here actually represents the ""second"" position in the old Chinese zodiac, which the Japanese still use as an alternate way of enumeration, much the same way that English will revert to Roman numerals. Among its many other meanings are ""pure,"" ""tasteful,"" ""quaint,"" and - get this! - <b>fish guts</b>. Since it is a pictograph of a fishhook, it should not be hard to associate it with the key word.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* We will keep <i>fishhook</i> as the primitive meaning. Its shape will rarely be quite the same as that of the kanji. When it appears at the bottom of another primitive, it is straightened out, almost as if the weight of the upper element had bent it out of shape. And when it appears to the right of another element, the short horizontal line that gets the shape started is omitted and it is stretched out and narrowed, all for reasons of space and aesthetics. Examples follow.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is a fish hook, that pulls out the fishguts.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You cut a fish in a z shape on the belly to make it easier to open the fish and rip out its fish guts silly!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>オツ、イツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おと-、きのと</p> <p id='words'>乙(おつ): strange, quaint, stylish, chic, spicy, queer, witty, tasty, romantic, 2nd in rank, second sign of the Chinese calendar</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>76</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>72</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>76</p> <p id='keyword'>riot</p> <p id='kanji'>乱</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B9B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>riot, tongue, thousand, drop, ten, needle, mouth, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In a <b>riot</b>, manners are laid aside and tempers get short, even in so courtesy-conscious a land as Japan. This kanji shows what happens to a <b>rioting</b> <i>tongue</i>: it gets ""barbed"" like a <i>fishhook</i>, and sets to attacking the opposition, to <i>hook</i> them as it were.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The riot police broke up the riot by dragging the rioters away by their tongues with fishooks.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A tongue with a hook can cause a riot.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ラン、ロン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みだ.れる、みだ.る、みだ.す、みだ、おさ.める、わた.る</p> <p id='words'>内乱(ないらん): civil war, insurrection, rebellion, domestic conflict<br>反乱(はんらん): insurrection, mutiny, rebellion, revolt, uprising<br>乱す(みだす): to throw out of order, to disarrange, to disturb<br>乱れる(みだれる): to get confused, to be disordered, to be disturbed<br>混乱(こんらん): disorder, chaos, confusion, mayhem<br>乱暴(らんぼう): rude, violent, rough, lawless, unreasonable, reckless</p> <p id='readingExamples'>乱す (みだ.す), 乱れる (みだ.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>77</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>73</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>77</p> <p id='keyword'>straightaway</p> <p id='kanji'>直</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79BB4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>straightaway, ten, needle, eye, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Begin with the top two primitives, <i>needle</i> and <i>eye</i>. Together they represent the <i>eye of a needle</i>. Below them is a <i>fishhook</i> that has been <b>straightened out</b> and its barb removed so that it can pass through the <i>eye of the needle</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital straightaway.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back straightaway.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョク、ジキ、ジカ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ただ.ちに、なお.す、-なお.す、なお.る、なお.き、す.ぐ</p> <p id='words'>直ぐ(すぐ): immediately, soon, easily, right (near), honest, upright<br>率直(そっちょく): frankness, candour, openheartedness<br>直面(ちょくめん): confrontation<br>直感(ちょっかん): intuition<br>出直し(でなおし): adjustment, touch up<br>直に(じかに): directly, in person, headlong<br>直(じき): direct, in person, soon, at once, just, near by, honesty, frankness, simplicity, cheerfulness, correctness<br>正直(しょうじき): honesty, integrity, frankness<br>垂直(すいちょく): vertical, perpendicular<br>素直(すなお): obedient, meek, docile, unaffected<br>卒直(そっちょく): frankness, candour, openheartedness<br>直ちに(ただちに): at once, immediately, directly, in person<br>直後(ちょくご): immediately following<br>直接(ちょくせつ): direct, immediate, personal, firsthand<br>直線(ちょくせん): straight line<br>直前(ちょくぜん): just before<br>直通(ちょくつう): direct communication<br>直流(ちょくりゅう): direct current<br>直角(ちょっかく): right angle<br>直径(ちょっけい): diameter<br>仲直り(なかなおり): reconciliation, make peace with<br>真っ直ぐ(まっすぐ): straight (ahead), direct, upright, erect, honest, frank<br>見直す(みなおす): look again, form a better opinion of<br>直す(なおす): repair<br>直る(なおる): be repaired</p> <p id='readingExamples'>直立 (ちょくりつ), 直接 (ちょくせつ), 実直 (じっちょく), 直ちに (ただ.ちに), 直す (なお.す), 直る (なお.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>78</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>74</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>78</p> <p id='keyword'>tool</p> <p id='kanji'>具</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E585B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tool, eye, tool, one, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here is the full kanji on which the last frame is based. If you can think of a table full of carpenter's <b>tools</b> of all sorts, each equipped with its own <i>eye</i> so that it can keep a watch over what you are doing with it, you won't have trouble later keeping the primitive and the kanji apart.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Keep an eye on your tools while you work at the table.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>One tool nobody should be without - a Mordor-type eye that floats over the workbench. It jerks around, monitoring all who come near, and if anyone so much as removes a stapler from the bench - ZAP.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>グ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そな.える、つぶさ.に</p> <p id='words'>雨具(あまぐ): rain gear<br>敬具(けいぐ): Sincerely yours<br>夜具(やぐ): bedding<br>絵の具(えのぐ): colors, paints<br>家具(かぐ): furniture<br>器具(きぐ): utensil<br>具体(ぐたい): concrete, tangible, material<br>具える(そなえる): furnish, provide for, equip, install, have ready, prepare for, possess, have, be endowed with, be armed with<br>文房具(ぶんぼうぐ): stationery<br>具合(ぐあい): condition<br>道具(どうぐ): tool</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>79</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>75</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>79</p> <p id='keyword'>true</p> <p id='kanji'>真</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79C9F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>true, ten, needle, eye, tool, one, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here again we meet the composite element, <i>eye of the needle</i>, which here combines with <i>tool</i> to give us a measure of what is <b>true</b> and what is not.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A compass is a tool with a needle on top that points to true north.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Ten tools are all a true craftsman needs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ま、ま-、まこと</p> <p id='words'>生真面目(きまじめ): too serious, person who is too serious, honesty, sincerity<br>真実(さな): truth, reality<br>真珠(しんじゅ): pearl<br>真相(しんそう): truth, real situation<br>真理(しんり): truth<br>真上(まうえ): just above, right overhead<br>真心(まこころ): sincerity, devotion<br>真に(まことに): truly, actually, really<br>真下(ました): right under, directly below<br>真っ二つ(まっぷたつ): in two equal parts<br>真ん前(まんまえ): right in front, under the nose<br>真ん丸い(まんまるい): perfectly circular<br>真空(しんくう): vacuum, hollow, empty<br>真剣(しんけん): seriousness, earnestness<br>真面目(まじめ): diligent, serious, honest<br>真っ赤(まっか): deep red, flushed (of face)<br>真っ暗(まっくら): total darkness, pitch dark, shortsightedness<br>真っ黒(まっくろ): pitch black<br>真っ青(まっさお): deep blue, ghastly pale<br>真っ先(まっさき): the head, the foremost, beginning<br>真っ白(まっしろ): pure white<br>真っ直ぐ(まっすぐ): straight (ahead), direct, upright, erect, honest, frank<br>真似(まね): mimicry, imitation, behavior, pretense<br>真似る(まねる): mimic, imitate<br>真ん中(まんなか): middle, center, half way<br>写真(しゃしん): photograph</p> <p id='readingExamples'>真 (ま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>80</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>76</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>80</p> <p id='keyword'>craft</p> <p id='kanji'>工</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B7A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>craft, artificial</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The pictograph of an I beam, like the kind used in heavy construction work on buildings and bridges, gives us the character for <b>craft</b> in general.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive element, the key word retains the meaning of <i>craft</i> and also takes on the related meanings of <i>I beam</i> and <i>artificial</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I consider craft to be one of the harder primitives to use in stories so I´ve personified it as Bender the crafty robot from Futurama who was designed to bend I-beams.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I crafty.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、ク、グ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>加工(かこう): manufacturing, processing, treatment<br>工学(こうがく): engineering<br>工作(こうさく): work, construction, handicraft, maneuvering<br>細工(さいく): work, craftsmanship, tactics, trick<br>着工(ちゃっこう): start of (construction) work<br>工夫(くふう): device, scheme<br>工員(こういん): factory worker<br>工芸(こうげい): industrial arts<br>工事(こうじ): construction work<br>工場(こうば): factory, plant, mill, workshop<br>人工(じんこう): artificial, man-made, human work, human skill, artificiality<br>大工(だいく): carpenter<br>工業(こうぎょう): industry<br>工場(こうじょう): factory</p> <p id='readingExamples'>工場 (こうじょう), 加工 (かこう), 人工 (じんこう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>81</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>77</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>81</p> <p id='keyword'>left</p> <p id='kanji'>左</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B7A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>left, by one’s side, craft</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>By combining the primitive and the kanji of the last two frames and reading the results, we get: <i>by one's side</i> . . . <i>craft</i>. Conveniently, the <b>left</b> has traditionally been considered the ""sinister"" <i>side</i>, where dark and occult <i>crafts</i> are cultivated. Note how the second stroke droops over to the <b>left</b> and is longer than the first.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The LEFT side of my brain posesses the faculties needed for logical crafts, like engineering.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The left side of my brain, is for crafts.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>サ、シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひだり</p> <p id='words'>左程(さほど): (not) very, (not) much<br>左様なら(さようなら): good-bye<br>左利き(ひだりきき): left-handedness, sake drinker, left-hander<br>左右(さゆう): left and right, influence, control, domination<br>左(ひだり): left hand side</p> <p id='readingExamples'>左 (ひだり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>82</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>78</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>82</p> <p id='keyword'>right</p> <p id='kanji'>右</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58FB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>right, by one’s side, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When thinking of the key word <b>right</b>, in order to avoid confusion with the previous frame, take advantage of the double meaning here, too. Imagine a little <i>mouth</i> hanging down by your <i>side</i>&nbsp;- like a little voice of conscience - telling you the <b>right</b> thing to do. Here the second stroke should reach out to the <b>right</b> and be drawn slightly longer than the first.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The right hand is for putting food in your mouth. (The other hand is for ass-wiping!).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Always keep your right to free speech (mouth) by your side!</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ウ、ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みぎ</p> <p id='words'>左右(さゆう): left and right, influence, control, domination<br>右(みぎ): right hand side</p> <p id='readingExamples'>右岸 (みぎぎし), 右折 (うせつ), 右派 (うは), 右 (みぎ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>83</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>79</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>83</p> <p id='keyword'>possess</p> <p id='kanji'>有</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69C89.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>possess, by one’s side, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The picture here is of someone with a slab of <i>meat</i> dangling <i>by the side</i>, perhaps from a belt or rope tied around the waist. Think of it as an evil spirit in <b>possession</b> of one's soul, who can be exorcized only by allowing fresh <i>meat</i> to hang <i>by one's side</i> until it begins to putrefy and stink so bad that the demon departs. Take careful note of the stroke order.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Possessed by the Earth´s gravity, the moon stays by its side.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>By my side I POSSESS a moon of flesh, better known as your big ass!</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ、ウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.る</p> <p id='words'>有難う(ありがとう): Thank you<br>有様(ありさま): state, condition, circumstances, the way things are or should be, truth<br>有りのまま(ありのまま): the truth, fact, as it is, frankly<br>有る(ある): to be, to have<br>国有(こくゆう): national ownership<br>固有(こゆう): characteristic, tradition, peculiar, inherent, eigen-<br>私有(しゆう): private ownership<br>特有(とくゆう): characteristic (of), peculiar (to)<br>有益(ゆうえき): beneficial, profitable<br>有機(ゆうき): organic<br>有する(ゆうする): to own, to be endowed with<br>有望(ゆうぼう): good prospects, full of hope, promising<br>有力(ゆうりょく): influence, prominence, potent<br>有難い(ありがたい): grateful, thankful, welcome, appreciated<br>有無(うむ): yes or no, existence, presence or absence marker<br>有効(ゆうこう): validity, availability, effectiveness<br>有能(ゆうのう): able, capable, efficient, skill<br>有利(ゆうり): advantageous, better, profitable, lucrative<br>有料(ゆうりょう): admission-paid, toll<br>有名(ゆうめい): fame</p> <p id='readingExamples'>有益 (ゆうえき), 所有 (しょゆう), 特有 (とくゆう), 有 (ある)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>84</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>80</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>84</p> <p id='keyword'>bribe</p> <p id='kanji'>賄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B384.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bribe, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, possess, by one’s side, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To the left we have the primitive for a <i>shellfish</i>, and to the right the kanji we just learned for <i>possess</i>. Keep the connotation of the last frame for the word <i>possess</i>, and now expand your image of <i>shells</i> to include the ancient value they had as money (a usage that will come in very helpful later on). Now one who is <i>possessed</i> by <i>shells</i> is likely to abandon any higher principles to acquire more and more wealth. These are the easiest ones to <b>bribe</b> with a few extra <i>shells</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To bribe someone, money is a necessary possession.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ワイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まかな.う</p> <p id='words'>賄う(まかなう): to give board to, to provide meals, to pay</p> <p id='readingExamples'>賄う (まかな.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>85</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>81</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>85</p> <p id='keyword'>tribute</p> <p id='kanji'>貢</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2A2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tribute, craft, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A <b>tribute</b> has a kind of double-meaning in English: honor paid freely and <i>money</i> collected by coercion. Simply because a ruler bestows a noble name on a deed is hardly any consolation to the masses who must part with their hard-earned <i>money</i>. Little wonder that this ancient <i>craft</i> of getting <i>money</i> by calling it a <b>tribute</b> has given way to a name closer to how it feels to those who pay it: a tax.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This next song is a TRIBUTE to a little SHELLFISH friend of mine who was tragically crushed by an I-shaped table..</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tribute is the craft of raising money.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、ク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みつ.ぐ</p> <p id='words'>貢献(こうけん): contribution, services</p> <p id='readingExamples'>貢献 (こうけん), 貢 (みつぐ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>86</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>82</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>86</p> <p id='keyword'>paragraph</p> <p id='kanji'>項</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A085.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>paragraph, craft, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To the right we see a <i>head</i> and to the left an element that means <i>craft</i>. When we think of a <b>paragraph</b>, we immediately think of a <i>heading</i> device to break a text into parts. (Think of the elaborate <i>heads</i> often seen at the start of medieval manuscripts and the task becomes easier still.) Just where and how to do it belongs to the writer's <i>craft</i>. Hence, we define <b>paragraphing</b> as the ""<i>heading craft</i>"" to remember this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To write a paragraph is the craft of grouping sentences on a page.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To craft a page well, we need paragraphs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うなじ</p> <p id='words'>事項(じこう): matter, item, facts<br>項目(こうもく): item</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>87</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>83</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>87</p> <p id='keyword'>sword</p> <p id='kanji'>刀</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58880.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sword, dagger</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Although this character no longer looks very much like a <b>sword</b>, it does have some resemblance to the handle of the <b>sword</b>. This is to our advantage, in that it helps us keep make a distinction between two primitive elements based on this kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* In the form of the kanji, this primitive means a <i>dagger</i>. When it appears to the right of another element, it is commonly stretched out and takes the sense of a great and flashing <i>saber</i>, a meaning it gets from a character we shall learn later (Frame 1801).</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there sword in his ass!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かたな、そり</p> <p id='words'>刀(かたな): sword, blade<br>剃刀(かみそり): razor</p> <p id='readingExamples'>刀 (かたな)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>90</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>86</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>90</p> <p id='keyword'>seduce</p> <p id='kanji'>召</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58FAC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>seduce, sword, dagger, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A <i>sword</i> or <i>dagger</i> posed over a <i>mouth</i> is how the character for ""beckoning"" is written. The related but less tame key word <b>seduce</b> was chosen because it seemed to fit better with the - how shall we put it? - Freudian implications of the kanji. (Observe if you will that it is not sure whether the long slender object is <b>seducing</b> the small round one or vice versa.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning remains the same: <i>seduce</i>. Just be sure to associate it with a very concrete image.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A man is easily seduced by a mouth to his ""sword."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To seduce is to make a sword of one´s mouth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>め.す</p> <p id='words'>召す(めす): to call, to send for, to put on, to wear, to take (a bath), to ride in, to buy, to eat, to drink, to catch (a cold)<br>召し上がる(めしあがる): eat (polite)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>召す (め.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>91</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>87</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>91</p> <p id='keyword'>shining</p> <p id='kanji'>昭</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E698AD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shining, sun, day, seduce, summon, sword, dagger, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let the key word suggest <b>shining</b> one's shoes, the purpose of which is to <i>seduce</i> the <i>sun</i> down on them for all to see.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Shining is the sun´s seduction.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The sun was shining so bright that it seduced Icarus and he flew too close.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>92</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>88</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>92</p> <p id='keyword'>rule</p> <p id='kanji'>則</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58987.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rule, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The character depicts a <i>clam</i> alongside a great and flashing <i>saber</i>. Think of digging for <i>clams</i> in an area where there are gaming <b>rules</b> governing how large a find has to be before you can keep it. So you take your trusty <i>saber</i>, which you have carefully notched like a yardstick, crack open a <i>clam</i> and then measure the poor little beastie to see if it is as long as the <b>rules</b> say it has to be.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you have both money and the power of the sword, you can make the rules.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you´ve got CRABs on your SABER, then you didn´t follow the rules of safe sex!</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>のっと.る</p> <p id='words'>原則(げんそく): principle, general rule<br>不規則(ふきそく): irregularity, unsteadiness, disorderly<br>法則(ほうそく): law, rule<br>規則(きそく): regulations</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>93</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>89</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>93</p> <p id='keyword'>vice-</p> <p id='kanji'>副</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E589AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vice-, wealth, one, ceiling, mouth, rice field, brains, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word <b>vice</b> has the sense of someone second-in-command. The great and flashing <i>saber</i> to the right (its usual location, so you need not worry about where to put it from now on) and the <i>wealth</i> on the left combine to create an image of dividing one's property to give a share to one's <b>vice</b>-<i>wealth</i> holder.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The wealthy guy with the sword standing next to the king, that´s the vice-roy who does all the dirty work.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Vice-president Cheney: a wealthy saber rattler.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>フク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>副詞(ふくし): adverb</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>94</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>90</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>94</p> <p id='keyword'>separate</p> <p id='kanji'>別</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E588A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>separate, mouth, bound up, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In the Old East, the samurai and his <i>saber</i> were never <b>separated</b>. They were constant companions, like the cowboy of the Old West and his six-shooter. This character depicts what must have been the height of <b>separation</b>-anxiety for a samurai: to be <i>bound up with a rope</i> and unable to get at his <i>saber</i> leaning only a few feet away from him. Look at that <i>mouth</i> bellowing out for shame and sorrow! Note the order in which the element for <i>tied up</i> is written - just as it had been with the character for <i>ten thousand</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I don´t know about you but to me this seems like someone´s head is about to be separated from his body. You can see he´s kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their mouths bound up to keep them quiet) in a separate room from his sabers. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ベツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わか.れる、わ.ける</p> <p id='words'>一別(いちべつ): parting<br>個別(こべつ): particular case<br>別(べつ): distinction, difference, different, another, particular, separate, extra, exception<br>格別(かくべつ): exceptional<br>区別(くべつ): distinction, differentiation, classification<br>差別(さべつ): discrimination, distinction, differentiation<br>性別(せいべつ): distinction by sex, sex, gender<br>送別(そうべつ): farewell, send-off<br>別荘(べっそう): holiday house, villa<br>別に(べつに): (not) particularly. nothing<br>別々(べつべつ): separately, individually<br>別れ(わかれ): parting, separation, farewell, (lateral) branch, fork, offshoot, division, section<br>特別(とくべつ): special<br>別れる(わかれる): separate</p> <p id='readingExamples'>別れる (わか.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>95</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>91</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>95</p> <p id='keyword'>street</p> <p id='kanji'>丁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B881.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>street, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The picture here is of a <b>street</b> sign on a long pole: Hollywood and Vine, if you please, or any <i>street</i> that immediately conjure sup the image of a <b>street</b> sign to you.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Used as a primitive, we change the meaning of the key word and take the shape to signify a <i>nail</i> or a <i>spike</i>. Should it happen, on reviewing, that you find the pictographs get jumbled, then think of jerking a <i>street</i> sign out of the ground and using it as a <i>nail</i> to repair your garage roof.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Today, the program ""Sesame Street"" is brought to you by the letter ""T"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Two streets make a T-intersection.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ、テイ、チン、トウ、チ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひのと</p> <p id='words'>丁目(ちょうめ): district of a town, city block (of irregular size)<br>丁々(とうとう): clashing of swords, felling of trees, ringing of an ax<br>庖丁(ほうちょう): kitchen knife, carving knife<br>丁寧(ていねい): polite, courteous</p> <p id='readingExamples'>丁数 (ちょうかず), 落丁 (らくちょう), 二丁目 (にちょうめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>96</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>92</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>96</p> <p id='keyword'>village</p> <p id='kanji'>町</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E794BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>village, rice field, brains, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Street</i> signs standing at the corner of the <i>rice fields</i> depict the <b>village</b> limits. (Remember what was said earlier: when used as a primitive, a kanji may either take its primitive meaning or revert to the original meaning of its key word.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Actually this means town, like one that has lots of streets and is surrounded by all the rice fields.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. 	"<p id='id'>97</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>93</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>97</p> <p id='keyword'>can</p> <p id='kanji'>可</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58FAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>can, mouth, street, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Remember the story about the ""Little Engine that <b>Could</b>"" when you hear this key word, and the rest is simple. See the determined little locomotive huffing and puffing up the mountain - ""I think I <b>can</b>, I think I <b>can</b>...."" - spitting railroad <i>spikes</i> out of its <i>mouth</i> as it chews up the line to the top.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A mouth on the street asking for things: ""Can I get some help?! Can I get directions, Can I have some money? 	"<p id='id'>98</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>94</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>98</p> <p id='keyword'>place on the head</p> <p id='kanji'>頂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A082.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>place on the head, street, nail, spike, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>5</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word is actually a formal metaphor meaning ""humble acceptance."" Reading off the two primitive elements in the order of their writing, we have: <i>nail</i> . . . <i>head</i>. As in ""hitting the <i>nail</i> on the <i>head</i>."" Now one presumes that most people can handle metaphors, but if you were to run into a dimwit working in a hardware store who only knew the literal meaning of things, and were to ask him, in your best Japanese, to <b>place on your head</b> a nail, he might miss the point and cause you considerable torment.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If I put a street sign on my head what do I get ? A place on the head !</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, 　　　The HEAD ON commercial nails it into your head......</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いただ.く、いただき</p> <p id='words'>頂(いただき): (top of) head, summit, spire<br>頂く(いただく): receive, take food or drink<br>頂上(ちょうじょう): top, summit, peak<br>頂点(ちょうてん): top, summit</p> <p id='readingExamples'>頂く (いただ.く), 頂 (いただき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>99</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>95</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>99</p> <p id='keyword'>child</p> <p id='kanji'>子</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AD90.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>child</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji is a pictograph of a <b>child</b> wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young <b>children</b> who cannot get around by themselves. The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air; the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up; and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's neck.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the meaning of <i>child</i> is retained, though you might imagine a little older <i>child</i>, able to run around and get into more mischief.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A child who is ten will still ask for his ma (top looks a bit like katakana ma).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A pictograph of a child, with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ、ス、ツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ、-こ、ね</p> <p id='words'>女子(おなご): woman, girl<br>原子(げんし): atom<br>子息(しそく): son<br>扇子(せんす): folding fan<br>梯子(ていし): ladder, stairs<br>捻子(ねじ): screw, helix, spiral<br>分子(ぶんし): numerator, molecule<br>利子(りし): interest (bank)<br>椅子(いす): chair<br>王子(おうじ): prince<br>菓子(かし): pastry<br>子孫(しそん): descendants, posterity, offspring<br>障子(しょうじ): paper sliding door<br>女子(じょし): woman, girl<br>末っ子(すえっこ): youngest child<br>男子(だんし): youth, young man<br>調子(ちょうし): tune, tone, key, pitch, time, rhythm, vein, mood, way, manner, style, knack, condition, state of health, strain, impetus, spur of the moment, trend<br>電子(でんし): electron, (as a prefix) electronic, electronics<br>梯子(はしご): ladder, stairs<br>判子(はんこ): seal (used for signature)<br>双子(ふたご): twins, a twin<br>迷子(まいご): lost (stray) child<br>様子(ようす): aspect, state, appearance<br>子(こ): child<br>息子(むすこ): son<br>お菓子(おかし): confections, sweets, candy<br>男の子(おとこのこ): boy<br>女の子(おんなのこ): girl<br>子供(こども): child, children<br>帽子(ぼうし): hat</p> <p id='readingExamples'>子孫 (しそん), 女子 (じょし), 帽子 (ぼうし), 子 (こ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>100</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>96</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>100</p> <p id='keyword'>cavity</p> <p id='kanji'>孔</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AD94.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cavity, child, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Probably the one thing most <i>children</i> fear more than anything else is the dentist's chair. Once a <i>child</i> has seen a dentist holding the x-rays up to the light and heard that ominous word <b>cavity</b>, even though it is not likely to know that the word means ""hole"" until it is much older, it will not be long before those two syllables get associated with the drill and that row of shiny <i>hooks</i> the dentist uses to torture people who are too small to fight back.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The child´s arms flailed around at the sight of the hooked tool the dentist was going to use to fill his cavity.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I warned him about cavities, but the child is still hooked on sweets.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あな</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>101</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>97</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>101</p> <p id='keyword'>complete</p> <p id='kanji'>了</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BA86.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>complete, child with arms wrapped up</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Learn this character by returning to frame 99 and the image given there. The only difference is that the ""arms"" have been left off (actually, only tucked inside). Thus a <i>child</i> with its arms wrapped up into the back-sack is the picture of a job successfully <b>completed</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The experiment was a complete failure! 	"<p id='id'>102</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>98</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>102</p> <p id='keyword'>woman</p> <p id='kanji'>女</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A5B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting <b>woman</b> drawn behind this character, with two legs at the bottom, two arms (the horizontal line) and the head poking out the top. A little farfetched, until you draw the character and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes. Remembering the kanji is easy; being able to write it beautifully is another thing.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning is the same: <i>woman</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a ""kunoichi"". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一(kanji, ichi=one).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>My mother taught me that a woman should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョ、ニョ、ニョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おんな、め</p> <p id='words'>貴女(あなた): you, lady<br>少女(おとめ): daughter, young lady, virgin, maiden, little girl<br>女子(おなご): woman, girl<br>女史(じょし): Ms.<br>王女(おうじょ): princess<br>女の人(おんなのひと): woman<br>少女(しょうじょ): daughter, young lady, virgin, maiden, little girl<br>女王(じょおう): queen<br>女子(じょし): woman, girl<br>女優(じょゆう): actress<br>長女(ちょうじょ): eldest daughter<br>女房(にょうぼう): wife<br>彼女(かのじょ): she<br>女性(じょせい): woman<br>女(おんな): woman, girl, daughter<br>女の子(おんなのこ): girl</p> <p id='readingExamples'>女子 (じょし), 女流 (じょりゅう), 少女 (しょうじょ), 女人 (にょにん), 天女 (てんにょ), 善男善女 (ぜんなんぜんにょ), 女 (おんな), 女 (め)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>103</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>99</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>103</p> <p id='keyword'>fond</p> <p id='kanji'>好</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A5BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fond, woman, child</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The phrase ""to be <b>fond</b> of someone"" has a natural gentleness about it, and lends a tenderness to the sense of touching by giving us the related term ""to <b>fondle</b>."" The character likens it to a <i>woman</i> <b>fondling</b> her <i>child</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A woman is fond of her child.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Jane Fonda carrying a Vietnamese child. 	"<p id='id'>104</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>100</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>104</p> <p id='keyword'>likeness</p> <p id='kanji'>如</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A682.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>likeness, woman, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pardon me if I revert to the venerable old Dr. Freud again, but his eye for symbolism is often helpful to appreciate things that more earthy imaginations once accepted more freely but that we have learned to cover over with a veneer of etiquette. For instance, the fact that things like the <i>mouth</i> of a cave served as natural ritual substitutes for the opening through which a <i>woman</i> gives birth. Hence, in order to be reborn as an adult, one may have to pass through the psychological equivalent of the womb, that is, something that bears a <b>likeness</b> to the <i>opening</i> of the <i>woman</i> from whom you were born.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Women share a common likeness. Their mouths are always open, whining about this and that.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>From a woman´s other 口comes a baby with a perfect likeness.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョ、ニョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ごと.し</p> <p id='words'>如何(いかが): how, in what way<br>如何に(いかに): how?, in what way?, how much?, however, whatever<br>如何にも(いかにも): indeed, really, phrase meaning agreement<br>如何しても(どうしても): by all means, at any cost, no matter what, after all, in the long run, cravingly, at any rate, surely<br>突如(とつじょ): suddenly, all of a sudden</p> <p id='readingExamples'>欠如 (けつじょ), 突如 (とつじょ), 躍如 (やくじょ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>105</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>101</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>105</p> <p id='keyword'>mama</p> <p id='kanji'>母</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AF8D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mama, mother, breasts</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Look closely at this kanji and you will find the outline of the kanji for <i>woman</i> in it, the second stroke of which has been expanded to make space for the two breasts that make her a <b>mama</b>. Likening this sound to a baby nursing at its mother's breast has afforded some scholars of comparative linguistics a way to explain the presence of the same word across a wide range of language groups.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive we shall add the meaning of <i>breasts</i> in accord with the explanation given above. Take careful note of the fact that the form is altered slightly when this kanji serves as a primitive, the final two dots joining together to form a longer stroke. An example follows in the next frame.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This mama had twins, one mouth for each nipple.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はは、も</p> <p id='words'>お祖母さん(おばあさん): grandmother, female senior-citizen<br>伯母さん(おばさん): aunt<br>父母(ちちはは): father and mother, parents<br>分母(ぶんぼ): denominator<br>母校(ぼこう): alma mater<br>保母(ほぼ): day care worker in a kindergarten nursery school etc.<br>母親(ははおや): mother<br>父母(ふぼ): father and mother, parents<br>祖母(そぼ): grand mother<br>お母さん(おかあさん): (polite) mother</p> <p id='readingExamples'>母 (はは)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>106</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>102</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>106</p> <p id='keyword'>pierce</p> <p id='kanji'>貫</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2AB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pierce, mama, mother, breasts, oyster, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>If one is asked to think of associations for the word <b>pierce</b>, among the first to come to mind is that of <b>piercing</b> one's ears to hold earrings, a quite primitive form of self-mutilation that has survived into the 21st century. The kanji here is read, top to bottom: <i>mama</i> . . . <i>oyster</i>. All you need to do is imagine <b>piercing</b> an ear so that it can hold a mother-of-pearl (actually, a <i>mama</i>-of-pearl) you have just wrested from an <i>oyster</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ariel the Little Mermaid´s clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The sad fate of Mama shellfish was to be captured and pierced to make an earring.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つらぬ.く、ぬ.く、ぬき</p> <p id='words'>貫禄(かんろく): presence, dignity<br>貫く(つらぬく): to go through</p> <p id='readingExamples'>貫く (つらぬ.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>107</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>103</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>107</p> <p id='keyword'>elder brother</p> <p id='kanji'>兄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58584.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>By now kanji like this one should ""look like"" something to you even though it is more of an ""ideogram"" than a ""pictograph."" The large <i>mouth</i> on top and the <i>human legs</i> below almost jump off the page as a caricature of <b>elder brother</b>, the one with the big <i>mouth</i> (or if you prefer a kinder image, the one who ""has the say"" among all the children).</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive this character will take the meaning of <i>teenager</i>, in accord with the familiar image of the big <i>mouth</i> and the gangling, clumsy <i>legs</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My elder brother was basically a mouth on legs when he was a teenager.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mother, why is elder brother´s mouth between the neighbor girl´s legs? RTK2:　ケイ　父兄　ふけい　(father and elder brother)　　　　　　　　　キョウ　兄弟　きょうだい(brothers)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　MIXED GROUP:　(ｺｸ): 克104　(ｷｮｳ): 況145　競434　(ｼｭｸ): 祝1089.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ、キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あに</p> <p id='words'>従兄弟(いとこ): male cousin<br>兄(あに): older brother<br>お兄さん(おにいさん): (polite) older brother, (vocative) ""Mister?""<br>兄弟(きょうだい): siblings</p> <p id='readingExamples'>兄事 (あにこと), 父兄 (ふけい), 義兄 (ぎあに), 兄 (あに)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>109</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>104</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>109</p> <p id='keyword'>overcome</p> <p id='kanji'>克</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5858B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>overcome, ten, needle, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In this frame we get a chance to use the kanji we just learned in its primitive meaning of <i>teenager</i>. The <i>needle</i> on top indicates one of the major problems confronting the <i>teenager</i> growing up in today's world: drugs. Many of them will fall under the shadow of the <i>needle</i> at some time during those tender years, but only when a whole generation rises up and decides that ""We Shall <b>Overcome</b>"" the plague, will the <i>needle</i> cease to hangover their heads, as it does in this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ten elder brothers can overcome anything.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A teenager addicted to heroine must overcome the needle.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.つ</p> <p id='words'>克服(こくふく): subjugation, conquest</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>110</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>105</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>110</p> <p id='keyword'>little</p> <p id='kanji'>小</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B08F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>little, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sense of <b>little</b> that this character represents is not the same as ""a little bit."" That meaning comes in the next frame. Here <b>little</b> means ""small"" or ""tiny."" The image is one of three <b>little</b> <i>drops</i>, the first of which (the one in the middle) is written larger so that the kanji has some shape to it. The point of writing it three times is to rub the point in: <b>little</b>, <b>little</b>, nothing but <b>little</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive of the same shape keeps the same meaning. Written above a horizontal line, its form is slightly altered, the last two strokes turning inwards.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A little penguin with its wings at its side.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he´s too little to ride the roller coaster.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ちい.さい、こ-、お-、さ-</p> <p id='words'>小売(こうり): retail<br>小柄(こがら): short (build)<br>小切手(こぎって): cheque, check<br>小銭(こぜに): coins, small change<br>小児科(しょうにか): pediatrics<br>小父さん(おじさん): middle-aged gentleman, uncle<br>小遣い(こづかい): personal expenses, pocket money, spending money, incidental expenses, allowance<br>小包(こづつみ): parcel, package<br>小麦(こむぎ): wheat<br>小屋(こや): hut, cabin, shed, (animal) pen<br>小指(こゆび): little finger<br>縮小(しゅくしょう): reduction, curtailment<br>小(しょう): small<br>小学生(しょうがくせい): grade school student<br>小数(しょうすう): fraction (part of), decimal<br>小便(しょうべん): (colloquial) urine<br>大小(だいしょう): size<br>小鳥(ことり): (small) bird<br>小学校(しょうがっこう): primary school<br>小説(しょうせつ): novel<br>小さな(ちいさな): small<br>小さい(ちいさい): small, little, tiny</p> <p id='readingExamples'>小 (お), 小 (こ), 小さい (ちい.さい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>111</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>106</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>111</p> <p id='keyword'>few</p> <p id='kanji'>少</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B091.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>few, little, small, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>First we need to look at the fourth stroke, the <i>drop</i> at the bottom that has been extended into a longer diagonal stroke leaning left. This happens because a single, isolated drop will NEVER appear beneath its relative primitive in its normal size, for fear it would drop off and get lost. As for the meaning, let the tiny <i>drop</i> indicate a further belittling of what is already <i>little</i>&nbsp;- thus making it a <b>few</b> of something <i>little</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Only a few people can make an ugly face like that.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Few usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すく.ない、すこ.し</p> <p id='words'>少女(おとめ): daughter, young lady, virgin, maiden, little girl<br>減少(げんしょう): decrease, reduction, decline<br>少数(しょうすう): minority, few<br>少ない(すくない): few, a little, scarce, insufficient, seldom<br>少なくとも(すくなくとも): at least<br>少女(しょうじょ): daughter, young lady, virgin, maiden, little girl<br>少々(しょうしょう): just a minute, small quantity<br>少年(しょうねん): boys, juveniles<br>少しも(すこしも): anything of, not one bit<br>青少年(せいしょうねん): youth, young person<br>多少(たしょう): more or less, somewhat, a little, some<br>少し(すこし): small quantity, little, few, something, little while, short distance</p> <p id='readingExamples'>少ない (すく.ない), 少し (すこ.し)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>112</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>107</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>112</p> <p id='keyword'>large</p> <p id='kanji'>大</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A4A7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we have a simple pictograph of a person, taking up the space of an entire character and giving it the sense of <b>large</b>. It should not be too hard to locate the two legs and outstretched arms.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we need a different meaning, since the element representing the human person will come up later. Therefore, this shape will become a <i>large dog</i> or, if you prefer, a <i>St. Bernard dog</i>. In frame 253 we will explain why this choice was made.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A person stretching their arms and legs to look large and scare a bear away.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think of a large
