	"<p id='id'>113</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>108</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>113</p> <p id='keyword'>many</p> <p id='kanji'>多</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A49A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>many, evening, evening2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""<b>Many</b> <i>moons</i> ago,"" begins much of Amerindian folklore - a colorful way of saying ""Once upon a time"" and a great deal of help for remembering this kanji. Here we have two <i>moons</i>&nbsp;(three of them would take us back to the beginning of time, which is further than we want to go), lacking the final stroke because they are partially hidden behind the clouds of time.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Two evenings too many!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: ""He who eats many prunes sits on toilet many moons"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>タ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おお.い、まさ.に、まさ.る</p> <p id='words'>幾多(いくた): many, numerous<br>過多(かた): excess, superabundance<br>加留多(かるた): (pt:) (n) playing cards (pt: carta)<br>多数決(たすうけつ): majority rule<br>多分(たぶん): perhaps, probably<br>多忙(たぼう): busy, pressure of work<br>多様(たよう): diversity, variety<br>多少(たしょう): more or less, somewhat, a little, some<br>滅多に(めったに): rarely (with negative verb), seldom<br>多い(おおい): have a lot of</p> <p id='readingExamples'>多い (おお.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>114</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>109</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>114</p> <p id='keyword'>evening</p> <p id='kanji'>夕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A495.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>evening</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Just as the word <b>evening</b> adds a touch of formality or romanticism to the ordinary word ""night,"" so the kanji for <b>evening</b> takes the ordinary looking <i>moon</i> in the night sky and has a cloud pass over it (as we saw in the last frame).</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive keeps the same meaning and connotation as the kanji.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The evening is young, the moon is not full.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the evening, I try my best to remember the katakana symbol for ""TA"" (ie. ""ta ta!"").</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆう</p> <p id='words'>夕暮れ(ゆうぐれ): evening, (evening) twilight<br>夕焼け(ゆうやけ): sunset<br>夕刊(ゆうかん): evening paper<br>夕立(ゆうだち): (sudden) evening shower (rain)<br>夕日(ゆうひ): setting sun<br>夕べ(ゆうべ): evening, last night<br>夕飯(ゆうはん): dinner<br>夕方(ゆうがた): evening</p> <p id='readingExamples'>夕 (ゆう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>115</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>110</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>115</p> <p id='keyword'>eventide</p> <p id='kanji'>汐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B190.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>eventide, water, water droplets, water pistol, evening</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In the next lesson we will meet the character for morning-<i>tide</i> and the element for <i>drops of water</i>. Meantime we have a perfect blend of picture and idea in this kanji to play on the English word for nightfall, <b>eventide</b>: <i>drops of water</i> inching their way up the shore in the <i>evening</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Eventide is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Drops of water shower the beach as the evening tide approaches: eventide.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しお、うしお、せい</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>116</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>111</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>116</p> <p id='keyword'>outside</p> <p id='kanji'>外</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A496.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>outside, evening, magic wand, augury</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>On the left, the primitive for <i>evening</i>, and on the right, that for the <i>magic wand</i>. Now, as every magician worth his abracadabra knows, bringing your <i>magic wand</i> out into the <i>evening</i> air makes your magic much more powerful than if you were to stay indoors. Hence, <i>evening</i> and <i>magic wand</i> takes you naturally <b>outside</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A young magician likes to practice outside in the evening with his magic wand (as opposed to the old magician who wakes early to practice with his wand in eminent (#51)).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Outside in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガイ、ゲ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そと、ほか、はず.す、はず.れる、と-</p> <p id='words'>域外(いきがい): outside the area<br>外貨(がいか): imported goods, foreign money<br>外観(がいかん): appearance, exterior, facade<br>外相(がいしょう): Foreign Minister<br>外来(がいらい): imported, outpatient clinic<br>課外(かがい): extracurricular<br>除外(じょがい): exception, exclusion<br>外方(そっぽ): look (or turn) the other way<br>その外(そのほか): besides, in addition, the rest<br>野外(やがい): fields, outskirts, open air, suburbs<br>案外(あんがい): unexpectedly<br>以外(いがい): except for, other than<br>意外(いがい): unexpected, surprising<br>屋外(おくがい): outdoors<br>海外(かいがい): foreign, abroad, overseas<br>外交(がいこう): diplomacy<br>外出(がいしゅつ): outing, going out<br>外部(がいぶ): the outside, external<br>外科(げか): surgical department<br>外す(はずす): unfasten, remove<br>外れる(はずれる): be disconnected, get out of place, be off, be out (e.g. of gear)<br>例外(れいがい): exception<br>郊外(こうがい): suburbs<br>外国(がいこく): foreign country<br>外国人(がいこくじん): foreigner<br>外(そと): other place, the rest<br>外(ほか): other place, the rest</p> <p id='readingExamples'>外出 (がいしゅつ), 海外 (かいがい), 除外 (じょがい), 外 (そと), 外す (はず.す), 外れる (はず.れる), 外 (ほか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>117</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>112</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>117</p> <p id='keyword'>name</p> <p id='kanji'>名</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5908D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>name, evening, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Perhaps you have heard of the custom, still preserved in certain African tribes, of a father creeping into the tent or hut of his newborn child on the night of the child's birth, to whisper into its ear the <b>name</b> he has chosen for it, before making his choice public. It is an impressive <b>naming</b> custom and fits in tidily with the way this character is constructed: <i>evening</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>. At <i>evening</i> time, a <i>mouth</i> pronounces the <b>name</b> that will accompany one throughout life.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your name so that people can recognise you.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my name.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>メイ、ミョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>な、-な</p> <p id='words'>記名(きめい): signature, register<br>姓名(せいめい): full name<br>著名(ちょめい): well-known, noted, celebrated<br>名残(なごり): remains, traces, memory<br>名高い(なだかい): famous, celebrated, well-known<br>名付ける(なづける): to name (someone)<br>名札(なふだ): name plate, name tag<br>本名(ほんみょう): real name<br>名産(めいさん): noted product<br>名称(めいしょう): name<br>名簿(めいぼ): register of names<br>名誉(めいよ): honor, credit, prestige<br>宛名(あてな): address, direction<br>送り仮名(おくりがな): kana written after a kanji to complete the full (usually kun) reading of the word<br>仮名(かな): kana, alias, pseudonym, pen name<br>仮名遣い(かなづかい): kana orthography, syllabary spelling<br>氏名(しめい): full name, identity<br>署名(しょめい): signature<br>題名(だいめい): title<br>代名詞(だいめいし): pronoun<br>地名(ちめい): place name<br>名(な): name, reputation<br>振り仮名(ふりがな): hiragana over kanji, pronunciation key<br>名字(みょうじ): surname, family name<br>名作(めいさく): masterpiece<br>名刺(めいし): business card<br>名詞(めいし): noun<br>名所(めいしょ): famous place<br>名人(めいじん): master, expert<br>名物(めいぶつ): famous product, speciality<br>片仮名(かたかな): katakana<br>名前(なまえ): name<br>平仮名(ひらがな): hiragana, 47 syllables, the cursive syllabary<br>有名(ゆうめい): fame</p> <p id='readingExamples'>名誉 (めいよ), 氏名 (しめい), 有名 (ゆうめい), 名 (な)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>118</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>113</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>118</p> <p id='keyword'>stone</p> <p id='kanji'>石</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79FB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stone, cliff, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>With a <i>mouth</i> under a <i>cliff</i>, what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern, before which a great <b>stone</b> has been rolled so that none may enter. Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their treasures, in which case that magic word known to every school child who ever delighted over the tales of the <i>Arabian Nights</i> should be enough to push the <b>stone</b> aside. But take care - the <i>cliff</i> is steep, and one slip will send you tumbling down into the ravine below. This is the one and only time that the second stroke in <i>cliff</i> will reach over to the middle of the horizontal stroke. If you think of the edge jutting outwards (in keeping with the story above), the problem should be taken care of.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The <i>stone</i> is a quite common primitive element, which is not restricted to great boulders but used of <i>stones</i> or <i>rocks</i> of any size or shape.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of cliff just in time to evade the huge STONE rolling out of the mouth of the cave!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There´s a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the cliff thing isn´t working for you... Just see it as a stone [いし] being hammered by a miner searching for jewel stones [ほうせき] ;).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ、シャク、コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いし</p> <p id='words'>化石(かせき): fossil, petrifaction, fossilization<br>岩石(がんせき): rock<br>石鹸(せっけん): soap<br>流石(さすが): clever, adept, good, expectations, as one would expect<br>磁石(じしゃく): magnet<br>石炭(せきたん): coal<br>石油(せきゆ): oil, petroleum, kerosene<br>宝石(ほうせき): gem, jewel<br>石(いし): stone</p> <p id='readingExamples'>石材 (せきざい), 岩石 (がんせき), 宝石 (ほうせき), 磁石 (じしゃく), 石 (いし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>119</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>114</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>119</p> <p id='keyword'>resemblance</p> <p id='kanji'>肖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88296.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>resemblance, spark, candle, small, little, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The word <b>resemblance</b> should suggest, among other things, a son's <b>resemblance</b> to his father. A ""chip off the old block"" is the way we often put it, but the character is more simple. It speaks of a <i>little</i> bit of <i>flesh</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* When used as a primitive, the sense of <i>resemblance</i> is replaced by that of <i>spark</i> or <i>candle</i>. (If you want an explanation: the kanji for <i>moon</i> also carries a secondary sense of <i>fire</i>, which we omitted because we are keeping that meaning for other primitives.)</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Using DNA matching, a very little bit of flesh can be used to show the resemblence between family members.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hey baby, it might be a little bit of flesh now, but in a moment it´ll bear a strong resemblance to a candlestick.(nudge nudge, wink wink).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あやか.る</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>120</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>115</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>120</p> <p id='keyword'>nitrate</p> <p id='kanji'>硝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A19D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>nitrate, stone, rock, resemblance, spark, candle, small, little, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The word <b>nitrate</b> should immediately suggest a beaker of <b>nitric</b> acid, which, as every high-school chemistry student knows, can eat its way through some pretty tough substances. Here we imagine pouring it over a <i>rock</i> and watching the <i>sparks</i> fly as it bores a hole through the rock.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured nitrate acid on it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Salpetre is the common name for Nitrate coming from Latin ""sal petrae"" or stone salt. It is also a component of gun powder so including a candle in this kanji can be quite explosive!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>121</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>116</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>121</p> <p id='keyword'>smash</p> <p id='kanji'>砕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A095.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>smash, stone, rock, ninety, nine, baseball, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We begin with the two elements on the right, <i>baseball</i> and <i>needle</i>. Since they will be coming together from time to time, let us give the two of them the sense of a <i>game of cricket</i> in which a <i>needle</i> is laid across the wicket. Then imagine using a <i>rock</i> for a ball. A <b>smash</b> hit would probably splinter the bat in all directions, and a <b>smashing</b> pitch would do the same with the <i>needle</i> wicket.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To SMASH a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they´ve done a new SMASH hit!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くだ.く、くだ.ける</p> <p id='words'>砕く(くだく): break, smash<br>砕ける(くだける): break, be broken</p> <p id='readingExamples'>砕く (くだ.く), 砕ける (くだ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>122</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>117</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>122</p> <p id='keyword'>sand</p> <p id='kanji'>砂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A082.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sand, stone, rock, few</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Good <b>sand</b> for beaches has <i>few</i> or no <i>stones</i> in it. That means that all of us whose feet have been spoiled by too much time in shoes don't have to watch our step as we cavort about.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Here´s how I remember that stone is on the left. 	"<p id='id'>124</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>118</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>124</p> <p id='keyword'>plane</p> <p id='kanji'>削</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5898A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>plane, resemblance, spark, candle, small, little, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Long before the invention of the carpenter's <b>plane</b>, people used knives and machetes (or here, <i>sabers</i>) to smooth out their woodwork. If you have ever seen the process, you will have been amazed at the speed and agility with which the adept can <b>plane</b> a hunk of wood into shape. Indeed, you can almost see the <i>sparks</i> fly from their <i>sabers</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sparks will fly if you attempt to PLANE your sabre.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>With today´s strict air regulations, carrying a sabre onto a plane could spark quite a commotion.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>けず.る、はつ.る、そ.ぐ</p> <p id='words'>削減(さくげん): cut, reduction, curtailment<br>削る(けずる): shave (wood or leather), sharpen, plane, whittle, scrape off, reduce, remove, erase<br>削除(さくじょ): elimination, cancellation, deletion, erasure</p> <p id='readingExamples'>削る (けず.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>125</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>119</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>125</p> <p id='keyword'>ray</p> <p id='kanji'>光</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58589.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ray, small, little, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>There are really only 2 primitives here, <i>little</i> and <i>human legs</i>. The 4th stroke that separates them is added for reasons of aesthetics. (If that doesn't make sense, try writing the kanji without it and see how ugly the results look, even to your beginner's eye.) Now if you have wondered what those little particles of ""dust"" are that dance around in the light-<b>rays</b> that come through the window and fall on your desk, try imagining them as <i>little</i> and disembodied <i>human legs</i>, and you should have no trouble with this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A ray of light is not a wave but made of little photons with human legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The ray from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people little - ha! look at them run around on their tiny legs!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひか.る、ひかり</p> <p id='words'>稲光(いなびかり): (flash of) lightning<br>光沢(こうたく): brilliance, polish, lustre, glossy finish (of photographs)<br>光熱費(こうねつひ): cost of fuel and light<br>観光(かんこう): sightseeing<br>蛍光灯(けいこうとう): fluorescent lamp, person who is slow to react<br>光景(こうけい): scene, spectacle<br>光線(こうせん): beam, light ray<br>日光(にっこう): sunlight<br>光(ひかり): light<br>光る(ひかる): shine, glitter, be bright</p> <p id='readingExamples'>光る (ひか.る), 光 (ひかり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>126</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>120</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>126</p> <p id='keyword'>plump</p> <p id='kanji'>太</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A4AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>plump, large, St. Bernard, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""<b>Plump</b>"" is one of those delightful English words that almost sound like their meaning. 	"<p id='id'>127</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>121</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>127</p> <p id='keyword'>utensil</p> <p id='kanji'>器</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E599A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>utensil, mouth, large, St. Bernard, mouth4</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The picture in this kanji is not a pleasant one. It shows a large and fluffy <i>St. Bernard dog</i> stretched out on a table all stuffed and stewed and garnished with vegetables, its paws in the air and an apple in its mouth. At each corner of the table sits an eager but empty <i>mouth</i>, waiting for the <b>utensils</b> to arrive so the feast can begin.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine four hungry mouths all sitting around the table. They are all banging their utensils on the table waiting for a big meal to be placed in the centre.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note: 器 by itself means container/caliber/vessel. And 食器 means eating utensils (""food container"", hehe).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うつわ</p> <p id='words'>器(うつわ): bowl, vessel, container<br>器官(きかん): organ (of body), instrument<br>計器(けいき): meter, gauge<br>磁器(じき): porcelain, china<br>聴診器(ちょうしんき): stethoscope<br>陶器(とうき): pottery, ceramics<br>兵器(へいき): arms, weapons, ordinance<br>宝器(ほうき): treasured article or vessel, outstanding individual<br>楽器(がっき): musical instrument<br>器械(きかい): instrument<br>器具(きぐ): utensil<br>器用(きよう): skillful, handy<br>受話器(じゅわき): telephone receiver<br>食器(しょっき): tableware<br>武器(ぶき): weapon, arms, ordinance<br>容器(ようき): container, vessel</p> <p id='readingExamples'>器 (うつわ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>130</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>123</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>130</p> <p id='keyword'>exquisite</p> <p id='kanji'>妙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A699.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>exquisite, woman, few</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The primitive for <i>woman</i> is on the left (there and at the bottom of another primitive is where you will always find her), and to the right the element for <i>few</i>. When we refer to a <i>woman</i> as <b>exquisite</b>, we mean to praise her as the sort of person we meet but <i>few</i> and far between. If you are interested in etymologies, it might help to recall that the Latin phrase lying at the root of the English word <b>exquisite</b> carries this same sense of ""seeking out"" the rare from the ordinary.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Exquisite women are few and far between.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A geisha is an exquisite and delicate (another meaning of this kanji) women, however, even in the past there was only few of them.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ミョウ、ビョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たえ</p> <p id='words'>巧妙(こうみょう): ingenious, skillful, clever, deft<br>奇妙(きみょう): strange, queer, curious<br>微妙(びみょう): delicate, subtle<br>妙(みょう): strange, unusual</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>131</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>124</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>131</p> <p id='keyword'>focus</p> <p id='kanji'>省</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79C81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>focus, few, eye</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When we think of <b>focusing</b> on something, we usually take it in a metaphorical sense, though the literal sense is not far behind. It means to block out what is nonessential in order to fix our <i>eye</i> on a <i>few</i> important matters. The kanji suggests picking up a <i>few</i> things and holding them before one's <i>eye</i> in order to <b>focus</b> on them better.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You focus by concentrating your eye on fewer objects.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Success (or survival?) method for accelerated juggling course: focus on a few nitroglycerine filled juggling balls flying OVER your eyes ---(I have trouble with this few primitive that can be anywhere in a kanji. 	"<p id='id'>132</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>125</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>132</p> <p id='keyword'>thick</p> <p id='kanji'>厚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58E9A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>thick, cliff, sun, day, child</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When we refer to someone as <b>thick</b>-skinned or <b>thick-</b>headed, we are usually quick to add - even if only under our breath - something about their upbringing. Perhaps it is because deep down we cherish the belief that by nature people are basically tender and sensitive. Be that as it may, the Japanese character for <b>thick</b> depicts a <i>child</i> abandoned out on the wild <i>cliffs</i>, exposed to the heat of the <i>sun</i>, and thus doomed to develop a head and skin as <b>thick</b> as the parent who left it there.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In Sparta we throw our Children over a Cliff. Under the Sun, they fight other Children. In the end, if they survive, they sure have thick skin.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The thick cliff walls protected the children from the sun.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あつ.い、あか</p> <p id='words'>厚かましい(あつかましい): impudent, shameless, brazen<br>厚い(あつい): thick, deep, cordial, kind, warm(hearted)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>厚い (あつ.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>133</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>126</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>133</p> <p id='keyword'>strange</p> <p id='kanji'>奇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A587.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>strange, large, St. Bernard, can, mouth, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The elements we are given to work with here are <i>St. Bernard dog</i> and <i>can</i>. Lots of phrases pop to mind to attach these words to the key word, but they end up too abstract because of the word <i>can</i>. It is important in such cases (and there will be plenty of them as we go along)&nbsp;to stick closely to the&nbsp;elements, in this case, <i>mouth</i>&nbsp;and <i>nails</i>. Now all we need do is create a fictitious ""<b>Strange</b> But True"" column in the Sunday funnies, featuring a <i>St. Bernard</i> whose <i>mouth</i> has been <i>nailed</i> shut because he was hitting the brandy keg around his neck too hard.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I find it strange that so many people commit suicide in Tokyo by throwing themselves in front of the train. To me when I look at this kanji, I see a train just about to come out of a tunnel, and above the man waiting for his oppourtunity where he can end it all.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine a ST. BERNARD DOG carrying a CAN instead of a barrel in rescue missions. How strange!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>く.しき、あや.しい、くし、めずら.しい</p> <p id='words'>奇数(きすう): odd number<br>奇麗(きれい): pretty, clean, nice, tidy, beautiful, fair<br>奇妙(きみょう): strange, queer, curious</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>134</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>127</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>134</p> <p id='keyword'>stream</p> <p id='kanji'>川</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B79D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stream, flood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We have taken the image of a river <b>stream</b> over into English to describe things that fall down in straight lines, or ripple along in lines. All of this is more than evident in the kanji given here, a pictograph of a <b>stream</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character adds to the meaning of <i>stream</i> the more vivid image of a <i>flood</i>. Note, however, that there are certain small changes in the writing of the element, depending on where it appears relative to other elements:<div>on the left, it is written the same.</div><div>on the top, it is written with the three strokes more like less-then signs</div><div>on the bottom, it is written with the third stroke similar to a fishhook</div></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>So as not to confuse this with river (#146) think of streamers falling down.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There are three default I/O Streams in UNIX, stdin, stdout, and stderr.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かわ</p> <p id='words'>河川(かせん): rivers<br>川(かわ): river</p> <p id='readingExamples'>川 (かわ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>135</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>128</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>135</p> <p id='keyword'>state</p> <p id='kanji'>州</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B79E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>state, stream, flood, drops</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we see <i>drops of</i> land (little islets) rising up out of a <i>stream</i>, creating a kind of sandbar or breakwater. Ever wonder how the <b>state</b>-line is drawn between <b>states</b> separated by a river? If there were little <i>drops of</i> land as in the kanji, there'd be nothing to it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There were 3 little islands in the stream who all decided to set themselves up as independent states.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>シュウ　The original meaning of this character was ""sandbar"", and for me this conjures up images of the Mississippi River, which is very wide with many sandbars and which was used to define the borders in ten American states. Picture Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer floating by state after state as they adventure down the mighty Mississippi, occasionally beaching their raft on sandbars.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ、ス</p> <p id='kunYomi'>す</p> <p id='words'>州(しゅう): state, province</p> <p id='readingExamples'>州 (す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>136</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>129</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>136</p> <p id='keyword'>obey</p> <p id='kanji'>順</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A086.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>obey, stream, flood, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In primitive language, this character would read <i>stream</i> . . . <i>head</i>. And that turns out to be convenient for remembering its meaning of <b>obey</b>. Either one <b>obeys</b> the person who is <i>head</i> of an organization or else <b>obeys</b> by following the <i>stream</i> of opinion (""current"" practice, we call it). Both these senses come together in this kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Obey, Obey! says the brain-washing scientist as he sends a stream of orders to fill your head.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Obey the orders streaming down from head office.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>手順(てじゅん): process, procedure, protocol<br>不順(ふじゅん): irregularity, unseasonableness<br>順(じゅん): order, turn<br>順々(じゅんじゅん): in order, in turn<br>順序(じゅんじょ): order, sequence, procedure<br>順調(じゅんちょう): favourable, doing well, O.K., all right<br>順番(じゅんばん): turn (in line), order of things<br>道順(みちじゅん): itinerary, route</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>137</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>130</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>137</p> <p id='keyword'>water</p> <p id='kanji'>水</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B0B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>water</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character, which looks a bit like a snowflake, is actually a pictograph of <b>water</b>&nbsp;- not any particular body of water or movement of water, but simply the generic name for <b>water</b>. Should you have any difficulty remembering it, simply think of a <i>walking stick</i> being dropped vertically into the <b>water</b>, sending <i>droplets</i> out in all four directions. Then all you need to learn is how to write it in proper order.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character can keep its form, or it can be written with three drops to the left of another primitive. This latter, as we will see, is far more common.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The kanji for water is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes; constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig´s story doesn´t do this).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>For those having issues with this* ""A 7K foot pool of water"" Notice it looks like a 7, and a K. Might have to practice writing it a few times.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みず、みず-</p> <p id='words'>大水(おおみず): flood<br>降水(こうすい): rainfall, precipitation<br>洪水(こうずい): flood<br>水気(すいき): moisture, dampness, vapor, dropsy, edema<br>水源(すいげん): source of river, fountainhead<br>水洗(すいせん): flushing<br>水田(すいでん): (water-filled) paddy field<br>水曜(すいよう): Wednesday<br>潜水(せんすい): diving<br>排水(はいすい): drainage<br>海水浴(かいすいよく): sea bathing, seawater bath<br>下水(げすい): drainage, sewage, ditch, gutter<br>香水(こうすい): perfume<br>水産(すいさん): marine products, fisheries<br>水準(すいじゅん): water level, level, standard<br>水蒸気(すいじょうき): water vapour, steam<br>水素(すいそ): hydrogen<br>水滴(すいてき): drop of water<br>水筒(すいとう): canteen, flask, water bottle<br>水分(すいぶん): moisture<br>水平(すいへい): water level, horizon<br>水平線(すいへいせん): horizon<br>淡水(たんすい): fresh water<br>断水(だんすい): water outage<br>地下水(ちかすい): underground water<br>噴水(ふんすい): water fountain<br>水泳(すいえい): swimming<br>水道(すいどう): water works<br>水曜日(すいようび): Wednesday<br>水(みず): water</p> <p id='readingExamples'>水 (みず)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>138</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>131</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>138</p> <p id='keyword'>icicle</p> <p id='kanji'>氷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B0B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>icicle, drop, water</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The appearance of the primitive for <i>water</i> in its full form tells us that we have something to do with <i>water</i> here. The extra <i>drop</i> to the left, added as a second stroke, changes the picture from a splash caused by a <i>walking stick</i> dropped into <i>water</i> to form an <b>icicle</b>. If it helps, when you hold an <b>icicle</b> up to the light, you can usually see little crystallizations of five-pointed stars inside of it, which is the shape we have in this kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Icicles start with 1 frozen drop of water.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A drop in temperature turns water into an icicle.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こおり、ひ、こお.る</p> <p id='words'>氷(こおり): ice</p> <p id='readingExamples'>氷 (こおり), 氷 (ひ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>139</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>132</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>139</p> <p id='keyword'>eternity</p> <p id='kanji'>永</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B0B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>eternity, drop, water</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji also uses the full form of <i>water</i>, though its meaning seems to have nothing at all to do with <i>water</i>. Remember what William Blake said about seeing ""infinity in a grain of sand and <b>eternity</b> in an hour""? Well, reading this character from top to bottom, we see ""<b>eternity</b> in a <i>drop of water</i>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It would take an eternity to count all the drops of water.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It takes but one drop from the most special water: the fountain of youth (and it is written in a special way to with an extra horizontal line on the top) to live for an eternity. (In order to remember that the drop is at the top, think that the drop must come from the topmost water in order for its effects to be true).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>エイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なが.い</p> <p id='words'>永遠(えいえん): eternity, perpetuity, immortality, permanence<br>永久(えいきゅう): eternity, perpetuity, immortality<br>永い(ながい): long, lengthy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>永い (なが.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>140</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>133</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>140</p> <p id='keyword'>spring</p> <p id='kanji'>泉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B389.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>spring, white, dove, water</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Call to mind the image of a fresh, bubbling <b>spring</b> of <i>water</i>, and you will probably notice how the top of the <b>spring</b> you are thinking of, the part where the ""bubbling"" goes on, is all <i>white</i>. Happily, the <i>white</i> is just where it should be, at the top, and the <i>water</i> is at the bottom.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* We will keep this image of a <i>spring</i> when using this kanji as a primitive, but not without first drawing attention to a slight change that distinguishes the primitive from the kanji. The final 4 strokes (the element for <i>water</i>) are abbreviated to the three small drops that we learned earlier as the kanji for <i>little</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>White is a symbol of purety, so white water is pure water, the precise definition of spring water.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Perhaps the most common appearance of this kanji is in the word 温泉 (おんせん, onsen), a Japanese hot spring. The kanji is an excellent image of someone enjoying a Japanese hot spring: a little white towel on top, water below. (This helps keep all associations: spring, little and onsen).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いずみ</p> <p id='words'>泉(いずみ): spring, fountain<br>温泉(おんせん): spa, hot spring</p> <p id='readingExamples'>泉 (いずみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>142</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>134</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>142</p> <p id='keyword'>meadow</p> <p id='kanji'>原</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58E9F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>meadow, cliff, spring, white, dove, small, little</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Though the kanji is broad enough to embrace both meanings, the <b>meadow</b> you should imagine here is not a flatland plain but a mountain <b>meadow</b> in the Austrian Alps. (Perhaps the opening scene of ""The Sound of Music"" will help.) Simply think of little <i>springs</i> bubbling up across the <b>meadow</b> to form a sort of path that leads you right to the brink of a precipitous <i>cliff</i>. Now if you can see Schwester Maria skipping along merrily, dodging in and out of the <i>springs</i>, and then falling headlong over the <i>cliff</i>, you have a ridiculous story that should help fix this kanji in memory.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Follow the springs down the cliff and you will find a nice meadow.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Sorry about this, but Heisig was stupid calling this kanji meadow, used in composite words the most common meaning is ORIGIN... 	"<p id='id'>143</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>135</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>143</p> <p id='keyword'>petition</p> <p id='kanji'>願</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A198.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>petition, meadow, cliff, white, dove, small, little, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A <i>meadow</i> and a <i>head</i> are all we are given to work with in the kanji for <b>petition</b>. Then just picture people kneeling hopefully before it, <b>petitioning</b> for whatever it is they want. (The scarecrow wanted brains, the lion, courage, and the tin man a heart. 	"<p id='id'>145</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>137</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>145</p> <p id='keyword'>marsh</p> <p id='kanji'>沼</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B2BC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>marsh, water, water droplets, water pistol, summon, seduce, sword, dagger, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Unlike the meadow with its cliffs, the <b>marsh</b>lands are low and near a source of <i>water</i> that feeds them until they get soggy through and through. Why certain land becomes <b>marshy</b> is probably due to the fact that it felt thirsty, and so tried its best to <i>seduce</i> the <i>water</i> over to its side. But, like most inordinate <i>seductions</i>, the last state of the victim is worse than the first. Hence the slushy <b>marsh</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The marshlands near Mordor seduce Frodo into gazing upon them, and he falls into the water--splash!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A marsh is where water is seduced into the ground.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ぬま</p> <p id='words'>沼(ぬま): swamp, bog, pond, lake</p> <p id='readingExamples'>沼 (ぬま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>146</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>138</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>146</p> <p id='keyword'>open sea</p> <p id='kanji'>沖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B296.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>open sea, water, water droplets, water pistol, in, stick, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji could hardly be simpler. The key word <b>open sea</b> readily suggests being out <i>in the middle of</i> a great body of <i>water</i> .Thinking of it in this way should avoid confusion with the kanji for ""open,"" which we will meet later on.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Open sea is a lot of water in the middle of nowhere.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Water in the middle of the ocean is referred to as open sea.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おき、おきつ、ちゅう.する、わく</p> <p id='words'>沖(おき): open sea</p> <p id='readingExamples'>沖 (おき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>148</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>139</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>148</p> <p id='keyword'>creek</p> <p id='kanji'>江</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B19F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>creek, water, water droplets, water pistol, craft</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Unlike the river, the ocean, the lake, and the pond, the <b>creek</b> is often no more then a dribble of <i>water</i> trickling down a small gully. While the geological history of the larger bodies of <i>water</i> is hard to surmise sometimes, all of us know from our childhood how <b>creeks</b> are made. You probably even dug one or two in your time. All you need to do is find a mainstream of <i>water</i> somewhere and dig a little path into dry land. The <b>creek</b> is thus a lesson in <i>water-craft</i>, as this kanji would agree.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A CREEK is a small trail of water easily crafted with a stick.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Creeks are small water, easily crossed with a simple i-beam.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>え</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>江 (え)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>150</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>140</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>150</p> <p id='keyword'>soup</p> <p id='kanji'>汁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B181.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>soup, water, water droplets, water pistol, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To make <b>soup</b>, one begins with <i>water</i> and then starts adding things to it, often leftovers from the icebox. This is how the thick <b>soup</b> or stew called ""seven-in-one"" is made. This kanji does it three better, giving us a <i>ten</i>-ingredient <b>soup</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To make soup you just take water and add (+) the rest of your ingredients.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To make soup you just take water and add ten tasty ingredients.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しる、-しる、つゆ</p> <p id='words'>汁(しる): juice, sap, soup, broth</p> <p id='readingExamples'>汁 (しる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>152</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>141</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>152</p> <p id='keyword'>tide</p> <p id='kanji'>潮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BDAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tide, water, water droplets, water pistol, morning , mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, ten2, needle2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Before we get to explaining this character, take a look at it and see if you can figure out the primitive elements on your own.... On the left is the <i>water</i>&nbsp;- that much is easy. On the right we have only one primitive, the kanji for <i>morning</i> learned back in Frame 53. See how an apparently complex kanji falls apart neatly into manageable pieces? To get the meaning of the key word <b>tide</b>, just think of it in connection with the character for <i>eventide</i> that we learned back in Frame 115. Here we have the <i>morning</i>-<b>tide</b>, its complement. By the way, if you missed the question about the number of primitives, it is probably because you forgot what we said earlier about kanji becoming primitives, independently of the pieces that make them up. As a rule, look for the largest kanji you can write and proceed from there to primitives stranded on their own.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The morning tide is basically, well, WATER in the MORNING.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is not the eventide, but the water of the morning tide.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しお、うしお</p> <p id='words'>潮(うしお): tide</p> <p id='readingExamples'>潮 (しお)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>153</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>142</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>153</p> <p id='keyword'>source</p> <p id='kanji'>源</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BA90.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>source, water, water droplets, water pistol, meadow, cliff, sun, day, small, little</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>With the advice of the last frame in mind, it is easy to see <i>water</i> and <i>meadow</i> in this character for <b>source</b>. Both in its etymology (it has a common parent with the word ""surge"") and in popular usage, <b>source</b> suggests the place <i>water</i> comes from. In this kanji, it is under the <i>meadow</i>, where we just saw it breaking the surface in those bubbly little <i>springs</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The water that flows from the meadow is the source of life for the wild antelope.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The source of clean water is from the meadow (#134): it comes from that spring at the bottom of the cliff. Pay no attention to Julie Andrews lying face down in spring. The water´s clean. Trust me.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みなもと</p> <p id='words'>起源(きげん): origin, beginning, rise<br>語源(ごげん): word root, word derivation, etymology<br>財源(ざいげん): source of funds, resources, finances<br>水源(すいげん): source of river, fountainhead<br>電源(でんげん): source of electricity, power (button on TV etc.)<br>源(みなもと): source, origin<br>資源(しげん): resources</p> <p id='readingExamples'>源 (みなもと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>154</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>143</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>154</p> <p id='keyword'>lively</p> <p id='kanji'>活</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B4BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lively, water, water droplets, water pistol, tongue, drop, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When we speak of a <b>lively</b> personality or a <b>lively</b> party, we immediately think of a lot of chatter. This kanji depicts the idea of <b>lively</b> by having <i>tongues</i> babble and splash around like flowing <i>water</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Conversations can become more lively after everyone has had a few drinks. It´s because ""watery tongues"" loosen lips!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I´m sure I can get her pretty lively and wet using my tongue.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い.きる、い.かす、い.ける</p> <p id='words'>活ける(いける): to arrange (flowers)<br>活発(かっぱつ): vigor, active<br>生活(せいかつ): living, life (one´s daily existence), livelihood<br>復活(ふっかつ): revival (e.g. musical), restoration<br>活気(かっき): energy, liveliness<br>活字(かつじ): printing type<br>活動(かつどう): action, activity<br>活躍(かつやく): activity<br>活用(かつよう): conjugation, practical use<br>活力(かつりょく): vitality, energy</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>155</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>144</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>155</p> <p id='keyword'>extinguish</p> <p id='kanji'>消</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B688.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>extinguish, water, water droplets, water pistol, resemblance, spark, candle, small, little, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Among the many things <i>water</i> is useful for is <b>extinguishing</b> fires, and that is just what we have here. First of all, take the <i>water</i> at the left as the <i>drops of water</i> that are used to depict <i>water</i> in general. In the best of all possible worlds, the most efficient way to <b>extinguish</b> a fire would be to see that each <i>drop of water</i> hits one <i>spark</i> of the conflagration. An unthinkable bit of utopian fire fighting, you say to yourself, but helpful for assigning this key word its primitives.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To extinguish a SPARK, you need WATER.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You need a few drops of water to extinguish the candle.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>き.える、け.す</p> <p id='words'>打ち消し(うちけし): negation, denial, negative<br>消去(しょうきょ): elimination, erasing, dying out, melting away<br>消耗(しょうこう): exhaustion, consumption<br>消息(しょうそく): news, letter, circumstances<br>打ち消す(うちけす): deny, negate, contradict<br>消しゴム(けしゴム): eraser, India rubber<br>消化(しょうか): digestion<br>消極的(しょうきょくてき): passive<br>消毒(しょうどく): disinfection, sterilization<br>消費(しょうひ): consumption, expenditure<br>消防(しょうぼう): fire fighting, fire department<br>消防署(しょうぼうしょ): fire station<br>消耗(しょうもう): exhaustion, consumption<br>取り消す(とりけす): cancel<br>消える(きえる): go out, vanish, disappear<br>消す(けす): erase, delete, turn off power</p> <p id='readingExamples'>消える (き.える), 消す (け.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>156</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>145</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>156</p> <p id='keyword'>but of course (condition)</p> <p id='kanji'>況</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B381.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>but of course, water, water droplets, water pistol, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word is a connector used to link contrasting phrase sand sentences together with much the same flavor as the English phrase <b>but of course</b>. Just picture yourself ready to go off on your first date as a <i>teenager</i>, and having your mother grill you about your manners and ask you embarrassing questions about your hygiene. ""Did you have a good shower?"" ""<b>But of course</b>,"" you reply, annoyed. So <i>water</i> and <i>teenager</i> combine to give us <b>but of course</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you ask your teenager if what he´s drinking is water (and not Vodka), he will answer ""but of course"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>キョウ But of course, this character really means ""situation/condition"". ""Elder brother gulped some water and said, ´What the hell was Heisig´s mental CONDITION when he came up with this definition? Heisig must have a drinking CONDITION. But of course, if Heisig sticks to water, rather than sake (like me, water quaffing, situation assessing, sober elder brother), his SITUATION may improve.´""　[MODEL COMPOUND: 状況　(じょうきょう)　state of affairs; conditions].</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まし.て、いわ.んや、おもむき</p> <p id='words'>好況(こうきょう): prosperous conditions, healthy economy<br>不況(ふきょう): recession, depression, slump<br>況して(まして): still more, still less (with neg. verb), to say nothing of, not to mention<br>状況(じょうきょう): state of affairs (around you), situation, circumstances</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>157</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>146</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>157</p> <p id='keyword'>river</p> <p id='kanji'>河</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B2B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>river, water, water droplets, water pistol, can, street, nail, spike, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The character in this frame represents a step up from the <i>stream</i> we met in Frame 134; it is a full-sized <b>river</b>. The <i>water</i> to the left tells us what we are dealing with, and the <i>can</i> at the right tells us that our ""little engine that <i>could</i>"" has now become amphibious and is chugging down the Mighty Mississip' like a regular riverboat.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A river CAN exist only if there is WATER.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I kept confusing this with stream. My Japanese friend said that to him this is for an artificial river. Looking at kanji compounds with this there are two that struck me: One is the Yellow River in China (黄河), and the other is the Milky Way (銀河). Now I either think of the Little Engine that could dragging a bunch of stuff down a river in China and polluting it (so it turned yellow) or I see the Little Engine that Could flying across the sky making the Milky Way.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かわ</p> <p id='words'>河川(かせん): rivers<br>運河(うんが): canal<br>河(かわ): river, stream</p> <p id='readingExamples'>河 (かわ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>158</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>147</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>158</p> <p id='keyword'>overnight</p> <p id='kanji'>泊</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B38A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>overnight, water, water droplets, water pistol, white, dove</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When you stop at an inn for an <b>overnight</b> rest, all you expect is a bit of <i>water</i> for a wash and a set of clean <i>white</i> sheets to wrap your weary bones in.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Please supply a guest who stays overnight with WATER and WHITE sheets.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When I go to an OVERNIGHT party, all I need is a bit of water and some of that hard white. (crack). (not really, but come on. much easier to recall than white sheets).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.まる、と.める</p> <p id='words'>泊(はく): counter for nights of a stay<br>宿泊(しゅくはく): lodging<br>泊まる(とまる): stay at (e.g. hotel)<br>泊める(とめる): stay</p> <p id='readingExamples'>泊まる (と.まる), 泊める (と.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>159</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>148</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>159</p> <p id='keyword'>lake</p> <p id='kanji'>湖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B996.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lake, water, water droplets, water pistol, uncivilized, zombie, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Water</i> . . . <i>old</i> . . . <i>flesh</i>. You have heard of legends of people being abandoned in the mountains when they had become too old to work. Well, here is a legend about people being set adrift in the <i>waters</i> of a stormy <b>lake</b> because their <i>flesh</i> had gotten too <i>old</i> to bear the burdens of life.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the lake and looking at the MOON reflected in the lake. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Water reflects the old moon in the lake.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みずうみ</p> <p id='words'>湖(みずうみ): lake</p> <p id='readingExamples'>湖 (みずうみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>160</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>149</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>160</p> <p id='keyword'>fathom</p> <p id='kanji'>測</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B8AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fathom, water, water droplets, water pistol, rule, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Connoting the measurement of the depth of <i>water</i>, the keyword <b>fathom</b> begins with the <i>water</i> primitive. To its right, we see the compound-primitive for <i>rule</i> (Frame 92) which we learned in the sense of a ""ruler"" or ""measure."" Hence, when we <i>rule</i> <i>water</i> we <b>fathom</b> it. What could be simpler? But be careful; its simplicity is deceptive. Be sure to picture yourself <b>fathoming</b> a body of <i>water</i> several hundred feet deep by using a <i>ruler</i> of gargantuan proportions.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A fathom is the unit you use when making rules about water´s depth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You can´t fathom how deep this water is. Perhaps you should use a ruler to measure it?</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はか.る</p> <p id='words'>推測(すいそく): guess, conjecture<br>測る(はかる): to measure, to weigh, to survey, to time (sound gauge estimate)<br>観測(かんそく): observation<br>測定(そくてい): measurement<br>測量(そくりょう): measurement, surveying<br>予測(よそく): prediction, estimation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>測る (はか.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>161</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>150</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>161</p> <p id='keyword'>soil</p> <p id='kanji'>土</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59C9F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>I don't like it any more than you do, but this kanji is not the pictograph it is trumped up to be: a mound of <b>soil</b> piled on the ground. All I can recommend is that you memorize it as it is. Anyway, it will be occurring with such frequency that you have almost no chance of forgetting it, even if you try.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the sense of <i>soil</i> is extended to that of <i>ground</i> because of its connection with the kanji for the same (Frame 554). From there it also takes the added meanings of <i>dirt</i> and <i>land</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened soil to claim his place as king.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ド、ト</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つち</p> <p id='words'>国土(こくど): realm<br>土産(どさん): product of the land<br>土台(どだい): foundation, base, basis<br>土手(どて): embankment, bank<br>土俵(どひょう): arena<br>土木(どぼく): public works<br>土曜(どよう): Saturday<br>風土(ふうど): natural features, topography, climate, spiritual features<br>領土(りょうど): dominion, territory, possession<br>土(つち): earth, soil<br>土地(とち): plot of land, lot, soil<br>土産(みやげ): product of the land<br>お土産(おみやげ): souvenir<br>土曜日(どようび): Saturday</p> <p id='readingExamples'>土木 (どぼく), 国土 (こくど), 粘土 (ねんど), 土 (つち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>162</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>151</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>162</p> <p id='keyword'>spit</p> <p id='kanji'>吐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59090.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>spit, mouth, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We have here a rather small <i>mouth</i> (it is always compressed when set on the left) next to a much larger piece of <i>dirt</i>. It is not hard to imagine what you might do if you got a <i>mouth</i> full of <i>dirt</i>. As least I know what I would do: <b>spit</b> it out as fast and far as I could!</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The only things that come out of my MOUTH and onto the GROUND are spit and vomit. Everything else (words, song) floats on the air.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>SPIT goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ト</p> <p id='kunYomi'>は.く、つ.く</p> <p id='words'>吐く(つく): to breathe, to tell (lies), to vomit, to disgorge<br>吐き気(はきけ): nausea, sickness in the stomach<br>吐く(はく): breathe, tell (lies), vomit</p> <p id='readingExamples'>吐く (は.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>163</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>152</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>163</p> <p id='keyword'>pressure</p> <p id='kanji'>圧</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59CA7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pressure, cliff, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>One of the things that causes the erosion of <i>soil</i> is the excessive <b>pressure</b> of the top<i>soil</i> on the lower <i>soil</i>. This can be caused by any number of things from heavy rainfall to heavy buildings to the absence of sufficient deep-rooted vegetation to hold the layers together. Here we see a steep <i>cliff</i> without a tree in sight. The <b>slightest</b> pressure on it will cause a landslide, which, with a little help from your imagination, you will be able to see happening in this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>For physics people: p = F/A (p:pressure, F:Force, A:Area). Where the force is from the immensity of the cliff. The area on the cliff is covered by soil. So the equation becomes p = F/A = cliff/soil which preserves the position of the primitives.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>アツ、エン、オウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.す、へ.す、おさ.える、お.さえる</p> <p id='words'>圧迫(あっぱく): pressure, coercion, oppression<br>圧力(あつりょく): stress, pressure<br>抑圧(よくあつ): check, restraint, oppression, suppression<br>圧縮(あっしゅく): compression, condensation, pressure<br>気圧(きあつ): atmospheric pressure<br>血圧(けつあつ): blood pressure</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>164</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>153</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>164</p> <p id='keyword'>cape</p> <p id='kanji'>埼</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59FBC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cape, soil, dirt, ground, strange, large, St. Bernard, street, nail, spike, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>cape</b> pictured here is a jut of <i>land</i> like <b>Cape</b> Cod. The <i>soil</i> on the left tells us we have to do with <i>land</i>, and the <i>strange</i> on the right tells us it is a <b><i>cape</i></b> where unusual things go on. Put a haunted house on it, an eerie sky overhead, and a howling wind rustling through the trees, and you have yourself a picture of <b>Cape</b> <i>Strange</i> (or, if you prefer, <b>Cape</b> <i>Odd</i>).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Cape Cod ""odd"" is a land where odd=strange things happen.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さき、さい、みさき</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>埼 (さい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>165</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>154</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>165</p> <p id='keyword'>hedge</p> <p id='kanji'>垣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59EA3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hedge, soil, dirt, ground, span, one, ceiling, sun, day, one, floor, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>hedge</b> depicted in this frame is the miraculous <b>hedge</b> of briar roses that completely <i>spanned</i> the castle <i>grounds</i> in which Sleeping Beauty lay for a hundred years, so that none but her predestined beloved could find his way through it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The HEDGE of roses growing from the castle grounds fully spanned the castle walls.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かき</p> <p id='words'>垣根(かきね): hedge</p> <p id='readingExamples'>垣 (かき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>167</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>155</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>167</p> <p id='keyword'>squared jewel</p> <p id='kanji'>圭</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59CAD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>square jewel, ivy, soil, dirt, ground, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Now I am going to do something unusual. The character in this frame is going to get one meaning and the primitive another, with no relation at all between the two. In time, I hope you will see how helpful this is. The kanji key word, <b>square jewel</b>, depicts a mammoth precious stone, several feet high, made by piling up large heaps of <i>soil</i> on top of one another. Not something you would want to present your betrothed on your wedding day, but a good image for remembering this rare character, used chiefly in personal names nowadays.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we shall use this character to mean <i>ivy</i>, that creepy vegetation that covers the surface of the <i>ground</i> to form a sort of ""second"" <i>ground</i> that can get somewhat tricky to walk on without tripping.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Piling SOIL upon SOIL for aeons is how SQUARE JEWELS are formed deep in the earth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>How would you stop someone stealing your biggest square jewel? Bury it deep in the soil under ground. Then plant ivy to mark the spot.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ、ケ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>168</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>156</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>168</p> <p id='keyword'>seal</p> <p id='kanji'>封</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B081.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>seal, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, glue, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of the key word <b>seal</b> as referring to a letter you have written and are preparing to close. Instead of using the traditional wax <b>seal</b>, you <i>glue</i> a sprig of <i>ivy</i> on the outside. In this way the elements <i>ivy</i> and <i>glue</i> give you a curious and memorable way to <b>seal</b> your secret letters.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A bit of ivy glued to a letter can make a lovely SEAL when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>フウ、ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>同封(どうふう): enclosure (e.g. in a letter)<br>封(ふう): seal<br>封鎖(ふうさ): blockade, freezing (funds)<br>封建(ほうけん): feudalistic<br>封筒(ふうとう): envelope</p> <p id='readingExamples'>封鎖 (ふうさ), 封書 (ふうしょ), 密封 (みっぷう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>169</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>157</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>169</p> <p id='keyword'>horizon</p> <p id='kanji'>涯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B6AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>english channel</p> <p id='constituent'>horizon, water, water droplets, water pistol, cliff, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>After seeing a constant <b>horizon</b> of <i>water</i>, <i>water</i> everywhere for months at sea, could there be anything more delightful to the eyes than to look astern and see the <i>ivy</i>-clad <i>cliffs</i> of land on a new <b>horizon</b>? Of course, you'd need the eyes of a stellar telescope to recognize that the vegetation was in fact <i>ivy</i>, but the phrase ""<i>ivy</i>-clad <i>cliffs</i>"" has such a nice ring to it that we won't worry about such details.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Try to reverse Heisig´s story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. 	"<p id='id'>170</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>158</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>170</p> <p id='keyword'>Buddhist temple</p> <p id='kanji'>寺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AFBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You have heard of people ""attaching"" themselves to a particular sect? Here is your chance to take that metaphor literally and imagine some fellow walking into a <b>Buddhist temple</b> with a fervent resolve to attach himself to the place. Since there is plenty of unused <i>land</i> around the precincts, he simply picks out a suitable patch, brushes the soles of his feet with <i>glue</i>, steps down firmly, and so joins the <b>Buddhist temple</b> as a ""permanent member.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To be allowed to join the Buddhist temple, imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the soil for a long time in a measurement of his resolve.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>てら</p> <p id='words'>寺院(じいん): temple<br>寺(てら): temple</p> <p id='readingExamples'>寺 (てら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>171</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>159</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>171</p> <p id='keyword'>time</p> <p id='kanji'>時</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69982.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>time, sun, day, Buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""What is <b>time</b>?"" asked St. Augustine in his memoirs. ""Ask me not, and I know. Ask me, and I cannot tell you."" Here we have the kanji's answer to that perennial riddle. <b>Time</b> is a <i>sun</i> rising over a <i>Buddhist temple</i>. It sounds almost like a Zen kōan whose repetition might yield some deep secret to the initiated. At any rate, imagining a monk seated in meditation pondering it might help us remember the character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it´s time to get up.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In ancient Japan, TIME of ´´day´´ was announced at the ´´buddhist temples´´. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the time of day.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とき、-どき</p> <p id='words'>何時(いつ): when, how soon<br>何時か(いつか): sometime, some day<br>何時でも(いつでも): (at) any time, always, at all times, never (neg), whenever<br>何時の間にか(いつのまにか): before one knows, unnoticed, unawares<br>何時も(いつも): always, usually, every time, never (with neg. verb)<br>時刻表(じこくひょう): table, diagram, chart, timetable, schedule<br>時差(じさ): time difference<br>時折(ときおり): sometimes<br>一時(いちじ): one hour, short time, once, temporarily, at one time<br>時間割(じかんわり): timetable, schedule<br>時期(じき): time, season, period<br>時刻(じこく): instant, time, moment<br>時速(じそく): speed (per hour)<br>当時(とうじ): at that time, in those days<br>同時(どうじ): simultaneous(ly), concurrent, same time, synchronous<br>時(とき): time, hour, occasion, moment<br>日時(にちじ): date and time<br>臨時(りんじ): temporary, special, extraordinary<br>時代(じだい): age, period, generation<br>時間(じかん): time<br>時々(ときどき): sometimes<br>時計(とけい): watch, clock</p> <p id='readingExamples'>時 (とき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>172</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>160</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>172</p> <p id='keyword'>level</p> <p id='kanji'>均</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59D87.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>level, soil, dirt, ground, ladle, drop, drop2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>level</b> this key word refers to is not the carpenter's tool but rather the even surface of a thing. It pictures <i>soil</i> being scooped up into a <i>ladle</i> and then made <b>level</b> (apparently because one is measuring <i>soil</i>). The excess <i>drops of soil</i> are brushed off the top, which accounts for the added <i>drop</i> at the <i>ladle's</i> edge.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Soil is scooped up into a ladel. The extra drop is brushed off to make it level.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil fr0m the ladle falling out onto the ground when you level it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なら.す</p> <p id='words'>均衡(きんこう): equilibrium, balance<br>平均(ならし): equilibrium, balance, average, mean<br>平均(へいきん): equilibrium, balance, average, mean</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>173</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>161</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>173</p> <p id='keyword'>fire</p> <p id='kanji'>火</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E781AB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fire</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Just as sitting before a <b>fire</b> enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames, this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of <b>fire</b> you want to see. It no longer makes a good pictograph, but I invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form - first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there - to see what you can come up with. Everything from matchbooks to cigarette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here. No doubt you, too, will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* To avoid confusion later on, it is best to keep to the meaning of a <i>fireplace</i> (or <i>hearth</i>) or a raging <i>conflagration</i> like a forest fire for this kanji's primitive meaning. Another primitive element for <i>fire</i>, based on this one, is written as 4 small drops and will mean <i>flames</i>, <i>cauldron</i>, <i>cooking fire</i>, or an <i>oven fire</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A tepee getting shot at by fire arrows.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひ、-び、ほ-</p> <p id='words'>火傷(かしょう): burn, scald<br>火星(かせい): Mars (planet)<br>火曜(かよう): Tuesday<br>火燵(こたつ): table with heater, (orig) charcoal brazier in a floor well<br>下火(したび): burning low, waning, declining<br>焚火(たきび): (open) fire<br>点火(てんか): ignition, lighting, set fire to<br>火花(ひばな): spark<br>防火(ぼうか): fire prevention, fire fighting, fire proof<br>火口(かこう): crater<br>火災(かさい): conflagration, fire<br>火山(かざん): volcano<br>花火(はなび): fireworks<br>噴火(ふんか): eruption<br>火傷(やけど): burn, scald<br>火事(かじ): fire<br>火(ひ): fire<br>火曜日(かようび): Tuesday</p> <p id='readingExamples'>火 (ひ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>174</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>162</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>174</p> <p id='keyword'>inflammation</p> <p id='kanji'>炎</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7828E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inflammation, fire, fire2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A <i>fire</i> belongs IN the <i>hearth</i>, not OVER it. When the <i>fire</i> spreads to the rest of the house, we have an <b>inflamed</b> house. And as with any <b>inflammation</b>&nbsp;- including those that attack our bodies - the danger is always that it might spread if not checked. This is the sense behind the reduplication of element for <i>fire</i>, one atop the other.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To fight fire with fire would just inflame a situation.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An inflammation can often feel like FIRE upon FIRE burning.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほのお</p> <p id='words'>炎(ほのお): flame, blaze</p> <p id='readingExamples'>炎 (ほのお)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>175</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>163</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>175</p> <p id='keyword'>anxiety</p> <p id='kanji'>煩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E785A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>anxiety, fire, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The existential condition of <b>anxiety</b> that arises from the inevitable frustration of our worldly passions is contained in this character. The <i>head</i> is set <i>afire</i>, causing deep torment of spirit (and a whopper of a headache).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An anxiety feels like FIRE in the HEAD.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Many performers get ""Michael Jackson anxiety"" wherein they fear their head will catch on fire.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン、ボン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わずら.う、わずら.わす</p> <p id='words'>煩わしい(わずらわしい): troublesome, annoying, complicated</p> <p id='readingExamples'>煩雑 (はんざつ), 煩う (わずら.う), 煩わす (わずら.わす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>176</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>164</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>176</p> <p id='keyword'>thin</p> <p id='kanji'>淡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B7A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>thin, water, water droplets, water pistol, inflammation, fire, fire2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The primitives in this kanji read: <i>water</i> . . . <i>inflammation</i>. Taking <i>inflammation</i> in its medical sense, the first <i>water</i>-related <i>inflammation</i> that pops into mind is dehydration, the principal symptom of which is that it makes one shrivel up and look very, very <b>thin</b>. If that is hard to remember, try thinking it backwards: a very <b>thin</b> chap passes by and you imagine him suffering from (being <i>inflamed</i> with) dehydration (hence the element for <i>water</i>).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Drink water and burn twice as many calories as you eat... you´ll definitely get thin. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being burned from above and below...
