	"<p id='id'>177</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>165</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>177</p> <p id='keyword'>lamp</p> <p id='kanji'>灯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E781AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lamp, fire, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Since it is very hard to read by the <i>fireplace</i> without going blind from the flickering of the flames or burning up from the heat, our ancestors invented a way to <i>nail</i> down a bit of that <i>fire</i>, just enough to light up the text of their evening newspapers and no more. Voilà! The <b>lamp</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A lamp is fire you can hang from a nail.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひ、ほ-、ともしび、とも.す、あかり</p> <p id='words'>灯(ともしび): light<br>蛍光灯(けいこうとう): fluorescent lamp, person who is slow to react<br>灯台(とうだい): lighthouse<br>灯油(とうゆ): lamp oil, kerosene<br>灯(ひ): light<br>電灯(でんとう): light</p> <p id='readingExamples'>灯 (ひ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>178</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>166</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>178</p> <p id='keyword'>farm</p> <p id='kanji'>畑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79591.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>farm, fire, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Looking at the primitives, a <i>fireplace</i> and a <i>rice field</i>, we find the essential ingredients for a <b>farm</b>: a warm <i>hearth</i> to sit by at night, and a well-plowed <i>field</i> to grow one's crops in by day.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When creating a farm, the prospective farmer must first set fire to the forest to clear the ground. Only then can he plow the fields. Fire before fields to make a farm.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'></p> <p id='kunYomi'>はた、はたけ、-ばたけ</p> <p id='words'>畑(はたけ): field</p> <p id='readingExamples'>畑 (はた), 畑 (はたけ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>179</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>167</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>179</p> <p id='keyword'>disaster</p> <p id='kanji'>災</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E781BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>disaster, stream, flood, fire</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Of all of nature's <b>disasters</b>, this kanji picks out two of the worst: <i>floods</i> and <i>fires</i>. To recall the disposition of the elements, think of nature's solution to nature's own problem: a great <i>flood</i> pouring down over a great forest <i>fire</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>What a disaster! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don´t know about Japan, but here in Australia, flooding rivers and bushfires are the most common natural disasters.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わざわ.い</p> <p id='words'>災害(さいがい): calamity, disaster, misfortune<br>戦災(せんさい): war damage<br>天災(てんさい): natural calamity, disaster<br>火災(かさい): conflagration, fire<br>災難(さいなん): calamity, misfortune</p> <p id='readingExamples'>災い (わざわ.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>180</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>168</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>180</p> <p id='keyword'>ashes</p> <p id='kanji'>灰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E781B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ashes, cliff, fire</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji for <b>ashes</b> naturally includes the primitive for <i>fire</i>, or more specifically, a <i>fireplace</i>. Now what do you do with that bucket of <b>ashes</b> you have just cleaned out of the <i>fireplace</i>? You walk to the edge of a <i>cliff</i> and tip it upside down, watching as they are swept away in the wind like a swarm of gray mosquitoes. Thus the <i>fire</i>, once it has turned to <b>ashes</b>, ends up at the bottom of the <i>cliff</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The fire underneath the cliff will eventually turn everything above to ashes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Scene from ""The Big Lebowski"" : Walter scatters Donny´s ashes, but a wind blows much of the ashes into ""The Dude"" Lebowski´s face. Upset, The Dude lashes out at Walter. Walter apologizes and hugs The Dude, before suggesting ""Fuck it, man. Let´s go bowling."" I bet you that The Dude wanted to cremate (fire) Walter right there and then, at the top of the cliff! (thanks Elktapestry).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はい</p> <p id='words'>灰(あく): puckery juice<br>灰皿(はいさら): ashtray<br>灰(はい): ash<br>灰色(はいいろ): grey, ashen<br>灰皿(はいざら): ashtray</p> <p id='readingExamples'>灰 (はい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>181</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>169</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>181</p> <p id='keyword'>spot</p> <p id='kanji'>点</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E782B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>spot, fortune-telling, magic wand, augury, mouth, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>If you look into the flickering of a <i>fire</i> for a long time and then turn aside, you will see <b>spots</b> before your eyes. Although nobody ever thought of such a thing before - as least as far as know, they didn't - imagine using those <b>spots</b> as a technique for <i>fortune-telling</i>. The old witch sits before her <i>cauldron</i> and watches the <b>spots</b> that show up when she turns to look at you, and from that <i>tells your fortune</i>. Think of it as a kind of <b>spot</b>-check on your future.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You have to stimulate the G-spot with your magic wand in order to get her on fire. 	"<p id='id'>182</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>170</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>182</p> <p id='keyword'>illuminate</p> <p id='kanji'>照</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E785A7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>illuminate, shining, sun, day, summon, seduce, sword, dagger, mouth, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Although the range of possible meanings that the kanji for <b>illuminate</b> can have is about as rich as the connotations of the English word, we need to focus on just one of them: to make something <i>shine</i>. If you glaze a pot and put it into the <i>oven</i> to <i>fire</i> it, you in fact <i>illuminate</i> it. Hence the kanji for <b>illuminate</b> compares the kanji for <i>shining</i> with the primitive element for the <i>oven's fire</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>SHINING FLAMES illuminate!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The sun was seduced to give us fire, by which we illuminate the night.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>て.る、て.らす、て.れる</p> <p id='words'>参照(さんしょう): reference, consultation, consultation<br>照合(しょうごう): collation, comparison<br>照明(しょうめい): illumination<br>照り返す(てりかえす): to reflect, to throw back light<br>対照(たいしょう): contrast, antithesis, comparison<br>照らす(てらす): shine on, illuminate<br>照る(てる): shine</p> <p id='readingExamples'>照らす (て.らす), 照る (て.る), 照れる (て.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>183</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>171</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>183</p> <p id='keyword'>fish</p> <p id='kanji'>魚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9AD9A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fish, bound up, rice field, brains, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The composition of this kanji shows three elements, which we list in the order of their writing: <i>bound up</i> . . . <i>rice field</i> . . . <i>cooking fire</i>. Not much to work with at first sight. But we can join them together by thinking of a three-part story: first a <b>fish</b> is caught and <i>bound up</i> on a line with its unfortunate school-mates; when the fisherman gets home, he cuts off the head and tosses it, with the entrails, out into the <i>rice fields</i> for fertilizer; and the rest he sets in a skillet over a <i>cooking fire</i> for his supper.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Bind that FISH and cook his brains! Yarhh!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うお、さかな、-ざかな</p> <p id='words'>魚(うお): fish<br>金魚(きんぎょ): goldfish<br>魚(さかな): fish</p> <p id='readingExamples'>魚 (うお), 魚 (さかな)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>184</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>172</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>184</p> <p id='keyword'>fishing</p> <p id='kanji'>漁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BC81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fishing, water, water droplets, water pistol, fish, bound up, rice field, brains, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To the story we have just made about <i>fish</i>, this kanji for the profession of <b>fishing</b> adds yet another element BEFORE the others: namely the <i>water</i>, where the fish was happily at home before being caught, disemboweled, and eaten. Be sure to get a clear image of the <i>water</i>&nbsp;when you put it all together.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You need WATER and FISH for fishing.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you are confusing this with angling like me, take fishing to mean not the act of catching a fish but the act of being a fish not living but fishing (i.e. in the water).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギョ、リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あさ.る</p> <p id='words'>漁船(ぎょせん): fishing boat<br>漁村(ぎょそん): fishing village<br>漁業(ぎょぎょう): fishing (industry)<br>漁師(りょうし): fisherman</p> <p id='readingExamples'>漁業 (ぎょぎょう), 漁船 (ぎょせん), 漁村 (ぎょそん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>185</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>173</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>185</p> <p id='keyword'>ri</p> <p id='kanji'>里</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9878C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ri, computer, rice field, brains, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>That's right - a <b><i>ri</i></b>. Don't bother looking it up in your English dictionary; it's a Japanese word for measuring distances. One <b><i>ri</i></b> is about 4 kilometers or 2.5 miles. The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used. Atop we see the <i>rice field</i>, and below the element for <i>land</i>. Those four sections you see in the <i>rice field</i> (and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14) are actually measurements of <i>land</i>, much the same as farm-sections in the United States have given us the notion of a ""country mile."" The <i>land</i> division based on the size of a <i>rice field</i> is called a <b><i>ri</i></b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* To get a more concrete primitive meaning for this kanji, we shall refer to it as a <i>computer</i>, a meaning deriving from the kanji for <i>logic</i>, which we will meet in Lesson 12.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hint: Heisig makes here a severe disservice to everyone by using a weird keyword for this character. You´ll save a lot (and I mean, a whole lot) of trouble later by giving it instead its intended meaning: House of the Parents.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>リ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さと</p> <p id='words'>郷里(きょうり): birth-place, home town</p> <p id='readingExamples'>里 (さと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>186</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>174</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>186</p> <p id='keyword'>black</p> <p id='kanji'>黒</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9BB92.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>black, computer, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Like most things electrical, a <i>computer</i>, too, can overheat. Here it is used to mark off the <i>dirt</i> with <i>black</i> lines for a foot ballgame (played, I presume, on a white field).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Theres BLACK on the GROUND...most likely someone spilt some black ink.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Anyone who has worked with laserjet ink cartridges will know the black ink looks like powdered dirt.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すみ</p> <p id='words'>墨(すみ): ink</p> <p id='readingExamples'>墨 (すみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>190</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>178</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>190</p> <p id='keyword'>rin</p> <p id='kanji'>厘</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58E98.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rin, cliff, computer</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>No doubt you will find it in your heart to forgive me for forcing yet another Japanese word on you in this frame. It is not the last time it will happen in this book, but I can assure you they are used only when absolutely necessary. One <b><i>rin</i></b> is equal to about 1/1000 of a yen - or rather was worth that much when it still made economic sense to mint them. While inflation took its toll on this kanji as a monetary unit, it survived with the not at all surprising sense of something ""very, very tiny."" The kanji shows a <i>cliff</i> with a <i>computer</i> under it, apparently because it has been pushed over into the abyss by someone fed up with the thing. The total market value of one home <i>computer</i> that has fallen over rock and bramble for several hundred feet: about one <b><i>rin</i></b>!</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it´s worth less than a rin.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A computer dropped off of a cliff would be worth about 1 RIN.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>191</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>179</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>191</p> <p id='keyword'>bury</p> <p id='kanji'>埋</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59F8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bury, soil, dirt, ground, computer</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When we speak of <b>burying</b> something (or someone, for that matter), we usually mean putting them under <i>ground</i>. Only here, we are <b>burying</b> our beloved <i>computer</i> that has served us so well these past years. Behind us a choir chants the ""Dies irae, dies illa"" and there is much wailing and grief among the bystanders as they pass by to shovel a little <i>dirt</i> into what will be its final resting place. R.I.P.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You can´t bury computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I used SOIL to BURY my COMPUTER.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>マイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>う.める、う.まる、う.もれる、うず.める、うず.まる、い.ける</p> <p id='words'>埋まる(うずまる): to be buried, to be surrounded, to overflow, to be filled<br>埋め込む(うめこむ): to bury<br>埋蔵(まいぞう): buried property, treasure trove<br>埋める(うめる): bury (e.g. one´s face in hands)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>埋まる (う.まる), 埋める (う.める), 埋もれる (う.もれる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>192</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>180</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>192</p> <p id='keyword'>same</p> <p id='kanji'>同</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5908C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>same, monks, hood, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The primitives in this kanji show us <i>one</i> and <i>mouth</i> under a <i>hood</i>. Let us take the key word to connote the <b>sameness</b> that characterizes the life in community of the monk. They all have the <b>same</b> habits, including the ""habit"" they wear on their backs. Here we see the monk's <i>cowl</i>, drawn down over the eyes so that all you can see when you look at him is a <i>mouth</i>. But since monks also speak their prayers in common, it is but a short step to think of <i>one mouth</i> under a <i>hood</i> as the kanji for the <b>sameness</b> of monastic life.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this will mean <i>monks</i> dressed in a common habit.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the same, you can just see ONE MOUTH and very little else.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おな.じ</p> <p id='words'>一同(いちどう): all present, all concerned, all of us<br>同い年(おないどし): of the same age<br>混同(こんどう): confusion, mixing, merger<br>同(どう): the same, the said, ibid.<br>同意(どうい): agreement, consent, same meaning, same opinion, approval<br>同感(どうかん): agreement, same opinion, same feeling, sympathy, concurrence<br>同級(どうきゅう): the same grade, same class<br>同居(どうきょ): living together<br>同志(どうし): same mind, comrade, kindred soul<br>同士(どうし): fellow, companion, comrade<br>同情(どうじょう): sympathy, compassion, sympathize, pity, feel for<br>同調(どうちょう): sympathy, agree with, alignment, tuning<br>同等(どうとう): equality, equal, same rights, same rank<br>同封(どうふう): enclosure (e.g. in a letter)<br>同盟(どうめい): alliance, union, league<br>共同(きょうどう): cooperation, association, collaboration, joint<br>合同(ごうどう): combination, incorporation, union, amalgamation, fusion, congruence<br>同一(どういつ): identity, sameness, similarity, equality, fairness<br>同格(どうかく): the same rank, equality, apposition<br>同時(どうじ): simultaneous(ly), concurrent, same time, synchronous<br>同様(どうよう): identical, equal to, same (kind), like<br>同僚(どうりょう): coworker, colleague, associate<br>同じ(おなじ): same, identical, equal, uniform, equivalent, similar, common (origin), changeless</p> <p id='readingExamples'>同じ (おな.じ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>193</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>181</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>193</p> <p id='keyword'>den</p> <p id='kanji'>洞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B49E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>den, water, water droplets, water pistol, same, monks, hood, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word <b>den</b> refers to an animal lair hollowed out in the side of a mountain. Now if we keep to the image of the monastic life as an image for <i>same</i>, we can picture a <b>den</b> of wild beasts dressed up in habits and living the common life in a mountain cavern. To bring in the element of <i>water</i> we need only give them a sacred ""puddle"" in the center of their <b>den</b>, the focus of all their pious attentions.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>All the animals in the den share the same water.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Den and ""cave"" also make me think of a monk´s cell. Monks take vows of silence and fast. So a den is where you´d find nothing but water (to drink) and a monk.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほら</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>洞 (ほら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>194</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>182</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>194</p> <p id='keyword'>trunk</p> <p id='kanji'>胴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E883B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>trunk, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, same, monks, hood, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The word <b>trunk</b> refers to the <i>part of the body</i> that is left when you have ""<b>truncated</b>"" all the limbs. I can hardly think of any reason for doing so, unless one were lumberjacking corpses and needed to have them all properly pruned and made the <i>same</i> so they could be floated downstream without causing a <i>body</i>-jam.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A trunk, a trunk // The body of a monk // The body of a monk in a trunk, a trunk.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. 	"<p id='id'>195</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>183</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>195</p> <p id='keyword'>yonder</p> <p id='kanji'>向</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59091.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>yonder, alien, drop, helmet, hood, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Something referred to as ""over <b>yonder</b>"" is usually far off in the distance and barely within sight - like a wee <i>drop</i> in the distance - and is usually an expression used in giving directions or pointing something out. Hence this kanji begins with a <i>drop</i>. Then we find a sort of transparent <i>helmet</i> with no eyes or nose, but only a prominent <i>mouth</i> under it, obviously an extraterrestrial. And what is it jabbering on about with its <i>mouth</i> open like that? Why, about his spaceship way over <b>yonder</b> with its fuel tank on empty.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Look over yonder ! That tiny dot is robin hood at the mouth of his secret cave !</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There was an old woman named Wanda,// Who wanted to make herself blonder.// She covered her くち// With a glass hood from Gucci// And dropped some hair dye on from yonder.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>む.く、む.い、-む.き、む.ける、-む.け、む.かう、む.かい、む.こう、む.こう-、むこ、むか.い</p> <p id='words'>意向(いこう): intention, idea, inclination<br>向上(こうじょう): elevation, rise, improvement, advancement, progress<br>志向(しこう): intention, aim<br>動向(どうこう): trend, tendency, movement, attitude<br>一向(ひたすら): earnestly<br>日向(ひなた): sunny place, in the sun<br>向かう(むかう): to face, to go towards<br>向き(むき): direction, situation, exposure, aspect, suitability<br>向け(むけ): for ~, oriented towards ~<br>傾向(けいこう): tendency, trend, inclination<br>方向(ほうこう): direction, course, way<br>向かい(むかい): facing, opposite, across the street, other side<br>向う(むかう): to face, go towards<br>向く(むく): to face<br>向ける(むける): turn towards, point<br>向こう(むこう): beyond, over there, opposite direction, the other party</p> <p id='readingExamples'>向かう (む.かう), 向く (む.く), 向ける (む.ける), 向こう (む.こう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>196</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>184</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>196</p> <p id='keyword'>esteem</p> <p id='kanji'>尚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B09A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>esteem, small, little, alien, glass canopy, hood, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Above we see the primitive for <i>little</i> attached to one of those <i>glass canopies</i> you might use to display a family heirloom. The <i>littleness</i> is important, because what is in fact on display is the shrunken, stuffed, and mounted <i>mouth</i> of an <b>esteemed</b> ancestor. We may be used to <b>esteeming</b> the words our forebears leave behind, but here we also <b>esteem</b> the very <i>mouth</i> that spoke them. I leave it to you to imagine a suitable place in your room for displaying such an unusual conversation piece.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Remember that scene from Star Wars, where Luke is wearing that helmet that only his mouth could see, and was swinging at that little thing buzzing around the room? 	"<p id='id'>197</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>185</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>197</p> <p id='keyword'>character</p> <p id='kanji'>字</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AD97.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>character, house, child</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here is the character for <b>character</b> itself. Not just kanji, but any written <b>character</b> from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet. It shows us simply a <i>child</i> in a <i>house</i>. But let us take advantage of the double-meaning of the key word to note that just as a <i>child</i> born to a Japanese <i>house</i> is given <b>characters</b> for its name, so it is also stamped with the <b>character</b> of those who raise it from infancy on.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father? 	"<p id='id'>198</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>186</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>198</p> <p id='keyword'>guard</p> <p id='kanji'>守</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE88.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>guard, house, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The notion of <b>guarding</b> something easily brings to mind the image of someone standing <b>guard</b>, like the royal soldiers in front of Buckingham Palace or the Pope's Swiss <b>Guard</b>. The whole idea of hiring <b>guards</b> is that they should stick like <i>glue</i> to your <i>house</i> to protect it from unwanted prowlers. So go ahead and <i>glue</i> a <b>guard</b> to your <i>house</i> in imagination.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A GUARD is usually ""glued"" to the house he watches.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A guard provides a measure of security to those under a roof.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ、ス</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まも.る、まも.り、もり、-もり、かみ</p> <p id='words'>守衛(しゅえい): security guard, doorkeeper<br>守備(しゅび): defense<br>保守(ほしゅ): conservative, maintaining<br>守る(まもる): protect, obey, guard, abide (by the rules)<br>留守番(るすばん): care-taking, caretaker, house-watching<br>留守(るす): being away, be out (of one´s home or office)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>守備 (しゅび), 保守 (ほしゅ), 攻守 (こうしゅ), 守る (まも.る), 守 (もり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>199</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>187</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>199</p> <p id='keyword'>perfect</p> <p id='kanji'>完</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>perfect, house, beginning, two, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In order not to confuse the key word <b>perfect</b> with others nearly synonymous in meaning, pull it apart to have a look at its native Latin roots. <i>Per-factum</i> suggests something so ""thoroughly made or done"" that nothing more needs to be added to it. Now look at the kanji, which does something similar. We see a <i>house</i> that has been made <b>perfectly</b> from its <i>beginnings</i> in the foundation to the roof on the top. Now return to frame 101 and make sure not to confuse this key word with the kanji for <i>complete</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Make the perfect impression in the beginning by removing your shoes upon entering a Japanese home.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the beginning, Adam and Eve had a home in Eden. It was perfect.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>完璧(かんぺき): perfection, completeness, flawless<br>完成(かんせい): complete, completion, perfection, accomplishment<br>完全(かんぜん): perfection, completeness<br>完了(かんりょう): completion, conclusion</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>200</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>188</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>200</p> <p id='keyword'>proclaim</p> <p id='kanji'>宣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AEA3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>proclaim, house, span, one, ceiling, sun, day, one, floor, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Under the primitive for <i>house</i> we meet the kanji for <i>span</i>. Think of the key word in its religious sense of missionary preaching: ""<b>proclaiming</b> the good news to all nations"" and ""shouting it from the <i>housetops</i>."" That should be enough to help you remember this simple kanji, used in fact both for traditional missionary work as well as for one of its contemporary replacements: advertising.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I heard young Muslims have to memorise the Koran and proclaim it aloud as a kind of rite of passage. 	"<p id='id'>201</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>189</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>201</p> <p id='keyword'>wee hours</p> <p id='kanji'>宵</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AEB5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wee hours, house, resemblance, spark, candle, small, little, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As the key word hints, the kanji in this frame refers to the late evening or early morning hours, well after one should be in bed asleep. It does this by picturing a <i>house</i> with a <i>candle</i> in it. The reason is obvious: whoever is living there is ""burning the <i>candle</i> at both ends,"" and working night after night into the <b>wee hours</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means ""early evening"", not ""wee hours"" [Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 ""but of course"" -- what the hell???). Oh well.] ""Every house lights candles in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the wee hours"". 	"<p id='id'>202</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>190</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>202</p> <p id='keyword'>relax</p> <p id='kanji'>安</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE89.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>relax, house, woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To be told that the place of the <i>woman</i> is in the <i>house</i> may not sit well with modern thought, but like all cultural habits the Chinese characters bear the birthmarks of their age. So indulge yourself in a Norman Rockwell image of <b>relaxing</b> after a hard day's work: the scruffy and weary <i>woman</i> of the <i>house</i> slouched asleep in the living room chair, her hair in curlers and a duster lying in her lap.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive... well... if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. 	"<p id='id'>204</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>192</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>204</p> <p id='keyword'>draw near</p> <p id='kanji'>寄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AF84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>draw near, house, strange, large, St. Bernard, can, street, nail, spike, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let the idea of <b>drawing near</b> suggest something dangerous or eerie that one approaches with fear and trembling. Here we see a <i>strange house</i> - perhaps the haunted <i>House</i> of Usher that Edgar Allen Poe immortalized, or the enchanted Gingerbread <i>House</i> that lured Hansel and Gretel to <b>draw near</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The strange house has a sign saying ""DRAW NEAR"" in its window, instead of a ´Beware´ sign. It must be a trick!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The house is very strange. The characters draw near to one another for protection against the unknown.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よ.る、-よ.り、よ.せる</p> <p id='words'>押し寄せる(おしよせる): to push aside, to advance on<br>寄贈(きそう): donation, presentation<br>寄与(きよ): contribution, service<br>立ち寄る(たちよる): to stop by, to drop in for a short visit<br>年寄り(としより): old people, the aged<br>取り寄せる(とりよせる): to order, to send away for<br>寄こす(よこす): to send, to forward<br>寄り掛かる(よりかかる): to lean against, to recline on, to lean on, to rely on<br>片寄る(かたよる): be one-sided, partial, prejudiced, biased, lean, be inclined<br>寄付(きふ): contribution, donation<br>近寄る(ちかよる): approach, draw near<br>寄せる(よせる): collect, gather, add, put aside<br>寄る(よる): drop in, stop by</p> <p id='readingExamples'>寄せる (よ.せる), 寄る (よ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>205</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>193</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>205</p> <p id='keyword'>wealth</p> <p id='kanji'>富</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AF8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wealth, house, wealth, one, ceiling, mouth, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we have the original character on which the primitive element for <b>wealth</b> is based. In keeping with the story introduced back then, note how all the <b>wealth</b> is kept under the roof of the same <i>house</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Remember Ducktales? That rich duck had that room in his house where he kept all the wealth! He had so much in that house you could even swim in it!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>フ、フウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.む、とみ</p> <p id='words'>富(とみ): wealth, fortune<br>富む(とむ): to be rich, to become rich<br>富豪(ふごう): wealthy person, millionaire<br>豊富(ほうふ): abundance, wealth, plenty, bounty</p> <p id='readingExamples'>富強 (ふきょう), 富裕 (ふゆう), 貧富 (ひんぷ), 富む (と.む), 富 (とみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>206</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>194</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>206</p> <p id='keyword'>savings</p> <p id='kanji'>貯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>savings, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, house, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>9</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To avoid confusing this frame with the last one, try to think of <b>savings</b> as actual money. The only difference is that our currency is not paper bills but <i>shells</i>, a not uncommon unit of exchange in older civilizations. The <i>nail</i> under the roof of the <i>house</i> points to a hiding place in the rafters on which one strings up one's <i>shells</i> for safekeeping.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>My SAVINGS plan - I nail my moneybags up in the rafters below my roof. I´m very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big mustache (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>た.める、たくわ.える</p> <p id='words'>貯蓄(ちょちく): savings<br>貯金(ちょきん): (bank) savings<br>貯蔵(ちょぞう): storage, preservation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>207</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>195</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>207</p> <p id='keyword'>tree</p> <p id='kanji'>木</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CA8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we see a pictograph of a <b>tree</b>, showing the main trunk in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke. The final two strokes sweep down in both directions to indicate the roots. Although it may look similar at first sight to the kanji for <i>water</i> (Frame 137), the order in which it is written is completely different and this affects its final appearance.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji can be used to mean <i>tree</i> or <i>wood</i>. In those cases where the last two strokes are detached from the trunk, we shall change its meaning to <i>pole</i>, or <i>wooden pole</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Pictograph of a tree.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボク、モク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>き、こ-</p> <p id='words'>木綿(きわた): cotton<br>雑木(ざつぼく): various kinds of small trees, assorted trees<br>樹木(じゅもく): trees and shrubs, arbour<br>土木(どぼく): public works<br>木曜(もくよう): Thursday<br>植木(うえき): garden shrubs, trees, potted plant<br>材木(ざいもく): lumber, timber<br>大木(たいぼく): large tree<br>並木(なみき): roadside tree, row of trees<br>木材(もくざい): lumber, timber, wood<br>木綿(もめん): cotton<br>木(き): tree, wood, timber<br>木曜日(もくようび): Thursday</p> <p id='readingExamples'>木石 (ぼくせき), 大木 (たいぼく), 土木 (どぼく), 木 (き)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>208</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>196</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>208</p> <p id='keyword'>grove</p> <p id='kanji'>林</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69E97.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grove, tree, wood, tree2, wood2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Learn this frame in connection with the next one. A <b>grove</b> is a small cluster of <i>trees</i>. Hence the simple reduplication of the kanji for <i>tree</i> gives us the <b>grove</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A grove has at least two TREEs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Two tree huggers saying that protecting the environment is grovey man...　RTK2:　リン　森林　しんりん(woods and forests).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>リン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はやし</p> <p id='words'>林業(りんぎょう): forestry<br>山林(さんりん): mountain forest, mountains and forest<br>森林(しんりん): forest, woods<br>林(はやし): woods, forest</p> <p id='readingExamples'>林 (はやし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_1</p>"

	"<p id='id'>210</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>198</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>210</p> <p id='keyword'>Japanese Judas-tree</p> <p id='kanji'>桂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A182.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>Japanese Judas tree, tree, wood, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Unless you are a botanist, you are not likely to know what a <b>Japanese Judas-tree</b> looks like, and probably never even heard of it before, but the name is sufficiently odd to make remembering it easy. Using the primitives as our guide, we define it as a <i>tree</i> with <i>ivy</i> growing down its branches in the shape of a hangman's rope.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Simple mnemonic : ""The Japanese Judas-tree is the tree on which Judas hang himself to the ivy"" (Judas the traitor of the Christian bible). Just picture Judas hanging himself, using ivy as a if it was a rope.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A tree covered in poison ivy will quickly betray you, thus the name JAPANESE JUDAS-TREE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かつら</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>211</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>199</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>211</p> <p id='keyword'>oak</p> <p id='kanji'>柏</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69F8F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>oak, tree, wood, white, dove</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji calls to mind the famous myth of the ""golden bough."" As you may recall, what made the sacred <b>oak</b> in the forest of Diana the Huntress outside of Rome ""golden"" were the <i>white</i> berries of the mistletoe that grew in the branches of the tree. When the light of the sun shone through them, they turned yellow and the branch to which they clung appeared to be made of gold. (If you don't know the story, take a break today and hunt it down in a dictionary of myth and fable. Even if you forget the kanji - which of course you won't - the story of the mistletoe and the fate it brought to Balder the Beautiful is most memorable.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The wood from oak trees can be used to make barrels in which white wine is aged. What´s more, I love white wine with an oaky flavour...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An oak tree is white, from left to right!</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ハク、ヒャク、ビャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かしわ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>212</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>200</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>212</p> <p id='keyword'>frame</p> <p id='kanji'>枠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69EA0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>frame, tree, wood, ninety, nine, baseball, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You might think of the <b>frame</b> this character refers to as the sort of <b>frame</b> we have created by drawing a dark line around this kanji and its explanation. Then think of that line as made of very thin <i>wood</i>; and finally note how each time the line bends it forms a 90° angle, thus giving us the <i>nine</i> and the <i>ten</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>wood at 90 (9 * 10) degrees.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Nine out of ten picture frames are made out of wood. 	"<p id='id'>213</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>201</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>213</p> <p id='keyword'>treetops</p> <p id='kanji'>梢</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A2A2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>treetops, tree, wood, resemblance, spark, candle, small, little, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As the days grow shorter and shorter, or so the northern European myth goes, the fear grows that the sun will take its leave of us altogether, abandoning the world to total darkness. Fixing <i>candles</i> to the branches of evergreen <i>trees</i>, it was believed, would lure the sun back (like things attracting like things), whence the custom of the lighted tree that eventually found its way into our Christmas customs. The story is a lot longer and more complex than that, but it should help to fix the image of climbing high up into the <b>treetops</b> to fix <i>candles</i> on the <i>tree</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At Christmas time, on the treetops, people used to place great big candles (Now we usually place a star instead).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you cut off the treetops, they still resemble the trees they used to be part of. 	"<p id='id'>214</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>202</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>214</p> <p id='keyword'>shelf</p> <p id='kanji'>棚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A39A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shelf, tree, wood, companion, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, moon2, month2, flesh, 2, part of the body2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>One often thinks of books as ""good <i>companions</i>,"" but here it is the <b>shelf</b> we store them on that is the <i>companion</i>. The reasons should be obvious: it is made of the same stuff, <i>wood</i>, and spends a lot more time with them than we do! Here again, be careful not to let the rationality of the explanation get in the way before you turn it into a proper story.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A shelf is a wooden companion to books.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I think of an Otaku, with a wooden shelf full of anime action figure statures, who are sadly his only companions.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たな、-だな</p> <p id='words'>戸棚(とだな): cupboard, locker, closet, wardrobe<br>棚(たな): shelf<br>本棚(ほんだな): bookshelves</p> <p id='readingExamples'>棚 (たな)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>216</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>204</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>216</p> <p id='keyword'>paulownia</p> <p id='kanji'>桐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A190.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>paulownia, tree, wood, same, monks, hood, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Since you probably don't know what a <b>paulownia</b> <i>tree</i> is, we shall let the key word suggest the phrase ""the Little Brothers of St. <b>Paulownia.</b>"" It is a short step to associate the <i>tree</i> with the <i>monks</i> to its right. (For the curious, the name of this oriental <i>tree</i> really comes from a Russian princess, Anna Pavlovna.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the ""princess tree"". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Paulownia is a Japanese tree which looks same as any other tree.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ、ドウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きり</p> <p id='words'>桐(きり): paulownia tree</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>217</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>205</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>217</p> <p id='keyword'>plant</p> <p id='kanji'>植</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A48D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>plant, tree, wood, straightaway, ten, needle, eye, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You have no doubt seen how people practicing the Japanese art of bonsai take those helpless little saplings and twist them into crippled dwarves before they have a chance to grow up as they should. The more proper way to <b>plant</b> a young <i>tree</i> and give it a fair shake in life is to set it into the earth in such a way that it can grow up <i>straight</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Plants don´t become trees straightaway.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you plant plants, you use a piece of WOOD to make the plant grow STRAIGHT.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>う.える、う.わる</p> <p id='words'>植わる(うわる): to be planted<br>植民地(しょくみんち): colony<br>植木(うえき): garden shrubs, trees, potted plant<br>植物(しょくぶつ): plant, vegetation<br>田植え(たうえ): rice planting<br>植える(うえる): plant</p> <p id='readingExamples'>植える (う.える), 植わる (う.わる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>219</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>206</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>219</p> <p id='keyword'>wither</p> <p id='kanji'>枯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69EAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wither, tree, wood, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>What makes a <i>tree</i> begin to <b>wither</b> up, and perhaps even die, is a kind of arteriosclerosis that keeps its sap from flowing freely. Usually this is due to simple <i>old age</i>, as this character shows us. Be sure to picture a wrinkled <i>old tree</i>, <b>withering</b> away in a retirement center so that the commonsense explanation does not take over.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A tree withers away as it gets old.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When flowers get old they suffer (frame 225), but old trees just WITHER away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.れる、か.らす</p> <p id='words'>枯れる(かれる): wither, die (plant)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>枯らす (か.らす), 枯れる (か.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>220</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>207</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>220</p> <p id='keyword'>crude</p> <p id='kanji'>朴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CB4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crude, tree, wood, magic wand, augury</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As all magicians who have passed their apprenticeship know, one makes one's <i>wand</i> out of a hazel branch and is careful not to alter the natural form of the <i>wood</i>. For the magic of the <i>wand</i> derives its power from its association with the hidden laws of nature, and needs therefore to be kept in its <b>crude</b>, natural state.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Wooden wands are the crudest. They are nothng compared to their carbon fibre equivilents.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A beginner magician starts with a crude wooden magic wand. Later he´ll upgrade to magicite, of course.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほう、ほお、えのき</p> <p id='words'>素朴(そぼく): simplicity, artlessness, naivete</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>221</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>208</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>221</p> <p id='keyword'>town</p> <p id='kanji'>村</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69D91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>town, tree, wood, measure, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The character for <i>village</i> was associated with <i>rice fields</i> (Frame 96). 	"<p id='id'>222</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>209</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>222</p> <p id='keyword'>inter-</p> <p id='kanji'>相</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79BB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inter-, tree, wood, eye</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The prefix <b>inter-</b> stirs up associations of cooperation among people. From there we read off the elements: <i>tree</i> . . . <i>eye</i>. With only a slight leap of the imagination, those two words call to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the block of timber out of one's own <i>eye</i> before helping your neighbors with the splinter in theirs. What more useful rule for <b>inter-</b>human relationships, and what more useful tool for remembering this kanji!</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The prime minister is having inter-course behind that tree! All you can see are his eyes poking out from the righthand-side of the tree.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. ""Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other´s aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck (首, neck (#70)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あい-</p> <p id='words'>相(あい): together, mutually, fellow<br>相変わらず(あいかわらず): as ever, as usual, the same<br>相対(あいたい): confrontation, facing, between ourselves, no third party, tete-a-tete<br>外相(がいしょう): Foreign Minister<br>真相(しんそう): truth, real situation<br>相応(そうおう): suitability, fitness<br>蔵相(ぞうしょう): Minister of Finance<br>相談(そうだん): consultation, discussion<br>相場(そうば): market price, speculation, estimation<br>相応しい(ふさわしい): appropriate<br>様相(ようそう): aspect<br>相手(あいて): companion, partner, company, other party, addressee<br>首相(しゅしょう): Prime Minister, Chancellor (Germany, Austria, etc.)<br>相撲(すもう): sumo wrestling<br>相違(そうい): difference, discrepancy, variation<br>相互(そうご): mutual, reciprocal<br>相続(そうぞく): succession, inheritance<br>相当(そうとう): suitable, fair, tolerable, proper, extremely</p> <p id='readingExamples'>相当 (そうとう), 相談 (そうだん), 真相 (しんそう), 相 (あい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>223</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>210</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>223</p> <p id='keyword'>desk</p> <p id='kanji'>机</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>desk, tree, wood, wind</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We need to fix imagination here on two things to learn the kanji for <b>desk</b>: the wonderful rough <i>wood</i> of which it has been hewn and the <i>wind</i> that blows across it, sending your papers flying all over the room. These two elements, written in that order, dictate how to write the character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My wooden desk is so messy, it looks like a strong wind blew my things all over it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Whenever I´m alone at my computer desk, I´m always getting wood and breaking wind.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つくえ</p> <p id='words'>机(つくえ): desk</p> <p id='readingExamples'>机 (つくえ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>224</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>211</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>224</p> <p id='keyword'>book</p> <p id='kanji'>本</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CAC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>book, tree, wood, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Recalling that <b>books</b> are made of paper, and paper made of <i>trees</i>, one might think of a <b>book</b> as a slice of a <i>tree</i>.
