	"<p id='id'>225</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>212</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>225</p> <p id='keyword'>tag</p> <p id='kanji'>札</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CAD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tag, tree, wood, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>tags</b> you see hanging on <i>trees</i> in public places in Japan are helpful to identify what sort of <i>trees</i> they are. Next time you see one, imagine the bit of wire that fixes the <b>tag</b> to the branch as a large <i>fishhook</i>. REALLY imagine it, illogical as it is, and you will never have trouble with this kanji again.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for ""Paper Money"" w/ the reading さつ (千円札＝1000 Yen paper bill)... It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 (""trump"" playing cards). For the tag meaning I like to think of wooden tags hung on hooks from trees... but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to ""hook you in"" so to speak.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>サツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふだ</p> <p id='words'>名札(なふだ): name plate, name tag<br>改札(かいさつ): examination of tickets<br>札(さつ): paper money</p> <p id='readingExamples'>札 (ふだ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>226</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>213</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>226</p> <p id='keyword'>calendar</p> <p id='kanji'>暦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69AA6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>calendar, cliff, grove, tree, wood, sun, day, tree2, wood2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Look at this character in reverse order, from bottom up. First we see the primitive for <i>days</i>, an appropriate enough way to begin a <b>calendar</b>. Next we see a <i>grove of trees</i> growing under a <i>cliff</i>. The laws of nature being what they are, the <i>trees</i> would be stunted under such conditions, unless they were strong enough to keep growing upwards until they passed through the layers of rock and soil, right up to the surface. Now imagine that in those little boxes marking off the <i>days</i> on your wall <b>calendar</b>, you see that very process taking place step by step: 365 or so time-lapse pictures of that <i>grove of trees</i> each month, from January under the <i>cliff</i> to December on top of the <i>cliff</i>. The story is not as complex as it sounds, particularly if you happen to have a <b>calendar</b> nearby and can flip through it with this image in mind.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>レキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こよみ、りゃく</p> <p id='words'>還暦(かんれき): 60th birthday<br>暦(こよみ): calendar, almanac<br>西暦(せいれき): Christian Era, Anno Domini (A.D.)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>暦 (こよみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>227</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>214</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>227</p> <p id='keyword'>plan</p> <p id='kanji'>案</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A188.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>plan, relax, house, woman, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Without much effort, the elements <i>relax</i> . . . <i>tree</i> suggest a hammock strung between two <i>trees</i> in your backyard, and you stretched out in it, hands folded behind your head, <b>planning</b> something or other. After all, it's something we all do from time to time: kick up our legs on the nearest piece of furniture and daydream about the best <b>plan</b> of action to take. Be sure to relate the <i>relaxation</i> to the <i>tree</i>, so that you don't end up with something else in its place (like ""legs"" or ""desk"" or ""table"").</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you bring a woman to your house, generally its not a good plan to stick your wood up her bottom, she may scream in pain あん!</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>アン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つくえ</p> <p id='words'>案じる(あんじる): to be anxious, to ponder<br>案の定(あんのじょう): sure enough, as usual<br>議案(ぎあん): legislative bill<br>法案(ほうあん): bill (law)<br>案(あん): plan, suffix meaning draft<br>案外(あんがい): unexpectedly<br>案内(あんない): information, guidance<br>提案(ていあん): proposal, proposition, suggestion<br>答案(とうあん): examination paper, examination script</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>228</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>215</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>228</p> <p id='keyword'>parch</p> <p id='kanji'>燥</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E787A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>parch, fire, furniture, wooden goods, mouth, tree, wood, mouth3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Parch</b>ment, made from animal skins, was the most common form of writing material used until the beginning of the nineteenth century. When paper took over, a method was devised to make artificial <b>parch</b>ment from <i>wood</i> pulp. The <i>fire</i> at the left and in the ""strong"" position serves to remind us of the root word, ""<b>parch</b>,"" since nothing dries, puckers, wrinkles, and scorches quite like <i>fire</i>. And here is how we put it all together. Take a sheet of paper (a ""<i>wood-good</i>,""), wet it, and hold it over a <i>hearth</i> in your mind's eye. Now watch as it <b>parches</b> the paper, leaving it with a strange and bumpy surface resembling <b>parch</b>ment.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""furniture"" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (FRAME 215) , maneuver (#671), winding (#1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: It´s been so parched recently that your furniture suddenly catches fire.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The parchment says you need fire to make goods from trees.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はしゃ.ぐ</p> <p id='words'>乾燥(かんそう): dry, arid, dehydrated, insipid</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>229</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>216</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>229</p> <p id='keyword'>not yet</p> <p id='kanji'>未</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CAA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>not yet, tree, wood, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As the key word suggests, this kanji has to do with something not quite over and done with. More concretely, it shows us a <i>tree</i> that is <b>not yet</b> fully grown. The extra short stroke in the upper branches shows new branches spreading out, leaving one with the feeling that the <i>tree</i> has a ways to go yet before it reaches maturity. In other words, the kanji conveys its meaning pictographically, playing on the earlier pictograph of the <i>tree</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I believe a better version of that by mameha1977: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) does not yet (未) have exremities (末) of vermilion (朱).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (末) vermilion (朱).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ミ、ビ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いま.だ、ま.だ、ひつじ</p> <p id='words'>未だ(いまだ): as yet, hitherto, not yet (neg)<br>未(ひつじ): eighth sign of Chinese zodiac (The Ram 1pm-3pm south-southwest June)<br>未開(みかい): savage land, backward region, uncivilized<br>未婚(みこん): unmarried<br>未熟(みじゅく): inexperience, unripeness, raw, unskilled, immature, inexperienced<br>未知(みち): not yet known<br>未定(みてい): not yet fixed, undecided, pending<br>未練(みれん): lingering affection, attachment, regret(s), reluctance<br>未だ(まだ): yet, still, more, besides<br>未満(みまん): less than, insufficient<br>未来(みらい): future tense, the future (usually distant), the world to come</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>230</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>217</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>230</p> <p id='keyword'>extremity</p> <p id='kanji'>末</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CAB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>extremity, tree, wood, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is best learned in connection with that of the previous frame. The first stroke shows a branch that is longer than the main branch, indicating that the tree has reached the <b>extremity</b> of its growth, so that its branches stop spreading and start drooping downwards. Be sure to keep this imagery in mind, to avoid confusing this key word with synonyms that will appear later.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There are no great stories for this one yet, and I always forget it.. So, let´s try something ridiculous: The man lived by himself in the wilderness, with no females within miles. So, his only way of relief was to stick his extremity into a small hole in a tree.. The poor guy. Which horizontal stroke is the extremity? The longer one or the shorter one? That, my friends, is up to your own imaginations. I´d prefer not to dwell on that point, myself. ;).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>マツ、バツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すえ</p> <p id='words'>末(うら): top end, tip<br>期末(きまつ): end of term<br>始末(しまつ): management, dealing, settlement, cleaning up afterwards<br>粉末(ふんまつ): fine powder<br>末期(まっき): closing years (period days), last stage<br>月末(げつまつ): end of the month<br>末(すえ): end, close, future, finally, tip, top, trivialities, posterity, youngest child<br>末っ子(すえっこ): youngest child<br>粗末(そまつ): crude, rough, plain, humble</p> <p id='readingExamples'>末代 (まつだい), 本末 (ほんまつ), 粉末 (ふんまつ), 末 (すえ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>232</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>218</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>232</p> <p id='keyword'>splash</p> <p id='kanji'>沫</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B2AB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>splash, water, water droplets, water pistol, extremity, one, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>splash</b> this kanji refers to is the dash of <i>water</i> against the rocks, with all the foam and spray that this creates. If you think of a <b>splash</b> in this sense as a wave that has run its full course and reached its <i>extremity</i>, namely the seashore, and if you think of it pictorially in your mind's eye, this somewhat rare (but oh so-easy-to-learn) kanji is yours for good.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The extremity of a wave of water is the splash.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A splash is WATER that has reached its EXTREMITY.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>マツ、バツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あわ、しぶき、つばき</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>233</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>219</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>233</p> <p id='keyword'>flavor</p> <p id='kanji'>味</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E591B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>flavor, mouth, not yet, one, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When a tree has <i>not yet</i> finished growing, it produces fruit with a full <b>flavor</b>. When the official taster (the professional <i>mouth</i> to the left) determines that full flavor has been reached, the tree is pruned back so that it remains permanently <i>not yet</i> grown. A neat little agricultural trick and an easy to way see the sense of <b>flavor</b> hidden in this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My mouth has not yet swallowed the food because the flavor is so delicious that I keep chewing it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To enjoy a food´s FLAVOR, it must be in one´s MOUTH but NOT YET swallowed.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ミ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あじ、あじ.わう</p> <p id='words'>味わい(あじわい): flavour, meaning, significance<br>加味(かみ): seasoning, flavoring<br>吟味(ぎんみ): testing, scrutiny, careful investigation<br>三味線(さみせん): three-stringed Japanese guitar, shamisen<br>中味(なかみ): contents, interior, substance, filling, (sword) blade<br>不味い(まずい): unappetising, unpleasant (taste appearance situation), ugly, unskilful, awkward, bungling, unwise, untimely<br>味覚(みかく): taste, palate, sense of taste<br>無意味(むいみ): nonsense, no meaning<br>味わう(あじわう): to taste, savor, relish<br>気味(きみ): sensation, feeling<br>地味(じみ): plain, simple<br>正味(しょうみ): net (weight)<br>調味料(ちょうみりょう): condiment, seasoning<br>味方(みかた): friend, ally, supporter<br>味噌(みそ): miso (bean paste), key (main) point<br>味(あじ): taste<br>興味(きょうみ): interest<br>趣味(しゅみ): hobby<br>意味(いみ): meaning, significance</p> <p id='readingExamples'>味 (あじ), 味わう (あじ.わう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>234</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>220</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>234</p> <p id='keyword'>younger sister</p> <p id='kanji'>妹</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A6B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>younger sister, woman, not yet, one, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>younger sister</b> in the family is the <i>woman</i> in the family who, like the newest branch in a tree, is <i>not yet</i> old enough or mature enough to do everything the elder sister can do (See frame 442).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My younger sister is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Is your younger sister a woman? Not yet! Damn!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>マイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いもうと</p> <p id='words'>姉妹(きょうだい): sisters<br>従姉妹(いとこ): female cousin<br>姉妹(しまい): sisters<br>妹(いもうと): younger sister</p> <p id='readingExamples'>妹 (いもうと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>235</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>221</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>235</p> <p id='keyword'>vermilion</p> <p id='kanji'>朱</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69CB1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vermillion, drop, not yet, one, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>That red-orange color we call <b>vermilion</b> is found in nature during the fall when the leaves lose their sugar and begin to change color. This kanji depicts the very last leaf on a tree in the fall (the <i>drop</i> hung in the first stroke), the leaf that has <i>not yet</i> fallen as it one day must. Look at its color - vermilion. (Well, not really. The truth is, <b>vermilion</b> is made from a mercuric sulfide, but I'm sure you will agree that autumn leaves area lot easier to work with.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s autumn: only one vermilion leaf on the tree has not yet fallen.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (未)[correction wrong character before] vermilion (朱).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あけ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>236</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>222</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>236</p> <p id='keyword'>stocks</p> <p id='kanji'>株</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A0AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stocks, tree, wood, vermillion, drop, not yet, one, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>stocks</b> bought and sold on the market by the tens of millions each day get their name from a comparison to a healthy <i>tree</i>, in which one takes ""<b>stock</b>"" in the hopes that it will grow and produce more and more <i>trees</i> like itself. Usually good <b>stocks</b> are referred to as ""blue chip,"" but here we are asked to associate the key word with the color <i>vermilion</i>, perhaps because one can assess the value of a tree from the color of its autumn leaves.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Which tree would you buy stocks in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one vermilion leaf left on the right?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Ideally, one buys stocks when a company is young, ""green,"" and rapidly growing -- then sells them just before the last vermillion leaf falls off, and a period of dormancy or limited growth begins.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かぶ</p> <p id='words'>株式(かぶしき): stock (company)<br>株(かぶ): share, stock, stump (of tree)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>株 (かぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>237</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>223</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>237</p> <p id='keyword'>young</p> <p id='kanji'>若</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88BA5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>young, flowers, right, by one’s side, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we see a <i>flower</i> held in the <i>right</i> hand. You can imagine yourself in a magic garden where <i>flowers</i> picked with the <i>right</i> hand grant eternal <b>youth</b>; and those picked with the left, premature senility. Go ahead, pick one with each hand and watch what happens.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The young little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In Hawaii, if you wear a flower over your left ear, it means you are taken. A flower over the right means you are not. The younger you are, the more likely you are to have a flower over your right ear…　　　　　　RTK2: 　ニャク　老若　ろうにゃく (young and old)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　 ジャク　若干　じゃっかん(few).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジャク、ニャク、ニャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わか.い、わか-、も.しくわ、も.し、も.しくは</p> <p id='words'>若干(じゃっかん): some, few, number of<br>若し(もし): if, in case, supposing<br>若しかして(もしかして): perhaps, possibly<br>若しくは(もしくは): or, otherwise<br>若しも(もしも): if<br>若々しい(わかわかしい): youthful, young<br>若い(わかい): young</p> <p id='readingExamples'>若年 (じゃくねん), 若干 (じゃっかん), 自若 (じじゃく), 若しくは (も.しくは), 若い (わか.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>238</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>224</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>238</p> <p id='keyword'>grass</p> <p id='kanji'>草</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88D89.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grass, flowers, sunflower, early, sun, day, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Perhaps you know the custom of seeding <b>grass</b> randomly or in some particular pattern with the <i>flower</i> called the crocus, which blooms for a few days each year in <i>early</i> spring. As the <b>grass</b> begins to turn green again after winter has passed, these tiny <i>flowers</i> dot up here and there. Now just look out your window at a patch of <b>grass</b> somewhere and think what a nice idea it would be to have your name spelled out in <i>flowers</i> once as a sort of <i>early</i> harbinger of spring.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Grass grows in earlier than flowers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This grass is very long. The only flowers you can see are sunflowers – the rest are hidden by the grass.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くさ、くさ-、-ぐさ</p> <p id='words'>草臥れる(くたびれる): to get tired, to wear out<br>煙草(たばこ): (pt:) (n) (uk) tobacco (pt: tabaco), cigarettes<br>草履(ぞうり): sandals<br>草(くさ): grass</p> <p id='readingExamples'>草 (くさ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>239</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>225</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>239</p> <p id='keyword'>suffering</p> <p id='kanji'>苦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88BA6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>suffering, flowers, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The picture of <b>suffering</b> we are given here is that of a <i>flower</i> that has grown <i>old</i>. When a <i>flower</i> ages, it pales and dries up, and probably even <b>suffers</b>. If you think that plants are incapable of such feelings, then ask yourself why so many people believe that talking to their flowers helps them bloom better.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The derivates from opium poppies such as morphine can be used to tame the suffering of the old.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くる.しい、-ぐる.しい、くる.しむ、くる.しめる、にが.い、にが.る</p> <p id='words'>苦しめる(くるしめる): to torment, to harass, to inflict pain<br>ご苦労様(ごくろうさま): Thank you very much for your....<br>見苦しい(みぐるしい): unsightly, ugly<br>無茶苦茶(むちゃくちゃ): confused, jumbled, mixed up, unreasonable<br>滅茶苦茶(めちゃくちゃ): absurd, unreasonable, excessive, messed up, spoiled, wreaked<br>苦情(くじょう): complaint, troubles, objection<br>苦心(くしん): pain, trouble, anxiety, diligence, hard work<br>苦痛(くつう): pain, agony<br>苦しい(くるしい): painful, difficult<br>苦しむ(くるしむ): suffer, groan, be worried<br>苦労(くろう): troubles, hardships<br>苦手(にがて): poor (at), weak (in), dislike (of)<br>苦い(にがい): bitter</p> <p id='readingExamples'>苦しい (くる.しい), 苦しむ (くる.しむ), 苦しめる (くる.しめる), 苦い (にが.い), 苦る (にが.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>241</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>226</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>241</p> <p id='keyword'>tolerant</p> <p id='kanji'>寛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AF9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tolerant, house, flowers, look, see, telescope, eye, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>house</i> of <i>flowers</i> or ""hothouse"" has become a metaphor for a narrow-minded, biased, and intolerant attitude distrustful of change. <b>Tolerance</b>, in contrast, is open-minded and welcomes novelty. The way to encourage <b>tolerance</b> in those who lack it is first to have them <i>see</i> through their own hothouse attitudes, which is the very counsel we are given in this kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A tolerant person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning ""beautiful things"") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くつろ.ぐ、ひろ.い、ゆる.やか</p> <p id='words'>寛容(かんよう): forbearance, tolerance, generosity</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>242</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>227</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>242</p> <p id='keyword'>dilute</p> <p id='kanji'>薄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E89684.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dilute, flowers, water, water droplets, water pistol, acupuncturist, specialty, drop, ten, needle, rice field, brains, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take a good look at this kanji: the ""strong"" element here is really the <i>flower</i>, not the <i>water</i> as you might have thought on first glance. To the right is the <i>acupuncturist</i> from frame 48. Taking the key word to connote <b>diluting</b> the vital humors of the body, we can imagine our <i>acupuncturist</i> performing his task with <i>flowers</i> in place of needles, and using their hollow stems to pipe <i>water</i> into the body of the patient.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note This character belongs to a set of characters which share the flower/water primitive such as:: dilute (#227), fall (#299), clan (#1912), and seaweed (#2035).... (落 薄 藩 藻) It may be helpful to create a primitive keyword for this occurrence (like seaweed or watering can) which can save a lot of time distinguishing them from characters like Sino 満 and Full 満, where the water primitive is larger than the flower primitive.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うす.い、うす-、-うす、うす.める、うす.まる、うす.らぐ、うす.ら-、うす.れる、すすき</p> <p id='words'>薄弱(はくじゃく): feebleness, weakness, weak<br>薄暗い(うすぐらい): dim, gloomy<br>薄める(うすめる): dilute<br>薄い(うすい): thin, weak, watery, diluted</p> <p id='readingExamples'>薄い (うす.い), 薄まる (うす.まる), 薄める (うす.める), 薄らく (うす.らく), 薄れる (うす.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>243</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>228</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>243</p> <p id='keyword'>leaf</p> <p id='kanji'>葉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E89189.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>leaf, flowers, Tarzan, generation, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Three elements are given here: <i>flower</i> . . . <i>generation</i> . . . <i>tree</i>. The first and last seem logical enough, since it is the <b>leaf</b> that feeds the <i>flowers</i> on a <i>tree</i>. The element for <i>generation</i> interposed between the two suggests that the movement of a <i>tree</i> from one <i>generation</i> to the next is like its ""turning over a new <b>leaf</b>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>は</p> <p id='words'>落ち葉(おちば): fallen leaves, leaf litter, defoliation, shedding leaves<br>紅葉(こうよう): autumn colours<br>言葉遣い(ことばづかい): speech, expression, wording<br>紅葉(もみじ): autumn colours, (Japanese) maple<br>葉(は): leaf<br>言葉(ことば): word(s), phrase, language, speech<br>葉書(はがき): postcard</p> <p id='readingExamples'>葉 (は)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>244</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>229</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>244</p> <p id='keyword'>imitation</p> <p id='kanji'>模</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A8A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>imitation, tree, wood, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ah, but haven't modern <i>graveyards</i> become a parody of their ancestors! The flowers are plastic, the writing on the stones is unimaginative and cold, and the whole thing looks more like a marble orchard than a right and proper graveyard. This kanji continues with the modernization trend by picturing <b>imitation</b> <i>trees</i> in the <i>graveyard</i>. But of course, how convenient! They don't need pruning or fertilizing, their leaves don't fall, and they remain the same color all year long.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If I find out this furniture you´re selling me is made of imitation wood, I´ll put you in the graveyard.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Japanese are so enamored of everything plastic, they even put IMITATION plastic trees in their graveyards! (No, not really, but I wouldn´t be surprised).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>モ、ボ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>規模(きぼ): scale, scope, plan, structure<br>模型(もけい): model, dummy, maquette<br>模索(もさく): groping (for)<br>模範(もはん): exemplar, exemplification, exemplum, model, example<br>模倣(もほう): imitation, copying<br>模様(もよう): pattern, figure, design</p> <p id='readingExamples'>模範 (もはん), 模型 (もけい), 模倣 (もほう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>245</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>230</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>245</p> <p id='keyword'>vague</p> <p id='kanji'>漠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BCA0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vague, water, water droplets, water pistol, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of the key word as having to do with something viewed through a haze, or in the twilight and from a distance, so that only its outlines are <b>vaguely</b> discernible. Now we are back again to the essence of the true <i>graveyard</i>. The <i>water</i> may be taken as the sound of waves dashing up against the rocks or the dripping of moisture on cold rock - anything that helps you associate <b>vagueness</b> with the <i>graveyard</i> and keep it distinct from the imitation we met in the last frame.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The water in the graveyard has worn away the headstones, so the writing is vague.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>バク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>漠然(ばくぜん): obscure, vague, equivocal<br>砂漠(さばく): desert</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>246</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>231</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>246</p> <p id='keyword'>grave</p> <p id='kanji'>墓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A293.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grave, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The mounds of <i>soil</i> with crude wooden crosses set at their head suggests those boot-hill <b>graves</b> we all know from cowboy lore. The only odd thing about this kanji is that the <i>soil</i> comes UNDER the <i>graveyard</i>, rather than to its left, where we might expect. Just think of the bodies as ""lying under boot-hill"" if you have any trouble. By the way, this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that we learn a kanji whose key word is the same, or almost the same, as a primitive element based on it, but whose shape differs somewhat. There is no cause to worry. By using the primitive in a variety of other characters, as we have done here, the confusion will be averted as a matter of course. In most cases, as here, the primitive element is taken from a part of the fuller kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A grave is a patch of soil in a graveyard.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はか</p> <p id='words'>墓地(はかち): cemetery, graveyard<br>墓(はか): gravesite, tomb</p> <p id='readingExamples'>墓 (はか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>247</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>232</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>247</p> <p id='keyword'>livelihood</p> <p id='kanji'>暮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69AAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>livelihood, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard, sun2, day2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Imagine that you have chosen the occupation of the keeper of a <i>graveyard</i> and spend your <i>days</i> tending to other's dead hood in order to make your means of <b>livelihood</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The gravedigger makes his LIVELIHOOD digging in the graveyard all day For graveyard, imagine an idyllic picture: beautiful grass with the sun shining down...and a dog peeing on one of the graves. Don´t confuse with occupation (#1034). Hold onto the irony of making your LIVElyhood from tending dead people.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>く.れる、く.らす</p> <p id='words'>夕暮れ(ゆうぐれ): evening, (evening) twilight<br>暮らし(くらし): living, livelihood, subsistence, circumstances<br>暮らす(くらす): live, get along<br>暮れ(くれ): year end, sunset, nightfall, end<br>暮れる(くれる): get dark</p> <p id='readingExamples'>暮らす (く.らす), 暮れる (く.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>248</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>233</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>248</p> <p id='keyword'>membrane</p> <p id='kanji'>膜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8869C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>membrane, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>part of the body</i> first affected by a stroll through a haunted <i>graveyard</i> is the skin, which gets goose bumps. But we save the word ""skin"" for another kanji, and use the odd word ""<b>membrane</b>"" here. Think of being so scared through and through that the goose flesh moves from the outside in, giving you goose <b>membranes</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The membranes in your flesh rot when placed in the graveyard.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>マク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>膜(まく): membrane, film</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>249</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>234</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>249</p> <p id='keyword'>seedling</p> <p id='kanji'>苗</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88B97.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>seedling, flowers, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>10</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To avoid confusion with the image of rice seedlings to appear later, we shall take these <b>seedlings</b> out of their agricultural setting in the <i>rice fields</i> and into the frame of Brave New World surgery, where ""ideas"" or ""values"" are being implanted into <i>brains</i> like <b>seedlings</b> to insure a harmonious society. Then you need only imagine them taking root and breaking out into <i>flower</i> right through the tops of the skulls of people walking around on the streets.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Crap! 	"<p id='id'>250</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>235</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>250</p> <p id='keyword'>portent</p> <p id='kanji'>兆</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58586.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>portent, turtle, portent</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we have a pictograph of the back of a turtle, the two sloping vertical strokes representing the central ridge and the four short strokes the pattern. Think of reading turtle shells as a way to foretell the future, and in particular things that <b>portend</b> coming evils.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* When this character is used as a primitive in its full form, we keep the key-word sense of a <i>portent</i>. When it appears to the left in its abbreviated form (namely, the left half only), we shall give it the pictographic sense of a <i>turtle</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When your wife´s LEGs get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad portent for things to come.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きざ.す、きざ.し</p> <p id='words'>兆し(きざし): signs, omen, symptoms</p> <p id='readingExamples'>兆し (きざ.し), 兆す (きざ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>251</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>236</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>251</p> <p id='keyword'>peach tree</p> <p id='kanji'>桃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A183.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>peach tree, tree, wood, portent, turtle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To associate the <b>peach tree</b> with the primitive for a <i>portent</i>, recall the famous Japanese legend of Momotarō, the <b>Peach</b> Boy. It begins once upon a time with a fisherman and his wife who wanted badly to have a child, but none was born to them. Then one day the old man caught a giant <b>peach</b>, out of which jumped a healthy young lad whom they named <b>Peach</b> Boy. Though the boy was destined to perform heroic deeds, his birth also <i>portended</i> great misfortune (how else could he become a hero?). Thus the <i>tree</i> that is associated with a <i>portent</i> of coming evil comes to be the <b>peach tree</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The pits of a peach tree look like turtles.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>King Koopa consistently captures Princess Peach. Eventually he´s going to run out of castles and just set her in a tree.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もも</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>桃 (もも)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>252</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>237</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>252</p> <p id='keyword'>stare</p> <p id='kanji'>眺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79CBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stare, eye, portent, turtle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To give someone the ""evil <i>eye</i>"" is to <b>stare</b> at them, wishing them evil. The roots of the superstition are old and almost universal throughout the cultures of the world. In this kanji, too, being <b>stared</b> at is depicted as an <i>eye</i> that <i>portends</i> evil.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sauron´s One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You lost a staring contest with a turtle because you blinked your eye before he did. (The contest wasn´t fair, because turtles have nictitating membranes, and don´t need to blink so often.) Eye comes first, because stare is most associated with eyes. And compare with challenge (#658) where this same obstreperous turtle challenges you to a finger wrestling contest. (Sibyl´s story with some notes that helped me).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なが.める</p> <p id='words'>眺め(ながめ): scene, view, prospect, outlook<br>眺める(ながめる): view, gaze at</p> <p id='readingExamples'>眺める (なが.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>253</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>238</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>253</p> <p id='keyword'>dog</p> <p id='kanji'>犬</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78AAC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dog, large, St. Bernard, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We know that the character for <i>large</i> takes on the meaning of the <i>St. Bernard</i> <b>dog</b> when used as a primitive. In this frame we finally see why. The <i>drop</i> added as a fourth and final stroke means that we have to do with a normal-sized <b>dog</b>, which compared to the <i>St. Bernard</i> is no more than a <i>drop</i> in the kennel.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive this character can take two meanings. In the form given here it will mean a very small dog (which we shall refer to as a <i>chihuahua</i> for convenience sake). When it takes the form 犭 to the left of a character, we shall give it the meaning of <i>a pack of wild dogs</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A large dog, dripping drool.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If we remember large (#107) as a man with his arms outstretched, the drop represents man´s best friend - a dog.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いぬ、いぬ-</p> <p id='words'>犬(いぬ): dog</p> <p id='readingExamples'>犬 (いぬ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>254</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>239</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>254</p> <p id='keyword'>status quo</p> <p id='kanji'>状</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78AB6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>status quo, turtle, chihuahua, dog, large, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Did you ever hear of the <i>turtle</i> who fell madly in love with a <i>chihuahua</i> but could not have her because their two families did not like the idea of their children intermarrying? Like all classic stories of ill-fated love, this one shows how the young upset the <b>status quo</b> with an emotion older and more powerful than anything their elders have devised to counter it: blind love.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It was left to the turtle to make right with the dog and thus maintain the status quo..</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A turtle mounting a chihuahua clearly disrupts the status quo.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>状(じょう): shape<br>白状(はくじょう): confession<br>現状(げんじょう): present condition, existing state, status quo<br>状況(じょうきょう): state of affairs (around you), situation, circumstances<br>症状(しょうじょう): symptoms, condition<br>状態(じょうたい): current status, condition, situation, circumstances, state</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>255</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>240</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>255</p> <p id='keyword'>silence</p> <p id='kanji'>黙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9BB99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>silence, black, computer, chihuahua, dog, large, drop, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Oddly enough, the character for <b>silence</b> shows us a <i>black chihuahua</i>. Actually, the cute little critter's name is Darkness, as I am sure you remember from the famous song about <b>silence</b> that begins, ""Hello, Darkness, my old friend...."" Note how the four dots reach all the way across the bottom of the character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The computer won´t stop beeping, which is making the chihauhua bark, and it´s driving this guy insane. 	"<p id='id'>256</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>241</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>256</p> <p id='keyword'>sort of thing</p> <p id='kanji'>然</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E784B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sort of thing, moon, crescent moon, month, flesh, part of the body, chihuahua, dog, large, drop, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word in this frame refers to a suffix that gives the word before it an adjectival quality; hence we refer to it as ""<b>sort of thing</b>."" Reverting to the time when dog was more widely eaten than it is today (See frame 127), we see here a large cauldron boiling over an <i>oven flame</i> with the <i>flesh</i> of a <i>chihuahua</i> being thrown into the whole concoction to make it into a ""hot-diggity, dog-diggity"" <b>sort of thing</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Flesh of a dog over a cooking fire = ""hotdog"". There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. Believe me, you don´t want to know what sort of things . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr´s. Thanks!).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. (I use hot dog for this primitive (meat of a dog over a cooking fire). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゼン、ネン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しか、しか.り、しか.し、さ</p> <p id='words'>依然(いぜん): still, as yet<br>公然(こうぜん): open (e.g. secret), public, official<br>然も(さも): with gusto, with satisfaction<br>然しながら(しかしながら): nevertheless, however<br>整然(せいぜん): orderly, regular, well-organized, trim, accurate<br>全然(ぜんぜん): wholly, entirely, completely, not at all (with neg. verb)<br>然して(そして): and<br>断然(だんぜん): firmly, absolutely, definitely<br>漠然(ばくぜん): obscure, vague, equivocal<br>必然(ひつぜん): inevitable, necessary<br>呆然(ぼうぜん): dumbfounded, overcome with surprise, in blank amazement<br>偶然(ぐうぜん): chance, accident, fortuity, unexpectedly, suddenly<br>自然(しぜん): nature, spontaneous<br>自然科学(しぜんかがく): natural science<br>天然(てんねん): nature, spontaneity<br>突然(とつぜん): abruptly, suddenly, unexpectedly, all at once</p> <p id='readingExamples'>当然 (とうぜん), 自然 (しぜん), 必然 (ひつぜん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>257</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>242</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>257</p> <p id='keyword'>reed</p> <p id='kanji'>荻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88DBB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>reed, flowers, pack of wild dogs, fire</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You've no doubt seen cattails, those swamp <b>reeds</b> with a furry <i>flower</i> to them like the tail of a cat. This might just turn out to be a good way to get rid of a troublesome <i>pack of wild dogs</i>: lure them into a swamp of these <b>reeds</b> with the cattail <i>flowers</i> and then set <i>fire</i> to the swamp. Take care to focus on the <i>flower</i> rather than the ""cattail"" to avoid confusion with frame 259 below.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>REEDS are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A reed is a flower that looks like a hot dog.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>テキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おぎ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>258</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>243</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>258</p> <p id='keyword'>hunt</p> <p id='kanji'>狩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78BA9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hunt, pack of wild dogs, guard, house, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>One of the worst problems you have to face when you go <b>hunting</b> is to <i>guard</i> your take from the <i>wild dogs</i>. If you imagine yourself failing at the task, you will probably have a stronger image than if you try to picture yourself succeeding.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Actually when hunting it may be a good idea to use a pack of dogs as your personal guard.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>After a pack of wild dogs hunt some food, they will guard it fiercely.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.る、か.り、-が.り</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>狩り (か.り), 狩る (か.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>259</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>244</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>259</p> <p id='keyword'>cat</p> <p id='kanji'>猫</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78CAB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cat, pack of wild dogs, seedlings, flowers, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Knowing how much dogs love to chase <b>cats</b>, picture a <i>pack of wild dogs</i> planting ""<b>cat</b>-<i>seedlings</i>,"" watering them, and fertilizing them until they can be harvested as a crop of <b>cats</b> for them to chase and torment. If you begin from the key word and think of a ""crop of <b>cats</b>,"" you will not confuse this story with the apparently similar story of two frames ago.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The cat hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Dawgs always wanna put their seedlings in pussies.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ビョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ねこ</p> <p id='words'>猫(ねこ): cat</p> <p id='readingExamples'>猫 (ねこ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>260</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>245</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>260</p> <p id='keyword'>cow</p> <p id='kanji'>牛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7899B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cow</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Can you the ""doodle"" of a <b>cow</b> that has just been run over by a steamroller? The small dot in the first stroke shows its head turned to one side, and the next two strokes, the four legs.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the same sense of <i>cow</i> is kept. Note only that when it is placed OVER another element, its tail is cut off. In this case, and when the element appears on the left, the stroke order is changed.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A cow tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A cow bleeds vermilion when you cut off two of it´s legs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うし</p> <p id='words'>牛(うし): cattle, cow<br>牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう): cow´s milk<br>牛肉(ぎゅうにく): beef</p> <p id='readingExamples'>牛 (うし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>261</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>246</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>261</p> <p id='keyword'>special</p> <p id='kanji'>特</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E789B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>special, cow, Buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Despite the strong phonetic similarity, there will be no problem keeping the key word <b>special</b> distinct from the character we met earlier for <i>specialty</i> (Frame 47), since the latter has immediate connotations lacking in this kanji. Anyway, we shall let the key word of this frame refer to something in a <b>special</b> class all its own - like the sacred <i>cows</i> of India that wander freely without fear of being butchered and ground into hamburger. Even though the practice is originally a Hindu one, and in any case no longer followed among the majority of Japanese Buddhist monks, the Buddha's refusal to take the life of any sentient being makes it only fitting that the <i>cows</i> should be placed on the sacred grounds of a <i>Buddhist temple</i> in this kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of not special people, but special animals. The sacred Hindu cows are special - they can wander around the temple without fear of becoming roast beef.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Church Lady is traveling through Japan and notices with distaste a sacred cow relieving itself inside a Buddhist Temple. ""Well, isn´t that special"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>トク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>特技(とくぎ): special skill<br>特産(とくさん): specialty, special product<br>特集(とくしゅう): feature (e.g. newspaper), special edition, report<br>特派(とくは): send specially, special envoy<br>特有(とくゆう): characteristic (of), peculiar (to)<br>特許(とっきょ): special permission, patent<br>特権(とっけん): privilege, special right<br>特殊(とくしゅ): special, unique<br>特色(とくしょく): characteristic, feature<br>特長(とくちょう): forte, merit<br>特徴(とくちょう): feature, characteristic<br>特定(とくてい): specific, special, particular<br>独特(どくとく): peculiarity, uniqueness, characteristic<br>特売(とくばい): special sale<br>特急(とっきゅう): limited express (train, faster than an express)<br>特に(とくに): specially<br>特別(とくべつ): special</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>262</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>247</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>262</p> <p id='keyword'>revelation</p> <p id='kanji'>告</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5918A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>revelation, cow, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Folklore throughout the world tells us of talking animals who show a wisdom superior to that of human beings, and that same tradition has found its way into television shows and cartoons right into our own century. This character depicts <b>revelation</b> through the <i>mouth</i> of a <i>cow</i>, suggesting oracular utterances about truths hidden to human intelligence.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The revelation makes the cow´s mouth drop down, ""Hamburgers are made of what?!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you get a revelation, you may drop to the ground with your mouth wide open.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つ.げる</p> <p id='words'>勧告(かんこく): advice, counsel, remonstrance, recommendation<br>告白(こくはく): confession, acknowledgement<br>申告(しんこく): report, statement, filing a return, notification<br>忠告(ちゅうこく): advice, warning<br>告げる(つげる): to inform<br>布告(ふこく): edict, ordinance, proclamation<br>警告(けいこく): warning, advice<br>広告(こうこく): advertisement<br>報告(ほうこく): report, information</p> <p id='readingExamples'>告げる (つ.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>263</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>248</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>263</p> <p id='keyword'>before</p> <p id='kanji'>先</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58588.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>before, cow, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take this key word in its physical, not its temporal, sense (even though it refers to both). If you have a <i>cow</i> with <i>human legs</i>, as the elements show us here, it can only be because you have two people in a <i>cow</i>-suit. I always thought I'd prefer to be the one standing <b>before</b>, rather than the one that holds up the rear and becomes the ""butt"" of everyone's laughter.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I´ve never seen a cow with human legs before!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Nasty story but it keeps the meaning true to the kanji. ""BEFORE you stick it in a COW and SPREAD the legs (the bottom stroke of this cow looks like two legs) make sure she has HUMAN LEGS""-------------sorry, I´ll remove if I get enough reports, but will keep if I get more stars.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さき、ま.ず</p> <p id='words'>お先に(おさきに): before, ahead, previously<br>先に(さきに): before, earlier than, ahead, beyond, away, previously, recently<br>先行(せんこう): preceding, going first<br>先代(せんだい): family predecessor, previous age, previous generation<br>先だって(せんだって): recently, the other day<br>先着(せんちゃく): first arrival<br>先天的(せんてんてき): a priori, inborn, innate, inherent, congenital, hereditary<br>勤め先(つとめさき): place of work<br>優先(ゆうせん): preference, priority<br>先程(さきほど): some time ago<br>先日(せんじつ): the other day, a few days ago<br>先々月(せんせんげつ): month before last<br>先々週(せんせんしゅう): week before last<br>先祖(せんぞ): ancestor<br>先端(せんたん): pointed end, tip, fine point, spearhead, cusp, vanguard, advanced, leading edge<br>先頭(せんとう): head, lead, vanguard, first<br>祖先(そせん): ancestor<br>先ず(まず): at first<br>真っ先(まっさき): the head, the foremost, beginning<br>先輩(せんぱい): one´s senior<br>先(さき): the future, forward, priority, precedence, former, previous, old, late<br>先月(せんげつ): last month<br>先週(せんしゅう): last week, the week before<br>先生(せんせい): teacher, master, doctor</p> <p id='readingExamples'>先 (さき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>264</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>249</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>264</p> <p id='keyword'>wash</p> <p id='kanji'>洗</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B497.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wash, water, water droplets, water pistol, before, cow, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>11</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is so logical that one is tempted to let the elements speak for themselves: <i>water</i> . . . <i>before</i>. But we have already decided we will not allow such rationalism to creep into our stories. Not even this once. Instead, let us change the character from the Peanuts comic strip called ""Pigpen,"" who is always preceded by a little cloud of dust and grime, and rename him ""<b>Wash</b>-Out."" Everywhere he walks, a spray of <i>water</i> goes <i>before</i> him to sanitize everything he touches.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In Japan, you always wash with water from the shower before you enter the bathtub.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You wash things with WATER to get them back to the clean state they were in BEFORE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あら.う</p> <p id='words'>水洗(すいせん): flushing<br>洗剤(せんざい): detergent, washing material<br>手洗い(てあらい): restroom, lavatory, hand-washing<br>洗う(あらう): to wash<br>お手洗い(おてあらい): toilet, restroom, lavatory, bathroom (US)<br>洗濯(せんたく): washing, laundry</p> <p id='readingExamples'>洗う (あら.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>265</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>250</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>265</p> <p id='keyword'>jammed in</p> <p id='kanji'>介</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BB8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>jammed in, umbrella, stick, walking cane</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The idea of something getting <b>jammed into</b> something else is depicted here by having a <i>walking stick</i> get <b>jammed into</b> an <i>umbrella</i> frame by someone shoving it into an already occupied slot in the <i>umbrella</i> stand at the door. First notice the vertical strokes: on the left is the curved umbrella handle, and on the right the straight <i>walking stick</i>. Now try to imagine the two parties tugging at their respective properties like two kids on a wishbone, creating a scene at the entrance of an elegant restaurant.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for ""jammed in."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Two people jammed in under an umbrella. A woman with a dress and a man (straight). It´s always me that ends up getting wet.... but the tail of the skirt is this time!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>介護(かいご): nursing<br>介入(かいにゅう): intervention<br>介抱(かいほう): nursing, looking after<br>厄介(やっかい): trouble, burden, care, bother, worry, dependence, support, kindness, obligation<br>紹介(しょうかい): introduce</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>266</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>251</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>266</p> <p id='keyword'>world</p> <p id='kanji'>界</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7958C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>world, rice field, brains, jammed in, umbrella, stick, cane</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As the <b>world</b> gets <i>jammed</i> with more and more people, there is less and less space. Imagine yourself taking an air flight over a <b>world</b> so densely populated that every bit of it is sectioned off like a gigantic checkerboard (the <i>rice fields</i>). If you look closely at the character, you should be able to see a kind of movement taking place as still more is being <b>jammed into</b> that already narrow space.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A famous philosopher once said that his world consisted of all the things he could jam into his brain.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>境界(きょうかい): boundary<br>限界(げんかい): limit, bound<br>世界(せかい): world</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>267</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>252</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>267</p> <p id='keyword'>tea</p> <p id='kanji'>茶</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88CB6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tea, flowers, umbrella, wooden pole</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As everyone knows, <b>tea</b> is made from <b>tea</b> leaves. But the <b>tea</b> plant itself has its own <i>flowers</i>, which can be quite beautiful and add a special flavor to the <i>tea</i>, as the Chinese found out already over 4,598 years ago. With the image of a terrace of <i>flowering</i> <b>tea</b> bushes in mind, picture a number of brightly painted and very l-o-n-g <i>wooden poles</i> (Frame 207) placed here and there in their midst, with a tiny <i>umbrella</i> at the top to shade the delicate-tasting <b>tea</b> <i>flowers</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Some people think drinking tea is boring and quaint. 	"<p id='id'>269</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>253</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>269</p> <p id='keyword'>fit</p> <p id='kanji'>合</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59088.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji for <b>fit</b> reads literally, top to bottom, as a <i>meeting</i> of <i>mouths</i>&nbsp;- which is a rather descriptive way of speaking of a romantic kiss. We all know what happens when there is no meeting of minds and when people's ideas don't <b>fit</b>&nbsp;with one another. But this kanji invites us to imagine what would happened to the romance of a certain unfortunate couple whose <i>mouths</i> didn't <b>fit</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I wouldn´t mind a meeting of mouths with her, she´s really fit !</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>He had such a big mouth that he could easily fit one whole umbrella in it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p 	"<p id='id'>270</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>254</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>270</p> <p id='keyword'>pagoda</p> <p id='kanji'>塔</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A194.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pagoda, soil, dirt, ground, flowers, fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>On the left we see a mound of <i>dirt</i>, and to the right <i>flowers</i> made to <i>fit</i> together. The two sides combine to create a great <b>pagoda</b> made of <i>dirt</i>, with <i>flowers</i> by the tens of thousands <i>fitted</i> together for the roofing of each of the layers. Be sure to put yourself in the scene and <i>fit</i> a few of the <i>flowers</i> in place yourself so that the image works its way into memory with full force.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Pictograph-o-rama. This is a corner of a Japanese garden, with a small mound of soil on the left, and a little concrete pagoda in the front with flowers behind it. (To my eye, the fit looks a lot like a little pagoda anyway. This may or may not cause confusion for you, though...).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>塔(とう): tower, pagoda</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>271</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>255</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>271</p> <p id='keyword'>king</p> <p id='kanji'>王</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78E8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>See what you can do to come up with a pictograph of a <b>king's</b> scepter here that suits your own idea of what it should look like. You might even begin with the basic element for <i>I beam</i> and then try to fit the remaining third stroke in.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this can mean either <i>king</i> or <i>scepter</i>, but it will usually be taken to mean <i>ball,</i>&nbsp;as an abbreviation of the character in the next frame.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To be king you have to be a real crafty one !</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The king unites heaven and earth.
