	"<p id='id'>272</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>256</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>272</p> <p id='keyword'>jewel</p> <p id='kanji'>玉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78E89.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>jewel, king, jewel, ball, earring, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Note the <i>drop</i> here in the king's <i>scepter</i>, which is exactly what you would expect it to be: a precious <b>jewel</b> handed down from of old as a symbol of his wealth and power.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we can use this to mean either <i>jewel</i> or <i>ball</i>. When it appears anywhere other than on the left side of a kanji, it takes the same shape as here. On the left, it will be lacking the final stroke, making it the same as the character in the previous frame.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the ""drop"").</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギョク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たま、たま-、-だま</p> <p id='words'>玉(ぎょく): king (shogi)<br>玉(たま): ball, sphere, coin</p> <p id='readingExamples'>玉 (たま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>273</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>257</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>273</p> <p id='keyword'>treasure</p> <p id='kanji'>宝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE9D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>treasure, house, king, jewel, ball, earring, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Every <i>house</i> has its <b>treasure</b>, as every thief knows only too well. While the things we <b>treasure</b> most are usually of sentimental value, we take the original sense of the term <b>treasure</b> here and make it refer to <i>jewels</i> kept in one's <i>house</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>On treasure island is a single house - where all the jewels are stored.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Put a ""roof"" (lid) on your jewels and voila! You´ve got a treasure chest.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たから</p> <p id='words'>重宝(じゅうほう): priceless treasure, convenience, usefulness<br>宝器(ほうき): treasured article or vessel, outstanding individual<br>宝(たから): treasure<br>宝石(ほうせき): gem, jewel</p> <p id='readingExamples'>宝 (たから)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>274</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>258</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>274</p> <p id='keyword'>pearl</p> <p id='kanji'>珠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78FA0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pearl, king, jewel, ball, vermillion, drop, not yet, one, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take care to keep the meaning of this kanji distinct from that for <i>jewel</i>. Think of the most enormous <b>pearl</b> you have ever seen, a great <i>vermilion</i>-colored <i>ball</i> sitting on your ring and making it extremely difficult to move without falling over from the weight of the thing.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion pearls!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>King Vermillion is a little queer and likes to wear pearl necklaces.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たま</p> <p id='words'>真珠(しんじゅ): pearl</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>275</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>259</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>275</p> <p id='keyword'>present</p> <p id='kanji'>現</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78FBE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>present, king, jewel, ball, see, telescope, eye, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Do not think of a ""gift"" here, but of the <b>present</b> moment, as distinct from the future and the past. The kanji gives us a <i>ball</i> in which we see the <b>present</b>&nbsp;- obviously a crystal <i>ball</i> that enables us to <i>see</i> things going on at the <b>present</b> in faraway places.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The KING ... can SEE clearly the PRESENT state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hey, I want my money back! This crystal ball is out of order, I can see the present instead of the future!</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あらわ.れる、あらわ.す、うつつ、うつ.つ</p> <p id='words'>現われ(あらわれ): embodiment, materialization<br>現われる(あらわれる): to appear, to come in sight, to become visible, to come out, to embody, to materialize, to express oneself<br>現行(げんこう): present, current, in operation<br>現場(げんじょう): actual spot, scene, scene of the crime<br>現像(げんぞう): developing (film)<br>現地(げんち): actual place, local<br>再現(さいげん): reappearance, reproduction, return, revival<br>現す(あらわす): indicate, show, display<br>現れ(あらわれ): embodiment<br>現れる(あらわれる): appear, embody, express oneself<br>現金(げんきん): cash, ready money, mercenary, self-interested<br>現在(げんざい): present, up to now, nowadays, modern times, current<br>現実(げんじつ): reality<br>現象(げんしょう): phenomenon<br>現状(げんじょう): present condition, existing state, status quo<br>現代(げんだい): nowadays, modern times, present-day<br>現に(げんに): actually, really<br>現場(げんば): actual spot, scene, scene of the crime<br>実現(じつげん): implementation, materialization, realization<br>表現(ひょうげん): expression, presentation, (mathematics) representation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>現す (あらわ.す), 現れる (あらわ.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>277</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>260</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>277</p> <p id='keyword'>lunatic</p> <p id='kanji'>狂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78B82.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lunatic, pack of wild dogs, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A <b>lunatic</b> is literally one driven mad by the light of the moon, and the most famous of the ""<b>looneys</b>"" are the legendary lycanthropes or ""wolfmen."" Sometimes the transformation is only a temporary phenomenon, sometimes it is permanent. In the latter case, the poor chap takes off on all fours to live with the beasts. To remember this kanji, imagine one of these lycanthropes going <b>looney</b> and setting himself up as <i>king</i> of a <i>pack of wild dogs</i> that roams about and terrorizes innocent suburban communities.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Oh no ! A pack of dogs has bitten the king. He has turned into a rabid lunatic !</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think of King Nebuchadnezzar, who for 7 years lost his sanity and had to live like a wild animal.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くる.う、くる.おしい、くるお.しい</p> <p id='words'>狂う(くるう): go mad, get out of order</p> <p id='readingExamples'>狂う (くる.う), 狂おしい (くる.おしい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>279</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>261</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>279</p> <p id='keyword'>emperor</p> <p id='kanji'>皇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79A87.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>emperor, white, dove, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>An <b>emperor</b>, as we all know, is a ruler - something like a <i>king</i> but higher in status. The <i>white bird</i> perched above the <i>king</i>, elevating him to <b>imperial</b> heights, is the messenger he sends back and forth to the gods to request advice and special favors, something that <i>white birds</i> have long done in folklore throughout the world.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ancient Rome had Emperors instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an emperor is a king in white. (make sure you picture a roman emperor not a japanese one and you´ll be ok).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The white dove descended on the king and he was promoted to emperor.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、オウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>皇居(こうきょ): Imperial Palace<br>天皇(すめらぎ): Emperor of Japan<br>天皇(てんのう): Emperor of Japan</p> <p id='readingExamples'>皇帝 (こうてい), 皇室 (こうしつ), 皇后 (こうごう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>280</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>262</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>280</p> <p id='keyword'>display</p> <p id='kanji'>呈</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59188.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>display, mouth, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The trick to remembering this character lies in associating the key word with the line from the nursery rhyme about 4 and 20 blackbirds baked in a pie: ""Wasn't this a dainty dish to set before the <i>king</i>?"" If we think of <b>display</b> in terms of that famous line, and the <i>king</i> with his head thrown back and his <i>mouth</i> wide open as 4 and 20 blackbirds fly in one after the other, we shall have satisfied both the elements and their position.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The mouth of the king is displaying his bling.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>What a pathetic display! The king is sprawled on his throne, head back and mouth wide open, fast asleep. We should never have let him drink so much at that banquet last night.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>進呈(しんてい): presentation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>281</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>263</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>281</p> <p id='keyword'>whole</p> <p id='kanji'>全</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E585A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>whole, umbrella, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Wholeness</b> suggests physical and spiritual health, ""having your act together."" The kanji-image for <b>wholeness</b> depicts being ""<i>king</i> under your own <i>umbrella</i>,"" that is, giving order to your own life. I know it sounds terribly abstract, but what could be more abstract than the word <b>whole</b>?</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro´s story. ""fat"" makes a more vivid image for me.).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The king takes up the whole space under his umbrella.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゼン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まった.く、すべ.て</p> <p id='words'>健全(けんぜん): health, soundness, wholesome<br>全快(ぜんかい): complete recovery of health<br>全盛(ぜんせい): height of prosperity<br>全然(ぜんぜん): wholly, entirely, completely, not at all (with neg. verb)<br>全滅(ぜんめつ): annihilation<br>完全(かんぜん): perfection, completeness<br>全て(すべて): all, the whole, entirely, in general, wholly<br>全員(ぜんいん): all members (unanimity), all hands, the whole crew<br>全(ぜん): all, whole, entire, complete, overall, pan-<br>全国(ぜんこく): nation-wide, whole country, national<br>全集(ぜんしゅう): complete works<br>全身(ぜんしん): the whole body, full-length (portrait)<br>全体(ぜんたい): whole, entirety, whatever (is the matter)<br>全般(ぜんぱん): whole, universal, wholly, general<br>全く(まったく): really, truly, entirely, completely, wholly, perfectly, indeed<br>安全(あんぜん): safety<br>全部(ぜんぶ): all, entire, whole, altogether</p> <p id='readingExamples'>全く (まった.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>282</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>264</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>282</p> <p id='keyword'>plug</p> <p id='kanji'>栓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A093.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>plug, tree, wood, whole, umbrella, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we think of <b>plug</b> in the sense of a cork or stopper used to seal the mouth of a bottle, water faucet, or something with liquid running out of it. Forgetting the abstract picture of the former frame, let us work with all the primitive units: <i>tree</i> . . . <i>umbrella</i> . . . <i>ball</i>. Imagine a <i>tree</i> with a faucet in the side out of which tennis <i>balls</i> are flowing, bouncing all over the ground by the hundreds. You fight your way up to it and shove your giant beach <i>umbrella</i> into the <i>tree</i> to <b>plug</b> it up.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. ""You´ll need the whole tree to plug that gap"". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they´re doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the ""whole"" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To plug the hole, you need to use a whole piece of wood - like a cork or something.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>栓(せん): stopper, cork</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>283</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>265</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>283</p> <p id='keyword'>logic</p> <p id='kanji'>理</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79086.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>logic, king, jewel, ball, computer</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We first referred to this character back in frame 185, to which you might want to return to have a peek. The image of <b>logic</b> we are given is something like a central <i>jewel</i> in a <i>computer</i>, like the <i>jewels</i> in old clocks that keep them running smoothly. Try to picture yourself making your way through all the rams and roms and approaching this shining <i>jewel</i>, a chorus of voice sand a blast of trumpets in the background heralding the great seat of all-knowing <b>logic</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The king of LOGIC is the computer.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Computers are ruled by logic (it is the king of computers).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>リ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ことわり</p> <p id='words'>義理(ぎり): duty, sense of duty, honor, decency, courtesy, debt of gratitude, social obligation<br>真理(しんり): truth<br>推理(すいり): reasoning, inference, mystery or detective genre (movie novel etc.)<br>生理(せいり): physiology, menses<br>調理(ちょうり): cooking<br>理屈(りくつ): theory, reason<br>理性(りせい): reason, sense<br>理論(りろん): theory<br>論理(ろんり): logic<br>管理(かんり): control, management (e.g. of a business)<br>原理(げんり): principle, theory, fundamental truth<br>合理(ごうり): rational<br>修理(しゅうり): repairing, mending<br>処理(しょり): processing, dealing with, treatment, disposition, disposal<br>心理(しんり): mentality<br>整理(せいり): sorting, arrangement, adjustment, regulation<br>総理大臣(そうりだいじん): Prime Minister<br>代理(だいり): representation, agency, proxy, deputy, agent, attorney, substitute, alternate, acting (principal, etc.)<br>物理(ぶつり): physics<br>理科(りか): science<br>理解(りかい): understanding, comprehension<br>理想(りそう): ideal<br>地理(ちり): geography, geographical features<br>無理(むり): compulsion<br>理由(りゆう): reason<br>料理(りょうり): cooking, cookery, cuisine</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>284</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>266</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>284</p> <p id='keyword'>lord</p> <p id='kanji'>主</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B8BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lord, drop, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A man's home is his castle, goes the proverb from an age where it was the male who was <b>lord</b> of the household. Fundamentally, it means only that every one of us is a bit (or <i>drop</i>) of a <i>king</i> in our own environment. As for the positioning of the elements, if you take care to ""read off"" the primitives in this way, you won't end up putting the <i>drop</i> down below, where it turns the kanji into a jewel.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive element, we set the key word aside entirely and take it as a pictograph of a solid brass <i>candlestick</i> (with the drop representing the flame at the top).</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Although this kanji´s meaning hasn´t caused me much trouble, I´ve had problems remembering the direction of the drop above king, since drops at tops of kanji often seem to appear in different directions. To remember this one, I think of the placement of the drop in jewel (#256). Both of them use the king primitive and include a short drop stroke going from the top left to bottom right.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ、ス、シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ぬし、おも、あるじ</p> <p id='words'>家主(いえぬし): landlord<br>君主(くんしゅ): ruler, monarch<br>自主(じしゅ): independence, autonomy<br>地主(じぬし): landlord<br>主演(しゅえん): starring, playing the leading part<br>主観(しゅかん): subjectivity, subject, ego<br>主義(しゅぎ): doctrine, rule, principle<br>主権(しゅけん): sovereignty, supremacy, dominion<br>主催(しゅさい): organization, sponsorship<br>主食(しゅしょく): staple food<br>主人公(しゅじんこう): protagonist, main character, hero(ine) (of a story), head of household<br>主体(しゅたい): subject, main constituent<br>主題(しゅだい): subject, theme, motif<br>主導(しゅどう): main leadership<br>主任(しゅにん): person in charge, responsible official<br>民主(みんしゅ): democratic, the head of the nation<br>主に(おもに): mainly, primarily<br>主語(しゅご): (grammar) subject<br>主張(しゅちょう): claim, request, insistence, assertion, advocacy, emphasis, contention, opinion, tenet<br>主婦(しゅふ): housewife, mistress<br>主役(しゅやく): leading part, leading actor or actress<br>主要(しゅよう): chief, main, principal, major<br>家主(やぬし): landlord<br>御主人(ごしゅじん): (polite) your husband, her husband</p> <p id='readingExamples'>主人 (しゅじん), 主権 (しゅけん), 施主 (せしゅ), 主 (おも), 主 (ぬし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>285</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>267</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>285</p> <p id='keyword'>pour</p> <p id='kanji'>注</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B3A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pour, water, water droplets, water pistol, candlestick, lord, drop, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Picture <b>pouring</b> water from a lighted <i>candlestick</i>. What could be more ridiculous, or simpler, as a way to recall this kanji?</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to pour it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Like water the hot wax poured down the side of the candlestick.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>チュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そそ.ぐ、さ.す、つ.ぐ</p> <p id='words'>注す(さす): pour or serve (drinks)<br>注文(ちゅうもん): order, request<br>注ぐ(そそぐ): pour (into), fill, irrigate, pay, feed (a fire)<br>注(ちゅう): annotation, explanatory note<br>注目(ちゅうもく): notice, attention, observation<br>注ぐ(つぐ): pour (in), fill (with)<br>注意(ちゅうい): advise, pay attention<br>注射(ちゅうしゃ): inject</p> <p id='readingExamples'>注ぐ (そそ.ぐ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>286</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>268</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>286</p> <p id='keyword'>pillar</p> <p id='kanji'>柱</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69FB1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pillar, tree, wood, candlestick, lord, drop, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>pillar</b> referred to here is the <i>wooden</i> beam that stands at the entrance to a traditional Japanese house. Carve it in imagination into the shape of a gigantic <i>candlestick</i> and your work is done.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The main pillar in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the lord of the trees.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Why has this pillar been carved in the shape of a giant penis?! ""You said that ´it should be made of wood´, My Lord."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はしら</p> <p id='words'>柱(はしら): pillar, post<br>電柱(でんちゅう): telephone pole, telegraph pole, lightpole</p> <p id='readingExamples'>柱 (はしら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>287</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>269</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>287</p> <p id='keyword'>gold</p> <p id='kanji'>金</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98791.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>gold, metal, gold, umbrella, drop, king, jewel, ball, drop2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write, I would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows. Anyway, we want to depict bars of <b>gold</b> bullion with an <i>umbrella</i> overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the <i>scepters</i> of the kingdom, <i>drop</i> by <i>drop</i>, and shaping them into bars.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, it means not only <i>gold</i> but any <i>metal</i> at all.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn´t fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Under the umbrella´s shade, the king sang, "" Drop it to the left, drop it to the right, give me all the GOLD in sight!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>キン、コン、ゴン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かね、かな-、-がね</p> <p id='words'>黄金(おうごん): gold<br>金槌(かなづち): (iron) hammer, punishment<br>金庫(かねぐら): safe, vault, treasury, provider of funds<br>金持ち(かねもち): rich man<br>基金(ききん): fund, foundation<br>金曜(きんよう): Friday<br>残金(ざんきん): remaining money<br>資金(しきん): funds, capital<br>送金(そうきん): remittance, sending money<br>大金(たいきん): great cost<br>賃金(ちんぎん): wages<br>募金(ぼきん): fund-raising, collection of funds<br>預金(よきん): deposit, bank account<br>金(かね): money, metal<br>金融(きんゆう): monetary circulation, credit situation<br>金(きん): metal, money, gold<br>金額(きんがく): amount of money<br>金魚(きんぎょ): goldfish<br>金庫(きんこ): safe, vault, treasury, provider of funds<br>金銭(きんせん): money, cash<br>金属(きんぞく): metal<br>現金(げんきん): cash, ready money, mercenary, self-interested<br>借金(しゃっきん): debt, loan, liabilities<br>集金(しゅうきん): money collection<br>奨学金(しょうがくきん): scholarship<br>賞金(しょうきん): prize, monetary award<br>税金(ぜいきん): tax, duty<br>代金(だいきん): price, payment, cost, charge, the money, the bill<br>貯金(ちょきん): (bank) savings<br>針金(はりがね): wire<br>料金(りょうきん): fee, charge, fare<br>お金(おかね): money<br>金曜日(きんようび): Friday</p> <p id='readingExamples'>金属 (きんぞく), 金銭 (きんせん), 純金 (じゅんきん), 金 (かね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>288</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>270</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>288</p> <p id='keyword'>pig iron</p> <p id='kanji'>銑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98A91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pig-iron, metal, gold, before, cow, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Pig iron</b> refers to iron in the crude form in which it emerges from the smelting furnaces. Of all the various forms <i>metal</i> can take, this one shows us <i>metal</i> <i>before</i> it has been refined. Imagine two photographs labeled ""<i>before</i>"" and ""after"" to show the process.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pig iron is basic/crude metal, that is, before it has been processed.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Pig-iron is crude metal (金) before (先) it is refined. If you have trouble with this character, envision a big minotaur (cow head with human legs) as a blacksmith, smelting metals and making swords for war.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>289</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>271</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>289</p> <p id='keyword'>bowl</p> <p id='kanji'>鉢</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E989A2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bowl, metal, gold, origin, book, tree, wood, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let <b>bowl</b> suggest a large and heavy <i>golden</i> <b>bowl</b> into which you are throwing all the <i>books</i> you own to mash them into pulp, for some outrageous reason you will have to think up yourself.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If I was begging with a BOWL, I would want GOLD and BOOKS.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハチ、ハツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>鉢(はち): bowl, pot, basin</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鉢 (はち), 植木鉢 (うえきばち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>290</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>272</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>290</p> <p id='keyword'>copper</p> <p id='kanji'>銅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98A85.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>copper, metal, gold, same, monks, hood, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Picture an order of <i>monks</i> serving as chaplains for the police force. Their special habit, made of protective <i>metal</i>, is distinguished by a row of <b>copper</b> buttons just like the ""<b>cops</b>"" they serve.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I can´t believe no one has used this one yet: Copper is metal which looks almost the same as gold. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it´s yellow and it´s shiny (atleast in some compounds)!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Copper is an excellent conductor. In other words, it´s a metal for which the voltage is the same everywhere. That´s why it´s used for wires.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あかがね</p> <p id='words'>銅(あかがね): copper<br>銅(どう): copper</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>291</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>273</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>291</p> <p id='keyword'>angling</p> <p id='kanji'>釣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E987A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>angling, metal, gold, ladle, bound up, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The character we learned for <i>fishing</i> (Frame 184) refers to the professional, net-casting industry, while the <b>angling</b> of this character refers to the sport. The odd thing is that your <b>angling</b> rod is a <i>golden</i> <i>ladle</i> which you are using to scoop <i>gold</i>fish out of a river.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I´m a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I´m a true ANGLING professional.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine an effeminate Roman 2000 years ago angling with a golden ladle instead of a rod because it matches his eyes and hair better and it impresses the boys. (Why a Roman? Because ´angling´ is just the roman-derived way to say ´fishing´ - use this to distinguish fishing from angling.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つ.る、つ.り、つ.り-</p> <p id='words'>釣り(つり): fishing, angling<br>釣鐘(つりがね): hanging bell<br>釣(つり): change (e.g. for a dollar)<br>釣(つり): fishing<br>釣り合う(つりあう): balance, be in harmony, suit<br>釣る(つる): to fish</p> <p id='readingExamples'>釣る (つ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Since we already expect that <b>needles</b> are made of <i>metal</i>, let us picture a set of solid <i>gold</i> darning <b>needles</b> to complete the kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Remember the story of the needle in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a needle if it wasn´t a GOLD NEEDLE?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A golden needle is worth ten times more than an ordinary needle.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はり</p> <p id='words'>針路(しんろ): course, direction, compass bearing<br>針(はり): needle, fish hook, pointer, hand (clock)<br>針金(はりがね): wire<br>方針(ほうしん): objective, plan, policy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>針 (はり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>293</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>275</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>293</p> <p id='keyword'>inscription</p> <p id='kanji'>銘</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98A98.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inscription, metal, gold, name, evening, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take <b>inscription</b> in the sense of the <i>name</i> you ask the jeweler to carve on a <i>gold</i> bracelet or inside a <i>gold</i> ring to identify its owner or communicate some sentimental message. It will help if you can recall the first time you had this done and the feelings you had at the time.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A piece of metal with a name on it. 	"<p id='id'>294</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>276</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>294</p> <p id='keyword'>tranquillize</p> <p id='kanji'>鎮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98EAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tranquilize, metal, gold, true, truth, ten, needle, eye, tool, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>12</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The first lie-detector machines of the twentieth century worked by wiring pieces of <i>metal</i> to the body to measure the amount of sweat produced when questions were asked. It was discovered that nervousness produced more sweat, indicating subconscious reactions when the <i>truth</i> was getting too close for comfort. Nowadays, people can take drugs that <b>tranquillize</b> them in such a way as to neutralize the effect of the device, which is why other means have had to be developed.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Tranquilize - using a metal syringe to get the truth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Enough gold can tranquilize the truth in anyone.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しず.める、しず.まる、おさえ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>鎮まる (しず.まる), 鎮める (しず.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>295</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>277</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>295</p> <p id='keyword'>road-way</p> <p id='kanji'>道</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98193.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>road-way, neck, horns, drop, eye, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word carries both the sense of a <b>road</b> for transit and a <b>way</b> or method of doing something, but the former is better for forming an image. The primitives read: the <i>neck</i> of a <i>road</i>. Think of a crowded <b>road-way</b> where traffic has come to a standstill - what we commonly refer to as a ""bottle<i>neck</i>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that´s why I take the train! ).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel´s neck over a dusty road. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her neck be ground into the road, spilling it´s precious contents into the dust?</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドウ、トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みち</p> <p id='words'>街道(かいどう): highway<br>軌道(きどう): orbit, railroad track<br>使い道(つかいみち): use<br>道場(どうじょう): dojo, hall used for martial arts training, mandala<br>報道(ほうどう): information, report<br>片道(かたみち): one-way (trip)<br>書道(しょどう): calligraphy<br>赤道(せきどう): equator<br>鉄道(てつどう): railroad<br>道徳(どうとく): morals<br>道路(どうろ): road, highway<br>歩道(ほどう): footpath, walkway, sidewalk<br>回り道(まわりみち): detour, diversion<br>道順(みちじゅん): itinerary, route<br>柔道(じゅうどう): judo<br>水道(すいどう): water works<br>道具(どうぐ): tool<br>道(みち): road, street, way, method</p> <p id='readingExamples'>道路 (どうろ), 道徳 (どうとく), 報道 (ほうどう), 道 (みち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>296</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>278</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>296</p> <p id='keyword'>guidance</p> <p id='kanji'>導</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B08E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>guidance, neck, horns, drop, eye, road, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When we accept someone's <b>guidance</b>, we permit ourselves to be <i>glued</i> to a certain <i>road</i> or <i>way</i> of doing something, and try to ""stick"" to it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Good guidance will help you stay glued to the right path.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みちび.く</p> <p id='words'>主導(しゅどう): main leadership<br>導入(どうにゅう): introduction, bringing in, leading in<br>導く(みちびく): to be guided, to be shown<br>誘導(ゆうどう): guidance, leading, induction, introduction, incitement, inducement<br>指導(しどう): leadership, guidance, coaching</p> <p id='readingExamples'>導く (みちび.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>297</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>279</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>297</p> <p id='keyword'>crossing</p> <p id='kanji'>辻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BEBB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crossing, cross, ten, needle, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take the first two strokes in the sense we gave them back in frame 10, as the pictograph of a <i>cross</i>, and set it on a <i>road</i> to create a ""<b>crossing</b>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Cross-road.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji appears in the remarkable compound, 辻斬り 【つじぎり】 (n): killing a passerby in order to test a new sword. Imagine a cross by the road, at a busy crossing, marking the spot of the unfortunate passerby´s death.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'></p> <p id='kunYomi'>つじ</p> <p id='words'>辻褄(つじつま): coherence, consistency</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>298</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>280</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>298</p> <p id='keyword'>swift</p> <p id='kanji'>迅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BF85.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>swift, fishhook, cross, ten, needle, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we see a <i>crossing</i> in the form of a barbed <i>fishhook</i>, suggesting a <b>swifter</b> alternate not only to the roundabouts used in Europe but also to the ""cloverleaf"" design used on superhighways in the United States.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image ten giant fish hooks sweeping across the road, with our hapless hero ´froggy´ forced to make a swift crossing or end up as fish bait.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>迅速(じんそく): quick, fast, rapid, swift, prompt</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>299</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>281</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>299</p> <p id='keyword'>create</p> <p id='kanji'>造</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E980A0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>create, revelation, cow, mouth, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of <b>creating</b> as making something out of nothing. Then recall how the <i>way</i> of <i>revelation</i> laid out in the Bible begins with the story of how God <b>created</b> the world out of a dark and chaotic nothingness.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>CREATION is the ROAD to REVELATION (if you´re feeling artsy) :).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゾウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つく.る、つく.り、-づく.り</p> <p id='words'>偽造(ぎぞう): forgery, falsification, fabrication, counterfeiting<br>創造(そうぞう): creation<br>造り(つくり): make up, structure, physique<br>荷造り(にづくり): packing, baling, crating<br>改造(かいぞう): remodeling<br>構造(こうぞう): structure, construction<br>人造(じんぞう): man-made, synthetic, artificial<br>製造(せいぞう): manufacture, production<br>造船(ぞうせん): shipbuilding<br>造る(つくる): make, create, manufacture, draw up, write, compose, build, organize, establish</p> <p id='readingExamples'>造る (つく.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>300</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>282</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>300</p> <p id='keyword'>urge</p> <p id='kanji'>迫</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BFAB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>urge, white, dove, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To <b>urge</b> someone to do something, you make the <i>way</i> as appealing as possible, perhaps even <i>white</i>washing it a bit.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you have the URGE to go to White Castle, you know it´s time to hit the road.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you start down the road of cocaine, you´re sure to feel some pretty bad URGEs soon.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>せま.る</p> <p id='words'>圧迫(あっぱく): pressure, coercion, oppression<br>脅迫(きょうはく): threat, menace, coercion, terrorism<br>迫害(はくがい): persecution<br>迫る(せまる): draw near, press</p> <p id='readingExamples'>迫る (せま.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>301</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>283</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>301</p> <p id='keyword'>escape</p> <p id='kanji'>逃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98083.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>escape, turtle, portent, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When <b>escaping</b> from something or someone, one always feels as if one is not going fast enough, like a <i>turtle</i> on an expressway. (Since the <i>turtle</i> is on the <i>road</i> and not on the left, it can keep its full kanji shape as given in frame 250.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to escape from prison; hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A turtle version of frogger dodging cars to escape to the other side of the road...　　　RTK2:　トウ　逃走　とうそう(escape)...　　　　　　　MIXED GROUP:　桃236　(ﾁｮｳ): 兆235　眺237　挑658　跳1284.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>に.げる、に.がす、のが.す、のが.れる</p> <p id='words'>逃走(とうそう): flight, desertion, escape<br>逃亡(とうぼう): escape<br>逃げ出す(にげだす): to run away, to escape from<br>逃す(のがす): to let loose, to set free, to let escape<br>逃れる(のがれる): to escape<br>見逃す(みのがす): to miss, to overlook, to leave at large<br>逃がす(にがす): let loose, set free, let escape<br>逃げる(にげる): run away</p> <p id='readingExamples'>逃がす (に.がす), 逃げる (に.げる), 逃す (のが.す), 逃れる (のが.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>302</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>284</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>302</p> <p id='keyword'>environs</p> <p id='kanji'>辺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BEBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>environs, dagger, sword, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To keep the <b>environs</b> clean and safe, you could cement <i>daggers</i>&nbsp;in the <i>road</i>, blades pointed upwards, so that no polluting traffic could pass by. To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To protect the environs around their village, samurai would travel the roads with their swords.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あた.り、ほと.り、-べ</p> <p id='words'>対辺(たいへん): (geometrical) opposite side<br>浜辺(はまべ): beach, foreshore<br>辺り(ほとり): (in the) neighbourhood, vicinity, nearby<br>辺り(あたり): neighbourhood, vicinity, nearby<br>周辺(しゅうへん): circumference, outskirts, environs, (computer) peripheral<br>辺(へん): side, part, area, vicinity</p> <p id='readingExamples'>辺境 (へんきょう), 周辺 (しゅうへん), その辺 (そのへん), 辺り (あた.り), 辺 (べ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>304</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>286</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>304</p> <p id='keyword'>car</p> <p id='kanji'>車</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BB8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>car, sun, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You may keep the whole range of connotations for this keyword, <b>car</b>, provided it does not interfere with the pictograph. Look for the front and back wheels (the first and last horizontal strokes) and the seat in the carriage in the middle. As an exercise, try to isolate the primitives on your own and make a story out of them.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* <i>Car</i>, <i>cart</i>, <i>wagon</i>, and <i>vehicle</i> may all be used as primitive meanings.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Rather than hobbling along with a walking stick to cross through a span, it´s much better to use a car. (Imagine an old man with a walking stick creeping along a span of road, and you, in a car, whizzing right by him. It´s funny ´cause it´s true.) Also, it´s important to include the word ""through,"" so you know the walking stick goes right THROUGH the span.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くるま</p> <p id='words'>風車(かざぐるま): windmill, pinwheel<br>機関車(きかんしゃ): locomotive, engine<br>下車(げしゃ): alighting, getting off<br>車庫(しゃこ): garage<br>車掌(しゃしょう): (train) conductor<br>車輪(しゃりん): (car) wheel<br>乗車(じょうしゃ): taking a train<br>駐車(ちゅうしゃ): parking (e.g. car)<br>停車(ていしゃ): stopping (e.g. train)<br>歯車(はぐるま): gear, cog-wheel<br>発車(はっしゃ): departure of a vehicle<br>列車(れっしゃ): train (ordinary)<br>汽車(きしゃ): train (locomotive)<br>駐車場(ちゅうしゃじょう): parking lot<br>車(くるま): car, vehicle, wheel<br>自転車(じてんしゃ): bicycle<br>自動車(じどうしゃ): automobile<br>電車(でんしゃ): electric train</p> <p id='readingExamples'>車 (くるま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>305</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>287</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>305</p> <p id='keyword'>take along</p> <p id='kanji'>連</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E980A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>jeepney</p> <p id='constituent'>take along, car, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>What you are meant to <b>take along</b> in this kanji are not things but people. The image of the <i>car</i> on the <i>road</i> should ground your image for picking up your friends to <i>take</i> them <i>along</i> to wherever you are going.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don´t confuse with carry (#303).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji also means ""linked"" or ""series"" so I´ve changed the kanji meaning to ""GO ALONG (WITH EACH OTHER)."" Well, a ROAD and a CAR certainly GO ALONG with each other. And the CAR will help you to GO ALONG the ROAD. This Kanji is the ""Union"" in Soviet Union and the ""United"" of United Nations (the countries that ""go along with each other"" at least some of the time).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>レン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つら.なる、つら.ねる、つ.れる、-づ.れ</p> <p id='words'>一連(いちれん): a series, a chain, a ream (of paper)<br>国連(こくれん): U.N., United Nations<br>連なる(つらなる): to extend, to stretch out, to stand in a row<br>連ねる(つらねる): to link, to join, to put together<br>連休(れんきゅう): consecutive holidays<br>連日(れんじつ): every day, prolonged<br>連中(れんじゅう): colleagues, company, a lot<br>連帯(れんたい): solidarity<br>連邦(れんぽう): commonwealth, federation of states<br>連盟(れんめい): league, union, alliance<br>連絡(れんらく): junction, communication, connection, coordination<br>関連(かんれん): relation, connection, relevance<br>連れ(つれ): companion, company<br>連合(れんごう): union, alliance<br>連想(れんそう): association (of ideas), suggestion<br>連続(れんぞく): serial, consecutive, continuity, occurring in succession, continuing<br>連れる(つれる): bring</p> <p id='readingExamples'>連れる (つ.れる), 連なる (つら.なる), 連ねる (つら.ねる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>307</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>289</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>307</p> <p id='keyword'>transport</p> <p id='kanji'>輸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BCB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>transport, car, meeting of butchers, umbrella, one, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>On the left we see a <i>vehicle</i> used for <b>transport</b>. On the right, we see a new tangle of elements that need sorting out. The first three strokes, you will remember, are the primitive for <i>meeting</i>. Below it we see the elements for <i>flesh</i> and <i>saber</i>, which combine to create a compound element for a <i>butcher</i> and his trade. Together they give us the image of a ""trucker's convoy.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The car is a cattle-car, used to transport animals for the butcher´s meeting - a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The vehicle transports animals for a meeting with the butcher.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユ、シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>運輸(うんゆ): transportation<br>輸血(ゆけつ): blood transfusion<br>輸送(ゆそう): transport, transportation<br>輸入(ゆにゅう): importation, import, introduction<br>輸出(ゆしゅつ): export</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>309</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>290</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>309</p> <p id='keyword'>in front</p> <p id='kanji'>前</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5898D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>in front, horns, butcher, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We waited to introduce this character until now, even though the pieces have been available for some time, because it helps to reinforce the odd kanji of the last frame. Picture the <i>butcher</i> hacking away with his knife at a slab of meat on his table with a pair of ram's <i>horns</i> placed <b>in front</b> of him (or on his head, if you prefer). There is no need to worry about confusing this kanji with that for <i>before</i> (Frame 263), since it will not appear as a primitive in any other character used in this book.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When I get horny my flesh sword sticks out in front of me.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you stand in front of a bull´s horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゼン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まえ、-まえ</p> <p id='words'>当たり前(あたりまえ): usual, common, ordinary, natural, reasonable, obvious<br>腕前(うでまえ): ability, skill, facility<br>事前(じぜん): prior, beforehand, in advance<br>前(せん): before<br>前提(ぜんてい): preamble, premise, reason, prerequisite<br>前途(ぜんと): future prospects, outlook, the journey ahead<br>前例(ぜんれい): precedent<br>建前(たてまえ): face, official stance, public position or attitude (as opposed to private thoughts)<br>前売り(まえうり): advance sale, booking<br>前置き(まえおき): preface, introduction<br>前もって(まえもって): in advance, beforehand, previously<br>真ん前(まんまえ): right in front, under the nose<br>以前(いぜん): ago, since, before, previous<br>前後(ぜんご): around, throughout, front and back, before and behind, before and after, about that (time), longitudinal, context, nearly, approximately<br>前者(ぜんしゃ): the former<br>前進(ぜんしん): advance, drive, progress<br>直前(ちょくぜん): just before<br>手前(てまえ): before, this side, we, you<br>午前(ごぜん): morning, A.M.<br>名前(なまえ): name<br>前(まえ): front</p> <p id='readingExamples'>前 (まえ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>311</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>291</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>311</p> <p id='keyword'>each</p> <p id='kanji'>各</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59084.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>each, walking legs, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""Suum cuique"" goes the popular Latin proverb. A certain disease of the English language makes it almost impossible to translate the phrase without gender bias. In any event, here we see someone walking with his/her <i>mouth</i> between his/her <i>walking legs</i>, giving us an image of ""To <b>each</b> his/her own.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The sense of the proverb should help when using this kanji as a primitive; otherwise, reduce it to its original elements. But do not associate it in any way with the word ""every,"" which we shall meet later in another context.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Son, I´ve never told you this but each woman has a second mouth between their fiiiiiine walking legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Each and every one of us walks and talks differently.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おのおの</p> <p id='words'>各種(かくしゅ): every kind, all sorts<br>各々(それぞれ): each, every, either, respectively, severally<br>各々(おのおの): each, every, either, respectively, severally<br>各自(かくじ): individual, each<br>各地(かくち): every place, various places</p> <p id='readingExamples'>各 (おのおの)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>312</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>292</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>312</p> <p id='keyword'>status</p> <p id='kanji'>格</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A0BC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>status, tree, wood, each, walking legs, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>If you can imagine <i>trees</i> as <b>status</b> symbols (as they might well be for those living in Japan's congested cities, where greenery has become something of a luxury item), then <i>each</i> might be aiming to have his/her own <i>tree</i>, just to keep up with the Suzukis.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree. ""Errr, Each tree sir?"" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. ""That´s Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A man measures his own status by the size of his woody...and compares it to each one he sees.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク、コウ、キャク、ゴウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>格(かく): status, character, case<br>格差(かくさ): qualitative difference, disparity<br>格好(かっこう): shape, form, appearance, manner<br>規格(きかく): standard, norm<br>資格(しかく): qualifications, requirements, capabilities<br>失格(しっかく): disqualification, elimination, incapacity (legal)<br>人格(じんかく): personality, character, individuality<br>体格(たいかく): physique, constitution<br>本格(ほんかく): propriety, fundamental rules<br>価格(かかく): price, value, cost<br>格別(かくべつ): exceptional<br>合格(ごうかく): success, passing (e.g. exam), eligibility<br>性格(せいかく): character, personality<br>同格(どうかく): the same rank, equality, apposition</p> <p id='readingExamples'>格式 (かくしき), 規格 (きかく), 性格 (せいかく)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>314</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>293</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>314</p> <p id='keyword'>abbreviation</p> <p id='kanji'>略</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E795A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>abbreviation, rice field, brains, each, walking legs, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Each field</i> has its own <b>abbreviations</b> (chemistry, philosophy, sports, etc.). Needless to say, the ""stronger"" primitive - thatis to say, the simpler and more often used one - takes the dominant position on the left, even though the story would read them off the other way around.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There are so many abbreviations and acronyms nowadays that no brain can remember each of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A very anal farmer wants to catologue each grain of rice in his rice field. Imagine him scribbling a tiny abbreviation of his name and a number on each grain.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>リャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほぼ、おか.す、おさ.める、はかりごと、はか.る、はぶ.く、りゃく.す、りゃく.する</p> <p id='words'>概略(がいりゃく): outline, summary, gist, in brief<br>侵略(しんりゃく): aggression, invasion, raid<br>略語(りゃくご): abbreviation, acronym<br>略奪(りゃくだつ): pillage, plunder, looting, robbery<br>省略(しょうりゃく): omission, abbreviation, abridgment<br>略す(りゃくす): abbreviate</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>315</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>294</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>315</p> <p id='keyword'>guest</p> <p id='kanji'>客</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AEA2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>guest, house, each, walking legs, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When you are a <b>guest</b> in a courteous town, <i>each house</i>hold has its own way of welcoming you, and <i>each house</i> becomes your home.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Each person under my roof is treated as a guest.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In my house I welcome each guest.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キャク、カク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>客(きゃく): guest, customer<br>客観(きゃっかん): objective<br>乗客(じょうかく): passenger<br>旅客(りょかく): passenger (transport)<br>観客(かんきゃく): audience, spectator(s)<br>客席(きゃくせき): guest seating<br>客間(きゃくま): parlor, guest room<br>乗客(じょうきゃく): passenger<br>客(きゃく): guest</p> <p id='readingExamples'>客間 (きゃくま), 客車 (きゃくしゃ), 乗客 (じょうきゃく)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>316</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>295</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>316</p> <p id='keyword'>forehead</p> <p id='kanji'>額</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A18D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>forehead, guest, house, each, walking legs, mouth, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As Miss Manners will be the first to tell you, out of respect, one does not look straight into the eyes of one's <i>guests</i>, but focus on the top button of their collar. Here, however, you are told to look above the eyes to the <b>forehead</b> of your <i>guest</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their foreheads together.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひたい</p> <p id='words'>差額(さがく): balance, difference, margin<br>額(がく): picture (framed), amount (of money)<br>金額(きんがく): amount of money<br>額(ひたい): forehead, brow</p> <p id='readingExamples'>額 (ひたい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>317</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>296</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>317</p> <p id='keyword'>summer</p> <p id='kanji'>夏</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A48F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>summer, one, ceiling, drop, eye, walking legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In the <b>summer</b>, fatigued by the heat, your <i>head</i> hangs down nearly as far as your <i>walking legs</i>, or rather, your ""dragging legs."" Note how the <i>walking legs</i> (instead of ""animal legs"") are the only thing that distinguishes this character from that for <i>page</i> (Frame 64).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I personally think it was too confusing to try and use head as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the animal legs are replaced with walking legs instead of human legs?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot summer and you want to keep oneself under a ceiling not out jogging around.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ、ガ、ゲ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なつ</p> <p id='words'>夏(なつ): summer<br>夏休み(なつやすみ): summer vacation, summer holiday</p> <p id='readingExamples'>夏季 (かき), 初夏 (しょか), 盛夏 (せいか), 夏 (なつ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>318</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>297</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>318</p> <p id='keyword'>dispose</p> <p id='kanji'>処</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E587A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dispose, walking legs, wind</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Both the stretching out of the <i>walking legs</i> and the little bit of <i>wind</i> tucked in on the right suggest using one's legs to kick something out of the way, or <b>dispose</b> of it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To dispose of rubbish you should walk it to the bin not throw it to the wind.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ところ、-こ、お.る</p> <p id='words'>彼処(あそこ): (uk) there, over there, that place, (X) (col) genitals<br>処置(しょち): treatment<br>処罰(しょばつ): punishment<br>処分(しょぶん): disposal, dealing, punishment<br>其処(そこ): that place, there<br>其処で(そこで): so (conj), accordingly, now, then, thereupon<br>其処ら(そこら): everywhere, somewhere, approximately, that area, around there<br>対処(たいしょ): deal with, cope<br>処理(しょり): processing, dealing with, treatment, disposition, disposal</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>319</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>298</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>319</p> <p id='keyword'>twig</p> <p id='kanji'>条</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69DA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>twig, walking legs, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Geppetto made <i>walking legs</i> for his little Pinocchio from two <b>twigs</b> of a <i>tree</i>, giving him a set of ""<b>twiggy</b>"" shanks.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>They all say they have a TREE between their WALKING LEGS but most only have a TWIG.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don´t confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping twigs. A twig is always the kind of wood that snaps when the hunter´s walking legs just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter´s presence.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ、チョウ、デキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>えだ、すじ</p> <p id='words'>箇条書き(かじょうがき): itemized form, itemization<br>条約(じょうやく): treaty, pact<br>発条(ばね): spring (e.g. coil leaf)<br>条件(じょうけん): conditions, terms</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>320</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>299</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>320</p> <p id='keyword'>fall</p> <p id='kanji'>落</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E890BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fall, flowers, water, water droplets, water pistol, each, walking legs, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When <i>water</i> <b>falls</b>, it splats and splashes; when <i>flower</i> petals <b>fall</b>, they float gently in the breeze. To <i>each</i> thing its own way of <b>falling</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[It´s been suggested on the forum (http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079) that flower across the full width of the kanji and water on the left below it should have its own keyword; seaweed is a popular choice. See also dilute (#227), clan (#1912), seaweed (#2035). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers falling through the sky -- suddenly each one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori seaweed to carry them safely down.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ラク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.ちる、お.ち、お.とす</p> <p id='words'>お洒落(おしゃれ): smartly dressed, someone smartly dressed, fashion-conscious<br>落ち込む(おちこむ): to fall into, to feel down (sad)<br>落ち着き(おちつき): calm, composure<br>落ち葉(おちば): fallen leaves, leaf litter, defoliation, shedding leaves<br>洒落(しゃらく): frank, open-hearted<br>洒落る(しゃれる): to joke, to play on words, to dress stylishly<br>墜落(ついらく): falling, crashing<br>転落(てんらく): fall, degradation, slump<br>没落(ぼつらく): ruin, fall, collapse<br>見落とす(みおとす): to overlook, to fail to notice<br>落下(らっか): fall, drop, come down<br>落着く(おちつく): calm down, settle in, be steady<br>落し物(おとしもの): lost property<br>洒落(しゃれ): frank, open-hearted<br>落第(らくだい): failure, dropping out of a class<br>落ちる(おちる): fall, drop, come down<br>落とす(おとす): drop, let fall</p> <p id='readingExamples'>落ちる (お.ちる), 落とす (お.とす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>321</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>300</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>321</p> <p id='keyword'>superfluous</p> <p id='kanji'>冗</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58697.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>superfluous, crown, weathercock, wind</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Picture a <i>weather vane</i> beneath a regal <i>crown</i>, spinning round and round. It is not only <b>superfluous</b> but makes a perfect ass out of the one who wears it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The king´s crown was blown off by the wind. ""Oh well,"" he said, ""it´s just a superfluous symbol."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The court jester wears a crown and is full of wind with bad jokes. He is superfluous to the King´s court. This kanji is read as ""JOU"" and commonly used to create the compound for jou-dan 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also jou-go 冗語 (redundancy) and jou-in 冗員 (useless workers) 員-employee (#56).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>冗談(じょうだん): jest, joke</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>323</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>301</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>323</p> <p id='keyword'>army</p> <p id='kanji'>軍</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BB8D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>army, chariot, crown, vehicle, car</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>crowned vehicle</i> depicted here is a ""<i>chariot</i>,"" symbol of an <b>army</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Used as a primitive this kanji means only <i>chariot</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>British army cars are at the service of the crown.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine a crown is the hood ornament on every army car.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>グン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>軍(いくさ): war, battle, campaign, fight<br>軍艦(ぐんかん): warship, battleship<br>軍事(ぐんじ): military affairs<br>軍備(ぐんび): armaments, military preparations<br>軍服(ぐんぷく): military or naval uniform<br>軍(ぐん): army, force, troops<br>軍隊(ぐんたい): army, troops</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>324</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>302</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>324</p> <p id='keyword'>radiance</p> <p id='kanji'>輝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BC9D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>radiance, ray, small, little, human legs, army, chariot, crown, vehicle, car</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take advantage of the first syllable of the key word to think of the <i>ray</i> of light to the left. Now add the glittering <i>chariot</i> that is emitting those <i>rays</i> and you have <b>radiance</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Rays of light emitted from Apollo´s chariot = radiance. Don´t put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Radiance is an army of rays.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かがや.く</p> <p id='words'>輝く(かがやく): shine, glitter, sparkle</p> <p id='readingExamples'>輝く (かがや.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>325</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>303</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>325</p> <p id='keyword'>carry</p> <p id='kanji'>運</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9818B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>carry, army, chariot, crown, vehicle, car, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A long string of ""sweet"" <i>chariots</i> ""swinging low"" to our <i>roads</i> is a sure sign that the Lord is ""comin' for to <b>carry</b>"" someone home.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Roads carry armies (in contrast to seas carrying navies or skies carrying air forces).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ウン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はこ.ぶ</p> <p id='words'>運輸(うんゆ): transportation<br>運用(うんよう): making use of, application, investment, practical use<br>運営(うんえい): management, administration, operation<br>運送(うんそう): shipping, marine transportation<br>運賃(うんちん): freight rates, shipping expenses, fare<br>運搬(うんぱん): transport, carriage<br>運命(うんめい): fate<br>海運(かいうん): maritime, marine transportation<br>運(うん): fortune, luck<br>運河(うんが): canal<br>運転(うんてん): operation, motion, driving<br>運動(うんどう): motion, exercise<br>幸運(こううん): good luck, fortune<br>不運(ふうん): unlucky, misfortune, bad luck, fate<br>運転手(うんてんしゅ): drive<br>運ぶ(はこぶ): bring</p> <p id='readingExamples'>運ぶ (はこ.ぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>326</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>304</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>326</p> <p id='keyword'>crown</p> <p id='kanji'>冠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E586A0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crown, beginning, two, human legs, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>By having the <b>crown</b> pass from one age to the next, a people keeps itself <i>glued</i> to its <i>beginnings</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying ""i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A crown, from the beginning of the new king´s life, is glued to him. He must inherit it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かんむり</p> <p id='words'>冠(かん): crown, diadem, first, best, peerless, cap, naming, designating, initiating on coming of age, top character radical<br>冠(かんむり): crown, cap, first, best, peerless, naming, designating, top kanji radical</p> <p id='readingExamples'>冠 (かんむり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>327</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>305</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>327</p> <p id='keyword'>dream</p> <p id='kanji'>夢</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A4A2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dream, flowers, eye, cross-eyed, net, crown, evening</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To have a <b>dream</b> after going to bed is really the <i>crown</i> to a perfect <i>evening</i>. The <i>flower</i> petals over the <i>eyes</i> (instead of the ""sand"" that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning) only confirms the image of a pleasant <b>dream</b> suggested by the rest of this rather complex kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Last night´s date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the movie American Beauty, Kevin Spacey liked to DREAM about his daughter´s friend and have a rose petal fall onto his eye from the ceiling. He did this lying in his bed each evening. You can almost see him lying in his bed in this kanji.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ム、ボウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆめ、ゆめ.みる、くら.い</p> <p id='words'>夢中(むちゅう): daze, (in a) trance, ecstasy, delirium, engrossment<br>夢(ゆめ): dream</p> <p id='readingExamples'>夢 (ゆめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>328</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>306</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>328</p> <p id='keyword'>pit</p> <p id='kanji'>坑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59D91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pit, soil, dirt, ground, whirlwind, top hat, wind</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A <i>whirlwind</i> begins to dig its way into the <i>soil</i> like a drill until it makes a deep <b>pit</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a pit into the soil. Note: Take care difference between pit and rut.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>329</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>307</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>329</p> <p id='keyword'>tall</p> <p id='kanji'>高</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9AB98.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>a beefeater piggybacking another</p> <p id='constituent'>tall, top hat, mouth, alien, hood, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Recalling an image from frame 195, first see the <i>mouth</i> under the extraterrestrial's glass <i>hood</i>, and then the <i>mouth</i> under the <i>top hat</i> of one of his mates who has tried on the strange earthling's headgear only to find that it makes him look much, much <b>taller</b> than everyone else.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character keeps its sense of <i>tall</i> and its position at the top of other primitives, but its writing is abbreviated to the first 5 strokes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a TALL hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たか.い、たか、-だか、たか.まる、たか.める</p> <p id='words'>高原(こうげん): tableland, plateau<br>高尚(こうしょう): high, noble, refined, advanced<br>高等学校(こうとうがっこう): senior high school<br>残高(ざんだか): (bank) balance, remainder<br>高(たか): quantity, amount, volume, number, amount of money<br>高まる(たかまる): to rise, to swell, to be promoted<br>名高い(なだかい): famous, celebrated, well-known<br>高価(こうか): high price<br>高級(こうきゅう): high class, high grade<br>高層(こうそう): upper<br>高速(こうそく): high speed, high gear<br>高度(こうど): altitude, height, advanced<br>高等(こうとう): high class, high grade<br>最高(さいこう): highest, supreme, the most<br>高める(たかめる): raise, lift, boost<br>高校(こうこう): high school<br>高校生(こうこうせい): high school student<br>高い(たかい): tall, high, expensive</p> <p id='readingExamples'>高 (たか), 高い (たか.い), 高まる (たか.まる), 高める (たか.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>330</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>308</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>330</p> <p id='keyword'>receive</p> <p id='kanji'>享</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BAAB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>receive, tall, top hat, mouth, children</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Tall children</i> <b>receive</b> more attention. <i>Tall children</i> grow up to make better wide <b>receivers</b>. Take your pick, depending on whether you prefer child psychology or American football. At any rate, be sure you have some particular <i>tall child</i> in mind, someone who really was outstanding and always attracting attention, because he or she will come in handy in the next two frames.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tall children receive all the attention. They also make great receivers in football... this kanji also means ´catch´ (therefore a football receiver is a great image).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ、コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>う.ける</p> <p id='words'>享受(きょうじゅ): reception, acceptance, enjoyment, being given</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>331</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>309</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>331</p> <p id='keyword'>cram school</p> <p id='kanji'>塾</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A1BE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cram school, receive, tall, top hat, mouth, child, children, round, nine, baseball, drop, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Cram schools</b> are after-hours educational institutions where kids can do concentrated preparing for their coming entrance examinations or drill what they missed during regular class hours. The exception are the <i>tall children</i> who are out on the school <i>grounds</i> practicing sports, and the <i>fat</i> ones who are out there burning off calories. So this character depicts those who do NOT go to the <b>cram schools</b>, rather than those who do.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You can receive a well-rounded education if you study at our cram school says the advertisement. ""Just come to our school grounds and check it out yourself!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>塾(じゅく): coaching school, lessons</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

(Note that here the keyword ´mellow´ only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill; not the colloquial meaning of ´chill out´).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>う.れる</p> <p id='words'>成熟(せいじゅく): maturity, ripeness<br>未熟(みじゅく): inexperience, unripeness, raw, unskilled, immature, inexperienced<br>熟語(じゅくご): idiom, idiomatic phrase, kanji compound</p> <p id='readingExamples'>熟れる (う.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>339</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>317</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>339</p> <p id='keyword'>circumference</p> <p id='kanji'>周</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E591A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>circumference, glass hood, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Look more closely at your <i>lidded crock</i> and you will see little ruler marks along its bottom edge. This is so you can use it to calculate the <b>circumference</b> of your <i>motorcycle helmet</i>: just begin at a fixed point and turn the <i>lidded crock</i> around and around, keeping it flush against the side of the <i>helmet</i>, until you come back to your starting point. If you kept track of how many turns and part-turns your <i>lidded crock</i> made, you now know the <b>circumference</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character can take the added significance of a <i>lap</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You´re at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the circumference of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まわ.り</p> <p id='words'>周(しゅう): circuit, lap, circumference, vicinity, Chou (dynasty)<br>周期(しゅうき): cycle, period<br>円周(えんしゅう): circumference<br>周囲(しゅうい): circumference, surroundings, environs<br>周辺(しゅうへん): circumference, outskirts, environs, (computer) peripheral<br>周り(まわり): surroundings</p> <p id='readingExamples'>周り (まわ.り)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>341</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>319</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>341</p> <p id='keyword'>gentleman</p> <p id='kanji'>士</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A3AB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>gentleman, gentleman, samurai</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for <i>soil</i> by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's <b>gentlemen</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning reverts to the more colorful image of the <i>samurai</i>, Japan's warrior class.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He´s like a modern samurai!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A gentleman has broad shoulders and doesn´t soil himself.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>学士(がくし): university graduate<br>修士(しゅうし): Masters degree program<br>紳士(しんし): gentleman<br>同士(どうし): fellow, companion, comrade<br>兵士(へいし): soldier<br>博士(はかせ): doctorate, PhD<br>武士(ぶし): warrior, samurai</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
