	"<p id='id'>351</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>329</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>351</p> <p id='keyword'>breed</p> <p id='kanji'>牧</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E789A7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>breed, cow, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When it is time to <b>breed</b> new cattle, the bull is usually willing but the <i>cow</i> is often not. Thus the <i>taskmaster</i> to the right forces the <i>cow</i> into a compromising position, so to speak, so that she and her mate can <b>breed</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to ""start breeding, and start doing it now!"", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hint: This is the kanji from which taskmaster is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with breed, and a lot to do with pastures and shepherds (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don´t differenciate between animals). Think of a cowboy (taskmaster) who brings his cows to the pasture.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まき</p> <p id='words'>牧師(ぼくし): pastor, minister, clergyman<br>遊牧(ゆうぼく): nomadism<br>牧場(ぼくじょう): farm (livestock), pasture land, meadow, grazing land<br>牧畜(ぼくちく): stock-farming</p> <p id='readingExamples'>牧 (まき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>354</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>332</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>354</p> <p id='keyword'>a sheet of</p> <p id='kanji'>枚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69E9A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sheet of…, tree, wood, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>English counts thin, flat objects, like bed linen and paper, in <b>sheets</b>. 	"<p id='id'>355</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>333</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>355</p> <p id='keyword'>happenstance</p> <p id='kanji'>故</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69585.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>happenstance, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Call it fate or providence or plain old Lady Luck, <b>happenstance</b> is the <i>oldest taskmaster</i> we know. It nearly always has its way.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Need to disambiguate from enemy (#443) as it´s easy to mix up antique and old here. Let´s think of an accidental president -- he is an old taskmaster who has managed to win the election by happenstance .</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆえ、ふる.い、もと</p> <p id='words'>故(こ): the late (deceased)<br>故人(こじん): the deceased, old friend<br>其れ故(それゆえ): therefore, for that reason, so<br>何故(なぜ): why, how<br>故郷(こきょう): home town, birthplace, old or historic village<br>故障(こしょう): breakdown<br>事故(じこ): accident</p> <p id='readingExamples'>故 (ゆえ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>356</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>334</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>356</p> <p id='keyword'>awe</p> <p id='kanji'>敬</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E695AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>awe, flowers, phrase, bound up, mouth, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Standing in <b>awe</b> of someone, you get self-conscious and may try to speak in <i>flowery phrases</i> out of veneration or fear. The <i>taskmaster</i> at the right is drilling you in the practice of your ""honorifics.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The flowery phrases of the schoolmaster held the students in awe.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>敬 【けい】 (n) reverence; respect. 敬語 【けいご】 (n) honorific; term of respect; (P) STORY: The TASKMASTER demands RESPECT. If you don´t talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ、キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うやま.う</p> <p id='words'>敬具(けいぐ): Sincerely yours<br>敬う(うやまう): show respect, to honour<br>敬意(けいい): respect, honour<br>敬語(けいご): honorific, term of respect<br>尊敬(そんけい): respect, esteem, reverence, honour</p> <p id='readingExamples'>敬う (うやま.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>357</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>335</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>357</p> <p id='keyword'>say</p> <p id='kanji'>言</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A880.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>say, words, keitai, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Of all the things we can do with our <i>mouths</i>, speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the kanji for <b>say</b> has four little sound-waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* This kanji, which appears often as a primitive, can mean <i>saying</i>, <i>speech</i>, or <i>words</i>, depending on which is most useful.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is simple a pictogram of a mouth SAYing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲン、ゴン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い.う、こと</p> <p id='words'>言い訳(いいわけ): excuse, explanation<br>一言(いちげん): single word<br>片言(かたこと): a smattering, talk like a baby, speak haltingly<br>予言(かねごと): prediction, promise, prognostication<br>言論(げんろん): discussion<br>言伝(ことづて): declaration, hearsay<br>証言(しょうげん): evidence, testimony<br>助言(じょげん): advice, suggestion<br>宣言(せんげん): declaration, proclamation, announcement<br>断言(だんげん): declaration, affirmation<br>伝言(つてごと): verbal message, rumor, word<br>発言(はつげん): utterance, speech, proposal<br>無言(むごん): silence<br>言い出す(いいだす): start talking, propose, suggest, break the ice<br>言い付ける(いいつける): tell, tell on (someone), to order, to charge, to direct<br>言わば(いわば): so to speak, so to call it, as it were<br>言語(げんご): language<br>言付ける(ことづける): send word, send a message<br>言葉遣い(ことばづかい): speech, expression, wording<br>一言(ひとこと): single word<br>独り言(ひとりごと): soliloquy, monologue, speaking to oneself<br>方言(ほうげん): dialect<br>言う(いう): to say<br>言葉(ことば): word(s), phrase, language, speech</p> <p id='readingExamples'>言行 (げんこう), 言論 (げんろん), 宣言 (せんげん), 言う (い.う), 言 (こと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>358</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>336</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>358</p> <p id='keyword'>admonish</p> <p id='kanji'>警</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8ADA6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>admonish, awe, flowers, phrase, bound up, mouth, taskmaster, say, words, keitai, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here you have a perfect example of how an apparently impossible snarl of strokes becomes a snap to learn once you know its elements. The idea of being <b>admonished</b> for something already sets up a superior-inferior relationship between you and the person you are supposed to stand in <i>awe</i> of. While you are restricted to answering in honorifics, the superior can use straightforward and ordinary <i>words</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Watch in awe as mom admonishes the rude clerk with words that you´ve never heard her use before.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いまし.める</p> <p id='words'>警戒(けいかい): warning, admonition, vigilance<br>警部(けいぶ): police inspector<br>警告(けいこく): warning, advice<br>警備(けいび): defense, guard, policing, security<br>警官(けいかん): policeman<br>警察(けいさつ): police</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>361</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>338</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>361</p> <p id='keyword'>prison</p> <p id='kanji'>獄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78D84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>prison, pack of wild dogs, say, words, keitai, mouth, chihuahua, dog, large, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Although we did not make note of it at the time, the kanji for <i>dog</i> is also a low-grade term for a spy. And later (Frame 1517) we will meet another association of criminals with <i>dogs</i>. The <b>prison</b> here depicts a <i>pack of wild dogs</i> (the long-timers and hardened criminals) into which the poor little c<i>hihuahua</i> (first offender) has been cast. The only thing he has to protect himself against the pack are his shrill and frightened <i>words</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The only thing keeping the new chihuahua inmate from being ´initiated´ by the pack of wild dogs were his quick words in prison.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>地獄(じごく): hell</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>362</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>339</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>362</p> <p id='keyword'>revise</p> <p id='kanji'>訂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A882.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>nailing the word lists om the wall</p> <p id='constituent'>revise, say, words, keitai, mouth, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>After completing the first draft, you <b>revise</b> it by <i>nailing</i> down your <i>words</i> and ""hammering"" them into shape.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Remember how Martin Luther revised the words of the catholic church and nailed his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>改訂(かいてい): revision<br>訂正(ていせい): correction, revision</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>364</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>340</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>364</p> <p id='keyword'>chastise (attack, avenge)</p> <p id='kanji'>討</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A88E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>chastise, say, words, keitai, mouth, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Words</i> spoken to <b>chastise</b> us stick to us like <i>glue</i> in a way no other <i>words</i> can.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had words glued to them. A famous example is the ""A"" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, words glued to you are supposed to chastise you and prevent further breaches of chastity.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>う.つ</p> <p id='words'>討議(とうぎ): debate, discussion<br>討論(とうろん): debate, discussion<br>討つ(うつ): attack, avenge<br>検討(けんとう): consideration, examination, investigation, study, scrutiny</p> <p id='readingExamples'>討つ (う.つ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>365</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>341</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>365</p> <p id='keyword'>instruction</p> <p id='kanji'>訓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A893.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>instruction, say, words, keitai, mouth, stream, flood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The personalism connoted by the word <b>instruction</b>, as opposed to ""teaching"" or ""discipline,"" suits the picture here of <i>words</i> guiding one's progress like the gentle flowing of a <i>stream</i>. Even the etymology of the word <b>instruction</b> suggests the sense of ""pouring into"".</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Listen carefully to the words of instruction before you try swimming in the river.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>クン、キン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おし.える、よ.む、くん.ずる</p> <p id='words'>教訓(きょうくん): lesson, precept, moral instruction<br>訓(くん): native Japanese reading of a Chinese character<br>訓練(くんれん): practice, training</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>366</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>342</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>366</p> <p id='keyword'>imperial edict</p> <p id='kanji'>詔</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A994.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>hitlerswords seduce masses</p> <p id='constituent'>imperial edict, say, words, keitai, mouth, summon, seduce, sword, dagger, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>imperial edict</b>, spoken with the force of unquestionable law, is made up of <i>words</i> intended to <i>seduce</i> the masses - be it through fear or respect - to follow obediently.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The mnemonic ""words to seduce the masses"" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus ""seducing"" the masses.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The emperor did not need an imperial edict; his words were more than enough to seduce Anakin to the dark side.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みことのり</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>詔 (みことのり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>367</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>343</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>367</p> <p id='keyword'>packed</p> <p id='kanji'>詰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A9B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>packed, say, words, keitai, mouth, aerosol, good luck, samurai, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A piece of writing that is pregnant with meaning and needs to be reread several times to be understood we refer to colloquially as ""<b>packed</b>."" The character sees the <i>words</i> as sealed tightly inside an <i>aerosol can</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of words and aerosol cans and then makes sure the words get tightly packed inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キツ、キチ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つ.める、つ.め、-づ.め、つ.まる、つ.む</p> <p id='words'>詰らない(つまらない): insignificant, boring, trifling<br>詰まり(つまり): in short, in brief, in other words, that is to say, in the long run, after all, blockade, stuffing, ultimate<br>詰る(なじる): to rebuke, to scold, to tell off<br>缶詰(かんづめ): canning, canned goods, tin can<br>詰まる(つまる): be blocked, be packed<br>詰める(つめる): pack, shorten, work out (details)<br>瓶詰(びんづめ): bottling, bottled</p> <p id='readingExamples'>詰まる (つ.まる), 詰む (つ.む), 詰める (つ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>368</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>344</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>368</p> <p id='keyword'>tale</p> <p id='kanji'>話</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A9B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tale, say, words, keitai, mouth, tongue, thousand, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>That the <i>words</i> of the <i>tongue</i> should come to mean a <b>tale</b> is clear from the etymology: a <b><i>tale</i></b> is something ""talked,"" not something read from a book.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tales are spoken words, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a thousand mouths.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ワ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はな.す、はなし</p> <p id='words'>対話(たいわ): interactive, interaction, conversation, dialogue<br>話し合い(はなしあい): discussion, conference<br>受話器(じゅわき): telephone receiver<br>神話(しんわ): myth, legend<br>童話(どうわ): fairy-tale<br>話し合う(はなしあう): discuss, talk together<br>話し掛ける(はなしかける): accost a person, talk (to someone)<br>話中(はなしちゅう): while talking, the line is busy<br>話題(わだい): topic, subject<br>会話(かいわ): conversation<br>世話(せわ): take care of<br>電話(でんわ): telephone<br>話(はなし): talk, speech, chat, story, conversation<br>話す(はなす): speak</p> <p id='readingExamples'>話す (はな.す), 話 (はなし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>370</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>346</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>370</p> <p id='keyword'>poem</p> <p id='kanji'>詩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A9A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>poem, say, words, keitai, mouth, Buddhist temple, soil, dirt, ground, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Since silence is treasured so highly at a <i>Buddhist temple</i> the <i>words</i> spoken there must be well-chosen. Perhaps this is why the records of the monks often read to us like <b>poems</b>. Before going on, back up a frame and make sure you have kept <b>poem</b> and <i>recitation</i> distinct in your mind.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A poem is a temple of words.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That´s why most people will speak using a poem if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うた</p> <p id='words'>詩(し): poem, verse of poetry<br>詩人(しじん): poet</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>371</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>347</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>371</p> <p id='keyword'>word</p> <p id='kanji'>語</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AA9E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>word, say, words, keitai, mouth, I, five, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whereas the character for <i>say</i> focused on the actual talking, that for <b>words</b> stresses the fact that although it is <i>I</i> who <i>say</i> them, the <b>words</b> of a language are not my own. You can see the clear distinction between <i>I</i> and <b>words</b> just by looking at the kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The simplest word to say is I.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>May I say a word about that?</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かた.る、かた.らう</p> <p id='words'>漢語(かんご): Chinese word, Sino-Japanese word<br>語彙(ごい): vocabulary, glossary<br>語句(ごく): words, phrases<br>語源(ごげん): word root, word derivation, etymology<br>標語(ひょうご): motto, slogan, catchword<br>文語(ぶんご): written language, literary language<br>略語(りゃくご): abbreviation, acronym<br>語る(かたる): talk, tell, recite<br>敬語(けいご): honorific, term of respect<br>言語(げんご): language<br>語(ご): language, word<br>語学(ごがく): language study<br>国語(こくご): national language<br>熟語(じゅくご): idiom, idiomatic phrase, kanji compound<br>主語(しゅご): (grammar) subject<br>述語(じゅつご): predicate<br>単語(たんご): word, vocabulary, (usually) single-character word<br>物語(ものがたり): tale, story, legend<br>物語る(ものがたる): tell, indicate<br>用語(ようご): term, terminology<br>英語(えいご): the English language</p> <p id='readingExamples'>語らう (かた.らう), 語る (かた.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>372</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>348</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>372</p> <p id='keyword'>read</p> <p id='kanji'>読</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AAAD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>read, say, words, keitai, mouth, sell, sale, samurai, paper punch, Miss World, crown, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In the age of advertising, most <i>words</i> we <b>read</b> are out to <i>sell</i> some product or point of view.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Read the WORDS used to SELL things.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don´t believe everything you read (読).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドク、トク、トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よ.む、-よ.み</p> <p id='words'>購読(こうどく): subscription (e.g. magazine)<br>講読(こうどく): reading, translation<br>読者(どくしゃ): reader<br>読み上げる(よみあげる): to read out loud (and clearly), to call a roll<br>朗読(ろうどく): reading aloud, recitation<br>句読点(くとうてん): punctuation marks<br>読書(どくしょ): reading<br>読み(よみ): reading<br>読む(よむ): read</p> <p id='readingExamples'>読書 (どくしょ), 音読 (おんどく), 購読 (こうどく), 読本 (どくほん), 読む (よ.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>380</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>356</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>380</p> <p id='keyword'>range</p> <p id='kanji'>域</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59F9F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>range, soil, dirt, ground, pope, fiesta, mouth, one, floor</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>16</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>From its original meaning of a defined area or zone, a <b>range</b> has also come to mean a grazing <i>land</i> where cowboys roam and do whatever it is they do with cows. When the herds have all been driven to market, there is a great homecoming <i>fiesta</i> like that pictured here. As soon as the cowboys come home, home on the <b>range</b>, the first thing they do is kiss the ground (the <i>mouth</i> on the <i>floor</i>), and then get on with the <i>fiesta</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Instead of Heisig´s ""Fiesta"" I use ""Spear"". Ok way too much etymology here, but back to story. With your SPEAR standing in a HOLE on the FLOOR with SOIL to its left9as you dug some out), you can see the RANGE of the spear in attacking a possible enemy (re Diablo and other RPGs, spear´s have range).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>イキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>域外(いきがい): outside the area<br>領域(りょういき): area, domain, territory, field, region, regime<br>区域(くいき): limits, boundary, domain, zone, sphere, territory<br>地域(ちいき): area, region<br>流域(りゅういき): (river) basin</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>384</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>360</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>384</p> <p id='keyword'>overgrown</p> <p id='kanji'>茂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88C82.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>pokuflowers</p> <p id='constituent'>overgrown, flowers, parade</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>16</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sense of the key word <b>overgrown</b> is of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess - in this case a whole <i>parade</i> of weeds (outcast&nbsp;<i>flowers</i>). By way of exception, the <i>flowers</i> take their normal place over the enclosure.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it´s like the plants are mocking you. 	"<p id='id'>386</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>361</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>386</p> <p id='keyword'>turn into</p> <p id='kanji'>成</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68890.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>turn into, parade, sword, dagger</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>16</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let the phrase ""<b>turn into</b>"" suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the <i>parade</i> marching down main street <b>turns into</b> a <i>dagger</i>-throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>な.る、な.す、-な.す</p> <p id='words'>行き成り(いきなり): suddenly<br>育成(いくせい): rearing, training, nurture, cultivation, promotion<br>可成(かなり): considerably, fairly, quite<br>形成(けいせい): formation<br>結成(けっせい): formation<br>合成(ごうせい): synthesis, composition, synthetic, composite, mixed, combined, compound<br>成果(せいか): results, fruits<br>成熟(せいじゅく): maturity, ripeness<br>成年(せいねん): majority, adult age<br>達成(たっせい): achievement<br>成り立つ(なりたつ): to conclude, to consist of, to be practical (logical feasible viable), to hold true<br>成る(なる): become<br>成る丈(なるたけ): as much as possible, if possible<br>成るべく(なるべく): as much as possible<br>持て成す(もてなす): to entertain, to make welcome<br>養成(ようせい): training, development<br>完成(かんせい): complete, completion, perfection, accomplishment<br>構成(こうせい): organization, composition<br>作成(さくせい): frame, draw up, make, producing, creating, preparing, writing,<br>賛成(さんせい): approval, agreement, support, favour<br>成功(せいこう): success, hit<br>成人(せいじん): adult<br>成績(せいせき): results, record<br>成長(せいちょう): growth, grow to adulthood<br>成分(せいぶん): ingredient, component, composition<br>成立(せいりつ): coming into existence, arrangements, establishment, completion</p> <p id='readingExamples'>成功 (せいこう), 完成 (かんせい), 賛成 (さんせい), 成す (な.す), 成る (な.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>387</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>362</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>387</p> <p id='keyword'>castle</p> <p id='kanji'>城</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59F8E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>sandcastle</p> <p id='constituent'>castle, soil, dirt, ground, turn into, parade, sword, dagger</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>16</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In this frame, we see a mound of <i>dirt</i> that is being <i>turned into</i> a <b>castle</b> (the way you may have done as a child playing on the beach).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The sand castle is just the soil (#150) that turns into a castle.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Someday this mound of dirt here will turn into our CASTLE, the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しろ</p> <p id='words'>城下(じょうか): land near the castle<br>城(しろ): castle</p> <p id='readingExamples'>城 (しろ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>388</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>363</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>388</p> <p id='keyword'>sincerity</p> <p id='kanji'>誠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AAA0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sincerity, say, words, keitai, mouth, turn into, sword, dagger, parade</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>16</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sure sign of <b>sincerity</b> is that one's mere <i>words</i> are <i>turned into</i> deeds.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Sincerity is turning your words into actions.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まこと</p> <p id='words'>誠実(せいじつ): sincere, honest, faithful<br>誠(まこと): truth, faith, fidelity, sincerity, trust, confidence, reliance, devotion</p> <p id='readingExamples'>誠 (まこと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>389</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>364</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>389</p> <p id='keyword'>intimidate</p> <p id='kanji'>威</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A881.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>intimidate, march, women, woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>16</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we see a <i>march</i> of <i>women</i> demonstrating on behalf of equal rights, something extremely <b>intimidating</b> to the male chauvinist population.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of ""dignity"" and ""threaten."" 	"<p id='id'>396</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>370</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>396</p> <p id='keyword'>stop</p> <p id='kanji'>止</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ADA2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stop, footprint</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The character for <b>stop</b> is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Although the meaning of <i>stop</i> will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of <i>footprint</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it´s some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you don´t remember this one from the 10,000,000 STOP signs on roads all over Japan, you´re beyyond help!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.まる、-ど.まり、と.める、-と.める、-ど.め、とど.める、とど.め、とど.まる、や.める、や.む、-や.む、よ.す、-さ.す、-さ.し</p> <p id='words'>受け止める(うけとめる): to catch, to stop the blow, to react to, to take<br>静止(せいし): stillness, repose, standing still<br>阻止(そし): obstruction, check, hindrance, prevention, interdiction<br>止まる(とどまる): to be limited to<br>止める(とどめる): to stop, to cease, to put an end to<br>廃止(はいし): abolition, repeal<br>止むを得ない(やむをえない): cannot be helped, unavoidable<br>呼び止める(よびとめる): to challenge, to call somebody to halt<br>禁止(きんし): prohibition, ban<br>立ち止まる(たちどまる): stop, halt, stand still<br>中止(ちゅうし): suspension, stoppage, discontinuance, interruption<br>停止(ていし): suspension, interruption, stoppage, ban, standstill, deadlock, stalemate, abeyance<br>引き止める(ひきとめる): detain, restrain<br>防止(ぼうし): prevention, check<br>止む(やむ): stop (e.g. rain)<br>止める(やめる): quit smoking<br>止す(よす): cease, abolish, resign, give up<br>止まる(とまる): come to a halt</p> <p id='readingExamples'>止まる (と.まる), 止める (と.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>397</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>371</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>397</p> <p id='keyword'>walk</p> <p id='kanji'>歩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ADA9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>walk, stop, footprint, few</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Footprints</i> that follow one another a <i>few</i> at a time indicate <b>walking</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you learn to walk, you take your steps a few at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every few steps but keeps getting up to try again.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホ、ブ、フ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ある.く、あゆ.む</p> <p id='words'>歩み(あゆみ): walking<br>歩む(あゆむ): to walk, to go on foot<br>譲歩(じょうほ): concession, conciliation, compromise<br>徒歩(とほ): walking, going on foot<br>歩(ふ): pawn (in chess or shogi)<br>進歩(しんぽ): progress, development<br>歩道(ほどう): footpath, walkway, sidewalk<br>歩く(あるく): to walk<br>散歩(さんぽ): walk, stroll</p> <p id='readingExamples'>歩道 (ほどう), 徒歩 (とほ), 進歩 (しんぽ), 歩合 (ぶあい), 日歩 (ひぶ), 歩む (あゆ.む), 歩く (ある.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>401</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>375</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>401</p> <p id='keyword'>undertake</p> <p id='kanji'>企</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BC81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>stop sth floating about in the air with an umbrella</p> <p id='constituent'>undertake, umbrella, stop, footprint</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To <b>undertake</b> a project is to take some idea floating in the air and <i>stop</i> it so that it can be brought down to earth and become a reality. Here we see some <b>undertaking</b> made to <i>stop</i> under a beach <i>umbrella</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mary Poppins floated down with her umbrella to undertake the job of stopping the children´s misbehaving.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Undertaker is an evil WWE wrestler - he beat his opponent with an umbrella until he stopped moving.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くわだ.てる、たくら.む</p> <p id='words'>企画(きかく): planning, project<br>企業(きぎょう): enterprise, undertaking</p> <p id='readingExamples'>企てる (くわだ.てる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>402</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>376</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>402</p> <p id='keyword'>curriculum</p> <p id='kanji'>歴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ADB4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>curriculum, cliff, grove, tree, wood, stop, footprint, tree2, wood2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>That same <i>grove of trees</i> we met in frame 226 shows up here in the character for <b>curriculum</b> (in the sense of a record of one's life or academic achievements, the <b>curriculum</b> vitae). Instead of the <i>grove</i> making its way slowly through the surface of the <i>cliff</i> as before, here we see it <i>stopped</i>, much the same as a <b>curriculum</b> vitae calls a halt to the calendar and talks only about the past.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A little like a calendar, your CV records your footsteps through time.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>レキ、レッキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>学歴(がくれき): academic background<br>経歴(けいれき): personal history, career<br>履歴(りれき): personal history, background, career, log<br>歴史(れきし): history</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>403</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>377</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>403</p> <p id='keyword'>warrior</p> <p id='kanji'>武</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ADA6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>warrior, one, arrow, stop, footprint</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>With a <i>quiver</i> of <i>arrows</i> set on one's back, the goal of the <b>warrior</b> depicted here is not to attack but merely to <i>stop</i> the attack of others: the oldest excuse in history!</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>ONE-ARROW can STOP a warrior.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A great warrior can stop any 0pponent with one arrow.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ブ、ム</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たけ.し</p> <p id='words'>武装(ぶそう): arms, armament, armed<br>武力(ぶりょく): armed might, military power, the sword, force<br>武器(ぶき): weapon, arms, ordinance<br>武士(ぶし): warrior, samurai</p> <p id='readingExamples'>武力 (ぶりょく), 武士 (ぶし), 文武 (ぶんぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>404</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>378</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>404</p> <p id='keyword'>levy</p> <p id='kanji'>賦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B3A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>levy, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, warrior, one, stop, footprint, arrow</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A certain portion of <i>shells</i> (money) is collected by the <i>warrior</i> from the local villages as he passes through to defray the costs of keeping the land safe, and this is called a <b>levy</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Drove my Chevy to the levy but the levy was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you´ll die. 	"<p id='id'>405</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>379</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>405</p> <p id='keyword'>correct</p> <p id='kanji'>正</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ADA3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>correct, one, ceiling, stop, footprint</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step,"" says the Chinese proverb. Here we see <i>one footprint</i>, complementing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not made <b>correctly</b>, the whole point of the journey will be forfeited. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in <b>correcting</b> their students, and parents in <b>correcting</b> their children.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The correct way of learning Japanese? First, stop everything you´re doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig´s book and work from there.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ただ.しい、ただ.す、まさ、まさ.に</p> <p id='words'>正解(せいかい): correct, right, correct interpretation (answer solution)<br>正規(せいき): regular, legal, formal, established, legitimate<br>正義(せいぎ): justice, right, righteousness, correct meaning<br>正常(せいじょう): normalcy, normality, normal<br>正当(せいとう): just, justifiable, right, due, proper, equitable, reasonable, legitimate, lawful<br>正門(せいもん): main gate, main entrance<br>是正(ぜせい): correction, revision<br>訂正(ていせい): correction, revision<br>正しく(まさしく): surely, no doubt, evidently<br>正に(まさに): correctly, surely<br>改正(かいせい): revision, amendment, alteration<br>公正(こうせい): justice, fairness, impartiality<br>修正(しゅうせい): amendment, correction, revision<br>正午(しょうご): noon, mid-day<br>正直(しょうじき): honesty, integrity, frankness<br>正味(しょうみ): net (weight)<br>正面(しょうめん): front, frontage, facade, main<br>正(せい): (logical) true, regular<br>正確(せいかく): accurate, punctual, exact, authentic, veracious<br>正式(せいしき): due form, official, formality<br>正方形(せいほうけい): square<br>不正(ふせい): injustice, unfairness, iniquity, impropriety, irregularity, dishonesty, illegality<br>正しい(ただしい): right, correct</p> <p id='readingExamples'>正義 (せいぎ), 正誤 (せいご), 訂正 (ていせい), 正しい (ただ.しい), 正す (ただ.す), 正 (まさ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>406</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>380</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>406</p> <p id='keyword'>evidence</p> <p id='kanji'>証</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A8BC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>evidence, say, words, keitai, mouth, correct, one, ceiling, stop, footprint</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Words</i> that testify to the <i>correctness</i> of some fact are classified as <b>evidence</b>. (Here we see a good example of how the more common primitive element takes the ""strong"" position to the left, even though it has more strokes.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as evidence.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If what you say is indeed correct, we could use use your testimony as evidence.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あかし</p> <p id='words'>証(あかし): proof, evidence<br>証言(しょうげん): evidence, testimony<br>証拠(しょうこ): evidence, proof<br>証人(しょうにん): witness<br>証明(しょうめい): proof, verification<br>保証(ほしょう): guarantee, security, assurance, pledge, warranty</p> <p id='readingExamples'>証 (あかし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>407</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>381</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>407</p> <p id='keyword'>politics</p> <p id='kanji'>政</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E694BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>politics, correct, one, ceiling, stop, footprint, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To the many definitions for <b>politics</b> that already exist, this character offers yet another: <i>correct taskmastering</i>. Think about what the primitives tell us. On the one hand, we see the pessimistic wisdom that <b>politics</b> has to do with <i>taskmastering</i>, maneuvering people with or without their will. And on the other, we see the campaign assurances that this duty can be performed <i>correctly</i> if only the right candidate is given a chance.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Insane political correctness on the left, and facists taskmasters on the right- thats politics in a nutshell right there.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まつりごと、まん</p> <p id='words'>行政(ぎょうせい): administration<br>財政(ざいせい): economy, financial affairs<br>政権(せいけん): administration, political power<br>政策(せいさく): political measures, policy<br>政党(せいとう): (member of) political party<br>政府(せいふ): government, administration<br>政治(せいじ): politic</p> <p id='readingExamples'>政治 (せいじ), 行政 (ぎょうせい), 家政 (かせい), 政 (まつりごと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>408</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>382</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>408</p> <p id='keyword'>determine</p> <p id='kanji'>定</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE9A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>determine, house, mend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Determination</b>, in the sense of settling on a certain course of action, is likened here to <i>mending</i> one's <i>house</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher´s HOUSE in various ways.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>People who decide to renovate (ooh, that´s a fancy word, let´s say ""mend"") their houses must be very determined DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see DEtermine).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ、ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さだ.める、さだ.まる、さだ.か</p> <p id='words'>案の定(あんのじょう): sure enough, as usual<br>一定(いちじょう): fixed, settled, definite, uniform, regularized, defined, standardized, certain, prescribed<br>改定(かいてい): reform<br>確定(かくてい): definition (math), decision, settlement<br>規定(きてい): regulation, provisions<br>協定(きょうてい): arrangement, pact, agreement<br>限定(げんてい): limit, restriction<br>国定(こくてい): state-sponsored, national<br>固定(こてい): fixation<br>定まる(さだまる): to become settled, to be fixed<br>定める(さだめる): to decide, to establish, to determine<br>所定(しょてい): fixed, prescribed<br>制定(せいてい): enactment, establishment, creation<br>設定(せってい): establishment, creation<br>定義(ていぎ): definition<br>定食(ていしょく): set meal, special (of the day)<br>定年(ていねん): retirement age<br>判定(はんてい): judgement, decision, award, verdict<br>未定(みてい): not yet fixed, undecided, pending<br>安定(あんてい): stability, equilibrium<br>一定(いってい): fixed, settled, definite, uniform, regularized, standardized, prescribed<br>仮定(かてい): assumption, supposition, hypothesis<br>勘定(かんじょう): calculation, settlement of an account, allowance<br>決定(けってい): decision, determination<br>肯定(こうてい): positive, affirmation<br>指定(してい): designation, specification, assignment, pointing at<br>定規(じょうぎ): (measuring) ruler<br>推定(すいてい): presumption, assumption, estimation<br>測定(そくてい): measurement<br>断定(だんてい): conclusion, decision<br>定員(ていいん): fixed number of regular personnel, capacity (of boat, hall, aeroplane, etc.)<br>定価(ていか): established price<br>定期(ていき): fixed term<br>定期券(ていきけん): commuter pass, season ticket<br>定休日(ていきゅうび): regular holiday<br>特定(とくてい): specific, special, particular<br>否定(ひてい): negation, denial, repudiation<br>予定(よてい): plan</p> <p id='readingExamples'>定価 (ていか), 安定 (あんてい), 決定 (けってい), 定か (さだ.か), 定まる (さだ.まる), 定める (さだ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>409</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>383</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>409</p> <p id='keyword'>lock</p> <p id='kanji'>錠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98CA0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lock, metal, gold, determine, determined, house, mend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Metal</i> of itself doesn't <b>lock</b>. It needs to be so <i>determined</i> by a <b>lock</b>smith. Now make a concrete image of that.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let´s try this one: My girlfriend wears a metal chastity belt with a lock but I am determined to open it! I must get inside!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>手錠(てじょう): handcuffs, manacles</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>410</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>384</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>410</p> <p id='keyword'>run</p> <p id='kanji'>走</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B5B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>run, soil, dirt, ground, mend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Running</b>, we are told here, <i>mends</i> the <i>soil</i>. Observe in the following frames how this kanji can embrace other elements from below, much the same way as the element for <i>road</i> does; and how, in order to do this, the final stroke needs to be lengthened.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been RUNNING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はし.る</p> <p id='words'>御馳走(ごちそう): feast, treating (someone)<br>ご馳走さま(ごちそうさま): feast<br>走行(そうこう): running a wheeled vehicle (e.g. car), traveling<br>逃走(とうそう): flight, desertion, escape<br>走る(はしる): to run</p> <p id='readingExamples'>走る (はし.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>411</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>385</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>411</p> <p id='keyword'>transcend</p> <p id='kanji'>超</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B685.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>400m wr</p> <p id='constituent'>transcend, run, soil, dirt, ground, mend, summon, seduce, sword, dagger, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When one is <i>running</i> after something, the goal that <i>seduces</i> one is said to <b>transcend</b> the seeker.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A successful marathon runner needs to be able to transcend seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To transcend oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to transcend his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and....</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ.える、こ.す</p> <p id='words'>超える(こえる): to cross over, to cross, to pass through, to pass over (out of)<br>超(ちょう): super-, ultra-, hyper-<br>超す(こす): cross, pass, tide over<br>超過(ちょうか): excess, being more than</p> <p id='readingExamples'>超える (こ.える), 超す (こ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>412</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>386</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>412</p> <p id='keyword'>proceed</p> <p id='kanji'>赴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B5B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>orienteerimine</p> <p id='constituent'>proceed, run, soil, dirt, ground, mend, magic wand, augury</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In <b>proceeding</b> to a new city or a new job, something in you <i>runs</i> ahead with excitement, and something else holds you back, like a <i>divining rod</i> built into your psyche warning you to check things out carefully before rushing in too wildly.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Don´t run into trouble, Dumbledore tells Harry. ""Proceed with caution with your wand out."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>While running, my magic wand tells me where to proceed.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>フ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おもむ.く</p> <p id='words'>赴く(おもむく): to go, to proceed, to repair to, to become<br>赴任(ふにん): (proceeding to) new appointment</p> <p id='readingExamples'>赴く (おもむ.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>413</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>387</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>413</p> <p id='keyword'>surpass</p> <p id='kanji'>越</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B68A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>surpass, run, soil, dirt, ground, mend, parade</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we see two <i>parades</i> in competition, each trying to <b>surpass</b> the other by <i>running</i> at high speed from one town to the next. Note the little ""hook"" at the end of the first stroke of the element for <i>parade</i>. This is the ONLY time it appears like this in the kanji treated in this book.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The person in charge of running the parade surpassed all our expectations (by just a extra drop...).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The parade of runners are all trying to SURPASS each other - and they end up running all the way to Vietnam (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>エツ、オツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ.す、-こ.す、-ご.し、こ.える、-ご.え</p> <p id='words'>越える(こえる): to cross over, to cross, to pass through, to pass over (out of)<br>優越(ゆうえつ): supremacy, predominance, being superior to<br>追い越す(おいこす): to pass (e.g. car), outdistance<br>越す(こす): go over (e.g. with audience)<br>引越し(ひっこし): moving (dwelling, office, etc.), changing residence<br>引っ越す(ひっこす): move to (house)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>越える (こ.える), 越す (こ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>414</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>388</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>414</p> <p id='keyword'>just so</p> <p id='kanji'>是</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E698AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>just so, sun, day, mend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In this kanji we are shown someone spending an entire <i>day</i> at <i>mending</i> one stocking, because they want the job done ""<b>just so</b>."" Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it´s just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A construction worker´s classic morning. 	"<p id='id'>419</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>392</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>419</p> <p id='keyword'>prolong</p> <p id='kanji'>延</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BBB6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>benij-jump</p> <p id='constituent'>prolong, drop, stop, footprint, stretch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>17</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is a kind of pictographic image of how <b>prolonging</b> is a clever way of <i>stopping</i> things by trying to <i>stretch</i> them out a little bit at a time (the extra <i>drop</i> at the top of <i>stop</i>). Be sure to get a concrete image of this process, by imagining yourself <b>prolonging</b> something you can really, physically, <i>stretch</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Here´s a great mnemonic: ""stop, drop, and stretch (!?)."" Now let´s associate it with ´prolong´: if you´re ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just PROLONG the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it´ll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>の.びる、の.べる、の.べ、の.ばす</p> <p id='words'>延ばす(のばす): to lengthen, to stretch, to reach out, to postpone, to prolong, to extend, to grow (beard)<br>延びる(のびる): to be prolonged<br>延べ(のべ): futures, credit (buying), stretching, total<br>延いては(ひいては): not only...but also, in addition to, consequently<br>延期(えんき): postponement, adjournment<br>延長(えんちょう): extension, elongation, prolongation, lengthening</p> <p id='readingExamples'>延ばす (の.ばす), 延びる (の.びる), 延べる (の.べる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>423</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>396</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>423</p> <p id='keyword'>garment</p> <p id='kanji'>衣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A1A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>garment, top hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>At the top we see the <i>top hat</i>, and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a <b>garment</b>. If you break the ""4-fold"" fold into 2 sets of 2 strokes, you will find it easier to remember.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of <i>cloak</i> or <i>scarf</i> will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here.<div>When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ネ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean <i>cloak</i>.&nbsp;At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the <i>top hat</i>) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a <i>scarf</i>.</div><div>On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a <i>top hat and scarf</i>.</div><div>And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of <i>garment</i> in general.</div><div>Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is ""unhooked.""</div></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The only garments allowed in this club are top hat and scarf.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The garments most commonly associated with the craft of a magician are the top hat and the magic wand. (It´s a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ、エ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ころも、きぬ、-ぎ</p> <p id='words'>衣装(いしょう): clothing, costume, outfit, garment, dress<br>衣料(いりょう): clothing<br>衣類(いるい): clothes, clothing, garments<br>衣食住(いしょくじゅう): necessities of life (food, clothing, etc.)<br>衣服(いふく): clothes<br>浴衣(ゆかた): bathrobe, informal summer kimono</p> <p id='readingExamples'>衣 (ころも)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"

So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ、エ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こわ.す、こわ.れる、やぶ.る</p> <p id='words'>破壊(はかい): destruction<br>崩壊(ほうかい): collapse, decay (physics), crumbling, breaking down, caving in<br>壊す(こわす): break, destroy<br>壊れる(こわれる): be broken</p> <p id='readingExamples'>壊す (こわ.す), 壊れる (こわ.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>428</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>401</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>428</p> <p id='keyword'>pathetic</p> <p id='kanji'>哀</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59380.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pathetic, top hat, scarf, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A drunken sod in a tattered <i>top hat</i> and soiled silk <i>scarf</i> with a giant <i>mouth</i> guzzling something or other gives us a <b>pathetic</b> character role in which W. C. Fields might find himself right at home.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can´t see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it´s cool. I think it´s pathetic.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is pathetic-- in the original sense of the noun ""pathos."" The tattered tophat and scarf he wears only adds to the pathos.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>アイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あわ.れ、あわ.れむ、かな.しい</p> <p id='words'>可哀想(かわいそう): poor, pitiable, pathetic<br>哀れ(あわれ): helpless, pathos, pity, sorrow, grief, misery, compassion</p> <p id='readingExamples'>哀れ (あわ.れ), 哀れむ (あわ.れむ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>443</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>414</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>443</p> <p id='keyword'>lungs</p> <p id='kanji'>肺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E882BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lungs, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, market, top hat, towel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>One is surprised, strolling through the <i>market</i>, to find among the <i>meats</i> hung out for sale a slab marked: <b>lungs</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>LUNGS are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your LUNGS so that you can shout out at the top of your voice ""IRASSHAIMASEEE"" to attract customers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>肺(はい): lung</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>444</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>415</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>444</p> <p id='keyword'>sash</p> <p id='kanji'>帯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B8AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sash, buckle, apron, crown, towel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The part of the <i>apron</i> where one finds the <i>buckle</i> (represented pictorially by the first 5 strokes) is on the <b>sash</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the ""number 1"" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan´s #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it´s royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king´s kimono.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Beautiful ""Miss Housewife Japan"" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the number one mountain) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an apron tied with a sash. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.びる、おび</p> <p id='words'>一帯(いったい): a region, a zone, the whole place<br>帯びる(おびる): to wear, to carry, to be entrusted, to have, to take on, to have a trace of, to be tinged with<br>携帯(けいたい): carrying something<br>世帯(せたい): household<br>連帯(れんたい): solidarity<br>帯(おび): kimono sash<br>温帯(おんたい): temperate zone<br>寒帯(かんたい): frigid zone<br>地帯(ちたい): area, zone<br>熱帯(ねったい): tropics<br>包帯(ほうたい): bandage, dressing</p> <p id='readingExamples'>帯びる (お.びる), 帯 (おび)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>445</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>416</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>445</p> <p id='keyword'>stagnate</p> <p id='kanji'>滞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BB9E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stagnate, water, water droplets, water pistol, sash, buckle, apron, crown, towel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>People that have been ""<i>sashed</i>"" to something (whether their mother's apron strings or a particular job) for too long become like <i>water</i> that has stopped moving: they start to <b>stagnate</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one´s karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren´t their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A moat is a stagnate ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タイ、テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とどこお.る</p> <p id='words'>滞納(たいのう): non-payment, default<br>停滞(ていたい): stagnation, tie-up, congestion, retention, accumulation, falling into arrears<br>滞る(とどこおる): to stagnate, to be delayed<br>渋滞(じゅうたい): congestion (e.g. traffic), delay, stagnation<br>滞在(たいざい): stay, sojourn</p> <p id='readingExamples'>滞る (とどこお.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>446</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>417</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>446</p> <p id='keyword'>thorn</p> <p id='kanji'>刺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E588BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>thorn, tree, wood, belt, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Thorns</b> grow on a bush here that has wrapped itself around a <i>tree</i> like a <i>belt</i>, cutting into the poor <i>tree</i> like little <i>sabers</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. 	"<p id='id'>447</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>418</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>447</p> <p id='keyword'>system</p> <p id='kanji'>制</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E588B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>system, cow, belt, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji show a unique <b>system</b> for leading <i>cows</i> to the slaughterer's <i>saber</i>: one ties a <i>belt</i> about their waist and fixes that <i>belt</i> to an overhead cable, pulling the <i>cow</i> up into the air where it hangs suspended, helpless against the fate that awaits it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn´t have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he´s part of the bushi SYSTEM. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very Special Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, ""Moo!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>規制(きせい): regulation<br>強制(きょうせい): obligation, coercion, compulsion, enforcement<br>制(せい): system, organization, imperial command, laws, regulation, control, government, suppression, restraint, holding back, establishment<br>制裁(せいさい): restraint, sanctions, punishment<br>制する(せいする): to control, to command, to get the better of<br>制定(せいてい): enactment, establishment, creation<br>制服(せいふく): uniform<br>制約(せいやく): limitation, restriction, condition, constraints<br>統制(とうせい): regulation, control<br>抑制(よくせい): suppression<br>制限(せいげん): restriction, restraint, limitation<br>制作(せいさく): work (film, book)<br>制度(せいど): system, institution, organization<br>専制(せんせい): despotism, autocracy<br>体制(たいせい): order, system, structure, set-up, organization</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"

The katakana-ization of this is {ニム}バス, so the rising cloud primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>テン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ころ.がる、ころ.げる、ころ.がす、ころ.ぶ、まろ.ぶ、うたた、うつ.る、くる.めく</p> <p id='words'>逆転(ぎゃくてん): (sudden) change, reversal, turn-around, coming from behind (baseball)<br>自転(じてん): rotation, spin<br>転回(てんかい): revolution, rotation<br>転換(てんかん): convert, divert<br>転居(てんきょ): moving, changing residence<br>転勤(てんきん): transfer, transmission<br>転校(てんこう): change schools<br>転じる(てんじる): to turn, to shift, to alter, to distract<br>転任(てんにん): change of post<br>転落(てんらく): fall, degradation, slump<br>移転(いてん): moving, transfer, demise<br>運転(うんてん): operation, motion, driving<br>回転(かいてん): rotation, revolution, turning<br>転がす(ころがす): roll (transitive)<br>転がる(ころがる): roll, tumble<br>転ぶ(ころぶ): fall down, fall over<br>転々(てんてん): rolling about, moving from place to place, being passed around repeatedly<br>運転手(うんてんしゅ): drive<br>自転車(じてんしゃ): bicycle</p> <p id='readingExamples'>転がす (ころ.がす), 転がる (ころ.がる), 転げる (ころ.げる), 転ぶ (ころ.ぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>451</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>422</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>451</p> <p id='keyword'>rain</p> <p id='kanji'>雨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99BA8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rain, rain, weather</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji, also a primitive, is one of the clearest instances we have of a complex pictograph. The top line is the sky, the next 3 strokes a pair of clouds, and the final 4 dots the <b>rain</b> collected there and waiting to fall.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive it can mean either <i>rain</i> or <i>weather</i> in general. Because it takes so much space, it usually has to be contracted into a crown by shortening the second and third strokes into a crown.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Towel hung out on a line to ....oops, it´s rain.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あめ、あま-、-さめ</p> <p id='words'>雨具(あまぐ): rain gear<br>雨天(うてん): rainy weather<br>梅雨(つゆ): rainy season, rain during the rainy season<br>雨戸(あまど): (sliding) storm door<br>雨(あめ): rain</p> <p id='readingExamples'>雨 (あま), 雨 (あめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"

	"<p id='id'>457</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>428</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>457</p> <p id='keyword'>heavens</p> <p id='kanji'>天</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A4A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>heavens, heavens, one, ceiling, large</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the <b>Heavens</b>. (You may, of course, use the elements <i>ceiling</i> and <i>St. Bernard</i> instead.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive can mean either the <i>heaven</i> of eternal bliss or the general term for sky, the <i>heavens</i>. Pay special attention to the fact that in its primitive form the first stroke is written right to left, rather like the first stroke of thousand (Frame 40), rather than left to right. From the next character, we shall give it the primitive meaning of a <i>witch</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The ceiling that all large dogs aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, All Dogs Go to Heaven.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>テン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あまつ、あめ、あま-</p> <p id='words'>天(あまつ): heavenly, imperial<br>天地(あめつち): heaven and earth, the universe, nature, top and bottom, realm, sphere, world<br>雨天(うてん): rainy weather<br>天皇(すめらぎ): Emperor of Japan<br>晴天(せいてん): fine weather<br>先天的(せんてんてき): a priori, inborn, innate, inherent, congenital, hereditary<br>天国(てんごく): paradise, heaven, Kingdom of Heaven<br>天才(てんさい): genius, prodigy, natural gift<br>天災(てんさい): natural calamity, disaster<br>天井(てんじょう): ceiling, ceiling price<br>天体(てんたい): heavenly body<br>天候(てんこう): weather<br>天然(てんねん): nature, spontaneity<br>天皇(てんのう): Emperor of Japan<br>天気予報(てんきよほう): weather forecast<br>天気(てんき): weather, the elements, fine weather</p> <p id='readingExamples'>天 (あめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>460</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>429</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>460</p> <p id='keyword'>bridge</p> <p id='kanji'>橋</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A98B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bridge, tree, wood, angel, heavens, mouth, hood, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>bridge</b> shown here is made of <i>trees</i> in their natural form, except that the trunks have been carved into the forms of <i>angels</i>, a sort of ""Ponte degli Angeli.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The nicest bridge is not in Hollywood or Los Angeles, but in San Francisco.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, ""Don´t worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you."" The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, ""What are you doing with that wood?"" ""I´m trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はし</p> <p id='words'>桟橋(さんきょう): wharf, bridge, jetty, pier<br>橋渡し(はしわたし): bridge building, mediation<br>鉄橋(てっきょう): railway bridge, iron bridge<br>橋(はし): bridge</p> <p id='readingExamples'>橋 (はし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>461</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>430</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>461</p> <p id='keyword'>attractive</p> <p id='kanji'>嬌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AC8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>xena</p> <p id='constituent'>attractive, woman, angel, heavens, mouth, hood, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Associating a particularly <b>attractive</b> <i>woman</i> you know with an <i>angel</i> should be no problem.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The most attractive woman in the world is obviously Angelina Jolie.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The most attractive of women are said to resemble angels. RTK2: 　テキ　敵地　てきち(enemy territory)...　　　　　　　　　　　Pure Group:　嫡440　適441　滴442 　摘657.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かたき、あだ、かな.う</p> <p id='words'>敵(かたき): enemy, rival<br>素敵(すてき): lovely, dreamy, beautiful, great, fantastic, superb, cool, capital<br>匹敵(ひってき): comparing with, match, rival, equal<br>敵(てき): foe, enemy, rival</p> <p id='readingExamples'>敵 (かたき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>476</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>444</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>476</p> <p id='keyword'>spoon</p> <p id='kanji'>匕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58C95.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>spoon, sitting on the ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character, a pictograph of a <b>spoon</b>, is easy enough to remember, provided you keep it distinct from that for <i>seven</i>, where the first stroke is written left to right (the opposite of here) and cuts noticeably across the second.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji can take on the additional meaning of someone <i>sitting on the ground</i>, of which it can also be considered a pictograph. In general, the second stroke does not cut through the first - or if it does in some fonts, only slightly.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the direction of a stroke. In both ´spoon´ and ´seven´, the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in ´seven´ it is a strong line from left to right.</p> <p id='jouYou'></p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さじ、さじのひ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_None</p>"
	"<p id='id'>480</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>445</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>480</p> <p id='keyword'>north</p> <p id='kanji'>北</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58C97.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>north, spoon, sitting on the ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The cold air from the <b>north</b> is so strong that we see <i>two people sitting on the ground</i> back to back, their arms interlocked so they don't blow away. (Pay special attention to the drawing of the first 3 strokes.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きた</p> <p id='words'>南北(なんぼく): south and north<br>北極(ほっきょく): North Pole<br>北(きた): north</p> <p id='readingExamples'>北 (きた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>500</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>461</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>500</p> <p id='keyword'>sea</p> <p id='kanji'>海</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B5B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sea, water, water droplets, water pistol, every, reclining, lying down, mother, breasts</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Behind <i>every drop of water</i>, a <b>sea</b> from which it originated.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>As depicted in the classic SF film Fantastic Voyage, every drop of water is a sea, if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast sea teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). Note: Take care not to confuse with ocean (#549).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うみ</p> <p id='words'>海路(うみじ): sea route<br>海運(かいうん): maritime, marine transportation<br>海峡(かいきょう): channel<br>海抜(かいばつ): height above sea level<br>海流(かいりゅう): ocean current<br>航海(こうかい): sail, voyage<br>領海(りょうかい): territorial waters<br>海外(かいがい): foreign, abroad, overseas<br>海水浴(かいすいよく): sea bathing, seawater bath<br>海洋(かいよう): ocean<br>海岸(かいがん): sea shore<br>海(うみ): sea, beach</p> <p id='readingExamples'>海 (うみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>501</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>462</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>501</p> <p id='keyword'>beg</p> <p id='kanji'>乞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B99E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>that woman in bacolod</p> <p id='constituent'>beg, reclining, lying down, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>See someone <i>lying down</i> in a public place with a <i>hook</i> in place of a hand, <b>begging</b> a morsel of rice or a few pence.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Lying down, Captain Hook is begging to be spared from the ticking crocodile.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Men beg lying down. 	"<p id='id'>502</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>463</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>502</p> <p id='keyword'>drought</p> <p id='kanji'>乾</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B9BE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>drought, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, beg, reclining, lying down, fishhook, ten2, needle2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In times of <b>drought</b> anything at all will do.
