	"<p id='id'>503</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>464</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>503</p> <p id='keyword'>abdomen</p> <p id='kanji'>腹</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E885B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>abdomen, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>If you <i>double back</i> (fold over) most animals - or people, for that matter - in the middle, the <i>part of the body</i> where the crease comes is the <b>abdomen</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The only body part that doubles over.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine getting punched in the abdomen, a fairly tender part of flesh, and instead of doubling forward, you double back. That would be pretty painful.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>フク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はら</p> <p id='words'>お腹(おなか): stomach<br>空腹(くうふく): hunger<br>山腹(さんぷく): hillside, mountainside<br>中腹(ちゅうっぱら): irritated, offended<br>腹立ち(はらだち): anger<br>腹(はら): abdomen, belly, stomach</p> <p id='readingExamples'>腹 (はら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>504</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>465</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>504</p> <p id='keyword'>duplicate</p> <p id='kanji'>複</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A487.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>duplicate, cloak, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In its original and etymologically transparent sense, to <b>duplicate</b> something means to <i>double</i> it <i>back</i> with a fold, like the fold of a <i>cloak</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Hermione uses a device called a ""time-turner"" to double back in time, but this creates duplicates. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione´s time-turner with Harry´s invisibility cloak. That way, one could double back in time without creating any visible duplicates.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>フク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>重複(じゅうふく): duplication, repetition, overlapping, redundancy, restoration<br>複合(ふくごう): composite, complex<br>複写(ふくしゃ): copy, duplicate<br>複数(ふくすう): plural, multiple<br>複雑(ふくざつ): complicated</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>505</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>466</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>505</p> <p id='keyword'>lack</p> <p id='kanji'>欠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ACA0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>lack of pain in the lower part of the spine</p> <p id='constituent'>lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a <b>lack</b> of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, it can mean either <i>yawn</i> or <i>lack</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケツ、ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.ける、か.く、あくび</p> <p id='words'>欠く(かく): to lack, to break, to crack, to chip<br>欠乏(けつぼう): want, shortage, famine<br>不可欠(ふかけつ): indispensable, essential<br>欠ける(かける): be lacking<br>欠陥(けっかん): defect, fault, deficiency<br>欠席(けっせき): absence, non-attendance<br>欠点(けってん): faults, defect, weakness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>欠く (か.く), 欠ける (か.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>506</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>467</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>506</p> <p id='keyword'>blow</p> <p id='kanji'>吹</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E590B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>blowing the lungs empty of air</p> <p id='constituent'>blow, mouth, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To <b>blow</b> is really no more than a deliberate effort to make one's <i>mouth lack</i> all the air that is in it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is clearly a BLOWJOB, we can see the MOUTH and the LACK OF condom. (I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I keep confusing this with suck (#689). Consider someone blowing bubbles using their chewing gum because they´re lacking attention in class.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふ.く</p> <p id='words'>吹奏(すいそう): playing wind instruments<br>吹雪(ふぶき): snow storm<br>吹く(ふく): blow (wind, etc.), emit</p> <p id='readingExamples'>吹く (ふ.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>507</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>468</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>507</p> <p id='keyword'>cook</p> <p id='kanji'>炊</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7828A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>clarkson on a caravan holiday</p> <p id='constituent'>cook, fire, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Better to picture what happens when you do not pay attention to your work in the kitchen. Here we see a blazing <i>fire</i> and an inattentive, <i>yawning</i> <b>cook</b> who let things get out of control.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This character shows the difference between a cook and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love; a cook only stands there with a pan over a fire, with no passion and just yawning.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>た.く、-だ.き</p> <p id='words'>炊事(すいじ): cooking, culinary arts<br>炊く(たく): boil, cook</p> <p id='readingExamples'>炊く (た.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>508</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>469</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>508</p> <p id='keyword'>song</p> <p id='kanji'>歌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AD8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>chistmas songs in church</p> <p id='constituent'>song, cancan, can, mouth, street, nail, spike, lack, yawn, can2, mouth2, street2, nail2, spike2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>song</b> in this kanji is being sung by a chorus line of <i>can-can</i> girls. 	"<p id='id'>510</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>471</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>510</p> <p id='keyword'>next</p> <p id='kanji'>次</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ACA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>james may standing un line in india</p> <p id='constituent'>next, ice, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word connotes the ""<b>next</b> in line"" of a succession of people or things. Let there be a <i>lack</i> of <i>ice</i> on the hottest day of summer, and you stand impatiently in line waiting for the distributor to call out ""<b>Next</b>!""</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character can either retain its key word meaning of <i>next</i> or the related meaning of <i>second</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Is this store lacking ice? Let´s try the next one, then.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A rapper called ""Ice"" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. Next...</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジ、シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つ.ぐ、つぎ</p> <p id='words'>次(し): order, sequence, times, next, below<br>次いで(ついで): next, secondly, subsequently<br>取り次ぐ(とりつぐ): to act as an agent for, to announce (someone), to convey (a message)<br>次第(しだい): order, precedence, circumstances, immediate(ly), as soon as, dependent upon<br>次々(つぎつぎ): in succession, one by one<br>次ぐ(つぐ): rank next to, come after<br>目次(もくじ): table of contents<br>次(つぎ): next, stage station, stage, subsequent</p> <p id='readingExamples'>次回 (じかい), 次元 (じげん), 目次 (もくじ), 次ぐ (つ.ぐ), 次 (つぎ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>511</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>472</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>511</p> <p id='keyword'>briar</p> <p id='kanji'>茨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88CA8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>next part of the story of the briar rose</p> <p id='constituent'>briar, flowers, next, ice, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Earlier we made mention of the story of <b>Briar</b> Rose (or ""Sleeping Beauty,"" as we called her in frame 165) and drew attention to the <b>briar</b> hedge that grew up all about her castle. But in the <i>second</i> part of the story, these <b>briars</b> blossomed into <i>flowers</i>. Hence her name, <b>Briar</b> Rose. Be careful not to confuse this character with that for <i>thorn</i> (Frame 446).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The briar patch may look unremarkable now before it blooms, but there will be flowers next, and it will be beautiful.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>シ、ジ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いばら、かや、くさぶき</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>茨 (いばら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>512</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>473</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>512</p> <p id='keyword'>assets</p> <p id='kanji'>資</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B387.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>taking out a loan for a downpayment of a bigger loan</p> <p id='constituent'>assets, next, ice, lack, yawn, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The first <i>shells</i> (money) you earn, you use to pay your debts. From then on, the <i>next shells</i> you accumulate become your <b>assets</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Assets are the next best thing to money.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The first SHELLS you get you obviously spend, but the NEXT SHELLS are your ASSETS, you should bury them in a low safe place (placement!).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>資格(しかく): qualifications, requirements, capabilities<br>資金(しきん): funds, capital<br>資産(しさん): property, fortune, means, assets<br>投資(とうし): investment<br>物資(ぶっし): goods, materials<br>融資(ゆうし): financing, loan<br>資源(しげん): resources<br>資本(しほん): funds, capital<br>資料(しりょう): materials, data</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>513</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>474</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>513</p> <p id='keyword'>figure</p> <p id='kanji'>姿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A7BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>a woman and a mirror. second self</p> <p id='constituent'>figure, next, ice, lack, yawn, woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji depicts a <i>woman's</i> <b>figure</b> as a sort of <i>second</i> self.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The next woman always has a better figure! Thinking like that, you´ll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Whenever I am next to a woman, I can´t help but take notice of her figure.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すがた</p> <p id='words'>姿勢(しせい): attitude, posture<br>姿(すがた): figure, shape, appearance</p> <p id='readingExamples'>姿 (すがた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>514</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>475</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>514</p> <p id='keyword'>consult with</p> <p id='kanji'>諮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8ABAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>words of a second mouth</p> <p id='constituent'>consult with, say, words, keitai, mouth, next, ice, lack, yawn, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To seek the <i>words</i> of a <i>second mouth</i> is to <b>consult with</b> someone about something.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Consulting with is having words with the next mouth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はか.る</p> <p id='words'>諮る(はかる): to consult with, to confer</p> <p id='readingExamples'>諮る (はか.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>515</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>476</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>515</p> <p id='keyword'>compensation</p> <p id='kanji'>賠</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B3A0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>compensation, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Picture a <i>clam</i> used as a <i>muzzle</i> to quiet the complaints of a fisherman's widow asking <b>compensation</b> for her husband lost at sea.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Compensation is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Compensation is a kind of euphemism for hush money here. Money that muzzles.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>バイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>賠償(ばいしょう): reparations, indemnity, compensation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>516</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>477</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>516</p> <p id='keyword'>cultivate</p> <p id='kanji'>培</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59FB9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cultivate, soil, dirt, ground, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The barrel hoops used by many Japanese farmers to stretch clear plastic over row of vegetables in a garden patch in the hopes of <b>cultivating</b> bigger and bigger vegetables is a way of <i>muzzling</i> the <i>soil</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it´s unruly, chaotic nature.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The illegal immigrants cultivate the land but are socially and politically muzzled (wear muzzles while they work too).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>バイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つちか.う</p> <p id='words'>栽培(さいばい): cultivation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>培う (つちか.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>517</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>478</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>517</p> <p id='keyword'>divide</p> <p id='kanji'>剖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58996.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>divide, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To ""<b>divide</b> and conquer"" you use a <i>saber</i> and a <i>muzzle</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That´s why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Divide and conquer - first you cut them up (saber) , then you shut them up (muzzle).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>解剖(かいぼう): dissection, autopsy</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>518</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>479</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>518</p> <p id='keyword'>sound</p> <p id='kanji'>音</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99FB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>the 50s uuuu rock song from fg</p> <p id='constituent'>sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, tongue wagging</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji for <b>sound</b> depicts something <i>standing</i> in the air over a <i>tongue wagging in a mouth</i>, much the same as a <b>sound</b> does for the briefest of moments before disappearing.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive from this kanji also means simply a sound.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you´d be making sound.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The tongue wagging in a mouth produces a very high-pitched sound, breaking a nearby vase.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>オン、イン、ノン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おと、ね</p> <p id='words'>音色(おんいろ): tone color, tone quality, timbre, synthesizer patch<br>音(ね): sound, note<br>本音(ほんね): real intention, motive<br>音(おん): sound, (music) note<br>五十音(ごじゅうおん): the Japanese syllabary<br>雑音(ざつおん): noise (jarring, grating)<br>騒音(そうおん): noise<br>物音(ものおと): sounds<br>録音(ろくおん): (audio) recording<br>音(おと): sound<br>発音(はつおん): pronunciation<br>音楽(おんがく): music, musical movement</p> <p id='readingExamples'>音楽 (おんがく), 発音 (はつおん), 騒音 (そうおん), 音 (おと), 音 (ね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>519</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>480</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>519</p> <p id='keyword'>darkness</p> <p id='kanji'>暗</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69A97.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>darkness, sun, day, sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, sun2, day2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When ""<b>darkness</b> covered the earth"" at the beginning of time, there was neither <i>sun</i> nor <i>sound</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then...nothing. Everything would plunge into darkness.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In places of complete darkness, such as caves where the sun can´t reach, creatures such as bats have learned to navigate by sound rather than sight. The poor guys must have to fly around screaming ""Marco!"" and ""Polo!"" all the time.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>アン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くら.い、くら.む、くれ.る</p> <p id='words'>暗殺(あんさつ): assassination<br>暗算(あんざん): mental arithmetic<br>暗示(あんじ): hint, suggestion<br>暗記(あんき): memorization<br>薄暗い(うすぐらい): dim, gloomy<br>真っ暗(まっくら): total darkness, pitch dark, shortsightedness<br>暗い(くらい): dark, gloomy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>暗い (くら.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>520</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>481</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>520</p> <p id='keyword'>rhyme</p> <p id='kanji'>韻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99FBB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>why do chinese poems make no sense</p> <p id='constituent'>rhyme, sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, employee, mouth, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Poetry restricted to verses that <b>rhyme</b> often finds it has to abandon clarity of thought in order to make the <b>rhyme</b> of the words work. In this kanji's picture, one becomes a kind of ""<i>sound-employee</i>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>What is a RHYME but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Dr Seuss´s employee finally rebels against him: ""I´m tired of odd sounds all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in RHYME!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>521</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>482</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>521</p> <p id='keyword'>discriminating</p> <p id='kanji'>識</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AD98.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>discriminating, say, words, keitai, mouth, kazoo, sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, fiesta</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A person of <b>discriminating</b> intellect can tell the difference between mere <i>kazoo</i>-buzzing and <i>words</i> spoken wisely.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Words are difficult to discriminate/discern from sounds in the middle of a fiesta.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I have discriminating taste. I´d rather listen to the words of a lecture than attend a kazoo concert. 	"<p id='id'>522</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>483</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>522</p> <p id='keyword'>mirror</p> <p id='kanji'>鏡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98FA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mirror, metal, gold, mirror, vase, stand up, sun, day, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>After lakes but before glass, polished <i>metal</i> was used for <b>mirrors</b>. These <i>metal mirrors</i> are recalled in this character for a <b>mirror</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mirror should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a Golden mirror so she can stand in front of it all day vainly admiring her lovely human legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>metal + stand up + sun + legs remember the legend of Amaterasu who retired in a cave. the other Gods brought a MIRROR made of polished METAL at the entrance of the cave. Amaterasu who was STANDING UP saw her image of the SUN and began to dance with her LEGS.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ、ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かがみ</p> <p id='words'>眼鏡(がんきょう): spectacles, glasses<br>顕微鏡(けんびきょう): microscope<br>望遠鏡(ぼうえんきょう): telescope<br>鏡(かがみ): mirror<br>眼鏡(めがね): spectacles, glasses</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鏡 (かがみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>523</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>484</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>523</p> <p id='keyword'>boundary</p> <p id='kanji'>境</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A283.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>boundary, soil, dirt, ground, mirror, vase, stand up, sun, day, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Imagine the <b>boundary</b> of a plot of <i>land</i> marked with gigantic <i>mirrors</i> enabling the landowner to keep trespassers in sight at all times.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put mirrors on the boundary of his land so it feels much bigger.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the boundary of your land and theirs. When they approach the boundary, what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn´t any better than their own and they head back home.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ、ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さかい</p> <p id='words'>境遇(きょうぐう): environment, circumstances<br>国境(くにざかい): national or state border<br>環境(かんきょう): environment, circumstance<br>境界(きょうかい): boundary<br>国境(こっきょう): national or state border<br>境(さかい): border, boundary, mental state</p> <p id='readingExamples'>境界 (きょうかい), 境地 (きょうち), 逆境 (ぎゃっきょう), 境 (さかい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>524</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>485</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>524</p> <p id='keyword'>deceased</p> <p id='kanji'>亡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BAA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>deceased, perish, top hat, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A <i>top hat</i> hanging on a <i>hook</i> in the front hall, right where the <b>deceased</b> left it the day he died, reminds us of him and his kanji.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* In addition to <i>deceased</i>, the primitive meaning of <i>to perish</i> will also be used for this character.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The top hat hanging on a hook belonged to the now deceased Charlie Chaplin.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The recently DECEASED are said to hang their hats on a hook by the door to the afterlife.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボウ、モウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>な.い、な.き-、ほろ.びる、ほろ.ぶ、ほろ.ぼす</p> <p id='words'>逃亡(とうぼう): escape<br>滅亡(めつぼう): downfall, ruin, collapse, destruction<br>死亡(しぼう): death, mortality<br>亡くす(なくす): lose something or someone, get rid of<br>亡くなる(なくなる): die</p> <p id='readingExamples'>亡父 (ぼうふ), 亡命 (ぼうめい), 存亡 (そんぼう), 亡い (な.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>525</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>486</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>525</p> <p id='keyword'>blind</p> <p id='kanji'>盲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79BB2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>blind, deceased, perish, top hat, fishhook, eye</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>If one's <i>eyes perish</i> before death, one remains <b>blind</b> for the rest of life.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Deceased eyes! 	"<p id='id'>526</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>487</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>526</p> <p id='keyword'>delusion</p> <p id='kanji'>妄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A684.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>delusion, deceased, perish, top hat, fishhook, woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The ""ideal <i>woman</i>"" one daydreams about is no more than a <b>delusion</b>. Hence, <i>perish</i> the thought of her.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I had a problem with remembering that ""deceased"" went over the ""woman"". So, here´s my story: The delusional woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you think you should perish for that woman, you have a major delusion.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>モウ、ボウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みだ.りに</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>妄信 (もうしん), 妄想 (もうそう), 迷妄 (めいもう)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>527</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>488</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>527</p> <p id='keyword'>laid waste</p> <p id='kanji'>荒</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88D92.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>laid waste, wreath, flowers, deceased, perish, top hat, fishhook, stream, flood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>flowers</i> that <i>perish</i> in the <i>flood</i> are taken here as symbols of an area that has been <b>laid waste</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Laying waste is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like flowers, more like deceased flowers, and it´s flushed down into a stream of sewage. Use ""waste"" to avoid destroy (#365) demolition (#400).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あら.い、あら-、あ.れる、あ.らす、-あ.らし、すさ.む</p> <p id='words'>荒らす(あらす): to lay waste, to devastate, to damage, to invade, to break into<br>荒っぽい(あらっぽい): rough, rude<br>荒廃(こうはい): ruin<br>荒い(あらい): rough, rude, wild</p> <p id='readingExamples'>荒らす (あ.らす), 荒れる (あ.れる), 荒い (あら.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>528</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>489</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>528</p> <p id='keyword'>ambition</p> <p id='kanji'>望</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69C9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>perishing moon</p> <p id='constituent'>ambition, deceased, perish, top hat, fishhook, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The story of <b>ambition</b> talks of a <i>king</i> walking under the <i>perishing</i>&nbsp;(or ""waning"") <i>moon</i> dreaming great dreams about his kingdom. (The roots of <b>ambition</b> are from the same word as ""ambulate,"" meaning to walk about.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You´re dead meat, buddy, my ambition is to be king.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The ambitions of kings often result in dead bodies.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボウ、モウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>のぞ.む、もち</p> <p id='words'>志望(しぼう): wish, desire, ambition<br>絶望(ぜつぼう): despair, hopelessness<br>待望(たいぼう): expectant waiting<br>展望(てんぼう): view, outlook, prospect<br>望ましい(のぞましい): desirable, hoped for<br>待ち望む(まちのぞむ): to look anxiously for, to wait eagerly for<br>有望(ゆうぼう): good prospects, full of hope, promising<br>要望(ようぼう): demand for, request<br>欲望(よくぼう): desire, appetite<br>希望(きぼう): hope, wish, aspiration<br>失望(しつぼう): disappointment, despair<br>望み(のぞみ): wish, desire, hope<br>望む(のぞむ): to desire, wish for, see, command (a view of)<br>望遠鏡(ぼうえんきょう): telescope</p> <p id='readingExamples'>望郷 (ぼうきょう), 希望 (きぼう), 人望 (じんぼう), 望む (のぞ.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>529</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>490</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>529</p> <p id='keyword'>direction</p> <p id='kanji'>方</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E696B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>pudelimäng</p> <p id='constituent'>direction, compass, direction</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Spinning a <i>dagger</i> about on its hilt on the top of a <i>top hat</i>&nbsp;- waiting to see in which <b>direction</b> it points when it comes to rest - one leaves to fate where one is going next. Take care in writing this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character will take the sense of a <i>compass</i>, the instrument used to determine <i>direction</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Note: The primitives are top hat and bound up. Compare ten thousand (#64). Story: A rich man wearing a top hat and bound up from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for directions to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I always keep my directions bound to the bottom of my top hat so I won´t lose them.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かた、-かた、-がた</p> <p id='words'>彼方此方(あちこち): here and there<br>彼方(あちら): there, yonder, that<br>彼方此方(あちらこちら): here and there<br>遠方(えんぽう): long way, distant place<br>大方(おおかた): perhaps, almost all, majority<br>方(かた): polite way of indicating person<br>地方(じかた): area, locality, district, region, the coast<br>其方(そちら): over there, the other<br>外方(そっぽ): look (or turn) the other way<br>立方(たちかた): dancing (geisha)<br>他方(たほう): another side, different direction, (on) the other hand<br>何方(どちら): which, who<br>平方(へいほう): square (e.g. metre), square<br>方(ほう): side<br>方策(ほうさく): plan, policy<br>方式(ほうしき): form, method, system<br>見方(みかた): viewpoint<br>目方(めかた): weight<br>明け方(あけがた): dawn<br>一方(いっぽう): one side, one way, one direction, one party, the other party, on the other hand, meanwhile, only, simple, in turn<br>方々(かたがた): persons, all people, this and that, here and there, everywhere, any way, all sides<br>正方形(せいほうけい): square<br>地方(ちほう): area, locality, district, region, the coast<br>長方形(ちょうほうけい): rectangle, oblong<br>方角(ほうがく): direction, way, compass point<br>方言(ほうげん): dialect<br>方向(ほうこう): direction, course, way<br>方針(ほうしん): objective, plan, policy<br>方程式(ほうていしき): equation<br>方法(ほうほう): method, process, manner, way, means, technique<br>方々(ほうぼう): persons, this and that, here and there, everywhere, any way, all sides, all people<br>方面(ほうめん): direction, district, field (of study)<br>味方(みかた): friend, ally, supporter<br>仕方(しかた): method, way<br>両方(りょうほう): both<br>夕方(ゆうがた): evening</p> <p id='readingExamples'>方 (かた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>542</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>503</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>542</p> <p id='keyword'>presents</p> <p id='kanji'>贈</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B488.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>presents, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, increase, formerly, horns, rice field, brains, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>presents</b> offered here are <i>money</i> that <i>increases</i> each time you give it away. Do not confuse with the temporal word ""present"" (Frame 275).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Presents represent money that was formerly yours.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine if the number of presents you get increases with each birthday. So on your first birthday, you receive just one shell as a present, but the next year it increases to two shells as presents, and so on, increasing and increasing so by the time you´re elderly, the number of shells you´ll get as presents will have increased to an awful lot of presents. GOT IT YET? PRESENTS = SHELLS + INCREASE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゾウ、ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おく.る</p> <p id='words'>寄贈(きそう): donation, presentation<br>贈る(おくる): send, give to, award to, confer on<br>贈り物(おくりもの): gift</p> <p id='readingExamples'>贈与 (ぞうよ), 贈呈 (ぞうてい), 贈答 (ぞうとう), 贈る (おく.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>543</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>504</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>543</p> <p id='keyword'>east</p> <p id='kanji'>東</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69DB1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>sunrise behind a tree</p> <p id='constituent'>east, sun, day, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>19</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As a ""Western"" language, English identifies the <b>east</b> with the rising <i>sun</i>. In more fanciful terms, we see the <i>sun</i> piercing through a <i>tree</i> as it rises in the <b>east</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Both the direction <i>east</i> and the part of the world called ""the <i>East</i>"" are primitive meanings of this character.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The sun pierces through the trees as it rises in the east…　　　　　　RTK2:　トウ　東北　とうほく (the northeast)　東京　とうきょう(Tokyo)… MIXED GROUP　凍506　(ﾁﾝ):陳1301　(ﾚﾝ): 練1343　錬2030.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひがし</p> <p id='words'>東(あずま): east, Eastern Japan<br>関東(かんとう): Kantou (eastern half of Japan, including Tokyo)<br>東西(とうざい): East and West, Orient and Occident, whole country, Your attention, please!<br>東洋(とうよう): Orient<br>東(ひがし): east</p> <p id='readingExamples'>東 (ひがし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"

Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a ´sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is´, back in those days when people used ridgepoles they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>むね、むな-</p> <p id='words'>棟(とう): place, section, building</p> <p id='readingExamples'>棟 (むね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Here, as elsewhere, any of the alternate meanings of the primitives may be used, provided they do not require a position other than that of the kanji in question.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To make this dye, I used water and the barks of nine different trees.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The baseball team hangs their freshly dyed dripping jerseys at the top of a tree to dry.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そ.める、-ぞ.め、-ぞめ、そ.まる、し.みる、-じ.みる、し.み、-し.める</p> <p id='words'>感染(かんせん): infection, contagion<br>染みる(しみる): to pierce, to permeate<br>染まる(そまる): to dye<br>染める(そめる): to dye, to colour<br>汚染(おせん): pollution, contamination<br>伝染(でんせん): contagion</p> <p id='readingExamples'>染み (し.み), 染みる (し.みる), 染まる (そ.まる), 染める (そ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"

Unless you make a vivid image of something <b>burning</b> and relate it just as vividly to those primitive meanings, you can count on forgetting this character very quickly.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Any sort of thing can burn in the fire.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Somebody from PETA is really angry that they sell dog meat in China, so they´ve gone to burn down the whole cart (my mnemonic for ""sort of thing"" was seeing strips of dog flesh roasting, and saying ""well, that´s just the sort of thing they do here in China).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ネン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>も.える、も.やす、も.す</p> <p id='words'>燃焼(ねんしょう): burning, combustion<br>燃料(ねんりょう): fuel<br>燃える(もえる): to burn<br>燃やす(もやす): to burn</p> <p id='readingExamples'>燃える (も.える), 燃す (も.す), 燃やす (も.やす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>551</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>512</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>551</p> <p id='keyword'>year-end</p> <p id='kanji'>歳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ADB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">Santa had to put his foot down to stop a march of little guys, namely elves. 	"<p id='id'>552</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>513</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>552</p> <p id='keyword'>prefecture</p> <p id='kanji'>県</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79C8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">In Japanese this is KEN, as in Barbie´s boyfriend. He has lovely blue </span><span style=""font-style: normal; ""><b>eyes</b></span><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">, a girlfriend who is as thin as a straightened out </span><span style=""font-style: normal; ""><b>fish hook</b></span><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">. But, down where it counts, he has very </span><span style=""font-style: normal; ""><b>little</b></span><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;""> to show...</span></p> <p id='constituent'>prefecture, eye, fishhook, small, little</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>20</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Above, an <i>eye</i> and a <i>fishhook</i>,&nbsp;and below the primitive for <i>little</i>. Although apparently the simplest of these first six kanji, when you begin to work on its plot and story you will soon find out that the number of strokes and visual complexity of a kanji does not make it easier or harder to remember. It is the primitives you have to work that are the critical factor, as in this case where the meaning of the key word is so seemingly distant from the elements. Remember, you can always break larger elements down (<i>eye of a needle</i> into <i>eye</i> and <i>fishhook</i>) if you think it helps.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;""><span style=""font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; "">In Japanese this is KEN, as in Barbie´s boyfriend. He has lovely blue&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: normal; ""><b>eyes</b></span><span style=""font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; "">, a girlfriend who is as thin as a straightened out&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: normal; ""><b>fish hook</b></span><span style=""font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; "">. But, down where it counts, he has very&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: normal; ""><b>little</b></span><span style=""font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; "">&nbsp;to show...</span></span></p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>After sticking a fishhook in your eye, the yakuza boss probably has little more to do to convince you to move to a different prefecture.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.ける</p> <p id='words'>県(けん): prefecture<br>県庁(けんちょう): prefectural office</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>553</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>514</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>553</p> <p id='keyword'>horse chestnut</p> <p id='kanji'>栃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A083.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">There are a bunch of HORSE CHESTNUT TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. 	"<p id='id'>554</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>515</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>554</p> <p id='keyword'>ground</p> <p id='kanji'>地</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59CB0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">Picture the ground as an extent of soil where scorpions are buried like land mines. 	"<p id='id'>555</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>516</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>555</p> <p id='keyword'>pond</p> <p id='kanji'>池</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B1A0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">Water . . . scorpion. It would be easy to slip into a ""lazy image""in cases like this one, picturing, let us say, a scorpion near thewater. But if you picture rather a scorpion letting its venom outdrop by drop until it has made a whole pond of the stuff, theimage is more likely to remain fixed.</span></p> <p id='constituent'>pond, water, water droplets, water pistol, scorpion</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Water</i> . . . <i>scorpion</i>. It would be easy to slip into a ""lazy image"" in cases like this one, picturing, let us say, a <i>scorpion</i> near the <i>water</i>. But if you picture rather a <i>scorpion</i> letting its venom out <i>drop by drop</i> until it has made a whole <b>pond</b> of the stuff, the image is more likely to remain fixed.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Remember the story of the scorpion that begged the turtle for a ride across the pond? Halfway across the water, the scorpion stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Water scorpions loves to live in the pond.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いけ</p> <p id='words'>乾電池(かんでんち): dry cell, battery<br>電池(でんち): battery<br>池(いけ): pond</p> <p id='readingExamples'>池 (いけ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>556</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>517</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>556</p> <p id='keyword'>insect</p> <p id='kanji'>虫</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E899AB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an insect biting into the arm, sucking some blood. 	"<p id='id'>564</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>525</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>564</p> <p id='keyword'>self</p> <p id='kanji'>己</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B7B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>mees, kes lausus ussisõnu</p> <p id='constituent'>self, snake, self</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji carries the abstract sense of the <b>self</b>, the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology has often depicted as a <i>snake</i> - which is what the kanji shows pictographically. Be sure to keep it distinct from the similar keywords, <i>oneself</i> (frame 36) and <i>I</i> (frame 17).</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive element, this kanji can be used for the <i>snake</i>&nbsp;- of which it is a pictograph - or any of the various concrete symbolic meanings the <i>snake</i> has in myth and fable.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji looks like the ""s"" of ""self"", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his ""self"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When Superman looks at himself in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ、キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おのれ、つちのと、な</p> <p id='words'>自己(じこ): self, oneself</p> <p id='readingExamples'>自己 (じこ), 利己 (りこ), 己 (おのれ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>567</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>528</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>567</p> <p id='keyword'>reformation</p> <p id='kanji'>改</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E694B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">Pluralizing the snake and focusing on a single taskmaster may help recommend the image of Ireland´s most famous reformer, St. Patrick, who, legend has it, drove away the snakes from the land.</span></p> <p id='constituent'>reformation, snake, self, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pluralizing the <i>snake</i> and focusing on a single <i>taskmaster</i> may help recommend the image of Ireland's most famous <b>reformer</b>, St. Patrick, who, legend has it, drove away the <i>snakes</i> from the land.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The taskmaster of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a snake ) plans a reformation of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle-born. こわいですね！.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is a Meiji reformation taskmaster, trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a snake in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あらた.める、あらた.まる</p> <p id='words'>改まる(あらたまる): to be renewed<br>改悪(かいあく): deterioration, changing for the worse<br>改革(かいかく): reform, reformation, innovation<br>改修(かいしゅう): repair, improvement<br>改定(かいてい): reform<br>改訂(かいてい): revision<br>改良(かいりょう): improvement, reform<br>改めて(あらためて): again<br>改める(あらためる): to change, alter, reform, revise<br>改札(かいさつ): examination of tickets<br>改正(かいせい): revision, amendment, alteration<br>改善(かいぜん): betterment, improvement, incremental and continuous improvement<br>改造(かいぞう): remodeling</p> <p id='readingExamples'>改まる (あらた.まる), 改める (あらた.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>568</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>529</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>568</p> <p id='keyword'>scribe</p> <p id='kanji'>記</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A898.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">Snakes have no hands. 	"<p id='id'>569</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>530</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>569</p> <p id='keyword'>wrap</p> <p id='kanji'>包</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58C85.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">The snake bound up its prey by wrapping his body around it.</span></p> <p id='constituent'>wrap, bound up, snake, self</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bind up . . . snake.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning of <i>wrap</i> should always be used with the <i>snake</i> in mind to avoid confusion with similar terms. Just let ""<i>wrap</i>"" mean ""with a snake coiled about it.""</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The snake bound up its prey by wrapping his body around it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine Jessie sending in her Ekans (snake pokemon), and telling it to use bind attack to wrap up pikachu.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つつ.む、くる.む</p> <p id='words'>包む(くるむ): to be engulfed in, to be enveloped by, to wrap up, to tuck in, to pack, to do up, to cover with, to dress in, to conceal<br>小包(こづつみ): parcel, package<br>包み(つつみ): bundle, package, parcel, bale<br>包装(ほうそう): packing, wrapping<br>包帯(ほうたい): bandage, dressing<br>包む(つつむ): wrap, pack</p> <p id='readingExamples'>包む (つつ.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>573</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>534</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>573</p> <p id='keyword'>tortoise</p> <p id='kanji'>亀</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BA80.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>kilpkonn angerja sabaga ja kala peaga.&nbsp;</p> <p id='constituent'>tortoise, bound up, eels, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This is not a <i>turtle</i> (See frame 250) but a <b>tortoise</b>, however you wish to picture the difference. Let the ""<i>bound up</i>"" at the to prefer to the head, and the two <i>suns</i>, with a long tail running through it, to the shell.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated to its bottom half, ⻲, and comes to mean <i>eel</i>. (If it is any help, this kanji in its full form can also be remembered through its abbreviation's primitive meaning.)</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It seems bizarre, but tortoises are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A tortoise is prosperity bound up with a tail. They are very lucky creatures.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ、キュウ、キン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かめ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>亀 (かめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>579</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>540</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>579</p> <p id='keyword'>consummate</p> <p id='kanji'>遂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98182.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">This is still Miss Piggy only she´s gotten horny (as she often does) and now she´s pursuing Kermit to help her consummate her desires. horny sow climbs all the way up the reoad</span></p> <p id='constituent'>consummate, horns, sow, pig, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>horns</i> atop the <i>sow</i> suggest a boar at work in the background. Now create a story whose meaning is: <b>consummate</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is still Miss Piggy only she´s gotten horny (as she often does) and now she´s pursuing Kermit to help her consummate her desires.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In association with pursue (#539), our sow has tracked down a suitable mate, they´ve consummated their relationship, and now the little sow is all grown up into a boar with horns.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.げる、つい.に</p> <p id='words'>遂げる(とげる): to accomplish, to achieve, to carry out<br>やり遂げる(やりとげる): to accomplish<br>遂に(ついに): finally, at last</p> <p id='readingExamples'>遂げる (と.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>580</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>541</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>580</p> <p id='keyword'>house</p> <p id='kanji'>家</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AEB6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>sows running around in the barn</p> <p id='constituent'>house, sow, pig</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This is the full character whose primitive form we learned already. To help a little, this kanji recalls the times when the ""domestic"" animals were, as the word itself suggests, really kept in the <b>house</b>. Hence: <i>house</i> . . . <i>sow</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of ""The Three Little Pigs"". There was a house made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a pig. So, naturally, housetop over pig means house, the central element of that story.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Man, ever hear of cleaning? This house is a pig sty.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ、ケ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いえ、や、うち</p> <p id='words'>家出(いえで): running away from home, leaving home<br>家主(いえぬし): landlord<br>家計(かけい): household economy, family finances<br>家畜(かちく): domestic animals, livestock, cattle<br>家来(けらい): retainer, retinue, servant<br>実業家(じつぎょうか): industrialist, businessman<br>一家(いっか): house, home, a family, a household, one´s family, one´s folks, a style<br>大家(おおや): landlord, landlady<br>家屋(かおく): house, building<br>画家(がか): painter, artist<br>家具(かぐ): furniture<br>家事(かじ): housework, domestic chores<br>貸家(かしや): house for rent<br>家庭(かてい): home, family, household<br>国家(こっか): state, country, nation<br>作家(さっか): author, writer, novelist, artist<br>農家(のうか): farmer, farm family<br>家賃(やちん): rent<br>家主(やぬし): landlord<br>家(いえ): house, family<br>家族(かぞく): family, members of a family<br>家内(かない): (my) wife</p> <p id='readingExamples'>家屋 (かおく), 家庭 (かてい), 作家 (さっか), 家 (いえ), 家 (や)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>581</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>542</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>581</p> <p id='keyword'>marry into</p> <p id='kanji'>嫁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AB81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>marry into, woman, house, sow, pig</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji in this frame demonstrates the traditional Japanese approach to marriage: it is the <i>woman</i> who leaves her family for another <i>house</i>hold, thus <b>marrying into</b> a man's family.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she´s married into the house than into a relationship.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Traditionally, it was the women who would marry into the households of their husband´s families.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よめ、とつ.ぐ、い.く、ゆ.く</p> <p id='words'>花嫁(はなよめ): bride<br>嫁(よめ): bride, daughter-in-law</p> <p id='readingExamples'>嫁ぐ (とつ.ぐ), 嫁 (よめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>583</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>544</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>583</p> <p id='keyword'>intestines</p> <p id='kanji'>腸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E885B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">Intestines are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks.&nbsp;</span></p> <p id='constituent'>intestines, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, piggy bank, sun, day, piglets</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flesh . . . piggy bank.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Intestines are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks. Just imagine factory workers scraping out the intestines of real piglets and packaging them up for little children.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Taking things too literally, you used a real piglet as a piggy bank. Now when you smash it open to get your coins out, you have to dig out your coins from its intestines. ew.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はらわた</p> <p id='words'>腸(ちょう): guts, bowels, intestines</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>584</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>545</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>584</p> <p id='keyword'>location</p> <p id='kanji'>場</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A0B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">You´re looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that´s easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to remember like this kanji.</span></p> <p id='constituent'>location, soil, dirt, ground, piggy bank, sun, day, piglets</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Soil . . . piggy bank.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You´re looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that´s easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to remember like this kanji.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don´t confuse with place (#1127). Think of location not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You´ve buried your piggy bank in the dirt in your backyard, but you can´t remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of location to find your piggy bank.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ、チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ば</p> <p id='words'>現場(げんじょう): actual spot, scene, scene of the crime<br>式場(しきじょう): ceremonial hall, place of ceremony (e.g. marriage)<br>相場(そうば): market price, speculation, estimation<br>道場(どうじょう): dojo, hall used for martial arts training, mandala<br>農場(のうじょう): farm (agriculture)<br>本場(ほんば): home, habitat, center, best place, genuine<br>満場(まんじょう): unanimous, whole audience<br>役場(やくば): town hall<br>来場(らいじょう): attendance<br>市場(いちば): town market, the marketplace (economics)<br>劇場(げきじょう): theatre<br>現場(げんば): actual spot, scene, scene of the crime<br>工場(こうば): factory, plant, mill, workshop<br>酒場(さかば): bar, bar-room<br>立場(たちば): standpoint, position, situation<br>登場(とうじょう): entry (on stage), appearance (on screen), entrance, introduction (into a market)<br>入場(にゅうじょう): entrance, admission, entering<br>場(ば): place, (physics) field<br>場所(ばしょ): place, location<br>場面(ばめん): scene, setting (e.g. of novel)<br>広場(ひろば): plaza<br>牧場(ぼくじょう): farm (livestock), pasture land, meadow, grazing land<br>売り場(うりば): selling area<br>会場(かいじょう): the place of meeting<br>工場(こうじょう): factory<br>駐車場(ちゅうしゃじょう): parking lot<br>場合(ばあい): case, occasion<br>飛行場(ひこうじょう): airfield, airport</p> <p id='readingExamples'>場 (ば)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>585</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>546</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>585</p> <p id='keyword'>hot water</p> <p id='kanji'>湯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B9AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'><span style="" font-style: normal; font-weight: normal;"">Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!</span></p> <p id='constituent'>hot water, water, water droplets, water pistol, piggy bank, sun, day, piglets</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . piggy bank.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hot water is a phrase that can mean ""getting into trouble."" This kanji pictures just one of the many meanings of that phrase: it´s water that you get into (with creditors and the like) when your piggy bank is empty!</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆ</p> <p id='words'>茶の湯(ちゃのゆ): tea ceremony<br>熱湯(ねっとう): boiling water<br>湯気(ゆげ): steam, vapour<br>湯飲み(ゆのみ): teacup<br>湯(ゆ): hot water</p> <p id='readingExamples'>湯 (ゆ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>586</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>547</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>586</p> <p id='keyword'>sheep</p> <p id='kanji'>羊</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BE8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>roomiku jäljed ülesõidetud lambal</p> <p id='constituent'>sheep, horns</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This pictograph shows the animal <i>horns</i> at the top attached to the head (3rd stroke), the front and back legs (strokes 4 and 5) and body (final stroke).</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning of <i>sheep</i> can add the further connotations given in the following frame. As we saw with the <i>cow</i>, the ""tail"" is cut off when it is set immediately over another element: ⺷. Note the change in stroke order, as exemplified in the following frame.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Picture of a sheep run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Our Lord and King put on ears and a tail to become a lowly sheep for the slaughter.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひつじ</p> <p id='words'>羊毛(ようもう): wool</p> <p id='readingExamples'>羊 (ひつじ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>587</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>548</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>587</p> <p id='keyword'>beauty</p> <p id='kanji'>美</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BE8E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>beauty, sheep, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Try to think of what the Chinese were on to when they associated the idea of <b>beauty</b> with a <i>large sheep</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I guess this kanji proves it´s not just the Welsh whose idea of beauty is a large sheep.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A Sheep on top of a dog is NOT a beautiful thing.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ビ、ミ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うつく.しい</p> <p id='words'>美しい(うつくしい): beautiful, lovely<br>華美(かび): pomp, splendor, gaudiness<br>賛美(さんび): praise, adoration, glorification<br>美(び): beauty<br>美術(びじゅつ): art, fine arts<br>褒美(ほうび): reward, prize<br>優美(ゆうび): grace, refinement, elegance<br>美人(びじん): beautiful person (woman)<br>美容(びよう): beauty of figure or form<br>美しい(うつくしい): beautiful<br>美術館(びじゅつかん): art gallery</p> <p id='readingExamples'>美しい (うつく.しい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>588</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>549</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>588</p> <p id='keyword'>ocean</p> <p id='kanji'>洋</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B48B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ocean, water, water droplets, water pistol, sheep</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Water</i> . . . <i>sheep</i>. Be sure to keep the stories and key word of this kanji distinct from those for <i>sea</i>. (Frame 500).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji refers to the waters of the Pasheephic ocean.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across oceans of water in order to recover the fleece of a certain sheep.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>洋風(ようふう): western style<br>海洋(かいよう): ocean<br>東洋(とうよう): Orient<br>洋品店(ようひんてん): shop which handles Western-style apparel and accessories<br>西洋(せいよう): West, Western countries<br>洋服(ようふく): Western-style clothes</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>589</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>550</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>589</p> <p id='keyword'>detailed</p> <p id='kanji'>詳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A9B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>detailed, say, words, keitai, mouth, sheep</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words/speaking . . . sheep.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Trembling from head to hoof from such a traumatic experience, the sheep gives a very detailed worded account to the detective about his wolf attack. ""We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Say! detailed sheep, not like that! DE-TAILED sheep. Got it?</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くわ.しい、つまび.らか</p> <p id='words'>詳細(しょうさい): detail, particulars<br>詳しい(くわしい): knowing very well, detailed, full, accurate</p> <p id='readingExamples'>詳しい (くわ.しい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>590</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>551</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>590</p> <p id='keyword'>fresh</p> <p id='kanji'>鮮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9AEAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fresh, fish, bound up, rice field, brains, oven-fire, barbecue, sheep</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fish . . . sheep.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The freshest fish is caught in the middle of the night while most people are ""counting sheep."" (If you´ve ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This one´s easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased fresh. To remember which foods, take the first letter of fresh, ""F"", to stand for fish and the final sound of fresh, ""SH"", to stand for sheep: FreSH. It even puts the primitives in the right order.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あざ.やか</p> <p id='words'>鮮やか(あざやか): vivid, clear, brilliant<br>新鮮(しんせん): fresh</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鮮やか (あざ.やか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>591</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>552</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>591</p> <p id='keyword'>accomplished</p> <p id='kanji'>達</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98194.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>accomplished, soil, dirt, ground, sheep, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word is meant to connote someone ""skilled"" at something. On the <i>road</i> we find <i>soil</i> OVER <i>a sheep</i>. You may have to work with this one a while longer.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Dolly (the first cloned sheep ever) grow tired of being a celebrity and escaped from the labs by digging a tunnel. She turned out to be an ACCOMPLISHED escapist, as she managed to dig a road under the soil. /Imagine Dolly performing a escape, like those movies where the main character has to escape from jail.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The dirty sheep had come far down this road and had accomplished many things.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>タツ、ダ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>-たち</p> <p id='words'>達者(たっしゃ): skillful, in good health<br>達成(たっせい): achievement<br>伝達(でんたつ): transmission (e.g. news), communication, delivery<br>到達(とうたつ): reaching, attaining, arrival<br>上達(じょうたつ): improvement, advance, progress<br>速達(そくたつ): express, special delivery<br>達する(たっする): reach, get to<br>配達(はいたつ): delivery, distribution<br>発達(はったつ): development, growth<br>友達(ともだち): friend</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>592</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>553</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>592</p> <p id='keyword'>envious</p> <p id='kanji'>羨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BEA8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>envious, sheep, water, water droplets, water pistol, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Sheep</i> . . . <i>water</i> . . . <i>yawn/lack</i>. Although this character looks rather simple, special care should be taken in learning it because of the proximity of the final two elements to the character for <i>next</i>, which we learned in frame 510. Note, too, that the <i>water</i> comes UNDER the <i>sheep</i>, rather than on its own to the left.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A very thirsty sheep, who always lacked water, spends his days watching his fellow sheep (in the farm next door or in another pen) and being very envious of their water.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Envious of the greener grass on the other side of the fence, the sheep looks down in disgust at his own dry grass lacking water.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>セン、エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うらや.む、あまり</p> <p id='words'>羨ましい(うらやましい): envious, enviable<br>羨む(うらやむ): envy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>羨ましい (うらや.ましい), 羨む (うらや.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>593</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>554</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>593</p> <p id='keyword'>distinction</p> <p id='kanji'>差</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B7AE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>distinction, wool, sheep, craft</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Wool . . . craft.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This New-Zealand pro-gamer has won many distinctions playing WoolCraft (a massively multi-user game in which the goal is to shear sheep).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Noob players make no distinction between what games they play, whether it´s the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of Wool-craft!</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さ.す、さ.し</p> <p id='words'>格差(かくさ): qualitative difference, disparity<br>誤差(ごさ): error<br>差異(さい): difference, disparity<br>差額(さがく): balance, difference, margin<br>差し掛かる(さしかかる): to come near to, to approach<br>差し出す(さしだす): to present, to submit, to tender, to hold out<br>差し支える(さしつかえる): to interfere, to hinder, to become impeded<br>差し引く(さしひく): to deduct<br>時差(じさ): time difference<br>指差す(ゆびさす): to point at<br>交差(こうさ): cross<br>交差点(こうさてん): crossing, intersection<br>差(さ): difference, variation<br>差し支え(さしつかえ): hindrance, impediment<br>差し引き(さしひき): deduction, subtraction, balance, ebb and flow, rise and fall<br>差す(さす): raise (stretch out) hands, to raise umbrella<br>差別(さべつ): discrimination, distinction, differentiation<br>人差指(ひとさしゆび): index finger<br>物差し(ものさし): ruler, measure<br>差し上げる(さしあげる): give</p> <p id='readingExamples'>差す (さ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>594</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>555</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>594</p> <p id='keyword'>don</p> <p id='kanji'>着</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79D80.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>don, wool, sheep, eye</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>I cannot resist doing this one for you, since it clearly describes <b>donning</b> (putting on) one's clothes as ""pulling the <i>wool</i> over one's <i>eyes</i>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A pullover is donned by pulling wool over your eyes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Someone who is donning a disguise does that in order to pull the wool over your eyes.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>チャク、ジャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>き.る、-ぎ、き.せる、-き.せ、つ.く、つ.ける</p> <p id='words'>落ち着き(おちつき): calm, composure<br>着飾る(きかざる): to dress up<br>執着(しゅうじゃく): attachment, adhesion, tenacity<br>先着(せんちゃく): first arrival<br>辿り着く(たどりつく): to grope along to, to struggle on to, to arrive somewhere after a struggle<br>着(ちゃく): counter for suits of clothing, arriving at ..<br>着手(ちゃくしゅ): embarkation, launch<br>着色(ちゃくしょく): colouring, coloring<br>着席(ちゃくせき): sit down, seat<br>着目(ちゃくもく): attention<br>着陸(ちゃくりく): landing, alighting, touch down<br>着工(ちゃっこう): start of (construction) work<br>着ける(つける): to arrive, to wear, to put on<br>落着く(おちつく): calm down, settle in, be steady<br>着替え(きがえ): changing clothes, change of clothes<br>着せる(きせる): put on clothes<br>着々(ちゃくちゃく): steadily<br>到着(とうちゃく): arrival<br>肌着(はだぎ): underwear, lingerie, singlet, chemise<br>着物(きもの): Japanese traditional dress<br>下着(したぎ): underwear<br>上着(うわぎ): coat, tunic, jacket, outer garment<br>着る(きる): to wear, put on (from shoulders down)<br>着く(つく): arrive at, reach</p> <p id='readingExamples'>着用 (ちゃくよう), 着手 (ちゃくしゅ), 土着 (どちゃく), 着せる (き.せる), 着る (き.る), 着く (つ.く), 着ける (つ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>595</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>556</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>595</p> <p id='keyword'>solely</p> <p id='kanji'>唯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E594AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>solely, mouth, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Mouth . . . turkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The mouth of a turkey is used solely for saying, ""Gobble."" Likewise, your mouth, full of turkey, is solely used to gobble it up.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Sadly my mouth gets to taste turkey solely on Christmas Day.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユイ、イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ただ</p> <p id='words'>唯(ただ): free of charge, mere, sole, only, usual, common<br>唯(たった): only, merely, no more than<br>唯一(ゆいいつ): only, sole, unique</p> <p id='readingExamples'>唯一 (ゆいいつ), 唯物論 (ゆいぶつろん), 唯美主義 (ただびしゅぎ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>599</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>557</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>599</p> <p id='keyword'>char</p> <p id='kanji'>焦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E784A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>char, turkey, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Turkey . . . oven fire.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When I put the turkey over the oven fire, it always ends up being charred beyond recognition. I´m not a very good cook.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Char could be any meat over oven fire. So why is it a turkey in this kanji? Because charred turkey is what sticks out most in your mind as the thing that ruined Thanksgiving dinner.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ.げる、こ.がす、こ.がれる、あせ.る</p> <p id='words'>焦る(あせる): to be in a hurry, to be impatient<br>焦げ茶(こげちゃ): black tea<br>焦がす(こがす): burn, scorch, singe, char<br>焦げる(こげる): burn, be burned<br>焦点(しょうてん): focus, point</p> <p id='readingExamples'>焦る (あせ.る), 焦がす (こ.がす), 焦がれる (こ.がれる), 焦げる (こ.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>600</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>558</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>600</p> <p id='keyword'>reef</p> <p id='kanji'>礁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A481.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>reef, stone, rock, char, turkey, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rocks . . . char.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Coral reefs are now dying off due to our abuse of the environment and now look like charred stone. For a picture illustrating this, see http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Reefs are often formed from volcanic rock, or ""rock that has been charred"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>601</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>559</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>601</p> <p id='keyword'>gather</p> <p id='kanji'>集</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99B86.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>gather, turkey, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Turkeys</i> . . . atop a <i>tree</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have gathered on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Gather the turkeys for Thanksgiving. Gather the trees for Christmas. In that order...</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あつ.まる、あつ.める、つど.う</p> <p id='words'>集まり(あつまり): gathering, meeting, assembly, collection<br>群集(ぐんしゅう): (social) group, crowd, throng, mob, multitude<br>採集(さいしゅう): collecting, gathering<br>集計(しゅうけい): totalization, aggregate<br>収集(しゅうしゅう): gathering up, collection, accumulation<br>特集(とくしゅう): feature (e.g. newspaper), special edition, report<br>密集(みっしゅう): crowd, close formation, dense<br>集会(しゅうかい): meeting, assembly<br>集金(しゅうきん): money collection<br>集合(しゅうごう): gathering, assembly, meeting, (mathematics) set<br>集団(しゅうだん): group, mass<br>集中(しゅうちゅう): concentration, focusing the mind<br>全集(ぜんしゅう): complete works<br>編集(へんしゅう): editing, compilation, editorial (e.g. committee)<br>募集(ぼしゅう): recruiting, taking applications<br>集まる(あつまる): gather<br>集める(あつめる): get (things) together</p> <p id='readingExamples'>集まる (あつ.まる), 集める (あつ.める), 集う (つど.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>602</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>560</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>602</p> <p id='keyword'>quasi-</p> <p id='kanji'>准</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58786.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>quasi-, ice, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ice . . . turkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Quasi-modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn´t actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An iced turkey is only quasi-as-good-as fresh turkey.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>604</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>562</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>604</p> <p id='keyword'>miscellaneous</p> <p id='kanji'>雑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99B91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>miscellaneous, nine, baseball, tree, wood, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Baseball . . . trees . . . turkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Newscast: ""Among today´s miscellaneous stories, we have a report on a baseball team that was chased up a tree by a turkey. Stay tuned for this and more!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>On the left we have baseball and wood, which obviously means a baseball bat. Instead of balls, there are miscellaneous other objects you may hit with it. While beating people may be one favorite use, in this case we see it used for making turkey mash.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ザツ、ゾウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まじ.える、まじ.る</p> <p id='words'>雑(ざつ): rough, crude<br>雑貨(ざっか): miscellaneous goods, general goods, sundries<br>雑談(ざつだん): chatting, idle talk<br>雑木(ざつぼく): various kinds of small trees, assorted trees<br>混雑(こんざつ): confusion, congestion<br>雑音(ざつおん): noise (jarring, grating)<br>雑巾(ぞうきん): dust cloth<br>複雑(ふくざつ): complicated<br>雑誌(ざっし): journal, magazine</p> <p id='readingExamples'>雑談 (ざつだん), 雑音 (ざつおん), 混雑 (こんざつ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>605</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>563</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>605</p> <p id='keyword'>female</p> <p id='kanji'>雌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99B8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>feminine, Prince, this here, stop, footprint, spoon, sitting on the ground, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character for <b>female</b> forms a pair with that for <i>male</i>, which we will learn later (Frame 804). 	"<p id='id'>607</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>565</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>607</p> <p id='keyword'>stirred up</p> <p id='kanji'>奮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A5AE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stirred up, large, St. Bernard, turkey, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . rice field/brains.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The St. Bernard dog pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around.
