	"<p id='id'>608</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>566</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>608</p> <p id='keyword'>rob</p> <p id='kanji'>奪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A5AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rob, large, St. Bernard, turkey, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whereas <i>burglary</i> (Frame 381) implies clandestine appropriation of another's property, <b>robbery</b> refers to taking by force. The primitive elements: <i>St. Bernard dog</i> . . . <i>turkey</i> . . . <i>glue</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Remember the scene in A Christmas Story where the big dogs robbed the family of their Christmas turkey? Well, the following year Ralphie´s mom glued the holiday bird to the kitchen table, just as a precaution.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don´t let the neighbor´s St.Bernard rob tonight´s turkey....glue it to the table if you must.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うば.う</p> <p id='words'>略奪(りゃくだつ): pillage, plunder, looting, robbery<br>奪う(うばう): snatch away</p> <p id='readingExamples'>奪う (うば.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>609</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>567</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>609</p> <p id='keyword'>assurance</p> <p id='kanji'>確</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A2BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>assurance, stone, rock, turkeyhouse, house, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>On the left you see the <i>rock</i>, which is familiar enough. But pay attention to the right. Taking careful note of the unusual stroke order that has the ""chimney"" on the <i>house</i> doubled up with the first stroke of the <i>turkey</i>, we may see the right side as a <i>turkey house</i> (or ""<i>coop</i>"").<div>We shall see this pattern only on one other occasion (Frame 2093), but even for these two characters it is well worth the trouble to single it out as a primitive.</div></p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You´ve heard the expression ""killing two birds with one stone."" (一石二鳥 is-seki-ni-chou). We´ll, there´s another one that roughly translates as ""killing an entire coop with a giant boulder. "" That´s the method that hunters use when they want absolute assurance of taking home a bird.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク、コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たし.か、たし.かめる</p> <p id='words'>確信(かくしん): conviction, confidence<br>確定(かくてい): definition (math), decision, settlement<br>確保(かくほ): guarantee, ensure, maintain, insure, secure<br>確立(かくりつ): establishment<br>確り(しっかり): firmly, tightly, reliable, level-headed, steady<br>的確(てきかく): precise, accurate<br>適確(てきかく): precise, accurate<br>確実(かくじつ): certainty, reliability, soundness<br>確認(かくにん): affirmation, confirmation<br>確率(かくりつ): probability<br>正確(せいかく): accurate, punctual, exact, authentic, veracious<br>確かめる(たしかめる): ascertain<br>明確(めいかく): clear up, clarify, define<br>確か(たしか): sure, certain</p> <p id='readingExamples'>確か (たし.か), 確かめる (たし.かめる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>610</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>568</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>610</p> <p id='keyword'>noon</p> <p id='kanji'>午</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58D88.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>noon, horse, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>With a bit of stretching, you might see a horse's head pointing leftwards in this character. That gives the primary meaning of the Chinese zodiacal sign of the horse, which corresponds to the hour of <b>noon</b>. Note how this kanji primitive differs from that for <i>cow</i> (Frame 260).</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character gets the meaning of a <i>horse</i>. Any <i>horse</i> image will do, except that of a <i>team of horses</i>, which will come later (Frame 2132) and get its own primitive.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Noon is a good time for a ten minute nap (using lie down as nap).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Noon is the hour of the horse.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うま</p> <p id='words'>正午(しょうご): noon, mid-day<br>午後(ごご): afternoon, P.M.<br>午前(ごぜん): morning, A.M.</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>611</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>569</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>611</p> <p id='keyword'>permit</p> <p id='kanji'>許</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A8B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>permit, say, words, keitai, mouth, horse, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . horse.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr Ed ( a famous talking horse ) was finally at a loss for words when told he would need a permit for public speaking.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆる.す、もと</p> <p id='words'>許容(きょよう): permission, pardon<br>特許(とっきょ): special permission, patent<br>許可(きょか): permission, approval<br>免許(めんきょ): license, permit, certificate<br>許す(ゆるす): permit, allow, approve, exempt (from fine), excuse (from), confide in, forgive, pardon, excuse, release, let off</p> <p id='readingExamples'>許す (ゆる.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>612</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>570</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>612</p> <p id='keyword'>delight</p> <p id='kanji'>歓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AD93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>delight, pegasus, horse, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse, turkey, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Again I cannot resist sharing my own associations. If you've ever seen Disney's animated interpretation of classical music, ""Fantasia,"" you will recall what was done there with Beethoven's ""Pastoral Symphony"" (the 6th), and the <i>flying horses</i> that figured in it. The mares are bathing in the stream and the stallions begin to gather. As dusk sets in, the <i>flying horses</i> all start <i>yawning</i> and pair off for the night: a perfectly <b>delightful</b> portrait of <b>delight</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her delight when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday... and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly... hence the yawn.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I would be delighted if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よろこ.ぶ</p> <p id='words'>歓声(かんせい): cheer, shout of joy<br>歓迎(かんげい): welcome, reception</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>613</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>571</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>613</p> <p id='keyword'>authority</p> <p id='kanji'>権</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A8A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>authority, tree, wood, pegasus, horse, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . 	"<p id='id'>614</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>572</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>614</p> <p id='keyword'>outlook</p> <p id='kanji'>観</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A6B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>outlook, pegasus, horse, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse, turkey, see, telescope, eye, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pegasus . . . see.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Microsoft Outlook works about as well as a pegasus that can´t see: they both crash all the time.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I used to hate birds.They´re loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a pegasus. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to look up. I saw it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my outlook completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>み.る、しめ.す</p> <p id='words'>外観(がいかん): appearance, exterior, facade<br>観(かん): look, appearance, spectacle<br>観衆(かんしゅう): spectators, onlookers, members of the audience<br>観点(かんてん): point of view<br>観覧(かんらん): viewing<br>客観(きゃっかん): objective<br>主観(しゅかん): subjectivity, subject, ego<br>悲観(ひかん): pessimism, disappointment<br>楽観(らっかん): optimism<br>観客(かんきゃく): audience, spectator(s)<br>観光(かんこう): sightseeing<br>観察(かんさつ): observation, survey<br>観測(かんそく): observation<br>観念(かんねん): idea, notion, conception, sense (e.g. of duty), resignation, preparedness, acceptance</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>615</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>573</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>615</p> <p id='keyword'>feathers</p> <p id='kanji'>羽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BEBD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>feathers, wings</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>From the pictograph of two bird-wings, we get <b>feathers</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The related image of <i>wings</i> can be added as a primitive meaning. It can also take the form <sup>ョョ</sup>&nbsp;when used as a primitive, as we shall see in frames 618 and 619.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pictograph. Easy enough.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their FEATHERS.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>は、わ、はね</p> <p id='words'>羽(はね): feather, wing<br>羽根(はね): shuttlecock</p> <p id='readingExamples'>羽 (は), 羽 (はね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>616</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>574</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>616</p> <p id='keyword'>learn</p> <p id='kanji'>習</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BF92.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>learn, feathers, wings, white, dove</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Feathers . . . white bird.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine a white bird loosing a couple feathers as it is learning to fly. You learn a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you learn that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Learning is all about adding more feathers to your cap and the most prestigious of all is the beautiful pure white feather you´ll receive when you have learned the kanji!</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ、ジュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なら.う、なら.い</p> <p id='words'>演習(えんしゅう): practice, exercises, manoeuvers<br>慣習(かんしゅう): usual (historical) custom<br>教習(きょうしゅう): training, instruction<br>講習(こうしゅう): short course, training<br>風習(ふうしゅう): custom<br>学習(がくしゅう): study, learning<br>自習(じしゅう): self-study<br>実習(じっしゅう): practice, training<br>習字(しゅうじ): penmanship<br>習慣(しゅうかん): habit, custom<br>復習(ふくしゅう): review<br>予習(よしゅう): preparation<br>習う(ならう): learn<br>練習(れんしゅう): practice</p> <p id='readingExamples'>習う (なら.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>617</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>575</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>617</p> <p id='keyword'>the following</p> <p id='kanji'>翌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BF8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>the following, feathers, wings, vase, stand up</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Feathers</i> . . . <i>vase</i>. Be sure to contrast the connotation of this keyword with that for <i>next</i> (Frame 510).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The following segment is sponsored by...Swiffer - who make excellent feather dusters for cleaning your vases.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Your feathers would also stand up if you were a hen in a slaughter house and you heard: ""The following!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>618</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>576</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>618</p> <p id='keyword'>weekday</p> <p id='kanji'>曜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69B9C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>weekday, sun, day, futon, feathers, wings, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Day . . . feathers . . . turkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""futon"" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: weekday (FRAME 576) , laundry (#577), leap (#1285), outstanding (#2272), twinkle (#2534), shimmering (#2880). Story: On weekdays you hang your futon out in the sun.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The poor farmer spends every weekday while the sun shines, plucking turkey feathers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>火曜(かよう): Tuesday<br>金曜(きんよう): Friday<br>月曜(げつよう): Monday<br>水曜(すいよう): Wednesday<br>土曜(どよう): Saturday<br>木曜(もくよう): Thursday<br>曜日(ようび): day of the week<br>火曜日(かようび): Tuesday<br>金曜日(きんようび): Friday<br>月曜日(げつようび): Monday<br>水曜日(すいようび): Wednesday<br>土曜日(どようび): Saturday<br>日曜日(にちようび): Sunday<br>木曜日(もくようび): Thursday</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>619</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>577</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>619</p> <p id='keyword'>laundry</p> <p id='kanji'>濯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BFAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>laundry, water, water droplets, water pistol, futon, feathers, wings, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . feathers . . . turkey</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At the laundry you stuff your large futon (made from turkey feathers) in the machine, thereby causing it to break -- as shown by the water spurting out the side.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When turkeys do the laundry, they put their feathers in water (they don´t have clothes).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>タク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すす.ぐ、ゆす.ぐ</p> <p id='words'>濯ぐ(すすぐ): to rinse, to wash out<br>洗濯(せんたく): washing, laundry</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>620</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>578</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>620</p> <p id='keyword'>sayeth</p> <p id='kanji'>曰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69BB0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sayeth, pent in, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Pent in</i> . . . <i>one</i>. The key word refers to famous sayings of famous people, and is the origin for the primitive meaning of <i>a tongue wagging in the mouth</i> that we learned in frame 12. The size of this kanji, a relatively rare one, is what distinguishes it from <i>day</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sayeth?! Who the hell says ""sayeth""? Doesn´t seem quite right...just like this kanji, which is just like ""day"" but doesn´t seem ""quite right."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When pent up alone, one sayeth little.</p> <p id='jouYou'></p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>エツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いわ.く、のたま.う、のたま.わく、ここに、ひらび</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_None</p>"
	"<p id='id'>621</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>579</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>621</p> <p id='keyword'>quandary</p> <p id='kanji'>困</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59BB0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>quandary, pent in, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pent in . . . trees.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I´m supposed to make an enclosure for my tree, but if I use its wood for the enclosure, there won´t be anything left to be pent-in. What a quandary!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You are pent in the garden of eden with one tree, but outside is the whole world to explore! What a quandary -- should you stay in paradise with the tree of knowledge or should you go out into the world?</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こま.る</p> <p id='words'>貧困(ひんこん): poverty, lack<br>困難(こんなん): difficulty, distress<br>困る(こまる): be troubled, be worried, be bothered</p> <p id='readingExamples'>困る (こま.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>622</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>580</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>622</p> <p id='keyword'>harden</p> <p id='kanji'>固</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59BBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>harden, pent in, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Old</i> . . . <i>pent in</i>. Leave the people out of your story to avoid complications later when we add the element for person to form a new kanji (Frame 1047).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Fossils are old things pent in that have hardened.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was harden, which kept it pent in until it grew old enough to evolve into Butterfree..</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かた.める、かた.まる、かた.まり、かた.い</p> <p id='words'>固める(かためる): to harden, to freeze, to fortify<br>頑固(がんこ): stubbornness, obstinacy<br>固体(こたい): solid (body)<br>固定(こてい): fixation<br>固有(こゆう): characteristic, tradition, peculiar, inherent, eigen-<br>固い(かたい): firm (not viscous or easily moved), stubborn, certain, solemn<br>固まる(かたまる): harden, solidify, become firm, become certain</p> <p id='readingExamples'>固い (かた.い), 固まる (かた.まる), 固める (かた.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>624</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>581</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>624</p> <p id='keyword'>country</p> <p id='kanji'>国</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59BBD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>country, pent in, king, jewel, ball, earring, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Jewels . . . pent in.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In my country (England) the crown jewels are kept pent-in in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also pent-in (probably for trying to steal those jewels).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Just think of Japan, a country which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くに</p> <p id='words'>国境(くにざかい): national or state border<br>国産(こくさん): domestic products<br>国定(こくてい): state-sponsored, national<br>国土(こくど): realm<br>国防(こくぼう): national defence<br>国有(こくゆう): national ownership<br>国連(こくれん): U.N., United Nations<br>国交(こっこう): diplomatic relations<br>天国(てんごく): paradise, heaven, Kingdom of Heaven<br>国王(こくおう): king<br>国語(こくご): national language<br>国籍(こくせき): nationality<br>国民(こくみん): people, citizen<br>国立(こくりつ): national<br>国家(こっか): state, country, nation<br>国会(こっかい): National Diet, parliament, congress<br>国境(こっきょう): national or state border<br>全国(ぜんこく): nation-wide, whole country, national<br>国際(こくさい): international<br>外国(がいこく): foreign country<br>外国人(がいこくじん): foreigner<br>国(くに): country</p> <p id='readingExamples'>国 (くに)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>625</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>582</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>625</p> <p id='keyword'>group</p> <p id='kanji'>団</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59BA3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>group, pent in, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Glued . . . pent in.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you are admitted into a group like the Yakuza, you´re well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the group like glue, and you will be pent-in for life, never being able to leave.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A pent-in group will naturally be more cohesive, or ""glued together."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダン、トン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かたまり、まる.い</p> <p id='words'>団扇(うちわ): fan<br>劇団(げきだん): troupe, theatrical company<br>公団(こうだん): public corporation<br>団結(だんけつ): unity, union, combination<br>座布団(ざぶとん): cushion (Japanese-- square cushion used when sitting on one´s knees on a tatami-mat floor)<br>集団(しゅうだん): group, mass<br>団体(だんたい): party of tourists<br>団地(だんち): multi-unit apartments<br>布団(ふとん): futon</p> <p id='readingExamples'>団結 (だんけつ), 団地 (だんち), 集団 (しゅうだん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>626</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>583</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>626</p> <p id='keyword'>cause</p> <p id='kanji'>因</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59BA0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cause, pent in, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>St. Bernard dog . . . pent in.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>We once had a dog with big paws // and oh what great trouble he´d cause // we built a huge pen // to keep him pent in // and stop him from breaking more laws //.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the cause is that you kept the dog pent in the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>イン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よ.る、ちな.む</p> <p id='words'>要因(よういん): primary factor, main cause<br>因る(よる): come from<br>原因(げんいん): cause</p> <p id='readingExamples'>因る (よ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>627</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>584</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>627</p> <p id='keyword'>matrimony</p> <p id='kanji'>姻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A7BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>matrimony, woman, cause, pent in, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Woman</i> . . . <i>cause</i>. Think here of the ""state of <b>matrimony</b>"" and you will not confuse it with other characters involving marriage, one of which we have already met (Frame 581).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Matrimony is the state in which the woman has got you pent in like a dog so that you cannot go after other bitches.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When the woman gets angry, she treats her man like a pent in dog (i.e., puts him in the doghouse). It´s a perfect metaphor for the state of matrimony.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>629</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>585</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>629</p> <p id='keyword'>park</p> <p id='kanji'>園</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59C92.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>park, pent in, earthenware jar, lidded crock, soil, dirt, ground, mouth, scarf</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pent in . . . lidded crock . . . scarf.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There was a homeless man living in a box at the park so I gave him a lidded crock filled with hot curry tied with a scarf...</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>その</p> <p id='words'>園(えん): garden (esp. man-made)<br>園(その): garden, park, plantation<br>田園(でんえん): country, rural districts<br>園芸(えんげい): horticulture, gardening<br>遊園地(ゆうえんち): amusement park<br>幼稚園(ようちえん): kindergarten<br>動物園(どうぶつえん): zoo<br>公園(こうえん): (public) park</p> <p id='readingExamples'>園 (その)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>630</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>586</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>630</p> <p id='keyword'>-times</p> <p id='kanji'>回</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59B9E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>times, pent in, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The suffix ""<b>-times</b>"" refers to a number of repetitions. Its elements: <i>a mouth</i>&nbsp;. . . <i>pent in</i>. Hint: you may find it more helpful to forget the primitives and think of one circle revovling inside of another.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Write mouth two -times.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ、エ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まわ.る、-まわ.る、-まわ.り、まわ.す、-まわ.す、まわ.し-、-まわ.し、もとお.る、か.える</p> <p id='words'>後回し(あとまわし): putting off, postponing<br>上回る(うわまわる): to exceed<br>回収(かいしゅう): collection, recovery<br>回送(かいそう): forwarding<br>回覧(かいらん): circulation<br>回路(かいろ): circuit (electric)<br>掻き回す(かきまわす): to stir up, to churn, to ransack, to disturb<br>手回し(てまわし): preparations, arrangements<br>転回(てんかい): revolution, rotation<br>遠回り(とおまわり): detour, roundabout way<br>ねじ回し(ねじまわし): screwdriver<br>根回し(ねまわし): making necessary arrangements<br>回(かい): counter for occurrences<br>回数(かいすう): number of times, frequency<br>回数券(かいすうけん): book of tickets<br>回転(かいてん): rotation, revolution, turning<br>回答(かいとう): reply, answer<br>回復(かいふく): recovery (from illness), improvement, rehabilitation, restoration<br>今回(こんかい): now, this time, lately<br>回す(まわす): turn, revolve<br>回り(まわり): circumference, surroundings, circulation<br>回り道(まわりみち): detour, diversion<br>回る(まわる): go round</p> <p id='readingExamples'>回答 (かいとう), 転回 (てんかい), 次回 (じかい), 回す (まわ.す), 回る (まわ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>631</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>587</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>631</p> <p id='keyword'>podium</p> <p id='kanji'>壇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A387.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>podium, soil, dirt, ground, Churchill, top hat, -times, pent in, mouth, nightbreak, sun, day, one, floor</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Soil/ground</i> . . . <i>top hat</i> . . . <i>-times</i> . . . <i>nightbreak</i>. With kanji as difficult as this one, it generally pays to toy with the various connotations of its primitives before settling on one image. Aim for as much simplicity as you can.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of soil for a podium, when he wore his top hat and gave the speech he had practiced many times until nightbreak. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダン、タン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>花壇(かだん): flower bed<br>壇(だん): platform, podium, rostrum, (arch) mandala</p> <p id='readingExamples'>壇上 (だんじょう), 花壇 (かだん), 文壇 (ぶんだん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>632</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>588</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>632</p> <p id='keyword'>store</p> <p id='kanji'>店</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BA97.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>store, cave, fortune-telling, magic wand, augury, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cave . . . fortune-telling.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The fortuneteller has a store in a cave.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>テン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みせ、たな</p> <p id='words'>店(てん): store, shop, establishment<br>支店(してん): branch store (office)<br>商店(しょうてん): shop, business firm<br>書店(しょてん): bookstore<br>売店(ばいてん): shop, stand<br>店屋(みせや): store, shop<br>洋品店(ようひんてん): shop which handles Western-style apparel and accessories<br>店員(てんいん): salesclerk<br>喫茶店(きっさてん): coffee shop<br>店(みせ): store, shop, establishment</p> <p id='readingExamples'>店 (みせ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>639</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>595</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>639</p> <p id='keyword'>heart</p> <p id='kanji'>心</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BF83.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>heart, drops, fishhook, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character, a pictographic representation of the <b>heart</b>, is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings.<div>In its kanji-form, it appears BENEATH or to the RIGHT of its relative primitive and means th physical organ of the <i>heart</i>.<br /><div>To the LEFT, it is abbreviated to three strokes, ⺖,  and means a wildly emotional <i>state of mind</i>.</div><div>And finally, at the very BOTTOM, it can take the form ⺗, in which case we give it the meaning of a <i>valentine</i>.</div></div></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The four chambers in the heart. In the West, we point to our head when asked about the mind. In the East, they point to the heart. So then, the radical for ""state of mind""…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　シン　安心　あんしん(peace of mind).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Heart needs three drops of blood to work.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こころ、-ごころ、りっしんべん</p> <p id='words'>一心(いっしん): one mind, wholeheartedness, the whole heart<br>肝心(かんじん): essential, fundamental, crucial, vital, main<br>心地(ここち): feeling, sensation, mood<br>心得(こころえ): knowledge, information<br>心掛け(こころがけ): readiness, intention, aim<br>心掛ける(こころがける): to bear in mind, to aim to do<br>心強い(こころづよい): heartening, reassuring<br>心細い(こころぼそい): helpless, forlorn, hopeless, unpromising, lonely, discouraging, disheartening<br>自尊心(じそんしん): self-respect, conceit<br>下心(したごころ): secret intention, motive<br>心中(しんじゅう): double suicide, lovers suicide<br>心情(しんじょう): mentality<br>心配(しんぱい): worry, concern, anxiety, care<br>真心(まこころ): sincerity, devotion<br>野心(やしん): ambition, aspiration, designs, treachery<br>良心(りょうしん): conscience<br>感心(かんしん): admiration, Well done!<br>関心(かんしん): concern, interest<br>苦心(くしん): pain, trouble, anxiety, diligence, hard work<br>決心(けっしん): determination, resolution<br>心当たり(こころあたり): having some knowledge of, happening to know<br>心得る(こころえる): be informed, have thorough knowledge<br>心身(しんしん): mind and body<br>心臓(しんぞう): heart<br>心理(しんり): mentality<br>中心(ちゅうしん): center, core, heart, pivot, emphasis, balance<br>都心(としん): heart of city<br>用心(ようじん): care, precaution, caution<br>安心(あんしん): peace of mind, relief<br>心(こころ): mind, heart<br>熱心(ねっしん): eagerness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>心 (こころ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (ninja) which is why I choose to use ninja as its primitive meaning.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Someone with a razor blade stuck in their heart has to endure the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ニン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しの.ぶ、しの.ばせる</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>忍ばせる (しの.ばせる), 忍ぶ (しの.ぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>649</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>603</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>649</p> <p id='keyword'>shish kebab</p> <p id='kanji'>串</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B8B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shish kebab, kebab, in, stick, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This pictograph of two pieces of meat on a skewer, a <b>shish kebab</b>, will help us in the next frame.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Naka naka , ""who´s there?"" shish kebab .... ""shish kebab who?"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>カン、ケン、セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くし、つらぬ.く</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>串 (くし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>650</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>604</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>650</p> <p id='keyword'>afflicted</p> <p id='kanji'>患</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E682A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>afflicted, kebab, in, stick, mouth, heart, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Shish kebab . . . heart.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A person who is afflicted with the vampire disease can only be killed with a sheesh-kebab through the heart.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you are afflicted with severe heartburn, eating a spicy shish kebab will feel only slightly less painful than having it jammed straight into your heart.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わずら.う</p> <p id='words'>患者(かんじゃ): a patient</p> <p id='readingExamples'>患う (わずら.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>652</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>606</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>652</p> <p id='keyword'>grace</p> <p id='kanji'>恩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E681A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grace, cause, pent in, large, St. Bernard, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take <b>grace</b> in its sense of a favor freely bestowed, not in its meaning of charming manners or fluid movement. The primitives: <i>cause</i> . . . <i>heart</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Grace here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a big dog pent up in a small cage and adopt him. That will cause a warm feeling in your heart!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause, grace is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a graceful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>オン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>恩(おん): favour, obligation, debt of gratitude<br>恩恵(おんけい): grace, favor, blessing, benefit</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>653</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>607</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>653</p> <p id='keyword'>apply</p> <p id='kanji'>応</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BF9C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>apply, cave, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Cave</i> . . . <i>heart</i>. The sense of the key word here is of something appropriate that fills a particular need, and hence ""<b>applies</b>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the videogame Zelda, Link enters a CAVE to visit a fairy that will APPLY magic to fill his HEART containers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[bravo, scottamus!] To apply for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the heart of the cave past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say ""Those who don´t make it to the heart of the cave need not apply."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>オウ、ヨウ、ノウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あた.る、まさに、こた.える</p> <p id='words'>応急(おうきゅう): emergency<br>応募(おうぼ): subscription, application<br>相応(そうおう): suitability, fitness<br>対応(たいおう): interaction, correspondence, coping with, dealing with<br>適応(てきおう): adaptation, accommodation, conformity<br>反応(はんのう): reaction, response<br>相応しい(ふさわしい): appropriate<br>一応(いちおう): once, tentatively, in outline, for the time being<br>応援(おうえん): aid, assistance, help, reinforcement, support, cheering<br>応じる(おうじる): respond, satisfy, accept, comply with, apply for<br>応ずる(おうずる): answer, respond, meet, satisfy, accept<br>応接(おうせつ): reception<br>応対(おうたい): receiving, dealing with<br>応用(おうよう): application, put to practical use</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>658</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>611</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>658</p> <p id='keyword'>recess</p> <p id='kanji'>憩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E686A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>recess, tongue, thousand, mouth, nose, drop, eye, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Tongue</i> . . . <i>nose</i> . . . <i>heart</i>. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of tongues, which helps me remember that in this kanji tongue comes first.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いこ.い、いこ.う</p> <p id='words'>休憩(きゅうけい): rest, break, recess, intermission</p> <p id='readingExamples'>憩い (いこ.い), 憩う (いこ.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>661</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>614</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>661</p> <p id='keyword'>beguile</p> <p id='kanji'>惑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68391.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>beguile, a, pope, fiesta, mouth, one, floor, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The first three elements, <i>fiesta</i> . . . <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>floor</i>, appeared together once already in frame 380. 	"<p id='id'>662</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>615</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>662</p> <p id='keyword'>emotion</p> <p id='kanji'>感</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6849F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>emotion, march, mouth, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Mouths . . . marching . . . heart.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Emotion is a march of mouths inside your heart telling you what to feel.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Strong EMOTIONS don´t stay hidden. They march right out of one´s heart (below) and out one´s mouth (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of emotion it is!).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>感慨(かんがい): strong feelings, deep emotion<br>感触(かんしょく): sense of touch, feeling, sensation<br>感染(かんせん): infection, contagion<br>感度(かんど): sensitivity, severity (quake)<br>感無量(かんむりょう): deep feeling, inexpressible feeling, filled with emotion<br>共感(きょうかん): sympathy, response<br>直感(ちょっかん): intuition<br>痛感(つうかん): feeling keenly, fully realizing<br>同感(どうかん): agreement, same opinion, same feeling, sympathy, concurrence<br>鈍感(どんかん): thickheadedness, stolidity<br>反感(はんかん): antipathy, revolt, animosity<br>敏感(びんかん): sensibility, susceptibility, sensitive (to), well attuned to<br>予感(よかん): presentiment, premonition<br>感覚(かんかく): sense, sensation<br>感激(かんげき): deep emotion, impression, inspiration<br>感じ(かんじ): feeling, sense, impression<br>感謝(かんしゃ): thanks, gratitude<br>感情(かんじょう): emotion(s), feeling(s), sentiment<br>感じる(かんじる): feel, sense, experience<br>感心(かんしん): admiration, Well done!<br>感ずる(かんずる): feel, sense<br>感想(かんそう): impressions, thoughts<br>感動(かんどう): being deeply moved, deep emotion, excitement, impression<br>実感(じっかん): feelings (actual, true)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>663</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>616</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>663</p> <p id='keyword'>melancholy</p> <p id='kanji'>憂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68682.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>melancholy, summer, head, page, crown, heart, walking legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Head</i> . . . <i>crown</i> . . . <i>heart</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i>. Two things merit mention here. First, the doubling-up of the last stroke of <i>head</i> with the top of the <i>crown</i> serves to make the whole more aesthetically beautiful. It happens so rarely that the exceptions are easily learned. Second, try to make a single image out of the four elements. (Religious statuary of <b>melancholy</b> figures should offer plenty of suggestions.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Melancholy makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so ´emo´. In order to play up his feelings he bares his head and holds his crown over his heart then walks (on walking legs) around the palace making everyone see how melancholy he is. What a wuss.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His crown of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his head and his heart. His walking legs can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How MELANCHOLY!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うれ.える、うれ.い、う.い、う.き</p> <p id='words'>憂鬱(ゆううつ): depression, melancholy, dejection, gloom</p> <p id='readingExamples'>憂い (う.い), 憂い (うれ.い), 憂える (うれ.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>664</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>617</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>664</p> <p id='keyword'>widow</p> <p id='kanji'>寡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AFA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>widow, house, head, page, animal legs, eight, sword, dagger</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>House</i> . . . <i>head</i> . . . <i>dagger</i>. Immediately we get another instance of a very odd exception. Notice how the final stroke of the head is lengthened, giving the final two strokes a chance to stretch out and make room for the <i>dagger</i> that fits in beneath.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The new widow sits in the house, her head in her lap (the extended stroke), her dagger in her husband.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The house´s head, her husband, was murdered with a dagger. You can still see the drops of blood above the dagger. She is now a widow.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

He was buried with his famous sun-flower wand in his hand.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Data laments that he could never see his eminent father, his creator, ever again. 	"<p id='id'>669</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>622</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>669</p> <p id='keyword'>enlightenment</p> <p id='kanji'>悟</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6829F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>enlightenment, Freud, state of mind, I, five, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>I know of an Indian religious sect which teaches that <b>enlightenment</b> is to be had by covering the eyes with one's index fingers, the ears with the thumbs, and the mouth with the little fingers. While these differ a bit from the <i>five holes</i> that we used to represent the ""<i>I</i>"" (frame 17), the idea of achieving a special <i>state of mind</i> by covering those five places can help you learn this kanji. You might try the position out while you are learning this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Enlightenment is a state of mind that goes beyond the five senses.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Data finds enlightenment when he discovers the answer to the question, ""Who am I?"". (Image: Data meditating in a sitting lotus position).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さと.る</p> <p id='words'>悟る(さとる): to attain enlightenment, to perceive, to understand, to discern<br>覚悟(かくご): resolution, resignation, readiness, preparedness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>悟る (さと.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>684</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>634</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>684</p> <p id='keyword'>annexed</p> <p id='kanji'>添</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B7BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>annexed, water, water droplets, water pistol, heavens, valentine</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . heavens . . . valentine.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Hawaii is a little drop of heaven nestled in the waters of the Pacific, most often visited by honeymooners and valentines. It was annexed to the U.S.A. in 1959, and more recently to Japan as well-- albeit only unofficially, and through private commercial holdings.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Annexed to the U.S.A. in 1898, Hawaii is nestled in the waters of the Pacific, a little drop of heaven, often visited on Valentines.. (from Ihatobu with the date corrected. Hawaii became a state in 1959)...　RTK2:　テン　添付　てんぷ(appendix).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そ.える、そ.う、も.える、も.う</p> <p id='words'>添う(そう): to accompany, to become married, to comply with<br>添える(そえる): to add to, to attach, to append, to accompany, to garnish, to imitate, to annex</p> <p id='readingExamples'>添う (そ.う), 添える (そ.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>685</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>635</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>685</p> <p id='keyword'>invariably</p> <p id='kanji'>必</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BF85.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>invariably, heart, stick, drop, fishhook, drop3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>First note the stroke order of this character, which did not really evolve from the <i>heart</i>, even though we take it that way. If one takes it as a pictograph ""dividing"" <i>the heart</i> in half, then one has one of those <b>invariably</b> true bits of human anatomy: the fact that each <i>heart</i> is divided into two halves.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You swear you´ll be in love forever, but invariably there comes a time when your heart is divided.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>For this kanji I invariably got the stroke order wrong. I nearly lost heart, but decided to stick (pun) to it. Then I noticed the order is 1) katakana ソ (altered slightly); 2) fishhook; 3) two drops. Now I invariably get it right.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かなら.ず</p> <p id='words'>必修(ひっしゅう): required (subject)<br>必然(ひつぜん): inevitable, necessary<br>必ずしも(かならずしも): (not) always, (not) necessarily, (not) all, (not) entirely<br>必死(ひっし): inevitable death, desperation, frantic, inevitable result<br>必需品(ひつじゅひん): necessities, necessary article, requisite, essential<br>必ず(かならず): certainly<br>必要(ひつよう): necessary</p> <p id='readingExamples'>必ず (かなら.ず)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>686</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>636</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>686</p> <p id='keyword'>ooze</p> <p id='kanji'>泌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B38C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ooze, water, water droplets, water pistol, invariably, heart, stick, drop, fishhook, drop3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>22</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Water</i> . . . the <i>invariably</i> divided heart.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Anything full of water will invariably begin to ooze.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you pierce a heart with a stake, it invariably oozes blood.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒツ、ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>泌み泌み(しみじみ): keenly, deeply, heartily</p> <p id='readingExamples'>分泌 (ぶんぴつ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>687</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>637</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>687</p> <p id='keyword'>hand</p> <p id='kanji'>手</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6898B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hand</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Any way you count them, there are either too many or too few fingers to see a good pictograph of a <b>hand</b> in this character. But that it is, and so you must.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Keep to the etymology when using this kanji as a primitive: a single <i>hand</i> all by itself.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a hand with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A hand is useful for 千一(1001) things.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ、ズ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>て、て-、-て、た-</p> <p id='words'>上手(うわて): upper part, upper 	"<p id='id'>701</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>649</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>701</p> <p id='keyword'>criticism</p> <p id='kanji'>批</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E689B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>criticism, finger, fingers, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Finger . . . compare.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of the two most famous critics, Ebert and Roeper. Using your fingers, you pick up all of the rocks and get them out of the way so that you can get a comfortable night sleep. 	"<p id='id'>716</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>663</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>716</p> <p id='keyword'>conjecture</p> <p id='kanji'>推</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68EA8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>conjecture, finger, fingers, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . turkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In mathematics, a conjecture is a mathematical statement which has been proposed as a true statement, but which no one has yet been able to prove or disprove. Have you heard of the Finger-Turkey conjecture ? It states that if turkeys had fingers, they would be able to count. Be sure to imagine a turkey with fingers at the tip of its wings, counting from one to ten.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the midst of conjecture on whether it was done or not, mom stuck her fingers in the turkey to check.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.す</p> <p id='words'>推進(すいしん): propulsion, driving force<br>推測(すいそく): guess, conjecture<br>推理(すいり): reasoning, inference, mystery or detective genre (movie novel etc.)<br>類推(るいすい): analogy<br>推薦(すいせん): recommendation<br>推定(すいてい): presumption, assumption, estimation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>推す (お.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"

They get their man in the vault through the ceiling - now he´s hanging from a rope a few feet from the ground (like in the movies, dodging laser beams). He reports back that he has found the loot, and its all in a large piggy bank in the center of the vault. The alarm sounds and he´s got to think fast. He jams the four fingers of his right hand in the piggy bank slot and tells his team to hoist him up, he´s got the loot!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.げる、-あ.げ、あ.がる</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>揚がる (あ.がる), 揚げる (あ.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>718</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>665</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>718</p> <p id='keyword'>propose</p> <p id='kanji'>提</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68F90.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>propose, finger, fingers, just so, sun, day, mend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . just so.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When a man PROPOSES to a lady, he takes her FINGER and places the ring on it JUST SO, and the moment sweeps her away.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I tried to propose to my girlfriend, but the ring was too small to fit her finger. Instead of saying yes, she just uttered an annoyed sigh. So I rushed to the jeweler where he made it bigger. But now it was too big, so I rushed back to make it smaller. This spiel kept going on until the ring was finally just so. Her eyes lit up and she said yes.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ、チョウ、ダイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さ.げる</p> <p id='words'>前提(ぜんてい): preamble, premise, reason, prerequisite<br>提供(ていきょう): offer, tender, program sponsoring, furnishing<br>提携(ていけい): cooperation, tie-up, joint business, link-up<br>提示(ていじ): presentation, exhibit, suggest, citation<br>提案(ていあん): proposal, proposition, suggestion<br>提出(ていしゅつ): presentation, submission, filing</p> <p id='readingExamples'>提げる (さ.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>735</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>680</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>735</p> <p id='keyword'>mould</p> <p id='kanji'>型</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59E8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mould, punish, two hands, sword, sabre, saber, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Punish</i> . . . <i>soil</i>. In cases like this, you might find it easier to break the character up into its more basic elements, like this: <i>two hands</i> . . . <i>saber</i> . . . <i>soil</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A famous ninja once pressed his two hands and saber into the soil of his temple, before going onto a mission from which he never came back. Think of some sort of signature that he left behind him. The mould of his two hands and saber has since become a popular attraction in the area.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>As a PUNISHMENT they made me lay face down in the DIRT leaving a nice imprinted MOULD of my whole BODY.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かた、-がた</p> <p id='words'>模型(もけい): model, dummy, maquette<br>型(かた): mold, model, style, shape, data type<br>典型(てんけい): type, pattern, archetypal</p> <p id='readingExamples'>型 (かた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>736</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>681</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>736</p> <p id='keyword'>genius</p> <p id='kanji'>才</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6898D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>genius, genius, genie</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whatever one is particularly adept at - one's special ""<b>genius</b>"" - one can do very easily, ""with one finger"" as the phrase goes. This kanji is a pictograph of that one finger. Note how its distinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the element for <i>fingers</i> backwards.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning, <i>genie</i>, derives from the roots of the word <i>genius</i>. Use the <i>genie</i> out in the open when the primitive appears to the right of or below its relative primitive; in that case it also keeps its same form. At the left, the form is altered, and the meaning becomes a <i>genie in the bottle</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Spinal tap: ""Every other band´s amps go to ten. But you see my extra stroke of genius - these go to eleven."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A TEN year old had a STROKE of GENIUS and wrote this joke: 何歳ですか？　　　。。。天才です！.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>天才(てんさい): genius, prodigy, natural gift<br>才能(さいのう): talent, ability</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>737</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>682</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>737</p> <p id='keyword'>property</p> <p id='kanji'>財</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>property, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, genie</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Clam . . . genie.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you´re a money genius, you can afford a lot of property.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The keyword refers to property in the sense of money or funds rather than of buildings or real estate. Keep this one distinct from frame 193 (“wealth”) and frame 473 (“assets”). Here we have a genie, gulping down oysters. Someone tries to grab an oyster and the genie puts his big arms around his oysters and states his “right of ownership” : “They´re mines, my property!”.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ザイ、サイ、ゾク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たから</p> <p id='words'>財(ざい): fortune, riches<br>財源(ざいげん): source of funds, resources, finances<br>財政(ざいせい): economy, financial affairs<br>文化財(ぶんかざい): cultural assets, cultural property<br>財産(ざいさん): property, fortune, assets<br>財布(さいふ): purse, wallet</p> <p id='readingExamples'>財産 (ざいさん), 私財 (しざい), 文化財 (ぶんかざい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>738</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>683</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>738</p> <p id='keyword'>lumber</p> <p id='kanji'>材</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69D90.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lumber, tree, wood, genie</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . genie.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A TREE GENIUS is a LUMBER jack. Duh.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Just when the were about to turn the last tree into lumber, the Lorax (the tree-genie) jumps out and puts a stop to the whole affair.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ザイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>教材(きょうざい): teaching materials<br>取材(しゅざい): choice of subject, collecting data<br>人材(じんざい): man of talent<br>素材(そざい): raw materials, subject matter<br>材木(ざいもく): lumber, timber<br>材料(ざいりょう): ingredients, material<br>木材(もくざい): lumber, timber, wood</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>739</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>684</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>739</p> <p id='keyword'>suppose</p> <p id='kanji'>存</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AD98.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>suppose, genie, child</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Genie in the bottle</i> . . . <i>a child</i>. Hint: focus on the key word's connotation of ""make believe"".</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>How do you suppose they manage to cram a genie inside a bottle? Well, I suppose they put him in there while he´s still a little child...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Villagers on a little remote island one day find a bottle washed out by the sea onto the beach. After wiping the bottle and taking a closer look, they are amazed to see a (very small) child in it. The villagers suppose that the child is a genie in a bottle.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソン、ゾン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>依存(いそん): dependence, dependent, reliance<br>共存(きょうそん): coexistence<br>存続(そんぞく): duration, continuance<br>生存(せいぞん): existence, being, survival<br>存在(そんざい): existence, being<br>存じる(ぞんじる): (humble) to know<br>存ずる(ぞんずる): (humble) to think, feel, consider, know, etc.<br>保存(ほぞん): preservation, conservation, storage, maintenance<br>ご存じ(ごぞんじ): know</p> <p id='readingExamples'>存在 (そんざい), 存続 (そんぞく), 既存 (きぞん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>740</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>685</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>740</p> <p id='keyword'>exist</p> <p id='kanji'>在</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59CA8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>exist, genie, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Genie in the bottle . . . soil.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Genie in the bottle does exist but you need to dig deep into the soil to find one.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You wipe the soil from the bottle, only to have a genie float out above you, saying: ´I am the genie in a bottle, what is your wish?´ So now you know that they do exist.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ザイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.る</p> <p id='words'>健在(けんざい): in good health, well<br>在庫(ざいこ): stockpile, stock<br>自在(じざい): freely, at will<br>所在(しょざい): whereabouts<br>不在(ふざい): absence<br>在る(ある): to live, to be<br>現在(げんざい): present, up to now, nowadays, modern times, current<br>在学(ざいがく): (enrolled) in school<br>存在(そんざい): existence, being<br>滞在(たいざい): stay, sojourn</p> <p id='readingExamples'>在る (あ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>741</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>686</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>741</p> <p id='keyword'>from</p> <p id='kanji'>乃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B983.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>from, fist, from</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This pictograph of a clenched fist is another of the ""hand primitives."" Take note of its rather peculiar drawing. Try to think of drawing a <i>fist</i> (the primitive meaning) ""<b>from</b>"" this character to give yourself a connotation for the otherwise abstract key word.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning is taken from the pictograph: a <i>fist</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>FROM a pictograph of a thumbs up. That´s how it also gets the primitive meaning of fist.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think Charlton Heston: ""From my cold, dead fists"". Speech given to the National Boxing Association, in response to stricter control on boxing gloves.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ナイ、ダイ、ノ、アイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>の、すなわ.ち、なんじ</p> <p id='words'>乃至(ないし): from...to, between...and, or</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>742</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>687</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>742</p> <p id='keyword'>portable</p> <p id='kanji'>携</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E690BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>portable, finger, fingers, turkey, fist, from</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . turkey . . . fist.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This character is the ""kei"" in ""keitai"" (cell phone), a word you will no doubt hear often in Japan, since everyone has one. Imagine you´ve just arrived in Japan, but don´t have a cell phone yet, so instead you´re carrying around a portable turkey you can hold in your fist. To dial a number, just poke it with your fingers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Because they have no fingers, turkeys must use their fists when dialing on a portable phone.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たずさ.える、たずさ.わる</p> <p id='words'>携帯(けいたい): carrying something<br>携わる(たずさわる): to participate, to take part<br>提携(ていけい): cooperation, tie-up, joint business, link-up</p> <p id='readingExamples'>携える (たずさ.える), 携わる (たずさ.わる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>743</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>688</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>743</p> <p id='keyword'>reach out</p> <p id='kanji'>及</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>reach out, fist, from, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The addition of a final stroke transforms this character from the primitive for a clenched <i>fist</i> into the kanji for <b>reaching out</b>, much as a stroke of kindness can often turn anger into acceptance.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this shall stand for <i>outstretched hands</i>. Only take care not to confuse it with that for <i>beg</i> (Frame 501)</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I like to think of this as a fist with with brass knuckles because of the extra line. An old school thug reaches out to help you up but then with his other hand ( with the brass knuckles) punches you.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Reach out and fist someone (Do you see the person primitive?).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>およ.ぶ、およ.び、および、およ.ぼす</p> <p id='words'>及び(および): and, as well as<br>及ぶ(およぶ): to reach, to come up to, to amount to, to befall, to happen to, to extend, to match, to equal<br>追及(ついきゅう): gaining on, carrying out, solving (crime)<br>及ぼす(およぼす): exert, cause, exercise<br>普及(ふきゅう): diffusion, spread</p> <p id='readingExamples'>及び (およ.び), 及ぶ (およ.ぶ), 及ぼす (およ.ぼす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>746</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>691</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>746</p> <p id='keyword'>length</p> <p id='kanji'>丈</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B888.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>length, stick, tucked under the arm</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>length</b> whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with <i>arms</i> at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from <i>large</i> (Frame 112).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare ""length"" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldn´t show ""it"" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your length. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たけ、だけ</p> <p id='words'>頑丈(がんじょう): solid, firm, stout, burly, strong, sturdy<br>丈夫(じょうふ): hero, gentleman, warrior, manly person, good health, robustness, strong, solid, durable<br>丈(たけ): height, stature, length, measure, all (one has)<br>丈(だけ): only, just, as<br>成る丈(なるたけ): as much as possible, if possible<br>丈夫(じょうぶ): good health, robustness, strong, solid, durable, hero, gentleman, warrior, manly person<br>大丈夫(だいじょうぶ): safe, all right, O.K.</p> <p id='readingExamples'>丈 (たけ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>747</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>692</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>747</p> <p id='keyword'>history</p> <p id='kanji'>史</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58FB2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>history, mouth, tucked under the arm</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A mouth . . . tucked under the arm.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I sleep in history class with my mouth tucked under my arm.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>History students usually going to school with a history book tucked under their arm.
