	"<p id='id'>749</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>694</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>749</p> <p id='keyword'>grow late</p> <p id='kanji'>更</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69BB4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grow late, Ameratasu, one, ceiling, sun, tucked under the arm</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The implication behind the meaning of <b>grow late</b> is that things are changing in the same way that the day turns into night. The elements: <i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>sun</i> . . . <i>tucked under the arm</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At nightbreak (#30) the sun rises above the floor, so it is logical that when it is growing late, the sun would rise to the ceiling. Time to pack up your things and take your belongings under your arm.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It´s starting to GROW LATE, so God will take the SUN, and TUCK IT UNDER HIS ARM, and walk away. In the morning, he´ll bring it back, so don´t worry.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さら、さら.に、ふ.ける、ふ.かす</p> <p id='words'>今更(いまさら): now, at this late hour<br>尚更(なおさら): all the more, still less<br>夜更かし(よふかし): staying up late, keeping late hours, sitting up late at night, nighthawk<br>夜更け(よふけ): late at night<br>更に(さらに): furthermore, again, after all, more and more, moreover<br>更ける(ふける): get late, advance, wear on,<br>変更(へんこう): change, modification, alteration</p> <p id='readingExamples'>更 (さら), 更かす (ふ.かす), 更ける (ふ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>750</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>695</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>750</p> <p id='keyword'>stiff</p> <p id='kanji'>硬</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A1AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stiff, stone, rock, grow late, Ameratasu, one, ceiling, sun, tucked under the arm</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rocks . . . grow late.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A stiff drink on the ROCKs after it GROWS LATE is a way to unwind after a long day...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Stones are so stiff that even if you spent all day straining trying to change their shape, it would grow late far before you ever accomplished your task.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かた.い</p> <p id='words'>強硬(きょうこう): firm, vigorous, unbending, unyielding, strong, stubborn<br>硬い(かたい): solid, hard (especially metal, stone), unpolished writing<br>硬貨(こうか): coin</p> <p id='readingExamples'>硬い (かた.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>752</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>696</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>752</p> <p id='keyword'>or again</p> <p id='kanji'>又</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F88.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>or again, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Like the several abbreviations in Roman script to indicate ""and"" (+, &amp;, etc.), this short two-stroke kanji is used for the similar meaning of <b>or again</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, it will mean <i>crotch</i>, as in the <i>crotch</i> of the arm. Or whatever.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>After her boyfriend´s crotch has been satisfied, a woman might suggest they cuddle. The boyfriend, on the other hand, might say, ""Or again, we could fool around . . . "".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This keyword should really be ""again"" not ""or again"" Here is some context: think of the phrase ""Jya mata"" ""じゃ又"" which is a farewell similar to ""then again"". Also ""Mata ne"" ""又ね"" and mata ashita (again tomorrow) ""又明日""。 Note this kanji is rarely used, most of the time JP people spell it out ""mata"" except for in the last example: 又明日.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>また、また-、また.の-</p> <p id='words'>又(また): again, and<br>又は(または): or, the other</p> <p id='readingExamples'>又 (また)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>753</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>697</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>753</p> <p id='keyword'>pair</p> <p id='kanji'>双</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pair, crotch, crotch2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>crotch</i> reduplicated gives us a <b>pair</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Crotch to crotch is how many pairs spend their private time together. . .</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The animals boarding Noah´s Ark all came in pairs – but Noah had to carefully check the two crotches in each pair to ensure that the animals were of different sexes and thus able to further their species after the flood.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふた、たぐい、ならぶ、ふたつ</p> <p id='words'>双子(ふたご): twins, a twin</p> <p id='readingExamples'>双 (ふた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>754</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>698</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>754</p> <p id='keyword'>mulberry</p> <p id='kanji'>桑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A191.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mulberry, crotch, tree, wood, crotch3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Crotches</i>, <i>crotches</i> everywhere . . . <i>tree</i>. Hint: think of a group of children playing an original version of ""Here We Go 'Round the <b>Mulberry</b> Bush.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Children going around the mulberry tree singing ""This is the way we wash our crotch, wash our crotch, wash our crotch..."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine kids all over the top of a mulberry tree, sitting astride limbs so that their weight is on their crotches. (Mulberry trees have big sprawling limbs that run horizontally or at shallow angles making them easy to climb and sit in. I have an old mulberry in my yard, and my kids are in it constantly).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くわ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>桑 (くわ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>755</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>699</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>755</p> <p id='keyword'>vessels</p> <p id='kanji'>隻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99ABB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vessels, turkey, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word indicates the Japanese generic term for counting ships. Its elements: <i>turkey</i> . . . <i>crotch</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>On Vessels that travel long distances, sailors often get quite lonely. They keep TURKEYS on the VESSELS, but not for use as food. The lonely sailors take turns enjoying the turkey´s CROTCH.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Donald Duck is a big bird that does not wear pants. It´s good to use him as a mnemonic because he is a sailor, and this kanji is used to count vessels.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>756</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>700</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>756</p> <p id='keyword'>safeguard</p> <p id='kanji'>護</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8ADB7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>safeguard, say, words, keitai, mouth, radio caroline, flowers, vessels, turkey, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>20</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . flowers . . . vessels.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of the flower-vessels as a the Greenpeace vessel “Arctic Sunrise”, only instead of a rainbow there is a big flower painted on the hull (this will come back in seize (#701) and harvest (#908)). Think of “flower-power” and of the “peace” in “Greenpeace” and it will make some sense hopefully. -- In this kanji, we see an inauguration speech being given before the Greenpeace vessel is set afloat and sent to safeguard our planet.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(With sarcasm) A Bush speech telling how all the US vessels are always welcomed, covered with flowers and words of gratitude for safeguarding democracy from the evil doers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まも.る</p> <p id='words'>介護(かいご): nursing<br>看護(かんご): nursing, (army) nurse<br>護衛(ごえい): guard, convoy, escort<br>弁護(べんご): defense, pleading, advocacy<br>保護(ほご): care, protection, shelter, guardianship, favor, patronage<br>養護(ようご): protection, nursing, protective care<br>看護婦(かんごふ): nurse</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>757</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>701</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>757</p> <p id='keyword'>seize</p> <p id='kanji'>獲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78DB2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>seize, pack of wild dogs, radio caroline, flowers, vessels, turkey, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A pack of <i>wild dogs</i> . . . <i>flowers</i> . . . <i>vessels</i>. Do not confuse this with the character for <i>arrest</i> (Frame 706).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A pack of genetically-modified wild dogs is seized by a group of Greenpeace activists and taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (the flower vessel, see safeguard (#700)).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Customs just seized a crate of poppies (flowers) detected by trained wild dogs who inspected the vessel.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>え.る</p> <p id='words'>獲物(えもの): game, spoils, trophy<br>獲得(かくとく): acquisition, possession<br>捕獲(ほかく): capture, seizure</p> <p id='readingExamples'>獲る (え.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>758</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>702</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>758</p> <p id='keyword'>guy</p> <p id='kanji'>奴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A5B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>guy, woman, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Woman . . . crotch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>That GUY stole my WOMAN so I kicked him in the CROTCH. (This story helps keep the word ""GUY"" as someone you hold in contempt).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Guys only care about 2 things: women and their crotch (preferably at the same time).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ド</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やつ、やっこ</p> <p id='words'>奴(やっこ): servant, fellow</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>759</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>703</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>759</p> <p id='keyword'>angry</p> <p id='kanji'>怒</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68092.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>angry, guy, woman, crotch, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Guy . . . heart.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This woman is angry because of the guys in the previous frame who pay more attention to her crotch than her heart. I prefer to decompose the kanji in three elements here because it is easier to read like a mnemonic.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>WOMEN get very ANGRY over the thought that GUYS are more interested in her CROTCH than her HEART.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ド、ヌ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いか.る、おこ.る</p> <p id='words'>怒り(いかり): anger, hatred<br>怒る(いかる): to get angry, to be angry<br>怒鳴る(どなる): to shout, to yell<br>怒る(おこる): get angry</p> <p id='readingExamples'>怒る (いか.る), 怒る (おこ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>760</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>704</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>760</p> <p id='keyword'>friend</p> <p id='kanji'>友</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>friend, by one’s side, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>By one's side . . . crotch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A good friend is always at your side. ---- I teach at a Japanese High School, and I often see chummy male students grabbing each other´s crotches in a joking manner. It´s still weird to me, but apparently reaching to your side and grabbing you neighbor´s crotch is a great way to express friendship.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think of a sex friend (a fuck buddy if you will). The benefit of such a relationship is that there will always be a crotch by your side. (the Japanese refer to such a friend as セフレ, just as we do).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とも</p> <p id='words'>友(とも): friend, companion, pal<br>親友(しんゆう): close friend<br>友好(ゆうこう): friendship<br>友情(ゆうじょう): friendship, fellowship<br>友人(ゆうじん): friend<br>友達(ともだち): friend</p> <p id='readingExamples'>友 (とも)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>761</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>705</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>761</p> <p id='keyword'>slip out</p> <p id='kanji'>抜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68A9C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>slip out, finger, fingers, friend, woman, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . friend.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Don´t let good friends slip out between your fingers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine a cliché Hollywood situation: one person is lying on the edge of the abyss and another (presumably his friend) is hanging, only thing holding him is the grip of their hands. Then fingers slip out of the grip and he falls in said abyss.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>バツ、ハツ、ハイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ぬ.く、-ぬ.く、ぬ.き、ぬ.ける、ぬ.かす、ぬ.かる</p> <p id='words'>海抜(かいばつ): height above sea level<br>抜かす(ぬかす): to omit, to leave out<br>抜け出す(ぬけだす): to slip out, to sneak away, to excel<br>抜く(ぬく): extract, omit, surpass, draw out, unplug<br>抜ける(ぬける): come out, fall out, be omitted, be missing, escape</p> <p id='readingExamples'>抜かす (ぬ.かす), 抜かる (ぬ.かる), 抜く (ぬ.く), 抜ける (ぬ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>762</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>706</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>762</p> <p id='keyword'>throw</p> <p id='kanji'>投</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68A95.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>throw, finger, fingers, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . missile.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Well, you usually use your fingers to throw objects used as missile weapons. Easy. By the way, for those of you looking for a less anachronistic image for the missile primitive as a modern rocket, try a slingshot. it´s a crotch (originally a tree branch) that sends missile projectiles flying into/like the wind. And for this present kanji, it is something you naturally use with your fingers...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you use the primitive ""semen"" (flying in the wind from your crotch) instead of missile then all kanjis with this primitive will hilariously create a perfect story.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>な.げる、-な.げ</p> <p id='words'>投資(とうし): investment<br>投入(とうにゅう): throw, investment, making (an electrical circuit)<br>投げ出す(なげだす): to throw down, to abandon, to sacrifice, to throw out<br>投書(とうしょ): letter to the editor, letter from a reader, contribution<br>投票(とうひょう): voting, poll<br>投げる(なげる): throw</p> <p id='readingExamples'>投げる (な.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>763</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>707</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>763</p> <p id='keyword'>drown</p> <p id='kanji'>没</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B2A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>drown, water, water droplets, water pistol, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . missile.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>(Note: this kanji is more collapse/cave-in/sink (#1888) than humans drowning) A water missile? A torpedo! And when it hits it´s target? The ship collapses then sinks and everyone drowns!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The submarine´s hull was breached after being struck by a torpedo (""water missile""), causing the entire crew to drown.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボツ、モツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おぼ.れる、しず.む、ない</p> <p id='words'>沈没(ちんぼつ): sinking, foundering<br>没収(ぼっしゅう): forfeited<br>没落(ぼつらく): ruin, fall, collapse</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Writers will use words, whereas militars will use missiles.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you attack the establishment with words, it fights back with missiles.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>セツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もう.ける</p> <p id='words'>施設(しせつ): institution, establishment, facility, (army) engineer<br>設置(せっち): establishment, institution<br>設定(せってい): establishment, creation<br>設立(せつりつ): establishment, foundation, institution<br>設ける(もうける): to create, to establish<br>建設(けんせつ): construction, establishment<br>設計(せっけい): plan, design<br>設備(せつび): equipment, device, facilities, installation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>設ける (もう.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"

That beats mine, hands down.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think 3 methods of attack all combined into 1 kanji: 1. Vehicle to transport troops 2. Once troops have disembarked they have their missiles 3. If they run out of missiles they resort to hand to hand combat to beat the enemy.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>う.つ</p> <p id='words'>襲撃(しゅうげき): attack, charge, raid<br>衝撃(しょうげき): shock, crash, impact, ballistic<br>打撃(だげき): blow, shock, strike, damage, batting (baseball)<br>反撃(はんげき): counterattack, counteroffensive, counterblow<br>撃つ(うつ): attack, defeat, destroy<br>攻撃(こうげき): attack, strike, offensive, criticism, censure</p> <p id='readingExamples'>撃つ (う.つ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Japan´s recent history in a nutshell: first the samurai became superfluous and then the Americans started to throw missiles and bombs during WWII.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク、コク、バイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>から、がら</p> <p id='words'>貝殻(かいがら): shell<br>殻(から): shell, husk, hull, chaff</p> <p id='readingExamples'>殻 (から)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>768</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>711</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>768</p> <p id='keyword'>branch</p> <p id='kanji'>支</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E694AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>branch, ten, needle, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Needle . . . crotch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Picture sliding down the branch of a tree (in this case a pine tree or any tree with needles) and getting a bunch of needles stuck in your crotch--ouch!!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A special branch of the military called the Needle Crotch Unit. Their only weapon is the needle embedded in their crotches, and they´re quite adept at using them.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ささ.える、つか.える、か.う、しんよう、じゅうまた</p> <p id='words'>差し支える(さしつかえる): to interfere, to hinder, to become impeded<br>支持(しじ): support, maintenance<br>収支(しゅうし): income and expenditure<br>支える(ささえる): support, prop up<br>差し支え(さしつかえ): hindrance, impediment<br>支給(しきゅう): payment, allowance<br>支出(ししゅつ): expenditure, expenses<br>支度(したく): preparation<br>支店(してん): branch store (office)<br>支配(しはい): rule, control, direction<br>支払(しはらい): payment<br>支払う(しはらう): to pay</p> <p id='readingExamples'>支える (ささ.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>769</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>712</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>769</p> <p id='keyword'>skill</p> <p id='kanji'>技</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68A80.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>skill, finger, fingers, branch, ten, needle, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . branch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>(Adapted from darg_sama´s) Balancing a branch on your finger is the prototypical example of a skill that is nothing more than a skill (i.e., it is completely useless).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I think of a guy balancing a branch on his finger, which definitely takes some minimal amount of skill.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わざ</p> <p id='words'>技能(ぎのう): technical skill, ability, capacity<br>特技(とくぎ): special skill<br>技(わざ): art, technique<br>演技(えんぎ): acting, performance<br>技師(ぎし): engineer, technician<br>競技(きょうぎ): game, match, contest<br>技術(ぎじゅつ): technique</p> <p id='readingExamples'>技 (わざ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>770</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>713</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>770</p> <p id='keyword'>bough</p> <p id='kanji'>枝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69E9D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bough, tree, wood, branch, ten, needle, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Tree</i> . . . <i>branch</i>. Take a moment to focus on the differences between a <b>bough</b>, a <i>branch</i>, and a <i>twig</i> (Frame 319).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The tree´s primary branch is known as the bough.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Differentiate between BOUGH and branch (#711): ´branch´ is smaller, and can also refer to the branch of a store (支店), which has nothing to do with a tree. But a BOUGH is a main part of a tree, perhaps where the trunk splits into several large boughs, and so it logically utilizes the 木 radical.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>えだ</p> <p id='words'>枝(えだ): branch</p> <p id='readingExamples'>枝 (えだ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>771</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>714</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>771</p> <p id='keyword'>limb</p> <p id='kanji'>肢</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E882A2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>limb, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, branch, ten, needle, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Part of the body . . . branch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The limbs that this kanji represents are parts of the body that are connected to the trunk, like the main branches to a tree (“arms and legs” is the second meaning of this kanji). In other words, limbs are ""flesh branches"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Limbs are body parts that branch off.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>772</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>715</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>772</p> <p id='keyword'>stalk</p> <p id='kanji'>茎</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88C8E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stalk, flowers, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flower . . . spool.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Suggestion: Replace ""spool"" with ""toilet paper/roll"". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Just get a flower and carefully wrap some toilet paper around its stalk. Spool also appears in suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), diameter (#882), sutra (#1360).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>PRIMITIVE: soiled crotch = soiled underwear. To precent anyone from picking the beautiful flower, the gardner hung soiled underwear on the stalk.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ、キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くき</p> <p id='words'>茎(くき): stalk</p> <p id='readingExamples'>茎 (くき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>773</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>716</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>773</p> <p id='keyword'>suspicious</p> <p id='kanji'>怪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E680AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>suspicious, Freud, state of mind, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>State of mind . . . spool.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you´re suspicious, your state of mind twists round and round like a spool of thread.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine a loud farting sound on The Enterprise (sorry). Everyone looks around trying to find who did it. The one looking most suspicious is Data. His soiled crotch gives him away.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ、ケ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あや.しい、あや.しむ</p> <p id='words'>怪獣(かいじゅう): monster<br>怪我(けが): injury, get hurt, be injured<br>怪しい(あやしい): suspicious, doubtful</p> <p id='readingExamples'>怪しい (あや.しい), 怪しむ (あや.しむ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>774</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>717</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>774</p> <p id='keyword'>lightly</p> <p id='kanji'>軽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BBBD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lightly, car, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Car . . . spool.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Fact: this kanji is used to denote a certain class of vehicles in Japan whose engines are under a certain size (less than 750cc I think) and are called light vehicles here. Imagine a so-called light vehicle or a light-truck with a load of spools driving down a road ever so lightly, careful not to let any of the spools roll out onto the street.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I want to tread lightly on the environment.... That´s why I CAR-SPOOL to work everyday.... I know, lame.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かる.い、かろ.やか、かろ.んじる</p> <p id='words'>気軽(きがる): cheerful, buoyant, lighthearted<br>軽快(けいかい): rhythmical (e.g. melody), casual (e.g. dress), light, nimble<br>軽減(けいげん): abatement<br>軽率(けいそつ): rash, thoughtless, careless, hasty<br>軽蔑(けいべつ): scorn, disdain<br>手軽(てがる): easy, simple, informal, offhand, cheap<br>軽い(かるい): light, non-serious, minor</p> <p id='readingExamples'>軽い (かる.い), 軽やか (かろ.やか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>775</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>718</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>775</p> <p id='keyword'>uncle</p> <p id='kanji'>叔</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F94.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>uncle, above, small, little, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Above . . . little . . . crotch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Oh come on people - say what we´ve all been thinking: the uncle is that creepy guy towering above a little one´s crotch.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team). You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>叔父(おじ): uncle (younger than one´s parent)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>776</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>719</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>776</p> <p id='keyword'>coach</p> <p id='kanji'>督</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79DA3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>coach, uncle, above, small, little, crotch, eye</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Uncle . . . eye.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Creepy uncle volunteers as gymnastics coach so he can eye the team from below.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. 	"<p id='id'>777</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>720</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>777</p> <p id='keyword'>loneliness</p> <p id='kanji'>寂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AF82.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>loneliness, house, uncle, above, small, little, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . uncle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The unmarried uncle´s house is the picture of lonlieness.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジャク、セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さび、さび.しい、さび.れる、さみ.しい</p> <p id='words'>寂しい(さびしい): lonely</p> <p id='readingExamples'>寂滅 (じゃくめつ), 静寂 (せいじゃく), 閑寂 (かんじゃく), 寂 (さび), 寂しい (さび.しい), 寂れる (さび.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>778</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>721</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>778</p> <p id='keyword'>graceful</p> <p id='kanji'>淑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B791.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>graceful, water, water droplets, water pistol, uncle, above, small, little, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . uncle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Uncle (the one who is lonely and coaches kids in his spare time) is actually a graceful guy once he hits the water, as he used to be part of the swimming team in his youth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しと.やか</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>779</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>722</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>779</p> <p id='keyword'>anti-</p> <p id='kanji'>反</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F8D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>anti-, demonstation, cliff, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cliff . . . crotch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I think of an anti-hero (Dirty Harry etc.) for this primitive, whose trademark for disposing of villians is not an honorable fight, but a kick in the crotch and then a shove off a cliff (perhaps whilst the villain´s back is turned).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Many cultures are so anti-sex you´d think they just want people to throw their crotches over a cliff.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン、ホン、タン、ホ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そ.る、そ.らす、かえ.す、かえ.る、-かえ.る</p> <p id='words'>反り(そり): warp, curvature, curve, arch<br>反(たん): roll of cloth (c. 10 yds.), .245 acres, 300 tsubo<br>反感(はんかん): antipathy, revolt, animosity<br>反響(はんきょう): echo, reverberation, repercussion, reaction, influence<br>反撃(はんげき): counterattack, counteroffensive, counterblow<br>反射(はんしゃ): reflection, reverberation<br>反する(はんする): to be inconsistent with, to oppose, to contradict, to transgress, to rebel<br>反応(はんのう): reaction, response<br>反発(はんぱつ): repelling, rebound, recover, oppose<br>反乱(はんらん): insurrection, mutiny, rebellion, revolt, uprising<br>違反(いはん): violation (of law), transgression<br>反る(かえる): change, turn over, turn upside down<br>反映(はんえい): reflection, influence<br>反抗(はんこう): opposition, resistance, insubordination, defiance, hostility, rebellion<br>反省(はんせい): reflection, reconsideration, introspection, meditation, contemplation<br>反対(はんたい): oppose</p> <p id='readingExamples'>反映 (はんえい), 反対 (はんたい), 違反 (いはん), 謀反 (むほん), 反らす (そ.らす), 反る (そ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>780</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>723</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>780</p> <p id='keyword'>slope</p> <p id='kanji'>坂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59D82.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>slope, soil, dirt, ground, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ground . . . anti-.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>As the villain (pushed off by the anti-hero) is tumbling down the slope, he activates gadget skis to escape, spraying soil everywhere as he flies down the slope.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji depicts a classic enviornmental problem: erosion. Erosion occurs when all of the soil washes of the side of the cliff, eventually causing the cliff to disappear, leaving a slope (an anti- cliff if you will) in its place.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さか</p> <p id='words'>坂(さか): slope, hill</p> <p id='readingExamples'>坂 (さか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>781</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>724</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>781</p> <p id='keyword'>plank</p> <p id='kanji'>板</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69DBF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>plank, tree, wood, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . anti-.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Of course, trees are anti-plank. Wouldn´t you be if you were a tree?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Trees are naturally opposed to, or anti, the making of planks.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン、バン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いた</p> <p id='words'>板(いた): board, plank<br>看板(かんばん): sign, signboard, doorplate, poster, billboard, appearance, figurehead, policy, attraction, closing time<br>黒板(こくばん): blackboard</p> <p id='readingExamples'>乾板 (かんばん), 鉄板 (てっぱん), 板 (いた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>782</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>725</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>782</p> <p id='keyword'>return</p> <p id='kanji'>返</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BF94.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>return, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Anti- . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pretty obvious: to return is to turn back on the road you´re on and go the opposite way.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In ""The Return of the anti-hero"", Clint Eastwood kicks the villain in the crotch, pushes them off the cliff and onto a busy highway. A tiring movie franchise to say the least....</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かえ.す、-かえ.す、かえ.る、-かえ.る</p> <p id='words'>裏返し(うらがえし): inside out, upside down<br>折り返す(おりかえす): to turn up, to fold back<br>返る(かえる): to return, to come back, to go back<br>宙返り(ちゅうがえり): somersault, looping-the-loop<br>照り返す(てりかえす): to reflect, to throw back light<br>返還(へんかん): return, restoration<br>返済(へんさい): repayment<br>返事(へんじ): reply, answer<br>返答(へんとう): reply<br>裏返す(うらがえす): turn inside out, turn the other way, turn over<br>繰り返す(くりかえす): repeat, do over again<br>引返す(ひきかえす): repeat, send back, bring back, retrace one´s steps<br>引っ繰り返す(ひっくりかえす): turn over, overturn, knock over, upset, turn inside out<br>引っ繰り返る(ひっくりかえる): be overturned, be upset, topple over, be reversed<br>返す(かえす): return (something)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>返す (かえ.す), 返る (かえ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>783</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>726</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>783</p> <p id='keyword'>marketing</p> <p id='kanji'>販</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>marketing, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Shells/money . . . anti-.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The goal of marketing is to get people who are naturally anti-buying to spend their shells (money).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>『MARKETING: MONEY, ANTI』 The wide presence of MARKETING in our society has led people to become ANTI-MONEY.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>販売(はんばい): sale, selling, marketing</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>784</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>727</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>784</p> <p id='keyword'>claw</p> <p id='kanji'>爪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E788AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>claw, vulture</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is a pictograph of a bird's <b>claw</b>, and from there comes to mean animal <b>claws</b> in general (including human fingernails).</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we shall use the graphic image of a <i>vulture</i>, a bird known for its powerful <i>claws</i>. It generally appears above another primitive, in which case it gets squeezed into the form ⺥.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A pictograph of Wolverine´s adamantium claws.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Pictograph, see book. * I prefer the primitive meaning of an eagle rather than vulture. Somehow vulture makes me think more about meat and dead corpses than claws. An eagle however immediately brings to my mind the image of an eagle plunging into a stream catching fish in his claws, or that of the great eagles rescuing Bilbo and his party in Jrr Tolkien´s novel “Bilbo the Hobbit”.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つめ、つま-</p> <p id='words'>爪(つめ): fingernail or toenail, claw, talon, hoof</p> <p id='readingExamples'>爪 (つめつま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>785</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>728</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>785</p> <p id='keyword'>gentle</p> <p id='kanji'>妥</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A6A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>gentle, claw, vulture, woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Vulture . . . woman.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Overly gentle women are vultures who want to marry you and steal your money - not true but an easy mnemonic!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An eagle must be extra gentle to pick up a dainty woman in its sharp claws.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>妥協(だきょう): compromise, giving in<br>妥結(だけつ): agreement<br>妥当(だとう): valid, proper, right, appropriate</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>786</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>729</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>786</p> <p id='keyword'>milk</p> <p id='kanji'>乳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B9B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>milk, fledgling, claw, vulture, child, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fledglings . . . hook.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A fledgling is being nursed at a zoo, it is fed milk through a small tube that is bent in the shape of a hook (so that it fits inside its beak). The fledgling soon becomes addicted to milk, giving us this very catchy mnemonic: “fledgling hooked on milk”.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Drinking milk not only reduces cavity (#96)´s but also strengthens nails (claws) thanks astgtciv.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ニュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ちち、ち</p> <p id='words'>乳(ちち): milk, breast, loop<br>牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう): cow´s milk</p> <p id='readingExamples'>乳 (ち), 乳 (ちち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>792</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>733</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>792</p> <p id='keyword'>pick</p> <p id='kanji'>採</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68EA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pick, finger, fingers, grab, claw, vulture, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Unlike <i>pick up</i> (Frame 720), this character is used for <b>picking</b> fruits from trees. Its elements: <i>finger</i> . . . <i>grab</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You pick cheries with your fingers, then along comes a giant vulture and picks up the whole tree with its claws.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tip: vulture + tree : Heisig later combines these into a single kanji 采 called grab (#2090). Story: As you go to pick your nose, your parent grabs your finger and pulls it away (& gives you a lecture on social etiquette). REF: ""grab"" also appears in vegetable (#734), coloring (#1714).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>サイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.る</p> <p id='words'>採掘(さいくつ): mining<br>採決(さいけつ): vote, roll call<br>採算(さいさん): profit<br>採集(さいしゅう): collecting, gathering<br>採択(さいたく): adoption, selection, choice<br>採用(さいよう): use, adopt<br>採点(さいてん): marking, grading, looking over<br>採る(とる): adopt (measure, proposal), pick (fruit), assume (attitude)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>採る (と.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>801</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>740</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>801</p> <p id='keyword'>broaden</p> <p id='kanji'>拡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68BA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>broaden, finger, fingers, wide, cave, elbow</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>wide</i>. Beware.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Japanese girls are tight and may require fingers inserted to broaden them and make them wide enough before you can...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Spread your fingers wide to broaden your hand.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク、コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひろ.がる、ひろ.げる、ひろ.める</p> <p id='words'>拡散(かくさん): scattering, diffusion<br>拡充(かくじゅう): expansion<br>拡大(かくだい): magnification, enlargement<br>拡張(かくちょう): expansion, extension, enlargement, escape</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>802</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>741</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>802</p> <p id='keyword'>mineral</p> <p id='kanji'>鉱</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E989B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mineral, metal, gold, wide, cave, elbow</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Metal . . . wide.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Elbonium: a new mineral found in wide caves shaped like elbows and made of metal.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A wide range of metals are classed as minerals.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あらがね</p> <p id='words'>鉱業(こうぎょう): mining industry<br>鉱山(こうざん): mine (ore)<br>鉱物(こうぶつ): mineral<br>炭鉱(たんこう): coal mine</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>805</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>744</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>805</p> <p id='keyword'>pedestal</p> <p id='kanji'>台</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58FB0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pedestal, elbow, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Elbow . . . mouth.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When someone´s elbow is above your mouth he/she is probably standing on a pedestal.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>After training your whole life, you manage to get a bronze medal in the Olympics. You´re extremely proud of your accomplishment as you step up to receive your medal. The guy in first place is up on a pedestal, towering above you, his elbow level with your mouth. Being a smug bastard, he ""accidentally"" knocks his elbow into your mouth, causing you to bleed and lose a tooth. Just cause he won the gold doesn´t mean he can place himself on such a high pedestal and do whatever he wants!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダイ、タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うてな、われ、つかさ</p> <p id='words'>台無し(だいなし): mess, spoiled, (come to) nothing<br>台本(だいほん): libretto, scenario<br>土台(どだい): foundation, base, basis<br>寝台(しんだい): bed, couch<br>台(だい): stand, rack, table, support<br>灯台(とうだい): lighthouse<br>舞台(ぶたい): stage (theatre), scene or setting (e.g. of novel, play, etc.)<br>台風(たいふう): typhoon<br>台所(だいどころ): kitchen</p> <p id='readingExamples'>台地 (だいち), 灯台 (とうだい), 一台 (いちだい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>811</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>749</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>811</p> <p id='keyword'>window</p> <p id='kanji'>窓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AA93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>window, hole, house, human legs, elbow, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . human legs . . . elbow . . . heart.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The top primitive is similar to hole (#1316). A window is a hole (#1316) in your house that you occassionally sit next to while leaning on your ELBOW and gazing out, a picture of a lonely HEARTedness.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Anna stood inside the house 宀 on her human legs 儿 enjoying some private 厶 time, looking out the window and communing with the feelings that were in her heart 心. The first five strokes are actually 穴、あな, ""hole,"" introduced later. 窓、まど, window; 窓口、まどぐち, ticket window; 車窓、しゃそう, car window.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ、ス</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まど、てんまど、けむだし</p> <p id='words'>窓口(まどぐち): ticket window<br>窓(まど): window</p> <p id='readingExamples'>窓 (まど)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>813</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>751</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>813</p> <p id='keyword'>method</p> <p id='kanji'>法</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B395.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>method, water, water droplets, water pistol, gone, soil, dirt, ground, elbow</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . gone.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji shows up in a lot of words related to the legal process. Try this image: using a very outdated judicial method, the people of Salem dunked accused witches in the water until they were all gone.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There already was a system (#418) for butchering cows, a technique (#421) for turning smoke into flowers - why can´t there be a method of about the same relevance for making water gone? Evaporation anyone?</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ、ハッ、ホッ、フラン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>のり</p> <p id='words'>司法(しほう): administration of justice<br>手法(しゅほう): technique<br>寸法(すんぽう): measurement, size, dimension<br>製法(せいほう): manufacturing method, recipe, formula<br>法(ほう): law<br>法案(ほうあん): bill (law)<br>法学(ほうがく): law, jurisprudence<br>法廷(ほうてい): courtroom<br>用法(ようほう): directions, rules of use<br>立法(りっぽう): legislation, lawmaking<br>憲法(けんぽう): constitution<br>作法(さほう): manners, etiquette, propriety<br>法則(ほうそく): law, rule<br>方法(ほうほう): method, process, manner, way, means, technique<br>文法(ぶんぽう): grammar<br>法律(ほうりつ): law</p> <p id='readingExamples'>法律 (ほうりつ), 文法 (ぶんぽう), 方法 (ほうほう), 法度 (ほうど)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>814</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>752</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>814</p> <p id='keyword'>meeting</p> <p id='kanji'>会</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BC9A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>meeting, meeting, one, wall, umbrella, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Meeting</i> . . . <i>wall</i>. This is the full character for <b>meeting</b>, from which the abbreviated primitive that we met back in lesson 12 gets its name.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business meeting in a very special room where the walls are ... meeting. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these meetings, he´s the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The only thing created in most meetings is a lot of hot air. Imagine a cloud of it rising to the roof.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ、エ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.う、あ.わせる、あつ.まる</p> <p id='words'>会(え): understanding<br>会(かい): meeting, assembly, party, association, club<br>会見(かいけん): interview, audience<br>会談(かいだん): conversation, conference, discussion, interview<br>協会(きょうかい): association, society, organization<br>再会(さいかい): another meeting, meeting again, reunion<br>座談会(ざだんかい): symposium, round-table discussion<br>総会(そうかい): general meeting<br>出会う(であう): to meet by chance, to come across, to happen to encounter, to hold a rendezvous, to have a date<br>面会(めんかい): interview<br>宴会(えんかい): party, banquet<br>会員(かいいん): member, the membership<br>開会(かいかい): opening of a meeting<br>会館(かいかん): meeting hall, assembly hall<br>会計(かいけい): account, finance, accountant, treasurer, paymaster, reckoning, bill<br>会合(かいごう): meeting, assembly<br>学会(がっかい): scientific society, academic meeting<br>議会(ぎかい): Diet, congress, parliament<br>国会(こっかい): National Diet, parliament, congress<br>司会(しかい): chairmanship<br>社会科学(しゃかいかがく): social science<br>集会(しゅうかい): meeting, assembly<br>大会(たいかい): convention, tournament, mass meeting, rally<br>出会い(であい): meeting, rendezvous, encounter<br>都会(とかい): city<br>閉会(へいかい): closure<br>会議(かいぎ): meeting<br>会場(かいじょう): the place of meeting<br>会話(かいわ): conversation<br>機会(きかい): opportunity, chance<br>教会(きょうかい): church<br>社会(しゃかい): society<br>展覧会(てんらんかい): exhibition<br>会う(あう): to meet, to interview<br>会社(かいしゃ): company, corporation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>会話 (かいわ), 会計 (かいけい), 社会 (しゃかい), 会う (あ.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>815</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>753</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>815</p> <p id='keyword'>climax</p> <p id='kanji'>至</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E887B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>climax, wall, one, ceiling, elbow, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Wall</i> . . . <i>soil</i>. The key word allows for the full variety of connotations: to peak, to arrive at the end, and the like.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sexual climaxes don´t always happen on the bed; they sometimes happen against a wall or on the ground!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The climax of the Berlin Wall affair was the tearing of it to ground.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いた.る</p> <p id='words'>至って(いたって): very much, exceedingly, extremely<br>乃至(ないし): from...to, between...and, or<br>至る(いたる): come, arrive<br>至急(しきゅう): urgent</p> <p id='readingExamples'>至る (いた.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>816</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>754</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>816</p> <p id='keyword'>room</p> <p id='kanji'>室</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AEA4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>room, house, climax, wall, one, ceiling, elbow, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . climax.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You book a room in a love hotel called ""Climax House"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A simple room is made up of a roof, some walls, and a dirt floor.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>むろ</p> <p id='words'>室(しつ): room<br>控室(ひかえしつ): waiting room<br>浴室(よくしつ): bathroom, bath<br>温室(おんしつ): greenhouse<br>待合室(まちあいしつ): waiting room<br>研究室(けんきゅうしつ): study (room)<br>教室(きょうしつ): classroom</p> <p id='readingExamples'>室 (むろ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>818</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>756</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>818</p> <p id='keyword'>doth</p> <p id='kanji'>致</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E887B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>doth, climax, wall, one, ceiling, elbow, soil, dirt, ground, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>23</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The archaic English form for ""does"" indicates a humble form of the verb ""to do."" It is made up of <i>climax</i> and <i>taskmaster</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To reach climax I doth the bidding of my dominatrix taskmaster.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This character is used in two very high-frequency words: ""you are welcome"" (どう致しまして) and the honorific form of onegaishimasu (お願い致します; おねがいいたします). Can´t you just picture this ridiculously polite S&M picture? A businessman, who DOTH the bidding of his taskmistress, is climaxing and yelling out ""お願い致します"" while she whips and says ""どう致しまして"". (This kanji also means ""to bring about"" and ""do humbly"", which is perfect for this image).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いた.す</p> <p id='words'>雅致(がち): artistry, good taste, elegance, grace<br>合致(がっち): agreement, concurrence, conforming to<br>一致(いっち): coincidence, agreement, union, match, conformity, consistency, cooperation<br>致す(いたす): do</p> <p id='readingExamples'>致す (いた.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

be going out<br>出来上がり(できあがり): finish, completion, ready, made for, cut out<br>出来上がる(できあがる): be finished, be ready, by definition, be very drunk<br>出来事(できごと): incident, affair, happening, event<br>出来るだけ(できるだけ): if at all possible<br>出迎え(でむかえ): meeting, reception<br>出迎える(でむかえる): to meet, to greet<br>飛び出す(とびだす): jump out, rush out, fly out, appear suddenly, protrude, project<br>取り出す(とりだす): take out, produce, pick out<br>引出す(ひきだす): pull out, take out, draw out, withdraw<br>日の出(ひので): sunrise<br>見出し(みだし): heading, caption, subtitle, index<br>呼び出す(よびだす): summon, call 	"<p id='id'>830</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>768</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>830</p> <p id='keyword'>mountain</p> <p id='kanji'>山</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B1B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mountain</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Note the clearer outline of a triangular <b>mountain</b> here.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a mountain often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the mountain (see FRAME 775 for an example).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>YOU CAN´T POSSIBLY NEED A MNEMONIC FOR THIS!!!!</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>サン、セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やま</p> <p id='words'>鉱山(こうざん): mine (ore)<br>山岳(さんがく): mountains<br>山腹(さんぷく): hillside, mountainside<br>山脈(さんみゃく): mountain range<br>不山戯る(ふざける): to romp, to gambol, to frolic, to joke, to make fun of, to flirt<br>火山(かざん): volcano<br>山林(さんりん): mountain forest, mountains and forest<br>登山(とざん): mountain climbing<br>山(やま): mountain, pile, heap, climax, critical point</p> <p id='readingExamples'>山 (やま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"

	"<p id='id'>840</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>778</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>840</p> <p id='keyword'>promontory</p> <p id='kanji'>崎</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B48E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>promontory, mountain, strange, large, St. Bernard, can, street, nail, spike, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Mountain</i> . . . <i>strange</i>. Hint: you might save yourself the trouble of a story here simply by recalling the kanji for <i>cape</i> (Frame 164) and toying around with the differing images suggested by the key words <b>promontory</b> and <i>cape</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is “Cape Strange” from FRAME 153, only with mountain in place of soil. Interestingly, there is also 碕 which is made of the primitives stone and strange. The three kanjis 碕, 埼 and 崎 all have the same meanings and pronunciations. They have very little uses other than names, for which promontory is the clear winner with over 2300 uses in place and people names, while the other two kanjis account for less than 200 names.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A promontory is a small, strange mountain that juts out into the sea.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さき、さい、みさき</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>崎 (さき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>842</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>779</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>842</p> <p id='keyword'>enter</p> <p id='kanji'>入</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E585A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>enter</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking leftwards, putting one leg forward in order to <b>enter</b> someplace. Since the ""in"" side of a character is the left, it should be easy to remember the writing of this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the meaning of the key word is expanded to include: <i>to go in</i>, <i>to put in</i>, <i>to come in</i>, and the like. It generally appears atop its relative primitive, where, unlike the element for <i>umbrella</i>, the two strokes do not touch each other, making it virtually the same as the kanji for <i>eight</i>. When it appears in any other position, however, it retains its original form.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Person enters stage left…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ニュウ　入院　にゅういん(admittance into a hospital).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ニュウ、ジュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い.る、-い.る、-い.り、い.れる、-い.れ、はい.る</p> <p id='words'>入口(いりくち): entrance, gate, approach, mouth<br>入る(いる): to get in, to go in, to come in, to flow into, to set, to set in<br>受け入れ(うけいれ): receiving, acceptance<br>受け入れる(うけいれる): to accept, to receive<br>恐れ入る(おそれいる): to be filled with awe, to feel small, to be amazed, to be surprised, to be disconcerted, to be sorry, to be grateful, to be defeated, to confess guilt<br>介入(かいにゅう): intervention<br>加入(かにゅう): becoming a member, joining, entry, admission, subscription, affiliation, adherence, signing<br>購入(こうにゅう): purchase, buy<br>仕入れる(しいれる): to lay in stock, to replenish stock, to procure<br>新入生(しんにゅうせい): freshman, first-year student<br>潜入(せんにゅう): infiltration, sneaking in<br>出入り口(でいりぐち): exit and entrance<br>投入(とうにゅう): throw, investment, making (an electrical circuit)<br>導入(どうにゅう): introduction, bringing in, leading in<br>入手(にゅうしゅ): obtaining, coming to hand<br>入賞(にゅうしょう): winning a prize or place (in a contest)<br>入浴(にゅうよく): bathe, bathing<br>納入(のうにゅう): payment, supply<br>申し入れる(もうしいれる): to propose, to suggest<br>入れ物(いれもの): container, case, receptacle<br>気に入る(きにいる): be pleased with, to suit<br>記入(きにゅう): entry, filling in of forms<br>四捨五入(ししゃごにゅう): rounding up (especially fractions)<br>収入(しゅうにゅう): income, receipts, revenue<br>侵入(しんにゅう): penetration, invasion, raid, aggression, trespass<br>出入り(でいり): in and out, coming and going, free association, income and expenditure, debits and credit<br>手入れ(ていれ): repairs, maintenance<br>取り入れる(とりいれる): harvest, take in, adopt<br>入社(にゅうしゃ): entry to a company<br>入場(にゅうじょう): entrance, admission, entering<br>日の入り(ひのいり): sunset<br>輸入(ゆにゅう): importation, import, introduction<br>押し入れ(おしいれ): closet<br>入院(にゅういん): enter hospital<br>入学(にゅうがく): enter a school<br>入口(いりぐち): entrance, gate, approach, mouth<br>入れる(いれる): put in, take in, bring in, let in, admit, introduce, usher in, insert, employ, listen to, tolerate, comprehend, include, pay (interest), cast (votes)<br>入る(はいる): enter, break into, join, enroll, contain, hold, accommodate, have (an income of)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>入る (い.る), 入れる (い.れる), 入る (はい.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>843</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>780</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>843</p> <p id='keyword'>crowded</p> <p id='kanji'>込</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BEBC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crowded, enter, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Enter . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>During a traffic jam it is impossible to get your car to enter the roadway as it is crowded with cars. Think of a grid lock so bad cars are litterally scraping up against each other like people on a Japanese train during rush hour.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Everybody tries to enter the road during rush hour. That´s why it´s so crowded.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'></p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ.み、 -こ.み、 -こ.む、 こ.む、 こ.める</p> <p id='words'>意気込む(いきごむ): to be enthusiastic about<br>打ち込む(うちこむ): to drive in (e.g. nail stake), to devote oneself to, to shoot into, to smash, to throw into, to cast into<br>埋め込む(うめこむ): to bury<br>追い込む(おいこむ): to herd, to corner, to drive<br>押し込む(おしこむ): to push into, to crowd into<br>落ち込む(おちこむ): to fall into, to feel down (sad)<br>組み込む(くみこむ): to insert, to include, to cut in (printing)<br>込める(こめる): to include, to put into<br>飲み込む(のみこむ): to gulp down, to swallow deeply, to understand, to take in, to catch on to, to learn, to digest<br>乗り込む(のりこむ): to board, to embark on, to get into (a car), to ship (passengers), to man (a ship), to help (someone) into, to march into, to enter<br>放り込む(ほうりこむ): to throw into<br>見込み(みこみ): hope, prospects, expectation<br>申し込み(もうしこみ): application, entry, request, subscription, offer, proposal, overture, challenge<br>割り込む(わりこむ): to cut in, to thrust oneself into, to wedge oneself in, to muscle in on, to interrupt, to disturb<br>思い込む(おもいこむ): be under impression that, be convinced that, imagine that, set one´s heart on, be bent on<br>突っ込む(つっこむ): thrust something into something, plunge into, go into deeply, meddle, interfere<br>溶け込む(とけこむ): melt into<br>飛び込む(とびこむ): jump in, leap in, plunge into, dive<br>払い込む(はらいこむ): deposit, pay in<br>引っ込む(ひっこむ): draw back, sink, cave in<br>人込み(ひとごみ): crowd of people<br>申し込む(もうしこむ): apply for, propose, offer, challenge, request<br>込む(こむ): be crowded</p> <p id='readingExamples'>込む (こ.む), 込める (こ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>844</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>781</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>844</p> <p id='keyword'>part</p> <p id='kanji'>分</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58886.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>part, eight, sword, dagger</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Go in . . . dagger.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When something is entered by a dagger, it ends up being cut in several parts.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(This kanji also has the meanings of ""understand"" and ""minute""). It´s important to understand that were you to enter an hour with a dagger and cut it into parts, those parts would be minutes.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ブン、フン、ブ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わ.ける、わ.け、わ.かれる、わ.かる、わ.かつ</p> <p id='words'>一部分(いちぶぶん): a part<br>十分(じっぷん): 10 minutes<br>処分(しょぶん): disposal, dealing, punishment<br>随分(ずいぶん): pretty much, very much<br>多分(たぶん): perhaps, shortcomings<br>分かる(わかる): to be understood<br>幾分(いくぶん): somewhat<br>区分(くぶん): division, section, compartment, demarcation, (traffic) lane, classification, sorting<br>水分(すいぶん): moisture<br>成分(せいぶん): 	"<p id='id'>845</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>782</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>845</p> <p id='keyword'>poverty</p> <p id='kanji'>貧</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2A7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>poverty, part, eight, sword, dagger, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Part . . . shells/money.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the case of true poverty, not having money is only part of the problem. There are other components as well, like lack of education, class structuring, etc., but that doesn´t really matter. Just remember that the money is only part of it, not the whole.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Parting with your money will lead to poverty.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒン、ビン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まず.しい</p> <p id='words'>貧困(ひんこん): poverty, lack<br>貧弱(ひんじゃく): poor, meagre, insubstantial<br>貧乏(びんぼう): poverty, destitute, poor<br>貧しい(まずしい): poor, needy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>貧富 (ひんぷ), 貧弱 (ひんじゃく), 清貧 (せいひん), 貧しい (まず.しい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>849</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>786</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>849</p> <p id='keyword'>venerable old man</p> <p id='kanji'>翁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BF81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>venerable old man, public, eight, elbows, feathers, wings</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Public . . . feathers.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The venerable old man is the public figure head of the Native American Village, answering all questions and solving all problems. The higher in rank you get in this tribe, the more feathers decorate you. Imagine this old man covered in beautiful feathers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The venerable old man is using the public restroom in the park where he feeds the pigeons. But, alas, there is no toilet paper! So, he´s caught a pigeon and is using it to wipe his bottom. (note the feathers on the bottom of the kanji, this helps remember placement). Can you see the feathers flying everywhere?</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>オウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おきな</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>851</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>788</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>851</p> <p id='keyword'>valley</p> <p id='kanji'>谷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B0B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>valley, eight, umbrella, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Go in</i> . . . <i>an umbrella</i> . . . <i>a mouth</i>. Because of space restrictions, the element for <i>go in</i> is shortened in this character. If you stand on your head and look at this kanji, the image of a <b>valley</b> stands out more clearly: the <i>mouth</i> of the river whose water flows down at the intersection of the two mountains, with the final two strokes adding the element of perspective. Now get back on your feet again and see if the image still remains clear. If not, then return to the primitives and make a story in the usual way.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This could be seen as a very accurate pictograph of another type of valley: a valley mouth open under the umbrella of inner labia, with the outer labia parted above. There are even more connections to be made among the primitive keywords and the visuals, but i will enter no further...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think of the classic anime 風の谷のナウシカ (Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind). We see Nausicaa entering the valley mouth gliding on an umbrella.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たに、きわ.まる</p> <p id='words'>谷(たに): valley</p> <p id='readingExamples'>谷 (たに)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>852</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>789</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>852</p> <p id='keyword'>bathe</p> <p id='kanji'>浴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B5B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bathe, water, water droplets, water pistol, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . valley.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This story is quite lascivious, sorry... Now, imagine you are at a 混浴　（こんよく） [two kanjis we now know] Onsen (温泉), and you are watching a woman bathe. Just picture the water dripping down her cleavage (that valley in between her breasts). Note: cleavage in Japanese is 谷間.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The mountain man uses the water from the valley to bathe.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.びる、あ.びせる</p> <p id='words'>浴びる(あびる): bathe, take a shower, bask in the sun<br>入浴(にゅうよく): bathe, bathing<br>浴室(よくしつ): bathroom, bath<br>海水浴(かいすいよく): sea bathing, seawater bath<br>浴衣(ゆかた): bathrobe, informal summer kimono</p> <p id='readingExamples'>浴びせる (あ.びせる), 浴びる (あ.びる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>853</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>790</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>853</p> <p id='keyword'>contain</p> <p id='kanji'>容</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AEB9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>contain, house, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character depicts a <i>house</i> so large that it can <b>contain</b> an entire <i>valley</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine a house big enough to contain an entire valley. might want to live there.
