	"<p id='id'>854</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>791</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>854</p> <p id='keyword'>melt</p> <p id='kanji'>溶</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BAB6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>melt, water, water droplets, water pistol, contents, contain, house, valley, animal legs, eight, umbrella, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . contain.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of what happens when the snow on top of the mountains melts: it turns into water and flows down onto the rooftops of all the houses in the valley below.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[melt; dissolve; thaw] An ice cube is melting, loosing the water it contained.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.ける、と.かす、と.く</p> <p id='words'>溶液(ようえき): solution (liquid)<br>溶かす(とかす): melt, dissolve<br>溶く(とく): dissolve (e.g. paint)<br>溶け込む(とけこむ): melt into<br>溶ける(とける): melt, thaw, fuse, dissolve<br>溶岩(ようがん): lava</p> <p id='readingExamples'>溶かす (と.かす), 溶く (と.く), 溶ける (と.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>855</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>792</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>855</p> <p id='keyword'>longing</p> <p id='kanji'>欲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ACB2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>longing, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Valley</i> . . . <i>yawn</i>. Be sure to keep the key word distinct from <i>pining</i> (Frame 683).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Guess what? Japanese has dirty words too! (In fact, a lot of them) A sexual story is NOT inappropriate here, as this kanji is very sexual, such as in 性欲; lust. As for a story: the lack of contact with a woman´s valley will leave a man LONGING for love.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The valley has something my life is lacking.... something I´ve been longing for.. peace and quiet.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほっ.する、ほ.しい</p> <p id='words'>意欲(いよく): will, desire, ambition<br>欲深い(よくふかい): greedy<br>欲望(よくぼう): desire, appetite<br>食欲(しょくよく): appetite (for food)<br>欲張り(よくばり): avarice, covetousness, greed<br>欲しい(ほしい): wanted, wished for, in need of, desired</p> <p id='readingExamples'>欲しい (ほ.しい), 欲する (ほっ.する)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>856</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>793</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>856</p> <p id='keyword'>abundant</p> <p id='kanji'>裕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A395.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>abundant, cloak, valley, eight, umbrella, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character shows the typical <i>cloak</i> of <i>valley</i> folk, which, unlike the tailor-made, high-fashion overcoats of city folk, is loose-fitting and free-form. Hence the key word's meaning of <b>abundant</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Again using the fact that cleavage in Japanese is called ""valley of the chest"": a woman with abundant cleavage tightly wraps up her bosom in a form-fitting cloak, but leaving her valley exposed. Another unforgettable image (thank you, thank you, I´ll be here all week).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Welcome to cloak-valley, the valley where everyone wears cloaks and every shop sells cloaks. Mnemonic : “cloaks are abundant in the valley”.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>余裕(よゆう): surplus, composure, margin, room, time, allowance, scope, rope</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>857</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>794</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>857</p> <p id='keyword'>lead (metal)</p> <p id='kanji'>鉛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9899B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lead, metal, gold, gully, eight, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Metal . . . gully.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Picture the molten lead (the heavy metal) being discreetly drained out of the factory into a gully behind.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Lead -> Dental fillings -> Metal that enters the mouth to fill a hole in a tooth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なまり</p> <p id='words'>鉛(なまり): lead (the metal)<br>鉛筆(えんぴつ): pencil</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鉛 (なまり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>858</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>795</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>858</p> <p id='keyword'>run alongside</p> <p id='kanji'>沿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B2BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>run alongside, water, water droplets, water pistol, gully, eight, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>24</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Water</i> . . . <i>gully</i>. The key word is meant to refer to things like rivers and railway tracks that <b>run alongside</b> something else.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Water in a gully runs alongside the path.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Picture one of those idiots that run alongside the bicyclists in the Tour de France trying to give them water. Watch as the cyclist shoves the person into a gully that runs alongside the road.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そ.う、-ぞ.い</p> <p id='words'>沿岸(えんがん): coast, shore<br>沿線(えんせん): along railway line<br>沿い(ぞい): along<br>沿う(そう): to run along, to follow</p> <p id='readingExamples'>沿う (そ.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>859</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>796</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>859</p> <p id='keyword'>prize</p> <p id='kanji'>賞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B39E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>prize, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Outhouse . . . shellfish.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is a bit silly.. or maybe not only a bit, but.. You know some foodstuffs (cereals come to mind) sometimes have prizes mixed in them? Well, in this case, the prize was a shell (money, remember) and you only notice in the outhouse... (see also secret (#904)).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>As a prize for being the 1,000,000th person to use the restaurant´s outhouse, I got all the clams I could eat.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほ.める</p> <p id='words'>懸賞(けんしょう): offering prizes, winning, reward<br>入賞(にゅうしょう): winning a prize or place (in a contest)<br>鑑賞(かんしょう): appreciation<br>賞(しょう): prize, award<br>賞金(しょうきん): prize, monetary award<br>賞品(しょうひん): prize, trophy</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>860</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>797</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>860</p> <p id='keyword'>party</p> <p id='kanji'>党</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5859A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>party, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of this key word as referring to a political <b>party</b>, not a gala affair. Its elements: <i>human legs</i> . . . sticking out of an <i>outhouse</i> window.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Every major political party, if personified, would look like a giant outhouse walking around with human legs spewing out a constant stream of bullshit.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Every political party is full of shit. But nobody ever says how they get that way. Well, here´s your answer - a political party memer is in the outhouse, greedily chowing down on the contents inside. He´s grown so accustomed to the taste that he´s in all the way, and all you can see are his legs through the window. He´ll come inside later to the auditorium to make a speech and spew everything out.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なかま、むら</p> <p id='words'>野党(やとう): opposition party<br>与党(よとう): government party, (ruling) party in power, government<br>政党(せいとう): (member of) political party<br>党(とう): party (political), faction, -ite</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>861</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>798</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>861</p> <p id='keyword'>hall</p> <p id='kanji'>堂</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A082.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>public chamber, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Outhouse . . . land.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There is a secret hall buried in the soil underneath the outhouse.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In most communities you will be hauled into city hall if you use the ground as an outhouse.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>議事堂(ぎじどう): Diet building<br>堂々(どうどう): magnificent, grand, impressive<br>講堂(こうどう): lecture hall<br>食堂(しょくどう): cafeteria, dining room</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>862</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>799</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>862</p> <p id='keyword'>usual</p> <p id='kanji'>常</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B8B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>usual, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, towel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Outhouse . . . towel.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s usual to take your towel with you when you go to the outhouse at the onsen (hot springs bath in Japan) so everybody doesn´t see your stuff.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the outhouse toilet you´d usually hope to find toilet paper to wipe your ass. If it´s already gone, which is usually the case, simply use the towel.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つね、とこ-</p> <p id='words'>正常(せいじょう): normalcy, normality, normal<br>通常(つうじょう): common, general, usually<br>平常(へいじょう): normal, usual<br>異常(いじょう): strangeness, abnormality, disorder<br>常識(じょうしき): common sense<br>常に(つねに): always, constantly<br>日常(にちじょう): ordinary, regular, everyday, usual<br>非常(ひじょう): emergency, extraordinary, unusual<br>非常に(ひじょうに): very, greatly</p> <p id='readingExamples'>常 (つね), 常 (とこ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>863</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>800</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>863</p> <p id='keyword'>skirt</p> <p id='kanji'>裳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A3B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>skirt, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word refers to an ancient <b>skirt</b> once used as part of a woman's costume. The primitives you have to work with are: <i>outhouse</i> . . . <i>garment</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Compared to pants, a SKIRT is the GARMENT to be wearing when you want to use one of those Japanese toilets. It makes it so much easier: you just walk in the OUTHOUSE hike it up, and do your business.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Haven´t you ever noticed that the men / women signs on the front of outhouses are sometimes very similar? The silhouettes are usually the same, but one will decidedly be wearing a garment in the shape of a SKIRT. Also, we´ve already learned the kanji for ""woman"", so if the signs are only in kanji you have no right to wander in and claim ignorance, perv!</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>も、もすそ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>864</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>801</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>864</p> <p id='keyword'>manipulate</p> <p id='kanji'>掌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68E8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>manipulate, outhouse, small, little, crown, mouth, hand</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Outhouse . . . hand.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you´re going to manipulate your body with your hand, then go do it in an outhouse, at least!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Instead of magazines, we keep a Rubiks Cube in the outhouse to manipulate with your hands while you do your business.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>てのひら、たなごころ</p> <p id='words'>掌(たなごころ): the palm<br>車掌(しゃしょう): (train) conductor</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>865</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>802</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>865</p> <p id='keyword'>pelt</p> <p id='kanji'>皮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79AAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The simplest way to remember this character is to see it as built up from that for <i>branch</i>. The first stroke can then stand for something ""hanging"" down from the <i>branch</i>, namely its bark or <b>pelt</b>. The barb at the end of the second stroke is the only other change. Merely by concentrating on this as you write the following small cluster of characters should be enough to fix the form in your mind. By way of exception, you might doodle around with the kanji's form to see what you can come up with.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A pelt is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To be honest, this is one of those cases where I have found it easier to ""just remember it"" as a radical, as it occurs so frequently: 彼（かれ him）波（なみ wave）and so on.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かわ、けがわ</p> <p id='words'>皮(かわ): skin, hide, leather, fur, pelt, bark, shell<br>毛皮(けがわ): fur, skin, pelt<br>皮肉(ひにく): cynicism, sarcasm, irony, satire<br>皮膚(ひふ): skin</p> <p id='readingExamples'>皮 (かわ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>866</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>803</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>866</p> <p id='keyword'>waves</p> <p id='kanji'>波</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B3A2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>waves, water, water droplets, water pistol, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water's . . . pelt.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Waves are the ocean´s pelt (skin).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Inuit used water-proof seal pelts for their kayaks, to travel the waves.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なみ</p> <p id='words'>短波(たんぱ): short wave<br>津波(つなみ): tsunami, tidal wave<br>電波(でんぱ): electro-magnetic wave<br>波(なみ): wave</p> <p id='readingExamples'>波 (なみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>867</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>804</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>867</p> <p id='keyword'>old woman</p> <p id='kanji'>婆</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A986.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>old woman, wave, water, water droplets, water pistol, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook, woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Waves . . . woman.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An old woman is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You know ""The Old Man and the Sea."" Well, this is the sequel, ""The Old Woman and the Sea Waves."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>バ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ばば、ばあ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>868</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>805</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>868</p> <p id='keyword'>expose</p> <p id='kanji'>披</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68AAB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>expose, finger, fingers, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . pelt.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You expose holes in a pelt by passing your fingers through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think of it in this vulgar way. You really want her to expose her “beaver” pelt, so you have to encourage her with your fingers to expose it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>869</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>806</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>869</p> <p id='keyword'>rend</p> <p id='kanji'>破</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A0B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rend, stone, rock, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rock . . . pelt.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Before the invention of scissors or knives, sharp STONES were used to REND PELTs, so that caveman designers could complete new styles for the upcoming year.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Rend is a violent, primitive kind of word. (Image: cavemen rending pelts right off live animals with stone tools).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やぶ.る、やぶ.れる</p> <p id='words'>突破(とっぱ): breaking through, breakthrough, penetration<br>破壊(はかい): destruction<br>破棄(はき): revocation, annulment, breaking (e.g. treaty)<br>爆破(ばくは): blast, explosion, blow up<br>破損(はそん): damage<br>破裂(はれつ): explosion, rupture, break off<br>破産(はさん): (personal) bankruptcy<br>破片(はへん): fragment, splinter, broken piece<br>破く(やぶく): tear, violate, defeat, smash, destroy<br>破る(やぶる): tear, violate, defeat, smash, destroy<br>破れる(やぶれる): get torn, wear out</p> <p id='readingExamples'>破る (やぶ.る), 破れる (やぶ.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>870</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>807</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>870</p> <p id='keyword'>incur</p> <p id='kanji'>被</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A2AB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>incur, cloak, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cloak . . . pelt.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you wear a coat of fur (pelt) you are sure to incur the wrath of animal rights extremists.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A cloak of fur (pelt) will incur the wrath of animal lovers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こうむ.る、おお.う、かぶ.る、かぶ.せる</p> <p id='words'>被る(かぶる): wear, put on (head), pour or dash water (on oneself)<br>被せる(かぶせる): cover (with something), plate something (with a metal), pour or dash a liquid (on something)<br>被害(ひがい): damage</p> <p id='readingExamples'>被る (こうむ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>871</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>808</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>871</p> <p id='keyword'>remainder</p> <p id='kanji'>残</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AE8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>remainder, bones, one, ceiling, evening, float</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Bones</i> . . . (parade) <i>float</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The remainder of the bones have been thrown from the float (for the dogs maybe, at the end of the parade).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Throwing all those coins (see coin (#368)) was a really bad idea; people got mad with greed. The only remainders left were the bones of those that was on the float.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ザン、サン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>のこ.る、のこ.す、そこな.う、のこ.り</p> <p id='words'>残金(ざんきん): remaining money<br>残酷(ざんこく): cruelty, harshness<br>残高(ざんだか): (bank) balance, remainder<br>名残(なごり): remains, traces, memory<br>残り(のこり): remnant, residue, remaining, left-over<br>残す(のこす): leave (behind, over), bequeath, save, reserve<br>残らず(のこらず): all, entirely, completely, without exception<br>残念(ざんねん): sorry<br>残る(のこる): remain</p> <p id='readingExamples'>残す (のこ.す), 残る (のこ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>872</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>809</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>872</p> <p id='keyword'>martyrdom</p> <p id='kanji'>殉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AE89.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>martyrdom, bones, one, ceiling, evening, decameron, bound up, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bones . . . decameron.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of the early Christian martyrs who suffered martyrdom because of their faith. See them held in cells for 10 days (a decameron) before being fed to the lions. They appear before the chanting Roman crowds as bones to be devoured. Think of what was leftover after the lions finished them off....nothing, not even a pile of bones to bury.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The boney man martyred himself during his 10 day hunger-strike.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>873</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>810</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>873</p> <p id='keyword'>particularly</p> <p id='kanji'>殊</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AE8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>particularly, bones, one, ceiling, evening, vermilion, drop, not yet, one, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bones . . . vermilion.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A t-bone steak is vermilion - particularly if served rare.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Castlevania -- The vermillion skeletons (bones) are particularly hard because they just keep regenerating.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こと</p> <p id='words'>殊に(ことに): especially, above all<br>特殊(とくしゅ): special, unique</p> <p id='readingExamples'>殊 (こと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

AUGMENT your breasts and all your troubles will be solved!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the movie “Gattaca”, Vincent Freeman (played by Ethan Hawke) augments his size by straightening his bones (his legs), in order to match up with the genetically “perfect” population, and reach his goal of travelling in space. The stretching of his lower leg bones involved multiplying the bone cells, another sense of this key word.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふ.える、ふ.やす</p> <p id='words'>繁殖(はんしょく): breed, multiply, increase, propagation<br>殖やす(ふやす): to increase, to add to, to augment<br>殖える(ふえる): increase, multiply</p> <p id='readingExamples'>殖える (ふ.える), 殖やす (ふ.やす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Note how the first stroke is extended to the right, forming a sort of ""roof"" overhead.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they´re out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of death), carrying a spoon made of human bones instead of a scythe.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>し.ぬ、し.に-</p> <p id='words'>死(し): death, decease<br>死刑(しけい): death penalty, capital punishment<br>生死(せいし): life and death<br>死体(したい): corpse<br>死亡(しぼう): death, mortality<br>必死(ひっし): inevitable death, desperation, frantic, inevitable result<br>死ぬ(しぬ): to die</p> <p id='readingExamples'>死ぬ (し.ぬ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>887</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>824</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>887</p> <p id='keyword'>post</p> <p id='kanji'>職</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E881B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>post, ear, kazoo, sound, vase, stand up, sun, day, fiesta</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word refers to one's occupation, or position of employment. Its elements: <i>ear</i> . . . <i>kazoo</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Worst post in history: quality checker at the kazoo factory. Imagine the toll on your ears!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Buckingham Palace guards are famous for staying at their post no matter what, even if you blow a kazoo in their ear!</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショク、ソク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>教職(きょうしょく): teaching certificate, the teaching profession<br>辞職(じしょく): resignation<br>職員(しょくいん): staff member, personnel<br>職務(しょくむ): professional duties<br>退職(たいしょく): retirement (from office)<br>役職(やくしょく): post, managerial position, official position<br>就職(しゅうしょく): finding employment, inauguration<br>職(しょく): employment<br>職業(しょくぎょう): occupation, business<br>職人(しょくにん): worker, mechanic, artisan, craftsman</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>888</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>825</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>888</p> <p id='keyword'>holy</p> <p id='kanji'>聖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88196.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>holy, ear, mouth, king, jewel, ball</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ear . . . mouth . . . king.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The trick for me is to remember that the 耳 is to the left of the 口. However, this is easy because a true holy man uses his ear to listen (i.e., to God or his supplicant) before he opens his mouth to speak, unlike a charlatan who just makes something up. Of course, kings are often true holy men and prophets (e.g., King David in the bible).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A holy man hears with his ears before he speaks with his mouth, which places him higher than a king in people´s esteem.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひじり</p> <p id='words'>神聖(しんせい): holiness, sacredness, dignity<br>聖書(せいしょ): Bible, scriptures</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"

(Intentionally said backwards to get the order of the primitives correct).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Listening to others is different from hearing [1626] with the ear. One must allow the words to pierce through the eyes (the window of the soul) and reach deep into the heart...a symbol of thinking about and contemplating on what was said, not just the sounds of words spoken. A married man while reading his newspaper, his wife going on about something suddenly, says, ""You´re not listening to me, are you?"" He replies, ""I heard every word you said. You said..."" “Yes, but you´re not listening."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ、テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>き.く、ゆる.す</p> <p id='words'>聴覚(ちょうかく): the sense of hearing<br>聴講(ちょうこう): lecture attendance, auditing<br>聴診器(ちょうしんき): stethoscope</p> <p id='readingExamples'>聴く (き.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the sun representing the cosmos, the eye represents the human observer, the crotch represents the animal instincts.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>He´ s often ridiculed for having his eye on crotches all day.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>マン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>怠慢(たいまん): negligence, procrastination, carelessness<br>我慢(がまん): patience, endurance, perseverance, tolerance, self-control, self-denial<br>自慢(じまん): pride, boast</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

One, you can say I´m sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I´m sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There is a 3-way masterplan for every goalkeeper to prevent a goal at penalty shootout: 1. Look directly into the eyes of the player --- 2. Confuse him by screaming senseless words --- 3. Pull out you your saber and ... (that´s up to you).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>バツ、バチ、ハツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ばっ.する</p> <p id='words'>刑罰(けいばつ): judgement, penalty, punishment<br>処罰(しょばつ): punishment<br>罰(ばち): (divine) punishment, curse, retribution<br>罰する(ばっする): punish, penalize</p> <p id='readingExamples'>罰金 (ばっきん), 処罰 (しょばつ), 天罰 (てんばつ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>898</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>835</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>898</p> <p id='keyword'>voiced</p> <p id='kanji'>濁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BF81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>voiced, water, water droplets, water pistol, spider, eye, cross-eyed, net, bound up, insect</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word for this kanji connotes the ""muddying"" effect on a soft consonant brought about by vibrating the vocal chords. For example, in English a ""j"" is <b>voiced</b> while a ""sh"" is unvoiced. In Japanese, the し is changed to じ when it is <b>voiced</b>. The primitives are: <i>water</i> . . . <i>eye</i> . . . <i>bound up</i> . . . <i>insect</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing ""Help me, Help Me"" under the watchful eye of the spider who´s venom is dripping like water from her fangs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Pour water over the eyes of a bound up insect if you want to hear a pitiful buzz that is very similar to a VOICED consanant.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダク、ジョク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>にご.る、にご.す</p> <p id='words'>清濁(せいだく): good and evil, purity and impurity<br>濁る(にごる): become muddy or impure</p> <p id='readingExamples'>濁す (にご.す), 濁る (にご.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

First we have a jewel. Next we have the great eye of Sauron searching for the fellowship hiding under the many ceilings during their journey. The fourth and fifth primitives are the mouth of Gollum always mumbling “My preciousss”; and Pippin´s scarf! Placement: the eye appears at the top similarly to how the Great Eye of Sauron is perched atop the Dark Tower.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In conjunction with send back (#837)....... When I tried to give her the jewel ring, she eyed me, threw it to the floor, opened her mouth and tried to speak, she said nothing. 	"<p id='id'>911</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>848</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>911</p> <p id='keyword'>retainer</p> <p id='kanji'>臣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E887A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>retainer, slave</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji is actually a pictograph for an eye, distorted to make it appear that the pupil is protruding towards the right. This may not be an easy form to remember, but try this: Draw it once rather large, and notice how moving the two vertical lines on the right as far right as possible gives you the pictograph of the eye in its natural form. The ""pop-eye"" image belongs to an Emperor's <b>retainer</b> standing in awe before his ruler.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the meaning of the key word becomes <i>slave</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Its a pictograph of a teeth with a retainer in the middle.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Retainer = A slave (for the purposes of this kanji.) This is a pictograph of a slave collar with two handcuffs dangling from it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン、ジン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>総理大臣(そうりだいじん): Prime Minister<br>大臣(だいじん): cabinet minister</p> <p id='readingExamples'>臣下 (しんか), 君臣 (くんしん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"

The arms move in, the penis moves out and vice versa.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The letter E, with a GIGANTIC middle stroke.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>巨(こ): big, large, great<br>巨大(きょだい): huge, gigantic, enormous</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>936</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>871</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>936</p> <p id='keyword'>threaten</p> <p id='kanji'>脅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88485.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>threaten, triceps, power, muscle, arnold, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, power3, muscle3, arnold3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Triceps . . . part of the body.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Compare the primitive positions of armpit (#870) and threaten (#871). When your triceps rest alongside your body, they fit snugly against your armpit. When you hold them above your body, however, your posture becomes quite threatening.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don´t threaten a warewolf. He´s three times as powerful ON a full moon.　RTK2:　キョウ　脅迫　きょうはく (blackmail)…　Pure Group:　協872.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おびや.かす、おど.す、おど.かす</p> <p id='words'>脅かす(おどかす): to threaten, to coerce<br>脅す(おどす): to threaten, to menace<br>脅迫(きょうはく): threat, menace, coercion, terrorism</p> <p id='readingExamples'>脅かす (おど.かす), 脅す (おど.す), 脅かす (おびや.かす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>937</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>872</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>937</p> <p id='keyword'>co-</p> <p id='kanji'>協</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58D94.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>co-, ten, needle, triceps, power, muscle, arnold, power3, muscle3, arnold3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This prefix should be kept distinct from <i>inter</i> (Frame 222) and <i>mutual</i> (Frame 819). Its elements: <i>needle</i> . . . <i>triceps</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The nurse says : “If you co-operate, that needle (syringe) in your triceps won´t hurt”. Note: both co- and cooperate are meanings for this kanji.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Co-operation: 3 persons can have the power of ten if they co-operate.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>協会(きょうかい): association, society, organization<br>協議(きょうぎ): conference, consultation, discussion, negotiation<br>協調(きょうちょう): co-operation, conciliation, harmony, firm (market) tone<br>協定(きょうてい): arrangement, pact, agreement<br>妥協(だきょう): compromise, giving in<br>協力(きょうりょく): cooperation, collaboration</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>938</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>873</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>938</p> <p id='keyword'>going</p> <p id='kanji'>行</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A18C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>going, boulevard, going</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>By joining the top four strokes, you should get a picture of the front current of a river, the stream trailing behind. Hence the character for <b>going</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this character has two forms. Reduced to the left side only, it can mean a <i>column</i>, <i>going</i>, or a <i>line</i> of something or other. When the middle is opened up to make room for other elements, it means a <i>boulevard</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I use The Flash for for this primitive; a superhero who is always going very fast.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To me, this looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、ギョウ、アン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い.く、ゆ.く、-ゆ.き、-ゆき、-い.き、-いき、おこな.う、おこ.なう</p> <p id='words'>行き(いき): 	"<p id='id'>939</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>874</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>939</p> <p id='keyword'>rhythm</p> <p id='kanji'>律</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BE8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rhythm, Nelson, column, going, line, brush</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character depicts a calligrapher's <i>brush</i> and its <b>rhythmic</b> sway as it flows down <i>a column</i> writing kanji on the way.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The calligrapher´s brush is moving down a column of a script, in rhythm with his meditation.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The army COLUMN walked to the RHYTHM made by the drummer using a cool BRUSH like drum stick. 	"<p id='id'>947</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>882</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>947</p> <p id='keyword'>diameter</p> <p id='kanji'>径</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BE84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>diameter, Nelson, column, going, line, spool, clod, toilet paper, crotch, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Line . . . spool.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a line of thread off a humongous spool until it got to the other side.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Suggestion: Replace ""spool"" with ""toilet paper/roll"". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Measure the diameter of a column (maybe Nelson´s Column in London?) using a roll of toilet paper. Spool also appears in stalk (#715), suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), sutra (#1360).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みち、こみち、さしわたし、ただちに</p> <p id='words'>直径(ちょっけい): diameter<br>半径(はんけい): radius</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>948</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>883</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>948</p> <p id='keyword'>he</p> <p id='kanji'>彼</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BDBC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>he, Nelson, column, going, line, pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Going</i> . . . <i>pelt</i>. This kanji refers to the third person singular personal pronoun, generally in its masculine form.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>What´s the main difference between a he and a she? The he has a column covered in a pelt... a penis. Badum-ching.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The ultimate he-man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar (column), and he wears a ragged pelt as his only clothing. To remember the column, imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かれ、かの、か.の</p> <p id='words'>彼処(あそこ): (uk) there, over there, that place, (X) (col) genitals<br>彼方此方(あちこち): here and there<br>彼方(あちら): there, yonder, that<br>彼方此方(あちらこちら): here and there<br>彼此(あれこれ): one thing or another, this and that, this or that<br>彼等(かれら): they (usually male)<br>彼女(かのじょ): she<br>彼(かれ): he<br>彼ら(かれら): they</p> <p id='readingExamples'>彼 (かれ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"

When the order comes they must decide whether to obey their concience or do their duty and damn the world to atomic annihilation.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヤク、エキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>役(えき): war, campaign, battle<br>重役(おもやく): heavy responsibilities, director<br>役職(やくしょく): post, managerial position, official position<br>役立つ(やくだつ): to be useful, to be helpful, to serve the purpose<br>役場(やくば): town hall<br>重役(じゅうやく): heavy responsibilities, director<br>主役(しゅやく): leading part, leading actor or actress<br>役(やく): use, service, role, position<br>役者(やくしゃ): actor, actress<br>役所(やくしょ): government office, public office<br>役人(やくにん): government official<br>役目(やくめ): duty, business<br>役割(やくわり): part, assigning (allotment of) parts, role, duties<br>役に立つ(やくにたつ): useful</p> <p id='readingExamples'>役所 (やくしょ), 役目 (やくめ), 荷役 (かやく)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>950</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>885</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>950</p> <p id='keyword'>benevolence</p> <p id='kanji'>徳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BEB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>benevolence, Nelson, column, going, line, stethoscope, camel, ten, needle, eye, cross-eyed, net, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>25</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Going</i> . . . <i>needle</i> . . . <i>eye</i> . . . <i>heart</i>. Like the characters for I (Frame 17) and <i>ego</i> (Frame 690), this kanji is also representative of the subject, with the special connotation of <b>privacy</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Warning sign: ""Private wheat, trespassers will be elbowed"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I already know this as watashi, or ""I"". In other words, it is the part which feeds us. 	"<p id='id'>984</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>917</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>984</p> <p id='keyword'>cereals</p> <p id='kanji'>穀</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A980.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cereals, samurai, crown, wheat, cereal, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Samurai . . . crown . . . wheat . . . missile.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There are different cereals in different parts of the world. Japan has samurai cereal. Great Britain has Crowned Wheat ... the United States and Russia have Missile cereals.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The samurai crowns wheat as the best cereal, and blows all others up with missiles (he´s a cereal killer).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>穀物(こくもつ): grain, cereal, corn</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>985</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>918</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>985</p> <p id='keyword'>germ</p> <p id='kanji'>菌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88F8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>germ, flowers, pent in, wheat, cereal</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flowers . . . pent in . . . wheat.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Can also mean bacteria.....imagine the wheat pent in your fridge growing to the point where they resemble flowers.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Actually it means germs as in microorganisms. So for example, you have to keep wheat enclosed so it isn´t exposed to other plants. That way it can´t catch any germs (like fungi) from them.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>細菌(さいきん): bacillus, bacterium, germ<br>黴菌(ばいきん): bacteria, germ(s)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>987</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>919</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>987</p> <p id='keyword'>rice</p> <p id='kanji'>米</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B1B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rice</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji has a pictographic resemblance to a number of grains of <b>rice</b> lying on a plate in the shape of a star.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, it keeps its meaning of <i>rice</i>, and is meant to connote a very ordinary, commonplace grain, in contrast to the primitive for <i>wheat</i> that we just learned. (This meaning accords well with Japan, where the output of <i>rice</i> far exceeds that of <i>wheat</i>.)<div>It occasionally takes a different shape when it stands on its own, or is joined to a line above. In this case, we shall have it refer specifically to <i>grains of rice</i>. This primitive is not to be confused with the similar-looking primitive for <i>water</i>. While the stroke orders are nearly alike, <i>grains of rice</i> has 5 strokes, while <i>water</i> only has 4 because it joins the second and third strokes into one.</div><div>Finally, we may note that by itself the kanji for <i>rice</i> is an abbreviation used for the <i>United States</i>, which can then also serve as an alternate reading for the main primitive form, if you so wish.</div></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Two drops of rice in a tree, simple.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ベイ、マイ、メエトル</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こめ、よね</p> <p id='words'>欧米(おうべい): Europe and America, the West<br>南米(なんべい): South America<br>米(こめ): rice</p> <p id='readingExamples'>米作 (べいさく), 米価 (べいか), 米食 (べいしょく), 米 (こめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>988</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>920</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>988</p> <p id='keyword'>flour</p> <p id='kanji'>粉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B289.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>flour, rice, part, eight, sword, dagger</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rice . . . part.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Parts of parts of parts of parts of rice... is flour. 	"<p id='id'>1003</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>933</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1003</p> <p id='keyword'>Esq. (sama)</p> <p id='kanji'>様</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A798.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>Esq., tree, wood, sheep, grains of rice</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The abbreviation <b>Esq.</b> will help associate this character with the honorific form of address to which it belongs. Its elements are: <i>tree</i> . . . <i>sheep</i> . . . <i>grains of rice</i>. Note that the final vertical stroke in the element for <i>sheep</i> is extended to form the first stroke for <i>grains of rice</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble Esq. You must posses a forested estate, herds of sheep, and granary full of grains of rice.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is -Sama, a generic high term of respect for someone in an unusual profession. If you met a person that created a wooden sheep that was squeezing a single grain of rice out of its ass, you´d definitely call that person -sama. Because that is impressive.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さま、さん</p> <p id='words'>有様(ありさま): state, condition, circumstances, the way things are or should be, truth<br>一様(いちよう): uniformity, evenness, similarity, equality, impartiality<br>お蔭様で(おかげさまで): Thanks to god, thanks to you<br>ご苦労様(ごくろうさま): Thank you very much for your....<br>様(さま): Mr. or Mrs., manner, kind, appearance<br>左様なら(さようなら): good-bye<br>仕様(しよう): way, method, resource, remedy, (technical) specification<br>多様(たよう): diversity, variety<br>殿様(とのさま): feudal lord<br>様式(ようしき): style, form, pattern<br>様相(ようそう): aspect<br>王様(おうさま): king<br>神様(かみさま): god<br>逆様(さかさま): inversion, upside down<br>様々(さまざま): varied, various<br>同様(どうよう): identical, equal to, same (kind), like<br>模様(もよう): pattern, figure, design<br>様(よう): way, manner, kind, sort, appearance, like, such as, so as to, in order to, so that<br>様子(ようす): aspect, state, appearance</p> <p id='readingExamples'>様 (さま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1004</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>934</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1004</p> <p id='keyword'>request</p> <p id='kanji'>求</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B182.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>request, arrow, grains of rice</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let the <i>drop</i> in the upper right-hand corner of this character close the right angle off to make an <i>arrowhead</i>. Whenever we find the <i>needle</i> with that <i>drop</i> in an element that has no other special meaning, we will take advantage of this primitive meaning. At the bottom, we see the <i>grains of rice</i>, the vertical line doubling up for the two elements. Do not confuse with <i>petition</i> (Frame 143).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Enemy: ""Any final requests?"" // MacGyver: ""Just an arrowhead and some grains of rice."" (MacGyver then throws the grains of rice at the enemy and uses the arrowhead to cut his hands free from the rope.).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Robin Hood holds his rich victim at arrowpoint and kindly requests that he hands over his grains of rice.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キュウ、グ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もと.める</p> <p id='words'>請求(せいきゅう): claim, demand, application, request<br>求める(もとめる): seek, request, demand, want, wish for, search for<br>要求(ようきゅう): request, demand, requisition</p> <p id='readingExamples'>求める (もと.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1007</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>937</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1007</p> <p id='keyword'>bamboo</p> <p id='kanji'>竹</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7ABB9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bamboo</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Bamboo</b> grows upwards, like a straight <i>nail</i>, and at each stage of its growth (which legend associates with the arrival of the new moon) there is a jointed rootstock (the first stroke). Two such <b>bamboo</b> stalks are pictured here.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the meaning remains the same, but the vertical lines are severely abbreviated so that they can take their place at the top where, like <i>flowers</i>, they are always to be found.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pandas like to eat bamboo. I´m using panda as the primitive name when it fits the story. ^__^.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Two reclining victims impaled on bamboo spheres...　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　チク　松竹梅　しょうちくばい(pine, bamboo, plum).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たけ</p> <p id='words'>竹(たけ): bamboo, middle (of a three-tier ranking system)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>竹 (たけ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_1</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1017</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>946</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1017</p> <p id='keyword'>calculate</p> <p id='kanji'>算</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AE97.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>calculate, bamboo, eye, two hands</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bamboo . . . eyes . . . two hands.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It´s not as easy as a calculator, but you don´t need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tip : you may see this as an Abacus, which is used to calculate. This particular ancient chinese Abacus has eyeballs in place of beads, and its frame is made of bamboo. You´d be amazed at how fast people can calculate with this, especially if they can use both hands at once to move the ... eyeballs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>サン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そろ</p> <p id='words'>暗算(あんざん): mental arithmetic<br>換算(かんさん): conversion, change, exchange<br>決算(けっさん): balance sheet, settlement of accounts<br>採算(さいさん): profit<br>清算(せいさん): liquidation, settlement<br>足し算(たしざん): addition<br>割り算(わりざん): division (math)<br>掛け算(かけざん): multiplication<br>計算(けいさん): calculation, reckoning<br>算数(さんすう): arithmetic<br>算盤(そろばん): abacus<br>引算(ひきざん): subtraction<br>予算(よさん): estimate, budget<br>割算(わりざん): (mathematics) division</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1019</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>948</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1019</p> <p id='keyword'>scheme</p> <p id='kanji'>策</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AD96.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>scheme, bamboo, tree, wood, belt</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Bamboo</i> . . . <i>belted tree</i> (See frame 446).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>(Elaboration of jameserb´s story:) A clever scheme from Wile E Coyote -- he ties one of those rubber belts to some trees and uses it to launch a bamboo spear at the roadrunner...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The temples in kyoto belt bamboo around trees in a scheme to protect them from the huge number of tourists. 	"<p id='id'>1020</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>949</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1020</p> <p id='keyword'>register</p> <p id='kanji'>簿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B0BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>register, bamboo, water, water droplets, water pistol, acupuncturist, specialty, drop, ten, needle, rice field, brains, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bamboo . . . water . . . acupuncturist.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 227), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won´t stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon´s story.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This doctor dilutes (see 227) his patients with bamboo stalks rather than the flowers of a standard diluting acupuncturist hence he needs to be on the Bamboo Accumpunturist Diltuers (BAD) register. Pumping that much water into a body can be dangerous; see the huge bamboo stems with gallons of water sloshing in and out of the patient.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>名簿(めいぼ): register of names</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1021</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>950</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1021</p> <p id='keyword'>fabricate</p> <p id='kanji'>築</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AF89.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fabricate, bamboo, barge, craft, mediocre, wind, drop, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bamboo . . . craft . . . mediocre . . . wood/tree.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Bamboo crafting is a mediocre substitute for wood when you are building or fabricating a house. While it may look good and might attract a chick (ちく) or two, the kids´ll (きず) just tear it to pieces as its not sturdy enough.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A bamboo fabrication is a mediocre substitute for wood.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きず.く</p> <p id='words'>築く(きずく): to build, to pile up, to amass<br>新築(しんちく): new building, new construction<br>建築(けんちく): construction, architecture</p> <p id='readingExamples'>築く (きず.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1023</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>951</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1023</p> <p id='keyword'>person</p> <p id='kanji'>人</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BABA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>person</p> <p id='strokeCount'>2</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The character for <i>enter</i> (Frame 842) showed someone walking inwards (in terms of the direction of writing), the one for <b>person</b>, shown here, represents someone walking outwards.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, it can keep its kanji form except when it appears to the left (its normal position), where it is made to stand up in the form ⺅ (Similar to イ).<div>The primitive meaning is another matter. The abstract notion of <i>person</i> so often has a relation to the meaning of the kanji that confusion readily sets in. So many of the previous stories have included people in them that simply to use <i>person</i> for a primitive meaning would be risky. We need to be more specific, to focus on one particular <i>person</i>. Try to choose someone who has not figured in the stories so far, perhaps a colorful member of the family or a friend whom you have known for a long time. That individual will appear again and again, so be sure to choose someone who excites your imagination.</div></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Behold Mister T (of ""A-Team"" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he´s sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he´s both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[I appreciate some people´s occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.].</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジン、ニン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひと、-り、-と</p> <p id='words'>商人(あきうど): trader, shopkeeper, merchant<br>他人(あだびと): another person, unrelated person, outsider, stranger<br>一人(いちにん): one person<br>玄人(くろうと): expert, Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - ""Stay on my left, foo!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>On your right is your ""right-hand man"" that you credit for all your success....on the left...... is your assistant who does all the grunt work and gets no credit for anything...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>佐(さ): help</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1033</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>960</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1033</p> <p id='keyword'>attend</p> <p id='kanji'>仕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BB95.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>attend, person, samurai</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Person</i> . . . <i>samurai</i>. Imagine Tom Cruise outside in the final scene, stabbing his knife into his stomach, while Mr T looks patiently on. ""I pity da foo....no, really."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ、ジ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つか.える</p> <p id='words'>給仕(きゅうじ): office boy (girl), page, waiter<br>仕上がり(しあがり): finish, end, completion<br>仕上げ(しあげ): end, finishing touches, being finished<br>仕上げる(しあげる): to finish up, to complete<br>仕入れる(しいれる): to lay in stock, to replenish stock, to procure<br>仕掛け(しかけ): device, trick, mechanism, gadget, (small) scale, half finished, commencement, set up, challenge<br>仕掛ける(しかける): to commence, to lay (mines), to set (traps), to wage (war), to challenge<br>仕切る(しきる): to partition, to divide, to mark off, to settle accounts, to toe the mark<br>仕組み(しくみ): devising, plan, plot, contrivance, construction, arrangement<br>仕立てる(したてる): to tailor, to make, to prepare, to train, to send (a messenger)<br>仕付ける(しつける): to be used to a job, to begin to do, to baste, to tack, to plant<br>仕舞(しまい): end, termination, informal (Noh play)<br>仕舞う(しまう): to finish, to close, to do something completely, to put away, to put an end to<br>仕様(しよう): way, method, resource, remedy, (technical) specification<br>仕える(つかえる): to serve, to work for<br>奉仕(ほうし): attendance, service<br>仕上がる(しあがる): be finished<br>仕方(しかた): method, way<br>仕事(しごと): work, occupation, employment</p> <p id='readingExamples'>仕事 (しごと), 出仕 (しゅつし), 仕える (つか.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"

So here, we see Mr T doing a bunch of cocaine, and then spreading it all over his face to look white, and trying out for the part of Hannibal. The directors were so impressed that they let him stunt double for Hannibal in a few episodes. OR, Mr T chiefin´ on some crack cocaine. 	"<p id='id'>1047</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>973</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1047</p> <p id='keyword'>individual</p> <p id='kanji'>個</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5808B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>individual, person, harden, pent in, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . harden.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This keyword gave me trouble, I could write the kanji from memory but could not remember the keyword the other way around. In such case the dictionary definition can be helpful : ""Middle English, single, indivisible"". Here we have Mr. T. who is so hardened (all the body workout he´s had) that he became in-dividual, that is, in-divisible. ""I pity da foo who can be divided into smaller units."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T insists that people be individual. He appears on television, saying, ""Being an individual is hard! But you gotta do it! Harden yourself, and be individual!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ、カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>個(か): article counter<br>個々(ここ): individual, one by one<br>個性(こせい): individuality, personality, idiosyncrasy<br>個別(こべつ): particular case<br>個所(かしょ): passage, place, point, part<br>個人(こじん): individual, personal, private<br>個体(こたい): an individual</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1048</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>974</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1048</p> <p id='keyword'>healthy</p> <p id='kanji'>健</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E581A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>healthy, person, build, brush, stretch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . build.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr. T in a public service announcement yells, ""I´m healthy because every day I build a food pyramid, foo!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr.T, sir, how do you stay so healthy? I asked. ""Simple, foo,"" he answered, ""you gotta build the body up by bodybuilding!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すこ.やか</p> <p id='words'>健在(けんざい): in good health, well<br>健全(けんぜん): health, soundness, wholesome<br>健やか(すこやか): vigorous, healthy, sound<br>健康(けんこう): health, sound, wholesome<br>保健(ほけん): health preservation, hygiene, sanitation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>健やか (すこ.やか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1066</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>991</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1066</p> <p id='keyword'>convenience</p> <p id='kanji'>便</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BEBF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>convenience, person, grow late, Ameratasu, one, ceiling, sun, tucked under the arm</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Person</i> . . . <i>grow late</i>. Hint: this kanji also means that unmentionable material that one disposes of when one goes to the ""<b>conveniences</b>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr. T loves the convenience of the new konbini. Not only does it stay open even if it grows late, they have brand new toilets, and a Post Office!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T takes a dump on the floor of a convenience store. Well, it was growing late and he couldn´t wait. He pities the fool who will have to clean it up!</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ベン、ビン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たよ.り</p> <p id='words'>大便(だいべん): feces, excrement, shit<br>不便(ふびん): pity, compassion<br>便宜(べんぎ): convenience, accommodation, advantage, expedience<br>小便(しょうべん): (colloquial) urine<br>便り(たより): news, tidings, information, correspondence, letter<br>便(びん): mail, post, flight (e.g. airline flight), service, opportunity, chance, letter<br>便箋(びんせん): writing paper, stationery<br>船便(ふなびん): surface mail (ship)<br>便所(べんじょ): toilet, lavatory, rest room, latrine<br>郵便(ゆうびん): mail, postal service<br>不便(ふべん): inconvenience<br>便利(べんり): convenient, handy, useful<br>郵便局(ゆうびんきょく): post office</p> <p id='readingExamples'>便利 (べんり), 便法 (べんぽう), 簡便 (かんべん), 便り (たよ.り)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1067</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>992</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1067</p> <p id='keyword'>double</p> <p id='kanji'>倍</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5808D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>double, person, muzzle, vase, stand up, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Person</i> . . . <i>muzzle</i>. The butt double has no speaking parts - he is muzzled. Of course T himself isn´t he´s rambling on about pity and foo.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>バイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>倍率(ばいりつ): diameter, magnification<br>倍(ばい): double, two times</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1069</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>994</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1069</p> <p id='keyword'>fell</p> <p id='kanji'>伐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BC90.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fell, person, fiesta</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Person</i> . . . <i>fiesta</i>. Hint: recall the German legend of the English missionary, Saint Boniface, who <b>felled</b> the sacred oak tree dedicated to Thor at Geismar (in lower Hessia), occasioning a great <i>fiesta</i> for the Christians in the neighborhood to mark the defeat of their pagan competition. Be sure to fit your special <i>person</i> into the story if you use it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At a fiesta, Mr. T tries to knock down a large pinata, but in his overly enthusiastic swings to get ""the sucka,"" he actually FELLS the tree the piñata is hanging from, crushing some party goers. “I pity da fools who got crushed by my FELLED tree!”.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr T at the fiesta fell over blind drunk.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>バツ、ハツ、カ、ボチ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>き.る、そむ.く、う.つ</p> <p id='words'>伐(ばつ): strike, attack, punish</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Now, as a new father, Mr.T is assuming all the RESPONSIBILITIES that comes with it.
