	"<p id='id'>1079</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1004</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1079</p> <p id='keyword'>fare</p> <p id='kanji'>賃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B383.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fare, responsibility, person, porter, drop, samurai, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Responsibility . . . shells/money.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s your own responsibility to pay the bus fare with the correct number of shells/money.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In Japan they have automatic ticket gates so you cant easily cheat on your train fare. In England however the ticket gates are fairly open. It is a different kind of system. In England you are given the RESPONSIBILITY to put in the right amount of MONEY, but if you are caught cheating, the fines are stiff and you feel like a real CHINCHIN. ""un.CHIN"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>運賃(うんちん): freight rates, shipping expenses, fare<br>賃金(ちんぎん): wages<br>家賃(やちん): rent</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1080</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1005</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1080</p> <p id='keyword'>substitute</p> <p id='kanji'>代</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BBA3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>substitute, person, arrow</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . arrow.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It´s best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to ""mediator"" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T shot the substitute teacher with an arrow.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダイ、タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.わる、かわ.る、かわ.り、-がわ.り、か.える、よ、しろ</p> <p id='words'>代える(かえる): to exchange, to interchange, to substitute, to replace<br>代わる(かわる): to take the place of, to relieve, to be substituted for, to be exchanged, to change places with, to take turns, to be replaced<br>代わる代わる(かわるがわる): alternately<br>古代(こだい): ancient times<br>代(しろ): price, materials, substitution<br>世代(せだい): generation, the world, the age<br>先代(せんだい): family predecessor, previous age, previous generation<br>代弁(だいべん): pay by proxy, act for another, speak for another<br>代用(だいよう): substitution<br>お代わり(おかわり): second helping, another cup<br>代る(かわる): take the place of, relieve, be substituted for, be exchanged, change places with, take turns, be replaced<br>近代(きんだい): present day<br>現代(げんだい): nowadays, modern times, present-day<br>代金(だいきん): price, payment, cost, charge, the money, the bill<br>代表(だいひょう): representative, representation, delegation, type, example, model<br>代名詞(だいめいし): pronoun<br>代理(だいり): representation, agency, proxy, deputy, agent, attorney, substitute, alternate, acting (principal, etc.)<br>年代(ねんだい): age, era, period, date<br>代わり(かわり): instead of<br>時代(じだい): age, period, generation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>代理 (だいり), 世代 (せだい), 現代 (げんだい), 代える (か.える), 代わる (か.わる), 代 (しろ), 代 (よ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1081</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1006</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1081</p> <p id='keyword'>sack</p> <p id='kanji'>袋</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A28B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sack, substitute, person, arrow, garment</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Substitute . . . garment.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A sack is an easy substitute for a garment.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A worker who was recently sacked from his job, is wearing a sack of potatoes as a substitute garment (naked otherwise), in some kind of protest. The kanji is close to frame 1547 ""bag"", and although the later really refers to a ""straw sack"", I use the image of a sack of potatoes here, and that of a ""plastic bag"" for frame 1547. The keywords would have been better swapped in my opinion, but the relevancy is not so important at this point (see notes of Lesson 31 in the book).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>タイ、ダイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふくろ</p> <p id='words'>足袋(たび): Japanese socks (with split toe)<br>袋(ふくろ): bag, sack<br>手袋(てぶくろ): gloves</p> <p id='readingExamples'>袋 (ふくろ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1082</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1007</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1082</p> <p id='keyword'>lend</p> <p id='kanji'>貸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lend, substitute, person, arrow, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Substitute . . . shells/money.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In order for the bank to lend you money, you need to put up some sort of collateral as a substitute for the money.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The poor substitute teacher asks the class to lend him some money for the bus fare home.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.す、か.し-、かし-</p> <p id='words'>貸し(かし): loan, lending<br>貸し出し(かしだし): lending, loaning<br>貸間(かしま): room to let<br>貸家(かしや): house for rent<br>貸す(かす): lend</p> <p id='readingExamples'>貸す (か.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1083</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1008</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1083</p> <p id='keyword'>change</p> <p id='kanji'>化</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58C96.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>change, person, spoon, sitting on the ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . spoon.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Referring to a scene in the movie ""The Matrix"" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine Mister T who changes a spoon into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of ""spare change"", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as ""shape"" or ""turn into"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T reaches into his wallet for some spare change but it has all changed into spoons.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ、ケ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ば.ける、ば.かす、ふ.ける、け.する</p> <p id='words'>悪化(あっか): deterioration, growing worse, aggravation, degeneration, corruption<br>化合(かごう): chemical combination<br>化する(かする): to change into, to convert into, to transform, to be reduced, to influence, to improve (someone)<br>化石(かせき): fossil, petrifaction, fossilization<br>化繊(かせん): synthetic fibres<br>誤魔化す(ごまかす): to deceive, to falsify, to misrepresent<br>酸化(さんか): oxidation<br>進化(しんか): evolution, progress<br>退化(たいか): degeneration, retrogression<br>化ける(ばける): to appear in disguise, to take the form of, to change for the worse<br>文化財(ぶんかざい): cultural assets, cultural property<br>化学(かがく): chemistry<br>強化(きょうか): strengthen, intensify, reinforce, solidify<br>化粧(けしょう): make-up (cosmetic)<br>消化(しょうか): digestion<br>変化(へんか): change, variation, alteration, mutation, transition, transformation, variety, diversity, inflection, declension, conjugation<br>文化(ぶんか): culture</p> <p id='readingExamples'>化石 (かせき), 化学 (かがく), 文化 (ぶんか), 化かす (ば.かす), 化ける (ば.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1084</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1009</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1084</p> <p id='keyword'>flower</p> <p id='kanji'>花</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88AB1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>flowers, change, person, spoon, sitting on the ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flower . . . change.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The flowers change with the seasons.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The flower is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual flower involves both the concept of flower plus change.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ、ケ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はな</p> <p id='words'>花壇(かだん): flower bed<br>花粉(かふん): pollen<br>花びら(はなびら): (flower) petal<br>火花(ひばな): spark<br>生け花(いけばな): flower arrangement<br>花火(はなび): fireworks<br>花見(はなみ): cherry blossom viewing, flower viewing<br>花嫁(はなよめ): bride<br>花瓶(かびん): (flower) vase<br>花(はな): flower</p> <p id='readingExamples'>花 (はな)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1085</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1010</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1085</p> <p id='keyword'>freight</p> <p id='kanji'>貨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>freight, change, person, spoon, sitting on the ground, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Change . . . shells.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don´t confuse with the similar 賃 fare (#1004).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is a freight train that runs on spare change. Imagine getting on the freight train with a bunch of spare change. You put in some change and it starts up...goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there´s actually a slot for spare change and one for regular shells. Your call, but it seems to prefer spare change over shells.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たから</p> <p id='words'>外貨(がいか): imported goods, foreign money<br>貨幣(かへい): money, currency, coinage<br>雑貨(ざっか): miscellaneous goods, general goods, sundries<br>貨物(かもつ): cargo, freight, money or assets<br>硬貨(こうか): coin<br>通貨(つうか): currency</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1086</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1011</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1086</p> <p id='keyword'>lean</p> <p id='kanji'>傾</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E582BE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lean, change, person, about that time, spoon, sitting on the ground, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Change</i> . . . <i>head</i>. The key word has the sense of <b>leaning</b> on or toward someone or something.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr. T gave a girl some change to lean over and give him head.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Leaning over changes the position of the head...　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ケイ　傾向　けいこう(tendency).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かたむ.く、かたむ.ける、かたぶ.く、かた.げる、かし.げる</p> <p id='words'>傾く(かたぶく): to incline toward, to slant, to lurch, to heel over, to be disposed to, to trend toward, to be prone to, to go down (sun), to wane, to sink, to decline<br>傾ける(かたむける): to incline, to list, to bend, to lean, to tip, to tilt, to slant, to concentrate on, to ruin (a country), to squander, to empty<br>傾(けい): lean, incline<br>傾斜(けいしゃ): inclination, slant, slope, bevel, list, dip<br>傾く(かたむく): incline toward, slant, lurch, be disposed to, go down (sun), wane, sink, decline<br>傾向(けいこう): tendency, trend, inclination<br>傾らか(なだらか): gently-sloping, gentle, easy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>傾く (かたむ.く), 傾ける (かたむ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1087</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1012</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1087</p> <p id='keyword'>what</p> <p id='kanji'>何</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BD95.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>what, person, can, mouth, street, nail, spike</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . can.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>What can Mr T do? ´You mean: what can´t MR T do, you fool´.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>What can´t Mr. T not do?</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なに、なん、なに-、なん-</p> <p id='words'>如何(いかが): how, in what way<br>如何に(いかに): how?, in what way?, how much?, however, whatever<br>如何にも(いかにも): indeed, really, phrase meaning agreement<br>何れ(いずれ): where, which, who, anyway, anyhow, at any rate<br>何時(いつ): when, how soon<br>何時か(いつか): sometime, some day<br>何時でも(いつでも): (at) any time, always, at all times, never (neg), whenever<br>何時の間にか(いつのまにか): before one knows, unnoticed, unawares<br>何時も(いつも): always, usually, every time, never (with neg. verb)<br>如何しても(どうしても): by all means, at any cost, no matter what, after all, in the long run, cravingly, at any rate, surely<br>何方(どちら): which, who<br>何の(どの): which, what<br>何れ(どれ): well, now, let me see, which (of three or more)<br>何々(どれどれ): which (emphatic)<br>何故(なぜ): why, how<br>何気ない(なにげない): casual, unconcerned<br>何しろ(なにしろ): at any rate, anyhow, anyway, in any case<br>何卒(なにとぞ): please<br>何も(なにも): nothing<br>何より(なにより): most, best<br>何だか(なんだか): a little, somewhat, somehow<br>何て(なんて): how...!, what...!<br>何と(なんと): what, how, whatever<br>何となく(なんとなく): somehow or other, for some reason or another<br>何とも(なんとも): nothing (with neg. verb), quite, not a bit<br>何なり(なんなり): any, anything, whatever<br>何か(なにか): something<br>何々(なになに): such and such, What?, What is the matter?<br>何分(なにぶん): anyway, please<br>何で(なんで): Why? 	"<p id='id'>1092</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1016</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1092</p> <p id='keyword'>long time</p> <p id='kanji'>久</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B985.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>long time, bound up, person, mummy</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for <i>bound up</i> and a <i>person</i>. 	"<p id='id'>1093</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1017</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1093</p> <p id='keyword'>furrow (sillon)</p> <p id='kanji'>畝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7959D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>furrow, top hat, rice field, brains, long time, mummy, bound up, person</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of the three kinds of <b>furrows</b> shown here in this character - a <i>top hat's</i> rim, a <i>rice field's</i> ridges, and the wrinkles that show you've been around a <i>long time</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Using a TOP HAT to make FURROWS in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A mummy tries to furrow his brow but realizes that he´s got no head - just a brain with a top-hat on it. So he furrows his brain. 	"<p id='id'>1094</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1018</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1094</p> <p id='keyword'>captured</p> <p id='kanji'>囚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59B9A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>captured, pent in, person</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . pent in.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A person pent in is obviously captured. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T can´t be captured. This kanji is lying.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とら.われる</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1095</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1019</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1095</p> <p id='keyword'>inside</p> <p id='kanji'>内</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58685.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inside, person, belt</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Person</i> . . . <i>belt</i>. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of <i>hood</i> here because the <i>person</i> runs THROUGH the element, not under it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr. T´s new belt is huge! When he´s inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>How is a person ever supposed to get inside that girl when she´s wearing such a huge chastity belt? I guess that´s kinda the point, eh?</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ナイ、ダイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うち</p> <p id='words'>内(うち): inside<br>内訳(うちわけ): the items, breakdown, classification<br>内閣(ないかく): cabinet, (government) ministry<br>内臓(ないぞう): internal organs, intestines, viscera<br>内部(ないぶ): interior, inside, internal<br>内乱(ないらん): civil war, insurrection, rebellion, domestic conflict<br>内陸(ないりく): inland<br>案内(あんない): information, guidance<br>内科(ないか): internist clinic, internal medicine<br>内線(ないせん): phone extension, indoor wiring, inner line<br>内容(ないよう): subject, contents, matter, substance, detail, import<br>以内(いない): within<br>家内(かない): (my) wife</p> <p id='readingExamples'>内外 (ないがい), 内容 (ないよう), 家内 (かない), 内 (うち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1096</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1020</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1096</p> <p id='keyword'>third class</p> <p id='kanji'>丙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B899.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>third class, one, ceiling, inside, person, belt</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from <i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>person</i> . . . <i>belt</i>. The kanji meaning ""<i>inside</i>"" should not be used because of its proximity to the element for ""<i>in</i>.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it´s almost pictographic here!).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>But third class is so small Mr. T´s head hits the celing.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひのえ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The tree grain design was too expensive for the third class airline to use for the panelling. 	"<p id='id'>1098</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1022</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1098</p> <p id='keyword'>meat</p> <p id='kanji'>肉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88289.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>meat, person, inside, belt, person, person2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>27</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let this doubling of one of the elements for ""<i>inside</i>"" yield the sense of ""<i>insides</i>"" to approach the key word, <b>meat</b>. The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of <i>flesh</i> or <i>part of the body</i> for the kanji 月.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A person´s inside - fleshy, raw, pink, meat.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ニク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しし</p> <p id='words'>肉親(にくしん): blood relationship, blood relative<br>肉体(にくたい): the body, the flesh<br>筋肉(きんにく): muscle, sinew<br>皮肉(ひにく): cynicism, sarcasm, irony, satire<br>牛肉(ぎゅうにく): beef<br>肉(にく): meat<br>豚肉(ぶたにく): pork</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1104</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1027</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1104</p> <p id='keyword'>monme</p> <p id='kanji'>匁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58C81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>monme, bound up, tucked under the arm</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: <i>bound up</i> . . . <i>arm</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! ""Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! ""Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"" ""You´ll never be able to use your dagger now!"" (adapted from ergerg).</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'></p> <p id='kunYomi'>もんめ、め</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>匁 (もんめ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1105</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1028</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1105</p> <p id='keyword'>by means of</p> <p id='kanji'>以</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BBA5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>by means of, plow, drop, person</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Picture a <i>person</i> dragging a <i>plow</i> behind, and the <i>drop of</i> sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living ""<b>by means of</b> the sweat of their brows.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age ""ard"" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr T now makes a living by means of a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もっ.て</p> <p id='words'>以て(もって): with, by, by means of, because, in view of<br>以外(いがい): except for, other than<br>以後(いご): from now on, thereafter<br>以降(いこう): on and after, hereafter, thereafter<br>以前(いぜん): ago, since, before, previous<br>以来(いらい): since, henceforth<br>以下(いか): ~ or less than?not more than<br>以上(いじょう): more than, over<br>以内(いない): within</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1106</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1029</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1106</p> <p id='keyword'>similar</p> <p id='kanji'>似</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BCBC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>becoming, similar, person, by means of, plow, drop, person</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Be sure to keep this key word distinct from <i>likeness</i> (Frame 104). 	"<p id='id'>1107</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1030</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1107</p> <p id='keyword'>join</p> <p id='kanji'>併</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BDB5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>join, person, puzzle, horns, two hands</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sense of the key word is one of <b>joining</b> things together that were previously separate. 	"<p id='id'>1110</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1033</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1110</p> <p id='keyword'>Shinto shrine</p> <p id='kanji'>宮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AEAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shinto shrine, house, spine, mouth, drop, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for <i>spine</i>. The two other characters in which it is used we can now learn together in this and the following frame. Here a <b>Shinto shrine</b> is composed of <i>house</i> and <i>spine</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This Shinto shrine is built with human spines. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for ""sedlec ossuary"", it´s quite a sight.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: ""house with a spine, Shinto shrine""!</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キュウ、グウ、ク、クウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みや</p> <p id='words'>お宮(おみや): Shinto shrine<br>宮殿(きゅうでん): palace</p> <p id='readingExamples'>宮殿 (きゅうでん), 宮廷 (きゅうてい), 離宮 (りきゅう), 宮 (みや)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1111</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1034</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1111</p> <p id='keyword'>occupation</p> <p id='kanji'>営</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E596B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>occupation, schoolhouse, owl, crown, spine, mouth, drop, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Schoolhouse . . . spine.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>During the German occupation, this Nazi officer´s occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : ""the occupation´s spine schools""). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also ""barracks; camp; encapment"". This story should help avoid confusion with post (#824) and employ (#1083). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 ""detention barracks"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>エイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いとな.む、いとな.み</p> <p id='words'>営む(いとなむ): to carry on (e.g. in ceremony), to run a business<br>運営(うんえい): management, administration, operation<br>営業(えいぎょう): business, trade, sales, operations<br>経営(けいえい): management, administration</p> <p id='readingExamples'>営む (いとな.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1112</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1035</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1112</p> <p id='keyword'>virtuous</p> <p id='kanji'>善</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59684.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>virtuous, sheep, horns, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Sheep</i> . . . <i>horns</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>. Pay special attention to the writing of this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine a priest´s teaching: ""To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God´s flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To be virtuous, a good rule to follow is to put your sheepishness (discretion) over your horns (anger) before using your mouth. In other words, ""discretion is the better part of virtue"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゼン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よ.い、い.い、よ.く、よし.とする</p> <p id='words'>最善(さいぜん): the very best<br>親善(しんぜん): friendship<br>善良(ぜんりょう): goodness, excellence, virtue<br>善し悪し(よしあし): good or bad, merits or demerits, quality, suitability<br>改善(かいぜん): betterment, improvement, incremental and continuous improvement<br>善(ぜん): good, goodness, right, virtue</p> <p id='readingExamples'>善い (よ.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1114</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1036</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1114</p> <p id='keyword'>year</p> <p id='kanji'>年</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B9B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>year, sign of the horse, sunglasses</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In an odd fashion, the kanji for <b>year</b> joins together the element for <i>horse</i>, on the top, and the right half of the element for <i>sunglasses</i>. Think of it as a <i>horse</i> wearing <i>sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out</i>. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like descend (#1308).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ネン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とし</p> <p id='words'>一昨年(おととし): year before last<br>同い年(おないどし): of the same age<br>元年(がんねん): first year (of a specific reign)<br>成年(せいねん): majority, adult age<br>定年(ていねん): retirement age<br>年頃(としごろ): age, marriageable age, age of puberty, adolescence, for some years<br>年寄り(としより): old people, the aged<br>年鑑(ねんかん): yearbook<br>年号(ねんごう): name of an era, year number<br>年生(ねんせい): pupil in .... year, student in .... year<br>年長(ねんちょう): seniority<br>年輪(ねんりん): annual tree ring<br>一昨年(いっさくねん): year before last<br>学年(がくねん): year in school, grade in school<br>少年(しょうねん): boys, juveniles<br>青少年(せいしょうねん): youth, young person<br>青年(せいねん): youth, young man<br>生年月日(せいねんがっぴ): birth date<br>中年(ちゅうねん): middle-aged<br>年月(としつき): months and years<br>年間(ねんかん): year (interval of time)<br>年月(ねんげつ): months and years<br>年中(ねんじゅう): whole year, always, everyday<br>年代(ねんだい): age, era, period, date<br>年度(ねんど): year, fiscal year, school year, term<br>年齢(ねんれい): age, years<br>年(とし): year<br>去年(きょねん): last year<br>今年(ことし): this year<br>再来年(さらいねん): year after next<br>万年筆(まんねんひつ): fountain pen<br>来年(らいねん): next year</p> <p id='readingExamples'>年 (とし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1115</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1037</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1115</p> <p id='keyword'>night</p> <p id='kanji'>夜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A49C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>night, top hat, person, walking legs, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of <b>night</b> with those of <i>evening</i> (Frame 114) and <i>nightbreak</i> (Frame 30). Its elements: <i>top hat</i> . . . <i>person</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i> . . . <i>drop</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Actually, the lower-right primitive isn´t quite ""walking legs."" It´s a little more like ""evening"" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Here we have Mister T sleepwalking, wearing a top hat as if he was the ambassador of the night, walking, and walking and walking on his tired walking legs, until he drops (back into his bed).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヤ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よ、よる</p> <p id='words'>日夜(にちや): day and night, always<br>夜行(やぎょう): walking around at night, night train, night travel<br>夜具(やぐ): bedding<br>夜中(やちゅう): all night, the whole night<br>夜更かし(よふかし): staying up late, keeping late hours, sitting up late at night, nighthawk<br>夜更け(よふけ): late at night<br>深夜(しんや): late at night<br>徹夜(てつや): all night, all-night vigil, sleepless night<br>夜間(やかん): at night, nighttime<br>夜行(やこう): walking around at night, night train, night travel<br>夜(よ): night<br>夜明け(よあけ): dawn, daybreak<br>夜中(よなか): all night, the whole night<br>今夜(こんや): tonight<br>夜(よる): evening, night</p> <p id='readingExamples'>夜 (よ), 夜 (よる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1121</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1042</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1121</p> <p id='keyword'>yell</p> <p id='kanji'>喚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5969A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>yell, mouth, bound up, four, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>mouth</i> on the left is obvious. The rest is harder. Try this: <i>four St. Bernard dogs bound up</i> in a bunch. Together they should supply a clear enough portrait of a <b>yell</b>, provided you are careful to see all <i>four</i> of them. Note how the final stroke of the <i>four</i> is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the <i>St .Bernard</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I´m imagining lots of yelping.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Yell? You mean, Old Yeller. Here, we see four St Bernard dogs all yelling for a chance to play a part in Old Yeller. They´re so loud that you have to bound them, and their mouths, up.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わめ.く</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1123</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1044</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1123</p> <p id='keyword'>dissolve</p> <p id='kanji'>融</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E89E8D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dissolve, tripod, one, ceiling, mouth, hood, human legs, street, nail, spike, insect</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>28</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Ceiling</i> . . . <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>hood</i> . . . <i>human legs</i> . . . <i>spike</i> . . . <i>insect</i>. This is the maximum number of elements <i>to appear in</i> any story in the book.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I have created the element ""old camera"" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject´s point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I´ve seen this crazy thing with only one mouth that can dissolve up to 4 nails and an insect at the same time. Sweet! (It´s a venus flytrap, btw).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.ける、と.かす</p> <p id='words'>融資(ゆうし): financing, loan<br>融通(ゆうずう): lending (money), accommodation, adaptability, versatility, finance<br>金融(きんゆう): monetary circulation, credit situation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don´t confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1127</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1048</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1127</p> <p id='keyword'>trip</p> <p id='kanji'>旅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69785.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>trip, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, Carol in rags, person, rag</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let the last 4 strokes, which are also the concluding strokes to the character for <i>garment</i>, represent a <i>rag</i> as its primitive meaning. We shall meet this only on one other occasion. This gives us as our elements: <i>banner</i> . . . <i>rag</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The boat starts to leave on it´s trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says ""Bon Voyage"", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>リョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たび</p> <p id='words'>旅客(りょかく): passenger (transport)<br>旅券(りょけん): passport<br>旅(たび): travel, trip, journey<br>旅館(りょかん): Japanese inn<br>旅行(りょこう): travel, trip</p> <p id='readingExamples'>旅 (たび)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1128</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1049</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1128</p> <p id='keyword'>not</p> <p id='kanji'>勿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58BBF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>not, knot, piglet’s tail</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>First take the primitive meaning of this character: <i>knot</i>. Think of it as the <i>piglet</i> minus its body (the horizontal stroke), that is, the curly tail that looks like a <i>knot</i>. As an exception, we will use the homonym to remember the abstract key word, <b>not</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji is NOT a piglett.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The butcher is standing over the piglet. ""This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>モチ、ブツ、ボツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なか.れ、なし</p> <p id='words'>勿論(もちろん): of course, certainly, naturally</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1129</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1050</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1129</p> <p id='keyword'>thing</p> <p id='kanji'>物</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E789A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>thing, cow, knot, piglet’s tail</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cow . . . knot.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The cow´s ""thing"" is tied in a knot! ouch.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A cow is not a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ブツ、モツ</p> <p 	"<p id='id'>1136</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1056</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1136</p> <p id='keyword'>fence</p> <p id='kanji'>塀</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A180.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fence, soil, dirt, ground, folding screen, flag, puzzle, horns, two hands</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Soil . . . flag . . . puzzle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>[fence; wall; (kokuji)] A fence separates one soil from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of soils in the world have a virtual fence called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their soil with one color, their national flag as the legend and a fence on the borders... don´t you think it looks like a giant puzzle?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Why the Earth has to be fenced off and flags used to represent each ""country"" is a puzzle to me - we´re all just monkeys on a big rock spinning round the Sun!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘイ、ベイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>塀(へい): wall, fence</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1137</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1057</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1137</p> <p id='keyword'>footgear</p> <p id='kanji'>履</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B1A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>footgear, flag, restore, Nelson, column, going, line, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flag . . . restore.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on footgear, rather than actual footgear itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR FOOTGEAR and run off to RESTORE the FLAG.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You should never use a flag as a shoeshine cloth to restore your footgear.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>は.く</p> <p id='words'>履く(はく): to wear, to put on (lower body)<br>履歴(りれき): personal history, background, career, log<br>草履(ぞうり): sandals</p> <p id='readingExamples'>履く (は.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Do not confuse with <i>dwell</i> (Frame 1027).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A humongous American flag in Florida marks the place where all the old people reside.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It is an old tradition that people plant a flag on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. set (#1064).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョ、コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い.る、-い、お.る</p> <p id='words'>隠居(いんきょ): retirement, retired person<br>居る(おる): be here (polite)<br>居住(きょじゅう): residence<br>皇居(こうきょ): Imperial Palace<br>転居(てんきょ): moving, changing residence<br>同居(どうきょ): living together<br>鳥居(とりい): torii (Shinto shrine archway)<br>居眠り(いねむり): dozing, nodding off<br>居間(いま): living room (Western style)<br>芝居(しばい): play, drama<br>住居(じゅうきょ): dwelling, house, residence, address<br>居る(いる): to be (animate), to exist</p> <p id='readingExamples'>居る (い.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1144</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1064</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1144</p> <p id='keyword'>set</p> <p id='kanji'>据</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68DAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>set, finger, fingers, reside, flag, old, tombstone, gravestone, church, ten, needle, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . reside.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The man set his finger firmly on the map and said ""Here is where they reside, I am certain of it"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Cf. reside (#1063): you set the flag with your fingers on the place where you reside: an old tradition.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>す.える、す.わる</p> <p id='words'>据え付ける(すえつける): to install, to equip, to mount<br>据える(すえる): to set (table), to lay (foundation), to place (gun), to apply (moxa)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>据える (す.える), 据わる (す.わる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1146</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1065</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1146</p> <p id='keyword'>stratum</p> <p id='kanji'>層</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B1A4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stratum, flag, increase, formerly, horns, rice field, brains, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flag . . . increase.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The strata have piled up in an ever increasing pile of dirt. As the geologists go down the rocks, they flag each stratum with the name of the corresponding era.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Archaeologists at a dig site place small flags marking layers or strata of rock. Each of these layers was formerly the top layer. (This is not increase! Hseige keeps messing up).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>階層(かいそう): class, level, stratum, hierarchy<br>一層(いっそう): much more, still more, all the more<br>高層(こうそう): upper<br>大層(たいそう): very much, exaggerated, very fine</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1147</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1066</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1147</p> <p id='keyword'>bureau</p> <p id='kanji'>局</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B180.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bureau, flag, phrase, bound up, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Flag</i> . . . <i>phrase</i>. Note how the <i>flag</i>'s long stroke doubles up for the first stroke of <i>phrase</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The Federal Bureau of Investigation has email scanners that flag certain phrases.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>They do nothing at the bureau other than repeating the stupid catchphrase they have on their flag.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つぼね</p> <p id='words'>局限(きょくげん): limit, localize<br>局(きょく): channel (i.e. TV or radio), department, affair, situation<br>結局(けっきょく): after all, eventually<br>薬局(やっきょく): pharmacy<br>郵便局(ゆうびんきょく): post office</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"

Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mark the holes where rain water can leak through with little flags.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ロウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>も.る、も.れる、も.らす</p> <p id='words'>漏らす(もらす): to let leak, to reveal<br>漏る(もる): to leak, to run out<br>漏れる(もれる): to leak out, to escape, to come through, to shine through, to filter out, to be omitted</p> <p id='readingExamples'>漏らす (も.らす), 漏る (も.る), 漏れる (も.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1150</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1069</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1150</p> <p id='keyword'>printing</p> <p id='kanji'>刷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E588B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>printing, flag, towel, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flag . . . towel . . . saber.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The image that keeps coming to me is of the giant mechanical printing presses. The cloth-based material is coming off the roll like a flag and then, after printing, gets cut into sheets by saber-like cutting tools.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>サツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>す.る、-ず.り、-ずり、は.く</p> <p id='words'>刷り(すり): printing<br>印刷(いんさつ): printing<br>刷る(する): print, publish</p> <p id='readingExamples'>刷る (す.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1151</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1070</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1151</p> <p id='keyword'>shaku</p> <p id='kanji'>尺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B0BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shaku, flag, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word <b>shaku</b> has actually come into English in the word <i><b>shaku</b>hachi</i>, the ancient Japanese flute that measured ""one <b>shaku</b> and eight <i>sun</i>"" (the ""sun"" being about an inch in length). Since the <b>shaku</b> is about one foot in length, this makes about 20 inches. Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the <i>flag</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this will mean the <i>shakuhachi</i> flute.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Slang for blowjob and that´s priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Since this is SLANG for BLOW JOB and since it looks like an ""R"", let´s have the primitive be the R in BROW JOB. :).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1152</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1071</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1152</p> <p id='keyword'>exhaust</p> <p id='kanji'>尽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B0BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>exhaust, shaku-hachi, flag, stick, ice</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Shakuhachi . . . ice.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A women is so exhausted by her ""shakuhachi"" that see needs to ice her jaw.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>That´s not ice...it´s my last drops and I´m exhausted! ;).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジン、サン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つ.くす、-つ.くす、-づ.くし、-つ.く、-づ.く、-ず.く、つ.きる、つ.かす、さかづき、ことごと.く、つか、つき</p> <p id='words'>尽きる(つきる): to be used up, to be run out, to be exhausted, to be consumed, to come to an end<br>尽くす(つくす): to exhaust, to run out, to serve (a person), to befriend</p> <p id='readingExamples'>尽かす (つ.かす), 尽きる (つ.きる), 尽くす (つ.くす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1157</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1076</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1157</p> <p id='keyword'>door</p> <p id='kanji'>戸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E688B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>door, one, flag</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ceiling . . . flag.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as ""noren,"" hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don´t usually hang from the ceiling.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と</p> <p id='words'>戸(こ): counter for houses<br>戸籍(こせき): census, family register<br>戸締り(とじまり): closing up, fastening the doors<br>雨戸(あまど): (sliding) storm door<br>井戸(いど): water well<br>瀬戸物(せともの): earthenware, crockery, china<br>戸棚(とだな): cupboard, locker, closet, wardrobe<br>戸(と): door (Japanese style)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>戸 (と)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"

Use your foot).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm´s story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かた</p> <p id='words'>肩(かた): shoulder</p> <p id='readingExamples'>肩 (かた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1161</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1080</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1161</p> <p id='keyword'>hearth</p> <p id='kanji'>炉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78289.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hearth-fire, door, one, ceiling, flag</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Hearth fire . . . door.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>-""Honey? Do we have any wood left for the hearth?"" -""Aagh, just use the frickin´ door!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ロ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いろり</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1162</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1081</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1162</p> <p id='keyword'>re-</p> <p id='kanji'>戻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E688BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>re-, door, one, ceiling, flag, large, St. Bernard</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word signals a ""coming back"" or return to some place or activity. Its elements: <i>door</i> . . . <i>St. Bernard dog</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The St. Bernard dog whining at the door of his master’s house in order to re-enter / re-turn inside.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think about hachiko, the dog waiting at the door of the station, waiting for his master to re-turn.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>レイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もど.す、もど.る</p> <p id='words'>取り戻す(とりもどす): to take back, to regain<br>払い戻す(はらいもどす): repay, pay back<br>戻す(もどす): restore, put back, return<br>戻る(もどる): return</p> <p id='readingExamples'>戻す (もど.す), 戻る (もど.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1164</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1083</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1164</p> <p id='keyword'>employ</p> <p id='kanji'>雇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99B87.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>employ, door, one, ceiling, flag, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>29</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Door</i> . . . <i>turkey</i>. Be sure to keep distinct from both <i>employee</i> (Frame 59) and <i>use</i> (Frame 1065).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Our company has no standards. We´ll employ any turkey who walks in the door.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Comedy. An executive is having an argument with a cocky, but skilled, employee: ""Damn it, you might be good. But that don´t account for your behavior. You keep this up and I´ll fire your ass."" ""No, you won´t."" ""What damn it, I´ll fire you your ass so fast you won´t...know...""-. ""And what will you do after you fire me, employ the next turkey that walks through that door?"" A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. --""The Exec employs the turkey that walked through the door"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やと.う</p> <p id='words'>雇用(こよう): employment (long term), hire<br>雇う(やとう): employ, hire</p> <p id='readingExamples'>雇う (やと.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1167</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1086</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1167</p> <p id='keyword'>show</p> <p id='kanji'>示</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A4BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>show, altar, show, two, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Although the elements <i>two</i> and <i>little</i> are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. Something placed atop the altar is put on <b>show</b> for all to see.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji means <i>altar</i>. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the <i>altar</i> in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for <i>cloak</i>, identical except for the one final short stroke.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A boy made an altar, but he´s afraid to show it to God because he thinks it´s two little.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I´ll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!, she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジ、シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しめ.す</p> <p id='words'>暗示(あんじ): hint, suggestion<br>指示(しじ): indication, instruction, directions<br>提示(ていじ): presentation, exhibit, suggest, citation<br>展示(てんじ): exhibition, display<br>掲示(けいじ): notice, bulletin<br>示す(しめす): show, indicate, denote, point out</p> <p id='readingExamples'>示威 (しい), 示談 (じだん), 指示 (しじ), 示す (しめ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1168</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1087</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1168</p> <p id='keyword'>salutation</p> <p id='kanji'>礼</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A4BC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>salute, salutation, altar, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of <b>salutation</b> so important in Japanese culture. Its elements: <i>altar</i> . . . <i>fishhook</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>レイ、ライ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>無礼(ぶれい): impolite, rude<br>礼(れい): expression of gratitude<br>礼儀(れいぎ): manners, courtesy, etiquette<br>お礼(おれい): courtesy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>礼儀 (れいぎ), 謝礼 (しゃれい), 無礼 (ぶれい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"

The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>On this ewe-spicious occasion, you sacrifice a sheep at the altar. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. 	"<p id='id'>1171</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1090</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1171</p> <p id='keyword'>blessing</p> <p id='kanji'>福</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A68F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>blessing, altar, wealth, one, ceiling, mouth, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Altar . . . wealth.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you´re called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>フク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>福(ふく): good fortune<br>福祉(ふくし): welfare, well-being<br>幸福(こうふく): happiness, blessedness</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1173</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1092</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1173</p> <p id='keyword'>company</p> <p id='kanji'>社</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A4BE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>company, altar, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Altar</i> . . . <i>soil</i>. The <b>company</b> referred to here is that of the modern business world.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you enter a Japanese company it´s like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やしろ</p> <p id='words'>社交(しゃこう): social life, social intercourse<br>社宅(しゃたく): company owned house<br>出社(しゅっしゃ): arrival (in a country at work etc.)<br>社(やしろ): Shinto shrine<br>社会科学(しゃかいかがく): social science<br>社説(しゃせつ): editorial, leading article<br>商社(しょうしゃ): trading company, firm<br>入社(にゅうしゃ): entry to a company<br>社会(しゃかい): society<br>社長(しゃちょう): president<br>神社(じんじゃ): Shinto shrine<br>新聞社(しんぶんしゃ): newspaper office<br>会社(かいしゃ): company, corporation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>社 (やしろ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1174</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1093</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1174</p> <p id='keyword'>inspection</p> <p id='kanji'>視</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A696.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inspection, altar, see, telescope, eye, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Altar . . . see.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a ""visual once over"" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[inspection; regard as; see; look at] Inspection: you 示 show (#1086) and someone else 見 see (#57).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>み.る</p> <p id='words'>監視(かんし): observation, guarding, inspection, surveillance<br>近視(きんし): shortsightedness<br>視覚(しかく): sense of sight, vision<br>視察(しさつ): inspection, observation<br>視点(してん): opinion, point of view, visual point<br>視野(しや): field of vision, outlook<br>重視(じゅうし): importance, stress, serious consideration<br>無視(むし): disregard, ignore</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1175</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1094</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1175</p> <p id='keyword'>Nara</p> <p id='kanji'>奈</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A588.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>nara, large, St. Bernard, altar, show, two, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We choose the city of <b>Nara</b> as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in <b>Nara</b>; and also because of <b>Nara's</b> famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: <i>St. Bernard dog</i> . . . <i>altar</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Nara is just a big show for tourists.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ナ、ナイ、ダイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いかん、からなし</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1176</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1095</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1176</p> <p id='keyword'>military officer</p> <p id='kanji'>尉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B089.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>military officer, flag, altar, show, two, small, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flag . . . altar . . . glue.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Of course it had to be the military officer´s idea to glue a national flag to the altar he´s stationed at.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Perhaps you have heard about Koizumis controversial visits at the Yasukuni war memorial shrine. It is the japanese flag waving above a small stone altar. A military officer keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ、ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>尉(じょう): jailer, old man, rank, company officer</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1177</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1096</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1177</p> <p id='keyword'>consolation</p> <p id='kanji'>慰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E685B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>consolation, military officer, flag, altar, show, two, small, glue, heart</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Military officer . . . heart.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II ""comfort women"" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なぐさ.める、なぐさ.む</p> <p id='words'>慰める(なぐさめる): comfort, console</p> <p id='readingExamples'>慰む (なぐさ.む), 慰める (なぐさ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1178</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1097</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1178</p> <p id='keyword'>goodwill</p> <p id='kanji'>款</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ACBE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>goodwill, samurai, altar, show, two, small, lack, yawn</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Samurai . . . altar . . . yawning.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The samurai kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his goodwill benefits everyone. No beheadings.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1179</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1098</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1179</p> <p id='keyword'>prohibition</p> <p id='kanji'>禁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A681.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>prohibition, grove, tree, wood, altar, show, two, small, tree2, wood2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Grove . . . altar.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Similar to radical tyro´s story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably ""no smoking"" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol ""for sacremental purposes"" and share it with his kin (きん).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>禁じる(きんじる): to prohibit<br>禁ずる(きんずる): to forbid, to suppress<br>禁物(きんもつ): taboo, forbidden thing<br>禁煙(きんえん): No Smoking!<br>禁止(きんし): prohibition, ban</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1180</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1099</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1180</p> <p id='keyword'>collar</p> <p id='kanji'>襟</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A59F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>collar, cloak, prohibition, grove, tree, wood, altar, show, two, small, tree2, wood2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cloak . . . prohibition.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A collar is the part of your cloak that, if tightened too tight, will prohibit breathing.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Collars are prohibited from wizarding cloaks. 	"<p id='id'>1182</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1101</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1182</p> <p id='keyword'>adore</p> <p id='kanji'>崇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B487.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>adore, mountain, religion, house, altar, show, two, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Mountain . . . religion.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to adore the gods who live on Mount Olympus.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I would adore the religious people if they just went and threw themselves off a mountain top.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>スウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あが.める</p> <p id='words'>崇拝(すうはい): worship, adoration, admiration, cult</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1183</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1102</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1183</p> <p id='keyword'>ritual</p> <p id='kanji'>祭</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A5AD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Flesh</i> . . . <i>crotch</i> . . . <i>altar</i>. Note how the second element is cut short, giving a tent-like effect to the character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>サイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まつ.る、まつ.り、まつり</p> <p id='words'>祭日(さいじつ): national holiday, festival day<br>祭(まつり): festival, feast<br>祭る(まつる): deify, enshrine<br>お祭り(おまつり): festival</p> <p id='readingExamples'>祭り (まつ.り), 祭る (まつ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1184</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1103</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1184</p> <p id='keyword'>guess</p> <p id='kanji'>察</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AF9F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>guess, house, ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""<b>Guess</b>"" here has the sense of a measured conjecture. Its elements: <i>house</i> . . . <i>ritual</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performet at.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It´s anyone´s guess who´s house she will wake up in the morning after the festival (祭-matsuri)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　サツ　警察　けいさつ(police)…　Pure Group:　擦1104.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>察する(さっする): to guess, to sense, to presume, to judge, to sympathize with<br>視察(しさつ): inspection, observation<br>観察(かんさつ): observation, survey<br>診察(しんさつ): medical examination<br>警察(けいさつ): police</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1185</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1104</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1185</p> <p id='keyword'>grate</p> <p id='kanji'>擦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E693A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grate, finger, fingers, guess, house, ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . guess.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you mis-guess the cheese you´ll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Ouch! Guess how many fingers I just grated in the grater? (Edit: OR: Ouch! Guess what I just grated in the grater? -- my finger!).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>す.る、す.れる、-ず.れ、こす.る、こす.れる</p> <p id='words'>擦る(かする): to touch lightly, to take a percentage (from)<br>擦れ違い(すれちがい): chance encounter<br>擦れる(すれる): to rub, to chafe, to wear, to become sophisticated<br>擦る(こする): rub, scrub<br>摩擦(まさつ): friction, rubbing, rubdown, chafe</p> <p id='readingExamples'>擦る (す.る), 擦れる (す.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1186</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1105</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1186</p> <p id='keyword'>wherefore</p> <p id='kanji'>由</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E794B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wherefore, sprout, shoot</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The ""<b>wherefore</b>"" of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a <i>rice field</i> sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and <b>wherefore</b> of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the <i>flower</i> appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full <i>seedling</i>.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean <i>shoot</i> or <i>sprout</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo? (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet´s dinner plate and rolled off).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Cogito ergo sum. Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it´s often mistranslated as ""where"" when in fact it´s an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.].</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユ、ユウ、ユイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よし、よ.る</p> <p id='words'>経由(けいゆ): go by the way, via<br>不自由(ふじゆう): discomfort, disability, inconvenience, destitution<br>自由(じゆう): freedom<br>理由(りゆう): reason</p> <p id='readingExamples'>由来 (ゆらい), 経由 (けいゆ), 自由 (じゆう), 理由 (りゆう), 事由 (じゆう), 由 (よし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1187</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1106</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1187</p> <p id='keyword'>pluck</p> <p id='kanji'>抽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68ABD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pluck, finger, fingers, sprout, shoot</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . sprout.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>[When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひき-</p> <p id='words'>抽選(ちゅうせん): lottery, raffle, drawing (of lots)<br>抽象(ちゅうしょう): abstract</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
