They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とど.ける、-とど.け、とど.く</p> <p id='words'>届け(とどけ): report, notification, registration<br>届く(とどく): reach<br>届ける(とどける): deliver</p> <p id='readingExamples'>届く (とど.く), 届ける (とど.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1192</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1111</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1192</p> <p id='keyword'>flute</p> <p id='kanji'>笛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AC9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>flute, bamboo, sprout, shoot</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bamboo . . . sprout.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Flute is made of bamboo sprout.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふえ</p> <p id='words'>笛(ふえ): flute</p> <p id='readingExamples'>笛 (ふえ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1193</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1112</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1193</p> <p id='keyword'>axis</p> <p id='kanji'>軸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BBB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>axis, car, sprout, shoot</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Car . . . shoot.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car´s wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>軸(じく): axis, stem, shaft, axle</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1194</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1113</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1194</p> <p id='keyword'>armor</p> <p id='kanji'>甲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E794B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>armour, armor, roots</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji reverses the element for <i>sprout</i>, giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the <i>rice field</i>. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, <b>armor</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning is <i>roots</i>. Important to that word is the image of ""pushing downwards,"" as <i>roots</i> do.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai´s armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the ""turtle samurai"" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It looks like a bird´s eye view of a tank (modern armor).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、カン、カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きのえ</p> <p id='words'>甲(きのえ): 1st in rank, first sign of the Chinese calendar, shell, instep, grade A</p> <p id='readingExamples'>甲乙 (こうおつ), 装甲車 (そうこうしゃ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1195</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1114</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1195</p> <p id='keyword'>push</p> <p id='kanji'>押</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68ABC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>push, finger, fingers, armour, armor, roots</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>roots</i>. Compare and contrast with <i>pluck</i> (Frame 1187).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Use your fingers to make sure the roots of your plant are deep underground by pushing them down, down, down.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>オウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.す、お.し-、お.っ-、お.さえる、おさ.える</p> <p id='words'>押さえる(おさえる): to stop, to restrain, to seize, to repress, to suppress, to press down<br>押し込む(おしこむ): to push into, to crowd into<br>押し寄せる(おしよせる): to push aside, to advance on<br>押える(おさえる): stop, restrain, seize, repress, suppress, press down<br>押し入れ(おしいれ): closet<br>押す(おす): push, press, stamp (e.g. a passport)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>押さえる (お.さえる), 押す (お.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1196</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1115</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1196</p> <p id='keyword'>headland</p> <p id='kanji'>岬</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B2AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>headland, mountain, armour, armor, roots</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Like the <i>cape</i> (Frame 164) and the <i>promontory</i> (Frame 840), the <b>headland</b> refers to a jut of land. Its elements: <i>mountain</i> . . . <i>roots</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みさき</p> <p id='words'>岬(みさき): cape (on coast)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>岬 (みさき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1197</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1116</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1197</p> <p id='keyword'>insert</p> <p id='kanji'>挿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68CBF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>insert, finger, fingers, thousand, armour, armor, roots</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>thousand</i> . . . <i>roots</i>. Observe how the writing order does not follow the elements in order, because the final stroke is used for two different elements.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A rice farmer´s delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and thousand of root-like tentacles are inserting themselves in... well, I think you can fill the rest.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さ.す、はさ.む</p> <p id='words'>挿す(さす): to insert, put in, graft</p> <p id='readingExamples'>挿す (さ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1198</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1117</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1198</p> <p id='keyword'>speaketh</p> <p id='kanji'>申</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E794B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>speaketh, monkey, sun, day, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb ""to speak."" It is written by a <i>tongue wagging in the mouth</i> with a <i>walking stick</i> rammed through it and coming out at both ends.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* While this kanji has obvious affinities to the ""seed"" group, it also happens to be the zodiacal sign of the <i>monkey</i> (the one who <i>speaketh</i> no evil, among other things). We shall therefore take <i>monkey</i> as its primitive meaning.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the ""s"" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 sayeth (#578). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in ""moshi moshi"" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say ""hello, this is X speaking."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もう.す、もう.し-、さる</p> <p id='words'>申告(しんこく): report, statement, filing a return, notification<br>申し入れる(もうしいれる): to propose, to suggest<br>申し込み(もうしこみ): application, entry, request, subscription, offer, proposal, overture, challenge<br>申出(もうしで): proposal, request, claim, report, notice<br>申し出る(もうしでる): to report to, to tell, to suggest, to submit, to request, to make an offer, to come forward with information<br>申し分(もうしぶん): objection, shortcomings<br>申請(しんせい): application, request, petition<br>申し込む(もうしこむ): apply for, propose, offer, challenge, request<br>申し訳(もうしわけ): apology, excuse<br>申し訳ない(もうしわけない): inexcusable<br>申し上げる(もうしあげる): say (polite)<br>申す(もうす): say (polite)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>申す (もう.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1199</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1118</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1199</p> <p id='keyword'>expand</p> <p id='kanji'>伸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BCB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>expand, person, monkey, sun, day, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . monkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Here we see Mr. T. expanding his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A person expands into an ape man. 	"<p id='id'>1200</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1119</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1200</p> <p id='keyword'>gods</p> <p id='kanji'>神</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A59E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>gods, altar, monkey, sun, day, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Altar . . . monkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus´ latest purchase for Mount Olympus. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン、ジン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かみ、かん-、こう-</p> <p id='words'>神聖(しんせい): holiness, sacredness, dignity<br>神殿(しんでん): temple, sacred place<br>神秘(しんぴ): mystery<br>神(かみ): god<br>神様(かみさま): god<br>神経(しんけい): nerve, sensitivity<br>神話(しんわ): myth, legend<br>精神(せいしん): mind, soul, heart, spirit, intention<br>神社(じんじゃ): Shinto shrine</p> <p id='readingExamples'>神聖 (しんせい), 神経 (しんけい), 精神 (せいしん), 神 (かみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1201</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1120</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1201</p> <p id='keyword'>search</p> <p id='kanji'>捜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68D9C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>search, finger, fingers, Buddha’s hand, monkey, sun, day, stick, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . monkey . . . crotch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you are familiar with the Monkey legends (西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While searching for the end of the universe, monkey reaches to his crotch and urinates on Buddha´s fingers. (Update: new link http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RYXFppaKLL4).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ、シュ、シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さが.す</p> <p id='words'>捜査(そうさ): search (esp. in criminal investigations), investigation<br>捜索(そうさく): search (esp. for someone or something missing), investigation<br>捜す(さがす): search, seek, look for</p> <p id='readingExamples'>捜す (さが.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1202</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1121</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1202</p> <p id='keyword'>fruit</p> <p id='kanji'>果</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69E9C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The final stage of the seed is reached when the plant has reached its full growth (the <i>tree</i>) and comes to fruition, producing <b>fruit</b> full of new seeds that can return to the earth and start the process all over again. The main thing to notice here is the element for <i>brains</i> at the top, which might prove more helpful than <i>rice field</i> for creating an image. The writing, however, follows the order of a <i>sun</i> with a <i>tree</i> whose trunk runs through the <i>sun</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Eve ate fruit from the tree and knowledge filled her brain.…　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　果汁　かじゅう (fruit juice)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Semi-Pure Group:　菓1122　課1123　(ﾗ): 裸1124.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>は.たす、はた.す、-は.たす、は.てる、-は.てる、は.て</p> <p id='words'>成果(せいか): results, fruits<br>果ない(はかない): fleeting, transient, short-lived, momentary, vain, fickle, miserable, empty, ephemeral<br>果たして(はたして): as was expected, really<br>果たす(はたす): to accomplish, to fulfill, to carry out, to achieve<br>果て(はて): the end, the extremity, the limit(s), the result<br>果てる(はてる): to end, to be finished, to be exhausted, to die, to perish<br>果実(かじつ): fruit, nut, berry<br>結果(けっか): result, consequence<br>効果(こうか): effect, effectiveness, efficacy, result<br>果物(くだもの): fruit</p> <p id='readingExamples'>果たす (は.たす), 果て (は.て), 果てる (は.てる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1204</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1123</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1204</p> <p id='keyword'>chapter</p> <p id='kanji'>課</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AAB2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>chapter, say, words, keitai, mouth, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>30</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . fruit.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I´ve learned. (Thanks Misha!).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It´s good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy´s ""War and Peace"" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you´d very quickly run out of fruit).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>課外(かがい): extracurricular<br>課題(かだい): subject, theme, task<br>課(か): counter for chapters (of a book)<br>課税(かぜい): taxation<br>課程(かてい): course, curriculum<br>日課(にっか): daily lesson, daily work, daily routine</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"

To the right of the door is the standard place for the axe.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ところ、-ところ、どころ、とこ</p> <p id='words'>所謂(いわゆる): the so-called, so to speak<br>箇所(かしょ): passage, place, point, part<br>所在(しょざい): whereabouts<br>所持(しょじ): possession, owning<br>所々(しょしょ): here and there, some parts (of something)<br>所属(しょぞく): attached to, belong to<br>所定(しょてい): fixed, prescribed<br>所得(しょとく): income, earnings<br>所が(ところが): however, while, even if<br>所で(ところで): by the way, even if, no matter what<br>余所見(よそみ): looking away, looking aside<br>個所(かしょ): passage, place, point, part<br>所為(せい): act, deed, one´s doing<br>短所(たんしょ): defect, demerit, weak point, disadvantage<br>長所(ちょうしょ): strong point, merit, advantage<br>停留所(ていりゅうじょ): bus or tram stop<br>所々(ところどころ): here and there, some parts (of something)<br>場所(ばしょ): place, location<br>便所(べんじょ): toilet, lavatory, rest room, latrine<br>名所(めいしょ): famous place<br>役所(やくしょ): government office, public office<br>余所(よそ): another place, somewhere else, strange parts<br>近所(きんじょ): neighbor hood<br>事務所(じむしょ): office<br>住所(じゅうしょ): address<br>台所(だいどころ): kitchen<br>所(ところ): place</p> <p id='readingExamples'>所 (ところ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1209</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1128</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1209</p> <p id='keyword'>pray</p> <p id='kanji'>祈</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A588.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pray, altar, axe</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Altar . . . ax.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the altars at the local missions, and if anybody refused to pray, they would get the axe.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A warrior prays for victory before the battle. He kneels at the altar, his battle axe at the ready.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いの.る</p> <p id='words'>祈り(いのり): prayer, supplication<br>祈る(いのる): pray</p> <p id='readingExamples'>祈る (いの.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1210</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1129</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1210</p> <p id='keyword'>near</p> <p id='kanji'>近</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BF91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>near, axe, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Ax</i> . . . <i>road</i>. Be careful not to confuse with <i>draw near</i> (Frame 204) or <i>bystander</i> (Frame 1090).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long road. To make A and B near, take an ax, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>キン、コン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ちか.い</p> <p id='words'>近眼(きんがん): nearsightedness, shortsightedness, myopia<br>近々(きんきん): nearness, before long<br>近郊(きんこう): suburbs, outskirts<br>近視(きんし): shortsightedness<br>近付く(ちかづく): to approach, to get near, to get acquainted with, to get closer<br>手近(てぢか): near, handy, familiar<br>身近(みぢか): near oneself, close to one, familiar<br>近代(きんだい): present day<br>接近(せっきん): getting closer, approaching<br>近頃(ちかごろ): lately, recently, nowadays<br>近々(ちかぢか): nearness, before long<br>近付ける(ちかづける): bring near, put close, let come near, associate with<br>近寄る(ちかよる): approach, draw near<br>付近(ふきん): neighbourhood, vicinity, environs<br>近所(きんじょ): neighbor hood<br>最近(さいきん): recently<br>近い(ちかい): near, close by, short<br>近く(ちかく): near, neighbourhood, vicinity</p> <p id='readingExamples'>近い (ちか.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1211</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1130</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1211</p> <p id='keyword'>fold</p> <p id='kanji'>折</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68A98.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fold, finger, fingers, axe</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>ax</i>. Hint: make an image out of the Japanese art of ""origami"" (paper-<b>folding</b>).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s the latest Japanese game show: Forudo! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to fold it into a complex origami shape. If they´re not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in folding, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Fold some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It´s even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.る、おり、お.り、-お.り、お.れる</p> <p id='words'>折り返す(おりかえす): to turn up, to fold back<br>屈折(くっせつ): bending, indentation, refraction<br>折衷(せっちゅう): compromise, cross, blending, eclecticism<br>時折(ときおり): sometimes<br>折る(おる): break, fold, pick (flower)<br>骨折(こっせつ): bone fracture<br>折角(せっかく): with trouble, at great pains, long-awaited<br>折れる(おれる): break, snap</p> <p id='readingExamples'>折る (お.る), 折れる (お.れる), 折 (おり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1212</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1131</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1212</p> <p id='keyword'>philosophy</p> <p id='kanji'>哲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E593B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>philosophy, fold, finger, fingers, axe, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fold . . . mouth.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are folding sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the mouth of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I fold my mouth, therefore I am.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さとい、あき.らか、し.る、さば.く</p> <p id='words'>哲学(てつがく): philosophy</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1213</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1132</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1213</p> <p id='keyword'>departed</p> <p id='kanji'>逝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9809D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>departed, fold, finger, fingers, axe, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The connotation is of a ""dearly <b>departed</b>"" who has passed away. The elements: <i>fold</i> . . . <i>road</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>One of the dearest of Japan´s dearly departed is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for folding more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still fold origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire road lined with folded cranes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently departed victims who died when the roads folded (from the earthquake).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆ.く、い.く</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>逝く (ゆ.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1214</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1133</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1214</p> <p id='keyword'>vow</p> <p id='kanji'>誓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AA93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vow, fold, finger, fingers, axe, say, words, keitai, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fold . . . words.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then folded it into an origami, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- ""the folded words are vows"". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive ""fold"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with origami cranes with their vows written on the BOTTOM.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ちか.う</p> <p id='words'>誓う(ちかう): swear, vow, take an oath, pledge</p> <p id='readingExamples'>誓う (ちか.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1216</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1134</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1216</p> <p id='keyword'>temporarily</p> <p id='kanji'>暫</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69AAB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>temporarily, executioner, chop off, car, axe, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Chop off . . . days.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can temporarily (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ザン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しばら.く</p> <p id='words'>暫く(しばらく): little while</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1217</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1135</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1217</p> <p id='keyword'>steadily</p> <p id='kanji'>漸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BCB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>steadily, water, water droplets, water pistol, executioner, chop off, car, axe</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . chop off.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Water + Car + Axe: The steadily rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゼン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やや</p> <p id='words'>漸く(ようやく): gradually, finally, hardly</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1218</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1136</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1218</p> <p id='keyword'>severance</p> <p id='kanji'>断</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E696AD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>severance, fishhook, rice, axe</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fishhook . . . rice . . . ax.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>[Based on fuaburisu´s] A man puts some rice on a fishhook as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his axe and sever the line lest he be dragged into the depths.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you get the ax at work, use your severance pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>た.つ、ことわ.る、さだ.める</p> <p id='words'>決断(けつだん): decision, determination<br>断言(だんげん): declaration, affirmation<br>断然(だんぜん): firmly, absolutely, definitely<br>断面(だんめん): cross section<br>中断(ちゅうだん): interruption, suspension, break<br>無断(むだん): without permission, without notice<br>横断(おうだん): crossing<br>断る(ことわる): refuse, reject, dismiss, turn down, decline, inform, give notice, ask leave, excuse oneself (from)<br>診断(しんだん): diagnosis<br>断水(だんすい): water outage<br>断定(だんてい): conclusion, decision<br>判断(はんだん): judgement, decision, adjudication, conclusion, decipherment, divination<br>油断(ゆだん): negligence, unpreparedness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>断る (ことわ.る), 断つ (た.つ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1219</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1137</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1219</p> <p id='keyword'>substance</p> <p id='kanji'>質</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B3AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>substance, axe, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, axe2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Two axes . . . shells.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>What is this substance on this clam? I´ve already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Another keyword that I do not like by Heisig. 質【しつ】 (n,n-suf) quality. Story: Your at a local ax dealer and you have TWO AXES which you are testing for QUALITY by trying to split CLAMS right down the opening. Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird SUBSTANCE comes out of the shell...eww (I don´t like clams).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シツ、シチ、チ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たち、ただ.す、もと、わりふ</p> <p id='words'>気質(かたぎ): spirit, character, trait, temperament, disposition<br>質疑(しつぎ): question<br>実質(じっしつ): substance, essence<br>質素(しっそ): simplicity, modesty, frugality<br>蛋白質(たんぱくしつ): protein<br>人質(ひとじち): hostage, prisoner<br>品質(ひんしつ): quality<br>本質(ほんしつ): essence, true nature, reality<br>良質(りょうしつ): good quality, superior quality<br>質(しつ): quality<br>性質(せいしつ): nature, property, disposition<br>素質(そしつ): character, qualities, genius<br>地質(ちしつ): geological features<br>物質(ぶっしつ): material, substance<br>質問(しつもん): question, inquiry</p> <p id='readingExamples'>質問 (しつもん), 質実 (しつじつ), 本質 (ほんしつ), 質屋 (しちや), 人質 (ひとじち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1220</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1138</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1220</p> <p id='keyword'>reject</p> <p id='kanji'>斥</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E696A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>reject, axe, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ax . . . a drop of.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The quality expectations are very high in our axe manufacturing facility. If there´s one drop of rust on any axe, it gets rejected.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しりぞ.ける</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1221</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1139</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1221</p> <p id='keyword'>accusation</p> <p id='kanji'>訴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A8B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>accusation, say, words, keitai, mouth, reject, axe, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . reject.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Words that make you feel rejected.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うった.える</p> <p id='words'>訴え(うったえ): lawsuit, complaint<br>訴訟(そしょう): litigation, lawsuit<br>訴える(うったえる): sue (a person), resort to, appeal to</p> <p id='readingExamples'>訴える (うった.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1222</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1140</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1222</p> <p id='keyword'>yesterday</p> <p id='kanji'>昨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E698A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>yesterday, sun, day, saw</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Day . . . saw.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Yester-DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away...</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>一昨日(おととい): day before yesterday<br>一昨年(おととし): year before last<br>一昨昨日(さきおととい): two days before yesterday<br>一昨日(いっさくじつ): day before yesterday<br>一昨年(いっさくねん): year before last<br>昨(さく): last (year), yesterday<br>昨日(きのう): yesterday</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1223</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1141</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1223</p> <p id='keyword'>lie</p> <p id='kanji'>詐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A990.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lie, say, words, keitai, mouth, saw</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>lie</b> in this character refers to falsehoods and fibs. Its elements: <i>words</i> . . . <i>saw</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Her lies are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いつわ.る</p> <p id='words'>詐欺(さぎ): fraud, swindle</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1224</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1142</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1224</p> <p id='keyword'>make</p> <p id='kanji'>作</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BD9C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>make, person, saw</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . saw.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr T.´s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he´s a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, Mr. T salvages a saw from the wreckage and says, ""I don´t know about y´all foos, but I´m gonna make a raft."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>サク、サ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つく.る、つく.り、-づく.り</p> <p id='words'>凶作(きょうさく): bad harvest, poor crop<br>原作(げんさく): original work<br>工作(こうさく): work, construction, handicraft, maneuvering<br>耕作(こうさく): cultivation, farming<br>作(さく): a work, a harvest<br>作戦(さくせん): military or naval operations, tactics, strategy<br>作物(さくぶつ): literary work<br>作用(さよう): action, operation, effect, function<br>創作(そうさく): production, literary creation, work<br>駄作(ださく): poor work, rubbish<br>作り(つくり): make-up, sliced raw fish<br>豊作(ほうさく): abundant harvest, bumper crop<br>発作(ほっさ): fit, spasm<br>傑作(けっさく): masterpiece, best work, blunder<br>作業(さぎょう): work, operation, manufacturing, fatigue duty<br>作者(さくしゃ): author<br>作成(さくせい): frame, draw up, make, producing, creating, preparing, writing,<br>作製(さくせい): manufacture<br>作品(さくひん): work, opus, performance, production<br>作物(さくもつ): literary work<br>作家(さっか): author, writer, novelist, artist<br>作曲(さっきょく): composition, setting (of music)<br>作法(さほう): manners, etiquette, propriety<br>制作(せいさく): work (film, book)<br>製作(せいさく): manufacture, production<br>操作(そうさ): operation, management, processing<br>動作(どうさ): action, movements, motions, bearing, behaviour, manners<br>名作(めいさく): masterpiece<br>作文(さくぶん): composition, writing<br>作る(つくる): to make, create, manufacture, construct, draw up, write, compose, build, cultivate, organize, establish, make up (a face), trim (a tree), prepare (food), commit (sin)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>作為 (さくい), 著作 (ちょさく), 豊作 (ほうさく), 作る (つく.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1225</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1143</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1225</p> <p id='keyword'>snow</p> <p id='kanji'>雪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99BAA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>snow, rain, weather, broom</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Rain</i> that undergoes a change so that it can be swept aside with a <i>broom</i> is <b>snow</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>SNOW isn´t all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Rain just soaks into the soil. Snow has to be swept away with a broom...　RTK2:　セツ　積雪　せきせつ(pilled up snow).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆき</p> <p id='words'>雪崩(なだれ): avalanche<br>吹雪(ふぶき): snow storm<br>雪(ゆき): snow</p> <p id='readingExamples'>雪 (ゆき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1226</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1144</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1226</p> <p id='keyword'>record</p> <p id='kanji'>録</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98CB2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>record, metal, gold, dustpan, broom, grains of rice</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Metal</i> . . . <i>broom</i> . . . <i>rice</i>. Note how the final stroke of the <i>broom</i> is extended slightly when an element below is attached directly to it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A monk won a gold metal for breaking the current record for most swept rice in one minute.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This character is about a recording for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a metal broom and the little pins on the cylinder are like metal grains of rice.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ロク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>登録(とうろく): registration, register, entry, record<br>付録(ふろく): appendix, supplement<br>目録(もくろく): catalogue, catalog, list<br>記録(きろく): record, minutes, document<br>録音(ろくおん): (audio) recording</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1228</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1145</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1228</p> <p id='keyword'>inquire</p> <p id='kanji'>尋</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B08B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inquire, broom, craft, mouth, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Broom . . . craft . . . mouth . . . glue.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>As a verb this means, this means ""to ask; to enquire; to search; to look for; to look into; to investigate;"". Imagine the police inquiring in an in-depth investigation. They are interrogating a suspect. But the suspect has a crafty mouth and is very sly. He/she also knows when to keep their mouth shut(glued) at the right moments to avoid self-incrimination. As a final measure, the police torture the suspect by tickling him/her with a broom while they inquire.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たず.ねる、ひろ</p> <p id='words'>尋ねる(たずねる): ask</p> <p id='readingExamples'>尋ねる (たず.ねる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Even the days are calm without storm.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>オン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おだ.やか</p> <p id='words'>穏やか(おだやか): calm, gentle, quiet</p> <p id='readingExamples'>穏やか (おだ.やか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1236</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1153</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1236</p> <p id='keyword'>hit</p> <p id='kanji'>当</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BD93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hit, small, broom</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Little . . . broom.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a broom like a javelin and throw it, trying to hit the center of a very small target. 	"<p id='id'>1238</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1154</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1238</p> <p id='keyword'>contend</p> <p id='kanji'>争</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BA89.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>contend, bound up, rake</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bound up . . . rake.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A boxing ring is bound up by the ropes. The contender is cheating and using a rake.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あらそ.う、いか.でか</p> <p id='words'>争い(あらそい): dispute, strife, quarrel, dissension, conflict, rivalry, contest<br>抗争(こうそう): dispute, resistance<br>紛争(ふんそう): dispute, trouble, strife<br>争う(あらそう): argue, dispute<br>論争(ろんそう): controversy, dispute<br>競争(きょうそう): compete<br>戦争(せんそう): war</p> <p id='readingExamples'>争う (あらそ.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1240</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1156</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1240</p> <p id='keyword'>matter</p> <p id='kanji'>事</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BA8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>matter, one, ceiling, mouth, rake</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word here refers to abstract <b>matters</b>. The elements are: <i>one</i> . . . <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>rake</i>. Note how the <i>rake</i> handle reaches out the top and bottom of the character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I had to take one day off from work due to ´personal matters´ after stepping on a rake and having the handle snap up and smack me across the mouth. I certainly wasn´t going to tell anyone about it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジ、ズ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こと、つか.う、つか.える</p> <p id='words'>大事(おおごと): important, valuable, serious matter<br>お大事に(おだいじに): Take care of yourself<br>議事堂(ぎじどう): Diet building<br>旧事(くじ): past events, bygones<br>軍事(ぐんじ): military affairs<br>検事(けんじ): public prosecutor<br>事(こと): thing, matter, fact, circumstances, business, reason, experience<br>事柄(ことがら): matter, thing, affair, circumstance<br>事によると(ことによると): depending on the circumstances<br>些事(さじ): something small or petty, trifle<br>事業(じぎょう): project, enterprise, business, industry, operations<br>事項(じこう): matter, item, facts<br>事前(じぜん): prior, beforehand, in advance<br>従事(じゅうじ): engaging, pursuing, following<br>食事(しょくじ): meal<br>百科事典(ひゃっかじてん): encyclopedia<br>返事(へんじ): reply, answer<br>家事(かじ): housework, domestic chores<br>記事(きじ): article, news story, report, account<br>行事(ぎょうじ): event, function<br>刑事(けいじ): criminal case, (police) detective<br>工事(こうじ): construction work<br>事件(じけん): event, affair, incident, case, plot, trouble, scandal<br>事実(じじつ): fact, truth, reality<br>事情(じじょう): circumstances, consideration, conditions, situation, reasons<br>事態(じたい): situation, present state of affairs, circumstances<br>事務(じむ): business, office work<br>炊事(すいじ): cooking, culinary arts<br>知事(ちじ): prefectural governor<br>出来事(できごと): incident, affair, happening, event<br>判事(はんじ): judge, judiciary<br>無事(ぶじ): safety, peace, quietness<br>見事(みごと): splendid, magnificent, beautiful, admirable<br>物事(ものごと): things, everything<br>領事(りょうじ): consul<br>火事(かじ): fire<br>事故(じこ): accident<br>事務所(じむしょ): office<br>大事(だいじ): important<br>用事(ようじ): business, errand<br>仕事(しごと): work, occupation, employment</p> <p id='readingExamples'>事物 (じぶつ), 無事 (ぶじ), 師事 (しじ), 事 (こと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1241</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1157</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1241</p> <p id='keyword'>T'ang</p> <p id='kanji'>唐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59490.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>T’ang, cave, rake, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word here refers of course to the <b>T'ang</b> Dynasty in China (and not to the name of the drink astronauts take with them into outer space, though this could be useful for the next frame). Its elements: <i>cave</i> . . . <i>rake</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, ""What about this – T´ang, do you think?"" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, ""Yes, it does tang a bit"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical caves, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden rakes to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their mouths to see if it´s tasty or not.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>から</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>唐 (から)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1242</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1158</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1242</p> <p id='keyword'>sugar</p> <p id='kanji'>糖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B396.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sugar, rice, T’ang, cave, rake, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rice . . . T'ang.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The T´ang are the ones who began using sugar in China--of course, the first thing they tried it on was rice.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>砂糖(さとう): sugar</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1243</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1159</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1243</p> <p id='keyword'>sane</p> <p id='kanji'>康</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BAB7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ease, sane, cave, sieve, rake, grains of rice</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'>sieve = tamis<br></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cave . . . sieve.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>People on the cave age became more sane after they started using sieves to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康, health).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>健康(けんこう): health, sound, wholesome</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1244</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1160</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1244</p> <p id='keyword'>apprehend</p> <p id='kanji'>逮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E980AE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>apprehend, sieve, rake, grains of rice, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of <b>apprehending</b> criminals. The elements are: <i>sieve</i> . . . <i>road</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to apprehend Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying ""Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>逮捕(たいほ): arrest, apprehension, capture</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1245</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1161</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1245</p> <p id='keyword'>Italy</p> <p id='kanji'>伊</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BC8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>italy, person, mop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Used chiefly in proper names, and given the sound ""i,"" this kanji can be remembered as an abbreviation of <b>Italy</b>, for which it is still used today in Japan. Its primitives: <i>person</i> . . . <i>mop</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The ""boot"" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Here I have Mister T cleaning up with a mop, a real mess of spaghetti, in front of the Piza (in Italy).</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かれ</p> <p id='words'>伊井(いい): that one, Italy</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1246</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1162</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1246</p> <p id='keyword'>old boy</p> <p id='kanji'>君</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5909B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>old boy, mop, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The somewhat highbrow British term of address is chosen hereto represent the kanji for a form of address used towards one's juniors. It is composed of: <i>mop</i> . . . <i>mouth</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There´s a tendancy in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. ""Well old boy,"" a senpai might say, ""If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Beatles, english old boys, had hairs like mop and a good singing mouth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>クン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きみ、-ぎみ</p> <p id='words'>君(くん): Mr (junior), master, boy<br>君主(くんしゅ): ruler, monarch<br>諸君(しょくん): Gentlemen!, Ladies!<br>君(きみ): you</p> <p id='readingExamples'>君 (きみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1247</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1163</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1247</p> <p id='keyword'>flock</p> <p id='kanji'>群</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BEA4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>flock, old boy, mop, mouth, sheep</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Old boys . . . sheep.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Good ol´ boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A little girl herder calls out, ""羊君、きて！"" to the sheeps and they flock to her at once.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>グン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>む.れる、む.れ、むら、むら.がる</p> <p id='words'>群(ぐん): group (math)<br>群集(ぐんしゅう): (social) group, crowd, throng, mob, multitude<br>群がる(むらがる): to swarm, to gather<br>群れ(むれ): group, crowd, flock, herd, bevy, school, swarm, cluster (of stars), clump</p> <p id='readingExamples'>群れ (む.れ), 群れる (む.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1248</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1164</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1248</p> <p id='keyword'>-proof</p> <p id='kanji'>耐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88090.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>proof, comb, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word is a suffix used to indicate ""safe from"" or ""protected against,"" as in the words rust<b>proof</b>, water<b>proof</b>, and fire<b>proof</b>. It is composed of: <i>comb</i> . . . <i>glue</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>[akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>た.える</p> <p id='words'>耐える(たえる): to bear, to endure</p> <p id='readingExamples'>耐える (た.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1249</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1165</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1249</p> <p id='keyword'>demand</p> <p id='kanji'>需</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99C80.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>demand, rain, weather, comb</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sense of <b>demand</b> is best captured by thinking of the economic principle of ""supply and <b>demand</b>."" The primitives: <i>rain</i> . . . <i>comb</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Supply and demand is a simple concept: when it rains, the demand for combs goes up to deal with wet hair.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If it´s raining combs, then the demand for them sure does drop.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>需要(じゅよう): demand, request<br>必需品(ひつじゅひん): necessities, necessary article, requisite, essential</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1250</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1166</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1250</p> <p id='keyword'>Confucian</p> <p id='kanji'>儒</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58492.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>confucian, person, demand, rain, weather, comb</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . demand.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it´s raining combs!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>One day, Mr. T started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a Confucian scholar. He was suddenly in high demand as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, ""You will find happiness with a new love"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1251</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1167</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1251</p> <p id='keyword'>edge</p> <p id='kanji'>端</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7ABAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>edge, vase, stand up, pick-axe, mountain, comb</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Vase . . . mountain . . . comb.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is standing at the edge of a sheer mountain face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn´t seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you stand a comb on its edge, it looks like the mountain (#768) kanji.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はし、は、はた、-ばた、はな</p> <p id='words'>極端(きょくたん): extreme, extremity<br>半端(はんぱ): remnant, fragment, incomplete set, fraction, odd sum, incompleteness<br>先端(せんたん): pointed end, tip, fine point, spearhead, cusp, vanguard, advanced, leading edge<br>途端(とたん): just (now, at the moment, etc.)<br>端(はし): edge, tip, margin, point, end (e.g. of street)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>端 (は), 端 (はし), 端 (はた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1252</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1168</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1252</p> <p id='keyword'>both</p> <p id='kanji'>両</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B8A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>both, street, nail, spike, belt, shovel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Ceiling</i> . . . <i>belt</i> . . . <i> mountain</i>.
