See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Both of Tiger Wood´s initials is the logo on his belt... 　　　　　　　　RTK2:　リョウ　両親　りょうしん(one´s parents).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>てる、ふたつ</p> <p id='words'>両極(りょうきょく): both extremities, north and south poles, positive and negative poles<br>両立(りょうりつ): compatibility, coexistence, standing together<br>両替(りょうがえ): change, money exchange<br>両側(りょうがわ): both sides<br>両方(りょうほう): both<br>両親(りょうしん): parents, both parents</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1253</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1169</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1253</p> <p id='keyword'>full</p> <p id='kanji'>満</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BA80.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>full, water, water droplets, water pistol, flowers, both, street, nail, spike, belt, shovel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Water</i> . . . <i>flowers</i> . . . <i>both</i>. Given the abstract nature of this last primitive, you may want to borrow the image from the previous frame.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I was thirsty so I gulped down the water. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the flowers. Yes, I am responsible for both the missing water and the missing flowers. Yes, I´m afraid both. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite full now.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>マン、バン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>み.ちる、み.つ、み.たす</p> <p id='words'>円満(えんまん): perfection, harmony, peace, smoothness, completeness, satisfaction, integrity<br>満月(まんげつ): full moon<br>満場(まんじょう): unanimous, whole audience<br>満たす(みたす): to satisfy, to ingratiate, to fill, to fulfill<br>不満(ふまん): dissatisfaction, displeasure, discontent, complaints, unhappiness<br>満員(まんいん): full house, no vacancy, sold out, standing room only, full (of people), crowded<br>満足(まんぞく): satisfaction<br>満点(まんてん): perfect score<br>満ちる(みちる): be full, rise (tide), mature, expire<br>未満(みまん): less than, insufficient</p> <p id='readingExamples'>満たす (み.たす), 満ちる (み.ちる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1254</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1170</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1254</p> <p id='keyword'>brush-stroke</p> <p id='kanji'>画</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E794BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>brush-stroke, one, ceiling, sprout, shoot, shovel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In forming an image for the key word, it is helpful to know that this kanji is used for artistic representations (like a completed painting), and as a counter for the number of <b>brush-strokes</b> in a character (as, for instance, in Indexes II and III at the end of this book). Its elements are: <i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>sprout</i> . . . <i>shovel</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To paint a kanji in your ceiling with only natural materials, you use a sprout as a brush and shovel some dirt to use as paint for your strokes. [modified from johnskb´s].</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガ、カク、エ、カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>えが.く、かく.する、かぎ.る、はかりごと、はか.る</p> <p id='words'>画(かく): stroke<br>画期(かっき): epoch-making<br>企画(きかく): planning, project<br>区画(くかく): division, section, compartment, boundary, area, block<br>版画(はんが): art print<br>絵画(かいが): picture<br>画家(がか): painter, artist<br>計画(けいかく): plan<br>漫画(まんが): cartoon<br>映画(えいが): movie, film<br>映画館(えいがかん): movie theatre (theater), cinema</p> <p id='readingExamples'>画家 (がか), 図画 (ずが), 映画 (えいが)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1255</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1171</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1255</p> <p id='keyword'>tooth</p> <p id='kanji'>歯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6ADAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tooth, stop, footprint, bag of rice, shovel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Footprint . . . rice . . . shovel.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you´ll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>My dentist used his foot and a shovel to dislodge the rice stuck between my teeth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よわい、は、よわ.い、よわい.する</p> <p id='words'>歯科(しか): dentistry<br>歯車(はぐるま): gear, cog-wheel<br>歯磨き(はみがき): dentifrice, toothpaste<br>虫歯(むしば): cavity, tooth decay, decayed tooth<br>歯医者(はいしゃ): dentist<br>歯(は): tooth</p> <p id='readingExamples'>歯 (は)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1256</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1172</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1256</p> <p id='keyword'>bend</p> <p id='kanji'>曲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69BB2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bend, rice field, brains, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Picture yourself grabbing hold of the two strokes poking out the top of the kanji and wrenching them apart, thus giving the sense of <b>bend</b>. If you think of them as deriving from the element for <i>brains</i> beneath (of course, the middle stroke has been reduplicated and pulled out to where it can be grabbed hold of), you can associate the key word with <b>bending</b> someone's mind to your own point of view.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It looks like the mouth of Bender the robot, from Matt Groening´s animated series ""Futurama"". Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Also means ""melody"". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to bend the strings to make a melody.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ま.がる、ま.げる</p> <p id='words'>婉曲(えんきょく): euphemistic, circumlocution, roundabout, indirect, insinuating<br>戯曲(ぎきょく): play, drama<br>曲(きょく): tune, piece of music<br>曲がる(まがる): to turn, to bend<br>曲線(きょくせん): curve<br>作曲(さっきょく): composition, setting (of music)<br>曲げる(まげる): bend, lean, be crooked<br>曲る(まがる): curve, be bent, be crooked, turn</p> <p id='readingExamples'>曲がる (ま.がる), 曲げる (ま.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1257</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1173</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1257</p> <p id='keyword'>cadet</p> <p id='kanji'>曹</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69BB9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cadet, one, bend, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is written in the order of its elements: <i>one</i> . . . <i>bend</i> . . . <i>sun</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A space cadet eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Bender lasted just one day in the space cadets.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ、ゾウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つかさ、ともがら、へや</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1258</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1174</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1258</p> <p id='keyword'>encounter</p> <p id='kanji'>遭</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E981AD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>encounter, cadet, one, bend, sun, day, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cadet . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) has an ""encounter of the third kind"" on the road. Reference to Steven Spielberg´s 1977 movie ""Close Encounters of the Third Kind"". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO´s while driving on the road.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.う、あ.わせる</p> <p id='words'>遭難(そうなん): disaster, shipwreck, accident<br>遭う(あう): meet, encounter (often something unpleasant)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>遭う (あ.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1259</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1175</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1259</p> <p id='keyword'>rowing</p> <p id='kanji'>漕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BC95.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rowing, water, water droplets, water pistol, cadet, one, bend, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . cadet.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he´s very afraid of water (Bender is a robot).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The space cadet is in training, rowing in the water (see it splash).</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ.ぐ、はこ.ぶ</p> <p id='words'>漕ぐ(こぐ): to row, to scull, to pedal</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1260</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1176</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1260</p> <p id='keyword'>vat</p> <p id='kanji'>槽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A7BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vat, tree, wood, cadet, one, bend, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . cadet.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Also as part of some army survival exercise, the cadets (including Bender see frame 1172) are sent into the woods to build a vat (for collecting water for example).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Bender the Cadet (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a tree, getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey Vat 69.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふね</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1261</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1177</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1261</p> <p id='keyword'>Big Dipper</p> <p id='kanji'>斗</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69697.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>big dipper, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>Big Dipper</b> here is of course the constellation of Ursa Major, of which this kanji is a sort of pictographic representation.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Since we already have a primitive element for a ""dipper"" - namely, the <i>ladle</i> - we shall let this one stand for a <i>measuring cup</i>. By the way, it would make a rather large one, since the kanji is also used for a measure of about 18 liters!</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Since the meaning of ""big dipper"" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ト、トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1262</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1178</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1262</p> <p id='keyword'>fee</p> <p id='kanji'>料</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69699.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fee, rice, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Measuring cup . . . rice.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When buying rice, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don´t just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Samurai(s) once received their fee in the form of rice that had been carefully weighed in a measuring cup beforehand.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>衣料(いりょう): clothing<br>香辛料(こうしんりょう): spices<br>燃料(ねんりょう): fuel<br>肥料(ひりょう): manure, fertilizer<br>料(りょう): material, charge, rate, fee<br>給料(きゅうりょう): salary, wages<br>原料(げんりょう): raw materials<br>材料(ざいりょう): ingredients, material<br>食料(しょくりょう): food<br>資料(しりょう): materials, data<br>送料(そうりょう): postage<br>調味料(ちょうみりょう): condiment, seasoning<br>無料(むりょう): free, no charge<br>有料(ゆうりょう): admission-paid, toll<br>料金(りょうきん): fee, charge, fare<br>食料品(しょくりょうひん): foods<br>料理(りょうり): cooking, cookery, cuisine</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1263</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1179</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1263</p> <p id='keyword'>department</p> <p id='kanji'>科</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A791.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>department, wheat, cereal, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think here of the faculty or <b>department</b> you entered in university, using the elements: <i>measuring cup</i> . . . <i>wheat</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The national DEPARTMENT of WHEATS and MEASURES. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Agriculture/astronomy departments...　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　科学　かがく (science).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>亜科(あか): suborder, subfamily<br>科(か): department, section<br>眼科(がんか): ophthalmology<br>教科(きょうか): subject, curriculum<br>産婦人科(さんふじんか): maternity and gynecology department<br>歯科(しか): dentistry<br>耳鼻科(じびか): otolaryngology<br>小児科(しょうにか): pediatrics<br>百科事典(ひゃっかじてん): encyclopedia<br>百科辞典(ひゃっかじてん): encyclopedia<br>学科(がっか): study subject, course of study<br>科目(かもく): (school) subject, curriculum, course<br>教科書(きょうかしょ): text book<br>外科(げか): surgical department<br>自然科学(しぜんかがく): natural science<br>社会科学(しゃかいかがく): social science<br>人文科学(じんぶんかがく): social sciences, humanities<br>内科(ないか): internist clinic, internal medicine<br>理科(りか): science<br>科学(かがく): science</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1264</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1180</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1264</p> <p id='keyword'>map</p> <p id='kanji'>図</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59BB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>map, pent in, measuring cup, big dipper, The Plough, drop, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Pent in</i> . . . <i>Big Dipper</i>. Hint: among the songs dating from the days of slavery that have become part of American folklore is one called ""Follow the Drinking Gourd."" It referred to the nighttime travel of runaway slaves (those <i>pent in</i>) who had no <b>maps</b> other than the stars to guide them, among them the bright and predominant <i>Big Dipper</i>, the ""Drinking Gourd.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Can´t see direct relation to Big Dipper (#1177) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it´s written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A pictograph of a treasure map. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず map; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ズ、ト</p> <p id='kunYomi'>え、はか.る</p> <p id='words'>意図(いと): intention, aim, design<br>指図(さしず): instruction, mandate<br>図々しい(ずうずうしい): impudent, shameless<br>図る(はかる): to plot, to attempt, to plan, to take in, to deceive, to devise, to design, to refer A to B<br>合図(あいず): sign, signal<br>図(ず): drawing, picture, illustration<br>図鑑(ずかん): picture book<br>図形(ずけい): figure<br>図表(ずひょう): chart, diagram, graph<br>図書(としょ): books<br>地図(ちず): map<br>図書館(としょかん): library</p> <p id='readingExamples'>図画 (ずが), 図表 (ずひょう), 地図 (ちず), 図る (はか.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1265</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1181</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1265</p> <p id='keyword'>utilize</p> <p id='kanji'>用</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E794A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>utilize, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, walking stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Meat</i> . . . <i>walking stick</i>. Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for <i>use</i> (Frame 1065). The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive element, we shall substitute the image of a <i>screwdriver</i>, perhaps the most <i>utilized</i> of all tools around the house.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I´ll confuse this with use (#990), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, ""utilize"" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only utilize ""utilize"" when you´re trying to puff up what you´re saying and sound important. So: ""BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, utilizing the our latest FleshGrip(tm) technology!"" I´m seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of flesh, a short shaft, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もち.いる</p> <p id='words'>運用(うんよう): making use of, application, investment, practical use<br>慣用(かんよう): common, customary<br>兼用(けんよう): multi-use, combined use, combination, serving two purposes<br>公用(こうよう): government business, public use, public expense<br>雇用(こよう): employment (long term), hire<br>採用(さいよう): use, adopt<br>作用(さよう): action, operation, effect, function<br>私用(しよう): personal use, private business<br>使用人(しようにん): employee, servant<br>専用(せんよう): exclusive use, personal use<br>代用(だいよう): substitution<br>無用(むよう): useless, futility, needlessness, unnecessariness<br>用件(ようけん): business<br>用紙(ようし): blank form<br>用品(ようひん): articles, supplies, parts<br>用法(ようほう): directions, rules of use<br>濫用(らんよう): abuse, misuse, misappropriation, using to excess<br>引用(いんよう): quotation, citation<br>応用(おうよう): application, put to practical use<br>活用(かつよう): conjugation, practical use<br>器用(きよう): skillful, handy<br>実用(じつよう): practical use, utility<br>信用(しんよう): confidence, dependence, credit, faith, reliance, belief, credence<br>使用(しよう): use, employment<br>通用(つうよう): popular use, circulation<br>適用(てきよう): applying<br>日用品(にちようひん): daily necessities<br>費用(ひよう): cost, expense<br>用いる(もちいる): use, make use of<br>用語(ようご): term, terminology<br>用心(ようじん): care, precaution, caution<br>用途(ようと): use, usefulness<br>用(よう): business, errand<br>用意(ようい): prepare<br>用事(ようじ): business, errand<br>利用(りよう): use</p> <p id='readingExamples'>用いる (もち.いる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1266</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1182</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1266</p> <p id='keyword'>comfortable</p> <p id='kanji'>庸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BAB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>commonplace, comfortable, cave, rake, screwdriver, utilise, utilize, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, walking stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cave . . . rake . . . screwdriver.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When I first moved in to my new cave, all I had was a bed (see bed (#592)). But now I´ve settled in, got myself a few handy things like a rake and a screwdriver, and made myself more comfortable.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1267</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1183</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1267</p> <p id='keyword'>equip</p> <p id='kanji'>備</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58299.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>equip, person, flowers, cliff, screwdriver, utilise, utilize, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, walking stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Person</i> . . . <i>flowers</i> . . . <i>cliff</i> . . . <i>screwdriver</i>. In cases like this you can jumble up the primitive into any order that seems best for the composition of a story, provided you feel confident about the relative position that those primitives take to one another in the completed character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An RPG where you´re using Mr T as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the flower cliff screwdriver. This is a small screwdriver obtained at the bottom of a cliff that, when used in battle, shoots out pink flowers. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ビ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そな.える、そな.わる、つぶさ.に</p> <p id='words'>軍備(ぐんび): armaments, military preparations<br>守備(しゅび): defense<br>装備(そうび): equipment<br>備え付ける(そなえつける): to provide, to furnish, to equip, to install<br>備える(そなえる): to furnish, to provide for, to equip, to install, to have ready, to prepare for, to possess, to have, to be endowed with, to be armed with<br>備わる(そなわる): to be furnished with, to be endowed with, to possess, to be among, to be one of, to be possessed of<br>警備(けいび): defense, guard, policing, security<br>整備(せいび): adjustment, completion, consolidation<br>設備(せつび): equipment, device, facilities, installation<br>予備(よび): preparation, preliminaries, reserve, spare<br>準備(じゅんび): prepare</p> <p id='readingExamples'>備える (そな.える), 備わる (そな.わる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1268</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1184</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1268</p> <p id='keyword'>once upon a time</p> <p id='kanji'>昔</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69894.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>once upon a time, salad, flowers, one, floor, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Salad</i> . . . <i>days</i>. This is the character with which Japanese fairytales commonly begin.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>For those who don´t know the expression, ""salad days"" means the time of one´s youth. (originally from Shakespeare´s Antony and Cleopatra - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days). I suspect Heisig chose ""salad"" as the name for the radical just for this phrase...</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ、シャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>むかし</p> <p id='words'>昔(むかし): old time, before, ago</p> <p id='readingExamples'>昔日 (むかしにち), 昔年 (むかしねん), 昔時 (むかしとき), 昔 (むかし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1269</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1185</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1269</p> <p id='keyword'>confused</p> <p id='kanji'>錯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98CAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>confused, metal, gold, once upon a time, storyteller, salad, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Metal . . . once upon a time.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A long time ago, people of the world got confused because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient ""art"" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サク、シャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>錯誤(さくご): mistake<br>錯覚(さっかく): optical illusion, hallucination</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1270</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1186</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1270</p> <p id='keyword'>borrow</p> <p id='kanji'>借</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5809F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>borrow, person, once upon a time, storyteller, salad, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . once upon a time.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Once upon a time I let Mr T borrow my salad bowl, but he won´t give it back. ""This be mine now, foo!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T borrowed a copy of Cinderella and won´t give it back. He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the Fairy Godmother does her magic.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.りる</p> <p id='words'>借り(かり): borrowing, debt, loan<br>拝借(はいしゃく): borrowing<br>借金(しゃっきん): debt, loan, liabilities<br>借りる(かりる): borrow, hire, rent, buy on credit</p> <p id='readingExamples'>借りる (か.りる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1271</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1187</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1271</p> <p id='keyword'>pity</p> <p id='kanji'>惜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6839C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pity, Freud, state of mind, once upon a time, storyteller, salad, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>State of mind</i> . . . <i>once upon a time</i>. The sense of the key word is that of a lost opportunity or bad turn of affairs, as in the phrase ""What a <b>pity</b>!""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>What a pity! My state of mind when i think of the opportunities I missed from once upon a time.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Data says ""What a pity"" when he hears that once upon a time there were no robots.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.しい、お.しむ</p> <p id='words'>惜しむ(おしむ): to be frugal, to value, to regret<br>惜しい(おしい): regrettable, disappointing, precious</p> <p id='readingExamples'>惜しい (お.しい), 惜しむ (お.しむ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1274</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1190</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1274</p> <p id='keyword'>twenty</p> <p id='kanji'>廿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BBBF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>twenty</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The two <i>tens</i> joined at the bottom by a short line is actually the old character for <b>twenty</b>, which we might as well learn since we need its primitive form. It is written the same as <i>salad</i>, except for the shorter final stroke.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Ten plus ten is twenty (see generation (#28)).</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュウ、ニュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>にじゅう</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1278</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1194</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1278</p> <p id='keyword'>degrees</p> <p id='kanji'>度</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BAA6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>degrees, caverns, cave, twenty, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word refers to a gradation of measurement, not to academic diplomas. Its primitives: <i>caverns</i> . . . <i>crotch</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The cavern refugees are so poor that they can´t afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their crotches inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in degrees from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ド、ト、タク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たび、-た.い</p> <p id='words'>お目出度う(おめでとう): (ateji) (int) (uk) Congratulations!, an auspicious occasion!<br>感度(かんど): sensitivity, severity (quake)<br>屹度(きっと): (uk) surely, undoubtedly, certainly, without fail, sternly, severely<br>進度(しんど): progress<br>度々(たびたび): often, repeatedly, frequently<br>恰度(ちょうど): just, right, exactly<br>程度(ていど): degree, amount, grade, standard, of the order of (following a number)<br>度忘れ(どわすれ): lapse of memory, forget for a moment<br>密度(みつど): density<br>一度に(いちどに): all at once<br>緯度(いど): latitude (geography)<br>温度(おんど): temperature<br>角度(かくど): angle<br>加速度(かそくど): acceleration<br>経度(けいど): longitude<br>限度(げんど): limit, bounds<br>高度(こうど): altitude, height, advanced<br>支度(したく): preparation<br>湿度(しつど): level of humidity<br>制度(せいど): system, institution, organization<br>速度(そくど): speed, velocity, rate<br>態度(たいど): attitude, manner<br>度(たび): times (three times, etc.), degree<br>適度(てきど): moderate<br>度(ど): time (occurrence), system<br>年度(ねんど): year, fiscal year, school year, term<br>濃度(のうど): concentration, brightness<br>毎度(まいど): each time, common service-sector greeting<br>一度(いちど): once, one time<br>今度(こんど): next time</p> <p id='readingExamples'>度胸 (どきょう), 制度 (せいど), 限度 (げんど), 法度 (ほうど), 度 (たび)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1279</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1195</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1279</p> <p id='keyword'>transit</p> <p id='kanji'>渡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B8A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>transit, water, water droplets, water pistol, degrees, caverns, cave, twenty, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . degrees.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the water if it´s not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The transit system in Tokyo is one of the best in the wrold, but why is it that when it is 35 degrees outside, it is about 2 degrees on the train? Or when it is 2 degrees outside, it is 35 degrees inside the train. This degree of difference means I am always sweating then getting the chills! I think I caught a fever!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ト</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わた.る、-わた.る、わた.す</p> <p id='words'>橋渡し(はしわたし): bridge building, mediation<br>見渡す(みわたす): to look out over, to survey (scene), to take an extensive view of<br>渡り鳥(わたりどり): migratory bird, bird of passage<br>渡す(わたす): pass over, hand over<br>渡る(わたる): cross over, go across</p> <p id='readingExamples'>渡す (わた.す), 渡る (わた.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Using soil and hay to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to entomb the Pharaohs along with all of their money.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>フン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1283</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1199</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1283</p> <p id='keyword'>aroused</p> <p id='kanji'>憤</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E686A4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>aroused, Freud, state of mind, pitchfork, haystack, ten, needle, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, needle3, ten3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>State of mind . . . haystack . . . clams.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of ""indignant"". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn´t seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Data was aroused/indignant when he saw what the volcano had done to the farmers building their haystacks and the fishermen collecting their shells . The tragedy of it all aroused him so much he didn´t even notice he was feeling emotion.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>フン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いきどお.る</p> <p id='words'>憤慨(ふんがい): indignation, resentment</p> <p id='readingExamples'>憤る (いきどお.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1285</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1201</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1285</p> <p id='keyword'>daybreak</p> <p id='kanji'>暁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69A81.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>daybreak, sun, lofty, strawman, wickerman, haystack, ten, needle, one, human legs, needle3, ten3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Sun . . . straw man.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The first person to see the sun at daybreak is of course the straw man who stands outside all day.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギョウ、キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あかつき、さと.る</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>暁 (あかつき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1286</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1202</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1286</p> <p id='keyword'>half</p> <p id='kanji'>半</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58D8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>half, small, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Although the writing order is different, one can remember the appearance of this character by seeing it as a <i>little needle</i> - the kind used for splitting hairs in <b>half</b>. (Again, according to rule, <i>little</i> takes a stroke beneath it in order to be placed over an element that has no horizontal line at the top.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first ""board"" breaks.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in half and there are still two more to go.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なか.ば</p> <p id='words'>半端(はんぱ): remnant, fragment, incomplete set, fraction, odd sum, incompleteness<br>過半数(かはんすう): majority<br>大半(たいはん): majority, mostly, generally<br>半ば(なかば): middle, half, semi, halfway, partly<br>半径(はんけい): radius<br>半島(はんとう): peninsula<br>半(はん): half<br>半分(はんぶん): half</p> <p id='readingExamples'>半ば (なか.ば)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1287</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1203</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1287</p> <p id='keyword'>consort</p> <p id='kanji'>伴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BCB4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>consort, person, half</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . half.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The person who is your consort is most commonly ""your other half"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T wants to splits himself in half so he can be his own CONSORT.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン、バン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ともな.う</p> <p id='words'>伴う(ともなう): to accompany, to bring with, to be accompanied by, to be involved in</p> <p id='readingExamples'>同伴 (どうはん), 随伴 (ずいはん), 伴う (ともな.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1288</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1204</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1288</p> <p id='keyword'>paddy ridge</p> <p id='kanji'>畔</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79594.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>paddy-ridge, rice field, brains, half</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Rice field</i> . . . <i>half</i>. The key word here refers to the <b>ridges</b> that rise up between the sections of a rice <b>paddy</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think about a large rice field as a big square. Then you draw a line down the middle, halving it into two. Then you draw a line across the middle, halving it again into four... These halvings are paddy-ridges that separate the rice field into separate sections. I dunno the reason why, but that´s how it´s done.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あぜ、くろ、ほとり</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1289</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1205</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1289</p> <p id='keyword'>judgment</p> <p id='kanji'>判</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E588A4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>judgement, half, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Half</i> . . . <i>saber</i>. You might recall the famous <b>judgment</b> of King Solomon, who offered to slice a baby in two with a <i>saber</i> to give <i>half</i> to each of the mothers who claimed it as her own.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the bible, King Solomon´s JUDGMENT was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It takes good judgement to cut things in exactly half with a saber.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン、バン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わか.る</p> <p id='words'>審判(しんばん): refereeing, trial, judgement, umpire, referee<br>判(はん): seal, stamp, monogram signature, judgment<br>判(ばん): size (of paper or books)<br>判決(はんけつ): judicial decision, judgement, sentence, decree<br>判定(はんてい): judgement, decision, award, verdict<br>裁判(さいばん): trial, judgement<br>審判(しんぱん): refereeing, trial, judgement, umpire, referee<br>判子(はんこ): seal (used for signature)<br>判事(はんじ): judge, judiciary<br>判断(はんだん): judgement, decision, adjudication, conclusion, decipherment, divination<br>批判(ひはん): criticism, judgement, comment<br>評判(ひょうばん): fame, reputation, popularity, arrant</p> <p id='readingExamples'>判定 (はんてい), 判明 (はんめい), 裁判 (さいばん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1292</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1207</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1292</p> <p id='keyword'>scroll</p> <p id='kanji'>巻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B7BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>scroll, quarter, snake, self</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Quarter</i> . . . <i>snake</i>. The key word refers to a manuscript rolled up into a <b>scroll</b>, not to a <i>hanging scroll</i> (Frame 435).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only 25¢. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous snake. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>How to make snake maki: Take a snake. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a scroll. Cut into quarters and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン、ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ま.く、まき、ま.き</p> <p id='words'>取り巻く(とりまく): to surround, to circle, to enclose<br>巻(まき): volume<br>寝巻(ねまき): sleep-wear, nightclothes, pyjamas, nightgown, nightdress<br>巻く(まく): wind, coil, roll</p> <p id='readingExamples'>巻き (ま.き), 巻く (ま.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

However the facsimile machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his flesh, it just transmits the word ""asshole"". 	"<p id='id'>1297</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1212</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1297</p> <p id='keyword'>one-sided</p> <p id='kanji'>片</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78987.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>one-sided, waiter with wine on tray</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji is based on the pictograph of a tree with some branches going upwards and others hanging down, split right down the middle. When that picture's right side is isolated, it becomes the kanji for <b>one-sided</b>, in the sense of only one part of a whole.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Fuaburisu´s pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn´t see any trees or branches in there).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かた-、かた</p> <p id='words'>片思い(かたおもい): unrequited love<br>片言(かたこと): a smattering, talk like a baby, speak haltingly<br>片付け(かたづけ): tidying up, finishing<br>鉄片(てっぺん): iron scraps<br>片付く(かたづく): be put in order, be put to rights, be disposed of, be solved, be finished, be married (off)<br>片道(かたみち): one-way (trip)<br>片寄る(かたよる): be one-sided, partial, prejudiced, biased, lean, be inclined<br>破片(はへん): fragment, splinter, broken piece<br>片付ける(かたづける): tidy up<br>片仮名(かたかな): katakana</p> <p id='readingExamples'>片 (かた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1298</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1213</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1298</p> <p id='keyword'>printing block</p> <p id='kanji'>版</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78988.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>printing block, one-sided, waiter with wine on tray, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Although this character also carries the sense of an ""edition"" of a publication, the elements, <i>one-sided</i> and <i>anti-</i>, more readily suggest its other meaning of a <b>printing block</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn´t be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Nazi propaganda. Picture the printing blocks producing very one-sided (Aryan), anti-Jewish propaganda spreading posters to hang around town.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>初版(しょはん): first edition<br>絶版(ぜっぱん): out of print<br>版(はん): edition<br>版画(はんが): art print<br>出版(しゅっぱん): publication</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1299</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1214</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1299</p> <p id='keyword'>of</p> <p id='kanji'>之</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B98B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>of, Zorro, building blocks, zig-zag</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is now used chiefly in proper names, and is best learned as the character closest to the hiragana え, though in fact it has no relation to it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* In order to give this kanji a more concrete meaning when it is used as a primitive element, think of it as referring to <i>building blocks</i> with the hiragana written on them, much the same as the A-B-C blocks you played with as a child.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Z of Zorro (and yes he has a hat).</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>の、これ、おいて、ゆく、この</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1300</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1215</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1300</p> <p id='keyword'>destitution</p> <p id='kanji'>乏</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B98F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>destitution, drop, of, Zorro, building blocks, zig-zag</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Drop of . . . building blocks.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Children in complete destitution have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny drop of a building block they are overjoyed.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Just one drop (of alcohol) and he starts walking in zig-zags – no wonder Zorro´s living in destitution. (Note: As a primitive let 之 be Zorro or Zig-Zag: it´s pictographic).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とぼ.しい、とも.しい</p> <p id='words'>窮乏(きゅうぼう): poverty<br>欠乏(けつぼう): want, shortage, famine<br>乏しい(とぼしい): meagre, scarce, limited, destitute, hard up, scanty, poor<br>貧乏(びんぼう): poverty, destitute, poor</p> <p id='readingExamples'>乏しい (とぼ.しい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1301</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1216</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1301</p> <p id='keyword'>turf</p> <p id='kanji'>芝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88A9D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>turf, flowers, of, Zorro, building blocks, zig-zag</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flowers . . . building blocks.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Artificial turf made easy: flowers stuck on top of building blocks that you can place anywhere.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Zorro, with a flower between his teeth for the ladies, defends his turf against evildoers. And this...is for the lady."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しば</p> <p id='words'>芝(しば): lawn, sod, turf<br>芝居(しばい): play, drama<br>芝生(しばふ): lawn</p> <p id='readingExamples'>芝 (しば)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1302</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1217</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1302</p> <p id='keyword'>negative</p> <p id='kanji'>不</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B88D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>negative, one, ceiling, person, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>32</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You may play with the primitives of this kanji as you wish (<i>ceiling</i> . . . <i>person</i> . . . <i>a drop of</i>), <i>but</i> you will probably find that its simplicity, and its frequency, make it easy to remember just as it is.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>[Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer´s face, he says ""Negative"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>One below zero is a negative number.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>フ、ブ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>不意(ふい): sudden, abrupt, unexpected, unforeseen<br>不可欠(ふかけつ): indispensable, essential<br>不吉(ふきつ): ominous, sinister, bad luck, ill omen, 	"<p id='id'>1327</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1239</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1327</p> <p id='keyword'>No.</p> <p id='kanji'>第</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7ACAC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>no., bamboo, dollar, bow, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>33</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word <b>No.</b> is the abbreviation for ""number."" Its elements: <i>bamboo</i> . . . <i>dollar sign</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Bamboo bling is the newest Asian Rapper, No. 1 on the charts right now.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダイ、テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>第(だい): ordinal<br>第一(だいいち): first, foremost, # 1<br>次第(しだい): order, precedence, circumstances, immediate(ly), as soon as, dependent upon<br>落第(らくだい): failure, dropping out of a class</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"

""Why, my dog will even walk right into a trap if I tell him to. Watch!"" With a single word, ""go!"", his dog obediently runs into a snare trap hanging from the ceiling. Note that the first two strokes for <i>snare</i> doubles up with the first stroke for <i>two</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are dirty.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Washing your dirty snare in water, the extra line represents the water level as you submerge the snare.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>オ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>けが.す、けが.れる、けが.らわしい、よご.す、よご.れる、きたな.い</p> <p id='words'>汚す(けがす): to disgrace, to dishonour<br>汚らわしい(けがらわしい): filthy, unfair<br>汚れ(けがれ): uncleanness, impurity, disgrace<br>汚れる(けがれる): to get dirty, to become dirty<br>汚染(おせん): pollution, contamination<br>汚す(よごす): disgrace, dishonour, pollute, contaminate, soil, make dirty, stain<br>汚れる(よごれる): get dirty<br>汚い(きたない): dirty, unclean, filthy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>汚い (きたな.い), 汚す (けが.す), 汚らわしい (けが.らわしい), 汚れる (けが.れる), 汚す (よご.す), 汚れる (よご.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1335</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1246</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1335</p> <p id='keyword'>bestow</p> <p id='kanji'>与</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B88E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bestow, slingshot, catapult, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>33</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Slingshot</i> . . . <i>one</i>. Later we shall learn the character for <i>give</i> (Frame 2046), but even so, it is a good idea already at this point to distinguish this key word from <i>impart</i> (Frame 795) and <i>grant</i> (Frame 1131).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>David went to battle with a slingshot and it only took him one shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to bestow upon David the throne of all Israel.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, one of the first weapons bestowed on Link was the slingshot.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あた.える、あずか.る、くみ.する、ともに</p> <p id='words'>関与(かんよ): participation, taking part in, participating in, being concerned in<br>寄与(きよ): contribution, service<br>与党(よとう): government party, (ruling) party in power, government<br>与える(あたえる): give, to award<br>給与(きゅうよ): allowance, grant, supply</p> <p id='readingExamples'>与える (あた.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1336</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1247</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1336</p> <p id='keyword'>copy</p> <p id='kanji'>写</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58699.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>copy, crown, bestow, slingshot, catapult, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>33</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Crown . . . bestow.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A crown was bestowed to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>True fact: in the UK the right to print a copy of the KJV Bible is bestowed by the crown -- there are only a few authorised bible printers. (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Bible#Copyright_status).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ、ジャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うつ.す、うつ.る、うつ-、うつ.し</p> <p id='words'>写し(うつし): copy, duplicate, facsimile, transcript<br>映写(えいしゃ): projection<br>描写(びょうしゃ): depiction, description, portrayal<br>写る(うつる): be photographed, be projected<br>写生(しゃせい): sketch, drawing from nature, portrayal, description<br>複写(ふくしゃ): copy, duplicate<br>写す(うつす): copy, photograph<br>写真(しゃしん): photograph</p> <p id='readingExamples'>写す (うつ.す), 写る (うつ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1337</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1248</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1337</p> <p id='keyword'>somebody</p> <p id='kanji'>身</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BAAB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>somebody, nose</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word <b>somebody</b> was chosen to convey the double meaning of this kanji: body and person. Its composition is based on the <i>nose</i> (which, you will recall, is also the kanji for <i>oneself</i>). The extension of the bottom and far right strokes of that element, together with the unusual diagonal stroke, forms the pictograph of <b>somebody</b> with a prominent paunch.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than someone (#1256) is that the story is full of body descriptions.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Somebody was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>み</p> <p id='words'>受身(うけみ): passive, passive voice<br>身体(からだ): the body<br>中身(なかみ): contents, interior, substance, filling, (sword) blade<br>生身(なまみ): living flesh, flesh and blood, the quick<br>身近(みぢか): near oneself, close to one, familiar<br>身なり(みなり): personal appearance<br>身振り(みぶり): gesture<br>刺身(さしみ): sliced raw fish<br>自身(じしん): by oneself, personally<br>出身(しゅっしん): person´s place of origin, institution from which one graduated, director in charge of employee relations<br>心身(しんしん): mind and body<br>身体(しんたい): body, health<br>身長(しんちょう): height (of body), stature<br>全身(ぜんしん): the whole body, full-length (portrait)<br>独身(どくしん): bachelorhood, single, unmarried, celibate<br>身(み): body, main part, oneself, sword<br>身分(みぶん): social position, social status</p> <p id='readingExamples'>身 (み)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1338</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1249</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1338</p> <p id='keyword'>shoot</p> <p id='kanji'>射</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B084.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shoot, somebody, nose, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>""I <b>shot</b> an arrow into the air, And it landed I know not where"" goes the poem. (The poor poet obviously loses a lot of arrows.) This kanji, however, tells us where it did land. Its elements: <i>somebody</i> . . . <i>glued to</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You SHOOT SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The aim of shooting is to end up with a bullet stuck in someone´s body.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い.る、さ.す</p> <p id='words'>反射(はんしゃ): reflection, reverberation<br>放射(ほうしゃ): radiation, emission<br>放射能(ほうしゃのう): radioactivity<br>射す(さす): to shine, to strike<br>発射(はっしゃ): firing, shooting, discharge, catapult<br>陽射(ひざし): sunlight<br>注射(ちゅうしゃ): inject</p> <p id='readingExamples'>射る (い.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1339</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1250</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1339</p> <p id='keyword'>apologize</p> <p id='kanji'>謝</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AC9D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>apologize, say, words, keitai, mouth, shoot bang bang, somebody, nose, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . shoot.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Dick Cheney...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The famous speech by the man that Dick Cheney shot in the face: ""I´m sorry for the trouble I have caused the Vice President"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あやま.る</p> <p id='words'>月謝(げっしゃ): monthly tuition fee<br>謝絶(しゃぜつ): refusal<br>感謝(かんしゃ): thanks, gratitude<br>謝る(あやまる): apologize</p> <p id='readingExamples'>謝る (あやま.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1340</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1251</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1340</p> <p id='keyword'>old man</p> <p id='kanji'>老</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88081.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>old man, old man, soil, dirt, ground, spoon, sitting on the ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>First, do not confuse this character with <i>venerable old man</i> (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an <b>old man</b> begins with an abbreviation of the character for <i>somebody</i>, the <i>nose</i> having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the <i>soil</i> drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when ""dust to dust"" begins to take on a personal meaning; the diagonal <i>walking stick</i> for getting around; and the <i>spoon</i> for being spoon-fed.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the meaning is the same, but the final two strokes are omitted so that they can be replaced with other elements.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An old man, wondering what it´s like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Old man sits in the dirt, having a stroke.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ロウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.いる、ふ.ける</p> <p id='words'>老いる(おいる): to age, to grow old<br>老ける(ふける): to age<br>老衰(ろうすい): senility, senile decay<br>老人(ろうじん): the aged, old person</p> <p id='readingExamples'>老いる (お.いる), 老ける (ふ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1341</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1252</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1341</p> <p id='keyword'>consider</p> <p id='kanji'>考</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88083.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>consider, old man, slingshot, catapult</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Old man</i> . . . <i>slingshot</i>. Remember: you already have kanji for <i>discriminating</i> (Frame 521), <i>deliberation</i> (Frame 692), and <i>think</i> (Frame 651).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Even though he had the old man Mr. Wilson within the sights of his slingshot, Dennis the Menace considered what he was doing and stopped.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かんが.える、かんが.え</p> <p id='words'>考古学(こうこがく): archaeology<br>思考(しこう): thought<br>選考(せんこう): selection, screening<br>考え(かんがえ): thinking, thought, ideas, intention<br>考慮(こうりょ): consideration, taking into account<br>参考(さんこう): reference, consultation<br>考える(かんがえる): think</p> <p id='readingExamples'>考える (かんが.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1343</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1254</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1343</p> <p id='keyword'>teach</p> <p id='kanji'>教</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69599.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>teach, filial piety, old man, child, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Filial piety . . . taskmaster.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You could say that the taskmistress is teaching you filial piety when she whips you and asks, ""Who´s your daddy?!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おし.える、おそ.わる</p> <p id='words'>教え(おしえ): teachings, precept, lesson, doctrine<br>教員(きょういん): teaching staff<br>教科(きょうか): subject, curriculum<br>教訓(きょうくん): lesson, precept, moral instruction<br>教材(きょうざい): teaching materials<br>教習(きょうしゅう): training, instruction<br>教職(きょうしょく): teaching certificate, the teaching profession<br>宣教(せんきょう): religious mission<br>教わる(おそわる): be taught<br>教科書(きょうかしょ): text book<br>教師(きょうし): classroom teacher<br>教授(きょうじゅ): teaching, instruction, professor<br>教養(きょうよう): culture, education, refinement, cultivation<br>宗教(しゅうきょう): religion<br>助教授(じょきょうじゅ): assistant professor<br>教育(きょういく): education<br>教会(きょうかい): church<br>教える(おしえる): teach, inform, instruct<br>教室(きょうしつ): classroom</p> <p id='readingExamples'>教える (おし.える), 教わる (おそ.わる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1344</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1255</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1344</p> <p id='keyword'>torture</p> <p id='kanji'>拷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68BB7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>torture, finger, fingers, consider, old man, slingshot, catapult</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . consider.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In Torture 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. 	"<p id='id'>1345</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1256</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1345</p> <p id='keyword'>someone</p> <p id='kanji'>者</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88085.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Old man</i> . . . <i>sun</i>. This key word looks to be difficult because of its proximity to <i>somebody</i>. In fact, it is a very common kanji that will cause you no difficulty at all. Its meaning should be seen as the human referent for the abstract noun ""something.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive it means a <i>puppet</i>-on-a-string.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it´s 者 who can 忍 great 拷!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Back in the day, the old man used to be someone. His name was in the papers and all that. I use CHUCKY from the movie Child´s Play as my major alternate meaning for this primitive.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もの</p> <p id='words'>業者(ぎょうしゃ): trader, merchant<br>信者(しんじゃ): believer, adherent, devotee, Christian<br>達者(たっしゃ): skillful, in good health<br>読者(どくしゃ): reader<br>配偶者(はいぐうしゃ): spouse, wife, husband<br>悪者(わるもの): bad fellow, rascal, ruffian, scoundrel<br>学者(がくしゃ): scholar<br>患者(かんじゃ): a patient<br>記者(きしゃ): reporter<br>後者(こうしゃ): the latter<br>作者(さくしゃ): author<br>前者(ぜんしゃ): the former<br>著者(ちょしゃ): author, writer<br>筆者(ひっしゃ): writer, author<br>者(もの): person<br>役者(やくしゃ): actor, actress<br>歯医者(はいしゃ): dentist<br>医者(いしゃ): doctor (medical)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>者 (もの)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1346</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1257</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1346</p> <p id='keyword'>boil</p> <p id='kanji'>煮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E785AE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>boil, someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Puppet . . . oven fire.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use ""puppet."" So i thought of ""voodoo doll"" but then found ""love doll"" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There is a lesser known voodoo practice of boiling a puppet over an oven fire, to really make your victim feel the heat!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>に.る、-に、に.える、に.やす</p> <p id='words'>煮える(にえる): boil, cook, be cooked<br>煮る(にる): boil, cook</p> <p id='readingExamples'>煮える (に.える), 煮やす (に.やす), 煮る (に.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1350</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1260</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1350</p> <p id='keyword'>sultry</p> <p id='kanji'>暑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69A91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sultry, sun, day, someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun2, day2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'>hot</p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word refers to the heat of summer. Its elements: <i>sun</i> . . . <i>puppet</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ahh, a fine sultry day with my love doll under the hot sun. I think she´s getting a tan!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[from decamer0n] This is the kanji for atsui (暑い) as in hot. If you´ve ever been in Japan in the summer no doubt you have heard hoards of people bellowing ""Atsui! Atsui!"" Here you are laying with your love doll under the hot sun. Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow ""Atsui! It´s so sultry!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あつ.い</p> <p id='words'>蒸し暑い(むしあつい): humid, sultry<br>暑い(あつい): hot, warm</p> <p id='readingExamples'>暑い (あつ.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1351</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1261</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1351</p> <p id='keyword'>various</p> <p id='kanji'>諸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8ABB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>various, say, words, keitai, mouth, someone, puppet, sooty, old man, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Words</i> . . . <i>puppet</i>. 	"<p id='id'>1363</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1271</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1363</p> <p id='keyword'>bureaucrat</p> <p id='kanji'>官</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE98.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bureaucrat, house, maestro without baton</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>By replacing the <i>maestro</i>'s baton (the <i>drop</i>) with the roof of a <i>house</i>, we have his equivalent in the institutional world of big government: the <b>bureaucrat</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Bureaucrat, def: The maestro without a baton, the one who orchestrates oppressive rules, regulations and taxes on every household.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>官僚(かんりょう): bureaucrat, bureaucracy<br>器官(きかん): organ (of body), instrument<br>長官(ちょうかん): chief, (government) secretary<br>官庁(かんちょう): government office, authorities<br>警官(けいかん): policeman</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1366</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1274</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1366</p> <p id='keyword'>father</p> <p id='kanji'>父</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E788B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>father</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kindness and hard work of the ideal <b>father</b> is seen in this abbreviation of the <i>taskmaster</i> that leaves off his rod or whip (the first stroke) and replaces it with the sweat of the <b>father's</b> brow (the two <i>drops</i> at the top).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>フ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ちち</p> <p id='words'>お祖父さん(おじいさん): grandfather, male senior-citizen<br>伯父さん(おじさん): middle-aged gentleman, uncle<br>父母(ちちはは): father and mother, parents<br>小父さん(おじさん): middle-aged gentleman, uncle<br>父親(ちちおや): father<br>父母(ふぼ): father and mother, parents<br>祖父(そふ): grand father<br>叔父(おじ): uncle (younger than one´s parent)<br>お父さん(おとうさん): (polite) father</p> <p id='readingExamples'>父 (ちち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1368</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1275</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1368</p> <p id='keyword'>mingle</p> <p id='kanji'>交</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BAA4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mingle, top hat, father</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Top hat . . . father.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can´t give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Darth Vader tries to mingle with his troops. He even weares one of the helmets of the stromtroopers. (one of them laughs: white helmet, black suit. Darth Vader thereby slashes him in 2).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まじ.わる、まじ.える、ま.じる、まじ.る、ま.ざる、ま.ぜる、-か.う、か.わす、かわ.す、こもごも</p> <p id='words'>交わす(かわす): to exchange (messages), to dodge, to parry, to avoid, to turn aside<br>交易(こうえき): trade, commerce<br>交互(こうご): mutual, reciprocal, alternate<br>交渉(こうしょう): negotiations, discussions, connection<br>交付(こうふ): delivering, furnishing (with copies)<br>国交(こっこう): diplomatic relations<br>社交(しゃこう): social life, social intercourse<br>交ざる(まざる): to be mixed, to be blended with, to associate with, to mingle with, to join<br>交える(まじえる): to mix, to converse with, to cross (swords)<br>交じる(まじる): to be mixed, to be blended with, to associate with, to mingle with, to interest, to join<br>交わる(まじわる): to cross, to intersect, to associate with, to mingle with, to interest, to join<br>外交(がいこう): diplomacy<br>交換(こうかん): exchange, interchange, reciprocity, barter, substitution<br>交差(こうさ): cross<br>交際(こうさい): company, friendship, association, society, acquaintance<br>交差点(こうさてん): crossing, intersection<br>交替(こうたい): alternation, change, shift, relief, relay<br>交通機関(こうつうきかん): transportation facilities<br>交流(こうりゅう): alternating current, intercourse, (cultural) exchange, intermingling<br>交ぜる(まぜる): be mixed, be blended with<br>交通(こうつう): traffic<br>交番(こうばん): police box</p> <p id='readingExamples'>交う (か.う), 交わす (か.わす), 交ざる (ま.ざる), 交じる (ま.じる), 交ぜる (ま.ぜる), 交える (まじ.える), 交わる (まじ.わる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1369</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1276</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1369</p> <p id='keyword'>merit</p> <p id='kanji'>効</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58AB9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>merit, mingle, top hat, father, power, muscle, arnold</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Mingle</i> . . . <i>power</i>. Note the distinct connotations that separate <b>merit</b> from <i>achievement</i> (Frame 927).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There is great merit in mingling with the powerful.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>き.く、ききめ、なら.う</p> <p id='words'>効き目(ききめ): effect, virtue, efficacy, impression<br>効率(こうりつ): efficiency<br>無効(むこう): invalid, no effect, unavailable<br>効く(きく): be effective<br>効果(こうか): effect, effectiveness, efficacy, result<br>効力(こうりょく): effect, efficacy, validity, potency<br>有効(ゆうこう): validity, availability, effectiveness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>効く (き.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1370</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1277</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1370</p> <p id='keyword'>contrast</p> <p id='kanji'>較</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BC83.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>contrast, car, mingle, top hat, father</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cars . . . mingle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Our world of today, cars mingling on busy streets, is in stark contrast to the one of yesteryear, where it was people who would mingle on the streets.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク、コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くら.べる</p> <p id='words'>比較(ひかく): comparison<br>比較的(ひかくてき): comparatively, relatively</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1371</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1278</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1371</p> <p id='keyword'>exam (school)</p> <p id='kanji'>校</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A0A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>exam, tree, wood, mingle, top hat, father</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . mingle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>With the exam scores posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around looking at the results. test. 試.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note: this Kanji does not mean exam. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as school by itself is not used elsewhere. Examples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief); 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>校(こう): -school, proof<br>高等学校(こうとうがっこう): senior high school<br>転校(てんこう): change schools<br>登校(とうこう): attendance (at school)<br>母校(ぼこう): alma mater<br>校舎(こうしゃ): school building<br>校庭(こうてい): campus<br>高校(こうこう): high school<br>高校生(こうこうせい): high school student<br>校長(こうちょう): principal<br>小学校(しょうがっこう): primary school<br>中学校(ちゅうがっこう): junior high school<br>学校(がっこう): school</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1372</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1279</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1372</p> <p id='keyword'>leg</p> <p id='kanji'>足</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B6B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>leg, mouth, mending, mend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Mouth</i> . . . <i>mending</i>. Note that the last stroke of <i>mouth</i> and the first of <i>mending</i> overlap.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive on the left, it is amended to something similar to <i>correct</i> in place of <i>mending</i>. Its meaning remains <i>leg</i>, but should be thought of as a <i>wooden leg</i> in order to avoid confusion with other similar elements, namely <i>human legs</i>, <i>animal legs</i>, and <i>walking legs</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale´s mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I´ll use my mouth to mend your leg, I´ll kiss it all better :).</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あし、た.りる、た.る、た.す</p> <p id='words'>駆け足(かけあし): running fast, double time<br>足し算(たしざん): addition<br>裸足(はだし): barefoot<br>発足(はっそく): starting, inauguration<br>補足(ほそく): supplement, complement<br>物足りない(ものたりない): unsatisfied, unsatisfactory<br>足跡(あしあと): footprints<br>遠足(えんそく): trip, hike, picnic<br>足袋(たび): Japanese socks (with split toe)<br>足りる(たりる): be sufficient, be enough<br>足る(たる): be sufficient, be enough<br>不足(ふそく): insufficiency, shortage, deficiency, lack<br>満足(まんぞく): satisfaction<br>足す(たす): add<br>足(あし): foot, pace, gait, leg</p> <p id='readingExamples'>足 (あし), 足す (た.す), 足りる (た.りる), 足る (た.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"
