	"<p id='id'>1381</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1287</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1381</p> <p id='keyword'>step</p> <p id='kanji'>踏</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B88F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>step, wooden leg, mouth, stop, footprint, wednesday, boots, water, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The meaning of this character is virtually identical with that of the last frame. Be sure to come up with distinct connotations suggested by phrases in which each is commonly used. <i>Wooden leg</i> . . . <i>water</i> . . . <i>sun</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You have to watch your step when moving your leg on a watery day.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>So, we´ve walked on the moon, but it´s going to take a pirate with a wooden leg, with a huge supply of cooling water to land on the sun and take that ""one small step for a man"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふ.む、ふ.まえる</p> <p id='words'>踏まえる(ふまえる): to be based on, to have origin in<br>踏切(ふみきり): railway crossing, level crossing, starting line, scratch, crossover<br>踏む(ふむ): step on</p> <p id='readingExamples'>踏まえる (ふ.まえる), 踏む (ふ.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1383</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1288</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1383</p> <p id='keyword'>skeleton</p> <p id='kanji'>骨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9AAA8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>skeleton, joint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji and primitive refers to the <i>part of the body</i> composed of the bones and their joints. The top part of the kanji, terminating in the element for <i>crown</i>, is a pictograph of a bone joint. I leave it to you to put the pieces together, so to speak.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Your body meat is attached to the bone joints of your skeleton.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The top box 口 is the skull and the brain 田 has shriveled to the size of marble (but following kanji convention it is depicted as a square) and rolled into the bottom right hand corner. With all the hair and flesh gone the crown has slipped down to the shoulders like a necklace. 月 represents the rest of the body of the skeleton. [Idea for position of crown thanks to n1williams].</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほね</p> <p id='words'>骨(こつ): knack, skill<br>骨董品(こっとうひん): curio<br>露骨(ろこつ): frank, blunt, plain, outspoken, conspicuous, open, broad, suggestive<br>骨折(こっせつ): bone fracture<br>骨(ほね): bone</p> <p id='readingExamples'>骨 (ほね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1384</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1289</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1384</p> <p id='keyword'>slippery</p> <p id='kanji'>滑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BB91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>slippery, water, water droplets, water pistol, skeleton, joint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . skeleton.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Don´t give water to a skeleton. When he drinks it, it´ll sluice right through his bones, forcing you to put one of those ""Caution - Slippery Floor"" signs up on the resultant puddle.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Slippery surfaces are very dangerous for skeletons, since their bone feet slip easily... a few drops of water, and zweep! A large mess of bones to pick up and reassemble!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カツ、コツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すべ.る、なめ.らか</p> <p id='words'>円滑(えんかつ): harmony, smoothness<br>滑稽(こっけい): funny, humorous, comical, laughable, ridiculous, joking<br>滑る(すべる): to slide, to slip, to glide<br>滑らか(なめらか): smoothness, glassiness<br>滑れる(ずれる): slide, slip off</p> <p id='readingExamples'>滑る (すべ.る), 滑らか (なめ.らか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1385</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1290</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1385</p> <p id='keyword'>marrow</p> <p id='kanji'>髄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9AB84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>marrow, skeleton, joint, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, highwayman, possess, by one’s side, road, moon2, month2, flesh2, part of the body2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Skeleton . . . possess . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A skeleton is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he´s going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still possesses.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A skeleton by the side of the road, holding a sign ""Possess marrow, will travel"". 	"<p id='id'>1386</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1291</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1386</p> <p id='keyword'>calamity</p> <p id='kanji'>禍</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A68D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>calamity, altar, jawbone, joint, hood, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Altar . . . jawbone.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Continued from auspicious (#1088). Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. But if the gods are feeling particularly mischievous, they´ll send down a jawbone to the altar. The people see this as a sign of calamity to come. The gods think of it as an amusing prank.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Calamity Jane went to the altar to confess her sins and the priest´s jawbone fell to the floor...　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　か　禍福　かふく (fortune and misfortune)...　Pure Group: 渦1292　過1293.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わざわい</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1387</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1292</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1387</p> <p id='keyword'>whirlpool</p> <p id='kanji'>渦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B8A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>whirlpool, water, water droplets, water pistol, jawbone, joint, hood, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . jawbone.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Grampa´s flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A whirlpool is water opening its jaws to swallow anything whole.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うず</p> <p id='words'>渦(うず): swirl</p> <p id='readingExamples'>渦 (うず)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1390</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1294</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1390</p> <p id='keyword'>Heights</p> <p id='kanji'>阪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E998AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>heights, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, anti-, demonstration, cliff, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is used for proper names, much as the English word ""<b>Heights</b>"" is. Its primitives: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>anti-</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you´re scared of Heights, you don´t want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with ""mountain"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>People are being displaced in 大阪 to make room for a new development, Osaka Heights, the pinnacle of modern Japanese housing. An angry mob of protestors are outside with Anti-Osaka Heights signs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さか</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>阪 (さか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

Its composite elements are: <i>pinnacles</i> . . . <i>can</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Can you see Africa from The Pinnacle? I can! 	"<p id='id'>1397</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1300</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1397</p> <p id='keyword'>sunshine</p> <p id='kanji'>陽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E999BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sunshine, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, piggy bank, sun, day, piglets</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Different from the primitive for <i>sun</i> (which figures in the character) and the kanji for <i>ray</i> (Frame 125), the key word <b>sunshine</b> is meant to convey the meaning of the masculine principle in nature, or ""Yang."" (The dark is viewed mythically as the feminine principle; see frame 1718.) From there it comes to mean <i>sun</i> also. The elements are: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>piggy bank</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people´s eyes, far below.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Pinnacle is environmentally friendly. They collect solar power through sunshine on their piggybank shaped solar arrays.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひ</p> <p id='words'>太陽(たいよう): sun, solar<br>陽射(ひざし): sunlight<br>陽気(ようき): season, weather, cheerfulness</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1405</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1308</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1405</p> <p id='keyword'>descend</p> <p id='kanji'>降</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9998D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>descend, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, walking legs, sunglasses with one lens missing, monocle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Pinnacle</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i> . . . <i>sunglasses with a lens popped out</i>. Distinguish from <i>fall</i> (Frame 320) and <i>crash</i>, which we considered in the previous frame.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sunglasses-missing-one-lens is obviously the monocle. The proper, high-class way to descend The Pinnacle is wearing a monocle with your walking legs splayed to a full gentlemanly stride.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>After a cool, hip businessman angered the executives at The Pinnacle, they beat him up, popping out a lens from his sunglasses, and tossed out the window, head first, walking legs second. One executive later commented, ""It was like he was descending into Hell from Heaven!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>お.りる、お.ろす、ふ.る、ふ.り、くだ.る、くだ.す</p> <p id='words'>降ろす(おろす): to take down, to launch, to drop, to lower, to let (a person) off, to unload, to discharge<br>降水(こうすい): rainfall, precipitation<br>降伏(こうふく): capitulation, surrender, submission<br>以降(いこう): on and after, hereafter, thereafter<br>下降(かこう): downward, descent, fall, drop<br>降りる(おりる): get off, descend (e.g. a mountain)<br>降る(ふる): to precipitate, to fall (e.g. rain)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>降りる (お.りる), 降ろす (お.ろす), 降る (ふ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1406</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1309</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1406</p> <p id='keyword'>story</p> <p id='kanji'>階</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99A8E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>storey, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, all, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, white, dove, spoon2, sitting on the ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>story</b> of this character refers to floors in a building. The elements: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>all</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don´t have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Some stupid kid has pushed all the buttons in the elevator. As it stops at all storeys you reach a pinnacle of impatience. Finally you reach your storey, the last one, at the pinnacle of the building.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きざはし</p> <p id='words'>階(かい): -floor (counter), stories<br>階級(かいきゅう): class, rank, grade<br>階層(かいそう): class, level, stratum, hierarchy<br>段階(だんかい): gradation, grade, stage<br>階段(かいだん): stairs</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1407</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1310</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1407</p> <p id='keyword'>highness</p> <p id='kanji'>陛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9999B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>highness, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, soil, dirt, ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word indicates a title of address to royalty. Its elements: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>compare</i> . . . <i>ground</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Your highness is the pinnacle of finesse compared to all of us commoners who are but like dirt on the ground.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>His Highness, the main man at the Pinnacle, often compares those who live outside the city´s walls to dirt.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1408</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1311</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1408</p> <p id='keyword'>neighboring</p> <p id='kanji'>隣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99AA3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>neighbouring, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, shoeshine, rice, sunglasses, dancing legs, ballerina, evening</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pinnacle . . . rice . . . sunglasses.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>America thinks it is the pinnacle of the world, looking down on all neighboring countries through its mirrored, aviator sunglasses.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>All the neighboring communities to the Pinnacle have a major problem. The kids at the Pinnacle have a habit of throwing down rice from the city walls in all directions, so people in neighboring communities are forced to wear sunglasses all the time in order to avoid getting rice in their eyes.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とな.る、となり</p> <p id='words'>隣(となり): next to, next door to</p> <p id='readingExamples'>隣る (とな.る), 隣 (となり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1413</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1316</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1413</p> <p id='keyword'>hole</p> <p id='kanji'>穴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A9B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hole, house, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>House</i> . . . <i>eight</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji uses an alternate form: the primitive for <i>eight</i> is replaced with that for <i>human legs</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A black hole is a ""House of Infinity"". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways ""8"", but here we have a Japanese ""8"" instead.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Billiards anyone? House rules here state that the first person to pot the eight ball into the hole wins the game.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あな</p> <p id='words'>穴(あな): hole</p> <p id='readingExamples'>穴 (あな)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1414</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1317</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1414</p> <p id='keyword'>empty</p> <p id='kanji'>空</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A9BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>empty, hole, house, human legs, craft</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Hole . . . craft.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The craft of creating a black hole is in creating an emptiness which can attract things.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hole-craft is the way of making empty spaces, like the sky.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>クウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そら、あ.く、あ.き、あ.ける、から、す.く、す.かす、むな.しい</p> <p id='words'>空き(あき): room, time to spare, emptiness, vacant<br>空間(あきま): vacancy, room for rent or lease<br>空ろ(うつろ): blank, cavity, hollow, empty (space)<br>大空(おおぞら): heaven, firmament, the sky<br>空腹(くうふく): hunger<br>上空(じょうくう): sky, the skies, high-altitude sky, upper air<br>空く(すく): be less crowded, open, become open, become empty<br>空しい(むなしい): vacant, futile, vain, void, empty, ineffective, lifeless<br>架空(かくう): aerial, overhead, fiction, fanciful<br>空(から): emptiness<br>空っぽ(からっぽ): empty, vacant, hollow<br>空想(くうそう): daydream, fantasy, fancy, vision<br>空中(くうちゅう): sky, air<br>航空(こうくう): aviation, flying<br>真空(しんくう): vacuum, hollow, empty<br>空く(あく): become vacant<br>空気(くうき): air<br>空港(くうこう): air port<br>空(そら): sky</p> <p id='readingExamples'>空く (あ.く), 空ける (あ.ける), 空 (から), 空 (そら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1421</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1323</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1421</p> <p id='keyword'>depression</p> <p id='kanji'>窪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AAAA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>depression, hole, house, human legs, water, water droplets, water pistol, ivy, square jewel, soil, dirt, ground, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Hole</i> . . . <i>water</i> . . . <i>ivy</i>. The <b>depression</b> referred to here is a sunken place in the ground, rather than in one's spirits.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A depression is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The depression in the ground become a trap: the hole was filled with water and covered with ivy.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ワ、ア</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くぼ.む、くぼ.み、くぼ.まる、くぼ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1422</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1324</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1422</p> <p id='keyword'>squeeze</p> <p id='kanji'>搾</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E690BE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>squeeze, finger, fingers, tight, hole, house, human legs, saw</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . hole . . . saw.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You have trouble squeezing your hand through the hole so you use a saw to enlarge it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(Thanks DrJones) You squeeze the teats of the cow with your fingers but it´s your first try and you don´t have any milk come through the holes, so you take a saw and cut the teats to make bigger holes. Poor cow, this story squeezes my heart.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しぼ.る</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>搾る (しぼ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1423</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1325</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1423</p> <p id='keyword'>kiln</p> <p id='kanji'>窯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AAAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>kiln, hole, house, human legs, sheep, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'>oven</p> <p id='heisigStory'>Hole . . . sheep . . . oven fire.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Be sure to put a hole in that ceramic sheep before you put it over the fire. Otherwise, it´ll just explode in the kiln. (If you´ve never done ceramics before, it´s important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You put the sheep in the hole of the kiln and turn on the flames.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かま</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>窯 (かま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1425</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1327</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1425</p> <p id='keyword'>grope</p> <p id='kanji'>探</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68EA2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grope, finger, fingers, paper punch, Miss World, hole, house, human legs, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . paper punch . . . tree.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting groped by perverts on the train. The fingers of course, a crown (her too short skirt) and her legs below (which to be honest are pretty thick like tree trunks).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note: The combination ""crown +human legs"" appears seven times in Heisig. In four cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) the crown is above the human legs, and in the other three cases (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. The naming is inconsistent, so I call the first pattern ""Miss World"" (who is wearing a crown she won due to her attractive human legs) and the second ""garter"" (one human leg passes through the crown and wears it as a garter).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>タン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さぐ.る、さが.す</p> <p id='words'>探検(たんけん): exploration, expedition<br>探る(さぐる): search, look for, sound out<br>探す(さがす): search for, look for</p> <p id='readingExamples'>探す (さが.す), 探る (さぐ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1426</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1328</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1426</p> <p id='keyword'>deep</p> <p id='kanji'>深</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B7B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>deep, water, water droplets, water pistol, paper punch, Miss World, hole, house, human legs, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . paper punch . . . tree.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If the groper´s ""tree"" goes up the girl´s miniskirt too deep, he´ll ejaculate fluid. (Sorry it´s kinda coarse but it works.).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Thrown in deep water, the Japanese School girl tries to reach a floating tree to save herself.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふか.い、-ぶか.い、ふか.まる、ふか.める、み-</p> <p id='words'>情け深い(なさけぶかい): tender-hearted, compassionate<br>深める(ふかめる): to deepen, to heighten, to intensify<br>欲深い(よくふかい): greedy<br>深夜(しんや): late at night<br>深刻(しんこく): serious<br>深まる(ふかまる): deepen, heighten, intensify<br>深い(ふかい): deep</p> <p id='readingExamples'>深い (ふか.い), 深まる (ふか.まる), 深める (ふか.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1427</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1329</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1427</p> <p id='keyword'>hill</p> <p id='kanji'>丘</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B898.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hill, axe, one, floor</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Since this supposedly pictographic representation of a hill looks like anything but, picture a row of <i>axes</i> driven into the ground up to their heads, and see if that doesn't present a more memorable image of <b>hill</b> - at least a riskier one sliding down!</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the axe planted on top of a hill.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>At Capitol Hill proposals get axed on the floor.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おか</p> <p id='words'>丘陵(きゅうりょう): hill<br>丘(おか): hill</p> <p id='readingExamples'>丘 (おか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1428</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1330</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1428</p> <p id='keyword'>Point</p> <p id='kanji'>岳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B2B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>point, hill, axe, one, floor, mountain</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of the key word as referring to proper names of mountains, but do not confuse with <i>mountain pass</i> (Frame 835). The elements are: <i>hill</i> . . . <i>mountain</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A point is a extra little hill at the top of a mountain. We´ll call it ´Fireman´s Point´.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This actually means a high mountain. So, to cater to the keyword, it´s surely obvious (ahem) that if something gets such a fine title as Point, it must be more magnificent than the average mountain. It´s as if there was a hill on top of an average mountain, adding to its height.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たけ</p> <p id='words'>山岳(さんがく): mountains</p> <p id='readingExamples'>岳 (たけ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

We´re going to take that hill. You are no longer men with human legs. You are voracious animals, with animal legs! Got it? Animal legs! Now take that hill!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The hill is so steep that you almost have to have animal legs to walk on it. However, the soldiers have no problem because they´ve been trained to march there.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘイ、ヒョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つわもの</p> <p id='words'>兵器(へいき): arms, weapons, ordinance<br>兵士(へいし): soldier<br>兵隊(へいたい): soldier, sailor</p> <p id='readingExamples'>兵器 (へいき), 兵隊 (へいたい), 撤兵 (てっぺい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1431</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1333</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1431</p> <p id='keyword'>thread</p> <p id='kanji'>糸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B3B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>thread, spiderman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Remember when your granny used to ask you to bend your arms at the <i>elbows</i> and hold them out so that she could use them like a rack to hold a skein of string or yarn (here <b>thread</b>) while she rolled it up into a <i>little</i> ball? Now can you see the two <i>elbows</i> (with the second stroke doubling up) at the top, and the character for <i>little</i> below?</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I´ve opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as dainty (#1363) and accumulate (#1364).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You´ll be seeing this one a lot. Seriously.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いと</p> <p id='words'>毛糸(けいと): knitting wool<br>糸(いと): thread</p> <p id='readingExamples'>糸 (いと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_1</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1435</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1337</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1435</p> <p id='keyword'>luxuriant</p> <p id='kanji'>繁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B981.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>luxuriant, cleverness, reclining, lying down, mother, breasts, taskmaster, thread, spiderman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cleverness . . . thread.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When Venom realized he couldn´t beat Spider-Man in a fair fight, he showed his cleverness by spraying venom all over Spider-Man´s luxuriant garden.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Venom is covered in a luxuriant and surprisingly clever symbiotic suit, but it´s also the taskmaster for his every evil act.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しげ.る、しげ.く</p> <p id='words'>繁栄(はんえい): prospering, prosperity, thriving, flourishing<br>繁盛(はんじょう): prosperity, flourishing, thriving<br>繁殖(はんしょく): breed, multiply, increase, propagation<br>頻繁(ひんぱん): frequency</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1438</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1339</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1438</p> <p id='keyword'>line</p> <p id='kanji'>線</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B79A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'>train line</p> <p id='constituent'>line, thread, spiderman, spring, white, dove, water</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . spring.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji is used for train lines. Spiderman does a hot spring tour of Japan using the train lines. You can see the Spidey costume hanging on the washing line as he enjoys the onsen.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Japan´s train lines are like threads that spring from Tokyo station.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すじ</p> <p id='words'>沿線(えんせん): along railway line<br>幹線(かんせん): main line, trunk line<br>三味線(さみせん): three-stringed Japanese guitar, shamisen<br>点線(てんせん): dotted line, perforated line<br>電線(でんせん): electric line<br>無線(むせん): wireless, radio<br>下線(かせん): underline<br>曲線(きょくせん): curve<br>光線(こうせん): beam, light ray<br>新幹線(しんかんせん): bullet train<br>水平線(すいへいせん): horizon<br>線路(せんろ): line, track, roadbed<br>脱線(だっせん): derailment, digression<br>地平線(ちへいせん): horizon<br>直線(ちょくせん): straight line<br>内線(ないせん): phone extension, indoor wiring, inner line<br>線(せん): line</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1440</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1340</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1440</p> <p id='keyword'>tighten</p> <p id='kanji'>締</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B7A0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tighten, thread, spiderman, sovereign, vase, stand up, apron, crown, towel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . sovereign.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The sovereign appears to be ruling, but in reality someone behind him (for instance his wife) has a thread around his throat, and if he dares to make a decision she doesn´t like, she starts pulling the thread and tightens it around his throat.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(astridtops) Spiderman managed to get behind the sovereign. (pick your favourite nowadays country ruler who isn´t doing a good job). Spidey has tightend a web around the sovereing´s throat. As long as the sovereign says what spidey whispers, he will be fine. Sovereign yelping : ´ we will draw are troops back! and we will spend more money on healthcare, schools and less on wars!´ Spidey whispering: ´ If you continue at this pace, you might be doing good things AND the people will like you.´.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>し.まる、し.まり、し.める、-し.め、-じ.め</p> <p id='words'>締め切り(しめきり): closing, cut-off, end, deadline, Closed, No Entrance<br>戸締り(とじまり): closing up, fastening the doors<br>取り締まり(とりしまり): control, management, supervision<br>取り締まる(とりしまる): to manage, to control, to supervise<br>締切(しめきり): closing, cut-off, end, deadline, Closed, No Entrance<br>締め切る(しめきる): shut up<br>締める(しめる): to tie, fasten</p> <p id='readingExamples'>締まる (し.まる), 締める (し.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1451</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1351</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1451</p> <p id='keyword'>tie</p> <p id='kanji'>結</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B590.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tie, thread, spiderman, aerosol, samurai, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . aerosol can.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ok, here, you have to think of the phrase ""TIE the knot"" , which means a wedding (this kanji is used in the marriage compound 結婚 けっこん ). Now, at US weddings, it ends with the couple driving away with cans being dragged behind the car. So here, think of SPIDERMAN, who will TIE the knot with Mary Jane. At his wedding, Spider THREAD attached (or TIED) to SPRAYCANS are being drug behind the limo as they drive off.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Spiderman and a fan have a competition to see who can tie up the most enemies fastest. Spidey´s using his webs and the fan is using an aerosol can of silly string. So far they are tied.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケツ、ケチ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>むす.ぶ、ゆ.う、ゆ.わえる</p> <p id='words'>結核(けっかく): tuberculosis, tubercule<br>結合(けつごう): combination, union<br>結晶(けっしょう): crystal, crystallization<br>結成(けっせい): formation<br>結束(けっそく): union, unity<br>妥結(だけつ): agreement<br>団結(だんけつ): unity, union, combination<br>結び(むすび): ending, conclusion, union<br>結び付き(むすびつき): connection, relation<br>結び付く(むすびつく): to be connected or related, to join together<br>結び付ける(むすびつける): to combine, to join, to tie on, to attach with a knot<br>結果(けっか): result, consequence<br>結局(けっきょく): after all, eventually<br>結論(けつろん): reason, sum up, conclude<br>結ぶ(むすぶ): tie, bind, link<br>結構(けっこう): splendid, nice, wonderful, delicious, sweet, construction, architecture, well enough, tolerably<br>結婚(けっこん): marriage</p> <p id='readingExamples'>結ぶ (むす.ぶ), 結う (ゆ.う), 結わえる (ゆ.わえる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1453</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1353</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1453</p> <p id='keyword'>class</p> <p id='kanji'>級</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B49A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>class, thread, spiderman, reach out, outstretched hands</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Threads . . . outstretched hands.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a ""class of students"" or ""classroom,"" but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend´s answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>We can almost see the outstreched hands of the lower classes wearing just a few threads in this kanji.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>階級(かいきゅう): class, rank, grade<br>等級(とうきゅう): grade, class<br>同級(どうきゅう): the same grade, same class<br>学級(がっきゅう): grade in school<br>級(きゅう): class, grade, rank<br>高級(こうきゅう): high class, high grade<br>上級(じょうきゅう): advanced level, high grade, senior<br>初級(しょきゅう): elementary level</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1454</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1354</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1454</p> <p id='keyword'>chronicle</p> <p id='kanji'>紀</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B480.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>chronicle, thread, spiderman, snake, self</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . snake.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In a CHRONICLE the THREAD of the story can twist and turn like a SNAKE.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Worst fan fiction ever....SPIDERMAN joins the CHRONICLES of narnia to battle a big SNAKE!!</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>世紀(せいき): century, era</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1455</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1355</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1455</p> <p id='keyword'>crimson</p> <p id='kanji'>紅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B485.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crimson, thread, spiderman, craft</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . craft.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>After Spider-Man is whacked in the head with a I-beam, crimson blood flows from the wound.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A person's first piece of thread craft is often stained crimson due to bleeding from the needle wounds sustained in the process.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、ク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>べに、くれない、あか.い</p> <p id='words'>口紅(くちべに): lipstick<br>紅茶(こうちゃ): black tea<br>紅葉(こうよう): autumn colours<br>紅葉(もみじ): autumn colours, (Japanese) maple</p> <p id='readingExamples'>紅白 (こうはく), 紅茶 (こうちゃ), 紅葉 (こうよう), 紅 (くれない), 紅 (べに)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1462</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1362</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1462</p> <p id='keyword'>promise</p> <p id='kanji'>約</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B484.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>promise, thread, spiderman, ladle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Consider for a moment the etymology of the word ""<b>promise</b>"" in order to notice its roots in the activity of putting one thing (e.g., one's word of honor) in place of another (e.g., the fulfillment of a task). For as it turns out, this character also means ""to abridge, economize, and abbreviate"" - all activities that involve putting one thing in place of another. With that in mind, we may now work with the elements: <i>thread</i> . . . <i>ladle</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>He tied a thread around the ladle as a reminder of his promise to do more house work.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Spiderman promised to get Aunt Mae´s ladle back. He started to do a blood oath by spilling drops of blood but Aunt Mae stopped him and bound up the wound. ""It´s only a ladle Peter"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヤク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>規約(きやく): agreement, rules, code<br>倹約(けんやく): thrift, economy, frugality<br>条約(じょうやく): treaty, pact<br>制約(せいやく): limitation, restriction, condition, constraints<br>契約(けいやく): contract, compact, agreement<br>婚約(こんやく): engagement, betrothal<br>節約(せつやく): economising, saving<br>約(やく): approximately, about, some<br>約束(やくそく): promise<br>予約(よやく): reservation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1470</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1370</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1470</p> <p id='keyword'>inherit</p> <p id='kanji'>継</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B699.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inherit, thread, spiderman, rice, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Thread</i> . . . <i>rice</i> . . . <i>fishhook</i>. (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Spider-Man is hooked on rice--it´s all he inherited from his Uncle Ben. (thanks Nukemarine).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つ.ぐ、まま-</p> <p id='words'>跡継ぎ(あとつぎ): heir, successor<br>受け継ぐ(うけつぐ): to inherit, to succeed, to take over<br>中継(ちゅうけい): relay, hook-up<br>継ぎ目(つぎめ): a joint, joining point<br>継ぐ(つぐ): to succeed<br>継続(けいぞく): continuation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>継ぐ (つ.ぐ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in waterfall (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as ""eels"". It is much better to call the right half of this character an ""unbound tortoise"".).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When Spiderman fights the giant tortoise, he grabs a straw rope from the edges of the sumo ring and swings it at his head. 	"<p id='id'>1481</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1381</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1481</p> <p id='keyword'>how many</p> <p id='kanji'>幾</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B9BE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>how many, cocoon, person, fiesta, cocoon2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Two cocoons</i> . . . <i>person</i> . . . <i>fiesta</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji will mean an <i>abacus</i>, the bead-instrument used in the Orient to calculate <i>how many</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It is a little awkward when you are at a fiesta and the host serves some rare delicacy, like moth cocoons, the guests must decide how many it would be polite to eat. You do the math in your head and it comes out to two cocoons per person. This is why the horizontal line is a fraction bar with two cocoons on the top, and one person the bottom.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>How many went to the party? Two aliens and one person (I feel sorry for that person).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いく-、いく.つ、いく.ら</p> <p id='words'>幾多(いくた): many, numerous<br>幾つ(いくつ): how many?, how old?<br>幾分(いくぶん): somewhat<br>幾ら(いくら): how much?, how many?</p> <p id='readingExamples'>幾 (いく)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1482</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1382</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1482</p> <p id='keyword'>mechanism</p> <p id='kanji'>機</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A99F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mechanism, tree, wood, abacus, how many, cocoon, person, fiesta, cocoon2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . abacus.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many ´anythings´.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To avoid confusing with contraption (#677), focus on the ""ism"" of mechanism. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish; mechanism here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable tree (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching abacus that smashes enemies between its giant beads.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はた</p> <p id='words'>危機(きき): crisis<br>機構(きこう): mechanism, organization<br>契機(けいき): opportunity, chance<br>動機(どうき): motive, incentive<br>機(はた): loom<br>有機(ゆうき): organic<div>&nbsp;<br>機械(きかい): machine, mechanism<br>機関(きかん): organ, mechanism, facility, engine<br>機関車(きかんしゃ): locomotive, engine<br>機嫌(きげん): humour, temper, mood<br>機能(きのう): function, faculty<br>交通機関(こうつうきかん): transportation facilities<br>ジェット機(ジェットき): jet airplane<br>扇風機(せんぷうき): electric fan<br>機会(きかい): opportunity, chance<br>飛行機(ひこうき): airplane</div></p> <p id='readingExamples'>機 (はた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

The Japanese amass a fortune pampering livestock feeding them flowers, offering beer, playing music and giving them massages… RTK2:　チク　蓄電池　ちくでんち(battery cell)…　Pure Group:　畜1384.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たくわ.える</p> <p id='words'>蓄積(ちくせき): accumulation, accumulate, store<br>貯蓄(ちょちく): savings<br>蓄える(たくわえる): to store</p> <p id='readingExamples'>蓄える (たくわ.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1487</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1386</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1487</p> <p id='keyword'>bowstring</p> <p id='kanji'>弦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BCA6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bowstring, bow, mysterious, top hat, cocoon</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bow . . . mysterious.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A magic bow that only Gandalf can yield: there is no bowstring on it, and he uses his magic to fire arrows.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A bow with a mysterious invisible bowstring.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つる</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>弦 (つる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1488</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1387</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1488</p> <p id='keyword'>hug</p> <p id='kanji'>擁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69381.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hug, finger, fingers, mysterious, top hat, cocoon, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Fingers</i> . . . <i>mysterious</i> . . . <i>turkey</i>. Note that the <i>top hat</i> is extended across both elements, though it belongs only to the <i>cocoon</i>. This means that you may either use <i>mysterious</i>&nbsp;- as we did here - or take the three elements separately.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A mysterious turkey with human fingers wants to hug me... I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine Gandalf hugging a turkey....ouch! It bit off his finger!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1489</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1388</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1489</p> <p id='keyword'>nourishing</p> <p id='kanji'>滋</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BB8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>nourishing, water, water droplets, water pistol, double-mysterious, mothballs, horns, one, cocoon, cocoon2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Water</i> . . . double-<i>mysterious</i>. Note the doubling up of the element for <i>top hat</i> in the primitive for <i>mysterious</i> and assign it a special image, as it will come up in the next two frames.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Water is doubly mysterious. It´s in all our nourishment...and yet, it´s really not nourishing at all.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Going off the idea of the right side meaning rapid growth/increase of small objects, I´ve decided to make the right side be Gremlins, those little mysterious creatures that double rapidly. Gremlins find water a little too nourishing, as it makes them instantly multiply.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1491</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1390</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1491</p> <p id='keyword'>magnet</p> <p id='kanji'>磁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A381.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>magnet, stone, rock, double-mysterious, mothballs, horns, one, cocoon, cocoon2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Stone</i> . . . double-<i>mysterious</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A magnet is a rock with two sides; one that mysteriously pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. 	"<p id='id'>1492</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1391</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1492</p> <p id='keyword'>lineage</p> <p id='kanji'>系</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B3BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lineage, stick, drop, thread, spiderman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The single stroke added to the beginning of the primitive for <i>thread</i> gives the image of threads woven into a single cord. Hence the meaning, <b>lineage</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we shall give this kanji the meaning of <i>yarn</i>, as the uniting of many threads into a single strand is most obvious with <i>yarn</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A single drop of your blood holds the proof of the unbroken thread of your lineage.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Spiderman´s lineage (who his family is etc...) can be found in his DNA in a drop of blood. The villain that gets blood of Spidey will be able to find out who is family and lineage is. be carfefull spidey...</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>系(けい): system, lineage, group<br>系統(けいとう): system, family line, lineage, ancestry, geological formation<br>体系(たいけい): system, organization</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1493</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1392</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1493</p> <p id='keyword'>person in charge</p> <p id='kanji'>係</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BF82.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>person in charge, person, lineage, drop, thread, spiderman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . yarn.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mister T gets a DNA test, and discovers that he was meant to be the person in charge after all.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The person in charge usually must come from a long standing lineage of persons in charge.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かか.る、かかり、-がかり、かか.わる</p> <p id='words'>係り(かかり): official, duty, person in charge<br>係わる(かかわる): concern oneself in, have to do with, affect, influence<br>関係(かんけい): relationship</p> <p id='readingExamples'>係る (かか.る), 係 (かかり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"

The supporting cables of the bridge actually look like DNA double-helices. That's Japan for you!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン、ケ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.ける、か.かる</p> <p id='words'>懸賞(けんしょう): offering prizes, winning, reward<br>一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい): as well as one can, as hard as one can</p> <p id='readingExamples'>懸垂 (けんすい), 懸賞 (けんしょう), 懸命 (けんめい), 懸かる (か.かる), 懸ける (か.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1498</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1396</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1498</p> <p id='keyword'>shins</p> <p id='kanji'>脚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8849A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>skids, shins, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, instead, gone, soil, dirt, ground, elbow, stamp</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Part of the body</i> . . . <i>instead</i>. This character has more or less the same meaning as that for <i>leg</i> learned back in frame 1372. It can also indicate the part of the legs from the <b>shins</b> down, which explains the choice of the key word.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Shins are the part of the body that one uses instead of one´s eyes, for finding furniture in the dark. (Ouch!).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Shins are the part of the body that Japanese traditionally sit on instead of their asses.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キャク、キャ、カク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あし</p> <p id='words'>脚色(きゃくしょく): dramatization (e.g. film)<br>脚本(きゃくほん): scenario</p> <p id='readingExamples'>脚部 (きゃくぶ), 脚本 (きゃくほん), 三脚 (さんきゃく), 脚 (あし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1499</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1397</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1499</p> <p id='keyword'>wholesale</p> <p id='kanji'>卸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58DB8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wholesale, horseshoe, horse, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse, stop, footprint, stamp</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The left primitive is a union of <i>a horse</i> and <i>footprint</i>. To the right, the <i>stamp</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Wholesale refers to the sale of goods in quantity to retailers for resale. When this kanji was invented, large loads of goods needed to be transported by horses who left steep footprints because of the weight they carried. The wholesale goods needed a special stamp to indicate that they were legal for resale.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you need horseshoes (shoes that fit your horse´s footprint), buy them at the wholesale shop. They lick and paste stamps in your membership card so you can get free merchandise later.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おろ.す、おろし、おろ.し</p> <p id='words'>卸す(おろす): sell wholesale, grated (vegetables)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>卸す (おろ.す), 卸 (おろし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1500</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1398</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1500</p> <p id='keyword'>honorable</p> <p id='kanji'>御</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BEA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>honorable, Nelson, column, going, line, wholesale, horseshoe, pantomime horse, noon, sign of the horse, stop, footprint, stamp</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Line . . . wholesale.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An honorable man will not try to cut in front of the line at the wholesale stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If a trader has an honorable reputation- then people will line up to buy his wholesale goods.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギョ、ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おん-、お-、み-</p> <p id='words'>御負け(おまけ): a discount, a prize, something additional, bonus, an extra, an exaggeration<br>御(ご): go-, honourable<br>御馳走(ごちそう): feast, treating (someone)<br>御免ください(ごめんください): May I come in?<br>御免なさい(ごめんなさい): I beg your pardon, excuse me<br>御覧なさい(ごらんなさい): (please) look, (please) try to do<br>御(お): honorific prefix<br>御辞儀(おじぎ): bow<br>御中(おんちゅう): and Company, Messrs.<br>御免(ごめん): your pardon, declining (something), dismissal, permission<br>御覧(ごらん): look, inspection, try<br>朝御飯(あさごはん): breakfast<br>御主人(ごしゅじん): (polite) your husband, her husband<br>御飯(ごはん): rice (cooked), meal<br>晩御飯(ばんごはん): dinner, evening meal<br>昼御飯(ひるごはん): lunch, midday meal</p> <p id='readingExamples'>御者 (ぎょしゃ), 制御 (せいぎょ), 御 (おん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1501</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1399</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1501</p> <p id='keyword'>clothing</p> <p id='kanji'>服</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69C8D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>clothing, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, underpants, stamp, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Flesh</i> . . . <i>stamp</i> . . . <i>crotch</i>. Note how the <i>stamp</i> is stretched out here.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s customary to cover the flesh with clothing, but some designs are so outrageous they´re not bigger than a stamp that just covers your crotch.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Modern clothing shows a lot of flesh -- some is practically no more than a postage stamp covering your crotch!</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>フク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>軍服(ぐんぷく): military or naval uniform<br>征服(せいふく): conquest, subjugation, overcoming<br>制服(せいふく): uniform<br>不服(ふふく): dissatisfaction, discontent, disapproval, objection, complaint, protest, disagreement<br>衣服(いふく): clothes<br>克服(こくふく): subjugation, conquest<br>服装(ふくそう): garments<br>和服(わふく): Japanese clothes<br>服(ふく): clothes<br>洋服(ようふく): Western-style clothes</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1502</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1400</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1502</p> <p id='keyword'>fate</p> <p id='kanji'>命</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E591BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fate, fit, meeting, umbrella, one, mouth, stamp</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character connotes life in general, but also the particular life that is <b>fated</b> one by virtue of the distinctive character with which one is born. Its elements are: <i>fit</i> . . . <i>stamp</i>. The bottom portion of <i>fit</i> is nudged to the left in order to make room for the <i>stamp</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you´re born, your fate is measured, fitted, and stamped onto your soul. Good luck defying it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Your ability to resist FATE can be fit on a postage stamp.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>メイ、ミョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いのち</p> <p id='words'>運命(うんめい): fate<br>革命(かくめい): revolution<br>使命(しめい): mission, errand, message<br>宿命(しゅくめい): fate, destiny, predestination<br>任命(にんめい): appointment, nomination, ordination, commission, designation<br>命中(めいちゅう): a hit<br>命(いのち): (mortal) life<br>寿命(じゅみょう): life span<br>人命(じんめい): (human) life<br>生命(せいめい): life, existence<br>命じる(めいじる): to order, command, appoint<br>命ずる(めいずる): to command, appoint<br>命令(めいれい): order, command, decree, directive, (software) instruction<br>一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい): as well as one can, as hard as one can</p> <p id='readingExamples'>命令 (めいれい), 運命 (うんめい), 生命 (せいめい), 命 (いのち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1503</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1401</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1503</p> <p id='keyword'>orders</p> <p id='kanji'>令</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BBA4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Meeting . . . chop-seal.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>(re: dingomick) ""These are your orders,"" declares the general while passing out documents at the meeting. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims ""Oh wait! I need to certify these orders!"" and went around stamping each paper with his personal chop-seal.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>These are your orders, declares the general at the meeting as he stamps them with his chop-seal. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one´s they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>レイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>指令(しれい): orders, instructions, directive<br>仮令(たとえ): example, even if, if, though, although<br>命令(めいれい): order, command, decree, directive, (software) instruction</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1504</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1402</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1504</p> <p id='keyword'>zero</p> <p id='kanji'>零</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99BB6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>zero, rain, weather, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rain . . . orders.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Despite the rain, the zero pilot flies on. He has kamikaze orders.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>レイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ぜろ、こぼ.す、こぼ.れる</p> <p id='words'>零す(こぼす): to spill<br>零れる(こぼれる): to overflow, to spill<br>零点(れいてん): zero, no marks<br>零(れい): zero, nought</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1505</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1403</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1505</p> <p id='keyword'>age</p> <p id='kanji'>齢</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9BDA2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>age, teeth, tooth, stop, footprint, rice, shovel, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is used to express the years of one's <b>age</b>. Its elements: <i>teeth</i> . . . <i>orders</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You know you are fast approaching a ripe old AGE when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This has the nuance of a life milestone. Here it's represented by the life-cycle of teeth: In childhood, your teeth give the orders, growing whenever they want. As a teenager, we give orders to the teeth, by putting braces on them. In old age, we order new teeth!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>レイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よわ.い、とし</p> <p id='words'>年齢(ねんれい): age, years</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1506</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1404</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1506</p> <p id='keyword'>cool</p> <p id='kanji'>冷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E586B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cool, ice, orders, meeting, chop-seal, hanko</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ice . . . orders.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To keep your water cool, just order some ice.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Japanese boss gives an order at the meeting: eat ice to stay cool (since they won´t be running the air conditioning anymore).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>レイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つめ.たい、ひ.える、ひ.や、ひ.ややか、ひ.やす、ひ.やかす、さ.める、さ.ます</p> <p id='words'>冷やかす(ひやかす): to banter, to make fun of, to jeer at, to cool, to refrigerate<br>冷酷(れいこく): cruelty, coldheartedness, relentless, ruthless<br>冷蔵(れいぞう): cold storage, refrigeration<br>冷淡(れいたん): coolness, indifference<br>冷ます(さます): cool, dampen, let cool, throw a damper on, spoil<br>冷める(さめる): become cool, wear off, abate, subside, dampen<br>冷やす(ひやす): cool, refrigerate<br>冷静(れいせい): calm, composure, coolness, serenity<br>冷凍(れいとう): freezing, cold storage, refrigeration<br>冷房(れいぼう): cooling, air-conditioning<br>冷える(ひえる): get cold<br>冷たい(つめたい): cold (to the touch), chilly, icy, freezing, coldhearted<br>冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ): refrigerator</p> <p id='readingExamples'>冷ます (さ.ます), 冷める (さ.める), 冷たい (つめ.たい), 冷える (ひ.える), 冷や (ひ.や), 冷やかす (ひ.やかす), 冷やす (ひ.やす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1509</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1407</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1509</p> <p id='keyword'>courage</p> <p id='kanji'>勇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58B87.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>courage, chop-seal, hanko, male, rice field, brains, power, muscle, arnold</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Chop-seal . . . man.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young man has to show his courage. They then receive a chopseal which is a mark of their courage.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Re: fuaburisu - The initiation rite in question is actually a reverse elbow chop to the brain, and you receive the chop seal if you have the power to withstand it. This initial imagery helps me with the altered chop seal and vertical placement.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いさ.む</p> <p id='words'>勇敢(ゆうかん): bravery, heroism, gallantry<br>勇ましい(いさましい): brave, valiant, gallant, courageous<br>勇気(ゆうき): courage, bravery, valour, nerve, boldness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>勇む (いさ.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1511</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1408</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1511</p> <p id='keyword'>traffic</p> <p id='kanji'>通</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9809A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>traffic, pogo stick, chop-seal, hanko, utilise, utilize, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Chop-seal</i> . . . <i>utilize</i> . . . <i>road</i>. By combining the first two primitives into a single image, you will be able to use that image in a few instances later, one of which comes immediately.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). [Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Building on gorgon´s story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the traffic. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge chopseal that they utilize to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the road.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ツウ、ツ</p> <p (money), accommodation, adaptability, versatility, finance<br>流通(りゅうつう): circulation of money or goods, flow of water or air, distribution<br>大通り(おおどおり): main street<br>開通(かいつう): opening, open<br>共通(きょうつう): commonness, community<br>交通機関(こうつうきかん): transportation facilities<br>透き通る(すきとおる): be or become transparent<br>直通(ちょくつう): direct communication<br>通過(つうか): passage through, passing<br>通貨(つうか): currency<br>通学(つうがく): commuting to school<br>通勤(つうきん): commuting to work<br>通行(つうこう): passage, passing<br>通じる(つうじる): run to, lead to, communicate, understand, be well-informed<br>通信(つうしん): correspondence, communication, news, signal<br>通ずる(つうずる): run to, lead to, communicate, understand, be well-informed<br>通知(つうち): notice, notification<br>通帳(つうちょう): passbook<br>通訳(つうやく): interpretation<br>通用(つうよう): popular use, circulation<br>通路(つうろ): passage, pathway<br>通す(とおす): let pass, overlook, continue, keep, make way for, persist in<br>通り掛かる(とおりかかる): You must then hanko (seal) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the zoo. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I doubt they’ll let you in).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うたが.う</p> <p id='words'>疑惑(ぎわく): doubt, misgivings, distrust, suspicion<br>質疑(しつぎ): question<br>疑う(うたがう): doubt, distrust, be suspicious of, suspect<br>疑問(ぎもん): question, problem, doubt, guess</p> <p id='readingExamples'>疑う (うたが.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1517</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1414</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1517</p> <p id='keyword'>crime</p> <p id='kanji'>犯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78AAF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crime, pack of wild dogs, fingerprint</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Wild dogs . . . fingerprint.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Crimes can often be solved using the tools of dogs and fingerprints.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This crime gang has yet to be caught because their pack of wild dogs takes care of licking off the fingerprints from all the crime scenes.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン、ボン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おか.す</p> <p id='words'>犯す(おかす): to commit, to perpetrate, to violate, to rape<br>犯罪(はんざい): crime<br>犯人(はんにん): offender, criminal<br>防犯(ぼうはん): prevention of crime</p> <p id='readingExamples'>犯す (おか.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1519</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1415</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1519</p> <p id='keyword'>unlucky</p> <p id='kanji'>厄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58E84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>unlucky, cliff, fingerprint</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cliff . . . fingerprint.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Sherlock Holmes is very unlucky: he just fell off a cliff while he was looking around for fingerprints.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヤク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>厄介(やっかい): trouble, burden, care, bother, worry, dependence, support, kindness, obligation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1526</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1422</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1526</p> <p id='keyword'>egg</p> <p id='kanji'>卵</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58DB5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>egg, sign of the hare, receipt, stamp, drops</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Receipt</i> . . . <i>stamp</i> . . . and <i>a drop</i> in each side to represent a little smear of <b>egg</b> yoke. The third stroke is drawn slightly higher to close the <b>egg</b> up tightly and keep the yoke inside.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The Easter Bunny dropped an egg on my desk and got yolk all over my receipts and stamps.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The 卯sign of the hare (#2041) hides eggs in his ears for Easter...　RTK2:　ラン　卵巣　らんそう(ovary).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ラン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たまご</p> <p id='words'>卵(たまご): egg(s), spawn, roe, (an expert) in the making</p> <p id='readingExamples'>卵 (たまご)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1527</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1423</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1527</p> <p id='keyword'>detain</p> <p id='kanji'>留</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79599.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>detain, receipt, sword, dagger, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Receipt . . . dagger . . . rice field.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The use of RANSOM NOTE (think of a receipt with a dagger through it on a door) works great with DETAIN. Here the RANSOM NOTE says that the girl has been DETAINED in an undisclosed location. To get her back take the RANSOM to a empty FIELD.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Got a receipt for that dagger, son? If not, we´re going to detain you and send you to work in the rice fields.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>リュウ、ル</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.める、と.まる、とど.める、とど.まる、るうぶる</p> <p id='words'>加留多(かるた): (pt:) (n) playing cards (pt: carta)<br>蒸留(じょうりゅう): distillation<br>留める(とどめる): to stop, to cease, to put an end to<br>書留(かきとめ): writing down, putting on record<br>停留所(ていりゅうじょ): bus or tram stop<br>留まる(とどまる): remain, abide, stay (in the one place), come to a halt, be limited to, stop<br>留まる(とまる): fasten, turn off, detain<br>留学(りゅうがく): studying abroad<br>留守番(るすばん): care-taking, caretaker, house-watching<br>留守(るす): being away, be out (of one´s home or office)<br>留学生(りゅうがくせい): overseas student</p> <p id='readingExamples'>留意 (りゅうい), 留学 (りゅうがく), 保留 (ほりゅう), 留まる (と.まる), 留める (と.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1529</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1424</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1529</p> <p id='keyword'>trade</p> <p id='kanji'>貿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>trade, receipt, sword, dagger, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Receipt</i> . . . <i>dagger</i> . . . <i>shells</i>. Though the meanings are related, do not confuse with <i>make a deal</i> (Frame 471) or <i>wholesale</i> (Frame 1499).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There´s a buyback program where you can trade in your dagger for money. But it´s quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the original receipts can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The new RANSOM note (a receipt stuck to a door with a dagger) from DETAIN (1423) appears again (probably after you went to the field as instructed) now gives instruction to TRADE the victim for CURRENCY you were told to bring.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>貿易(ぼうえき): trade</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1530</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1425</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1530</p> <p id='keyword'>stamp</p> <p id='kanji'>印</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58DB0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stamp, staples, stamp</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>At last we come to the general character meaning <b>stamp</b>. Its elements: <i>staples</i> . . . <i>stamp</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Before sticky backs, they had to staple stamps to letters.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Aaaagh, this old stamp doesn´t stick! 	"<p id='id'>1533</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1426</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1533</p> <p id='keyword'>entertain</p> <p id='kanji'>興</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88888.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>entertain, staples, same, monks, hood, one, mouth, tool, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>37</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Mortar</i> . . . <i>same</i> . . . <i>tool</i>. Be careful to make an image that keeps <i>same</i> in the middle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be entertained. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the same: staples. What tools! [ayoung24].</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Photographically, this kanji simply looks like a set of two speakers (the staples primitives) between the sub-woofer (primitive for same) -- all this as a tool to entertain a group of drunks at a club.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おこ.る、おこ.す</p> <p id='words'>興じる(きょうじる): to amuse oneself, to make merry<br>興業(こうぎょう): industrial enterprise<br>興奮(こうふん): excitement, stimulation, agitation, arousal<br>新興(しんこう): rising, developing, emergent<br>振興(しんこう): promotion, encouragement<br>復興(ふっこう): revival, renaissance, reconstruction<br>余興(よきょう): side show, entertainment<br>興味(きょうみ): interest</p> <p id='readingExamples'>興行 (こうぎょう), 復興 (ふっこう), 振興 (しんこう), 興す (おこ.す), 興る (おこ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1534</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1427</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1534</p> <p id='keyword'>sign of the bird</p> <p id='kanji'>酉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98589.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sign of the bird, whiskey bottle, west, one</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Though we shall later encounter the kanji for <i>bird</i>, we introduce this one for the tenth sign of the zodiac mainly because of its use as a primitive, where it has a different meaning.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, it means <i>whiskey bottle</i>. In its pictograph, you can see the loosely corked lid, the bottle and the contents (about one-third full). You might also think of the Spanish ""porrón,"" a decanter shaped like a long-necked bird.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The sign of the bird on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Normally birds fly south, but one bird flew west. People were worried about it and kept asking ""Is there any sign of the bird – you know, the one that flew west?"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ユウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とり</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1535</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1428</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1535</p> <p id='keyword'>saké</p> <p id='kanji'>酒</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98592.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sake, water, water droplets, water pistol, whiskey bottle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . whiskey bottle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sake is just watered down whisky.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Sake is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is whiskey and water.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さけ、さか-</p> <p id='words'>酒場(さかば): bar, bar-room<br>酒(さけ): alcohol, sake<br>お酒(おさけ): (polite) wine, sake</p> <p id='readingExamples'>酒 (さけ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1536</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1429</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1536</p> <p id='keyword'>bartending</p> <p id='kanji'>酌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9858C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bartending, whiskey bottle, ladle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whiskey bottle . . . ladle.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Ever seen the anime Bartender?
