	"<p id='id'>1538</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1430</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1538</p> <p id='keyword'>fermentation</p> <p id='kanji'>酵</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E985B5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fermentation, whiskey bottle, filial piety, old man, child</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whiskey bottle . . . filial piety.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Since filial piety is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a whiskey bottle is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn´t, sink back some whiskey and it will.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1539</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1431</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1539</p> <p id='keyword'>cruel</p> <p id='kanji'>酷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E985B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cruel, whiskey bottle, revelation, cow, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whiskey bottle . . . revelation.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s cruel to pour alcohol down a cow´s mouth.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There is a saying that a drunk man's words are a sober man's thoughts. Be careful about giving someone a bottle of whiskey, you may get some revelations about their cruelty. Of course, they'll just say that it's the whiskey speaking.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひど.い</p> <p id='words'>残酷(ざんこく): cruelty, harshness<br>酷い(ひどい): cruel, awful, severe, very bad, serious, terrible, heavy, violent<br>冷酷(れいこく): cruelty, coldheartedness, relentless, ruthless</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1540</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1432</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1540</p> <p id='keyword'>repay</p> <p id='kanji'>酬</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E985AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>repay, whiskey bottle, state, stream, drop, drop3</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whiskey bottle . . . state.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will repay the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ、シュ、トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>むく.いる</p> <p id='words'>報酬(ほうしゅう): remuneration, recompense, reward, toll</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

[thanks to akahige].</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Red Bull, the chieftain (#2906) is so revered in his clan that everyone sticks to him like glue.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たっと.い、とうと.い、たっと.ぶ、とうと.ぶ</p> <p id='words'>自尊心(じそんしん): self-respect, conceit<br>尊い(たっとい): precious, valuable, priceless, noble, exalted, sacred<br>尊ぶ(たっとぶ): to value, to prize, to esteem<br>尊敬(そんけい): respect, esteem, reverence, honour<br>尊重(そんちょう): respect, esteem, regard</p> <p id='readingExamples'>尊い (たっと.い), 尊ぶ (たっと.ぶ), 尊い (とうと.い), 尊ぶ (とうと.ぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1550</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1442</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1550</p> <p id='keyword'>short</p> <p id='kanji'>短</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79FAD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>short, dart, drop, heavens, beans, table, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Dart . . . table.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>He is so short so he has to throw darts from the table.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw darts over a table at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be short.------------ This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>タン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みじか.い</p> <p id='words'>短歌(たんか): tanka, 31-syllable Japanese poem<br>短気(たんき): quick temper<br>短縮(たんしゅく): shortening, abbreviation, reduction<br>短大(たんだい): junior college<br>短波(たんぱ): short wave<br>短期(たんき): short term<br>短所(たんしょ): defect, demerit, weak point, disadvantage<br>短編(たんぺん): short (e.g. story, film)<br>長短(ちょうたん): length, long and short, advantages and disadvantages, pluses and minuses, strong and weak points, merits and demerits<br>短い(みじかい): short</p> <p id='readingExamples'>短い (みじか.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1552</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1444</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1552</p> <p id='keyword'>drum</p> <p id='kanji'>鼓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9BC93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>drum, samurai, beans, table, one, mouth, branch, ten, needle, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The full kanji for the <i>drum</i> adds a <i>branch</i>, apparently to serve as a <b>drum</b>stick, to the primitive for <i>drum</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Japanese festivals have drums so big, a samurai has to SIT (not stand) on a table to beat one with a tree branch! http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/~hidafyh/furukawayh/gyouji/image/maturi03.jpg.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I really hate the primitive meaning of ""table"" for ""bean."" I just use ""bean."" Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: ""DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つづみ</p> <p id='words'>太鼓(たいこ): drum, tambourine</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鼓 (つづみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

It helps me to imagine the placement this way.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the taiko (drum (#1444)) song of rejoicing, the drummers shout with open mouths.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よろこ.ぶ、よろこ.ばす</p> <p id='words'>喜劇(きげき): comedy, funny show<br>喜び(よろこび): joy, (a) delight, rapture, pleasure, gratification, rejoicing, congratulations, felicitations<br>喜ぶ(よろこぶ): be delighted</p> <p id='readingExamples'>喜ぶ (よろこ.ぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

They have glued themselves to the timber-trees and are beating their drums.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Everyone likes to see big trees fall down. 	"<p id='id'>1556</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1448</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1556</p> <p id='keyword'>blood</p> <p id='kanji'>血</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A180.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>blood, drop, dish</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>drop</i> in the <i>dish</i> is <b>blood</b>. It is similar to the <i>drop</i> we saw earlier on the <i>dagger</i> in the character for <i>blade</i> (Frame 88).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Vampire orders blood in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of blood spraying everywhere.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Image: Holy Grail with a drop of Jesus blood on it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ち</p> <p id='words'>血管(けっかん): blood vessel<br>混血(こんけつ): mixed race, mixed parentage<br>出血(しゅっけつ): bleeding, haemorrhage<br>血圧(けつあつ): blood pressure<br>血液(けつえき): blood<br>輸血(ゆけつ): blood transfusion<br>血(ち): blood</p> <p id='readingExamples'>血 (ち)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1557</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1449</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1557</p> <p id='keyword'>basin</p> <p id='kanji'>盆</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79B86.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>basin, part, eight, sword, dagger, dish</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Part . . . dish.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The part of the kitchen sink in which you wash dishes in is the basin.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I'm not an expert, but it seems that as a basin this refers more to an oceanic basin that a kitchen one, and in any case seems most common in reference to the famous O-Bon festival. So, a story: in the O-Bon festival, so many dishes are broken that all the parts have to be thrown into a deep oceanic basin.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>盆(ぼん): Lantern Festival, Festival of the Dead, tray<br>盆地(ぼんち): basin (e.g. between mountains)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

As a symbol of their alliance they clean up together one dish, and present it to the photographers. The clean dish under the flash lights appears very bright, and it´s pretty much all you can see on the photo that appears on the next morning´s newspapers, with the title ""New alliance, one bright dish!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>メイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>同盟(どうめい): alliance, union, league<br>連盟(れんめい): league, union, alliance</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1560</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1452</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1560</p> <p id='keyword'>warm</p> <p id='kanji'>温</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B8A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>warm, water, water droplets, water pistol, sun, day, dish</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . sun . . . dish.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you leave water out in the sun in a dish, naturally it will get warm.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To distinguish from warmth (#1949), which refers to warm weather, remember that this means warm objects or feelings. Imagine a plastic kiddy pool in the backyard full of lukewarm water. The kiddy pool is shaped like a huge dish, and it's been under the sun all day - that's why the water is warm now.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>オン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あたた.か、あたた.かい、あたた.まる、あたた.める、ぬく</p> <p id='words'>温和(おんわ): gentle, mild, moderate<br>生温い(なまぬるい): lukewarm, halfhearted<br>保温(ほおん): retaining warmth, keeping heat in, heat insulation<br>温室(おんしつ): greenhouse<br>温泉(おんせん): spa, hot spring<br>温帯(おんたい): temperate zone<br>温暖(おんだん): warmth<br>温度(おんど): temperature<br>気温(きおん): temperature<br>体温(たいおん): temperature (body)<br>温い(ぬるい): lukewarm, tepid</p> <p id='readingExamples'>温か (あたた.か), 温かい (あたた.かい), 温まる (あたた.まる), 温める (あたた.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"

Note that the two elements (sun and hairpin) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しろがね</p> <p id='words'>銀(ぎん): silver<br>銀行(ぎんこう): bank</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"

A new node can be formed in an instant.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セツ、セチ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふし、-ぶし、のっと</p> <p id='words'>節(せつ): node, section, occasion, time<br>節約(せつやく): economising, saving<br>調節(ちょうせつ): regulation, adjustment, control<br>節(ふし): node, section, occasion, time<br>季節(きせつ): season</p> <p id='readingExamples'>節約 (せつやく), 季節 (きせつ), 関節 (かんせつ), 節 (ふし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1575</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1465</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1575</p> <p id='keyword'>retreat</p> <p id='kanji'>退</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98080.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>retreat, road, silver</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Road . . . silver.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you see silver on the road (eg. gun, armour, sword) => retreat!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the land of Oz, you advance by following the golden road, but you reatreat by following the Silver Road.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しりぞ.く、しりぞ.ける、ひ.く、の.く、の.ける、ど.く</p> <p id='words'>後退(こうたい): retreat, backspace (BS)<br>辞退(じたい): refusal<br>退く(しりぞく): to retreat, to recede, to withdraw<br>退ける(しりぞける): to repel, to drive away<br>退化(たいか): degeneration, retrogression<br>退学(たいがく): dropping out of school<br>退治(たいじ): extermination<br>退職(たいしょく): retirement (from office)<br>脱退(だったい): secession<br>引退(いんたい): retire<br>退屈(たいくつ): tedium, boredom<br>退く(どく): retreat, recede, withdraw<br>退ける(どける): remove, take away, dislodge, put something out of the way<br>退院(たいいん): leave hospital</p> <p id='readingExamples'>退く (しりぞ.く), 退ける (しりぞ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"

As with <i>silver</i>, on the left the final two strokes of this element are combined into one.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>That umbrella looks good enough to eat!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Umbrella + Good: Let's go eat at that restaurant - the table with the umbrella looks good.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショク、ジキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>く.う、く.らう、た.べる、は.む</p> <p id='words'>給食(きゅうしょく): school lunch, providing a meal<br>食い違う(くいちがう): to cross each other, to run counter to, to differ, to clash, to go awry<br>主食(しゅしょく): staple food<br>食事(しょくじ): meal<br>定食(ていしょく): set meal, special (of the day)<br>衣食住(いしょくじゅう): necessities of life (food, clothing, etc.)<br>食う(くう): eat<br>食塩(しょくえん): table salt<br>食卓(しょくたく): dining table<br>食品(しょくひん): commodity, foodstuff<br>食物(しょくもつ): food, foodstuff<br>食欲(しょくよく): appetite (for food)<br>食料(しょくりょう): food<br>食糧(しょくりょう): provisions, rations<br>食器(しょっき): tableware<br>昼食(ちゅうしょく): lunch, midday meal<br>食料品(しょくりょうひん): foods<br>食堂(しょくどう): cafeteria, dining room<br>食べ物(たべもの): food<br>食べる(たべる): eat</p> <p id='readingExamples'>食事 (しょくじ), 食料 (しょくりょう), 会食 (かいしょく), 食う (く.う), 食らう (く.らう), 食べる (た.べる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1591</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1479</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1591</p> <p id='keyword'>foster</p> <p id='kanji'>養</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A48A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>foster, sheep, eat, food, umbrella, good, halo, drop, silver</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Sheep</i> . . . <i>food</i>. The key word has the sense of promoting the development of something, especially in a psychological or spiritual sense.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A sheep became the foster parent for a wolf pup, feeding it with milk. This story cannot end well...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Judy Foster in ""The Silence of the Lambs"" is what Dr. Hannibal-the cannibal-Lecter would like to eat.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ、リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やしな.う</p> <p id='words'>扶養(ふよう): support, maintenance<br>保養(ほよう): health preservation, recuperation, recreation<br>養う(やしなう): to rear, to maintain, to cultivate<br>養護(ようご): protection, nursing, protective care<br>養成(ようせい): training, development<br>栄養(えいよう): nutrition, nourishment<br>休養(きゅうよう): rest, break, recreation<br>教養(きょうよう): culture, education, refinement, cultivation<br>養分(ようぶん): nourishment, nutrient</p> <p id='readingExamples'>養う (やしな.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1592</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1480</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1592</p> <p id='keyword'>sated</p> <p id='kanji'>飽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A3BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sated, eat, food, umbrella, good, halo, drop, silver, wrap, bound up, snake, self</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Eat . . . wrap.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My gluttony was only sated after I ate the hamburger AND the wrapper!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This guy is sated only after eating the hamburger AND its wrapping!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.きる、あ.かす、あ.く</p> <p id='words'>飽和(ほうわ): saturation<br>飽きる(あきる): get tired of, lose interest in<br>飽くまで(あくまで): to the end, stubbornly, persistently</p> <p id='readingExamples'>飽かす (あ.かす), 飽きる (あ.きる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1593</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1481</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1593</p> <p id='keyword'>previously</p> <p id='kanji'>既</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E697A2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>previously, silver, waitress</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Silver</i> . . . <i>waitress</i>. Do not confuse this kanji's key word with <i>before</i> (Frame 263).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Distinguish from formerly (#501). Think of previously as ""the previous customer"" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the waitress gives you unwashed silverware that was previously used by the previous customer. Yuck.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>For the waitress primitive, I don´t really see the receipt. So instead, I imagine a waitress holding a plate above her head, using those legs to weave through the tables.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すで.に</p> <p id='words'>既婚(きこん): marriage, married<br>既に(すでに): already, too late</p> <p id='readingExamples'>既に (すで.に)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1594</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1482</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1594</p> <p id='keyword'>outline</p> <p id='kanji'>概</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A682.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>outline, roots, tree, wood, silver, waitress, previously</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Roots</i> . . . <i>waitress</i>. Note that the kanji meaning of the two primitives to the right is not used here because we shall later meet a primitive meaning <i>beforehand</i> and want to preempt any confusion. The same holds true in the following frame.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The police tried to draw a chalk outline around the dead waitress, but it was kinda tough with all the tree roots underneath her.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you attempted to outline the biography of most famous actresses, you´d find that they have roots working as waitresses before getting their big break.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おうむ.ね</p> <p id='words'>一概に(いちがいに): unconditionally, as a rule<br>概説(がいせつ): general statement, outline<br>概念(がいねん): general idea, concept, notion<br>概略(がいりゃく): outline, summary, gist, in brief<br>大概(たいがい): in general, mainly<br>概論(がいろん): introduction, outline, general remarks</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1595</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1483</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1595</p> <p id='keyword'>rue</p> <p id='kanji'>慨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E685A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rue, regret, resentment, Freud, state of mind, silver, waitress, previously</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>38</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Resentment . . . waitress.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you don´t leave some silver as a tip, you will rue the day you earned the resentment of your waitress.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The resentment of a waitress who gave up going to college to help her boyfriend (with his tuition). 	"<p id='id'>1596</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1484</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1596</p> <p id='keyword'>even</p> <p id='kanji'>平</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B9B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>even, water-lily, lily pad</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is easiest remembered as a pictograph of a water lily floating on the surface of the water, which gives it its meaning of <b>even</b>. The fourth stroke represents the calm, smooth surface of a pond, and the final stroke the long stem of the plant reaching underwater.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji can keep its pictographic meaning of a <i>water lily</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There´s an even covering of water lilies on the pond at 金閣寺（きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Frogs stay dry (#1648) 干 even as rain drops on their lily pads... RTK2:　ヘイ　　平均　へいきん(an average)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　ビョウ　平等　びょうどう(equality).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘイ、ビョウ、ヒョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たい.ら、-だいら、ひら、ひら-</p> <p id='words'>平均(ならし): equilibrium, balance, average, mean<br>平たい(ひらたい): flat, even, level, simple, plain<br>平行(へいこう): (going) side by side, concurrent, abreast, at the same time, occurring together, parallel, parallelism<br>平常(へいじょう): normal, usual<br>平方(へいほう): square (e.g. metre), square<br>公平(こうへい): fairness, impartial, justice<br>水平(すいへい): water level, horizon<br>水平線(すいへいせん): horizon<br>平ら(たいら): flatness, level, smooth, calm, plain<br>地平線(ちへいせん): horizon<br>平等(びょうどう): equality, impartiality, evenness<br>不平(ふへい): complaint, discontent, dissatisfaction<br>平気(へいき): coolness, calmness, composure, unconcern<br>平均(へいきん): equilibrium, balance, average, mean<br>平日(へいじつ): weekday, ordinary days<br>平凡(へいぼん): common, commonplace, ordinary, mediocre<br>平野(へいや): plain, open field<br>平和(へいわ): peace, harmony<br>平仮名(ひらがな): hiragana, 47 syllables, the cursive syllabary</p> <p id='readingExamples'>平面 (へいめん), 平和 (へいわ), 公平 (こうへい), 平ら (たい.ら), 平 (ひら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1597</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1485</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1597</p> <p id='keyword'>call</p> <p id='kanji'>呼</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E591BC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>call, mouth, even, water-lily, lily pad, question mark</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Mouth</i> . . . <i>water lily</i>. 	"<p id='id'>1598</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1486</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1598</p> <p id='keyword'>two-mat area</p> <p id='kanji'>坪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59DAA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>two-mat area, soil, dirt, ground, even, water-lily, lily pad</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji belongs to an old Japanese system of measurement and indicates an area of about 36 square feet, or the <b>area</b> taken up by <b>two</b> tatami <b>mats</b>. Its elements: <i>ground</i> . . . <i>water lily</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A two-mat area is just about as much ground as you will need for a lily pond.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A two-mat area is plenty of space for sleeping in a tent but you won´t be comfortable unless the ground is even.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つぼ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>坪 (つぼ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1605</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1492</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1605</p> <p id='keyword'>detach</p> <p id='kanji'>離</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99BA2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>detach, sheik, top hat, villain, sheaf, shovel, belt, elbow, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Top hat</i> . . . <i>villain</i> . . . <i>belt</i> . . . <i>elbow</i> . . . <i>turkey</i>. This is potentially one of the most difficult characters to remember. Tackle it positively and let the image ""sink in"" by carrying it around with you today and calling it up in your spare moments.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I´ve finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I´m about to fight him. But what´s this? He´s suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The left side isn't too hard---a top-hatted villain whose villainy involves belts around elbows? Clearly he's a drug dealer. And the best way to detach yourself from the drug dealer's influence is to go cold turkey.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はな.れる、はな.す</p> <p id='words'>距離(きょり): distance, range<br>分離(ぶんり): separation, detachment, segregation, isolation<br>離す(はなす): part, divide, separate<br>離れる(はなれる): be separated from, leave, go away, be a long way off<br>離婚(りこん): divorce</p> <p id='readingExamples'>離す (はな.す), 離れる (はな.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1607</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1493</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1607</p> <p id='keyword'>kill</p> <p id='kanji'>殺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AEBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>kill, sheaf, tree, wood, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Sheaf . . . tree . . . missile.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>X marks the spot on the tree where the missile hit. No doubt, it was meant to kill us.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I suppose when this kanji was made, it was most effective to kill your enemies with sheafs of wood used as missiles.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サツ、サイ、セツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ころ.す、-ごろ.し、そ.ぐ</p> <p id='words'>暗殺(あんさつ): assassination<br>殺人(さつじん): murder<br>殺す(ころす): kill<br>自殺(じさつ): suicide</p> <p id='readingExamples'>殺人 (さつじん), 殺到 (さっとう), 黙殺 (もくさつ), 相殺 (そうさい), 殺す (ころ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1609</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1494</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1609</p> <p id='keyword'>genuine</p> <p id='kanji'>純</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B494.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>genuine, thread, spiderman, earthworm, drop, shovel, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . earthworm.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>For remembering the primitive earthworm: Drops of rain were falling so I took my shovel to dig up some earthworms to put them on my fishook..... My story: To have a genuine fishing line you don't just pick up a stick but you also attach some thread onto it and at the end an earthworm must be hung.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You need to attach a genuine earthworm to the thread. With plastic bait you won´t catch anything.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>清純(せいじゅん): purity, innocence<br>純情(じゅんじょう): pure heart, naivete, self-sacrificing devotion<br>純粋(じゅんすい): pure, true, genuine, unmixed<br>単純(たんじゅん): simplicity</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1611</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1495</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1611</p> <p id='keyword'>dull</p> <p id='kanji'>鈍</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9888D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dull, metal, gold, earthworm, drop, shovel, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Metal . . . earthworm.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The metal hook is too dull to even pierce an earthworm....</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>From the earthworm´s perspective, it most be pretty dull when you are put in a metal bowl, just waiting for being put on the hook on the fishing trip the next day.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ドン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>にぶ.い、にぶ.る、にぶ-、なま.る、なまく.ら</p> <p id='words'>鈍感(どんかん): thickheadedness, stolidity<br>鈍る(なまる): to become less capable, to grow dull, to become blunt, to weaken<br>鈍い(にぶい): dull (e.g. a knife), thickheaded, slow, stupid<br>鈍い(のろい): dull (e.g. a knife), thickheaded, slow, stupid</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鈍い (にぶ.い), 鈍る (にぶ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1612</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1496</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1612</p> <p id='keyword'>spicy</p> <p id='kanji'>辛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BE9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>spicy, stand up, vase, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character pictures food whose taste is so hot and <b>spicy</b> that it makes the hairs on your body <i>stand up</i> as straight as <i>needles</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we shall use this meaning of <i>spicy</i>, except when the two extra strokes are added to the bottom, giving it the form of a tree. Then we take its alternate meaning of a <i>red pepper</i> plant. The connection is obvious.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Eating spicy food makes you stand up ten times faster than usual, ´cause you just need to get something to drink!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Eating spicy food makes you stand up as if you had sat on a needle.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>から.い、つら.い、-づら.い、かのと</p> <p id='words'>辛うじて(かろうじて): barely, narrowly, just manage to do st<br>香辛料(こうしんりょう): spices<br>辛抱(しんぼう): patience, endurance<br>塩辛い(しおからい): salty (flavor)<br>辛い(つらい): painful, heart-breaking<br>辛い(からい): painful, heart-breaking</p> <p id='readingExamples'>辛い (から.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1619</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1502</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1619</p> <p id='keyword'>new</p> <p id='kanji'>新</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E696B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>new, red pepper, stand up, vase, tree, wood, axe</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Red pepper . . . ax.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Don't confuse left primitive with catalpa (#1498). Every time the farmer cuts down the peppers from the red pepper plant, he has to use a brand new axe. This is because the spicy peppers cause the metal to erode very quickly, thereby rendering the axe completely useless.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Axe-man grows a patch of red pepper plants in his back garden. He rubs red peppers on the edge of his axes, and this seems to keep them sharp like brand new.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あたら.しい、あら.た、あら-、にい-</p> <p id='words'>革新(かくしん): reform, innovation<br>新(しん): new<br>新興(しんこう): rising, developing, emergent<br>新婚(しんこん): newly-wed<br>新人(しんじん): new face, newcomer<br>新築(しんちく): new building, new construction<br>新入生(しんにゅうせい): freshman, first-year student<br>新た(あらた): new, fresh<br>新幹線(しんかんせん): bullet train<br>新鮮(しんせん): fresh<br>新聞社(しんぶんしゃ): newspaper office<br>新しい(あたらしい): new<br>新聞(しんぶん): newspaper</p> <p id='readingExamples'>新しい (あたら.しい), 新た (あら.た), 新 (にい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1622</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1505</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1622</p> <p id='keyword'>happiness</p> <p id='kanji'>幸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B9B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>happiness, ten, needle, stand up, vase, ten, needle, ten2, needle2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Simply by turning the dot at the top of the primitive for <i>spicy</i> into a cross shape, we move from things bitter and <i>spicy</i> to things <b>happy</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Happiness adds a bit (or ten) of spice to your life.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is one of those rare occasions when I forgo Heisig for other methods. 「幸せから一本取ると辛い」 -- if you take but one stroke away from happiness, you get painfulness. (oh well, Heisig used similar one for 百).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さいわ.い、さち、しあわ.せ</p> <p id='words'>幸運(こううん): good luck, fortune<br>幸福(こうふく): happiness, blessedness<br>幸い(さいわい): happiness, blessedness<br>幸せ(しあわせ): happiness, good fortune, luck, blessing<br>不幸(ふこう): unhappiness, sorrow, misfortune, disaster, accident, death</p> <p id='readingExamples'>幸い (さいわ.い), 幸 (さち), 幸せ (しあわ.せ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1628</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1510</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1628</p> <p id='keyword'>income</p> <p id='kanji'>収</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F8E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>income, cornucopia, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Cornucopia</i> . . . <i>crotch</i>. Keep distinct from both <i>fare</i> (Frame 1079) and <i>salary</i> (Frame 1449).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Prostitutes can make a veritable cornucopia of income by using their crotches -- they put the ""come"" in ""income."" (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like profit (#906) or earnings (#893)).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Women love men with money. If you have a high income you can get a cornicopia of crotches.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おさ.める、おさ.まる</p> <p id='words'>収まる(おさまる): to be obtained, to end, to settle into, to fit into, to be settled, to be paid, to be delivered<br>収める(おさめる): to obtain, to reap, to pay, to supply, to accept<br>回収(かいしゅう): collection, recovery<br>収益(しゅうえき): earnings, proceeds, returns<br>収支(しゅうし): income and expenditure<br>収集(しゅうしゅう): gathering up, collection, accumulation<br>収容(しゅうよう): accommodation, reception, seating, housing, custody, admission, entering (in a dictionary)<br>徴収(ちょうしゅう): collection, levy<br>没収(ぼっしゅう): forfeited<br>吸収(きゅうしゅう): absorption, suction, attraction<br>収穫(しゅうかく): harvest, crop, ingathering<br>収入(しゅうにゅう): income, receipts, revenue<br>領収(りょうしゅう): receipt, voucher</p> <p id='readingExamples'>収まる (おさ.まる), 収める (おさ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1629</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1511</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1629</p> <p id='keyword'>lowly</p> <p id='kanji'>卑</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58D91.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lowly, Wayne Slob, drop, rice field, brains, cornucopia, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A drop of . . . brains . . . cornucopia.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Lowly people only have a drop of brains and use nothing but 4-letter words.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いや.しい、いや.しむ、いや.しめる</p> <p id='words'>卑しい(いやしい): greedy, vulgar, shabby, humble, base, mean, vile<br>卑怯(ひきょう): cowardice, meanness, unfairness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>卑しい (いや.しい), 卑しむ (いや.しむ), 卑しめる (いや.しめる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A STONE makes a LOWLY TOMBSTONE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いしぶみ</p> <p id='words'>碑(いしぶみ): stone monument bearing an inscription</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1631</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1513</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1631</p> <p id='keyword'>land</p> <p id='kanji'>陸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E999B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>land, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, mini-tractor, rice seedlings, soil, dirt, ground, human legs, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sense of <b>land</b> carried by this kanji is distinct from <i>soil</i> (Frame 161) and <i>ground</i> (Frame 554) in that it is meant to represent <b>land</b> seen from a distance, that is, <i>land</i> as opposed to ""water."" Its elements: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>rice seedlings</i> . . . <i>ground</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My rice-seedlings have become sentient and will go on a mission. I can only apologise for the next 6 frames. In the distance, there is a pinnacle, which the newly-awakened rice-seedlings who are still stuck in the ground can see. Could it be the Promised Land?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When sailors see land in the distance, they first see the pinnacles of the new land, but when they come close enough they´ll be able to make out the rice seedlings, and finally the ground!</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>リク、ロク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おか</p> <p id='words'>上陸(じょうりく): landing, disembarkation<br>着陸(ちゃくりく): landing, alighting, touch down<br>内陸(ないりく): inland<br>大陸(たいりく): continent<br>陸(りく): land, shore</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1632</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1514</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1632</p> <p id='keyword'>intimate</p> <p id='kanji'>睦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79DA6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>intimate, eye, mini-tractor, rice seedlings, soil, dirt, ground, human legs, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Eye . . . rice seedlings . . . ground.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The farmer was never very intimate with his wife. He always kept his eye on his precious rice seedlings in the soil.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I keep an intimate relationship with my rice seedlings -- I never take my eye from the soil.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボク、モク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>むつ.まじい、むつ.む、むつ.ぶ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The forces of nature.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The forces of nature need to be just right for the rice seedlings in the ground to become fat and strong.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ゼイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いきお.い、はずみ</p> <p id='words'>形勢(けいせい): condition, situation, prospects<br>情勢(じょうせい): state of things, condition, situation<br>勢力(せいりょく): influence, power, might, strength, potency, force, energy<br>態勢(たいせい): attitude, conditions, preparations<br>優勢(ゆうせい): superiority, superior power, predominance, preponderance<br>勢い(いきおい): force, vigor, energy, spirit, life, authority, influence, power, might, tendency, necessarily<br>姿勢(しせい): attitude, posture<br>大勢(おおぜい): many, a great number (of people)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>勢い (いきお.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1634</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1516</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1634</p> <p id='keyword'>heat</p> <p id='kanji'>熱</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E786B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>heat, mini-tractor, rice seedlings, soil, dirt, ground, human legs, fat man, musashimaru, round, nine, baseball, drop, oven-fire, barbecue, soil2, dirt2, ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rice seedlings . . . ground . . . fat man . . . oven fire.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Heat up those RICE SEEDLINGS you pulled from the SOIL in a ROUND pan over a low FLAME. (Note: the hot pan image helps reinforce the idea that this kanji for ""atsui"" refers to something hot to the touch, as opposed to hot weather).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Just a comment on Erikkusan's story: Although one of the pronunciations of this kanji is ""atsui"" this isn't the atsui that you feel in Tokyo in August, (which is Frame 1260's ""sultry' 暑). This atsui is the one when you touch something hot, like a fry pan. Another reading of this is ""netsu,"" which is the ""fever"" this fat man may feel after planting the rice seedlings.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ネツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あつ.い</p> <p id='words'>光熱費(こうねつひ): cost of fuel and light<br>情熱(じょうねつ): passion, enthusiasm, zeal<br>熱意(ねつい): zeal, enthusiasm<br>熱湯(ねっとう): boiling water<br>熱量(ねつりょう): temperature<br>加熱(かねつ): heating<br>熱する(ねっする): to heat<br>熱帯(ねったい): tropics<br>熱中(ねっちゅう): enthusiasm, zeal, mania<br>熱(ねつ): heat, fever<br>熱心(ねっしん): eagerness<br>熱い(あつい): hot (thing)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>熱い (あつ.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1635</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1517</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1635</p> <p id='keyword'>diamond</p> <p id='kanji'>菱</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88FB1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>diamond, flowers, Mao, soil, dirt, ground, human legs, walking legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Named after a <b>diamond</b>-shaped flower (the water caltrop), this key word refers to things shaped like a <b>diamond</b>. Its elements: <i>flower</i> . . . <i>rice seedlings</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Some girls want diamonds, but others will be satisfied with just flowers. However if you think you can win her over with rice seedlings, expect her to get up on her walking legs and walk on out!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Not a real diamond but a baseball one. No proper bases so we improvise, 1st is a bunch of flowers, 2nd is the pile of rice seedlings and so on... watch the running legs charge around after a big hit!</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひし</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"

It's on the pinnacle of Mt. Fuji, and it has a statue of a guy with huge walking legs planting rice seedlings as he goes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>At the pinnicle is a mausolem. The ground is sown with rice seedings to stop the dead from rising on walking legs.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みささぎ</p> <p id='words'>丘陵(きゅうりょう): hill</p> <p id='readingExamples'>陵 (みささぎ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1637</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1519</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1637</p> <p id='keyword'>sign of the hog</p> <p id='kanji'>亥</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BAA5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sign of the hog, acorn, top hat</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji is the 12th sign of the Chinese zodiac: the <b>sign of the hog</b>. It is best learned by thinking of an acorn-eating <b>hog</b> in connection with the primitive meaning given below.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The <i>top hat</i> represents the external shape of the <i>acorn</i>, and the unusual but easily written complex of strokes beneath it (which you might also see as distortions of an <i>elbow</i> and <i>person</i>) stands for the mysterious secret whereby the <i>acorn</i> contains the oak tree in a nutshell.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Top Hat + Elbow + Person: The sign of the hog was a very recognizable tattoo - a hog with a big grin in a top hat, sticking his elbow into the person next to him.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガイ、カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1639</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1521</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1639</p> <p id='keyword'>engrave</p> <p id='kanji'>刻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E588BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>engrave, sign of the hog, acorn, top hat, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Acorn . . . saber.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with sabres, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto acorns, and throw the acorns to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the acorn and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>While it´s traditional for lovers to engrave their names on a tree in many countries, in Japan, however, it was traditional for a samurai to signify his undying love for a woman by engraving the kanji of her name on an acorn with his sabre.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>コク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きざ.む、きざ.み</p> <p id='words'>時刻表(じこくひょう): table, diagram, chart, timetable, schedule<br>刻む(きざむ): mince, chop up, carve, engrave, cut fine, hash, chisel, notch<br>時刻(じこく): instant, time, moment<br>深刻(しんこく): serious<br>遅刻(ちこく): lateness, late coming<br>彫刻(ちょうこく): carving, engraving, sculpture</p> <p id='readingExamples'>刻む (きざ.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1640</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1522</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1640</p> <p id='keyword'>above-stated</p> <p id='kanji'>該</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A9B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>above-stated, say, words, keitai, mouth, sign of the hog, acorn, top hat</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . acorn.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I asked my teacher what this strange word meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an acorn at me!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The above-stated words are the acorn from which the following statement grows.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>該当(がいとう): corresponding, answering to, coming under</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

It is a flex of muscle by congress against the current president, but it is a very weak one. Imagine censure as congress flexing as hard as it can, only to have a little acorn-sized bump of muscle pop up suddenly.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Acorn Power is the people´s way to CENSURE a congressman you don´t agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1643</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1524</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1643</p> <p id='keyword'>mention</p> <p id='kanji'>述</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8BFB0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mention, resin, pole, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Resin . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Why are the roads leading through the woods so sticky and dirty? Hmm... I think the forest ranger mentioned something about excess resin on the roads...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>No-body mentioned that there was resin on the road. Now I´m stuck!</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>の.べる</p> <p id='words'>記述(きじゅつ): describing, descriptor<br>口述(こうじゅつ): verbal statement<br>述語(じゅつご): predicate<br>述べる(のべる): state, express, mention</p> <p id='readingExamples'>述べる (の.べる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1644</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1525</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1644</p> <p id='keyword'>art</p> <p id='kanji'>術</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A193.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>art, boulevard, going, resin, pole</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Boulevard . . . resin.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Behold the ""Boulev´Art"" : a life-size section of a boulevard cast in a huge block of resin. Some call it ... art.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The definition of art is getting more and more loose these days. Why even some resin spilled onto the boulevard is now counted as art! Hmmph!</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すべ</p> <p id='words'>戦術(せんじゅつ): tactics<br>美術(びじゅつ): art, fine arts<br>学術(がくじゅつ): science, learning, scholarship<br>芸術(げいじゅつ): fine art, the arts<br>手術(しゅじゅつ): surgical operation<br>技術(ぎじゅつ): technique<br>美術館(びじゅつかん): art gallery</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1645</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1526</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1645</p> <p id='keyword'>cold</p> <p id='kanji'>寒</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AF92.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cold, Baba Yaga’s hut, house, celery, animal legs, ice</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . celery . . . animal legs . . . ice.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Don't mix up with cool (#1404), when the cool boys order each other around. This kind of cold has to do with weather. When its cold outside, I stay at home and have hot celery soup with chicken legs to keep out the ice. 寒い　＝　さむい　＝cold.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn´t get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さむ.い</p> <p id='words'>寒気(かんき): cold, frost, chill<br>寒帯(かんたい): frigid zone<br>寒い(さむい): cold (e.g. weather)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>寒い (さむ.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1647</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1527</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1647</p> <p id='keyword'>brew</p> <p id='kanji'>醸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E986B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>brew, whiskey bottle, grass skirt, top hat, eight, six, animal legs, celery, scarf</p> <p id='strokeCount'>20</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Whiskey bottle . . . grass skirt.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Grass Skirt primitive: Picture some Hawaiian girls, wearing grass skirts and tropical scarfs (or leis), doing a dance. ""3, 4, 5, 6 pick up all the celery sticks!"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A classic alcohol commercial: whiskey being brewed while girls dance around, scantily clad in their grass skirts.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かも.す</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>醸す (かも.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

It means ""defer"" in the sense of ""submit"" or ""yield"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆず.る</p> <p id='words'>譲歩(じょうほ): concession, conciliation, compromise<br>譲る(ゆずる): turn over, assign, hand over, transmit, convey, sell, dispose of, yield, surrender</p> <p id='readingExamples'>譲る (ゆず.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1652</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1532</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1652</p> <p id='keyword'>elementary</p> <p id='kanji'>素</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B4A0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>elementary, grow up, thread, spiderman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Grow up . . . thread.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji has nothing to do with elementary school - it means element, elemental, basic, bare. Imagine the thread as a thread connecting all life, starting from the basic elements and growing up into everything.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is a pictogram of string theory. Strings are the most elementary particles of matter, which then grow up to become matter itself.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ、ス</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もと</p> <p id='words'>簡素(かんそ): simplicity, plain<br>元素(げんそ): chemical element<br>酸素(さんそ): oxygen<br>質素(しっそ): simplicity, modesty, frugality<br>素敵(すてき): lovely, dreamy, beautiful, great, fantastic, superb, cool, capital<br>素早い(すばやい): fast, quick, prompt, agile<br>素晴らしい(すばらしい): wonderful, splendid, magnificent<br>素材(そざい): raw materials, subject matter<br>素っ気ない(そっけない): cold, short, curt, blunt<br>素朴(そぼく): simplicity, artlessness, naivete<br>炭素(たんそ): carbon (C)<br>素人(しろうと): amateur, novice<br>水素(すいそ): hydrogen<br>素直(すなお): obedient, meek, docile, unaffected<br>素質(そしつ): character, qualities, genius<br>要素(ようそ): element</p> <p id='readingExamples'>素材 (そざい), 元素 (げんそ), 平素 (へいそ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1654</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1534</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1654</p> <p id='keyword'>blue</p> <p id='kanji'>青</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99D92.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>blue, grow up, moon, flesh</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Grow up . . . moon.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The last time I saw a blue moon was in my youth when I was growing up.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Once in a blue moon refers to a rare event. But originally ""blue moon"" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we´re talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あお、あお-、あお.い</p> <p id='words'>青白い(あおじろい): pale<br>青春(せいしゅん): youth, springtime of life, adolescent<br>青(あお): the color blue, the color green (noun), green light<br>青少年(せいしょうねん): youth, young person<br>青年(せいねん): youth, young man<br>真っ青(まっさお): deep blue, ghastly pale<br>青い(あおい): blue, pale, green, unripe, inexperienced</p> <p id='readingExamples'>青天 (せいてん), 青銅 (せいどう), 青年 (せいねん), 青 (あお), 青い (あお.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1658</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1538</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1658</p> <p id='keyword'>clear up</p> <p id='kanji'>晴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E699B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>clear up, sun, day, blue, grow up, moon, flesh</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Take the key word in its associations with the weather (unless that tempts you to include the primitive for <i>weather</i>, which doesn't belong here). 	"<p id='id'>1659</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1539</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1659</p> <p id='keyword'>pure</p> <p id='kanji'>清</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B885.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pure, water, water droplets, water pistol, blue, grow up, moon, flesh</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . blue.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Bottles of water claim to be pure. 	"<p id='id'>1660</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1540</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1660</p> <p id='keyword'>quiet</p> <p id='kanji'>静</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99D99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>quiet, blue, grow up, moon, flesh, contend, bound up, rake</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Blue</i> . . . <i>contend</i>. Do not confuse with <i>calm</i> (Frame 1230).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When someone you know who is normally talkative goes quiet, it´s usually a sign that they are contending with the blues.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don't confuse with silence (#240), something achieved through action. On the other hand, quiet refers to a personal quality of not speaking out. Members of Blue-man group jump into the wrestling ring of contenders for tag-team wrestling. Though the other contenders are screaming, the blue men never say anything - they are a very quiet bunch, that Blue-man group. Primitive order: blue man group's first and main characteristic is being blue and quiet; only later did they decide to become wrestling contenders.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しず-、しず.か、しず.まる、しず.める</p> <p id='words'>安静(あんせい): rest<br>静止(せいし): stillness, repose, standing still<br>静的(せいてき): static<br>静まる(しずまる): calm down, subside, die down, abate, be suppressed<br>冷静(れいせい): calm, composure, coolness, serenity<br>静か(しずか): quiet, peaceful</p> <p id='readingExamples'>静止 (せいし), 静穏 (せいおん), 安静 (あんせい), 静 (しず), 静か (しず.か), 静まる (しず.まる), 静める (しず.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1661</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1541</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1661</p> <p id='keyword'>blame</p> <p id='kanji'>責</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8B2AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>blame, grow up, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Grow up . . . oyster.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>As one grows up, one typically starts to blame all of their problems on money.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is the story of a poor fisherman and his wife. A long time ago he caught an oyster with a small but precious pearl. The intelligent wife told him to sell the pearl immediately: the greedy husband figured if he kept the oyster and fed it, it would grow up and yield an even bigger pearl. One day the oyster grew so big, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, blaming his blind greed for their poverty.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>せ.める</p> <p id='words'>責務(せきむ): duty, obligation<br>責任(せきにん): duty, responsibility<br>責める(せめる): condemn, blame, criticize</p> <p id='readingExamples'>責める (せ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1662</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1542</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1662</p> <p id='keyword'>exploits</p> <p id='kanji'>績</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B8BE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>exploits, thread, spiderman, blame, grow up, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . blame.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Spidey´s exploits are world famous but still The Daily Bugle´s pages blame him for every problem out there.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[Geek alert] A lot of modern software is full of exploits which can be abused by hackers. I blame multi-threading.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>業績(ぎょうせき): achievement, performance, results, work, contribution<br>紡績(ぼうせき): spinning<br>功績(こうせき): achievements, merit, meritorious service, meritorious deed<br>実績(じっせき): achievements, actual results<br>成績(せいせき): results, record</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"

After the 1985 JAL air crash that killed 520 people (the world´s worst). 	"<p id='id'>1675</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1555</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1675</p> <p id='keyword'>life</p> <p id='kanji'>生</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7949F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p for <i>grow up</i> gives us the character for <b>life</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we may think of a microscopic cell, that miraculous unit that grows up to become a living being.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire LIFE, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Growing Up is just a Drop of our LIFE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>い.きる、い.かす、い.ける、う.まれる、う.まれ、うまれ、う.む、お.う、は.える、は.やす、き、なま、なま-、な.る、な.す、む.す、-う</p> <p (human) life (i.e. conception to death)<br>生産(せいさん): production, manufacture<br>生存(せいぞん): existence, being, survival<br>生年月日(せいねんがっぴ): birth date<br>生物(せいぶつ): living things, creature<br>生命(せいめい): life, existence<br>誕生(たんじょう): birth<br>生(なま): raw, unprocessed<br>生意気(なまいき): impertinent, saucy, cheeky, conceit, audacious, brazen<br>生る(なる): bear fruit<br>生える(はえる): grow, spring up<br>生きる(いきる): live, exist<br>一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい): as well as one can, as hard as one can<br>高校生(こうこうせい): high school student<br>大学生(だいがくせい): university student<br>生まれる(うまれる): be born<br>学生(がくせい): student<br>生徒(せいと): pupil<br>先生(せんせい): teacher, master, doctor<br>誕生日(たんじょうび): birthday<br>留学生(りゅうがくせい): overseas student</p> <p id='readingExamples'>生活 (せいかつ), 発生 (はっせい), 先生 (せんせい), 生かす (い.かす), 生きる (い.きる), 生ける (い.ける), We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>犠牲(ぎせい): sacrifice</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

""Buy my products!! Buy my products! Or else I´ll take my own life""! Man, that´s selling on pressure.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>う.む、う.まれる、うぶ-、む.す</p> <p id='words'>産む(うむ): to give birth, to deliver, to produce<br>お産(おさん): (giving) birth<br>国産(こくさん): domestic products<br>産休(さんきゅう): maternity leave<br>産後(さんご): postpartum, after childbirth<br>産出(さんしゅつ): yield, produce<br>産婦人科(さんふじんか): maternity and gynecology department<br>産物(さんぶつ): product, result, fruit<br>資産(しさん): property, fortune, means, assets<br>出産(しゅっさん): (child)birth, delivery, production (of goods)<br>畜産(ちくさん): animal husbandry<br>倒産(とうさん): (corporate) bankruptcy, insolvency<br>特産(とくさん): specialty, special product<br>土産(どさん): product of the land<br>不動産(ふどうさん): real estate<br>名産(めいさん): noted product<br>共産(きょうさん): communism<br>原産(げんさん): place of origin, habitat<br>財産(ざいさん): property, fortune, assets<br>産業(さんぎょう): industry<br>産地(さんち): producing area<br>水産(すいさん): marine products, fisheries<br>生産(せいさん): production, manufacture<br>農産物(のうさんぶつ): agricultural produce<br>破産(はさん): (personal) bankruptcy<br>土産(みやげ): product of the land<br>お土産(おみやげ): souvenir</p> <p id='readingExamples'>産まれる (う.まれる), 産む (う.む), 産 (うぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1682</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1561</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1682</p> <p id='keyword'>hump</p> <p id='kanji'>隆</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99A86.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hump, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, walking legs, life, This is Your Life, cell, drop, grow up</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character, used for everything from little <b>humps</b> of hills to camel <b>humps</b>, easily suggests the hunch on the pig's back and hind parts where the best cuts of meat are to be found (and hence the English expression for luxury, ""living high off the hog."") The elements we have to work with are: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i> . . . <i>cell</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You are struggling to the top across the humps, but you suddenly see the pinnacle and you feel new life in your walking legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A woman takes her bra off and what happens? Nine months later the hump in her belly pops out between her legs as a new life.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1683</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1562</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1683</p> <p id='keyword'>summit</p> <p id='kanji'>峰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B3B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>summit, mountain, Segway, Macbeth, walking legs, bushes</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Mountain . . . walking legs . . . bushes.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Walking legs over ""bushes"" needs to have a primitive meaning of its own. It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 sew (#1563), 逢 tryst (#2417), 蜂 bee (#2687), and 鋒 sword´s point (#2768), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. ""Pointy"" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a summit is the pointy end of a mountain.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Upon reaching the summit of the mountain, I noticed my walking legs were all gouged up from walking through prickly bushes.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みね、ね</p> <p id='words'>峰(みね): peak, ridge</p> <p id='readingExamples'>峰 (みね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

I always have trouble remembering that the bonsai tree is on top, so think of them growing on top of the clouds.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かな.でる</p> <p id='words'>吹奏(すいそう): playing wind instruments<br>演奏(えんそう): musical performance</p> <p id='readingExamples'>奏でる (かな.でる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1694</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1572</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1694</p> <p id='keyword'>reality</p> <p id='kanji'>実</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE9F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>reality, house, bonsai</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . bonsai.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Bonsais are grown in a house, away from the harsh reality of the real world where they wouldn´t survive.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>On this rather boring ´big brother´ type reality show, they have locked up bonsai inside a house and everyone is watching them on TV 24x7. The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジツ、シツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>み、みの.る、まこと、まことに、みの、みち.る</p> <p id='words'>真実(さな): truth, reality<br>実(じつ): truth, reality, sincerity, fidelity, kindness, faith, substance, essence<br>実業家(じつぎょうか): industrialist, businessman<br>実質(じっしつ): substance, essence<br>実情(じつじょう): real condition, actual circumstances, actual state of affairs<br>実践(じっせん): practice, put into practice<br>実態(じったい): truth, fact<br>実は(じつは): as a matter of fact, by the way<br>実費(じっぴ): actual expense, cost price<br>充実(じゅうじつ): fullness, completion, perfection, substantiality, enrichment<br>誠実(せいじつ): sincere, honest, faithful<br>切実(せつじつ): compelling, serious, severe, acute, earnest, pressing, urgent<br>忠実(ちゅうじつ): fidelity, faithfulness<br>確実(かくじつ): certainty, reliability, soundness<br>果実(かじつ): fruit, nut, berry<br>現実(げんじつ): reality<br>口実(こうじつ): excuse<br>事実(じじつ): fact, truth, reality<br>実感(じっかん): feelings (actual, true)<br>実験(じっけん): experiment<br>実現(じつげん): implementation, materialization, realization<br>実行(じっこう): practice, performance, realization, execution (e.g. program)<br>実際(じっさい): practical, actual condition, status quo<br>実施(じっし): enforcement, enact, put into practice, carry out, operation<br>実習(じっしゅう): practice, training<br>実績(じっせき): achievements, actual results<br>実に(じつに): indeed, truly, surely<br>実物(じつぶつ): real thing, original<br>実用(じつよう): practical use, utility<br>実力(じつりょく): merit, efficiency, arms, force<br>実例(じつれい): example, illustration<br>実(み): fruit, nut, seed, content, good result<br>実る(みのる): bear fruit, ripen</p> <p id='readingExamples'>実 (み), 実る (みの.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1695</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1573</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1695</p> <p id='keyword'>dedicate</p> <p id='kanji'>奉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A589.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>observance, dedicate, bonsai, cornstalk</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Bonsai</i> . . . <i>cornstalk</i>. Use a ritualistic, religious meaning.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To join the temple, you have to dedicate yourself to raising bonsai for enlightenment, and cornstalks for sustenance.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A Japanese farmer who was growing corn tried to dedicate himself to the god of corn (in the hope it would bring better harvests). He had a little room with prayer beads, incense, etc. One day he brought an offerand that he thought would please the god of corn : a bonsai - corn (a corn plant turned into a bonsai). The god was infuriated and yelled at him ""HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!"". The End.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホウ、ブ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たてまつ.る、まつ.る、ほう.ずる</p> <p id='words'>奉る(たてまつる): to offer, to present, to revere, to do respectfully<br>奉仕(ほうし): attendance, service</p> <p id='readingExamples'>奉納 (ほうのう), 奉仕 (ほうし), 信奉 (しんぽう), 奉る (たてまつ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Seriously, it´s called ´bolting´ or something. The key word has come to refer to things Chinese in general, including the kanji themselves (for which this character is used).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Sino- (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat/water into learning the kanji. For right-hand kanji primitive - The dumb Western husband of a Japanese woman buys her flowers to apologise, after he opened his big mouth and said ""kanji are a stupid writing system""..</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the water between Japan and China, the Sino- side has put scarecrows in the water to try and keep the Japanese away.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>漢語(かんご): Chinese word, Sino-Japanese word<br>漢和(かんわ): Chinese-Japanese (e.g. dictionary)<br>漢字(かんじ): Chinese characters, kanji</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1709</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1585</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1709</p> <p id='keyword'>ride</p> <p id='kanji'>乗</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B997.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ride, wheat, cereal, silage</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The simplest way to remember this character is to find the sprig of <i>wheat</i> in it, hidden because it doubles up with one stroke of <i>silage</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s a hay ride! You sit on piles of silage and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of wheat sticking out of their mouths.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to ride on biomass fueled vehicles. Good news for those who have wheat silage surplus.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>の.る、-の.り、の.せる</p> <p id='words'>乗客(じょうかく): passenger<br>乗せる(のせる): to place on (something), to take on board, to give a ride, to let (one) take part, to impose on, to record, to mention, to load (luggage), to publish, to run (an ad)<br>乗っ取る(のっとる): to capture, to occupy, to usurp<br>乗り換え(のりかえ): transfer (trains buses etc.)<br>乗り込む(のりこむ): to board, to embark on, to get into (a car), to ship (passengers), to man (a ship), to help (someone) into, to march into, to enter<br>乗客(じょうきゃく): passenger<br>乗車(じょうしゃ): taking a train<br>乗換(のりかえ): transfer (trains, buses, etc.)<br>乗り換える(のりかえる): transfer<br>乗り物(のりもの): vehicle, vessel<br>乗る(のる): get on, get up on, ride in, be taken in, share in, join, feel like doing, be mentioned in, be in harmony with</p> <p id='readingExamples'>乗せる (の.せる), 乗る (の.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1710</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1586</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1710</p> <p id='keyword'>surplus</p> <p id='kanji'>剰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E589B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>surplus, ride, wheat, cereal, silage, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>40</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ride . . . saber.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you go for a ride and find a saber beside you, perhaps you got into an Army surplus jeep.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Remember the wheat we cut with scythes (farmer's equivalent of a saber) for profit (#906)?　Well, we harvested too much and have to use the surplus for silage. 過剰 (かじょう) : excess.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あまつさえ、あま.り、あま.る</p> <p id='words'>過剰(かじょう): excess</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1711</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1587</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1711</p> <p id='keyword'>now</p> <p id='kanji'>今</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BB8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>now, meeting, umbrella, one, 7</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The final stroke of this kanji is a rare shape, which we have not met before and will only meet in this character and others that include it as a primitive. We are more accustomed to seeing it straightened out as part of other shapes - for instance, as the second stroke of <i>mouth</i>. If you need any help at all with this character, you may picture it as two hands of a clock pointing to what time it is <b>now</b>. The element above it, <i>meeting</i>, should easily relate to that image.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* We shall use <i>clock</i> as the primitive meaning of this character, in line with the above explanation.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My MEETING is at 7- but that´s NOW!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(re: ruuku35) The meeting is not at quarter to seven but now!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>コン、キン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いま</p> <p id='words'>今更(いまさら): now, at this late hour<br>今日は(こんにちは): hello, good day (daytime greeting id)<br>今に(いまに): before long, even now<br>今にも(いまにも): at any time, soon<br>今回(こんかい): now, this time, lately<br>今後(こんご): from now on, hereafter<br>今日(こんにち): today<br>今夜(こんや): tonight<br>今度(こんど): next time<br>今(いま): this, now<br>今日(きょう): today, this day<br>今朝(けさ): this morning<br>今年(ことし): this year<br>今月(こんげつ): this month<br>今週(こんしゅう): this week<br>今晩(こんばん): tonight, this evening</p> <p id='readingExamples'>今後 (こんご), 今日 (きょう), 今朝 (けさ), 今年 (こんねん), 昨今 (さっこん), 今 (いま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1712</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1588</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1712</p> <p id='keyword'>include</p> <p id='kanji'>含</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E590AB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>include, now, clock, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Clock . . . mouth.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This clock includes a mouth that will tell you what the time is now. Hearing impaired people have this kind of watches... now imagine them as a big mouth under the clock.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Batteries included with this clock. Open the mouth at the back and insert them after purchase.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふく.む、ふく.める</p> <p id='words'>含む(ふくむ): hold in the mouth, bear in mind, understand, cherish, harbor, contain, comprise, have, hold, include, embrace, be full of<br>含める(ふくめる): include, instruct, make one understand, put in one´s mouth</p> <p id='readingExamples'>含む (ふく.む), 含める (ふく.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1714</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1589</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1714</p> <p id='keyword'>versify</p> <p id='kanji'>吟</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5909F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>versify, mouth, now, clock</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As we have already learned characters for <i>poem</i> (Frame 370), <i>chant</i> (Frame 21), and <i>song</i> (Frame 508), it is important to protect this key word with an image all its own. Its elements are the same as those above; only the position has changed: <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>clock</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Versify this kanji as follows: Hickery dickery dock, the mouth ran by the clock.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To versify, words of rhythm needs to shoot out of your MOUTH with a CLOCK-like regularity.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>吟味(ぎんみ): testing, scrutiny, careful investigation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1717</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1591</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1717</p> <p id='keyword'>harp</p> <p id='kanji'>琴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E790B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>harp, king, jewel, ball, now, clock, king2, jewel2, ball2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A pair of <i>jewels</i> . . . <i>clock</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Two kings were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). Prepare to meet the king of kings now.
