	"<p id='id'>1718</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1592</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1718</p> <p id='keyword'>shade</p> <p id='kanji'>陰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E999B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>shade, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, now, clock, rising cloud, two, elbow, wall</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Just as the <i>sunshine</i> (Frame 1397) represents the masculine principle in nature (Yang), the <b>shade</b> stands for the feminine principle (Yin). Its elements are: <i>pinnacle</i> . . . <i>clock</i> . . . <i>rising cloud</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There are three types of shade: 1. natural (a high pinnacle), 2. man-made buildings (a clock tower), 3. meteorological (a cloud).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Frosty the snowman is running around the pinnacle, staying in the shade. As he looks at his clock to see how much longer he can last, small clouds rise (steam) from his body. Nooo, Frosty!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かげ、かげ.る</p> <p id='words'>陰気(いんき): gloom, melancholy<br>日陰(ひかげ): shadow<br>陰(かげ): shade, shadow, other side</p> <p id='readingExamples'>陰 (かげ), 陰る (かげ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1719</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1593</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1719</p> <p id='keyword'>beforehand</p> <p id='kanji'>予</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BA88.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>beforehand, halberd with stroke missing</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of this character as identical to the <i>halberd</i> (Frame 1311) except that the final stroke has been omitted. Return to that character and devise some image to take this difference into account.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Beforehand, this was a halberd but I cut it short so it could be for hand to hand combat.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Your halberd doesn´t have a handguard? You should have thought of that beforehand (i.e., before you were missing your hand).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨ、シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あらかじ.め</p> <p id='words'>予め(あらかじめ): beforehand, in advance, previously<br>予言(かねごと): prediction, promise, prognostication<br>予感(よかん): presentiment, premonition<br>予想(よそう): expectation, anticipation, prediction, forecast<br>予期(よき): expectation, assume will happen, forecast<br>予算(よさん): estimate, budget<br>予測(よそく): prediction, estimation<br>予備(よび): preparation, preliminaries, reserve, spare<br>予報(よほう): forecast, prediction<br>予防(よぼう): prevention, precaution, protection against<br>天気予報(てんきよほう): weather forecast<br>予習(よしゅう): preparation<br>予定(よてい): plan<br>予約(よやく): reservation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1720</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1594</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1720</p> <p id='keyword'>preface</p> <p id='kanji'>序</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BA8F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>preface, cave, beforehand</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cave . . . beforehand.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The preface to all human history was written beforehand in caves.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Rename the ""beforehand"" part to be glove (because you have to wear gloves beforehand if you want to wield the halberd, which is why this primitive is an incomplete halberd). The story: a winter morning. A textbook author is holed up in his tiny office, a veritable cave. He wants to start his masterpiece textbook by first writing the preface. But he can´t get started. He sits and stares at empty paper until evening. It gets cold and he puts on gloves, shivering, but still unable to start his preface.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つい.で、ついで</p> <p id='words'>秩序(ちつじょ): order, regularity, system, method<br>順序(じゅんじょ): order, sequence, procedure</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1721</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1595</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1721</p> <p id='keyword'>deposit</p> <p id='kanji'>預</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A090.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>deposit, beforehand, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Beforehand . . . head.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Depositing money into your savings account is something you do beforehand if you use your head. If you´re in Japan your passbook says 預金機（よきんき）when you make a deposit.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You bang your head on the ATM, wishing you´d deposited some money beforehand.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あず.ける、あず.かる</p> <p id='words'>預金(よきん): deposit, bank account<br>預かる(あずかる): take charge of, receive deposit<br>預ける(あずける): put in charge of, to deposit</p> <p id='readingExamples'>預かる (あず.かる), 預ける (あず.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1722</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1596</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1722</p> <p id='keyword'>plains</p> <p id='kanji'>野</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9878E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>plains, computer, beforehand</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character refers to rustic life and rustic fields primarily, and from there gets derived meanings. Its elements: <i>computer</i>. . <i>beforehand</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the plains.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The plains are a challenging place to get any work done. Be sure you recharge your computer´s battery beforehand, or you won´t get anything done.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヤ、ショ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>の、の-</p> <p id='words'>視野(しや): field of vision, outlook<br>野外(やがい): fields, outskirts, open air, suburbs<br>野心(やしん): ambition, aspiration, designs, treachery<br>野生(やせい): wild<br>野党(やとう): opposition party<br>野(の): field<br>分野(ぶんや): field, sphere, realm, division, branch<br>平野(へいや): plain, open field<br>野菜(やさい): vegetable</p> <p id='readingExamples'>野 (の)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1723</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1597</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1723</p> <p id='keyword'>concurrently</p> <p id='kanji'>兼</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E585BC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>concurrently, animal horns, rake, stick, stick2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>At the top we have <i>the animal horns</i> and the single horizontal stroke to give them something to hang onto. Below that, we see one <i>rake</i> with two handles. Finally, we see a pair of strokes splitting away from each of the handles, indicating that they are both splitting under the pressure. The composite picture is of someone holding down two jobs <b>concurrently</b>, using the same kit of tools to move in two different directions and ending up in a mess. Take the time to find this sense in the kanji and it will be easy to remember, despite initial appearances.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a rake, is suddenly attacked from both left and right concurrently by bulls with animal horns. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You decide to take the bull by the horns and do both chores concurrently, grabbing your double-handled rake before attempting to clean up both your´s and your neighbours´ garden. But unfortunately, it´s not long until your rake splits in two.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.ねる、-か.ねる</p> <p id='words'>兼ねて(かねて): simultaneously<br>気兼ね(きがね): hesitance, diffidence, feeling constraint, fear of troubling someone, having scruples about doing something<br>兼用(けんよう): multi-use, combined use, combination, serving two purposes<br>兼業(けんぎょう): side line, second business<br>兼ねる(かねる): hold (position), serve, be unable, be beyond one´s ability, cannot, hesitate to, combine with, use with, be impatient</p> <p id='readingExamples'>兼ねる (か.ねる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1724</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1598</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1724</p> <p id='keyword'>dislike</p> <p id='kanji'>嫌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AB8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dislike, woman, concurrently, animal horns, rake</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Woman . . . concurrently.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Naturally, if you´re dating more than one woman concurrently, they will certainly dislike each other!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Attempting to court two women concurrently will make them both dislike you.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン、ゲン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きら.う、きら.い、いや</p> <p id='words'>嫌がる(いやがる): hate, dislike<br>機嫌(きげん): humour, temper, mood<br>嫌う(きらう): hate, dislike, loathe<br>好き嫌い(すききらい): likes and dislikes, taste<br>嫌(いや): disagreeable, detestable, unpleasant, reluctant<br>嫌い(きらい): dislike, hate</p> <p id='readingExamples'>嫌悪 (けんお), 嫌疑 (けんぎ), 嫌 (いや), 嫌う (きら.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1725</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1599</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1725</p> <p id='keyword'>sickle</p> <p id='kanji'>鎌</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98E8C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sickle, metal, gold, concurrently, animal horns, rake</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'>faucile</p> <p id='heisigStory'>Metal . . . concurrently.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is a special sickle with metal blades on both sides. It can cut many things concurrently!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The gold sickle of the USSR flag represents both leaders and workers laboring concurrently.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>レン、ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かま</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>鎌 (かま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1726</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1600</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1726</p> <p id='keyword'>self-effacing</p> <p id='kanji'>謙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AC99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>self-effacing, say, words, keitai, mouth, concurrently, animal horns, rake</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . concurrently.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you are self-effacing you use words to concurrently bring yourself down and make yourself look better.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Though the man´s words were self-effacing, his actions concurrently made it clear that his modesty was false.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>謙る(へりくだる): to deprecate oneself and praise the listener<br>謙虚(けんきょ): modesty, humility<br>謙遜(けんそん): humble, humility, modesty</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1728</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1602</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1728</p> <p id='keyword'>west</p> <p id='kanji'>西</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A5BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>west, one, four</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>41</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>To our way of counting directions, the <b>west</b> always comes fourth. So it is convenient to find the character for <i>four</i> in this kanji. But since we want only <i>one</i> of the <i>four</i> directions, the <b>west</b> adds the <i>one</i> at the top and sucks the <i>human legs</i> a bit out of their <i>mouth</i> in the process.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the meaning of <i>west</i> can be expanded to refer to the <i>Old West</i> of cowboy-movie fame, just as the meaning of the character for <i>east</i> was expanded into <i>the East</i>. Note, however, that in its primitive form the <i>legs</i> are straightened out and reach down to the bottom of the <i>mouth</i>. Hence, we get the shape ⻃. With the exception of one kanji, given in the following frame, this element always appears at the top of its relative primitives.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare sign of the bird (#1427) whiskey bottle about one third full).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note: this kanji is also used to denote Spain.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、サイ、ス</p> <p id='kunYomi'>にし</p> <p id='words'>西日(にしび): westering sun<br>関西(かんさい): Kansai (SW half of Japan, including Osaka)<br>西暦(せいれき): Christian Era, Anno Domini (A.D.)<br>東西(とうざい): East and West, Orient and Occident, whole country, Your attention, please!<br>西洋(せいよう): West, Western countries<br>西(にし): west</p> <p id='readingExamples'>西暦 (せいれき), 西部 (せいぶ), 北西 (ほくせい), 西 (にし)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"

Although (as wrightak said) this kanji really refers to the hips, Heisig clearly chose the keyword ´loins´ because it was anatomically close enough, and the primitives lent themselves to an easy-to-remember story. 	"<p id='id'>1743</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1616</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1743</p> <p id='keyword'>gates</p> <p id='kanji'>門</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99680.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>gates</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The pictograph of two swinging <b>gates</b> is so clear in this kanji that only its stroke order needs to be memorized. In case you should have any trouble, though, you might doodle with the shapes on a piece of paper, taking care to note the difference in the stroke order of the two facing doors. The <b>gates</b> usually serve as an enclosure, and are written BEFORE whatever it is they enclose.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we shall continue to give it the meaning of <i>gates</i>, but recommend the image of swinging doors (like the kind once common at entrances to saloons) to distinguish it from the primitive for <i>door</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Heisig´s stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the ""sun"" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you´ll get the stroke order exactly correct.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The gates to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or ... Bill Gates?</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>モン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かど、と</p> <p id='words'>門(かど): gate<br>正門(せいもん): main gate, main entrance<br>部門(ぶもん): class, group, category, department, field, branch<br>門(もん): gate</p> <p id='readingExamples'>門 (かど)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1744</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1617</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1744</p> <p id='keyword'>question</p> <p id='kanji'>問</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5958F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>question, gates, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Gates . . . mouth.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A mouth on the Gates of Hell says ""Answer me these questions three, or thru the gates ye soon will be"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hark! Who goes there? is the expected question from the mouth of the guard at the gate…　　　RTK2:　モン　質問　しつもん(question).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>モン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.う、と.い、とん</p> <p id='words'>問い合わせる(といあわせる): to enquire, to seek information<br>問屋(といや): wholesale store<br>問う(とう): to ask, to question, to charge (i.e. with a crime), to accuse, without regard to (neg)<br>問(もん): problem, question<br>学問(がくもん): scholarship, study, learning<br>疑問(ぎもん): question, problem, doubt, guess<br>問い(とい): question, query<br>問い合わせ(といあわせ): enquiry<br>訪問(ほうもん): call, visit<br>問答(もんどう): questions and answers, dialogue<br>質問(しつもん): question, inquiry<br>問題(もんだい): problem, question</p> <p id='readingExamples'>問い (と.い), 問う (と.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1745</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1618</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1745</p> <p id='keyword'>review</p> <p id='kanji'>閲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E996B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>review, gates, devil, horns, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Gates</i> . . . <i>devil</i>. Keep the connotation of this key word distinct from those of <i>inspection</i> (Frame 1174), <i>revise</i> (Frame 362), and <i>perusal</i> (Frame 919).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you´re evil enough to get in.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>As I was reviewing for my exam at a quiet saloon, the devil popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that´s cheating. Besides, I´m just reviewing things I already know. I won´t fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance gates.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>けみ.する</p> <p id='words'>閲覧(えつらん): inspection, reading</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1747</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1620</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1747</p> <p id='keyword'>interval</p> <p id='kanji'>間</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99693.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>interval, gates, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Gates</i> . . . <i>sun/day</i>. This <b>interval</b> applies to time and space alike, but the latter is better for creating an image.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>We open the gates at regular intervals to let a bit of sun in.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン、ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あいだ、ま、あい</p> <p id='words'>間柄(あいだがら): relation(ship)<br>合間(あいま): interval<br>空間(あきま): vacancy, room for rent or lease<br>何時の間にか(いつのまにか): before one knows, unnoticed, unawares<br>区間(くかん): section (of track etc)<br>この間(このあいだ): the other day, lately, recently<br>週間(しゅうかん): week, weekly<br>茶の間(ちゃのま): living room (Japanese style)<br>昼間(ちゅうかん): daytime, during the day<br>束の間(つかのま): moment, brief time, brief, transient<br>間違う(まちがう): to make a mistake, to be incorrect, to be mistaken<br>間に合う(まにあう): to be in time (for)<br>間々(まま): occasionally, frequently<br>間もなく(まもなく): soon, before long, in a short time<br>間(あいだ): space, interval<br>居間(いま): living room (Western style)<br>貸間(かしま): room to let<br>間隔(かんかく): space, interval<br>間接(かんせつ): indirectness<br>期間(きかん): period, term<br>客間(きゃくま): parlor, guest room<br>時間割(じかんわり): timetable, schedule<br>瞬間(しゅんかん): moment, second, instant<br>隙間(すきま): crevice, crack, gap, opening<br>世間(せけん): world, society<br>中間(ちゅうかん): middle, midway, interim<br>手間(てま): time, labour<br>床の間(とこのま): alcove<br>仲間(なかま): company, fellow, colleague, associate, comrade, mate, group, circle of friends, partner<br>人間(にんげん): human being, man, person<br>年間(ねんかん): year (interval of time)<br>間(ま): space, room, time, pause<br>間違い(まちがい): mistake<br>民間(みんかん): private, civilian, civil, popular, folk, unofficial<br>夜間(やかん): at night, nighttime<br>昼間(ひるま): daytime, during the daytime<br>間違える(まちがえる): make a mistake<br>時間(じかん): time</p> <p id='readingExamples'>間隔 (かんかく), 中間 (ちゅうかん), 時間 (じかん), 間 (あいだ), 間 (ま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"

Its design is simplicity itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The simplicity of bamboo plant is in all its joints being at equal intervals.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>簡易(かんい): simplicity, easiness, quasi-<br>簡潔(かんけつ): brevity, conciseness, simplicity<br>簡素(かんそ): simplicity, plain<br>簡単(かんたん): easy, simple</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

Needless to say he got wet.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(I had the same idea as Dingomick) I imagine some prankster who put a bucket full of water on top of the huge gates, so that it would fall on the king as he came through them. 	"<p id='id'>1757</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1629</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1757</p> <p id='keyword'>fight</p> <p id='kanji'>闘</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99798.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fight, gates, beans, table, one, mouth, glue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Gates</i> . . . <i>table</i> . . . <i>glue</i>. Do not confuse with <i>contend</i> (Frame 1238).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>During the saloon brawl, one guy got glued to a table and was tossed out through the saloon gates. But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Food fight! Look, beans are stuck to the gates like glue.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たたか.う、あらそ.う</p> <p id='words'>戦闘(せんとう): battle, fight, combat<br>奮闘(ふんとう): hard struggle, strenuous effort</p> <p id='readingExamples'>闘う (たたか.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1758</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1630</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1758</p> <p id='keyword'>godown</p> <p id='kanji'>倉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58089.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>godown, meeting, single gate, umbrella, stable door, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The single <i>gate</i> is used here not in order to represent one <i>gate</i>, but many of them, indeed a <i>meeting of gates</i>. Add <i>mouth</i> (as an entrance here) and you end up with <b>godown</b>. That should help keep this character distinct from <i>warehouse</i> (Frame 633).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A godown is a dockside warehouse. This is actually a meeting of large doors and mouths. The stroke order is the same as door, not gates, just with the top stroke moved down into the now larger door.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note: this is not gate but actually a variation of door and is written as such, with the vertical stroke last not first.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くら</p> <p id='words'>倉庫(そうこ): storehouse, warehouse</p> <p id='readingExamples'>倉 (くら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1759</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1631</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1759</p> <p id='keyword'>genesis</p> <p id='kanji'>創</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E589B5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>genesis, godown, meeting, single gate, umbrella, stable door, mouth, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Godown . . . saber.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I prefer to have girls Godown on my sabre to prevent unwanted GENESIS of babies............創造　そうぞう (creation).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つく.る、はじ.める、きず、けず.しける</p> <p id='words'>創刊(そうかん): launching (e.g. newspaper), first issue<br>創作(そうさく): production, literary creation, work<br>創造(そうぞう): creation<br>創立(そうりつ): establishment, founding, organization<br>独創(どくそう): originality</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1760</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1632</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1760</p> <p id='keyword'>un-</p> <p id='kanji'>非</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99D9E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>un-, jail cell, prison bars</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word, a negating prefix, is a doodle of a heavy iron pole with bars extending in both directions, to create the picture of a jail cell. From there to ""<b>un-</b>"" is but a short step.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, we shall draw on the explanation above for the meaning of <i>jail cell</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That´s an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>People in the jail cell are un-friendly, un-comely, and un-cooperative.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あら.ず</p> <p id='words'>是非とも(ぜひとも): by all means (with sense of not taking ""no"" for an answer)<br>非(ひ): faulty-, non-<br>非行(ひこう): delinquency, misconduct<br>非難(ひなん): blame, attack, criticism<br>是非(ぜひ): certainly, without fail<br>非常(ひじょう): emergency, extraordinary, unusual<br>非常に(ひじょうに): very, greatly</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1761</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1633</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1761</p> <p id='keyword'>haiku</p> <p id='kanji'>俳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BFB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>haiku, person, un-, jail cell, prison bars</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is used for the <b>haiku</b>, the 17-syllable poem that is one of Japan's best-known literary forms. Its elements: <i>person</i> .. . <i>jail cell</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. There are no other doors.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like door at the back of his jail cell, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers ""Which door?"", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - ""The front door !"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とびら</p> <p id='words'>扉(とびら): door, opening</p> <p id='readingExamples'>扉 (とびら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1773</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1644</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1773</p> <p id='keyword'>difference</p> <p id='kanji'>違</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98195.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>difference, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Locket . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they´ve seen it, but no luck. ""Just buy another one,"" someone says. ""I mean, what´s the difference?"" Then of course you say ""Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don´t want a different one! "" Then of course they understand.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An odd version of The Road Less Traveled: ""I found a locket in the road, and that has made all the difference."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ちが.う、ちが.い、ちが.える、-ちが.える、たが.う、たが.える</p> <p id='words'>行き違い(いきちがい): misunderstanding, estrangement, disagreement, crossing without meeting, going astray<br>食い違う(くいちがう): to cross each other, to run counter to, to differ, to clash, to go awry<br>擦れ違い(すれちがい): chance encounter<br>すれ違う(すれちがう): to pass by one another, to disagree, to miss each other<br>違える(ちがえる): to change<br>間違う(まちがう): to make a mistake, to be incorrect, to be mistaken<br>違反(いはん): violation (of law), transgression<br>勘違い(かんちがい): misunderstanding, wrong guess<br>相違(そうい): difference, discrepancy, variation<br>違い(ちがい): difference, discrepancy<br>違いない(ちがいない): sure, no mistaking it, for certain<br>間違い(まちがい): mistake<br>間違える(まちがえる): make a mistake<br>違う(ちがう): differ (from)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>違う (ちが.う), 違える (ちが.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1774</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1645</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1774</p> <p id='keyword'>horizontal</p> <p id='kanji'>緯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B7AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>horizontal, thread, spiderman, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . locket.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The thread that holds the locket around my neck is choker-length so it stays horizontal.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hint : this kanji also means ""latitude"", which are the horizontal lines on a globe. Do you remember James Heisig's story for frame 175 ""black ink"" ? Here a cartographer on a ship, is using his ""thread locket"" to mark horizontal lines on a map. He pulls a chalked thread from the locket, and snaps it to mark horizontal lines. Imagine the ""thread-locket"" in the shape of a globe, filled with dark powder and a little bobbin of thread.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よこいと、ぬき</p> <p id='words'>経緯(いきさつ): details, whole story, sequence of events, particulars, how it started, how things got this way, complications, position<br>緯度(いど): latitude (geography)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1775</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1646</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1775</p> <p id='keyword'>defense</p> <p id='kanji'>衛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A19B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>defence, boulevard, going, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Boulevard</i> . . . <i>locket</i>. 	"<p id='id'>1776</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1647</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1776</p> <p id='keyword'>Korea</p> <p id='kanji'>韓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99F93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>korea, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, locket, stick, key, mouth, monocle, sunglasses with one lens missing, ten2, needle2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>42</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>As with <i>Italy</i> (Frame 1245) and <i>Africa</i> (Frame 1391), this character simply abbreviates the full name of <i>Korea</i>. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama´s picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called ""Winter Sonata"".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This character represents the flag of South Korea: a locket (circular taegeuk) in the middle of the mist (white background). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_South_Korea.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>から、いげた</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1777</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1648</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1777</p> <p id='keyword'>dry</p> <p id='kanji'>干</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B9B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dry, clothesline</p> <p id='strokeCount'>3</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>It is best to see this kanji as a pictograph of a revolving circular clothesline (viewed from the side). Spin it around quickly in your mind's eye to give it the connotation of to <b>dry</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning is <i>clothesline</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note: the book shows the strokes for potato rather than dry...dry does not have the hook at the end.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ほ.す、ほ.し-、-ぼ.し、ひ.る</p> <p id='words'>梅干(うめぼし): dried plum<br>干渉(かんしょう): interference, intervention<br>若干(じゃっかん): some, few, number of<br>干し物(ほしもの): dried washing (clothes)<br>干す(ほす): to air, dry, desiccate, drain (off), drink up</p> <p id='readingExamples'>干る (ひ.る), 干す (ほ.す)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1783</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1654</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1783</p> <p id='keyword'>tree trunk</p> <p id='kanji'>幹</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B9B9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tree trunk, mist, ten, needle, early, sun, day, umbrella, dry, clothesline, ten2, needle2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Mist</i> . . . <i>umbrella</i> . . . <i>dry</i>. The meaning of this key word extends beyond <b>tree trunks</b> to represent the main stem or line of anything from railway lines to managerial staffs. This should help distinguish it from the stories used earlier for <i>book</i> (Frame 224) and <i>body</i> (Frame 1030), both of which made use of the image of a <b>tree trunk</b>, as well as the kanji for <i>trunk</i> (Frame 194).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みき</p> <p id='words'>幹(かん): (tree) trunk<br>幹線(かんせん): main line, trunk line<br>幹部(かんぶ): management, (executive) staff, leaders<br>新幹線(しんかんせん): bullet train</p> <p id='readingExamples'>幹 (みき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1785</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1656</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1785</p> <p id='keyword'>eaves</p> <p id='kanji'>宇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE87.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>eaves, house, potato</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . potato.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>宇宙(うちゅう): universe, cosmos, space</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1786</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1657</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1786</p> <p id='keyword'>too much</p> <p id='kanji'>余</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BD99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>too much, umbrella, potato, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Umbrella</i> . . . <i>potato</i> . . . <i>little</i>. The last stroke of <i>potato</i> and the first of <i>little</i> coincide in this character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Since the phrase ""<i>too much</i>"" is overly abstract, we shall take the image of a <i>scale</i> whose indicator spins round and round on the dial because <i>too much</i> weight has been set on it. It will help to use this image in learning the kanji itself.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol "">"" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using two (#2) and little (#105) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means ""two much"" (more than 2) or ""two little"". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あま.る、あま.り、あま.す、あんま.り</p> <p id='words'>余り(あんまり): not very (this form only used as adverb), not much, remainder, rest, remnant, surplus, balance, excess, remains, scraps, residue, fullness, other, too much<br>余暇(よか): leisure, leisure time, spare time<br>余興(よきょう): side show, entertainment<br>余所見(よそみ): looking away, looking aside<br>余地(よち): place, room, margin, scope<br>余程(よっぽど): very, greatly, much, to a large extent, quite<br>余り(あまり): remainder, remnant, surplus, balance, excess, scraps, residue<br>余り(あまり): not very, not much<br>余る(あまる): remain, be left over, be too many<br>余計(よけい): too much, unnecessary, abundance, surplus, excess<br>余所(よそ): another place, somewhere else, strange parts<br>余分(よぶん): extra, excess, surplus<br>余裕(よゆう): surplus, composure, margin, room, time, allowance, scope, rope</p> <p id='readingExamples'>余す (あま.す), 余る (あま.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1787</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1658</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1787</p> <p id='keyword'>exclude</p> <p id='kanji'>除</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E999A4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>exclude, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pinnacle . . . scale.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You won´t make it unless you exclude something. 	"<p id='id'>1789</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1660</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1789</p> <p id='keyword'>confer</p> <p id='kanji'>叙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>confer, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Scale</i> . . <i>crotch</i>. The key word has to do with <b>conferring</b> ranks, titles, and awards. It should not be confused with <i>bestow</i> (Frame 1335) or <i>impart</i> (Frame 795).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If there is such a thing as too much crotch, the guy who gets that much should have an honor conferred upon him.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つい.ず、ついで</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1790</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1661</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1790</p> <p id='keyword'>route</p> <p id='kanji'>途</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98094.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>route, scales, too much, umbrella, potato, small, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Scale . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There are too many roads, so you need to plan a route.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ト</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みち</p> <p id='words'>前途(ぜんと): future prospects, outlook, the journey ahead<br>途中(つちゅう): on the way, en route<br>途上(とじょう): en route, half way<br>途絶える(とだえる): to stop, to cease, to come to an end<br>中途(ちゅうと): in the middle, half-way<br>途端(とたん): just (now, at the moment, etc.)<br>用途(ようと): use, usefulness<br>途中(とちゅう): on the way</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1793</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1664</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1793</p> <p id='keyword'>bundle</p> <p id='kanji'>束</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69D9F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bundle, Chaplin, tree, wood, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In the same way that we were able to see the <i>sun</i> in the <i>tree</i> within the kanji for <i>east</i>, here we see a square container in the shape of a <i>mouth</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn´t drop the bundle.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Unlike in 杏, this big mouth isn´t content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in bundles.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たば、たば.ねる、つか、つか.ねる</p> <p id='words'>結束(けっそく): union, unity<br>拘束(こうそく): restriction, restraint<br>束縛(そくばく): restraint, shackles, restriction, confinement, binding<br>束の間(つかのま): moment, brief time, brief, transient<br>束(たば): bundle, bunch, sheaf, coil<br>約束(やくそく): promise</p> <p id='readingExamples'>束 (たば)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"

Think of the <b>order</b> here as a mail <b>order</b> or an <b>order</b> of pizza phoned in by the Emperor for delivery to the <b>imperial</b> palace. Then it will not be hard to put together <i>bundle</i> and <i>muscle</i> to form a story about an <b>imperial order</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is an imperial order for pizza. Note that the element for <i>zoo</i> is flattened out on the left just as <i>leg</i> (Frame 1372) had been. This is the only time we will meet this form in this book.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>[True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji is so strange that it was alienated at the kanji zoo. The bundle of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ、ショ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うと.い、うと.む、まば.ら</p> <p id='words'>疎か(おろそか): neglect, negligence, carelessness<br>過疎(かそ): depopulation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>疎い (うと.い), 疎む (うと.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1801</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1671</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1801</p> <p id='keyword'>saber</p> <p id='kanji'>剣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E589A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sabre, saber, awl, fit, meeting, umbrella, mouth, person, sword, sabre, saber</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Awl</i> . . . <i>saber</i>. As we promised way back in frame 87, here at last is the kanji on which the primitive element of the same name is based.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They´re basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of ""The Awl and the Sabre"". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill. And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : ""The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can´t use the sabre."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つるぎ</p> <p id='words'>真剣(しんけん): seriousness, earnestness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>剣 (つるぎ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Once at the top it is so precipitous that the person is afraid to climb down and instead punctures the inflatable pinnacle with an awl to get safely and slowly back to the ground.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>けわ.しい</p> <p id='words'>保険(ほけん): insurance, guarantee<br>険しい(けわしい): inaccessible place, impregnable position, steep place, sharp eyes<br>冒険(ぼうけん): risk, venture, adventure<br>危険(きけん): danger</p> <p id='readingExamples'>険しい (けわ.しい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1803</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1673</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1803</p> <p id='keyword'>examination</p> <p id='kanji'>検</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A49C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>examination, tree, wood, awl, fit, meeting, umbrella, mouth, person</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . awl.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>After intense cross-examination from the prosecutor, the tree confessed to murdering the wood-pecker with an awl... ""He just kept at it, he kept poking at me with that beak, so I thought I'd see how HE liked it!!"" The autopsy examination revealed at least a dozen puncture wounds, what a brutal case.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Don´t confuse with exam (#1278), test (#354), evaluate (#1487). Think of examination as a doctor´s examination. You´re having problems getting wood in bed. You go in for a doctor´s examination. The doctor shoves an icepick into your manhood as part of the examination.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しら.べる</p> <p id='words'>検事(けんじ): public prosecutor<br>探検(たんけん): exploration, expedition<br>点検(てんけん): inspection, examination, checking<br>検査(けんさ): inspection (e.g. customs, factory), examination<br>検討(けんとう): consideration, examination, investigation, study, scrutiny</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Khatzumoto needs to be frugal after spending all his money on Japanese media and none on food. 	"<p id='id'>1805</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1675</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1805</p> <p id='keyword'>heavy</p> <p id='kanji'>重</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9878D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>heavy, thousand, computer, rice field, brains, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>43</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Thousand</i> . . . <i>ri</i>. Note how the long vertical stroke doubles up to serve both elements.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To me it looks like a car with two extra wheels, like a truck. As it is a very heavy vehicle I suggest an image of a huge mining truck, like the yellow Liebherr T282B. Remember that the first ""wheel"" is a bit bent. http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュウ、チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>え、おも.い、おも.り、おも.なう、かさ.ねる、かさ.なる、おも</p> <p id='words'>重(え): -fold, -ply<br>重なる(おもなる): main, principal, important<br>重役(おもやく): heavy responsibilities, director<br>重んじる(おもんじる): to respect, to honor, to esteem, to prize<br>重んずる(おもんずる): to honor, to respect, to esteem, to prize<br>重複(じゅうふく): duplication, repetition, overlapping, redundancy, restoration<br>重宝(じゅうほう): priceless treasure, convenience, usefulness<br>比重(ひじゅう): specific gravity<br>重たい(おもたい): heavy, massive, serious, important, severe, oppressed<br>重なる(かさなる): be piled up, lie on top of one another, overlap each other<br>重ねる(かさねる): pile up, add, repeat<br>貴重(きちょう): precious, valuable<br>厳重(げんじゅう): strict, severe, firm, strong, secure, rigour<br>重視(じゅうし): importance, stress, serious consideration<br>重体(じゅうたい): seriously ill, serious condition, critical state<br>重大(じゅうだい): serious, important, grave, weighty<br>重点(じゅうてん): important point, lay stress on, emphasis, colon<br>重役(じゅうやく): heavy responsibilities, director<br>重要(じゅうよう): important, momentous, essential, principal, major<br>重量(じゅうりょう): weight, heavyweight boxer<br>重力(じゅうりょく): gravity<br>慎重(しんちょう): discretion, prudence<br>尊重(そんちょう): respect, esteem, regard<br>重い(おもい): heavy, massive, serious, important, severe, oppressed</p> <p id='readingExamples'>重量 (じゅうりょう), 重大 (じゅうだい), 二重 (にじゅう), 重 (え), 重い (おも.い), 重なる (かさ.なる), 重ねる (かさ.ねる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"

Imagine seeing footage of a place where those sickness-missiles are built : rows after rows of missiles, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different sickness such as ""flu"", ""plague"", etc.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>SICKNESS / MISSILE ** Hint: True fact about biochemical warfare: in the medieval and ancient world, SICKNESS in the form of the corpses of those who had died from some EPIDEMIC or plague were often hurled at the enemy via the crude MISSILE launchers of the time. [C].</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エキ、ヤク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>疫病 (えきびょう), 悪疫 (あくえき), 防疫 (ぼうえき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1825</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1690</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1825</p> <p id='keyword'>pain</p> <p id='kanji'>痛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7979B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pain, sickness, hospital, pogo stick, chop-seal, hanko, utilise, utilize</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Sickness . . . chop-seal . . . utilize.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of the phrase pain in the xxx. Then think of a pogostick up your xxx. That's painful, right? The real question is why a pogostick is up your xxx. That's sick, dude.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When I was feeling sick my mum said I shouldn´t go out to play on my pogo stick until I felt better. Well I wasn´t strong enough to stay up on it and so fell over and have the pain to prove my mum right.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ツウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いた.い、いた.む、いた.ましい、いた.める</p> <p id='words'>痛む(いたむ): to hurt, to feel a pain, to be injured<br>痛める(いためる): to hurt, to injure, to cause pain, to worry, to bother, to afflict, to be grieved over<br>痛感(つうかん): feeling keenly, fully realizing<br>痛切(つうせつ): keen, acute<br>痛み(いたみ): pain, ache, sore, grief, distress<br>苦痛(くつう): pain, agony<br>頭痛(ずつう): headache<br>痛い(いたい): painful</p> <p id='readingExamples'>痛い (いた.い), 痛む (いた.む), 痛める (いた.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1826</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1691</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1826</p> <p id='keyword'>mannerism</p> <p id='kanji'>癖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79996.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mannerism, sickness, hospital, ketchup, flag, mouth, spicy, stand up, vase, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Sickness . . . ketchup.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Caveman has a bad mannerism of putting ketchup on everything he eats. 	"<p id='id'>1830</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1695</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1830</p> <p id='keyword'>equal</p> <p id='kanji'>匹</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58CB9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>equal, box, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Box . . . human legs.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL´S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He´s probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Imagine a magician doing that trick where he puts his assistant in a box and proceeds to saw her in half. Don’t the human legs sticking horizontally out of the box remind you of an equal sign?</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひき</p> <p id='words'>匹(ひき): head, small animal counter, roll of cloth<br>匹敵(ひってき): comparing with, match, rival, equal</p> <p id='readingExamples'>匹 (ひき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1831</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1696</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1831</p> <p id='keyword'>ward</p> <p id='kanji'>区</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58CBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ward, box, sheaf</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>ward</b> referred to here is a subdivision of a large city. Its elements: <i>box</i> . . . <i>sheaves</i>. When used as a primitive element, it may be helpful at times to break it up into these same composite elements.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the homeless ward of the city you see people sleeping in CARDBOARD BOXES using a SHEAF as a pillow.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>That´s the homeless ward of the city. Do not confuse with <i>rise up</i> (Frame 43).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to ASCEND to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When I was a kid I went out camping in a teepee. I ate beans for dinner, and afterwards I produced so much gas that my teepee actually ascended in the air!</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ、ト、ドウ、ショウ、チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>のぼ.る、あ.がる</p> <p id='words'>登校(とうこう): attendance (at school)<br>登録(とうろく): registration, register, entry, record<br>登場(とうじょう): entry (on stage), appearance (on screen), entrance, introduction (into a market)<br>登山(とざん): mountain climbing<br>登る(のぼる): climb<div>登壇(とうだん): plateform</div><div>登記(とうき): registration</div></p> <p id='readingExamples'>登壇 (とうだん), 登校 (とうこう), 登記 (とうき), 登る (のぼ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1839</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1704</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1839</p> <p id='keyword'>lucidity</p> <p id='kanji'>澄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6BE84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lucidity, water, water droplets, water pistol, ascend, teepee, wigwam, beans, table, one, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . ascend.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Scuba divers know that when you ascend in the water, your lucidity increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A few drops of acid/peyote and the Indians obtain lucidity on their vision quest, as if they were floating in the lucid sky.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>す.む、す.ます、-す.ます</p> <p id='words'>澄ます(すます): to clear, to make clear, to be unruffled, to look unconcerned, to look demure, look prim, put on airs<br>澄む(すむ): to clear (e.g. weather), to become transparent</p> <p id='readingExamples'>澄ます (す.ます), 澄む (す.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1840</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1705</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1840</p> <p id='keyword'>discharge</p> <p id='kanji'>発</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E799BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>discharge, teepee, wigwam, two, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word refers to the <b>discharging</b> of guns, trains, people, and even words. The elements: <i>teepee</i> . . . <i>two</i> . . . <i>human legs</i>. Contrast the writing with frame 63.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Two pairs of human legs poking out of a teepee: you know there´ll be a discharge soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I spent some time in her TEEPEE...just the TWO of us...but I looked between her HUMAN LEGS and I saw a nasty DISCHARGE...so I made my 出発　rather hastily.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハツ、ホツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>た.つ、あば.く、おこ.る、つか.わす、はな.つ</p> <p id='words'>開発(かいはつ): development, exploitation<br>活発(かっぱつ): vigor, active<br>再発(さいはつ): return, relapse, reoccurrence<br>始発(しはつ): first train<br>発(はつ): departure, beginning, counter for gunshots<br>発育(はついく): (physical) growth, development<br>発芽(はつが): burgeoning<br>発掘(はっくつ): excavation, exhumation<br>発言(はつげん): utterance, speech, proposal<br>発生(はっせい): outbreak, spring forth, occurrence, incidence, origin<br>発足(はっそく): starting, inauguration<br>発病(はつびょう): attack (disease)<br>発条(ばね): spring (e.g. coil leaf)<br>反発(はんぱつ): repelling, rebound, recover, oppose<br>発作(ほっさ): fit, spasm<br>蒸発(じょうはつ): evaporation, unexplained disappearance<br>発つ(たつ): depart (on a plane, train, etc.)<br>爆発(ばくはつ): explosion, detonation, eruption<br>発揮(はっき): exhibition, demonstration, utilization, display<br>発見(はっけん): discovery, detection, finding<br>発行(はっこう): issue (publications)<br>発車(はっしゃ): departure of a vehicle<br>発射(はっしゃ): firing, shooting, discharge, catapult<br>発想(はっそう): expression (music), conceptualization<br>発達(はったつ): development, growth<br>発展(はってん): development, growth<br>発電(はつでん): generation (e.g. power)<br>発売(はつばい): sale<br>発表(はっぴょう): announcement, publication<br>発明(はつめい): invention<br>出発(しゅっぱつ): depart<br>発音(はつおん): pronunciation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>発明 (はつめい), 発射 (はっしゃ), 突発 (とっぱつ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1841</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1706</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1841</p> <p id='keyword'>abolish</p> <p id='kanji'>廃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BB83.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>abolish, cave, dicharge, teepee, wigwam, two, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cave . . . discharge.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Slaves have been discharged from the caves where they were kept thanks to the abolition of slavery.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Guns were abolished, so gun enthusiats left for the hills to discharge their guns in caves.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すた.れる、すた.る</p> <p id='words'>荒廃(こうはい): ruin<br>廃れる(すたれる): to go out of use, to become obsolete, to die out, to go out of fashion<br>廃棄(はいき): annullment, disposal, abandon, scrap, discarding, repeal<br>廃止(はいし): abolition, repeal</p> <p id='readingExamples'>廃る (すた.る), 廃れる (すた.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1842</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1707</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1842</p> <p id='keyword'>colleague</p> <p id='kanji'>僚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5839A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>colleague, person, pup tent, large, St. Bernard, sun, day, small, little</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Person</i> . . . <i>pup tent</i>. Choose some connotation of the key word that will keep it distinct for you from <i>companion</i> (Frame 19), <i>friend</i> (Frame 760), <i>consort</i> (Frame 1287), and <i>comrade</i> (Frame 1765).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A colleague implies someone that you share work with, such as in your company or profession, etc. Here your colleague helps you to erect your pup tent during a company outing. Note: Heisig's warning to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as companion (#19), friend (#704), consort (#1203) and comrade (#1637). That is why I chose to have the person element pictured as someone (the colleague in this case) helping with the work of building the pup tent.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T began working in a japanese compagny. As he sees that his colleague accept to do some extra work during the week-end and even sleep at the office, he says to them: ""I pity da fool who work during week-end! You might as well install a pup tent in the office and forget about your home"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>官僚(かんりょう): bureaucrat, bureaucracy<br>同僚(どうりょう): coworker, colleague, associate</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1844</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1708</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1844</p> <p id='keyword'>dormitory</p> <p id='kanji'>寮</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AFAE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dormitory, house, pup tent, large, St. Bernard, sun, day, small, little</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . pup tent.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A dormitory is right in the middle between living in a house and living in a pup tent.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This guy would rather use his pup-tent as a house, than sleep in the dormitory. So he effectively turned that pup-tent into a house by getting a postal address for it etc. (just to emphasize house).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>寮(りょう): hostel, dormitory</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1855</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1719</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1855</p> <p id='keyword'>swell</p> <p id='kanji'>膨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E886A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>swell, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, drum, samurai, beans, table, one, mouth, shape</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Part of the body</i> . . . <i>drum</i> . . . <i>shape</i>. Compare <i>expand</i> (Frame 1199).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji does not mean swell as in a inflammation. There is a different kanji for that meaning (腫れる). This kanji means swell as in, a tire swelling/expanding, your income swelling/expanding, dough swelling/expanding, etc. Johnskb's story is best b/c it does not involve swelling in the sense of inflammation, just general expansion of the stomach. STORY: ""If a PART OF your BODY begins to SWELL/EXPAND and resembles the SHAPE of a bass DRUM, you’re either pregnant or in desperate need of a diet."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Which part of your body can change shape and, when it does, swells up and throbs like a drumb? Hmmm...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふく.らむ、ふく.れる</p> <p id='words'>膨れる(ふくれる): to get cross, to get sulky, to swell (out), to expand, to be inflated, to distend, to bulge<br>膨脹(ぼうちょう): expansion, swelling, increase, growth<br>膨らます(ふくらます): swell, expand, inflate, bulge<br>膨らむ(ふくらむ): expand, get big, become inflated<br>膨大(ぼうだい): huge, bulky, enormous, extensive, swelling, expansion</p> <p id='readingExamples'>膨らむ (ふく.らむ), 膨れる (ふく.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1856</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1720</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1856</p> <p id='keyword'>visit</p> <p id='kanji'>参</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58F82.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>nonplussed, visit, elbow, large, St. Bernard, shape</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Elbow . . . St. Bernard dog . . . shape.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I´m going to visit my grandpa in the hospital. He broke his elbow, and it became really big and contorted into a weird shape. I hope he will be all right!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Whenever the postman has to pay a visit to this place, he brings an elbow-shaped thingy that he throws to the St. Bernard.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サン、シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まい.る、まい-、まじわる、みつ</p> <p id='words'>参議院(さんぎいん): House of Councillors<br>参照(さんしょう): reference, consultation, consultation<br>参上(さんじょう): calling on, visiting<br>お参り(おまいり): worship, shrine visit<br>参加(さんか): participation<br>参考(さんこう): reference, consultation<br>持参(じさん): bringing, taking, carrying<br>参る(まいる): come (polite )</p> <p id='readingExamples'>参る (まい.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1857</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1721</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1857</p> <p id='keyword'>wretched</p> <p id='kanji'>惨</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E683A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wretched, Freud, state of mind, nonplussed, visit, elbow, large, St. Bernard, shape</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>A state of mind . . . visit.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Whenever I have to visit the relatives... that puts me in one hell of a wretched state of mind.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Data feels wretched because he has no family to visit.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サン、ザン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みじ.め、いた.む、むご.い</p> <p id='words'>悲惨(ひさん): misery<br>惨め(みじめ): miserable</p> <p id='readingExamples'>惨劇 (さんげき), 悲惨 (ひさん), 陰惨 (いんさん), 惨め (みじ.め)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1859</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1723</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1859</p> <p id='keyword'>rare</p> <p id='kanji'>珍</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78F8D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rare, king, jewel, ball, parasol, umbrella, shape</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Jewel . . . umbrella . . . shape.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It's rare to see the king carrying his own parasol - typically he gets one of his attendants to do it for him (thanks to Katsuo for umbrella + shape = parasol and to Peppi for the story idea).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tip: umbrella + shape : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it may be worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest ""parasol"" (because it is the same shape as an umbrella). REF: rare (FRAME 1723) , check-up (#1724), measles (#2574), fallible (#2720).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>めずら.しい、たから</p> <p id='words'>珍しい(めずらしい): unusual, strange</p> <p id='readingExamples'>珍しい (めずら.しい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1860</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1724</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1860</p> <p id='keyword'>checkup</p> <p id='kanji'>診</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A8BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>check up, say, words, keitai, mouth, parasol, umbrella, shape</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Words</i> . . . <i>umbrella</i> . . . <i>shape</i>. [Umbrella over shape = parasol].</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The doctor at my checkup was expressing words of concern about my umbrella shaped gut.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>み.る</p> <p id='words'>診療(しんりょう): medical examination and treatment, diagnosis<br>聴診器(ちょうしんき): stethoscope<br>診察(しんさつ): medical examination<br>診断(しんだん): diagnosis<br>診る(みる): (medicine) examine</p> <p id='readingExamples'>診る (み.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1861</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1725</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1861</p> <p id='keyword'>sentence</p> <p id='kanji'>文</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69687.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sentence, plaid, kilt, Billy Connolly</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Under the familiar <i>top hat</i> we see a crisscross pattern or design, like that found on woodwork or garments. This should make an ugly enough image to help remember it. It can be associated with <b>sentence</b> by thinking of a <b>sentence</b> as a grammatical pattern.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning for this character will be <i>plaid</i>, the familiar crisscross pattern frequently used in textiles.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct sentences, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The teacher in the tophat puts an X on all the grammatically incorrect sentences.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ブン、モン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふみ、あや</p> <p id='words'>原文(げんぶん): the text, original<br>注文(ちゅうもん): order, request<br>文(ふみ): letter, writings<br>文化財(ぶんかざい): cultural assets, cultural property<br>文語(ぶんご): written language, literary language<br>文書(ぶんしょ): document, writing, letter, note, records, archives<br>本文(ほんぶん): text (of document), body (of letter)<br>文字(もじ): letter (of alphabet), character<br>和文(わぶん): Japanese text, sentence in Japanese<br>英文(えいぶん): sentence in English<br>人文科学(じんぶんかがく): social sciences, humanities<br>文(ぶん): sentence<br>文芸(ぶんげい): literature, art and literature<br>文献(ぶんけん): literature, books (reference)<br>文章(ぶんしょう): sentence, article<br>文体(ぶんたい): literary style<br>文房具(ぶんぼうぐ): stationery<br>文脈(ぶんみゃく): context<br>文明(ぶんめい): civilization, culture<br>文句(もんく): phrase, complaint<br>論文(ろんぶん): thesis, essay, treatise, paper<br>文化(ぶんか): culture<br>文学(ぶんがく): literature<br>文法(ぶんぽう): grammar<br>作文(さくぶん): composition, writing</p> <p id='readingExamples'>文学 (ぶんがく), 文化 (ぶんか), 作文 (さくぶん), 文 (ふみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_1</p>"

He reached down and adjusted the two things between his skinny fencepost legs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>HINT: this kanji as a primitive can mean goalkeeper. The ""fence posts"" are goalposts, and the two goalkeepers wear plaid uniforms (this kanji also means uniform as in even), making them uniform with each other and distinguishing them as goalkeepers from the rest of the team.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、サイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>そろ.う、ひと.しい、ひと.しく、あたる、はやい</p> <p id='words'>一斉(いっせい): simultaneous</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Take special care to draw this character in the same order as the primitive. Note too, that the fourth stroke for <i>rice</i> is already taken care of by the fourth stroke of <i>rake</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Even though it´s a maddening task, the monks stay solemn as they rake rice between the fenceposts.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note: This is not sieve as it has a full rice and not rice grains and the hook is missing from rake. Also the given stroke order is incorrect (fenceposts should come last).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュク、スク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つつし.む</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1871</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1734</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1871</p> <p id='keyword'>bases</p> <p id='kanji'>塁</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A181.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bases, rice field, brains, sparkler, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji of this frame refers to the four <b>bases</b> that are placed at the corners of a baseball infield. The elements: <i>field</i> . . . <i>sparkler</i> . . . <i>ground</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Playing baseball in a rice field with sparklers stuck into the ground to act as bases.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The traditional New Year´s baseball game in Japan is held at midnight in a rice field. They stick sparklers in the ground for the bases so they can be seen, and to be more festive.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ルイ、ライ、スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とりで</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1872</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1735</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1872</p> <p id='keyword'>music</p> <p id='kanji'>楽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A5BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>music, white, dove, sparkler, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Dove . . . sparkler . . . tree.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Zelda: Ocarina of Time - The white sparkly thing is Navi. 	"<p id='id'>1874</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1737</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1874</p> <p id='keyword'>ratio</p> <p id='kanji'>率</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78E87.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ratio, mysterious, question mark, top hat, cocoon, sparkler, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Mysterious</i> . . . <i>sparkler</i> . . . <i>ten</i>. Physicists have been studying this effect for decades, known as the Sparkler Effect, and using it to explain why stars look like sparklers in the night sky.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It's mysterious how there's always a ratio of ten sparklers to one package.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソツ、リツ、シュツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひき.いる</p> <p id='words'>軽率(けいそつ): rash, thoughtless, careless, hasty<br>効率(こうりつ): efficiency<br>率直(そっちょく): frankness, candour, openheartedness<br>統率(とうそつ): command, lead, generalship, leadership<br>倍率(ばいりつ): diameter, magnification<br>率いる(ひきいる): to lead, to spearhead (a group), to command (troops)<br>比率(ひりつ): ratio, proportion, percentage<br>確率(かくりつ): probability<br>能率(のうりつ): efficiency<br>率(りつ): rate, ratio, proportion, percentage</p> <p id='readingExamples'>率先 (そっせん), 引率 (いんそつ), 軽率 (けいそつ), 率いる (ひき.いる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

The two strokes of the <i>dagger</i> take the place of the middle stroke of <i>little</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive on the left, this kanji keeps the same form. Elsewhere, the first two strokes are abbreviated to a single dot. This latter form will take the meaning of an <i>apple</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>He was stabbed with a dagger, and little drops of red blood dropped onto the ground.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>There was red all over the soil after Little Red Riding Hood plunged a dagger into the wolf. 	"<p id='id'>1887</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1750</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1887</p> <p id='keyword'>yellow</p> <p id='kanji'>黄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9BB84.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>yellow, salad, sprout, shoot, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>45</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Salad . . . sprout . . . animal legs.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The salad did not look very appetizing... My salad then arrives . . . . topped with these horribly gnarled yellow things. Chicken feet! (animal legs) ugh.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ、オウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>き、こ-</p> <p id='words'>黄金(おうごん): gold<br>黄色(おうしょく): yellow<br>黄色(きいろ): the color yellow (noun)<br>黄色い(きいろい): yellow</p> <p id='readingExamples'>黄葉 (こうよう), 黄 (き)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1894</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1757</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1894</p> <p id='keyword'>sweet</p> <p id='kanji'>甘</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79498.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sweet, wicker basket, picnic basket</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>46</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji is a pictograph of a small wicker basket. (The extra short stroke in the middle helps keep it distinct from the character for <i>twenty</i>.) All one needs to add is some image of <b>sweet</b> cakes or breads carried in the basket, and the union of picture and meaning is complete. Take care not to confuse with <i>confectionary</i> (Frame 1203).</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, the pictograph's meaning of a <i>wicker basket</i> is used, a small one like the kind used for picnics.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with sweet baked cookies for granny.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Girls are kinda sweet and sexy until they reach their twenties. So 20 minus ONE.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あま.い、あま.える、あま.やかす、うま.い</p> <p id='words'>甘える(あまえる): to behave like a spoiled child, to fawn on<br>甘口(あまくち): sweet flavour, mildness, flattery, stupidity<br>甘い(うまい): delicious<br>甘やかす(あまやかす): pamper, spoil<br>甘い(あまい): delicious</p> <p id='readingExamples'>甘い (あま.い), 甘える (あま.える), 甘やかす (あま.やかす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
