The key word refers to the Japanese game played with black and white colored <i>stones</i> on a lined board.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Go is chess played with stones.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The ignorant gaijin put a rook on top of his opponent´s stone when playing Go, much to the consternation of the Japanese players.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>碁盤(ごばん): Go board<br>碁(ご): go (board game)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1904</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1767</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1904</p> <p id='keyword'>fundamentals</p> <p id='kanji'>基</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59FBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fundamentals, bushel basket, hamper, animal legs, eight, soil, dirt, ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>46</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bushel basket . . . soil.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Fundamentals of chess: use the rooks to protect your ground.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A Bushel-basket full of earth contains the fundementals of farming. i.e. earth.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>もと、もとい</p> <p id='words'>基金(ききん): fund, foundation<br>基準(きじゅん): standard, basis, criteria, norm<br>基(もとい): basis<br>基礎(きそ): foundation, basis<br>基地(きち): base<br>基盤(きばん): foundation, basis<br>基本(きほん): foundation, basis, standard<br>基(もと): basis<br>基づく(もとづく): be grounded on, be based on, be due to, originate from</p> <p id='readingExamples'>基 (もと), 基 (もとい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1905</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1768</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1905</p> <p id='keyword'>tremendously</p> <p id='kanji'>甚</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7949A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tremendously, bushel basket, hamper, equal, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>46</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Bushel basket</i> . . . <i>equal</i>. Note how the first stroke of <i>equal</i> doubles up with the sixth stroke of the <i>bushel basket</i>, and how the <i>animal legs</i> of the <i>bushel basket</i> are dropped to make room for the <i>human legs</i> of <i>equal</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It´s a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother´s equal.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>These two bushel baskets are tremendously huge. But not only they are huge, they are also perfectly equal in size.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はなは.だ、はなは.だしい</p> <p id='words'>甚だ(はなはだ): very, greatly, exceedingly<br>甚だしい(はなはだしい): extreme, excessive, terrible, intense, severe, serious, tremendous</p> <p id='readingExamples'>甚だ (はなは.だ), 甚だしい (はなは.だしい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Furthermore, they don´t even have to think, really. Their intuition takes control. 	"<p id='id'>1910</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1773</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1910</p> <p id='keyword'>dispatch</p> <p id='kanji'>遣</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E981A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dispatch, purse, in, one, floor, maestro without baton, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>46</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji takes away the <i>maestro</i>'s baton and replaces it with a <i>purse</i>. The <i>road</i> represents his being <b>dispatched</b> on his way a san obvious misfit. You will remember that when he did have his baton, he was being <i>chased</i> down the road by his fans. All of which shows what a difference a single stroke can make!</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Bond has stolen a lady spy's purse while she was asleep after their evening together. When she discovers it's gone, she dispatches some henchmen on the road after him to dispatch him, but Bond evades them and escapes with the purse.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Apart from meaning DISPATCH, this kanji can mean ""to give (to someone lower than you),"" ""to do,"" and to even ""have intercourse."" STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to DISPATCH some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO´S baton? You don´t wanna know...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つか.う、-つか.い、-づか.い、つか.わす、や.る</p> <p id='words'>遣い(つかい): mission, simple task, doing<br>派遣(はけん): dispatch, send<br>無駄遣い(むだづかい): waste money on, squander money on, flog a dead horse<br>遣り通す(やりとおす): to carry through, to achieve, to complete<br>遣る(やる): to do, to have sexual intercourse, to kill, to give (to inferiors animals etc.), to dispatch (a letter), to send, to study, to perform, to play (sports game), to have (eat drink smoke), to row (a boat), to run or operate (a restaurant)<br>仮名遣い(かなづかい): kana orthography, syllabary spelling<br>小遣い(こづかい): personal expenses, pocket money, spending money, incidental expenses, allowance<br>言葉遣い(ことばづかい): speech, expression, wording</p> <p id='readingExamples'>遣う (つか.う), 遣わす (つか.わす)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1912</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1774</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1912</p> <p id='keyword'>dance</p> <p id='kanji'>舞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8889E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>dance, reclining, lying down, tub, sunglasses, dancing legs, ballerina, evening</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>46</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The top two strokes show someone <i>reclining</i>, and the next six are a pictograph of an oaken <i>tub</i> ribbed with metal strips, like the kind once used for bathing. At the bottom, the <i>sunglasses</i> round off the character.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem dances naked for him.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I learned nothingness (#1775) first because it is a very common kanji. Attractive dancers should dance wearing nothing but sunglasses.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ブ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ま.う、-ま.う、まい</p> <p id='words'>仕舞(しまい): end, termination, informal (Noh play)<br>仕舞う(しまう): to finish, to close, to do something completely, to put away, to put an end to<br>舞う(まう): to dance, to flutter about, to revolve<br>見舞(みまい): enquiry, expression of sympathy, expression of concern<br>舞台(ぶたい): stage (theatre), scene or setting (e.g. of novel, play, etc.)<br>振舞う(ふるまう): behave, conduct oneself, entertain<br>見舞い(みまい): enquiry, expression of sympathy or concern<br>見舞う(みまう): ask after (health), visit<br>お見舞い(おみまい): asking after (a person´s health)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>舞い (ま.い), 舞う (ま.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1913</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1775</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1913</p> <p id='keyword'>nothingness</p> <p id='kanji'>無</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E784A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>nothingness, reclining, lying down, tub, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>46</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is the Japanese character for the supreme philosophical principle of much Oriental thought: <b>nothingness</b>. Its meaning today would seem to be very similar. Imagine the farmer putting aside some of his harvested wheat on a shelf in order to pay the tariff to his lord.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1918</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1779</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1918</p> <p id='keyword'>ancestor</p> <p id='kanji'>祖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7A596.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>ancestor, altar, shelf, my bookshelves</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Altar . . . shelf.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The ancestor worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The urns of ancestors are kept on shelves next to the altar.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>お祖父さん(おじいさん): grandfather, male senior-citizen<br>お祖母さん(おばあさん): grandmother, female senior-citizen<br>先祖(せんぞ): ancestor<br>祖先(そせん): ancestor<br>祖父(そふ): grand father<br>祖母(そぼ): grand mother</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1919</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1780</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1919</p> <p id='keyword'>thwart</p> <p id='kanji'>阻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E998BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>thwart, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, shelf, my bookshelves</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'>contrecarré</p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pinnacle . . . shelf.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>prevent someone from accomplishing something.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Keeping porn on the pinnacle of a bookshelf can thwart snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The shortness of the Japanese thwarts their attempts to reach the topmost (pinnacle) shelf without grabbing a chair.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はば.む</p> <p id='words'>阻止(そし): obstruction, check, hindrance, prevention, interdiction<br>阻む(はばむ): to keep someone from doing, to stop, to prevent, to check, to hinder, to obstruct, to oppose, to thwart</p> <p id='readingExamples'>阻む (はば.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1920</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1781</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1920</p> <p id='keyword'>investigate</p> <p id='kanji'>査</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69FBB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>investigate, tree, wood, shelf, my bookshelves</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . shelf.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Like the ""ero inquiry"" that had been partially swept under the rug (see inquire (#1145)), this kanji depicts the investigation into the forestry scandal being shelved.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The result of the inverstigation of the missing Trees? 	"<p id='id'>1921</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1782</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1921</p> <p id='keyword'>help</p> <p id='kanji'>助</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58AA9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>help, shelf, my bookshelves, power, muscle, arnold</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Shelf</i> . . . <i>power</i>. The reason why the <i>shelf</i> appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power, the stronger primitive. Indeed, the only exception in all the kanji is the character for <i>add</i> (Frame 932).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>HELP! Someone´s pinned under this bookshelf and it´s gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Can you help me move this shelf? I don´t have the muscle to do it alone.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たす.ける、たす.かる、す.ける、すけ</p> <p id='words'>助(じょ): help, rescue, assistant<br>助言(じょげん): advice, suggestion<br>助詞(じょし): particle, postposition<br>助動詞(じょどうし): auxiliary verb<br>助け(たすけ): assistance<br>補助(ほじょ): assistance, support, aid, auxiliary<br>援助(えんじょ): assistance, aid, support<br>救助(きゅうじょ): relief, aid, rescue<br>助教授(じょきょうじゅ): assistant professor<br>助手(じょしゅ): helper, assistant, tutor<br>助かる(たすかる): be saved, be rescued, survive, be helpful<br>助ける(たすける): help, save, rescue, give relief to, reinforce, promote, abet</p> <p id='readingExamples'>助 (すけ), 助かる (たす.かる), 助ける (たす.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1922</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1783</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1922</p> <p id='keyword'>best regards</p> <p id='kanji'>宜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE9C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>best regards, house, shelf, my bookshelves</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji, a polite way of expressing one's <b>best regards</b> to another. Its elements: <i>house</i> . . . <i>shelf</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their best regards, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I´ve gotten so many that I had to buy a second house which contains nothing but several fancy shelves. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>We have a shelf in our house where we put Christmas cards from people who send best regards for the holiday season...　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ギ　便宜主義　べんぎしゅぎ(opportunism).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よろ.しい、よろ.しく</p> <p id='words'>適宜(てきぎ): suitability<br>どうぞ宜しく(どうぞよろしく): pleased to meet you<br>便宜(べんぎ): convenience, accommodation, advantage, expedience<br>宜しく(よろしく): well, properly, suitably, best regards, please remember me<br>宜しい(よろしい): good</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1923</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1784</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1923</p> <p id='keyword'>tatami mat</p> <p id='kanji'>畳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E795B3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tatami mat, rice field, brains, crown, shelf, my bookshelves</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Rice field . . . crown . . . shelf.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The king is peacefully sleeping on his new tatami mat when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Making tatami mats from rice field waste was Japan´s crowning achievement, but for some reason other countries just shelved the idea.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ、チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たた.む、たたみ、かさ.なる</p> <p id='words'>畳(じょう): counter for tatami mats, measure of room size (in mat units)<br>畳む(たたむ): fold (clothes)<br>畳(たたみ): tatami mat</p> <p id='readingExamples'>畳む (たた.む), 畳 (たたみ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1924</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1785</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1924</p> <p id='keyword'>row</p> <p id='kanji'>並</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B8A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>row</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of the kanji for <i>stand up</i>. By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes, you will see how this is done.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji, but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shape this element can undergo. It is the most difficult one you will meet in this book. When it appears BENEATH its relative primitive, the top three strokes are omitted, though the third horizontal stroke may be doubled up with the bottom horizontal stroke of the element above it. ATOP its relative primitive, it can keep its kanji shape. When it does not, the top three strokes are removed and all of them are replaced BELOW the primitive's bottom line. We shall acknowledge this latter transformation by changing its meaning to <i>upside down in a row</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing in a row.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a rowing boat. In a rowing boat people sit in rows, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for ""rowboat"" coming at frame 1876. The rowing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for ""rowboat"" has a generic meaning of ""a small boat"". In any case, the kanji for ""rowboat"" will not appear as a primitive in the book.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘイ、ホウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>な.み、なら.べる、なら.ぶ、なら.びに</p> <p id='words'>月並み(つきなみ): every month, common<br>並み(なみ): average, medium, common, ordinary<br>並びに(ならびに): and<br>軒並み(のきなみ): row of houses<br>並列(へいれつ): arrangement, parallel, abreast<br>並木(なみき): roadside tree, row of trees<br>並行(へいこう): (going) side by side, concurrent, abreast, at the same time, occurring together, parallel, parallelism<br>並ぶ(ならぶ): line up, stand in a line<br>並べる(ならべる): line up, set up</p> <p id='readingExamples'>並 (なみ), 並びに (なら.びに), 並ぶ (なら.ぶ), 並べる (なら.べる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1925</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1786</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1925</p> <p id='keyword'>universal</p> <p id='kanji'>普</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E699AE.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>universal, row, sun, day</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Row . . . sun.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A row of suns is actually a normal, plain, and ordinary occurrence in an infinitely large and expanding universe. FUtsuu.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To me, row is way too close to file (#812), so I´m adopting Fab´s meaning of rowboat from the previous frame. Universal Studios went through a number of logo animations before settling on the one they are most famous for: the letters UNIVERSAL orbiting the Earth. One of the most ridiculous of these involved a man rowing himself in a boat around the sun.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>フ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あまね.く、あまねし</p> <p id='words'>普遍(ふへん): universality, ubiquity, omnipresence<br>普及(ふきゅう): diffusion, spread<br>普段(ふだん): usually, habitually, ordinarily, always<br>普通(ふつう): normally, usually</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1927</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1788</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1927</p> <p id='keyword'>damp</p> <p id='kanji'>湿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B9BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>damp, water, water droplets, water pistol, sun, day, row</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'>humide</p> <p id='heisigStory'>Water . . . sun . . . row.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You first wash you clothes with water and wring them until they are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. 	"<p id='id'>1931</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1792</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1931</p> <p id='keyword'>profession</p> <p id='kanji'>業</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A5AD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>business, profession, upside down in a row, not yet, tree, wood</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In a row upside down . . . not yet.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The oldest profession: prostitution. I was once in a brothel in Amsterdam where the working girls had a group of businessmen blindfolded and hanging upside down in a row, not yet spanked and whipped, but waiting eagerly.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A bunch of kids are hanging upside down in a row on the monkeybars. Naturally, they haven't chosen a profession, at least not yet.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギョウ、ゴウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わざ</p> <p id='words'>業者(ぎょうしゃ): trader, merchant<br>業績(ぎょうせき): achievement, performance, results, work, contribution<br>業務(ぎょうむ): business, affairs, duties, work<br>兼業(けんぎょう): side line, second business<br>業(ごう): Buddhist karma, actions committed in a former life<br>興業(こうぎょう): industrial enterprise<br>鉱業(こうぎょう): mining industry<br>事業(じぎょう): project, enterprise, business, industry, operations<br>実業家(じつぎょうか): industrialist, businessman<br>就業(しゅうぎょう): employment, starting work<br>従業員(じゅうぎょういん): employee, worker<br>分業(ぶんぎょう): division of labor, specialization, assembly-line production<br>林業(りんぎょう): forestry<br>営業(えいぎょう): business, trade, sales, operations<br>企業(きぎょう): enterprise, undertaking<br>休業(きゅうぎょう): closed (e.g. store), business suspended, shutdown, holiday<br>漁業(ぎょぎょう): fishing (industry)<br>作業(さぎょう): work, operation, manufacturing, fatigue duty<br>産業(さんぎょう): industry<br>失業(しつぎょう): unemployment<br>商業(しょうぎょう): commerce, trade, business<br>職業(しょくぎょう): occupation, business<br>農業(のうぎょう): agriculture<br>工業(こうぎょう): industry<br>卒業(そつぎょう): graduate<br>授業(じゅぎょう): lesson, class work</p> <p id='readingExamples'>業績 (ぎょうせき), 職業 (しょくぎょう), 卒業 (そつぎょう), 業 (わざ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1932</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1793</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1932</p> <p id='keyword'>slap</p> <p id='kanji'>撲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E692B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>slap, finger, fingers, upside down in a row, husband</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . upside down in a row . . . husbands.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and slap them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn´t get me banned…).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Here we have badly behaving HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. Each wife approaches her HUSBAND, berates him, gives him a sharp SLAP in the face and, Three-Stooges style, pokes him in the eyes with her FINGERS.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>相撲(すもう): sumo wrestling</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1933</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1794</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1933</p> <p id='keyword'>me</p> <p id='kanji'>僕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58395.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>me, person, upside down in a row, husband</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word is yet another synonym for ""I,"" somewhat more familiar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men use to refer to themselves. Its elements: <i>person</i> . . . <i>husbands</i> . . . <i>in a row upside down</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it´s the kanji for ""boku."" Males usually use either ""boku"" or ""ore"" (instead of ""watashi"") to refer themselves. ""Boku"" is slightly boyish and soft; ""ore"" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use ""ore"" -- but when he´s one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to ""boku"" when he pleads ""come on baby, it´s ME!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ボク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しもべ</p> <p id='words'>僕(しもべ): manservant, servant (of God)<br>僕(ぼく): I (used by men with close acquaintances)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1934</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1795</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1934</p> <p id='keyword'>together</p> <p id='kanji'>共</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E585B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>together, salad, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Salad</i> . . . <i>animal legs</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive retains the meaning of <i>together</i>. Imagine things <i>strung together</i> like fish on a line, beads on a thread, or whatever. The main thing is to avoid putting them in a straight row, which would confound this element with the previous one. As we saw with <i>bushel basket</i>, this primitive can join its legs to the final horizontal stroke and stretch them to form an enclosure.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The character for deluge (#1799) gave me the idea to use together as a primitive for Noah´s Ark. Noah kept plenty of salad on board to entice the animals with their animal legs to scurry on board together, two by two.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The conjoined twins, who are always together, have trouble eating together because one is a vegetarian, eating salad and the other is a avid meat eater, eating chicken legs.[Thanks fuaburisu!].</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とも、とも.に、-ども</p> <p id='words'>共(きょう): both, neither (neg), all, and, as well as, including, with, together with, plural ending<br>共学(きょうがく): coeducation<br>共感(きょうかん): sympathy, response<br>共存(きょうそん): coexistence<br>共鳴(きょうめい): resonance, sympathy<br>共和(きょうわ): republicanism, cooperation<br>共稼ぎ(ともかせぎ): working together, (husband and wife) earning a living together<br>共働き(ともばたらき): dual income<br>共産(きょうさん): communism<br>共通(きょうつう): commonness, community<br>共同(きょうどう): cooperation, association, collaboration, joint<br>公共(こうきょう): public, community, public service, society, communal<br>共に(ともに): sharing with, participate in, both, alike, together, along with, with, including</p> <p id='readingExamples'>共 (とも)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1935</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1796</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1935</p> <p id='keyword'>submit</p> <p id='kanji'>供</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4BE9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>submit, person, strung together, salad, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>47</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Submit</b> here is a transitive verb, meaning to offer or present. They invented so much martial arts: karate, judo, kungfu, muay thai, silat, etc... just to hurt each other. They torture their own people (China, North Korea). They torture other people (Japan in China and Korea). And they are able to hide all this behind their nice facade of kindness. Bad, bad Asians. (did i shatter some people´s ideas on Asia? my bad).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>アク、オ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>わる.い、わる-、あ.し、にく.い、-にく.い、ああ、いずくに、いずくんぞ、にく.む</p> <p id='words'>悪(あく): evil, wickedness<br>悪日(あくび): unlucky day<br>悪化(あっか): deterioration, growing worse, aggravation, degeneration, corruption<br>悪口(あっこう): abuse, insult, slander, evil speaking<br>悪戯(いたずら): tease, prank, trick, practical joke, mischief<br>改悪(かいあく): deterioration, changing for the worse<br>決まり悪い(きまりわるい): feeling awkward, being ashamed<br>悪い(にくい): hateful, abominable, poor-looking<br>善し悪し(よしあし): good or bad, merits or demerits, quality, suitability<br>悪者(わるもの): bad fellow, rascal, ruffian, scoundrel<br>悪魔(あくま): evil spirit, devil, demon<br>意地悪(いじわる): malicious, ill-tempered, unkind<br>悪口(わるくち): abuse, insult, slander, evil speaking<br>悪い(わるい): bad, inferior</p> <p id='readingExamples'>悪事 (あくじ), 悪意 (あくい), 醜悪 (しゅうあく), 悪い (わる.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1952</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1811</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1952</p> <p id='keyword'>circle</p> <p id='kanji'>円</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58686.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>circle, yen</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>48</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This kanji, also used for Yen, is one you are not likely to need to study formally, since you can hardly get around in Japan without it. The connection is that the yennies, like pennies, are <b>circular</b> in shape. In any case, the elements are: <i>glass canopy</i> . . . <i>walking stick</i> . . . <i>one</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The shape of a Yen coin.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A poor old man is almost killing himself trying to lift a huge glass hood with his cane (using it as a lever), to get to just one yen coin. Note : the kanji refers to a circular, round object, but also to the Japanese currency (pronounced ""en"").</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まる.い、まる、まど、まど.か、まろ.やか</p> <p id='words'>円滑(えんかつ): harmony, smoothness<br>円満(えんまん): perfection, harmony, peace, smoothness, completeness, satisfaction, integrity<br>円(えん): yen, circle<br>円周(えんしゅう): circumference<br>楕円(だえん): ellipse<br>円(まる): circle, money<br>円い(まるい): round, circular, spherical</p> <p id='readingExamples'>円い (まる.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_1</p>"

Argument at academic conferences is naturally carried out using words.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It´s very difficult to present a good argument if you don´t bring along a scrapbook with some key words jotted down to the meeting.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ロン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>異論(いろん): different opinion, objection<br>言論(げんろん): discussion<br>世論(せろん): public opinion<br>討論(とうろん): debate, discussion<br>弁論(べんろん): discussion, debate, argument<br>無論(むろん): of course, naturally<br>目論見(もくろみ): a plan, a scheme, a project, a program, intention, goal<br>理論(りろん): theory<br>論議(ろんぎ): discussion<br>論理(ろんり): logic<br>概論(がいろん): introduction, outline, general remarks<br>議論(ぎろん): argument, discussion, dispute<br>結論(けつろん): reason, sum up, conclude<br>評論(ひょうろん): criticism, critique<br>勿論(もちろん): of course, certainly, naturally<br>論じる(ろんじる): argue, discuss, debate<br>論ずる(ろんずる): argue, discuss, debate<br>論争(ろんそう): controversy, dispute<br>論文(ろんぶん): thesis, essay, treatise, paper</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1965</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1824</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1965</p> <p id='keyword'>everywhere</p> <p id='kanji'>遍</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9818D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>everywhere, fishfinger, door, one, ceiling, flag, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>48</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Door . . . scrapbook . . . a road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics EVERYWHERE, newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are everywhere here along the road.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Go down any road in Japan and you´ll find konbini hentai everywhere.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あまね.く</p> <p id='words'>普遍(ふへん): universality, ubiquity, omnipresence</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1966</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1825</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1966</p> <p id='keyword'>compilation</p> <p id='kanji'>編</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B7A8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>compilation, thread, spiderman, fishfinger, door, one, ceiling, flag, scrapbook, glass canopy, hood, flowers</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>48</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . door . . . scrapbook.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Raulir has a good idea. I prefer to think of the manga compilations as the individual comics (serials from the anthologies) bound together with a coarse thread down the spine, produced quickly and put on the market. Good way to recycle those pulpy manga, and since when has the consumer not gotten screwed in Japan? ;-).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A Japanese comic book is a compilation of the individual chapters (which have already appeared in weekly comic magazines) with a thread (story arc) going through it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.む、-あ.み</p> <p id='words'>長編(ちょうへん): long (e.g. novel film)<br>編(へん): compilation, editing, completed poem, book, part of book<br>編物(あみもの): knitting, web<br>編む(あむ): to knit, to braid, compile (anthology, dictionary, etc.), edit<br>短編(たんぺん): short (e.g. story, film)<br>編集(へんしゅう): editing, compilation, editorial (e.g. committee)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>編む (あ.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1967</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1826</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1967</p> <p id='keyword'>tome</p> <p id='kanji'>冊</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5868A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tome</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>48</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word is a counter for books. It differs from <i>scrapbook</i> both in the writing order and in the extension of the second horizontal stroke.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Pictograph. I think of that Harry Potter spell book that had to be bound shut coz it wanted to eat you.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>冊 さつ 1: counter for books A heavy scrapbook so full that flowers are sticking out. Only if a scrapbook is that full, it can be called a heavy book.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>サツ、サク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふみ</p> <p id='words'>冊(さつ): counter for books</p> <p id='readingExamples'>冊子 (さっし), 別冊 (べっさつ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1969</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1827</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1969</p> <p id='keyword'>code</p> <p id='kanji'>典</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E585B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>code, bend, tool</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>48</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We introduce this character here because of its connection to the book-related kanji treated above. It is based on the character for <i>bend</i> (frame 1256), whose last stroke is lengthened to coincide with the first stroke of the element for <i>tool</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Coding is a tool which you can use to bend the computer to your will.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Think ""codex"" (mnemonic help) or ""code of laws"", or even Leonardo Da Vinci´s code. Here I see a codex as a tool used to bend the masses into submission. Picture a huge codex book lifted down on crowds to bend them down in submission. Another: if you bend to the code without asking questions, you are a tool!</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テン、デン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>原典(げんてん): original (text)<br>百科事典(ひゃっかじてん): encyclopedia<br>百科辞典(ひゃっかじてん): encyclopedia<br>古典(こてん): old book, classic, classics<br>典型(てんけい): type, pattern, archetypal<br>辞典(じてん): dictionary</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1970</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1828</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1970</p> <p id='keyword'>family name</p> <p id='kanji'>氏</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B08F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>family name, drop, fishhook, fishhook2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>49</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Pay close attention to the stroke order of the elements when learning to write this character. The elements: a long <i>drop</i> . . . <i>fishhook</i> . . . a <i>one</i> . . . <i>fishhook</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The family name is important to me! Drop me from a building, torture me with a fishhook, I´m keeping my one family name. Hook me with a second fishhook, I refuse to change my family name.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うじ、-うじ</p> <p id='words'>氏(うじ): family name<br>氏(し): family name, lineage<br>氏名(しめい): full name, identity</p> <p id='readingExamples'>氏 (うじ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1974</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1832</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1974</p> <p id='keyword'>resist</p> <p id='kanji'>抵</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68AB5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>resist, finger, fingers, calling card, family name, one, floor</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>49</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . calling card.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a business card, resist the impulse to fiddle around with it with your fingers, and by all means resist the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your fingernails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don´t know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Most japanese find it impossible to resist pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned business cards into your fingers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>大抵(たいてい): usually, generally<br>抵抗(ていこう): electrical resistance, resistance, opposition</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1978</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1836</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1978</p> <p id='keyword'>catch</p> <p id='kanji'>捕</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68D95.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>catch, finger, fingers, dog-tag, arrowhead, screwdriver, utilize, utilise</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>49</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . dog tag.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to catch them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Dog tag: This is a wild animal track device. It has an arrowhead and screwdriver-shaped radio beacon. It´s evidently fired in animals to track their movements. When animal has a dog tag, it´s easy to catch it: just take a dog tag in your fingers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.らえる、と.らわれる、と.る、とら.える、とら.われる、つか.まえる、つか.まる</p> <p id='words'>捕らえる(とらえる): to seize, to grasp, to capture, to arrest<br>捕獲(ほかく): capture, seizure<br>捕鯨(ほげい): whaling, whale fishing<br>捕吏(ほり): constable<br>捕虜(ほりょ): prisoner (of war)<br>逮捕(たいほ): arrest, apprehension, capture<br>捕まる(つかまる): be caught, be arrested<br>捕える(とらえる): seize, grasp, capture, arrest<br>捕る(とる): take, catch (fish), capture<br>捕まえる(つかまえる): catch</p> <p id='readingExamples'>捕まえる (つか.まえる), 捕まる (つか.まる), 捕らえる (と.らえる), 捕らわれる (と.らわれる), 捕る (と.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The key word refers to the noun, not the verb.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A shop in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Normal cottages (舎 actually means a building) don´t have tags advertising their names, but shops do.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>舗装(ほそう): pavement, road surface</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1983</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1840</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1983</p> <p id='keyword'>supplement</p> <p id='kanji'>補</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A39C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>supplement, cloak, dog-tag, arrowhead, screwdriver, utilize, utilise</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>49</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Cloak . . . dog tag.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I usually hear supplement in ""dietry supplement"". So you´re given a cloak for extra fibre and dogtags for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The name and number printed on a soldier´s cloak is a supplement to his main I.D. tag; his dog-tag, in helping identify the soldier.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おぎな.う</p> <p id='words'>補給(ほきゅう): supply, supplying, replenishment<br>補強(ほきょう): compensation, reinforcement<br>補充(ほじゅう): supplementation, supplement, replenishment, replenishing<br>補助(ほじょ): assistance, support, aid, auxiliary<br>補償(ほしょう): compensation, reparation<br>補足(ほそく): supplement, complement<br>補う(おぎなう): compensate for<br>候補(こうほ): candidacy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>補う (おぎな.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1984</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1841</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1984</p> <p id='keyword'>residence</p> <p id='kanji'>邸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E982B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>residence, calling card, family name, one, floor, city walls</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>49</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Calling card . . . city walls.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The business card says his residence is just to the left of the city walls. Can you find it? Yep, got it.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>So fed up am I, I´ve finally built city walls around my residence to keep these Japanese from soliciting me with their business cards.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>やしき</p> <p id='words'>邸宅(ていたく): mansion, residence</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Picture the enemy of a Spartan soldier poking his eyes out with a sewing needle and trying to steal his shield. However, the Spartan desperately clutches on, and is dragged around for a while, preferring to die than to lose his shield.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たて</p> <p id='words'>盾(たて): shield, buckler, escutcheon, pretext<br>矛盾(むじゅん): contradiction, inconsistency</p> <p id='readingExamples'>盾 (たて)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A column of shielded soldiers advancing sequentially to avoid revealing the size of their army (Think ""Sandpeople always ride single file to hide their numbers"" from Star Wars).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジュン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>循環(じゅんかん): circulation, rotation, cycle</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The zombie population became more diverse, separating into different factions. One of them being the water Zombies.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The radical faction is almost eliminated, sir. 	"<p id='id'>2002</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1858</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2002</p> <p id='keyword'>parcel post</p> <p id='kanji'>逓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98093.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>parcel post, drag, cornstalk, belt, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>50</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Drag . . . cornstalk . . . belt . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Picture a crude drag-sled - in this case, made from cornstalks that have been belted together - filled with parcels, that the postman drags along behind him down the road along his delivery route.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(I prefer 2 towels over cornstalk and belt) - Have you ever wondered why your parcels always end up in such bad condition when you get them? Or why you never get them at all? That´s because you´ve never looked at how they´re actually delivered - each postman is given a load of parcel post and 2 towels to drag them down the road on.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>テイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かわ.る、たがいに</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2003</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1859</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2003</p> <p id='keyword'>grade</p> <p id='kanji'>段</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AEB5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grade, staple gun, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>50</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji connoting rank or class shows us a new element on the left: the familiar primitive for <i>staples</i> with an additional stroke cutting through the vertical stroke. It is easiest in these cases to make a primitive related to what we already know. Hence, we call it a <i>staple gun</i>. To the right, <i>missile</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is a military-grade staple gun! It can be loaded with real missiles.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>1st grade: staple gun, 9th grade: missiles.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダン、タン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>段々(だんだん): gradually, by degrees<br>値段(ねだん): price, cost<br>一段と(いちだんと): greater, more, further, still more<br>手段(しゅだん): means, way, measure<br>段(だん): step, stair, flight of steps, grade, rank, level<br>段階(だんかい): gradation, grade, stage<br>普段(ふだん): usually, habitually, ordinarily, always<br>階段(かいだん): stairs</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2004</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1860</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2004</p> <p id='keyword'>forge</p> <p id='kanji'>鍛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98D9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>forge, metal, gold, grade, staple gun, cruise missile, missile, wind, crotch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>50</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Metal . . . grade.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>As a discriminating metalsmith, I use the highest grade metals when forging such precision devices as staple guns and missiles.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Metal has to be forged many times over in order to reach a high grade.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きた.える</p> <p id='words'>鍛える(きたえる): to forge, to drill, to temper, to train, to discipline</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鍛える (きた.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2009</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1865</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2009</p> <p id='keyword'>parts of speech</p> <p id='kanji'>詞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A99E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>part of speech, say, words, keitai, mouth, director, Ken Russel, clothes hanger, coat hanger, one, mouth, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>50</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word, <b>parts of speech</b>, refers to nouns, verbs, adjective, adverbs, and so on. The elements: <i>words</i> . . . <i>directors</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Parts of speech act as word directors, giving it meaning and indicating its correct placement and usage in grammar.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The big mouthed diretor is even picky about the parts of speech you use, shouting, ""More verbs! Less adjectives!"" and such all the time.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>自動詞(じどうし): intransitive verb (no direct obj)<br>助詞(じょし): particle, postposition<br>助動詞(じょどうし): auxiliary verb<br>数詞(すうし): numeral<br>接続詞(せつぞくし): conjunction<br>他動詞(たどうし): transitive verb (direct obj)<br>形容詞(けいようし): ""true"" adjective<br>形容動詞(けいようどうし): adjectival noun, quasi-adjective<br>代名詞(だいめいし): pronoun<br>動詞(どうし): verb<br>副詞(ふくし): adverb<br>名詞(めいし): noun</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"

No Ferrari, no mansion, ...scrapbook?! Turns out the scrapbook was of my great uncle's company, and I had been named the new director of the multi-million dollar business. My mouth literally hit the scrapbook when I learned I'd be director.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>My mouth hung open when I found out I was the heir to not only my father's scrapbooks, but he also left me as director of the company.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2012</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1868</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2012</p> <p id='keyword'>boat</p> <p id='kanji'>舟</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8889F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>boat</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>50</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>After the <i>drop</i> and the <i>glass canopy</i>, we come to a combination of three strokes that we met only once before, in the character for <i>mama</i> (frame 105). The pictographic meaning we gave it there has no etymological relationship to this character, but use it if it helps.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Cinnabar (丹) colored boat, the extra drop signifying that the paint hasn´t dried yet. The stick represents the oars.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふね、ふな-、-ぶね</p> <p id='words'>舟(ふね): ship, boat, watercraft, shipping, vessel, steamship</p> <p id='readingExamples'>舟 (ふね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2013</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1869</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2013</p> <p id='keyword'>liner</p> <p id='kanji'>舶</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E888B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>liner, boat, white, dove</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>50</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The type of <i>boat</i> connoted by this key word is a large oceangoing <b>liner</b>. The important thing here is to work with the elements <i>boat</i> and <i>dove</i> to make an image distinct from that of the former frame. Don't count on size alone to distinguish the <i>boat</i> from the <b>liner</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A liner is to boat as an emperor (#261) is to a king (#255), or a chief (#967) is to a person (#951): in each case we need only add white to the latter in order to get the former.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>船舶(せんぱく): ship</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The morse code specialist was the conveyor of messages to and from the crew of the carrier, using his fingers to tap out the secret messages. (This works especially well for 搬送周波数 carrier frequency and 搬送波 carrier wave, being the radio waves/frequencies used in morse code).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>運搬(うんぱん): transport, carriage</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

How about this: the phrase ""shape up or ship out!"" This phrase originally meant that a soldier had better get his act together, or else face being shipped off into a combat zone. Here we see a poor WW-I soldier who has been shipped off to a combat zone. He´s riding in the boat overseas to fight in the trenches (gulley).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふね、ふな-</p> <p id='words'>汽船(きせん): steamship<br>漁船(ぎょせん): fishing boat<br>船舶(せんぱく): ship<br>船(ふね): ship, boat, watercraft, shipping, vessel, steamship<br>造船(ぞうせん): shipbuilding<br>風船(ふうせん): balloon<br>船便(ふなびん): surface mail (ship)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>船 (ふね)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2021</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1876</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2021</p> <p id='keyword'>rowboat</p> <p id='kanji'>艇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88987.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>rowboat, boat, courts, porter, drop, samurai, stretch</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>50</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Boat . . . courts.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Rowboats are a classic way to court (go on a date with) someone...</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Courts in olden times would often punish convicts by sentencing them to a life of being the rower crew for large rowboat ships (there were no engines or boilers back then)... 	"<p id='id'>2025</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1880</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2025</p> <p id='keyword'>cocoon</p> <p id='kanji'>繭</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B9AD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cocoon, flowers, hood, stick, thread, spiderman, insect</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Though it's a good thing that the primitive for <b>cocoon</b> has been radically abbreviated from this, its full form as a kanji, the story it holds is a charming one. The silkworm (<i>insect</i>) eats the leaves of the mulberry bush (the <i>flowers</i>), digests them and transforms them into <i>thread</i> with which it spins about itself, in mystic wisdom, its own coffin (the <i>hood</i>). The dividing line that separates the two elements helps the picture of the little worm cutting itself off from contact with the outside world, but as a character stroke, it is a clear exception.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ケン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まゆ、きぬ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>繭 (まゆ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2026</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1881</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2026</p> <p id='keyword'>benefit</p> <p id='kanji'>益</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E79B8A.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>benefit, animal horns, one, floor, animal legs, eight, dish</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Poised over the <i>dish</i> here is a pair of <i>animal horns</i> that are attached to a pair of <i>animal legs</i> by a single horizontal stroke.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The benefit of being an animal with horns and fast legs is in keeping it from becoming a dish for the other animals! (shaydwyrm).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エキ、ヤク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ま.す</p> <p id='words'>収益(しゅうえき): earnings, proceeds, returns<br>益々(ますます): increasingly, more and more<br>有益(ゆうえき): beneficial, profitable<br>利益(りえき): profits, gains, (political, economic) interest</p> <p id='readingExamples'>有益 (ゆうえき), 利益 (りえき), 益する (まする), 益 (やく)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2027</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1882</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2027</p> <p id='keyword'>spare time</p> <p id='kanji'>暇</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69A87.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>spare time, sun, day, hobby, staples, mouth, box, crotch, box2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The element for <i>day</i> on the left is logical enough. Next to it we see <i>staples</i> being held in <i>mouth</i> (one stroke is doubled up), indicating working in one's hobby or handicrafts at home on one's <b>spare time</b>. The small <i>box</i> at the top right is facing backwards, or more properly ""inside out."" Finally, we have the <i>crotch</i> at the bottom.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video´s of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tip: The complex right side of this kanji appears twice more in Heisig. He later names it ""hobby"". 	"<p id='id'>2029</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1884</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2029</p> <p id='keyword'>come</p> <p id='kanji'>来</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69DA5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>come, not yet, animal horns</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This odd but common kanji is built up of the character for <i>not yet</i> into which a pair of <i>animal horns</i> has been inserted.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You horny bastard, don´t come, at least not yet!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Here I see, of all things, Bambi. His animal horns have not yet come out. (As we can see in the kanji, the animal horns are not at the top, not ""poking through"". ) Remember: Bambi will soon come to have a great set of animal horns but they have not yet come out.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>ライ、タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>く.る、きた.る、きた.す、き.たす、き.たる、き、こ</p> <p id='words'>外来(がいらい): imported, outpatient clinic<br>元来(がんらい): originally, primarily, essentially, logically, naturally<br>来る(きたる): to come, to arrive, to be due to, to be next, to be forthcoming<br>家来(けらい): retainer, retinue, servant<br>為来り(しきたり): customs<br>従来(じゅうらい): up to now, so far, traditional<br>出来物(できもの): able man, tumour, growth, boil, ulcer, abcess, rash, pimple<br>伝来(でんらい): ancestral, hereditary, imported, transmitted, handed down<br>来場(らいじょう): attendance<br>以来(いらい): since, henceforth<br>再来月(さらいげつ): month after next<br>再来週(さらいしゅう): week after next<br>出来上がり(できあがり): finish, completion, ready, made for, cut out<br>出来上がる(できあがる): be finished, be ready, by definition, be very drunk<br>出来事(できごと): incident, affair, happening, event<br>出来るだけ(できるだけ): if at all possible<br>本来(ほんらい): essentially, naturally, by nature, in (and of) itself, originally<br>未来(みらい): future tense, the future (usually distant), the world to come<br>来(らい): since (last month), for (10 days), next (year)<br>来日(らいにち): arrival in Japan, coming to Japan, visit to Japan<br>さ来月(さらいげつ): the month after next<br>さ来週(さらいしゅう): the week after next<br>将来(しょうらい): future<br>来る(くる): come, come to hand, arrive, approach, call on, set in, be due, become, grow, get, come from, be caused by, derive from<br>再来年(さらいねん): year after next<br>来月(らいげつ): next month<br>来週(らいしゅう): next week<br>来年(らいねん): next year</p> <p id='readingExamples'>来す (きた.す), 来る (きた.る), 来る (く.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2030</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1885</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2030</p> <p id='keyword'>spirit</p> <p id='kanji'>気</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B097.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>spirit, landed fish, reclining, lying down, one, floor, fishhook, sheaf</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>spirit</b> in this character refers to the changeable moods and airs of one's personality as well as to the more essential combination of vital forces that distinguish things and individuals one from the other. Its elements are: <i>reclining</i> . . . <i>floor</i> . . . <i>fishhook</i> . . . <i>sheaf</i>. Do not confuse with <i>spirits</i> (Frame 1930).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You´re reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you´ve been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws.</p> <p id='jouYou'>1</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ、ケ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いき</p> <p id='words'>呆気ない(あっけない): not enough, too quick (short long 	"<p id='id'>2031</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1886</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2031</p> <p id='keyword'>vapor</p> <p id='kanji'>汽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B1BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vapor, water, water droplets, water pistol, landed fish, reclining, lying down, one, floor, fishhook</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Think of this character as a sibling of that for <i>spirit</i>. Simply replace <i>sheaves</i> with drops of <i>water</i> on the left in order to get <i>vapor</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Wolverine disappears into water vapor, seemingly his spirit dissipating into nothingness.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>汽船(きせん): steamship<br>汽車(きしゃ): train (locomotive)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2032</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1887</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2032</p> <p id='keyword'>fly</p> <p id='kanji'>飛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A39B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fly, hook, propeller, measuring box, thousand, needles, propeller2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The two <i>large hooks</i> have little propellers (the two <i>drops</i> on each <i>hook</i>) attached to them for <b>flying</b>. Beneath is the <i>measuring box</i>, which serves as the body of this <b>flying</b> contraption. The stroke order will cause some problems, so take care with it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Two hummingbirds flying into a measuring box serving as a bird feeder…　RTK2:　ヒ　飛行機　ひこうき(airplane).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヒ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>と.ぶ、と.ばす、-と.ばす</p> <p id='words'>蹴飛ばす(けとばす): to kick away, to kick off, to kick (someone), to refuse, to reject<br>飛ばす(とばす): skip over, omit<br>飛び込む(とびこむ): jump in, leap in, plunge into, dive<br>飛び出す(とびだす): jump out, rush out, fly out, appear suddenly, protrude, project<br>飛行(ひこう): flying, flight, aviation<br>飛行場(ひこうじょう): airfield, airport<br>飛ぶ(とぶ): jump, fly, leap, spring, bound, hop<br>飛行機(ひこうき): airplane</p> <p id='readingExamples'>飛ばす (と.ばす), 飛ぶ (と.ぶ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2033</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1888</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2033</p> <p id='keyword'>sink</p> <p id='kanji'>沈</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B288.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sink, water, water droplets, water pistol, garter, crown, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The technique for <b>sinking</b> used in this kanji is unique. Rather than the biblical image of tying a millstone about the victim's neck, here we see a <i>crown</i> tied about one <i>leg</i> before the unfortunate party is tossed into the <i>water</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>(thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn´t have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend´s schemes.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling ""Eureka! Eureka!"" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>チン、ジン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しず.む、しず.める</p> <p id='words'>沈める(しずめる): to sink, to submerge<br>沈殿(ちんでん): precipitation, settlement<br>沈没(ちんぼつ): sinking, foundering<br>沈黙(ちんもく): silence, reticence<br>沈む(しずむ): sink, feel depressed</p> <p id='readingExamples'>沈む (しず.む), 沈める (しず.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2035</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1889</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2035</p> <p id='keyword'>wife</p> <p id='kanji'>妻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A6BB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wife, ten, needle, rake, woman</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Ten . . . rakes . . . woman.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(I´m really not sexist, this just helps me remember the kanji): I make my WIFE do all the yard work, and as a really mean joke, I bought her TEN RAKES for her birthday this year. ""Do the yardwork, WOMAN! You have TEN perfectly good RAKES to choose from!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>サイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つま</p> <p id='words'>夫妻(ふさい): man and wife, married couple<br>妻(つま): wife</p> <p id='readingExamples'>妻 (つま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2037</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1890</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2037</p> <p id='keyword'>decline</p> <p id='kanji'>衰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A1B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>decline, pathetic, stick, top hat, scarf, mouth</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let this key word connote the <b>decline</b> and fall of the Roman Empire. It shows a fellow in a <i>top hat</i> and <i>scarf</i>, trying hard to look happy by putting a <i>walking stick</i> in his <i>mouth</i> sideways to twist his face into a grotesque but semi permanent smile.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, allowing people to rent him and play catch with him for money!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おとろ.える</p> <p id='words'>衰える(おとろえる): to become weak, to decline, to wear, to abate, to decay, to wither, to waste away<br>老衰(ろうすい): senility, senile decay</p> <p id='readingExamples'>衰える (おとろ.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2038</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1891</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2038</p> <p id='keyword'>inmost</p> <p id='kanji'>衷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A1B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>inmost, ten, needle, mouth, scarf</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Between the <i>top hat</i> and the <i>scarf</i> you will see the character for <i>in</i> which is truncated at the bottom so as not to interfere with the <i>scarf</i>. You can think of this character forming as a pair with that of the former frame: there the <i>in</i> (the <i>walking stick</i> in the <i>mouth</i>) was set on its side; here it is set upright.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The guy from pathetic (#401) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Besides making money from acting like a dog (see decline), the pathetic man has risked his inmost internal organs by becoming a cane swallower!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>折衷(せっちゅう): compromise, cross, blending, eclecticism</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2039</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1892</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2039</p> <p id='keyword'>mask</p> <p id='kanji'>面</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99DA2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mask, hundred, one, ceiling, drop, pent in, eye</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Imagine a <b>mask</b> over your head with <i>eyes</i> peeping out from all over the head, a <i>hundred</i> in all (the element for <i>eye</i> displacing the fifth stroke of that for <i>hundred</i>).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p 	"<p id='id'>2041</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1893</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2041</p> <p id='keyword'>leather</p> <p id='kanji'>革</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99DA9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>leather, flowers, car, mouth, ten, needle</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>After the <i>flowers</i> at the top (painted on the <b>leather</b> for decoration), we see the element for <i>car</i> with the middle stroke left out. 	"<p id='id'>2044</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1896</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2044</p> <p id='keyword'>voice</p> <p id='kanji'>声</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A3B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>voice, samurai, flag, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>samurai</i> at the top is familiar enough. The combination beneath, which looks like a <i>flag</i> with a line running through it, is not. Try to devise some way to take note of it, and pay attention to the writing.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When an enemy´s flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>セイ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こえ、こわ-</p> <p id='words'>歓声(かんせい): cheer, shout of joy<br>声明(せいめい): declaration, statement, proclamation<br>声(こえ): voice</p> <p id='readingExamples'>声楽 (せいがく), 声援 (せいえん), 名声 (めいせい), 声 (こえ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2046</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1897</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2046</p> <p id='keyword'>give</p> <p id='kanji'>呉</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59189.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>give, mouth, chair, tool, animal legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult, because of the fourth stroke, which is rare (see frames 33 and 34). The <i>mouth</i> and <i>tool</i> are already familiar.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, ""My uncle gave me this watch."" Following -て form of another verb, means ""to do the favor of"": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, ""Won't you open the window [do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?"" Usu. written in hiragana.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>く.れる、くれ</p> <p id='words'>呉れる(くれる): to give, to let one have, to do for one, to be given</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2047</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1898</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2047</p> <p id='keyword'>recreation</p> <p id='kanji'>娯</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5A8AF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>recreation, woman, give, mouth, chair, tool, animal legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Woman . . . give.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A woman gives up her recreation time in order to raise a family.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Typical male fantasy of recreation: women ""giving it up"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>娯楽(ごらく): pleasure, amusement</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2048</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1899</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2048</p> <p id='keyword'>mistake</p> <p id='kanji'>誤</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8AAA4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mistake, say, words, keitai, mouth, give, mouth, chair, tool, animal legs, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . give.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You must give words of apology when you make a mistake.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It is a rookie mistake to believe the words when your sweetie says ""You don´t have to give me anything for my birthday.""
