	"<p id='id'>2049</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1900</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2049</p> <p id='keyword'>steam</p> <p id='kanji'>蒸</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E892B8.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>steam, flowers, helping hand, complete, water, one, floor, oven-fire, barbecue</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>flower</i> at the top and the <i>floor</i> with the <i>oven fire</i> beneath are familiar. The problem is what comes in between. It is formed by the character for <i>complete</i>, whose vertical stroke doubles up as the first stroke of <i>water</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Think of a picture of someone steaming vegetables. On top you see the flowers of cauliflower or something else that is being steamed. Underneath, the pan is completely full of water. Below the pan is a floor - that's the hotplate - and under that the oven fire. Caution: don't confuse with boil (#1257), or the steam radical in spirit (#1885).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When you want to steam some flowers/vegetation you don't cover them completely with water, rather you have just a little at the floor of the saucepan and then heat.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジョウ、セイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>む.す、む.れる、む.らす</p> <p id='words'>蒸留(じょうりゅう): distillation<br>蒸気(じょうき): steam, vapour<br>蒸発(じょうはつ): evaporation, unexplained disappearance<br>水蒸気(すいじょうき): water vapour, steam<br>蒸し暑い(むしあつい): humid, sultry<br>蒸す(むす): to steam, poultice, be sultry</p> <p id='readingExamples'>蒸す (む.す), 蒸らす (む.らす), 蒸れる (む.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2050</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1901</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2050</p> <p id='keyword'>acquiesce</p> <p id='kanji'>承</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E689BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>acquiesce, water, complete, three</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sense of passive acceptance or reception of information is contained in this key word. The form is based on the middle portion of the preceding character, with three additional strokes, best thought of as the kanji for <i>three</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To get someone to acquiesce, duck them completely in aqua (=water) three times. (variation on dingomick´s).</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショウ、ジョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うけたまわ.る、う.ける、ささ.げる、とど.める、たす.ける、こ.らす、つい.で、すく.う</p> <p id='words'>承諾(しょうだく): consent, acquiescence, agreement<br>了承(りょうしょう): acknowledgement, understanding (e.g. ""please be understanding of the mess during our renovation"")<br>承る(うけたまわる): (humble) hear, be told, know<br>承認(しょうにん): recognition, acknowledgement, approval, consent, agreement<br>承知(しょうち): consent, agree</p> <p id='readingExamples'>承る (うけたまわ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_5</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2051</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1902</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2051</p> <p id='keyword'>bin</p> <p id='kanji'>函</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E587BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bin, snare, sparkler, shovel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This is the character from which the element for <i>shovel</i> derives. Within it comes the element for <i>snare</i>, with the <i>sparkler</i> surrounding it.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(thegeezer3) Damn racoons... I´ll show them. I´ll put a SNARE in the BIN as well as a few SPARKLERS so as to scare the shit out of the buggers, then hit them with a SHOVEL.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はこ、い.れる</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2052</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1903</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2052</p> <p id='keyword'>poles</p> <p id='kanji'>極</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A5B5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>poles, decay, tree, wood, snare, mouth, crotch, one, floor</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>51</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>poles</b> this key word refers to are the extremities of the earth or the terminals of an electric field. The elements are: <i>tree</i> . . . <i>snare</i> . . . <i>mouth</i> . . . <i>crotch</i> . . . <i>floor</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Can simplify this using decay (#1243). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>(modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using decay (#1243). You travel to the poles, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is decayed (see story for decay (#1243)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your mouth as your lips turn blue, then your crotch also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the floor.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョク、ゴク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きわ.める、きわ.まる、きわ.まり、きわ.み、き.める、-ぎ.め、き.まる</p> <p id='words'>究極(きゅうきょく): ultimate, final, eventual<br>極端(きょくたん): extreme, extremity<br>極めて(きわめて): exceedingly, extremely<br>極楽(ごくらく): paradise<br>両極(りょうきょく): both extremities, north and south poles, positive and negative poles<br>極(ごく): pole, climax, extreme, extremity, culmination, height, zenith, nadir<br>消極的(しょうきょくてき): passive<br>積極的(せっきょくてき): positive, active, proactive<br>南極(なんきょく): south pole, Antarctic<br>北極(ほっきょく): North Pole</p> <p id='readingExamples'>極限 (きょくげん), 終極 (おわりきょく), 積極的 (せっきょくてき), 極まる (きわ.まる), 極み (きわ.み), 極める (きわ.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2053</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1904</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2053</p> <p id='keyword'>tusk</p> <p id='kanji'>牙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E78999.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tusk</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'>defense</p> <p id='heisigStory'>If you play with this primitive's form with pencil and paper, you will see that it begins with a <i>box</i>-like shape, and ends with the final two strokes of the <i>halberd</i>, a convenient combination for the <b>tusk</b> protruding from the mouth of an animal.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* Since this kanji has 4 strokes, you would expect that as a primitive it would also have 4 - but in fact it has 5 in the following two frames (the second stroke between divided into 2 strokes) and reverts to 4 again in frame 2056.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant´s eye. The final stroke is the tusk.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ガ、ゲ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>きば、は、きばへん</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>牙 (きば)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2054</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1905</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2054</p> <p id='keyword'>bud</p> <p id='kanji'>芽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E88ABD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bud, flowers, tusk</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flowers . . . tusk.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Buds while they´re still small tend to be tusk-shaped.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant´s tusks keep budding into flowers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>め</p> <p id='words'>発芽(はつが): burgeoning<br>芽(め): sprout</p> <p id='readingExamples'>芽 (め)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2055</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1906</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2055</p> <p id='keyword'>wicked</p> <p id='kanji'>邪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E982AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>wicked, tusk, city walls</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tusk . . . city walls.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>As everyone knows, rhinoceroses and elephants are often killed for the value of their TUSKS. Here we see a WICKED city mayor who has had countless elephants killed just to make his CITY WALLS out of TUSKS.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ジャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>よこし.ま</p> <p id='words'>お邪魔します(おじゃまします): Excuse me for disturbing (interrupting) you<br>邪魔(じゃま): obstacle, intrusion<br>無邪気(むじゃき): innocence, simple-mindedness<br>風邪(かぜ): common cold</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2056</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1907</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2056</p> <p id='keyword'>gracious</p> <p id='kanji'>雅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99B85.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>gracious, tusk, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tusk . . . an old turkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk. This mnemonic is meant to join RtK´s keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used ""elegant"" here, which is not confounded so easily with graceful (#721), and accurately represents the character´s meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha´s Kanji Learner´s Dictionary).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>To not confuse it with grace (#606) or graceful (#721), think of the phrase ""Goodness gracious."" Like: ""Goodness gracious! A turkey with tusks!"".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ガ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>みや.び</p> <p id='words'>雅致(がち): artistry, good taste, elegance, grace</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2057</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1908</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2057</p> <p id='keyword'>interpretation</p> <p id='kanji'>釈</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98788.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>explanation, animal tracks, drop, rice, shaku-hachi, flag, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Animal tracks . . . shakuhachi.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I´d purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They´re so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he´s playing.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An interpretive dance of some kind where somebody follows animal tracks, a shakuhachi providing the soundtrack, suggesting the tracker's thoughts and intentions.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シャク、セキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とく、す.てる、ゆる.す</p> <p id='words'>解釈(かいしゃく): explanation, interpretation</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2058</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1909</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2058</p> <p id='keyword'>turn</p> <p id='kanji'>番</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E795AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>turn, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This key word has been chosen for its overlay of several meanings similar to those of the kanji: a <b>turn</b> of duty, a round, a number, and so forth. Its composite elements: <i>animal tracks</i> . . . <i>rice field</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive element, we choose the image of a pair of <i>dice</i> which it is your <i>turn</i> to throw.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>They take turns alternating between wheat and rice in this field…　　RTK2:　バン　電話番号　でんわばんごう(telephone number).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>バン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つが.い</p> <p id='words'>下番(かばん): going off duty<br>番目(ばんめ): cardinal number suffix<br>順番(じゅんばん): turn (in line), order of things<br>当番(とうばん): being on duty<br>番地(ばんち): house number, address<br>留守番(るすばん): care-taking, caretaker, house-watching<br>番組(ばんぐみ): TV program<br>一番(いちばん): best, first, number one, a game, a round, a bout, a fall, an event (in a meet)<br>交番(こうばん): police box<br>番号(ばんごう): number, series of digits</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2059</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1910</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2059</p> <p id='keyword'>hearing</p> <p id='kanji'>審</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AFA9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hearing, house, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>hearing</b> referred to in this character relates to trials in the courts. The elements: <i>house</i> . . . <i>dice</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. (""I can´t believe what I´m hearing!"" you say).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the courthouse the judge decides your hearing with a roll of the dice.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つまび.らか、つぶさ.に</p> <p id='words'>審議(しんぎ): deliberation<br>審査(しんさ): judging, inspection, examination, investigation<br>審判(しんばん): refereeing, trial, judgement, umpire, referee<br>不審(ふしん): incomplete understanding, doubt, question, distrust, suspicion, strangeness, infidelity<br>審判(しんぱん): refereeing, trial, judgement, umpire, referee</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2060</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1911</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2060</p> <p id='keyword'>flip</p> <p id='kanji'>翻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BFBB.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>flip, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains, feathers, wings</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Dice . . . feathers.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Flipping the bird: After finding out the dice is crooked, you kindly present the middle feather to the dealer.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>When the birds out the back are playing dice, they flip their feathers (not their finger) at their opponents.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ホン、ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひるがえ.る、ひるがえ.す</p> <p id='words'>翻訳(ほんやく): translate</p> <p id='readingExamples'>翻す (ひるがえ.す), 翻る (ひるがえ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2061</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1912</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2061</p> <p id='keyword'>clan</p> <p id='kanji'>藩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E897A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>clan, flowers, water, water droplets, water pistol, dice, animal tracks, drop, rice, rice field, brains</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flowers . . . water . . . dice.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans´ location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the particular clan depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her turn watering the flowers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2062</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1913</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2062</p> <p id='keyword'>fur</p> <p id='kanji'>毛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6AF9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>fur</p> <p id='strokeCount'>4</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of <i>hand</i> to produce <b>fur</b>. If you reverse your <i>hand</i> and put its palm down, you will have the side on which <b>fur</b> grows.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I´ve heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That´s not hair, that´s fur!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats don´t like you rubbing your hand backwards over their fur.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>モウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>け</p> <p id='words'>毛(け): fur, hair, wool<br>髪の毛(かみのけ): hair (on head)<br>毛糸(けいと): knitting wool<br>毛皮(けがわ): fur, skin, pelt<br>毛布(もうふ): blanket<br>羊毛(ようもう): wool</p> <p id='readingExamples'>毛 (け)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2065</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1916</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2065</p> <p id='keyword'>home</p> <p id='kanji'>宅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AE85.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>home, house, lock of hair</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>House . . . lock of hair.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This kanji is, of course, pronounced ""taku"", and it seems the owner of this home is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up locks of hair suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his house. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose home you wouldn´t want to visit.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Home is where the hair is.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>タク</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>社宅(しゃたく): company owned house<br>邸宅(ていたく): mansion, residence<br>帰宅(きたく): returning home<br>住宅(じゅうたく): resident, housing<br>宅(たく): house, home, husband<br>お宅(おたく): your house (polite)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2066</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1917</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2066</p> <p id='keyword'>consign</p> <p id='kanji'>託</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A897.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>consign, say, words, keitai, mouth, lock of hair</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . lock of hair.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don´t keep their word).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In ""The Lord of the Rings"", Galadriel consigned a lock of her hair to Gimli the dwarf, along with some wise words.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かこつ.ける、かこ.つ、かこ.つける</p> <p id='words'>委託(いたく): consign (goods (for sale) to a firm), entrust (person with something), commit</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2067</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1918</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2067</p> <p id='keyword'>do</p> <p id='kanji'>為</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E782BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>do, so, strange building, tail feathers</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character rightly belongs to the previous lesson, but we held it until now because of the final element, the <i>tail feathers</i>. After the <i>drop</i> at the outset, the next three strokes are completely novel and should be given special attention.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: ""So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna DO it?"" ""Only if you (ユ) do"" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Do me from behind, says the bird, as she shakes her tailfeathers.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ため、な.る、な.す、す.る、たり、つく.る、なり</p> <p id='words'>行為(こうい): act, deed, conduct<br>為来り(しきたり): customs<br>その為(そのため): hence, for that reason<br>為さる(なさる): to do<br>為替(かわせ): money order, exchange<br>為る(する): do, try, play, practice, cost, serve as, pass, elapse<br>所為(せい): act, deed, one´s doing<br>為(ため): for, in order to<br>為す(なす): accomplish, do<br>為る(なる): change, be of use, reach to</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2068</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1919</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2068</p> <p id='keyword'>falsehood</p> <p id='kanji'>偽</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E581BD.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>falsehood, person, do, so, strange building, tail feathers</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Person . . . do.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A person who claims he didn't do something while he actually did, is telling a falsehood.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It depends on what your definition of do, uh, is, says Mr. T giving falsehood about his affair with a peacock.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギ、カ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>いつわ.る、にせ、いつわ.り</p> <p id='words'>偽造(ぎぞう): forgery, falsification, fabrication, counterfeiting</p> <p id='readingExamples'>偽る (いつわ.る), 偽 (にせ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2070</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1920</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2070</p> <p id='keyword'>long</p> <p id='kanji'>長</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E995B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>long, hair, hairpin, safety-pin</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>In line with the story of the preceding frame, the <i>hair</i> that needs the <i>hairpin</i> is <b>long</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* The primitive of this kanji has two more shapes in addition to that of the kanji itself. Above its relative primitive, it is abbreviated form will mean <i>hair</i>. Further abbreviated,  it will mean the long, mangy <i>mane</i> of an animal.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here´s my story: The girl´s hair was so long that she had to use staples instead of hairpins. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>5</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なが.い、おさ</p> <p id='words'>長(おさ): chief, head<br>生長(せいちょう): growth, increment<br>長官(ちょうかん): chief, (government) secretary<br>長大(ちょうだい): very long, great length<br>長編(ちょうへん): long (e.g. novel film)<br>長々(ながなが): long, drawn-out, very long<br>年長(ねんちょう): seniority<br>長閑(のどか): tranquil, calm, quiet<br>延長(えんちょう): extension, elongation, prolongation, lengthening<br>議長(ぎちょう): chairman<br>身長(しんちょう): height (of body), stature<br>成長(せいちょう): growth, grow to adulthood<br>長期(ちょうき): long time period<br>長所(ちょうしょ): strong point, merit, advantage<br>長女(ちょうじょ): eldest daughter<br>長短(ちょうたん): length, long and short, advantages and disadvantages, pluses and minuses, strong and weak points, merits and demerits<br>長男(ちょうなん): eldest son<br>長方形(ちょうほうけい): rectangle, oblong<br>特長(とくちょう): forte, merit<br>長引く(ながびく): be prolonged, drag on<br>校長(こうちょう): principal<br>社長(しゃちょう): president<br>長い(ながい): long</p> <p id='readingExamples'>長い (なが.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_5 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2071</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1921</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2071</p> <p id='keyword'>lengthen</p> <p id='kanji'>張</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BCB5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>lengthen, bow, long</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>52</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Bow . . . long.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The longbow is follows the design of a standard bow, only it has been lengthened.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Legolas recieves spam telling him that his can lengthen his ""bow""...he smirks...he know´s it´s already long enough.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>は.る、-は.り、-ば.り</p> <p id='words'>嵩張る(かさばる): to be bulky, to be unwieldy, to grow voluminous<br>誇張(こちょう): exaggeration<br>突っ張る(つっぱる): to support, to become stiff, to become taut, to thrust (ones opponent), to stick to (ones opinion), to insist on<br>張り紙(はりがみ): paper patch, paper backing, poster<br>矢っ張り(やっぱり): also, as I thought, still, in spite of, absolutely<br>威張る(いばる): swagger, be proud<br>拡張(かくちょう): expansion, extension, enlargement, escape<br>緊張(きんちょう): tension, mental strain, nervousness<br>主張(しゅちょう): claim, request, insistence, assertion, advocacy, emphasis, contention, opinion, tenet<br>出張(しゅっちょう): official tour, business trip<br>張り切る(はりきる): be in high spirits, be full of vigor, be enthusiastic, be eager, stretch to breaking point<br>張る(はる): to stick, paste, put, affix, stretch, spread, strain, stick out, slap, be expensive, tighten<br>引っ張る(ひっぱる): pull, draw, stretch, drag<br>欲張り(よくばり): avarice, covetousness, greed</p> <p id='readingExamples'>張る (は.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

""Soil"" is not drawn in its stroke order.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji means miss as in ""miss a (dearly departed) person"", not as in ""miss a target"".　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Here the dearly departed has been buried in the ground, with her favourite hairpin in place of a gravestone, and two mourners stand around crying with open mouths.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>も</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>喪 (も)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2085</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1935</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2085</p> <p id='keyword'>trouble</p> <p id='kanji'>悩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E682A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>trouble, Freud, state of mind, owl, villain, sheaf, shovel</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>State of mind . . . owl . . . villain.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>When I am in trouble, my state of mind is on two sides: 1. The wise part of me (owl) 2. The villain part of me (villain) Think of the devil and the angel on your shoulders in a troubled situation.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The owl villain is the one that troubles me most of all the super-villains. He´s just so smart... you never know what he´ll do! Definitely enough to put you in a troubled state of mind.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ノウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なや.む、なや.ます、なや.ましい、なやみ</p> <p id='words'>悩ましい(なやましい): seductive, melancholy, languid<br>悩ます(なやます): to afflict, to torment, to harass, to molest<br>悩み(なやみ): trouble(s), worry, distress, anguish, agony, problem<br>悩む(なやむ): be worried, be troubled</p> <p id='readingExamples'>悩ます (なや.ます), 悩む (なや.む)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2086</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1936</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2086</p> <p id='keyword'>stern</p> <p id='kanji'>厳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E58EB3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stern, owl, cliff, daring, spike, ear, taskmaster</p> <p id='strokeCount'>17</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Owl . . . cliff . . . daring.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This represents a stern looking owl, perched up on a cliff. This cliff is quite famous for daring individuals to cliff dive off of, but is any of them daring enough to threaten the owl?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The daring mouse gets a stern look after he climbs onto the owl´s cliff...　RTK2:　ゲン　厳禁　　げんきん　(""Strickly Prohibited!"")　　　　　　　　　　　ゴン　華厳経　けごんギョウ(Avatamsaka Sutra).</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲン、ゴン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おごそ.か、きび.しい、いか.めしい、いつくし</p> <p id='words'>厳か(おごそか): austere, majestic, dignified, stately, awful, impressive<br>厳密(げんみつ): strict, close<br>厳重(げんじゅう): strict, severe, firm, strong, secure, rigour<br>厳しい(きびしい): strict</p> <p id='readingExamples'>厳格 (げんかく), 厳重 (げんじゅう), 威厳 (いげん), 厳か (おごそ.か), 厳しい (きび.しい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2087</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1937</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2087</p> <p id='keyword'>chain</p> <p id='kanji'>鎖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E98E96.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>chain, metal, gold, small, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Metal</i> . . . <i>little</i> . . . <i>shells</i>. We have saved this character until no win order to draw attention to the visual difference between the <i>owl</i> and <i>little</i>. By now your eyes should be so accustomed to these apparently infinitesimal differences that the point is obvious.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The chain on this chainsaw is made of little metal shells.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A gold chain with small seashells hanging on it is in fashion these days.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>くさり、とざ.す</p> <p id='words'>封鎖(ふうさ): blockade, freezing (funds)<br>閉鎖(へいさ): closing, closure, shutdown, lockout, unsociable<br>鎖(くさり): chain</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鎖 (くさり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2088</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1938</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2088</p> <p id='keyword'>raise</p> <p id='kanji'>挙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68C99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>raise, owl, tool, hand</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Owl . . . tool . . . hand.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The owl was asked to raise his hand if he needed anything, but he had a wing, not a hand! So he made a tool that looked like a hand which he used when he needed to raise his hand. For raiseing, owl has a tool hand.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>What raises mankind above others is the wisdom of an owl, the use of tools, and his hand with an opposable thumb. (compare with reputation (#1939)).</p> <p id='jouYou'>4</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あ.げる、あ.がる、こぞ.る</p> <p id='words'>挙げる(あげる): to raise, to fly, to give (an example)<br>一挙に(いっきょに): at a stroke, with a single swoop<br>選挙(せんきょ): election</p> <p id='readingExamples'>挙がる (あ.がる), 挙げる (あ.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_4</p>"

So, for 鼡 (which I´ll call rat) I have: an owl, flying in the wind, can easily spot a rat even if it´s hiding in the cornstalks. Now 猟 is easy: wild dogs are having fun by game-hunting rats.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The WILD DOGS are GAME HUNTING the OWL who flies like the WIND through the CORN STORKS.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>リョウ、レフ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かり、か.る</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2091</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1941</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2091</p> <p id='keyword'>bird</p> <p id='kanji'>鳥</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9B3A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>bird, white, dove, one, tail feathers</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Dove</i> . . . <i>one</i> . . . <i>tail feathers</i>. This is, of course, the character from which we derived the primitive meaning of <i>dove</i>. Note the lengthening of the second stroke.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There is only one bird with such beautiful white tail feathers: the albino peakcock.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The BIRD let loose a WHITE ONE from it´s TAIL FEATHERS...right on my new car!</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とり</p> <p id='words'>鳥居(とりい): torii (Shinto shrine archway)<br>渡り鳥(わたりどり): migratory bird, bird of passage<br>小鳥(ことり): (small) bird<br>鳥(とり): bird, fowl, poultry</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鳥 (とり)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2092</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1942</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2092</p> <p id='keyword'>chirp</p> <p id='kanji'>鳴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9B3B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>chirp, mouth, bird</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Mouth . . . bird.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A chirp is quite simply the sound that comes from the mouth of birds.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This kanji is not limited to the chirp of a bird, but stands for the sound of any kind of animal. Picture a very weird bird that can imitate with its mouth (a bird with mouth, heh) the voice of many different animals: Meeow! Woof! Mooo! Cuack!!! (Maybe the bird has Kirby powers and obtains the abilities of the animals it eats).</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>メイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>な.く、な.る、な.らす</p> <p id='words'>共鳴(きょうめい): resonance, sympathy<br>怒鳴る(どなる): to shout, to yell<br>悲鳴(ひめい): shriek, scream<br>鳴らす(ならす): ring, sound, chime, beat<br>鳴る(なる): sound, ring<br>鳴く(なく): bark, purr, chirp, make sound (animal)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鳴く (な.く), 鳴らす (な.らす), 鳴る (な.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2093</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1943</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2093</p> <p id='keyword'>crane</p> <p id='kanji'>鶴</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9B6B4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crane, turkey house, bird</p> <p id='strokeCount'>21</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Turkey house</i> . . . <i>bird</i>. The first element appears on only one other occasion, back in frame 609.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Do you know how cranes came to be? Well, they used to keep the poor bird cooped all the time. But the crane really wanted to be free, so it would always streatch its head and neck out of the coop trying to be free.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The original version of the ""Ugly Duckling"" was about a crane who grew up in a turkey coop. All the other birds made fun of it for not having a wattle or a snood or fanning its tail...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つる</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>鶴 (つる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2094</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1944</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2094</p> <p id='keyword'>crow</p> <p id='kanji'>烏</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7838F.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>crow, drop, mouth, one, tail feathers</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The only thing that distinguishes this character from that for <i>bird</i> is the omission of the one stroke that makes it <i>white</i>. Which is logical enough, when you consider that there are no <b>crows</b> of that color.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The book´s story is just fine, but I found a kanji dictionary explanation also interesting: As crows are all black, it´s hard to see where their eyes are (black on black), so a stroke is removed from the part in the pictograph where the eyes would be.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A crow is a bird, but not a white one. MEANING: write bird, but skip writing one in white.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ウ、オ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>からす、いずくんぞ、なんぞ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_Names</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2095</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1945</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2095</p> <p id='keyword'>vine</p> <p id='kanji'>蔦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E894A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>vine, flowers, bird</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Flower . . . bird.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the jungle there is a flowery vine called hedera rhombea that attracts humming birds by the dozens. They scoot around the flowers sucking up nectar off the vine.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Note : if you´ll remember we already have a primitive for ""ivy"", but it was completely made up from the ""square jewel"" kanji. The kanji here refers to ivy, or vine, and is used in a particular compound for ""Hedera rhombea"", which is a type of ivy native to Japan. This vine here produces a lot of flowers, and attracts many small birds, which is sure to cheer up even the most depressed Japanese gardener.</p> <p id='jouYou'>Names</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>チョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つた</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_Names</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2098</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1948</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2098</p> <p id='keyword'>island</p> <p id='kanji'>島</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B3B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>island, bird, mountain</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>bird's tail</i> is tucked under here, because it has come to stop on a <i>mountain</i> to rest from its journey across the waters. Thus the kanji comes to mean an <b>island</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This island is the home of the terrible mythical bird Roc. It sits mighty atop the mountain waiting for the next hapless ship to pass by.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Birds living on remote mountainous islands have few preditors. Tail feathers aren´t really needed are they? Evolutionary process at work!...　RTK2:　トウ　半島　はんとう(peninsula).</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しま</p> <p id='words'>半島(はんとう): peninsula<br>列島(れっとう): chain of islands<br>島(しま): island</p> <p id='readingExamples'>島 (しま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2099</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1949</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2099</p> <p id='keyword'>warmth</p> <p id='kanji'>暖</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E69A96.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>warmth, sun, day, migrating ducks, claw, vulture, one, friend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Unlike the character for <i>warm</i> weather learned earlier (Frame 1560), this kanji and its key word can also refer to the <b>warmth</b> of human congeniality. Its elements are: <i>sun</i> . . . <i>migrating ducks</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Note: Just confirming Heisig has confused these two characters. This is used primarily for weather and climate (and colours).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A massive group of migrating ducks is blocking the warmth of the sun as they pass over your house/barbecue/picnic. Their formation is so humongous they block the warmth for a good 10 minutes while they pass over. Mnemonic for the migrating ducks primitive : the migrating ducks stick together like the best of friends, flying together as one (fifth stroke), they are not easy prey for the great eagles / vultures.</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ダン、ノン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>あたた.か、あたた.かい、あたた.まる、あたた.める</p> <p id='words'>暖まる(あたたまる): to warm oneself, to sun oneself, to warm up, to get warm<br>暖める(あたためる): to warm, to heat<br>温暖(おんだん): warmth<br>暖房(だんぼう): heating<br>暖かい(あたたかい): warm, mild, genial</p> <p id='readingExamples'>暖か (あたた.か), 暖かい (あたた.かい), 暖まる (あたた.まる), 暖める (あたた.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2100</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1950</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2100</p> <p id='keyword'>beautiful woman</p> <p id='kanji'>媛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5AA9B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>beautiful woman, woman, migrating ducks, claw, vulture, one, friend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Woman . . . migrating ducks.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You want to know about a beautiful woman? 	"<p id='id'>2101</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1951</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2101</p> <p id='keyword'>abet</p> <p id='kanji'>援</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68FB4.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>abet, finger, fingers, migrating ducks, claw, vulture, one, friend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'>assistance</p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . migrating ducks.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>You abet the escape of migrating ducks by pointing them the way.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Aiding and abetting: You are accuse of abetting a drug dealer, by smuggling drugs in migrating ducks. Of course, this means you have to stick your fingers in their mouths.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>エン</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>救援(きゅうえん): relief, rescue, reinforcement<br>援助(えんじょ): assistance, aid, support<br>応援(おうえん): aid, assistance, help, reinforcement, support, cheering</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2102</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1952</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2102</p> <p id='keyword'>slacken</p> <p id='kanji'>緩</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7B7A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>slacken, thread, spiderman, migrating ducks, claw, vulture, one, friend</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Thread . . . migrating ducks.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>[slacken; loosen; relax; lessen; be moderate; ease] The thread in this story is a cable line, something like a power or phone line. The thread was tense with all the migrating ducks perched on it, but got back to being slackened when the entire flock flew away. (darg_sama-modified,2-11-2005).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Spiderman is a slacken off. He lays around all day in the park watching migrating ducks...　RTK2:　カン　緩和　かんわ(mitigation).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>カン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ゆる.い、ゆる.やか、ゆる.む、ゆる.める</p> <p id='words'>緩和(かんわ): relief, mitigation<br>緩む(ゆるむ): to become loose, to slacken<br>緩める(ゆるめる): to loosen, to slow down<br>緩やか(ゆるやか): lenient<br>緩い(ゆるい): loose, lenient, slow</p> <p id='readingExamples'>緩い (ゆる.い), 緩む (ゆる.む), 緩める (ゆる.める), 緩やか (ゆる.やか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2103</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1953</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2103</p> <p id='keyword'>belong</p> <p id='kanji'>属</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B19E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>belong, flag, gnats, drop, insect, belt</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Flag</i> . . . <i>gnats</i> (see frame 563) . . . with a <i>belt</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>These bugs BELONG TO an extremist group promoting insect independence. They are parading the FLAG of their group, the Nationalist GNATS, and wearing explosives BELTS for their planned terrorist war.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This FLAG BELONGS to the terror group called the GNATS, oftern seen wearing explosive BELTS. My opinion is they all BELONG in jail.</p> <p id='jouYou'>5</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゾク、ショク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さかん、つく、やから</p> <p id='words'>所属(しょぞく): attached to, belong to<br>付属(ふぞく): attached, belonging, affiliated, annexed, associated, subordinate, incidental, dependent, auxiliary<br>金属(きんぞく): metal<br>属する(ぞくする): belong to, come under, be affiliated with, be subject to<br>附属(ふぞく): attached, belonging, affiliated, annexed, associated, subordinate, incidental, dependent, auxiliary</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_5</p>"

My mouth belongs to you and your secret is safely entrusted with me.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>If you entrust me with something, my mouth belongs to you.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しょく.する、たの.む</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2105</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1955</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2105</p> <p id='keyword'>accidentally</p> <p id='kanji'>偶</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E581B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>accidentally, person, talking cricket, brains, insect, belt</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>person</i> on the left is familiar. As for the right side, we may combine the <i>insect</i> with a <i>brain</i> (observe the writing) and a <i>belt</i> to create the <i>Talking Cricket</i> who served as Pinocchio's conscience. (<i>The belt</i> is there because he pulls it off to give unrepentant little Pinocchio a bit of ""strap"" now and again.)</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Mr. T accidentially stepped on Jiminy Cricket (a brainy insect, with a belt sort of sash to hold his ""conscience"" badge).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Mr. T accidentally steps on Jiminy Cricket. // Primitive: right side: Talking cricket = Jiminy Cricket, a brainy insect with a belt to whip little kids who misbehave.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>グウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たま</p> <p id='words'>偶(たま): even number, couple, man and wife, friend, same kind, doll, occasional, rare<br>偶に(たまに): occasionally, once in a while<br>配偶者(はいぐうしゃ): spouse, wife, husband<br>偶数(ぐうすう): even number<br>偶然(ぐうぜん): chance, accident, fortuity, unexpectedly, suddenly<br>偶々(たまたま): casually, unexpectedly, accidentally, by chance</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The elements for composing it are: <i>mountain goat</i> . . . <i>moon</i> . . . <i>soil</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>This guy is such a gifted sculptor. He can model a MOUNTAIN GOAT and a MOON with just SOIL mold.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A legend says that if you model a mountain goat (with tail and everything) from dirt and leave to the light of the moon on the first day of the month (#2846), the dirt will became flesh. (blackstockc).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>でく</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2112</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1961</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2112</p> <p id='keyword'>Mount</p> <p id='kanji'>岡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B2A1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>mount, glass canopy, hood, mountain goat, horns, mountain</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Here we see a  <i>mountain goat</i> ""<b>mounted</b>"" under a <i>glass canopy</i>. In this and the following frames, think of a particular <b>Mount</b> you know.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>White mount , Fuji mount , olympus mount whatever ....The choice is yours but wherever you go they sell those snowglobe souvenir : under a GLASS HOOD you can see the mount with a MOUTAIN GOAT standing on top of it .... So kitsch you just can´t forget it .</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This has the same meaning as 丘, so my ""Mount"" is a hill with mountain goats on it under a glass canopy. It´s obviously an effort by the locals to add some Mount atmosphere to their hill. As a primitive, it has the meaning ""sturdy"" (really), which Heisig has not used for some reason, but I will. The glass canopy must be pretty sturdy to keep the goats inside (bulletproof glass, I´m sure).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>コウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おか</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>岡 (おか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

Perhaps this is because it´s symmetry is believed to make it rather sturdy itself, unlike all those crooked mountains that are around and tend to fall apart (think rock slides, avalanches, etc.). Here we see Sturdy-brand sabers with Mount Fuji engraved on the blade.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ゴウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

China. For some reason he insisted on working at the top of a pinnacle, away from the distractions of the world. He kept in touch with the local people, and took orders, through bound tin cans (tin cans bound with rope, the children's version of the telephone).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>トウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>鬱陶しい(うっとうしい): gloomy, depressing<br>陶器(とうき): pottery, ceramics</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2118</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1967</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2118</p> <p id='keyword'>swing</p> <p id='kanji'>揺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E68FBA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>swing, finger, fingers, condor, claw, vulture, king, mountain</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Fingers . . . condor.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Primitive: A condor is like a vulture but twice the size and lives in mountainous regions (+1 Elphalpo). Story: I swing my fingers back and forth, trying to fend off the attacking condor.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>For the condor primitive: A condor is like a vulture, but twice as big and it lives near mountains (a suitable place for such a majestic bird). For swing: I´m sitting on a swing when a condor comes by and picks up the whole swing set with its big finger-like claws and now I´m swinging in mid-air. 	"<p id='id'>2119</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1968</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2119</p> <p id='keyword'>Noh chanting</p> <p id='kanji'>謡</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8ACA1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>noh chanting, say, words, keitai, mouth, condor, claw, vulture, king, mountain</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Words . . . condor.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Noh chanting?!? I meant ""NO CHANTING!"" Now all you, just shut up! Not another word! Don´t you know that chanting can provoke attacks from the local condor? So, no chanting, and especially no Noh chanting.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Picture guy dressed in a condor mask up on stage during Noh performance chanting some words nobody understands.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うた.い、うた.う</p> <p id='words'>歌謡(かよう): song, ballad<br>民謡(みんよう): folk song, popular song</p> <p id='readingExamples'>謡う (うた.う), 謡 (うたい)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2121</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1969</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2121</p> <p id='keyword'>concerning</p> <p id='kanji'>就</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5B0B1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>concerning, capital, tall, top hat, mouth, small, little, understandably, chihuahua with one human leg</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Capital</i> . . . <i>chihuahua</i> with a <i>human leg</i> in place of one of its paws.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In the capital they have been having hearings concerning bioethics and bioengineering they call as their first witness a chihuahua with one human leg.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Ahem...CONCERNING your recent science fair project, it was a CAPITAL idea, but the CHIHUAHUA with a HUMAN LEG is freaking out the other contestants!</p> <p id='jouYou'>6</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ、ジュ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つ.く、つ.ける</p> <p id='words'>就業(しゅうぎょう): employment, starting work<br>就任(しゅうにん): inauguration<br>就職(しゅうしょく): finding employment, inauguration<br>就く(つく): settle in (place), take (seat, position), study (under teacher)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>就任 (しゅうにん), 就寝 (しゅうしん), 去就 (きょしゅう), 就く (つ.く), 就ける (つ.ける)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_6</p>"

The elements: <i>skunk</i> . . . <i>silver</i> . . . <i>soil</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>It was the groundbreaking of the new farm, but there was an uninvited guest to the ceremony. It was a famous skunk, the one with the familiar silver stripe. The feet of the crowd rushing from the ceremony site churned up the soil very nicely. The ceremony was ruined but the groundbreaking was a great success.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I got sprayed by a skunk, so no one is helping me with the groundbreaking of my farm. 	"<p id='id'>2126</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1972</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2126</p> <p id='keyword'>excuse</p> <p id='kanji'>免</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5858D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>excuse, village stocks, rabbit, bound up, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character is used for <b>excusing</b> oneself for a failure of courtesy. The elements are: <i>bound up</i> . . . <i>sun</i> (oddly enough, laid on its side) . . . <i>human legs</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* For the primitive meaning, we shall refer to this character as a <i>rabbit</i>, for which the old form of the character is 兔.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Obviously this is the rabbit from Alice, excusing himself and rushing away on his legs, as he has a binding day schedule. This is at the same time an image, with bound=ears, day=head and legs are just legs. The image is used in rabbit (#2093).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>What is the rabbit´s excuse for being such a jerk? Well he was bound up for a whole day while being stepped on by peoples human legs in some make-up labratory. Yeah I think I can excuse him after knowing that.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>メン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>まぬか.れる、まぬが.れる</p> <p id='words'>御免ください(ごめんください): May I come in?<br>御免なさい(ごめんなさい): I beg your pardon, excuse me<br>免れる(まぬかれる): to escape from, to be rescued from, to avoid, to evade, to avert, to elude, to be exempted, to be relieved from pain, to get rid of<br>免除(めんじょ): exemption, exoneration, discharge<br>御免(ごめん): your pardon, declining (something), dismissal, permission<br>免許(めんきょ): license, permit, certificate<br>免税(めんぜい): tax exemption</p> <p id='readingExamples'>免れる (まぬか.れる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2132</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1978</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2132</p> <p id='keyword'>horse</p> <p id='kanji'>馬</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A6AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>horse, team of horses</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Let the extra vertical stroke in the <i>mane</i> combine with the first vertical stroke to give an image of the <b>horse's</b> long neck. The only odd thing is the <i>tail feathers</i> at the end, but that should present a good image to remember the character by. The fact that the last stroke of <i>mane</i> and the first of <i>tail feathers</i> coincide should no longer surprise you.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji will mean a <i>team of horses</i> as distinct from the single <i>horse</i> whose primitive we met earlier.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail ""feathers"". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The top part is half a comb (see frame 1920) with an extra vertical stroke to account for a sturdier version used to comb a horse mane. As a primitive I used the theme of the Trojan Horse. Not the modern computer viruses, but the large wooden horse which led to the demise of Troy and of the Trojans. Either its size (much greater than a live horse), or the fact that it conceals things into its belly, will set it appart from the horse primitive that came in frame 568 (""noon"").</p> <p id='jouYou'>2</p> <p id='jlpt'>3</p> <p id='onYomi'>バ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うま、うま-、ま</p> <p id='words'>馬鹿馬鹿しい(ばかばかしい): stupid<br>馬鹿らしい(ばからしい): absurd<br>馬(うま): horse<br>競馬(けいば): horse racing<br>馬鹿(ばか): fool, idiot, trivial matter, folly</p> <p id='readingExamples'>馬 (うま)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_3 Jouyou_2</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2138</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1984</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2138</p> <p id='keyword'>station</p> <p id='kanji'>駅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A785.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>station, team of horses, shaku-hachi, flag, stick</p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Team of horses . . . shakuhachi.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Anyone living in Japan knows that train stations play little melodies when the train is about to arrive. In Ye Olden Days, when horses and carriages were used for transport, the carriage driver would play a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know the carriage was arriving at the next station.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A homeless horse playing the flute at the station to make a dime.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>4</p> <p id='onYomi'>エキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>駅(えき): station</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_4 Jouyou_3</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2139</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1985</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2139</p> <p id='keyword'>boisterous</p> <p id='kanji'>騒</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A892.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>boisterous, team of horses, crotch, insect</p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'>bruyant</p> <p id='heisigStory'>Team of horses . . . crotch . . . insect.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Or more precisely: the team of horses are getting boisterous because one of them got bitten in the crotch by a horse fly. The kanji also means to roar, make up noise, to kick up a fuss and to make merry. Perhaps it is exactly the etymology behind this kanji.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The hidden Greeks inside the Trojan Horse are getting boisterous as one of them is bitten in the crotch by a nasty insect. If they don´t shut up, the Trojans will hear them...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さわ.ぐ、うれい、さわ.がしい</p> <p id='words'>騒動(そうどう): strife, riot, rebellion<br>騒がしい(さわがしい): noisy<br>騒ぎ(さわぎ): uproar, disturbance<br>騒音(そうおん): noise<br>騒々しい(そうぞうしい): noisy, boisterous<br>物騒(ぶっそう): dangerous, disturbed, insecure<br>騒ぐ(さわぐ): make a noise</p> <p id='readingExamples'>騒ぐ (さわ.ぐ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

The Trojans stood in awe of the magnificent Trojan Horse that they thought was a gift. But imagine their surprise (wonder) when a bunch of Greeks came rushing out of it! (To further cement the connection between the primitives, if needed: It´s a wonder that the Trojans managed to speak keigo 敬語 even then, saying ""わたくしたちを殺さないでください!!お願い致します!!"").</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おどろ.く、おどろ.かす</p> <p id='words'>驚き(おどろき): surprise, astonishment, wonder<br>驚異(きょうい): wonder, miracle<br>吃驚(びっくり): be surprised, be amazed, be frightened, astonishment<br>驚かす(おどろかす): surprise, frighten, create a stir<br>驚く(おどろく): to surprise</p> <p id='readingExamples'>驚かす (おどろ.かす), 驚く (おどろ.く)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2145</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1990</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2145</p> <p id='keyword'>tiger</p> <p id='kanji'>虎</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8998E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tiger, magic wand, augury, cliff, hook, diced, seven, human legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The kanji in this frame recalls the famous Bengali fable about the group of magicians (the <i>magic wand</i>) who decided to make a <b>tiger</b>. It seems that each of them knew how to make one part of the beast, so they pooled their talents and brought all the pieces (<i>diced</i> into pieces) together, at which point the fabricated <b><i>tiger</i></b> promptly ate its makers up (the bodiless <i>human legs</i>). Whatever the parable's significance for modern civilization and its arsenals, it should help with this kanji. Oh yes, we should not forget that cliff-like element. Think of it as an abbreviation of the primitive for <i>zoo</i> (the first and fourth strokes, actually), in order to fit the <b>tiger</b> somewhere into the picture. In fact, the abbreviation is perfectly logical, since the bottom elements usurp the room for the rest of the primitive for <i>zoo</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive element itself, the <i>human legs</i> are also swallowed up, but the meaning of <i>tiger</i> is kept, and the whole serves as a roof for what comes beneath 虍, giving the <i>tiger</i> something else to eat.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Magic wand + first two strokes of pelt (皮) + diced + human legs. A wizard who turns people he doesn´t like into newts with his magic wand goes for variety - he has always wanted a tiger pelt - but things go awry when the tiger promptly dices and eats him, leaving only a pair of legs. (a fitting end for a wicked wizard).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Tigger, the tiger, (from Pooh stories) is happy to have found a magic wand. Using it he can bounce up to a the top of a cliff, seven times as high as some human legs could bounce. Tigger thinks ""Its great to be a tiger!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>コ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>とら</p> <p id='words'>虎(とら): tiger</p> <p id='readingExamples'>虎 (とら)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2146</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1991</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2146</p> <p id='keyword'>captive</p> <p id='kanji'>虜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8999C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>captive, tiger, male, rice field, brains, power, muscle, arnold</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tiger . . . man.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Captive men are thrown to the tigers. 	"<p id='id'>2150</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1995</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2150</p> <p id='keyword'>uneasiness</p> <p id='kanji'>虞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8999E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>uneasiness, tiger, give, mouth, chair, tool</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tiger . . . give.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I feel a sense of uneasiness about giving this HUGE tiger a steak.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>My dear friend, a Bengali merchant, gave me a tiger as a birthday present. 	"<p id='id'>2153</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1998</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2153</p> <p id='keyword'>tyrannize</p> <p id='kanji'>虐</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E89990.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>tyrannize, tiger, one, box</p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Tiger</i> . . . <i>box</i> with a <i>one</i> in it (or a backwards <i>broom</i>, if that makes it easier).</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Here we see the evil tyrannizing tiger. What is on his chest? A giant E, for EVIL, of course.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The ""E"" shape actually means claws here, and the real etymology is a tiger tyrannizing other animals with its claws (the etymologies actually make sense once in a blue moon!). I think of the claws here as two hooks, representing the front paws. (stroke order of that part: 二＋last of 直).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ギャク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しいた.げる</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>虐げる (しいた.げる)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2154</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>1999</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2154</p> <p id='keyword'>deer</p> <p id='kanji'>鹿</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9B9BF.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>deer, cave, antlers, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Drawn on the walls of a complex of <i>caves</i> near Niaux in southern France are a number of animal likenesses dating from the Upper Paleolithic period. Among them we find pictures of <b>deer</b>, some of them showing men in <b>deer</b> masks. By <i>comparing</i> their drawings to real <b>deer</b>, Stone Age people hoped to acquire power over the animal in the hunt; and by <i>comparing</i> themselves to the <b>deer</b>, to take on that animal's characteristics. But time has locked with a ""double-<i>key</i>"" (the extra stroke through the element for <i>key</i>) the real secret of this art form from us, and we can only surmise such meanings. But more important than the enigmas of the troglodytic mind is the way in which <i>caves</i>, a double-<i>key</i>, and <i>comparing</i> gives us the kanji for <b>deer</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'>* As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated much the same as the <i>tiger</i> was: the lower element is dropped to leave room for a replacement. Its meaning, however, remains the same. There are a very few cases (see frame 2158) in which there is no abbreviation. When this happens, we may keep the image suggested by the above explanation: <i>painting of a deer</i>.</p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Bambi wanders into a cave and sees a side order of salad and 2 spoons...but what´s the main course?</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Santa´s reindeer, Rudolf, opens a nightclub in a cave. It´s popular with all the deer and reindeer in the world. The cave speciality is a salad w/ dressing on the side. There is no other deer club that can compare. How many other deer nightclubs are there?</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ロク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しか、か</p> <p id='words'>馬鹿馬鹿しい(ばかばかしい): stupid<br>馬鹿らしい(ばからしい): absurd<br>馬鹿(ばか): fool, idiot, trivial matter, folly</p> <p id='readingExamples'>鹿 (しかか)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2156</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2000</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2156</p> <p id='keyword'>recommend</p> <p id='kanji'>薦</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E896A6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>recommend, flowers, deer, cave, antlers, slingshot, catapult, tail feathers</p> <p id='strokeCount'>16</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Flowers</i> . . . <i>deer</i> . . . <i>one</i> . . . <i>tail feathers</i>. Note the doubling up in these last two elements as in frame 2091.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Customer in restaurant asks you (waiter) what you recommend: ""I recommend ze deer or ze 'eadless chicken. And I recommend you garnish it wiz some flowers."" (let last six strokes = headless chicken).</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It is recommended that deers stick to eating flowers. If they try to eat birds, they may end up choking on them, like this one here. Note that the head (白) is gone and the visible part of the body which is normally written with a stroke of the head must by necessity be drawn with a stroke of the tail.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すす.める</p> <p id='words'>推薦(すいせん): recommendation</p> <p id='readingExamples'>薦める (すす.める)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2157</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2001</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2157</p> <p id='keyword'>jubilation</p> <p id='kanji'>慶</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E685B6.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>jubilation, deer, cave, antlers, crown, heart, walking legs</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Deer</i> . . . <i>crown</i> (note the doubling up) . . . <i>heart</i> . . . <i>walking legs</i>. Helpful in war, yes, but also a boon for agriculture. The dragon could use its sharp claws to plough the ground, and use its firey breath to clear the land. But first you'd have to bend the dragon to your will -- not an easy task.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It's a good agricultural sign when, as the farmer is bending down, he discovers some plants arranged in the sign of the dragon. It means the weather and earth will be supportive of the crops.</p> <p id='jouYou'>3</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ノウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'>農耕(のうこう): farming, agriculture<br>農場(のうじょう): farm (agriculture)<br>農村(のうそん): agricultural community, farm village, rural<br>農地(のうち): agricultural land<br>酪農(らくのう): dairy (farm)<br>農家(のうか): farmer, farm family<br>農業(のうぎょう): agriculture<br>農産物(のうさんぶつ): agricultural produce<br>農民(のうみん): farmers, peasants<br>農薬(のうやく): agricultural chemicals</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_3</p>"

Just add water... oh wait...</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>2</p> <p id='onYomi'>ノウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>こ.い</p> <p id='words'>濃い(こい): thick (as of color, liquid), dense, strong<br>濃度(のうど): concentration, brightness</p> <p id='readingExamples'>濃い (こ.い)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_2 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2181</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2025</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2181</p> <p id='keyword'>attack</p> <p id='kanji'>襲</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A5B2.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>attack, old dragon, vase, stand up, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, slingshot, catapult, snake, self, three, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment, dragon*</p> <p id='strokeCount'>22</p> <p id='lessonNo'>55</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Vase</i> . . . <i>meat</i> . . . <i>slingshot</i> (doubled up with) <i>snake</i> . . . <i>three</i> . . . <i>garment</i>. The top half of this character is the old form for the kanji in frame 575.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The top 16 strokes are the chinese radical for ""dragon"". Joining up both meanings of the radical we can name the top part of this kanji ""imperial dragon"". Two-headed snakes do exist as biological curiosities, and they look a bit like a slingshot (with the heads splitting at a junction). Our imperial dragon here, the pet of a Chinese emperor, is a rare ""three-headed slingshot-snake"" kept in a vase and fed with meat. When the emperor attacked neighbours, his army wore the imperial dragon garment.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You attack an old dragon 龍 and take his clothes. REF: dragon [old] (#2981).</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おそ.う、かさ.ね</p> <p id='words'>襲う(おそう): to attack<br>襲撃(しゅうげき): attack, charge, raid</p> <p id='readingExamples'>襲う (おそ.う)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Play on words. I imagine visiting someone who has an impressive collection of medals and trophies (chess champion, for example). After spending an hour showing you all the trophies in the glass shelf, you think ""Whew! It´s over."" ... but the person says ""... and wait, there´s ""moreover"" !"", pointing at more trophies lined atop the glass shelf.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ショ、ソ、ショウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.つ</p> <p id='words'>且つ(かつ): yet, and</p> <p id='readingExamples'>且つ (か.つ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

You know how nori, ie: seaweed, comes in sheets for putting in your ramen or for your sushi? Well that's because it's water paper! Seaweed is also a sea flower of sorts, so it all just works out.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Let wooden goods = furniture. Then: Walking along the sea shore you see some washed-up furniture with water (waves) splashing against it. From a distance it looks like flowers are growing out the top, but as you get closer you see it is in fact seaweed.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ソウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>も</p> <p id='words'>藻掻く(もがく): to struggle, to wriggle, to be impatient</p> <p id='readingExamples'>藻 (も)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Think of slave in the virtual sense (a slave to your passions). The samurai is standing on the altar lecturing about goodwill (see goodwill (#1097)). He notices the boredom of most of the crowd. However some audience members are attentive about the message of goodwill. The samurai views his sermon as a sieve of character: those of good character pass through and see the merit; those of poor character - slaves to their passions - are blocked from understanding.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>レイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>したが.う、しもべ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>108</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2169</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>108</p> <p id='keyword'>curse</p> <p id='kanji'>呪</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E591AA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>curse, mouth, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs, mouth2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>8</p> <p id='lessonNo'>6</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>For some reason, the inventor of this kanji associated a <b>curse</b> with the <i>mouth</i> of an <i>older brother</i>. 	"<p id='id'>57</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2178</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>57</p> <p id='keyword'>pop song</p> <p id='kanji'>唄</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59484.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pop song, mouth, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>4</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>There is a lot of money to be made of one's <b>songs</b> are ""<b>pop</b>ular."" This is depicted here as a stream of <i>clams</i> spewing out of the <i>mouth</i> of someone performing a <b>pop song</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The new generation of pop songs have no depth. They just mouth empty lyrics to get money. Not like the pop songs of my day.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A new way for sluts to use their mouths to make alot of money.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>バイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うた、うた.う</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>唄 (うた)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>151</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2296</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>151</p> <p id='keyword'>grains of sand</p> <p id='kanji'>沙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B299.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>grains of sand, water, water droplets, water pistol, few</p> <p id='strokeCount'></p> <p id='lessonNo'></p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>We have already learned the kanji for <i>sand</i> (Frame 122), so let's use it to remember the character for <b>grains of sand</b>. Instead of the ""few stones"" that make for nice sand, here we have a <i>few drops of water</i>, one for each <b>grand of sand</b> - a beach in perfect ecological balance.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Wet sand is simply sand but to see beautiful grains of sand, the water must be few.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Near the water is one of the few places you will find grains of sand.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>サ、シャ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すな、よなげる</p> <p id='words'>ご無沙汰(ごぶさた): not writing or contacting for a while<br>無沙汰(ぶさた): neglecting to stay in contact</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>149</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2316</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>149</p> <p id='keyword'>cleanse</p> <p id='kanji'>汰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B1B0.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cleanse, water, water droplets, water pistol, plump, large, St. Bernard, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'></p> <p id='lessonNo'></p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>This character can mean both to <b>cleanse</b> and to make dirty. We will choose the latter and imagine someone who is displeasingly <i>plump</i> going to a skinny spa whose medicinal <i>waters</i> promise to <b>cleanse</b> him of his unwanted corpulence. Picture him sitting in the spa as the pounds melt away, leaving a greasy scum on top of the <i>water</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>I couldn´t find any reference to this kanji as meaning cleanse. It seems to be most often used in the following compound 沙汰（さた）to mean affair. The other meanings seem to be closer to ´select´ so maybe Heisig meant cleanse in the ethnic sense here.. I´m going to use the keyword ""selection"", as in natural selection. Story: natural selection first began in the water, and those that were too plump were selected out.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Water is used to cleanse a plump man´s colon.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>タ、タイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>おご.る、にご.る、よな.げる</p> <p id='words'>ご無沙汰(ごぶさた): not writing or contacting for a while<br>無沙汰(ぶさた): neglecting to stay in contact</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>147</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2327</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>147</p> <p id='keyword'>pan-</p> <p id='kanji'>汎</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6B18E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>pan-, water, water droplets, water pistol, mediocre, wind, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>6</p> <p id='lessonNo'>8</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The sense of the key word here is the ""all-inclusive"" we find in terms like ""<b>Pan-</b>American Games."" (It is also the character used in mathematics for ""partial"" as in partial differentials, in case you are a math major and want to take your story in that direction.) Instead of a <i>water</i> sports event that brings together the best talent, think of a meet of the region's most <i>mediocre</i> athletes, many of whom cannot even tread <i>water</i>. Now try to find a sponsor for the ""<b>Pan-</b><i>Mediocre</i> <i>Water</i> Sports Competition.""</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Yeah, all our water is fairly mediocre, but if we work together in some pan-continental union, we can make some better water! As if.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>This is pan- as in the prefix meaning ""all"". I think of Pangea as being a mediocre continent with water covering the rest of the planet. This was before it broke up into the first-class, well-distributed continents we got now.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ハン、ブ、フウ、ホウ、ホン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ただよ.う、ひろ.い</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
