A photo is taken every day showing this scene and a time lapse video shows the wheat growing through the year until the wheat is tall and the top sprouts to look like its flowers. At this point, the girl can no longer be seen in the photos and she fades away.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>な、しお.れる、しな.びる、しぼ.む、な.える</p> <p id='words'>萎びる(しなびる): to wilt, to fade<br>萎む(しぼむ): to wither, to fade (away), to shrivel, to wilt</p> <p id='readingExamples'>萎える (な.える)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

However, two kanji that describe the hues specifically are 藍 and 緑. This kanji is the ""blue"" counterpart of green (#1371). 	"<p id='id'>492</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2398</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>492</p> <p id='keyword'>kudzu</p> <p id='kanji'>葛</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8919B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>kudzu, flowers, mexican bandit, muchacho, siesta, sun, day, aroma, bound up, spoon, sitting on the ground</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><b>Kudzu</b>&nbsp;is a word taken over from Japanese to name the crawling vines that creep up and completely take over trees. Seeing it at its worst in the Georgia countryside makes it easy to understand why it has a reputation as the ""plague of the South."" From there it should not be hard to arrange the primitives, <i>flowers</i>&nbsp;and <i>siesta</i>&nbsp;into a memorable image.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a siesta in the kudzu field. The kudzu grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the kudzu flowers mark his grave.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The muchacho takes a siesta under the flowers of the kudzu.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>カツ、カチ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つづら、くず</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'>葛 (くず)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1496</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2422</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1496</p> <p id='keyword'>modest</p> <p id='kanji'>遜</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9819C.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>modest, grandchild, child, lineage, drop, thread, spiderman, road</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>36</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Grandchild . . . road.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>My parents aren´t at all modest about their grandchildren, at every opportunity they take them on the road showing them off to their friends!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>He wasn´t at all modest when telling us about his grandchildren - ""They´re all on the road to success"" he said.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ソン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>したが.う、へりくだ.る、ゆず.る</p> <p id='words'>謙遜(けんそん): humble, humility, modesty</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1394</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2426</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1394</p> <p id='keyword'>chink</p> <p id='kanji'>隙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E99A99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>chink, pinnacle, parthenon, acropolis, small, little, sun, day, small2, little, 2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>35</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Pinnacle</i> . . . <i>little</i> . . . <i>sun</i> . . . <i>little</i>. Note that the form of the first element for <i>little</i> given here is the simpler form that has become standard in general-use characters (See Frame 110). For the time being, until typesetting fonts have made the adjustment, the official approved drawing has the drops similar to the bottom <i>little</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>There was only one chink in his plan. Even standing atop the highest pinnacle, standing above even the sun, the little man was still just as little as when he was under the sun.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Man those little chinks can do anything! They were the first to build rockets, and by launching one off the top of the highest pinnacle in China, one little chink was the first to ride above the sun, and see all the little chinks below!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲキ、キャク、ケキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すき、す.く、す.かす、ひま</p> <p id='words'>隙間(すきま): crevice, crack, gap, opening</p> <p id='readingExamples'>隙 (すき)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

Ninjas on rollerblades. Ultimate 90s flashback). Instead, they would simply dip their knees in laquer, and wait until it dried (hence the flesh, and the abscence of any drops of water). Unfortunately, this meant that you would have to wait about 30 minutes after deciding to go rollerblade until you could actually do it (took some time to dry) - and removing it was a serious pain.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>シツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ひざ</p> <p id='words'>膝(ひざ): knee, lap</p> <p id='readingExamples'>膝 (ひざ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

From this it gets the secondary sense of rugged or <b>spiny</b>. 	"<p id='id'>597</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2505</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>597</p> <p id='keyword'>sweet oak</p> <p id='kanji'>椎</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A48E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>sweet oak, tree, wood, turkey</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>21</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Tree . . . turkey.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Why is the sweet oak so sweet? Not sure, but to me it tastes just like turkey (with gravy and cranberry sauce!) Now that is sweet.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Sweeter than Shiit~ake? Turkeys gobble Shiitake mushrooms椎茸 off the sweet oak tree. 　http://www.flickr.com/photos/tinyhare/13963627/.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ツイ、スイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>つち、う.つ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"

Tome can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set wooden stakes, braced by one horizontal bar.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>An army of scholars build a wooden palisade to protect their precious tome of literature.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>サク、サン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しがら.む、しがらみ、とりで、やらい</p> <p id='words'>柵(さく): fence, paling</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

Note that the older (and still official) form of this kanji uses the old character for dragon 龍, which is good to learn and is fun to write in any case. It is made up of five primitive elements: <i>vase</i> . . . <i>flesh</i> . . . <i>slingshot</i> . . . <i>fishhook</i> (enclosure) . . . <i>three</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The only cage that can keep a dragon is made of bamboo.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>A bamboo cage won´t hold a dragon!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ロウ、ル</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かご、こ.める、こも.る、こ.む</p> <p id='words'>篭る(こもる): to seclude oneself, to be confined in, to be implied, to be stuffy</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

The mysterious origin of this part of a boat comes from the strengthened sides of warships that used artillery (it means ""gun ridge"").</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ゲン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふなべい、ふなばた</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>2143</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2699</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2143</p> <p id='keyword'>insult</p> <p id='kanji'>罵</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BDB5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>insult, eye, cross-eyed, net, team of horses</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Eyeball . . . team of horses.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>In ancient Japan, the most grievous insult was to poke a rival´s horse in the eye (consider how rare an expensive a steed was in those days). It was the final step in preparation for a duel to the death.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In Japan, is is considered insulting to look at someone from atop your horse. You have to step down and face people properly.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>バ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ののし.る</p> <p id='words'>罵る(ののしる): to speak ill of, to abuse</p> <p id='readingExamples'>罵る (ののし.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>479</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2791</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>479</p> <p id='keyword'>about that time</p> <p id='kanji'>頃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A083.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>about that time, spoon, sitting on the ground, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>When Uncle Bob starts his comic routine of sticking <i>spoons </i>on his <i>head</i>, you know it is <b>about that time</b>&nbsp;to come up with a reason to excuse yourself.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>After spooning for hours it´s about that time he got some head. Dayum woman.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ケイ、キョウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ころ、ごろ、しばら.く</p> <p id='words'>頃(けい): time, about, toward, approximately (time)<br>この頃(このごろ): recently<br>年頃(としごろ): age, marriageable age, age of puberty, adolescence, for some years<br>日頃(ひごろ): normally, habitually<br>一頃(ひところ): once, some time ago<br>頃(ころ): time, about, toward, approximately (time)<br>近頃(ちかごろ): lately, recently, nowadays<br>手頃(てごろ): moderate, handy</p> <p id='readingExamples'>頃 (ころ)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1358</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2792</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1358</p> <p id='keyword'>cheek</p> <p id='kanji'>頬・頰</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9A0AC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>cheek, scissors, husband, horns, head, page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight</p> <p id='strokeCount'>15</p> <p id='lessonNo'>34</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Scissors . . . head.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Your cheeks contain your jawbones, which are known as the ""scissors of the head."".</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The Joker from Batman had his cheeks cut with scissors to give him that eternal smile. 	"<p id='id'>2155</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2839</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2155</p> <p id='keyword'>foot of a mountain</p> <p id='kanji'>麓</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9BA93.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>foot of a mountain, grove, tree, wood, deer, cave, antlers, compare, spoon, sitting on the ground, spoon2, sitting on the ground2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>19</p> <p id='lessonNo'>54</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Grove . . . deer.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Many deer can be found in the grove at the foot of a mountain.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Deer are well known for frolicking in groves of trees. However, they are not well known for actually watching where the heck they are bounding about. Here we have a bunch of dead deer bodies that you find at the foot of a mountain. You are trying to figure why there are so many dead deer in one spot, and then you trace a line up the mountain - leaves and such are scattered all the way up...to a grove. Looks like they hopped through some leaves to their doom.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ロク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふもと</p> <p id='words'>麓(ふもと): foot, the bottom, base (of a mountain)</p> <p id='readingExamples'>麓 (ふもと)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>322</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2841</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>322</p> <p id='keyword'>Hades</p> <p id='kanji'>冥</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E586A5.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>hades, crown, sun, day, six</p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>14</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word in this frame refers to the underworld, the world of the dead. By way of the classic Greek association, it is also used for the ""dwarf planet"" Pluto. Since no one knows precisely when this part of the cosmos was finished, we may imagine it as the <i>crowning</i> deed of <i>day six</i> of the creation.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In Hades you have to work six days a week before crowning it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Under the light of the moon, as it's illegal, you catch the salmon going upstream.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In this kanji we see a mountain goat that decided to go upstream along a road, but for some reason it will only go upstream when the full moon is up. It's actually stubborn like a mountain goat about not going upstream along the road at any other period of time. The road itself is also very confused about this.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ソ、サク</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さかのぼ.る</p> <p id='words'>遡る(さかのぼる): go back, go upstream, make retroactive</p> <p id='readingExamples'>遡る (さかのぼ.る)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1947</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2884</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1947</p> <p id='keyword'>donburi</p> <p id='kanji'>丼</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E4B8BC.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>domburi, well, drop</p> <p id='strokeCount'>5</p> <p id='lessonNo'>48</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i style=""font-weight: bold; "">Donburi</i> is a bowl of rice with eel or meat on it. The character is a pictograph, perhaps designed by someone who felt that the portion of meat he was served with his bowl of rice looked to be no more than a tiny <i>drop</i> in the <i>well</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I drop a domburi down into the well for the goblin living there.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>トン、タン、ショウ、セイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>どんぶり</p> <p id='words'>丼(どんぶり): porcelain bowl, bowl of rice with food on top</p> <p id='readingExamples'>丼 (どんぶりどん)</p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

The full kanji for the City Walls primitive is city walls (#2180). Beyonce went for an invigorating walk up a large hill on a summer´s afternoon. Since the grass was so lush and cool, she took off her sandals and immediately stepped on a used hypodermic needle. 岐阜県　ぎふけん Gifu Prefecture.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>フ、フウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1992</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2960</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1992</p> <p id='keyword'>interrogative</p> <p id='kanji'>那</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E982A3.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>interrogative, sword, dagger, two, city walls</p> <p id='strokeCount'>7</p> <p id='lessonNo'>49</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Sword</i> . . . <i>two</i> . . . <i>city walls</i>. Used classically to indicate an <b>interrogative</b> part of speech, this character is used chiefly now for its sound.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>If you arrive with two swords at the city walls, expect some interrogatives before they´ll let you in.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Interrogation at the city walls: ""Any weapons, question mark."" ""Just a blade."" ""Why the two scratches on the blade, question mark."" ""To remind me that I cut off my other ear too, exclamation mark (exclamation (#2680))."".</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'>1</p> <p id='onYomi'>ナ、ダ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>なに、なんぞ、いかん</p> <p id='words'>旦那(だんな): master (of house), husband (informal)</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_1 Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1011</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2991</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1011</p> <p id='keyword'>stationery</p> <p id='kanji'>箋・䇳</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7AE8B.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>stationery, bamboo, float, fiesta, float*, fiesta2</p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>26</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'><i>Bamboo</i> . . . <i>float</i>. Note that the drawing of the primitive for <i>float</i> uses the abbreviated form that has become standard in the general-use kanji and as we met it earlier (Frames 393-95). Until such time as typesetting fonts make the adjustment, only the older form has been approved. Here we have opted for the simpler, avant garde drawing.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Note: the spelling should be stationery (= paper, office supplies), not stationary (= not moving). The error is in the original book.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The two fiestas communicated to each other on their respective floats by using bamboo stationery.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>セン</p> <p id='kunYomi'>ふだ</p> <p id='words'>便箋(びんせん): writing paper, stationery</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1237</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>2997</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1237</p> <p id='keyword'>glossary</p> <p id='kanji'>彙</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E5BD99.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'>glossary, broken broom, mutual, crown, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood, broom*</p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>31</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The top primitive of this character is actually an old form of <i>broom</i>. The remaining elements are: <i>crown</i> . . . <i>fruit</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>People who read the glossary are mutually exclusive (exclude the top line of mutually (#757) ) from those who eat crowned fruit イ はりねずみ same kind 語彙.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>I was having mutual difficulties in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the crown and I was the one picking the fruit. In order to fix the problem I checked the glossary for ""mutual difficulties"" but found nothing. I guess we´re going to have to mutually end our relationship.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>イ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はりねずみ</p> <p id='words'>語彙(ごい): vocabulary, glossary</p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>129</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3008</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>129</p> <p id='keyword'>sniff</p> <p id='kanji'>嗅</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E59785.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>7</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>You have seen those scratch'n'<b>sniff</b> advertisements for perfumes. This one is for a <i>mouth</i>wash that replaces one <i>stinking</i> oder with another.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Your mouth stinks: you need to sniff your breath.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>You open your mouth and gasp for air, 1 sniff of that stinking chihuahua is too much. *Edited thecite's to reflect the keyword in the supplement.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>キュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>か.ぐ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>308</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3009</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>308</p> <p id='keyword'>metaphor</p> <p id='kanji'>喩・喻</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E596A9.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>12</p> <p id='lessonNo'>13</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>People who try to sound literary often end up butchering the language. Here we see a <i>meeting</i> of <i>butchers</i> whose <i>mouths</i> are producing the <b>metaphors</b>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Metaphorically speaking, all the equipment in your mouth is basically just a meeting of butchers, designed to pulverize whatever meat you put in there.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>Metaphor: A good metaphor flows from the mouth like the meeting of flesh and saber, smoothly piercing the listener with its meaning. But a bad metaphor is like when you barely nick the flesh and only spill two drops of blood or when your saber doesn't penetrate at all but rather bends into a くく shape when you whack the flesh. (Note: This story incorporates both the traditional form of the kanji (口＋兪) and the simplified form (口＋俞)) .</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ユ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>さと.す、 たと.える</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>363</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3010</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>363</p> <p id='keyword'>obituary</p> <p id='kanji'>訃</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E8A883.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>9</p> <p id='lessonNo'>15</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <i>words</i> of this <b>obituary</b> work like a <i>magic wand</i>, conjuring up the desceased.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Obituary. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the words of his obituary until a magician, with a wave of his wand, restored the man back to health.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>In the Harry Potter world, obituary's are magical. If you wave your wand over them you can hear the person's last words. Creepy!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>フ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>しらせ<span class=""Apple-tab-span"" style=""white-space:pre""> </span></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>485</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3011</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>485</p> <p id='keyword'>block letters</p> <p id='kanji'>楷</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E6A5B7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>13</p> <p id='lessonNo'>18</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The key word refers to kanji that are written in full, squared form, as opposed to cursive writing which is more flowing andabbreviates some of the strokes. Here <b>block letters</b> are pictured as tidy rows of <i>trees</i> that are <i>all</i> the same size and can be read easily by <i>all</i>, whatever calligraphic skills they possess.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Block letters (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like wood; they're all the same size so that all can read them.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>all the hiragana are in ""block letters"" on wooden blocks, like children's toys.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>カイ</p> <p id='kunYomi'></p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1617</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3021</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1617</p> <p id='keyword'>holed gem</p> <p id='kanji'>璧</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E792A7.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>18</p> <p id='lessonNo'>39</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>The <b>holed gem</b> to which this kanji refers is a flat, circular object of about a foot in length, made of stone or glass and having a large hole in the middle. It's elements: <i>ketchup</i> . . . <i>ball</i>.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>Even more valuable and perfect (完璧) than a holed gem is a delicious meatball (ball = たま = 玉) with ketchup. Yum!</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>It's a little known fact that ketchup is highly corrosive and is used to cut holes into gemstones so they can be put onto chains. This kanji shows a piece of Jade with a blob of ketchup on the top eating a hole through it.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ヘキ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>たま</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"

	"<p id='id'>1817</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3026</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1817</p> <p id='keyword'>carbuncle</p> <p id='kanji'>瘍</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7988D.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>14</p> <p id='lessonNo'>44</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Sickness . . . piggy bank.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>His sickness caused numerous carbuncles, which when emptied by the doctors also emptied his piggy bank.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The witches piggy bank was cursed with a spell causing any thief who stole it's contents to fall ill. The illness would result in the victim being covered from head to toe in a mass of carbuncles. Crime doesn't pay!</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ヨウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>かさ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>1979</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3027</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>1979</p> <p id='keyword'>suckle</p> <p id='kanji'>哺</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E593BA.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>10</p> <p id='lessonNo'>49</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Mouth . . . dog tag.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The scaredy-cat soldier puts his dog tags in his mouth and suckles them nervously. It sounds like he's a suckling infant.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>suckle: this mother had heptuplets. Wow! But she had to put dog tags on the mouths of her babies to keep track of which ones had been suckled.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ホ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>はぐく.む、 ふく.む</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2120</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3030</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2120</p> <p id='keyword'>gloom</p> <p id='kanji'>鬱</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E9ACB1.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>29</p> <p id='lessonNo'>53</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Learning this character will take a little doing. Before we start, it is a good idea to keep the key word distinct from <i>melancholy</i> (Frame 663), with which it combines to create the psychological condition of depression (a metaphor based on the hollow or sinking of the material <i>depression</i> we met in Frame 1421).<div>The picture of <b>gloom</b> begins with a small <i>grove</i> of trees, under which we see a <i>crown</i> made out of used <i>tin cans</i>. Next (the lower half of the kanji) we find a combination that appears only a few times in modern characters and only once in those treated in the volumes of <i>Remembering the Kanji</i>. It is composed of a <i>shovel</i> with a <i>sheaf</i> dotted with small <i>drops</i> on all sides. Think of it as a large scoop <i>shovel</i> attached to the front of a bulldozer, whose driver is singing: ♪ ""Bulldozing in the <i>sheaves</i>, bulldozing in the <i>sheaves</i>..."" ♪ The <i>drops</i> represent the chaff flying about as the <i>sheaves</i> are tossed about by the heavy machinery.</div><div>There is <i>someone sitting on the ground</i> alongside, watching as the machinery makes its way around the neighboring farmland - and it's you, wearing your <i>tin-can crown</i>. You feel overwhelmed by the impending doom as the invasion of agro-business draws closer and closer to the <i>grove</i>, the only patch of woods that remains of what once was a vast forest. The whole scene represents a re-<i>shaping</i> of the natural environment that brings the heavy weight of <b>gloom</b> down upon you.</div><div>A bit much, perhaps, but there are enough elements to allow for any number of other combinations.</div></p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The pixie, wearing a tin can crown, watches from the middle of the grove, the sparkling villain approach. She sits down in gloom wondering if she belongs amongst the trees, for she has never seen such a beautiful shape.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>The context of gloom here refers to an environmental disaster that humans make. The story begins at a GROVE with TIN CANS shaped like CROWNS which are really soda cans. They belonged to workers who bulldozes (or SHOVELS) lots and lots of SHEAVES with DROPS of its pieces. Afar, a boy is SITTING while watching the workers reSHAPING the environment. His face now has a very gloomy expression.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>ウツ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>うっ.する、 しげ.る、 ふさ.ぐ</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
	"<p id='id'>2198</p> <p id='frameNoV4'>3029</p> <p id='frameNoV6'>2198</p> <p id='keyword'>humiliate</p> <p id='kanji'>羞</p> <p id='strokeDiagram'><img src=""E7BE9E.png"" /></p> <p id='hint'></p> <p id='constituent'></p> <p id='strokeCount'>11</p> <p id='lessonNo'>56</p> <p id='myStory'></p> <p id='heisigStory'>Wool . . sign of the cow.</p> <p id='heisigComment'></p> <p id='koohiiStory1'>The sheep had his coat shaven in the winter and a sign of th cow branded on him. How humiliating.</p> <p id='koohiiStory2'>[+melchan] The sheep was humiliated by being branded with the sign of the cow (which is a major insult to anyone, even sheep) and tries to cover it up with it's wool.</p> <p id='jouYou'>JH</p> <p id='jlpt'></p> <p id='onYomi'>シュウ</p> <p id='kunYomi'>すすめ.る、 はじ.る、 は.ずかしい</p> <p id='words'></p> <p id='readingExamples'></p> <p id='Tags'>JLPT_None Jouyou_JH</p>"
